BYD, which overtook Tesla last year as the world’s No. 1 electric vehicle manufacturer, will use Nvidia’s next generation of in-vehicle chips, called Drive Thor, to enable increased levels of autonomous driving and other digital functions, Nvidia said.
Chinese automobile maker BYD pipped American counterpart Tesla to be the top electric vehicle seller in Singapore in 2023.

site_title: Insurer Lloyd's of London swings to US$13.5 billion profit in 2023
summary: Lloyd's of London reported a pre-tax profit of US$13.51 billion in 2023, driven by strong underwriting and investment performance. The insurance market's underwriting profit more than doubled to £5.9 billion, while investments returned £5.3 billion, compared to a £3.1 billion loss in 2022. The market suffered an £800 million loss in 2022, but has coped with recent challenges such as the pandemic and natural catastrophes by excluding certain businesses and raising prices. The collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge is expected to result in a multi-billion dollar insurance loss.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The interior of the Lloyd's of London building is seen in the City of London financial district in London, Britain, April 16, 2019. Picture taken April 16, 2019. REUTERS/Hannah McKay//File Photo

site_title: China property crisis is rippling through its biggest banks
summary: China's largest state banks are struggling due to the country's protracted property downturn, which is eroding their balance sheets. Five major lenders, including Bank of Communications, Industrial & Commercial Bank of China, and China Construction Bank, have posted shrinking net interest margins and warned of ongoing property sector risks. Bad loans from residential mortgages have increased, with Bank of Communications' property bad loan ratio jumping to 5.0% and Industrial & Commercial Bank of China's rising 9.6%. The banks have lowered lending rates and stepped up financing support for developers, but face challenges in maintaining growth amid the crisis.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: A worker speaking on his phone walks past a construction site in Beijing, China April 14, 2022. Picture taken April 14, 2022. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Thailand’s February factory output falls 2.84% y/y, above forecast
summary: Thailand's manufacturing production index in February dropped 2.84% from the previous year, exceeding the forecasted 3.9% decline. This marks the second consecutive month of decline, following a 2.94% drop in January. The drop is attributed to various factors including the global economic slowdown and rising costs.

site_title: Cybersecurity startup StealthMole raises US$7 million in Series A funding
summary: StealthMole, a Singapore-based cybersecurity startup, has raised US$7 million in Series A funding to expand its cybersecurity efforts across Asia. The company, which uses artificial intelligence to detect and mitigate cybercrime, will focus on the corporate sector. With the funding, StealthMole plans to diversify its capabilities and improve cyber incident response and prevention. The startup has already aided government agencies and law enforcement, and its technology traces criminals through 255 billion analyzed data points from the dark web and hidden sources.

images.alt_text: Local organisations recognised the importance of cybersecurity, but there is still “much room for improvement” given partial adoption of measures, said the Cyber Security Agency of Singapore.
Late-stage funding declined, data intelligence platform Tracxn said in its report released on Wednesday (Mar 27).
Qoala's co-founders Tommy Martin (left) and Harshet Lunani plan to use the company's fresh funding to further the use of generative artificial intelligence.
Applecrumby says it will use the funding to enter new markets and expand its PureBasics product line.

site_title: The rich, the richer and the super-rich of South-east Asia
summary: The article highlights the wealthiest individuals in South-east Asia, according to Forbes' latest rich list. The top five include the Hartono brothers from Indonesia ($48 billion), the Chearavanont brothers from Thailand ($34 billion), the Sy siblings from the Philippines ($14.4 billion), Malaysian centenarian Robert Kuok ($11.8 billion), and Vietnamese billionaire Pham Nhat Vuong ($4.5 billion). These individuals have amassed their fortunes through various business ventures, including conglomerates, real estate, and banking, and are shaping the economic landscape of their respective countries.

site_title: Seoul bus drivers end strike after city agrees to wage increase
summary: Seoul bus drivers ended an hours-long strike after agreeing to a 4.48% wage hike with the city's employers, following an initial 13% demand. The deal brings an end to the city's first full-scale strike in 12 years, which affected over 9 million people. Public transport operations resumed immediately after the agreement.

images.alt_text: Hospitals have been forced to cancel crucial treatments and surgeries since thousands of trainee doctors stopped working Feb 20 to protest proposed training reforms, but the government has vowed not to back down, threatening striking medics with legal action.

South Korean medical professors holding up signs protesting the government's plan to augment medical student admissions at Jeonbuk National University.  The health ministry this week reiterated that negotiations over the reform plans were out of the question.

site_title: UBS looks to keep, grow shipping loans in post-merger green overhaul
summary: UBS plans to increase lending to the shipping sector and run off loans to fossil fuel clients inherited from Credit Suisse, as part of its post-merger green overhaul. The bank aims to reduce fossil fuel sector emissions by 72% by 2030, despite re-basing its emissions-reduction targets from 2021. UBS will also keep shipping-linked loans and expand its sustainability and climate risk policy framework. The bank's chief sustainability officer said "every single deal" was discussed, and loans in sectors not aligned with the bank's sustainability risk appetite will be housed in a "non-core" unit and allowed to run off over time.

images.alt_text: The deal allows UBS to close another chapter in its acquisition of Credit Suisse and accelerate the disposal of unwanted assets.

site_title: South Korea market watchdog vows to further develop corporate reform plan
summary: South Korea's financial market watchdog has vowed to further develop its corporate reform plan, dubbed the "Corporate Value-up Programme", after initial proposals fell short of market expectations. The plan aims to resolve the "Korea discount" in the local stock market, where Korean firms tend to have lower valuations than global peers. The watchdog is considering tax incentives and other measures to boost the plan, with the goal of creating a more transparent environment for foreign investors and fostering a sound and fair financial environment. The plan's development is seen as crucial for attracting more foreign investment into the country's companies.

images.alt_text: Housing prices are a key barometer of risks for developers.
South Korea’s consumer inflation accelerated in February, after three months of easing, due to supply-side pressures, mostly from higher agricultural prices.
South Korea, a semiconductor powerhouse, has come under pressure because it is both a key American ally and relies on China as its biggest trading partner.

site_title: Cushman & Wakefield appoints Natalie Craig as Singapore CEO
summary: Cushman & Wakefield has appointed Natalie Craig as its Singapore CEO, effective April 1, 2024. Craig will oversee a team of over 2,000 staff from the company's commercial real estate business and C&W Services. The appointment reflects clients' changing buying behavior and marks the next phase of the firm's growth. Craig has over 20 years of experience in commercial real estate and previously held leadership positions at CBRE, Macquarie Bank, and Minter Ellison.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Singapore is currently the largest data-centre market on a city basis in the Asia-Pacific outside of mainland China, with around 917MW of capacity in operation.

site_title:
SGX RegCo requires large issuers 
to take lead to reduce AGM crunch
summary: SGX RegCo is requiring large issuers to take the lead in scheduling their annual general meetings (AGMs) to avoid conflicts with other large issuers' AGMs. This move aims to ensure that all shareholders can attend their company's AGMs. The regulator's new rule applies to primary-listed issuers, who must hold their AGMs in Singapore unless prohibited by relevant laws. This change is intended to enhance communication between shareholders and issuers, allowing for more effective engagement and feedback.

images.alt_text: 新加坡交易所（Singapore Exchange，SGX）标志。

site_title: Seatrium’s two former executives, including CEO, charged with bribery involving more than S$20 million in Brazil
summary: Two former Seatrium executives, including CEO Wong Weng Sun, have been charged with corruption offences in Singapore for paying over S$20 million in bribes to a former consultant in Brazil to further the company's business interests. Wong, who stepped down in February 2023, was accused of conspiring to corruptly give gratification to Guilherme Esteves de Jesus, a former consultant. The charges were made on March 28, 2024, by Singapore's State Court.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Tan Nai Lun

site_title: UBS ends Apollo management deal struck by Credit Suisse
summary: UBS Group has agreed to sell $8 billion in unwanted assets to Apollo Global Management as part of the carve-out of Credit Suisse's securitised products group. The revised deal renegotiates key terms, ending a contentious investment management arrangement and a transition service agreement. UBS aims to accelerate the disposal of unwanted assets, marking another chapter in its acquisition of Credit Suisse.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed after Fed official floats rate cut delay
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Thursday after a Federal Reserve official suggested delaying or reducing interest rate cuts, citing recent above-forecast inflation data. The yen held gains after hitting a 34-year low, while Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, and Wellington stocks rose, while Singapore, Seoul, Taipei, and Jakarta stocks fell. Despite US stocks reaching record highs, concerns about the Fed's ability to stick to its inflation projections have led to caution among investors, with a string of above-forecast economic data.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 1.10 per cent, or 449.41 points, to 40,313.32 in early trade on Thursday, while the broader Topix index gave up 1.02 per cent, or 28.56 points, to 2,770.72.

site_title: UK home sellers trim discounts as expectations for rate cut grow
summary: UK home sellers are offering smaller discounts, with an average reduction of 3.9% in asking prices, as rising expectations of interest-rate cuts boost demand. This marks a recovery from 18 months of markdowns due to inflation, high mortgage rates, and a cost-of-living crisis. Experts say sellers must set realistic prices to capitalize on improving market conditions, which favor buyers with greater choice. Demand for homes has rebounded to a six-month high, with nearly half of UK house hunters accelerating their purchase plans to avoid potential price rebounds.

images.alt_text: Homes in Britain have less floor space per person than many other developed economies, trailing France, Germany, Japan, the United States and Taiwan.

Homeowners in the UK generally do not pay capital gains on their main residence, so the changes will mainly affect private landlords and second homeowners.
Experts expect a stronger year for the property market after a stagnant 2023 caused by the surge in mortgage rates.

site_title: WeWork fund loses last London office after Deutsche Bank breach
summary: WeWork's fund, WeWork Capital Advisors, has lost control of its last London office, 51 Eastcheap, after breaching banking covenants with Deutsche Bank. The building was owned by WeWork Capital Advisors and was rented to WeWork. The fund had repeatedly attempted to sell the property, with initial terms agreed at £50 million, but talks collapsed. The receivership comes as WeWork retrenches following its US bankruptcy filing last year, and the company has recently closed sites across the UK capital.

images.alt_text: WeWork has racked up losses on its long-term lease obligations as more people began working from home during the Covid-19 pandemic.
The beleaguered company needs the funds mainly to pay rent on office spaces used by its customers.
Under Neumann, WeWork grew to be the most valuable US startup worth US$47 billion.

site_title: Mixed signals in private housing; possible oversupply of agents
summary: Singapore's private housing market appears to be experiencing mixed signals, with luxury condominiums struggling and sub-sales showing a 69.2% jump in 2023. However, this surge may be a lagging indicator, as the market is still recovering from the post-Covid pandemic price run-up. The oversupply of property agents, with 65% of industry executives feeling there is too many salespersons, may also impact the market. Meanwhile, residential leasing prices are experiencing negative growth, but long-stay serviced apartments may provide a new option for locals and foreigners.

site_title: Automakers face ‘daunting’ task to meet 2032 EV rules, industry says
summary: The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has revised its 2027-2032 vehicle emissions rules, reducing the target for electric vehicles (EVs) from 67% by 2032 to 35%. Automakers face "daunting" targets to sell at least 50% of new vehicles as electric or plug-in hybrids by 2030. Industry officials, including John Bozzella of the Alliance for Automotive Innovation, describe the revised rules as "ambitious and daunting." Despite the softer rules, companies like Volkswagen and Hyundai remain committed to their EV rollout plans.

site_title: Household electricity, gas tariffs to fall in Q2
summary: Singaporean households can expect slightly lower electricity and gas rates in Q2 2024 compared to the previous quarter. Electricity tariffs will decrease by 0.3% or S$0.001 to S$0.2979 per kWh before GST, while gas tariffs will fall by 0.1% or S$0.0003 to S$0.2312 per kWh. These decreases translate to lower average monthly electricity bills for families, with the electricity bill expected to drop by S$0.33.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares sink 1.1% on ex-dividend day
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 1.1% on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index dropping 449.41 points to 40,313.32, and the Topix index losing 28.56 points to 2,770.72. The decline comes as investors locked in dividend rights during the previous session, and pressure from recent rallies. The yen plummeted to a 34-year low against the dollar on Wednesday, prompting Tokyo's currency officials to consider action. Major shares including Sony, Toyota, and SoftBank Group also fell.

images.alt_text: The broad-based S&P 500 finished at 5,248.49, up 0.9 per cent, topping a record set last week.
Singapore shares muted at Thursday’s open; STI up 0.03%

site_title: Gold slips as US dollar, bond yields firm after Fed official comment
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $2,189.29 per ounce as the US dollar rose 0.1% against its rivals, making gold more expensive for other currency holders. This followed comments from a Federal Reserve official, Christopher Waller, who suggested holding off on cutting interest rates due to recent disappointing inflation data. Investors await the US core personal consumption expenditure price index report and weekly initial jobless claims report for policy clues.

site_title: Oil giants plan to bury massive amounts of CO2 in South-east Asia
summary: Oil giants ExxonMobil, Shell, and Chevron are investing in massive CO2 storage projects in Indonesia and Malaysia, aiming to neutralize their industrial emissions. The companies, under global pressure to reduce emissions, are seeking to secure storage space for up to 20% of today's oil and gas demand. However, a huge gap remains between the amount of CO2 to be captured and the available storage space, with over 1 billion tonnes needed annually to meet global climate goals. Governments in Indonesia and Malaysia are offering incentives to companies seeking to build storage facilities, with the potential for $16 billion in annual revenue by 2050.

images.alt_text: Research and development investments in low-carbon energy solutions can help to expand the range of technological solutions suited for Singapore, said Dr Tan.

site_title: Yellen to warn China of industrial oversupply risks
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warned China of industrial oversupply risks, citing excess capacity in industries like electric vehicles and solar panels as a potential threat to global prices and production. Yellen plans to raise these concerns during her upcoming trip to China, urging Beijing to take necessary steps to address the issue. She believes excess capacity poses risks to China's own productivity and economic growth, and that American firms and workers must compete on a level playing field.

site_title: Apple’s iPhone maker sets record high as AI mania persists
summary: Hon Hai Precision Industry, the manufacturer of iPhones, saw its shares rise 3.7% to a record high as investors optimistic about the growth of the artificial intelligence (AI) sector. The company's fourth-quarter earnings beat estimates, fuelling hopes that demand for AI servers will drive growth. AI revenue may contribute half of server revenue this year, according to analysts. Despite being overbought, analysts see the positive story for Hon Hai continuing, with Morgan Stanley and others upgrading their price targets for the stock. The company's AI exposure is expected to remain at 10-12% of total revenue.

site_title: Australia retail sales rise modestly in Feb thanks to Taylor Swift concerts
summary: Australian retail sales rose 0.3% in February, driven by increased spending on clothing and dining out following Taylor Swift concerts. However, annual sales growth remained modest at 1.6% due to high interest rates eating into incomes. Underlying growth in retail turnover was 0.1% in trend terms, with pressure on consumers contributing to the Reserve Bank of Australia's decision to keep interest rates unchanged for a third straight meeting.

Australia faces a long-term drop in the number of younger people buying homes, which could mean more people retiring in weaker financial positions.

site_title: Los Angeles office tower dumped by Brookfield faces foreclosure sale
summary: A Los Angeles office tower, the Gas Company Tower, is facing foreclosure after its owner, an affiliate of Brookfield Asset Management, walked away from the building a year ago. The tower, valued at $632 million in 2020, is now worth around $200 million due to the decline in office building values and high interest rates. The building has $465 million in loans, including a $167 million slice of commercial mortgage backed securities. A foreclosure sale is expected to occur within 90 days.

site_title: Bank of Japan board divided on economy’s strength upon stimulus exit, March summary shows
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) ended its eight-year period of negative interest rates and other unorthodox policies, marking a shift away from its focus on reflating growth. Policymakers were divided on whether the economy is strong enough to weather an exit from ultra-loose monetary policy, with some citing recent data such as bumper wage hikes as justification for ending the policy. The BOJ is now considering the next interest rate hike, with some policymakers indicating it may take time to achieve the 2% inflation target.

site_title: Amazon says Japan isn’t meeting corporate needs for clean power
summary: Amazon has criticized Japan's energy policy, stating that the country is not meeting its needs for clean power to meet internal emissions targets and customer demands. Despite Japan's plans to invest heavily in renewable energy, the country still relies heavily on fossil fuels, with 70% of its power generation coming from non-renewable sources. Amazon's head of energy and environmental policy in the Asia-Pacific region, Ken Haig, emphasized that the company needs more supply of renewable power to meet the growing demand from companies like Amazon.

images.alt_text: Service price moves are closely watched by the BOJ as a key indicator of whether wages and inflation are rising in tandem.
Confidence is growing that the world’s fourth-largest economy is exiting decades of price declines and subdued growth.

site_title: Reducing bad cholesterol without medication
summary: Dr. Michael Lim, a cardiologist, advises reducing bad cholesterol without medication by making healthy lifestyle choices. Key foods to limit or avoid include processed meats, red meat, fried foods, and those high in saturated fat and trans-fatty acids. Instead, focus on whole foods, fruits, and vegetables, and limit sugar and saturated fat intake. A balanced diet with 20-30g of dietary fiber, moderate alcohol consumption, and regular exercise can help reduce LDL-C and minimize heart attack and stroke risk.

With a starting price estimated between 200,000 to 300,000 yuan, Xiaomi aims to muscle into the market with its technological capabilities. The reception of the SU7 will likely dictate Xiaomi's stock momentum, with analysts expecting over 50,000 shipments in the first 12 months. The company's billionaire co-founder, Lei Jun, has called the challenge his final major endeavor, testing Xiaomi's ability to crack the crowded market.

site_title: US is asking allies to tighten servicing of chip gear in China
summary: The US is urging its allies to restrict servicing of chipmaking equipment in China, following the launch of a 5G smartphone powered by a cutting-edge Chinese chip in 2023. The US has already restricted Applied Materials and its peers from servicing equipment at blacklisted Chinese entities. The move aims to limit China's access to advanced technology and thwart its ambitions in semiconductors. The US is not targeting companies that can repair themselves, but is instead focusing on restricting equipment suppliers.

site_title: Singapore shares muted at Thursday’s open; STI up 0.03%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) edged up 0.03% to 3,252.69 on Thursday, with gainers outnumbering losers 72 to 38. site_title: Bank of Korea warns of economic hit if property slump lasts
summary: The Bank of Korea warned that a prolonged property slump could significantly impact the economy, as rising delinquencies among developers indicate worsening credit market woes. The central bank noted that project-finance loans to developers, secured against expected future profits, pose risks to the financial system. A stable overall financial system is maintained, but the bank's warning highlights potential economic consequences if the property market continues to decline.

summary: A recent podcast episode of PropertyBT from The Business Times discusses the attributes of a good investment home and the value of landed homes in Singapore. summary: Amazon has invested an additional $2.75 billion in AI startup Anthropic, bringing its total investment to $4 billion. Anthropic, which develops AI tools for generating text and analysis, has committed to using Amazon Web Services data centers and custom-built computer chips. The company has emphasized developing AI safely and responsibly. Anthropic's annualized revenue is expected to reach $850 million by 2024-end. site_title: Climate change is messing with how we measure time: study
summary: A study found that climate change has slowed down the Earth's rotation since 1990, delaying the need for a negative leap second until at least 2029. The melting ice in Greenland and Antarctica has caused the Earth's rotation to slow down, which in turn has delayed the introduction of a negative leap second, a minute with only 59 seconds, into standard time. This delay could help avoid potential disruptions to computer systems worldwide.

Governments and policymakers must prioritise preparedness and resilience-building at national and regional levels to address food security issues and mitigate future impacts.

Last year, BP said its carbon emissions would not fall as quickly as anticipated, as it posted record annual profit thanks to soaring oil and gas prices.

site_title: Lufthansa, ground staff reach pay deal after strikes
summary: Lufthansa and the Verdi union representing ground staff reached a pay deal, averting Easter holiday strikes. The deal includes substantial salary increases, following a series of strikes that led to widespread disruption for air travelers. Ground staff had sought a 12.5% pay rise, while Lufthansa offered a "good compromise" with increases over the term of the agreement. The agreement comes after a lengthy dispute, with direct pay talks failing and arbitration being entered. The deal is a breakthrough for employers in Europe's top economy, which has faced a tough season of wage negotiations and strikes.

images.alt_text: The European Commission says the removal of ITA as an independent airline may have negative effects on competition in these already concentrated markets.
The European Commission is due to say this week how it views Lufthansa’s bid to acquire a 41 per cent minority stake in state-owned ITA for 325 million euros (S$473.7 million).
Boeing’s recent problems are further widening the gap between supply and demand.

FILE PHOTO: Lufthansa's aircrafts are seen on the tarmac the day before VERDI union called airport workers at Frankfurt, Munich, Stuttgart, Hamburg, Dortmund, Hanover and Bremen airports to go on a 24-hour strike on Friday, at the Munich International Airport, Germany, February 16, 2023. REUTERS/Leonhard Simon///File Photo
The union wants a 12.5 per cent salary increase and an extra 3,000 euros (S$4,373.47) inflation bonus for Lufthansa ground staff.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Second Chance Properties, ESR-Logos Reit, Banyan Tree
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several companies had notable developments on March 28, 2024. Second Chance Properties reported a 52.8% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$4.3 million due to lower contributions from its properties and securities businesses. ESR-Logos Reit secured a S$200 million sustainability-linked unsecured revolving credit facility agreement. Banyan Tree obtained its first sustainability-linked loan worth S$70 million. Trading halted for Seatrium pending an announcement. These developments may affect trading of these companies' securities.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: Australia to invest A$1 billion on domestic solar panel push to cut reliance on China
summary: Australia plans to invest A$1 billion to boost domestic solar panel production, aiming to reduce its reliance on Chinese imports. The Solar Sunshot programme will provide subsidies and grants to support local manufacturing, with the goal of increasing domestic production to 10% of global supply. Despite having the highest rooftop solar uptake, just 1% of panels are made locally. This move follows similar initiatives by the US and India, but may still face competition from China, which supplies over 90% of Australia's panels.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 ekes out gain on defensive boost; H&M jumps
summary: The pan-European Stoxx 600 edged up 0.1% on Wednesday, driven by firmer utilities and healthcare sectors. H&M shares surged 15.2% after reporting a stronger-than-expected first-quarter operating profit. The retailer's new CEO cited positive reception to spring collections. The Stoxx 600 reached a record high, underpinned by defensive sectors and upbeat quarterly results from H&M.

images.alt_text: The broad-based S&P 500 finished at 5,248.49, up 0.9 per cent, topping a record set last week.

site_title: China Life profit falls as market rout hurts investments
summary: China Life Insurance reported a 31% drop in net income to 46.2 billion yuan (S$8.8 billion) last year due to a 12% rise in new business value and a 11% slump in the CSI 300 Index, along with lower bond yields. The decline was exacerbated by changes in China's accounting policies, which amplified the impact of market volatility on profits. This is the second consecutive year that China's largest life insurer has reported a decline in earnings.

images.alt_text: A China Life Insurance branch in Beijing,. Bloomberg Source: Bloomberg
China Life Hong Kong is looking to raise between US$1 billion and US$2 billion.

site_title:
SingPost’s bid to raise market value 
might not yield immediate results
summary: SingPost, a Singaporean postal service provider, aims to revive its fortunes by pivoting to a pure-play logistics provider. The company plans to divest non-core assets, including the retail-commercial mixed development SingPost Centre, and explore options to list its Australian business. Despite a 6.6% share price spike following a strategic review, SingPost's market capitalization remains under $1 billion. The company will lower its dividend payout ratio to 30-50% and prioritize debt repayment and investments over shareholder rewards. Investors may prefer to wait for sustained improvements in SingPost's financial performance.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: Art Basel Hong Kong’s full-scale return tests city’s events appeal
summary: Art Basel Hong Kong returns at its pre-pandemic scale, featuring 242 international galleries and 69 returning galleries. The event aims to boost Hong Kong's image as an art hub, following several controversies and cancellations, including a postponed Christian Dior fashion show and a football match controversy. Authorities hope the fair will attract international visitors and showcase the city's cultural appeal, despite China's economic challenges and ongoing concerns over freedom of discussion.

images.alt_text: Artwork at gallery Hauser & Wirth’s booth at Art Basel Hong Kong, which is being held at its pre-pandemic scale this year.Source: Art Basel

site_title: Oil prices fall on stronger dollar, weak US petrol demand
summary: Oil prices fell for the second consecutive session, with Brent crude futures for May shedding 16 cents to $86.09 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures for May delivery dropping 27 cents to $81.35 a barrel. The decline was attributed to a stronger dollar and weak US petrol demand. The selling pressure on oil futures began after hitting four-month highs last week, and both Brent and WTI futures have been under pressure since.

images.alt_text: Phillips 66, which has a market value of US$67 billion, is aiming to raise about US$3 billion from asset sales this year.

Brent crude futures due to expire on Thursday settled down 50 cents at US$86.25 a barrel while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures settled 33 cents, or 0.4 per cent, lower at US$81.62 on Tuesday.

site_title: Talking about World War III
summary: A growing number of geopolitical tensions, including the Russia-Ukraine and Israel-Hamas conflicts, have raised concerns about the possibility of World War III. Despite these risks, investors and businesses show little reaction, with monetary policy and potential rate cuts being more closely watched. The situation in Asia, including North Korea and China's actions in the South China Sea, also poses flashpoints. Companies are beginning to take a more proactive approach to geopolitics, with some appointing experts with political and strategic expertise to senior management and boards. However, few are preparing specifically for the risk of WWIII, despite the potential for significant winners and losers in such a scenario.

images.alt_text: Companies that once dreamed of a borderless world are having to deal with a world fragmenting along ideological lines.

site_title: Remains of two people recovered following Baltimore bridge collapse
summary: Two construction workers, Alejandro Hernandez Fuentes and Dorlian Ronial Castillo Cabrera, were found dead in the Baltimore harbour after a cargo ship, the Dali, crashed into the Francis Scott Key Bridge on March 26, 2024, causing a collapse. Six workers are believed to have been killed, with four still missing. The ship's data record and a salvage operation are underway to recover the bodies, while officials warn of the risk of divers entering the wreckage. The incident has blocked the busy port, affecting over 15,000 jobs and causing significant disruptions to supply chains.

images.alt_text: Initial reports indicate the nature of the Baltimore bridge incident is likely to fall within the scope of Protection and Indemnity coverage, which covers third party liability for vessels including damage to fixed or floating objects.
US authorities on Tuesday suspended their search for six people missing after the incident, taking into consideration the cold water temperatures and time passed.

US Coast Guard and Maryland State Police officials said that based on the frigid temperature of the water and the length of time that had elapsed since the bridge came down there was little if any chance that the six workers missing could be found alive.
The Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore partially collapses after a container ship runs into it.
The Francis Scott Key Bridge rests partially collapsed after a Singapore-flagged container ship ran into it in Baltimore on Tuesday.

site_title: Kobayashi Pharma ordered to recall red yeast rice pills after 2 deaths
summary: Kobayashi Pharmaceutical has been ordered to recall three dietary supplement products containing red yeast rice after two deaths and over 100 hospitalizations were reported. The supplements, marketed as cholesterol-lowering aids, were linked to kidney problems. The Osaka-based drugmaker is investigating the suspected link and has urged other manufacturers to recall products using beni koji, a red mould also used in some foods. The company's share price has fallen nearly 20% since the initial recall.

site_title: US: S&P 500 ends at record high as stocks bounce
summary: US stocks reached a record high on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 closing at 5,248.49, up 0.9% from its previous record set last week. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and Nasdaq Composite Index also gained, with the Dow up 1.2% and the Nasdaq up 0.5%. Analysts attribute the rebound to "window dressing" ahead of the first-quarter earnings season, and note that investors are awaiting further market-moving data.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - MARCH 20: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on March 20, 2024 in New York City. The Dow was up slightly in late morning trading as traders analyze the Federal Reserve's latest decision on interest rates.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SPENCER PLATT / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as growth stocks recover
summary: US stock markets opened higher on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gaining 0.44% and 0.67% respectively. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.46%. Growth stocks and chipmakers rebounded in light trading ahead of economic data and a long holiday weekend.

site_title: Bitcoin ETF awareness helping to create favourable view of the cryptocurrency by investors: survey
summary: A survey by Independent Reserve found that the approval of Bitcoin exchange-traded funds (ETFs) in the US has led to a more favorable view of the cryptocurrency among investors. 60% of Singapore residents have a favorable view of Bitcoin, with 39% saying they view it more favorably after ETF approval. Despite this, only 33% of respondents would consider investing in the overseas ETF, with 75% preferring to invest directly in Bitcoin via a crypto exchange due to lower fees and direct access.

Goldman currently provides cash-settled Bitcoin option and Ether option trading, in addition to CME-listed Bitcoin and Ether futures.

site_title: Lieberman, first Jewish candidate to seek US vice-presidency, dies
summary: US politics: Joe Lieberman, the first Jewish candidate to run for US vice-president, has died at 82 due to complications from a fall. A longtime senator from Connecticut, Lieberman was known for his independent streak and made history as a major party's vice-presidential candidate in 2000. He also ran for president in 2004 and was considered as a running mate by John McCain in 2008. Lieberman recently returned to politics as a leader of No Labels, a push for a third presidential candidate in the 2024 election.

images.alt_text: President Joe Biden’s decarbonisation plan and the huge subsidies it offers to green energy are boosting demand for soybean oil, key to renewable diesel production.

Donald Trump, who unlike most US presidents rarely attends church except during public political events, has advertised the Bibles, which feature a cover embossed with an American flag, during what Christians call Holy Week.

site_title: Sam Bankman-Fried, at sentencing, acknowledges FTX customers have suffered
summary: Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of the now-bankrupt FTX cryptocurrency exchange, has acknowledged that customers have suffered from his actions. During his sentencing hearing, Bankman-Fried apologized for minimizing the pain to customers and acknowledged that they lost a total of $8 billion. The judge rejected Bankman-Fried's defense that customers would be made whole through the bankruptcy process, stating that the defendant lied about knowing where his hedge fund's FTX customer deposits went. Bankman-Fried faces a statutory maximum of 110 years in prison, but is likely to receive less, with prosecutors seeking a sentence of 40-50 years.

images.alt_text: US prosecutors are seeking a prison term of 40 to 50 years after a New York jury found SBF guilty in November following a five-week trial that probed the one-time high roller’s spectacular fall.

Sam Bankman-Fried faces up to 110 years in prison after a jury found him guilty in November on seven counts of fraud and conspiracy.

site_title: ESR-Logos Reit secures S$200m sustainability-linked credit facility
summary: ESR-Logos Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) has secured a S$200 million sustainability-linked credit facility, its first of its kind. The unsecured revolving credit facility will be used for general corporate funding purposes, including refinancing existing debt and asset acquisition. The loan is offered by lenders RHB, CIMB, Maybank, Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation, and HSBC. This move follows the Reit's plan to deploy S$700 million for investments in 2024, aiming for both organic and inorganic growth.

images.alt_text: Only 14% of sustainability-linked bonds aligned with key climate goal: report

Banyan Tree says the loan will support its commitment to responsible tourism.

site_title: Jefferies profit rises on capital-markets strength, deal rebound
summary: Jefferies Financial Group's first-quarter earnings rose 35% to $1.74 billion, driven by strong capital markets and investment-banking revenue. The company's capital-markets business had its third-best quarter on record, while investment-banking revenue increased 31% to $739.7 million. CEO Richard Handler expressed optimism, citing increased market activity and a backlog of client deals. This improvement suggests a possible return to dealmaking and bodes well for the rest of the year.

images.alt_text: Jefferies headquarters in New York. Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg

site_title: Crypto hit by US$63 million hack of ‘Munchables’ game in one of year’s biggest exploits
summary: A hacker stole approximately US$63 million from the blockchain-based game "Munchables" in one of the year's biggest crypto security incidents. The exploiter initially targeted 17,400 Ether tokens worth around US$63 million but returned the funds in full later the same day. The game's developer, Blast, hailed the incident as an "incredible lift" to secure the funds and the hacker's decision to return the funds without ransom. The incident highlights ongoing security concerns in the crypto sector, with security exploits costing the industry around US$1.8 billion last year.

images.alt_text: The SEC sued Ripple in 2020, claiming the firm broke its rules when it raised money by selling the digital token without registering it as a security.
Around 90 per cent of the world’s central banks are now exploring digital versions of their currencies.

Users can continue trading USDC on Binance, while deposits and withdrawals of USDC via other supported networks will not be impacted.

site_title: UK says rules of origin deal with Canada probably won't be extended
summary: Britain says post-Brexit trade arrangements with Canada over rules of origin will likely expire next week, blaming Canada for not rolling over the arrangements. The expired deal could lead to a 6.1% tariff on car imports from Canada, potentially harming UK carmakers. The UK government remains open to working with Canada to find a solution, but refuses to roll back the current terms. The expired deal affects car exports worth almost US$883.68 million from Britain to Canada in 2023.

images.alt_text: UK car production up in May as domestic demand surges

site_title: Germany’s 23 billion euros green experiment to save its industrial economy
summary: Germany is launching a 23 billion euros experiment to reach net zero by 2045 without destroying its energy-intensive industrial base. The government has introduced "climate protection contracts" to help companies in sectors like steel, cement, and glass cover additional expenses incurred in using cleaner technologies. The program, similar to Contracts for Difference, aims to cover early-stage technologies and will have its first auction round with a 4 billion euros pot. Companies must bid on the amount of support needed, with the highest CO2 reductions for lowest price receiving funding, and the government will provide pricing support for 15 years.

site_title: Singapore designers break new ground in Milan
summary: Singapore designers showcase their technology-led, sustainable designs at Milan Design Week's "Future Impact 2" exhibition, featuring seven newly commissioned works. The exhibition aims to reflect a forward-thinking approach to design. This marks the second year Singapore participates in the event, following a successful inaugural exhibition last year.

site_title: Democrats are better for the US economy
summary: US President Joe Biden's administration has seen the US economy perform better than predicted, with job creation averaging 1.7% per year under Democratic administrations, compared to 1% under Republican administrations. Since WWII, the US economy has consistently done better during Democratic administrations, with a 4.23% average gross domestic product growth under Democrats versus 2.36% under Republicans. Statistical analysis suggests that this is not a matter of chance, but rather a consistent pattern that is statistically significant at the 95% level of confidence.

images.alt_text: President Joe Biden walks on stage during a visit to the Intel campus in Chandler, Ariz., March 20, 2024. The president's tax cuts include incentives to semiconductor factories as part of a bipartisan advanced manufacturing bill he signed in 2022. (Tom Brenner/The New York Times)

site_title: Just a third of Singapore firms adopt at least three key cybersecurity measures: survey
summary: Only a third of Singaporean organizations have fully implemented at least three of five key cybersecurity measures, according to the Cyber Security Agency of Singapore's first Singapore Cybersecurity Health Report. The report found that 70% of measures were adopted on average, but partial adoption is inadequate and exposes organizations to cyber risks. The top challenges to adopting cybersecurity measures include lack of knowledge, experience, and resources. The agency estimates that implementing cyber hygiene measures would cost between S$1,800 and S$4,500, and urged organizations to prioritize cybersecurity to avoid costly business disruptions.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Interpol has observed an “explosion” of cyber-enabled crime in recent years, says secretary-general Jurgen Stock.
The next wave of network using Optical Fibre Patch cord.
Google said that it will continue to support CSA by assisting with malware detection and analysis, sharing malware insights and techniques, and creating user and developer education resources.
Communications and Information Minister Josephine Teo addressing the media in a press conference after the closing of the fourth Asean Digital Ministers Meeting at Shangri-La Hotel on Feb 2 (Friday).

site_title: China’s Bank of Communications posts slight profit gain, warns of property risks
summary: China's Bank of Communications (BoCom) reported a slight 0.68% profit gain to 92.73 billion yuan (S$17.3 billion) in 2023, despite tepid growth. The bank warned of property risks and plans to improve risk control, citing a liquidity crisis in the sector. Analysts worry that loans to debt-laden developers will increase banks' exposure to the ailing property market. BoCom's non-performing loan ratio for real estate lending was 4.99%, higher than the overall ratio. The bank will implement the "whitelist" mechanism to support the sector.

images.alt_text: Chinese state banks sold dollars for yuan after the local currency weakened past the psychologically important 7.2 per dollar to lows of 7.24, sources said.
LGFVs’ financing activities have come under increasing scrutiny in recent months as the government seeks to rein in debt risks.
Authorities are struggling to arrest a slowdown in China’s property market, which saw new home sales last month tumble 34.2 per cent from a year earlier.

site_title: Florida governor, Disney reach settlement in lawsuit over special district
summary: Florida Governor Ron DeSantis and Walt Disney have reached a settlement to end a high-profile lawsuit over the control of the special district that includes Walt Disney World in Orlando. The settlement ends all litigation pending in state court between Disney and the Central Florida Tourism Oversight District. Under terms of the agreement, Disney agreed not to challenge the oversight board's determination that a 2020 land use plan is invalid, allowing the plan to remain the working blueprint for the Orlando theme parks and retail district.

images.alt_text: ORLANDO, FLORIDA - FEBRUARY 01: A sign welcomes visitors near an entrance to Walt Disney World on February 01, 2024, in Orlando, Florida. A federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit against Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis, which Walt Disney Co. said it will be appealing its loss in a lawsuit. Filmmaker George Lucas, who received 37.1 million Disney shares as part of the company’s US$4.05 billion purchase of his Lucasfilm studio in 2012, is currently the largest individual investor in the company.
Disney has received powerful endorsements from hedge fund ValueAct Capital, and JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon.

site_title: Uptick in commodity prices bears close watch
summary: Commodity prices have surged this year, driven by heightened geopolitical risks and tight oil supplies. Energy prices, particularly oil, have risen 12% to $85.17 per barrel, with OPEC and allies expected to maintain output cuts. Soft commodity prices like cocoa and palm oil are also surging, while industrial metals like copper and aluminum have rallied due to robust demand. This uptick in commodity prices may signal that the battle against rising inflation is far from over, despite easing consumer prices and a potential shift in monetary policies.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Cocoa pods are pictured at a farm in Sinfra, Ivory Coast April 29, 2023. REUTERS/Luc Gnago/File Photo
Commodities have made a modest advance in the first quarter, with crude strengthening, gold hitting a record, and copper topping US$9,000 a tonne.
Brent crude futures settled US$1.32 higher or 1.55 per cent, at US$86.75 a barrel.
This photo taken on October 27, 2023 shows workers producing forklifts at a factory in Qingzhou, in China's eastern Shandong province. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: BlackRock’s tokenised fund draws over US$240 million since debut
summary: BlackRock's USD Institutional Digital Liquidity Fund, a tokenized fund investing in cash, US Treasury bills, and repurchase agreements, has drawn over $240 million since its debut a week ago. The fund's holders receive BUIDL tokens, valued at $1 per token, and can transfer them through approved digital wallets. This marks another successful launch for BlackRock, following the $13 billion inflows into its iShares Bitcoin Trust. The company's chairman, Larry Fink, has advocated for the tokenization of every financial asset, signaling its growing investment in the crypto space.

images.alt_text: Tokenisation is a method of purchasing securities in the form of digital assets using blockchains.
Abaxx has been working for about five years to set up the technology and obtain regulatory approvals to run a futures exchange and clearinghouse.
The outlook for monetary policy will define future capital flows after billions of US dollars have poured in over the past year.
A BlackRock infrastructure fund and GIC have agreed to buy Kellas from Antin Infrastructure Partners in 2019.

site_title: Japan unveils next-generation passenger plane project
summary: Japan has announced plans to develop a next-generation passenger jet over the next decade, with a focus on using "new environmental technologies" such as hydrogen or hybrid electrics. The project, which will require a 10-year investment of $45 billion, aims to make Japan competitive in the aviation industry while contributing to the decarbonization of air transport. The new plane is expected to be ready by 2035, and the country is partnering with global players to develop a narrow-body plane.

images.alt_text: Confidence is growing that the world’s fourth-largest economy is exiting decades of price declines and subdued growth.
Inflation in Japan has proven stickier than expected over the last year.

The flash au Jibun Bank Japan manufacturing PMI rose to 48.2 in March from 47.2 in February. While the index has remained below the 50 index level that separates growth from contraction since June, the pace of deterioration was the softest in four months.

site_title: Germany is Europe’s sick man, but others are coughing
summary: Germany's economy is expected to deliver little to no growth in 2024, following a contraction in the first three months of the year. The euro zone's other major economies, including France, the Netherlands, and Ireland, are also showing signs of slowing growth. However, Italy's economy is expected to expand around 1% this year, driven by its successful "superbonus" tax credit for eco-friendly home renovations. Despite this, Italy's public finances are under pressure due to the cost of the superbonus, which is being pared back. European officials are concerned about the long-term gap between Europe and the US economy, and a report on the future of the European single market is expected to highlight the need for structural reforms and more demand-led policies to boost consumption.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni’s government  halted the tax credit system, which threatened the solidity of Italy’s finances.
The institutes now forecast Germany's gross domestic product (GDP) to increase by 1.4 per cent in 2025, revised from 1.5 per cent previously.

site_title: UBS to sell US$8 billion loans to Apollo in revised SPG deal
summary: UBS finalized a deal with Apollo Global Management to sell US$8 billion in senior secured financing facilities, replacing Credit Suisse's securitized products group. UBS will book a net gain of about US$300 million, while Credit Suisse is expected to recognize a net loss of US$900 million. The revised deal ends an investment management agreement and transition service agreement, with Apollo gaining control of the assets and employees, including former Credit Suisse trader Jay Kim.

images.alt_text: UBS sees “secular trends” such as demographic change in Asia sustaining its growth, the CEO Sergio Ermotti says.

site_title: Bank of England steps up scrutiny of private equity and bank valuations
summary: The Bank of England's Financial Policy Committee is scrutinizing private equity and bank valuations amid increased uncertainty over investor risk sentiment. The committee notes that finance for riskier corporates may be particularly vulnerable to a sharp correction in asset prices. The BOE is also examining why British banks' valuations are subdued compared to international peers. The committee's review aims to ensure the UK's financial system remains stable and resilient.

images.alt_text: The Swiss National Bank has become the first major central bank to ease its policy with a surprise 25 basis point cut to its key rate.
Bank of England governor Andrew Bailey says "we are not seeing a lot of sticky persistence" in inflation and "that is the judgment we have to keep coming back to".
The UK’s inflation rate has tumbled since striking a 41-year peak of 11.1 per cent in October 2022.

site_title: Coinbase must face US securities regulator’s lawsuit
summary: A US federal judge in Manhattan partially granted Coinbase's motion to dismiss the Securities and Exchange Commission's (SEC) lawsuit, allowing the lawsuit to move forward but dismissing one claim against the largest US cryptocurrency exchange. The decision largely blesses the SEC's approach to cryptocurrency, aligning with other judges who have sided with the regulator.

images.alt_text: Coinbase also expects to grant a 30-day option to allow the purchase of up to an additional US$150 million of the securities to cover over-allotments.
The crypto exchange also has benefited from its partnership with Circle, which issues the USD Coin stablecoin.
Coinbase is asking the court to dismiss the Securities and Exchange Commission’s lawsuit alleging the largest US crypto exchange is flouting its rules.

site_title: Biden’s biofuel push risks dethroning corn as king of US crops
summary: US farmers are expected to plant more soybeans than corn in 2024, a shift that could dethrone corn as the country's top crop. President Joe Biden's decarbonization plan and subsidies for green energy are boosting demand for soybean oil, key to renewable diesel production. Companies like Cargill and Bunge Global are expanding soybean processing capacity, while warmer spring temperatures are preventing some corn acres from being switched to soybeans. While this year's planting may not see soybeans surpass corn, the trend is expected to continue in the longer term, with soybeans poised to become the US's No. 1 crop.

images.alt_text: US corn, soyabean crops seen heading for record highs, putting pressure on prices

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Wednesday, March 27, 2024 (Ep 31)
summary: Japan's yen has hit a 34-year low, prompting warnings of potential intervention by the government. In related news, Thailand's stock exchange continues its decline due to a corporate setback, while Singapore's stocks rallied after a report showed high factory output in February. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) rose 0.5% in response.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 73 to 37.
The dollar briefly rose to 151.97 yen in the Asia session, its strongest against the yen since mid-1990, but was last down 0.25 per cent at 151.19.

site_title: China's pledges to South-east Asia come up US$50 billion short, says study
summary: China's Belt and Road Initiative in South-east Asia has fallen short of its pledged investment, with over $50 billion unallocated since 2015. The Australian think tank Lowy Institute found that more than half of the projects were either cancelled, reduced in scale, or unlikely to proceed due to political instability, poor stakeholder engagement, and declining interest in fossil fuel projects. Despite this, China remains the largest infrastructure partner in the region, involved in 24 of 34 megaprojects, with a 33% completion rate.

images.alt_text: A view of Colombo Port shows the red and white gantries of the South Asia Gateway container handling terminal in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Monday, Jan. 29, 2007.

site_title: Keppel sets sights on private equity, infrastructure in shift to be asset management powerhouse
summary: Keppel, a Singaporean conglomerate, is shifting its focus towards becoming an asset management powerhouse, driven by the need for steady streams of recurring income. The company is exploring opportunities in private equity markets and infrastructure, with a target to achieve a return-on-equity of 15% by 2030. Despite market headwinds, Keppel's infrastructure segment has shown significant growth, with recurring income rising 54% year-on-year in FY2023. The company aims to continue streamlining itself, investing in human capital, and leveraging technology to drive organic growth and bolster its value proposition.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
In May 2023, Keppel said it would transform itself from a conglomerate to a global alternative asset manager, with a target of S$100 billion in assets under management.
