site_title: Chinese EV maker BYD targets 20% jump in annual sales: sources
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker BYD aims to sell 3.6 million units in 2024, a 20% increase from last year, with plans to sell 500,000 vehicles overseas and one million units in 2025. Chairman Wang Chuanfu set a target of reaching 1 million vehicles sold annually by 2025, despite the company posting its slowest quarterly profit growth in two years due to declining EV sales in China. BYD's aggressive expansion into overseas markets and price cuts have led to a price war against Tesla, with Wang estimating a 40-10% market share shift in favor of domestic brands in China by 2026.

images.alt_text: Net profit totalled 8.67 billion yuan (S$1.6 billion) in the fourth quarter, on a 15.1 per cent jump in revenue to 180.04 billion yuan.
People walk past a booth of Zeekr, Chinese automaker Geely's premium electric vehicle (EV) brand, at a shopping mall in Beijing, China November 3, 2023. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo
The automaker is currently discounting almost every electric and hybrid car model it sells, as part of a marketing campaign declaring “electricity is cheaper than oil”.

BYD, which overtook Tesla last year as the world’s No. 1 electric vehicle manufacturer, will use Nvidia’s next generation of in-vehicle chips, called Drive Thor, to enable increased levels of autonomous driving and other digital functions, Nvidia said.
The BYD logo is displayed on a car during the media day of the 91st Geneva Auto Show, in Geneva, Switzerland, February 26, 2024. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse
To spur electric car demand, the government has introduced tax exemptions for EV car leasing/purchase agreements available to some consumers through their employers.

site_title: China changes tack on water politics
summary: China is shifting its approach to water politics, prioritizing regional cooperation on transboundary rivers that supply fresh water to nearly three billion people in 14 Asian countries. The country's success will depend on navigating diplomacy with neighboring states and the unpredictable US-China rivalry. China's involvement in multilateral water and environmental cooperation has increased, with the creation of the Lancang-Mekong Cooperation platform in 2017. The country has also negotiated with relevant parties on other rivers, such as the Ili, Irtysh, and Eurasia Economic Union. However, challenges remain, including the need for a unified regulatory agency and framework for transnational water management.

images.alt_text: Mekong crisis could deepen fault lines within Asean if not seen as regional issue: ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute report
Chinese dams under US scrutiny in Mekong rivalry

site_title: Second Chance Properties H1 profit falls 52.8% to S$4.3 million
summary: Second Chance Properties reported a 52.8% fall in its net profit to S$4.3 million for the first half of 2024, mainly due to lower contributions from its properties and securities businesses. Revenue fell 10.4% to S$13.3 million, with rental revenue from its properties segment declining 26% and net profit from the segment falling 58.4%. The company's gold business saw a 33.8% rise in net profit to S$1.9 million due to higher gold prices.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
The expected decrease is likely due to lower gains on disposal of investment properties. The company also expects it will report unrealised foreign exchange losses.

site_title: Nissan will invest in Renault’s Ampere in pursuit of global EV roadmap: CEO
summary: Nissan Motor will invest in Renault's electric vehicle unit Ampere despite listing plans falling through, aiming to deepen its European presence. CEO Makoto Uchida stated the company wants to be a global EV player and is already discussing investment. Nissan is also evaluating a partnership with Honda Motor to further expand its global EV presence. The move comes as the company faces intense competition from Chinese rivals and aims to capitalize on the growing demand for electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: The share sale is its second as Renault looks to cut its Nissan stake to 15 per cent from around 43 per cent as the two firms reshape their longstanding partnership.

Announcing an update to its medium-term business plan, Nissan says it would target an operating profit margin of over 6 per cent by end of the financial year to March 2027 and total shareholder returns of more than 30 per cent.

site_title: Ferrari to expand cooperation with battery supplier SK On
summary: Ferrari has entered a preliminary agreement with South Korea's battery supplier SK On to expand their cooperation. The two companies will share expertise to advance cell technology and explore new possibilities. Ferrari, known for its high-performance luxury sports cars, plans to launch its first fully electric model next year. The agreement follows existing collaborations, including supplying battery cells for Ferrari models since 2019. Ferrari's CEO Benedetto Vigna stated the companies are working together to "explore new frontiers." No further details on the deal were provided.

images.alt_text: California resident Iliya Nechev claims his 2010 Ferrari 458 Italia (not pictured), which he bought in 2020, had “brake issues” from the day he got it and “would experience partial or total loss of braking capability”.
The top seller during the live auctions is a 1903 Mercedes-Simplex 60 HP Roi Des Belges at Gooding & Co, which achieved US$12.1 million including premiums.
The upbeat forecasts has sent Ferrari’s shares roaring ahead by as much as 9.5 per cent, putting the company’s market value in sight of a record US$100 billion mark.

Painted scarlet and bearing a No 7 racing livery, the car is special because it is the only Ferrari GTO example originally equipped with a four-litre engine and the only factory GTO Tipo 1962 to have been raced by Scuderia Ferrari.

FILE PHOTO: The logo of Ferrari is seen in the headquarters as CEO Benedetto Vigna unveils the company's new long term strategy, in Maranello, Italy, June 15, 2022. Picture taken June 15, 2022. REUTERS/Flavio Lo Scalzo/File Photo

site_title: Law firm to launch investment treaty claims against Swiss government for Credit Suisse AT1 write-downs
summary: Global law firm Clyde & Co plans to launch investment arbitration claims against the Swiss government for the write-down of Credit Suisse AT1 bonds. The claims will use an international arbitration mechanism, applying international investment agreements and classifying the write-down as expropriation. This approach sets them apart from other claims brought before Swiss courts, which will be determined under Swiss national law. The move aims to seek compensation for the write-down, which affected Credit Suisse investors.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Most market watchers also expect more issuances to come this year, given that the bonds are part of banks’ capital adequacy requirements.
The latest move adds to a growing number of legal actions in Singapore against the Swiss government.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Swiss bank Credit Suisse is seen in front of a branch office in Bern, Switzerland November 29, 2022. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

This is the first major lawsuit in the public domain to be filed over the Swiss decision to wipe out around US$18 billion of Credit Suisses AT1 debt during the three billion Swiss franc all-share rescue deal.

If the AT1 bondholders are successful, they will not have to pay for the suit and will have a chance of getting perhaps 15 per cent to 20 per cent of their monies back, says WilmerHale partner Jonathan Lim.
Lawyers advised investors to read the fine print in bond instruments carefully before buying.

In a suit filed on Monday (Dec 4) to the Tokyo District Court, two plaintiffs are demanding around 42.7 million yen in compensation from SBI Securities, alleging it sold the Credit Suisse notes while offering incorrect explanations about them.
The claims against Finma relate to 2,500 individual parties.

site_title: Top China bank ICBC reports flat 2023 profit
summary: ICBC, China's largest bank by assets, reported a 0.79% rise in 2023 net profit to 363.99 billion yuan, slightly exceeding analyst estimates. The bank attributed the growth to increased risk controls on real estate loans. ICBC's net interest margin narrowed to 1.61%, and its non-performing loan ratio remained unchanged at 1.36%. The bank's real estate non-performing loan ratio was 5.37%, down from 6.14% a year earlier. The results reflect a sputtering economy, with China's GDP growth expected to slow.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) is seen at its branch at its headquarters in Beijing, China, March 30, 2016.  REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Chinese EV maker Nio cuts Q1 deliveries forecast amid tepid demand
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker Nio lowered its Q1 delivery forecast to 30,000 vehicles, down from 31,000-33,000, due to slowing demand in China amid a price war. The company's US-listed shares fell 4% in premarket trading. Nio faces intense competition from domestic EV companies and is exploring expansion into European markets. European investigators are also set to inspect Chinese automakers over potential unfair state subsidies. Nio had delivered 31,041 vehicles in the same period last year.

images.alt_text: The partnership will leverage technologies from both companies seeking to lower the so-called “full life cycle” costs of batteries.
Net loss per share stood at 3.18 yuan for Q4 FY2023, lower than 3.55 yuan for the year-ago period.

The agreement will give electric car startup Forseven a global licence to use Nio’s technical information and software for the research and development, manufacturing, and distribution of its vehicles
As of January 31, 2024, the number of vehicles Nio delivered cumulatively stood at 459,649.
BYD has met its ambitious three million target, selling 3.01 million cars in 2023 – in the process overtaking Tesla as the world’s top-selling EV maker.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 27)
summary: A Baltimore bridge collapse on Tuesday left six workers presumed dead, potentially involving "sizeable" compensation under protection and indemnity coverage. Industry experts expect significant payouts due to extensive damage and loss of life. In other news, Singapore's anti-scam efforts are being hailed as a model for tackling transnational organised crime, according to Interpol's secretary-general. The cut-off yield on Singapore's six-month Treasury bill rose to 3.8% and nominations opened for the 2024 Enterprise 50 Awards.

site_title: Indonesia's losing candidates urge court to disqualify president-elect
summary: Indonesia's losing presidential candidates, Anies Baswedan and Ganjar Pranowo, have urged the Constitutional Court to disqualify President-elect Prabowo Subianto, citing alleged interference and unfair practices in the election. They claim the administration of President Joko Widodo used social aid to ensure one outcome and pressured regional officials to support Prabowo. The court is expected to make a decision on April 22, with the candidates asking for a re-run of the election and the disqualification of Prabowo and his running mate.

images.alt_text: Hugely popular but without a political party of his own, former Indonesia President Joko Widodo is seeking to install a key ally as head of Golkar, said four senior politicians, who include three senior Golkar officials who have direct knowledge of the matter.

Defence Minister Prabowo and his vice-presidential running mate Gibran Rakabuming Raka received more than 96 million votes, roughly 58.6 per cent of the total count and enough to secure a first-round majority.

site_title: Xi tells Dutch PM Rutte 'no force can stop' China tech progress
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping told Dutch PM Mark Rutte that China's technological progress cannot be stopped, citing the country's "legitimate development rights." The statement came during talks on the semiconductor industry, a key battleground in recent years due to US and European concerns over China's military use. China's technological advancements are seen as a major challenge to global powers, with the US and Europe blocking exports of high-tech chip technology to China.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Prime Minister Mark Rutte (R) of the Netherlands welcomes China's President Xi Jinping on the second day of his state visit, at The Hague March 23, 2014.   REUTERS/Paul Vreeker/United Photos/File Photo

site_title: Japan’s Mitsui, Rohto said near deal for Eu Yan Sang: source
summary: Japan's Mitsui and Rohto Pharmaceutical are nearing a deal to acquire a majority stake in Eu Yan Sang International, a traditional Chinese medicine company, after outbidding others. The deal could value the company at around $800 million. The Mitsui and Rohto group is finalizing details of the transaction, which could be signed as early as next week. The companies are outbidding other groups, including Tower Capital Asia and members of Eu Yan Sang's founding family, who have been considering selling their majority holding.

images.alt_text: The Singapore-headquartered company has over 170 retail outlets, about 25 TCM clinics and three medical centres across Greater China, Singapore and Malaysia.

site_title: HDB rental market to sustain growth momentum; private condo rents may face more headwinds in H2 2024
summary: The HDB rental market is expected to sustain growth momentum, with four-room HDB flats and two-bedroom condo units being the most popular among tenants. In contrast, private condo rents may face more headwinds in H2 2024, due to a supply glut in the non-landed private housing market. The rental price index for HDB flats reached an all-time high of 137.5 in February, while the index for non-landed private housing declined 1% in February.

images.alt_text: Rents of HDB flats have grown 1 per cent month on month, but volumes are down 19.1 per cent.
The kitchen and living room of a two-bedroom unit at the Treasure at Tampines condominium.
January 2024 marks the sixth straight month of declines for condominium rental prices.

site_title: UBS to nearly double planned  Hong Kong office and occupy entire tower
summary: UBS Group is set to lease an entire 14-storey office tower in Hong Kong, expanding its space to 460,000 square feet, nearly doubling its initial planned space. The deal provides a vote of confidence for the city, which is battling to maintain its status as a premier financial hub. The move will consolidate UBS staff in one location, despite relocating from the central financial district, and aims to capitalize on opportunities in the Greater Bay Area.

site_title: Tech startup funding in South-east Asia falls 13% in Q1 as late-stage deals decline: Tracxn
summary: South-east Asia's tech startup funding declined 13% year-over-year to $816 million in Q1 2024, with late-stage funding dropping 80% to $175 million. Early-stage investments rose 60.9% to $526 million. Singapore-based startups received the most funding, followed by Jakarta and Ho Chi Minh City. Fintech, enterprise applications, and retail sectors were the top performers in terms of funding. The decline in late-stage deals and absence of large deals over $100 million were notable trends.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Tech investments fell to US$5.5 billion in 2023.
Wind turbines in South Sulawesi. The interest to invest in technologies that address carbon emissions and the impacts of climate change has been growing over the past five years.
The cryptocurrency sector ranked first in fintech deal volume in South-east Asia, although its share of funding fell from 21% in 2022 to 11% in 9M 2023.
Cryptocurrencies, insurance IT and investment tech were the top-funded fintech sectors in Q3 of 2023.
JPMorgan is one of the largest foreign lenders in the country, employing more than 50,000 people in cities including Mumbai, Hyderabad and Bengaluru.
Singapore's top-funded position in South-east Asia is in contrast to the regional decline in tech funding, data from Tracxn shows.

site_title: Thailand moves closer to legalising same-sex unions as Parliament passes landmark Bill
summary: Thailand's lower house of parliament passed a marriage equality bill with the support of all major parties, moving the country closer to legalizing same-sex unions. The bill, passed by 400 of 415 lawmakers, now requires Senate approval and royal endorsement before it becomes law. If approved, Thailand would become the third Asian territory to legalize same-sex unions, following Taiwan and Nepal. The bill marks a significant step towards cementing Thailand's liberal stance on LGBT issues, with the potential to take effect within 120 days of royal approval.

images.alt_text: The Bill proposes a key fundamental change to the composition of a marriage, from “a man and a woman” to “two individuals,” and a change in the official legal status from “husband and wife” to a genderless “married couple.”
People take part in the annual LGBTQ Pride parade in Bangkok, Thailand, June 4, 2023. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha

site_title: Only 14% of sustainability-linked bonds aligned with key climate goal: report
summary: A report by the Climate Bonds Initiative found that only 14% of sustainability-linked bonds (SLBs) globally are in line with the Paris Agreement's goal of limiting global temperature rise to below 2°C. The majority of SLBs lack greenhouse gas targets, including Scope 3 emissions, which are highly material in many sectors. The report recommends standardizing SLB structures, enforcing rules around key performance indicators, and improving transparency around disclosures. It also suggests regulators monitor misuse of callable structures and ensure issuers provide assurance on target performance.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
CapitaLand Investment views its latest bond issuance as an opportunity to access lower-cost yuan-denominated capital, and further expand its domestic channels and investor base.
Banyan Tree says the loan will support its commitment to responsible tourism.

site_title: India to spend US$3.7 billion to fence Myanmar border
summary: India plans to spend nearly $3.7 billion to fence its 1,610-km border with Myanmar over the next decade to prevent smuggling and other illegal activities. The fencing, which will be built in difficult hilly terrain, will cost around $2.02 million per km, more than double the cost of a previous border fence with Bangladesh. The project aims to prevent communal tensions from spreading to India's northeastern region, where thousands of civilians and troops have fled Myanmar since a military coup in 2021.

images.alt_text: Myanmar's Khawmawi village, on the country's border with India. Parts of Myanmar near the border have seen frequent clashes since Arakan Army fighters attacked security forces in November 2023.

site_title: Nominations open for 2024 Enterprise 50 Awards
summary: Nominations are open for the 2024 Enterprise 50 (E50) Awards, recognizing Singapore's 50 most enterprising, privately owned companies. The awards, now in their 30th year, celebrate three decades of the awards' history and focus on sustainability efforts. The theme "Celebrating Legacies and Inspiring the Future" aims to honor previous winners and set new benchmarks for success. Nominations close on July 1, with the winners to be announced in late November. The awards are supported by OCBC, KPMG, and Enterprise Singapore, and will evaluate companies based on financial performance and sustainability initiatives.

images.alt_text: VIPs including guest of honour Minister for Education Chan Chun Sing (seventh form left) and E50 Award winners gathering for a group photo at the end of the gala event.
Ant International hopes to leverage its ecosystem to help MSMEs improve the accuracy of their sustainability reports.

site_title: German economic institutes slash 2024 GDP forecast to 0.1%
summary: German economic institutes have revised their 2024 GDP forecast to 0.1%, a significant downgrade from the previous 1.3%. The institutes now predict a 1.4% growth in 2025, down from 1.5%. The downward revision is attributed to high interest rates, weak global demand, and political uncertainty. According to Stefan Kooths, head of economic research, a recovery is likely to set in from the spring but will not be strong.

images.alt_text: People visit the Berlin Art Market by the Zeughaus building, near castle Berliner Schloss - Humboldtforum in Berlin, Germany, May 1, 2023.  REUTERS/Fabrizio Bensch/File Photo
Analysts say Germany is in the midst of a recession after contracting in the final three months of last year and, they predict, the first quarter of 2024.
Long the economic powerhouse of Europe, Germany is now the slowest-growing among the 20 countries using the euro.
Germany is broadly expected to enter another technical recession in the first quarter of this year, after its economy shrank by 0.3 per cent in the final quarter of last year.
The composite PMI index tracks the services and manufacturing sectors that together account for more than two-thirds of the German economy.

site_title: Singapore’s anti-scam efforts are a model for tackling ‘epidemic’: Interpol chief
summary: Interpol secretary-general Jurgen Stock praises Singapore's anti-scam efforts as a model for tackling cyber-enabled crime, citing the country's collaboration between law enforcement and the private sector. The Anti-Scam Centre in Singapore has been successful in combating scams, with an "explosion" of cyber-enabled crime observed globally. Stock estimates that up to $3 trillion in illicit proceeds are channelled through the global financial system each year, with cybercrime being a major threat. Interpol is releasing a report on transnational organised crime groups, calling for increased global cooperation and data sharing to combat the issue.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo

site_title: ANZ aims to open operation at India’s Gift special economic zone
summary: ANZ Group Holdings plans to open an operation in India's Gift International Financial Services Centre, aiming to serve global clients and raise dollar funds. Approval is expected in the next few months after a due diligence process. The move adds to India's push to develop Gift City as a financial hub rivaling Singapore and Dubai. ANZ's expansion in India and Vietnam, as well as China, is part of its CEO Shayne Elliott's strategy to diversify the bank's presence in the region.

images.alt_text: “Right now there is still an enormous demand for our services in mainland China,” ANZ CEO Shayne Elliott says.
The settlement of the sale is expected to take place on Mar 8.
The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission had rejected the deal in August after ANZ had attempted to buy Suncorp’s bank in 2022 as part of plans to expand its retail banking franchise.

FILE PHOTO: A pedestrian is reflected in the window of a branch of the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group (ANZ) in central Sydney, Australia, October 25, 2017. Picture taken October 25, 2017.     REUTERS/Steven Saphore/File Photo
ANZ Group now has about 800 people in Singapore, double its headcount in Hong Kong.

FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: A pedestrian is reflected in the window of a branch of the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group (ANZ) in central Sydney, Australia, October 25, 2017. Picture taken October 25, 2017.     REUTERS/Steven Saphore/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: From tea bags to canned beverages, Gryphon brews a new identity
summary: Gryphon, a Singaporean tea company, is expanding its product line to include canned beverages, marking a significant shift away from its traditional tea bags and loose-leaf tea. The move, prompted by rising costs and supply chain disruptions, aims to attract younger customers and boost demand. Beverage sales now account for 20% of Gryphon's revenue, with the company projecting 60% of sales to come from beverages by 2027. Gryphon's founder, Lim Tian Wee, plans to expand into new markets, including China and the US, through licensing agreements rather than exporting products.

images.alt_text: "Our mission here is to upskill our talent – not just with a full time qualification but also a career switch for people who are looking for a second career,” says Shatec chief executive officer Lim Boon Kwee.
Malcolm Ong, chief executive and founder of The Fish Farmer, with a water quality monitoring sensor that detects changes in water conditions on his farms.

“Bread is something that many Singaporeans eat every day.  Our main direction is to keep the products affordable. We want you to come back every day, we don’t want you to come back only once a week," said executive director of Swee Heng, Eric Ng.
Lim Tian Wee

site_title: Yellen warns China's industry ramp-up is distorting world economy
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen plans to press China on its industrial capacity, citing overcapacity that distorts global prices and production patterns, hurting American firms and workers worldwide. Yellen says China's industrial policy led to substantial overinvestment in products like steel and aluminum, forcing global industries to contract. She will raise the issue during her upcoming visit to China, which comes after years of US-China diplomacy. China's dominance in the global solar energy industry and excess capacity in new industries like EVs and lithium-ion batteries are also concerns.

site_title: Rich rewards could lie ahead for Jurong Lake District’s master developer
summary: A consortium of five Asian property giants, including CapitaLand Development, City Developments Limited, Frasers Property, Mitsubishi Estate, and Mitsui Fudosan (Asia), submitted joint bids for the Jurong Lake District master-developer site, with different concept proposals. The tender closed on March 26, with no other contenders. The success of the project hinges on the consortium's ability to start work soon, despite high interest rates and construction costs, and the need for skilled migrants to bring dynamism to the area.

images.alt_text:
Three plots of land for a new precinct in the Jurong Lake District, March 26, 2024. 

Plot 1 (left) - Greenery beside Genting Hotel Jurong. 

Plot 2 (centre) - The current Interim Jurong East Bus Interchange. 

Plot 3 (right) - Construction site beside Jurong East MRT Station.
Leslie Yee

site_title: Renault to sell Nissan stake of about 2.5%
summary: Renault plans to sell approximately 2.5% of its stake in Nissan, valued at up to €362 million, as part of its efforts to cut its stake to 15% from around 43%. This is Renault's second share sale, following a 5% stake sold back to Nissan in December. The deal is part of a share buyback program and aims to reduce Renault's debt. The move supports the group's goal of returning to an investment-grade rating.

images.alt_text: The stronger cash position and margin growth are the latest sign that the carmaker’s turnaround under chief executive Luca de Meo is bearing fruit.
FILE PHOTO: A board with the logo of Renault is on display near a car showroom in Saint Petersburg, Russia March 24, 2022. REUTERS/REUTERS PHOTOGRAPHER/File Photo
The sale will be implemented as part of a share buyback programme announced by Nissan, and is to be executed on Wednesday, Renault says.

site_title: Singapore stocks close higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.6% to close at 3,251.71 on Wednesday, driven by gains from energy company Sembcorp Industries and local banks DBS and UOB. The broader market saw advancers outnumber decliners 289 to 270, with 1.4 billion securities worth S$1.4 billion traded. Regional markets were mixed, with Australia's ASX 200 up 0.5% and Japan's Nikkei 225 up 0.9%. Investors remain cautious ahead of economic data and the US Federal Reserve's policy direction, citing a tug-of-war between inflation realities and weaker growth expectations.

images.alt_text: CMG20231215-HengYY01 / 王彦燕 / SGX Centre 新加坡交易所 [Shenton Way] SGX logo in front of the SGX Centre building at Shenton Way.

site_title: Sri Lanka PM says China to develop strategic infrastructure
summary: Sri Lanka's Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardena announced that China has pledged to develop the island nation's strategic deep-sea port and the capital's airport. China, Sri Lanka's largest bilateral creditor, will assist the country's debt restructuring process and help develop its economy. This comes as a key condition to maintaining a $2.9 billion International Monetary Fund bailout. China's involvement is seen as crucial to Sri Lanka's economic recovery, but the terms of the agreement remain unclear.

images.alt_text: epa11022753 A vendor counts Sri Lankan rupee banknotes in the commercial hub of Colombo, Sri Lanka, 11 December 2023. The International Monetary Fund's executive board is slated to vote on 12 December regarding the release of approximately 330 million US dollars as the second tranche of the Extended Fund Facility program to Sri Lanka. In the preceding year, the IMF approved a three-billion-dollar Extended Fund Facility (EFF) to bolster Sri Lanka's economic strategies and reforms. Meanwhile, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) recently approved a 200 million US dollars concessional loan to Sri Lanka's government aimed at stabilizing the nation's financial sector in response to the economic crisis that arose in 2022 due to the suspension of external debt payments. Sri Lanka is experiencing its worst economic crisis in over seven decades as a result of a lack of foreign reserves.  EPA-EFE/CHAMILA KARUNARATHNE

site_title: H&M beats earnings expectations as new CEO plots turnaround
summary: H&M, the world's second-largest listed fashion retailer, beat first-quarter operating profit expectations with a 2.08 billion kronor (S$264.2 million) operating profit, exceeding analyst expectations. New CEO Daniel Erver attributes the result to well-received spring collections and signs of recovery in sales. Sales fell 2% in the first quarter, but rose 2% at the start of the second quarter, with stronger demand for clothing and accessories. The company's shares rose 12% in early trade following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Daniel Erver, who has worked for H&M for 18 years, will take over as CEO of the group.
H&M aims to reach an operating margin of 10 per cent by the end of 2024.
H&M has 91 stores and employs 4,000 people in Spain and will close 28.
Shein has a huge valuation and is primed for an IPO.
The Stockholm-based company tells its garment providers in Bangladesh that it will absorb the increase of wages in its product prices.

site_title: Japan’s yen hits 34-year low, sparking intervention warnings
summary: Japan's yen reached a 34-year low against the US dollar, briefly hitting 151.97 yen before rebounding slightly after a meeting of top monetary officials suggested intervention to address the currency's rapid decline. The dollar rose to its strongest level against the yen since mid-1990, but ended the day down 0.25%. Japan's top diplomat, Masato Kanda, indicated that the government is prepared to take action to stabilize the currency, citing "orderly FX moves".

images.alt_text: A rise in the yen helped push the US dollar index down 0.16 per cent to 104.26, after a weekly gain of nearly 1 per cent last week.
Service price moves are closely watched by the BOJ as a key indicator of whether wages and inflation are rising in tandem.
Confidence is growing that the world’s fourth-largest economy is exiting decades of price declines and subdued growth.
Inflation in Japan has proven stickier than expected over the last year.

The flash au Jibun Bank Japan manufacturing PMI rose to 48.2 in March from 47.2 in February. While the index has remained below the 50 index level that separates growth from contraction since June, the pace of deterioration was the softest in four months.

site_title: Malaysia considers extending US$10 billion rail to Thailand border
summary: Malaysia is considering extending its US$10.6 billion East Coast Railway Link (ECRL) to Thailand's existing or planned rail infrastructure, aiming to reduce economic competition with the country. Transport Minister Anthony Loke stated the government is open to connecting the ECRL to Thailand's rail infrastructure, which Thailand plans to build two new ports to bypass Malaysia's shipping route. The project could take 15 years to implement, with the potential impact limited to Malaysia's northernmost port in Penang.

images.alt_text: Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin makes a pitch to potential investors about the land bridge project during his visit to the US. PHOTO: X

site_title: India central bank keen to build up record high FX reserves
summary: India's Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has reached a record high of $642.49 billion in foreign exchange (FX) reserves as of March 15. The central bank plans to continue building its reserves, despite the economy's high growth and positive balance of payments, to insulate emerging market economies from global currency fluctuations. Large dollar inflows into equity and debt markets are expected to continue, with Indian debt being included in emerging market debt indexes later this year, and analysts say reserves seem adequate to meet the economy's needs.

images.alt_text: India’s forex reserves, including the central bank’s forward holdings, can now cover more than 11 months of imports, a nearly two-year peak.

site_title: Thailand weighs budget support as option for US$14 billion digital wallet plan
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin has ordered a financing plan for a US$14 billion cash handout plan, dubbed the "digital wallet," to revive the country's sluggish economy. The plan, which involves a combination of borrowing and state budget funding, may be finalized by April 10. The handout, worth 10,000 baht each to 50 million adult Thais, will be implemented in the fourth quarter of 2024 and aims to stimulate the economy, which has experienced sub-2% growth for a decade.

images.alt_text: As much as 210 billion baht (S$7.76 billion) is expected into the country’s automotive industry as Chinese EV makers rush to set up a supply chain in South-east Asia’s second-largest economy.
The report may prompt the House of Representatives to push ahead with a bill to legalise casinos and other forms of gambling.

site_title: Singapore prime office rents jump to highest level since 2008
summary: Singapore's prime office rents have reached a 15-year high, with gross effective monthly rents for premium office space in the city's central business district jumping to S$11.42 per square foot in the first quarter. This reverses a drop in the prior two quarters and is driven by a widespread return-to-office push and a boom in private wealth. Vacancies for prime office space have reached a post-pandemic low of 5.3%, and tenants have not secured space for more than 1.5 million square feet of office space coming online in 2024 and 2025.

Despite lower transaction volume, prices remain stable for the GCB segment, noted CBRE.

site_title: Thailand eyes US$15 billion in investment after PM’s global pitch
summary: Thailand aims to secure at least $15 billion in foreign direct investment over the next three years, following Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin's global pitches to electric-vehicle and technology companies. The country expects $7.76 billion in automotive investments and $250 billion in data centre and cloud services. Chinese EV makers are leading the charge, with more expected to set up supply chains in Thailand. The government's proactive approach has increased investor confidence and created opportunities for Thai businesses to raise competitiveness.

site_title: HSBC launches US$1 billion Asean growth fund
summary: HSBC has launched two new funds, a $1 billion Asean growth fund and a $150 million lending fund, to support businesses expanding in the region. The funds cater to high-growth industries and non-bank financial institutions looking to scale up through digital platforms across multiple Asean markets. The bank aims to support companies in Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam, addressing a funding gap in the market.

site_title: Latest Singapore 6-month T-bill offers cut-off yield of 3.8%
summary: The Singapore 6-month T-bill auction saw a cut-off yield of 3.8%, up slightly from the previous auction's 3.78% yield. The auction received a total of S$15.6 billion in applications, representing a bid-to-cover ratio of 2.55. Demand continued to rise, indicating a strong interest in the T-bill.

site_title: PBOC chief seeks to deepen currency ties with Asian economies
summary: PBOC Governor Pan Gongsheng announced plans to deepen currency ties with Asian economies to enhance financial stability in the region. China will aim to boost bilateral currency swaps with Asean member states, Japan, and Korea, and increase its representation at the International Monetary Fund. The move aims to support trade and investment activities, as well as financial risk prevention. This follows several steps taken by the central bank to shore up confidence in an ailing economy, including cutting reserve requirements and opening up China's financial sector.

site_title: Citi lays off 10 research staff in Asia-Pacific as part of global revamp: sources
summary: Citi has laid off at least 10 staff in its equities research department in Asia-Pacific as part of its global revamp, which includes reducing management layers to eight from 13. The move is part of a broader goal to trim its global workforce of 239,000 by 20,000 over the next two years. The bank has already eliminated 1,500 managerial roles, resulting in annual savings of about US$1 billion. Citi notified the impacted staff earlier this week, with further cuts planned across all divisions in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Ripple should pay more than US$2 billion for sales, SEC says
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is seeking a fine of over $2 billion from Ripple Labs for selling its XRP token to institutional investors without registering it as a security. The SEC claims Ripple has increased sales of the cryptocurrency since being sued in 2020, has not accepted responsibility, and intended to evade the law. Ripple has made statements dismissing the July ruling against it as a "total victory." The case has significant implications for the scope of the SEC's jurisdiction in the crypto industry.

site_title: Banyan Tree obtains S$70 million sustainability-linked loan
summary: Banyan Tree, a resort operator, has secured a S$70 million sustainability-linked loan to support its commitment to responsible tourism and decarbonization. The loan, led by Maybank, aims to help the group navigate challenges and capitalize on opportunities in a higher-for-longer interest rate environment. This comes after the company posted a 23% increase in total property sales for FY2023. The bank's commitment to mobilizing RM68 billion (S$19 billion) in sustainable finance by 2025 aligns with Singapore's efforts to achieve its carbon neutrality goal by 2050.

site_title: Baltimore bridge collapse: Compensation may run into billions, say industry watchers
summary: A major bridge in Baltimore collapsed on Tuesday, leaving six workers presumed dead. Initial reports suggest the incident is likely to be covered under protection and indemnity (P&I) insurance, which provides third-party liability coverage for vessels. Experts estimate the compensation for the significant losses could be "sizeable" due to high liability costs in the US, property values, and environmental implications. The total cost of the bridge collapse and associated claims may run into billions of dollars, with multiple insurers and reinsurers involved. The ship's owner, Grace Ocean, may face lawsuits and could be subject to "arrest" while claims are pursued.

Liu, Minister of the International Department of the Communist Party of China, stressed that Asia's main priority is maintaining peace and stability, regardless of external opinions. He also hinted at his potential candidacy for China's next foreign minister, highlighting his role in cultivating and fostering relations with foreign political parties.

site_title: China’s Country Garden hires Kroll to carry out liquidation analysis: sources
summary: China's Country Garden hires Kroll to conduct an independent business review and project a recovery rate for creditors under a liquidation scenario ahead of a court hearing in mid-May. The review aims to assess the developer's financial situation and determine a potential recovery rate for creditors. This move comes as Country Garden pushes ahead with its offshore debt restructuring plan.

site_title: Insurtech startup Qoala secures US$47 million in Series C funding
summary: Qoala, an Indonesia-based insurtech startup, has secured US$47 million in Series C funding led by PayPal Ventures and MassMutual Ventures. The funding will be used to further develop generative artificial intelligence, enhancing customer experience and operational efficiency. The company aims to develop tools for insurance partners to advance their capabilities in underwriting, claims processing, and fraud detection. Qoala's total capital raised now exceeds US$130 million, following its Series B round in 2022, which saw a 2.5-fold growth in gross written premiums.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as traders assess latest rally, eye data and earnings
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Wednesday, with some stocks rising and others falling, as investors assessed the latest rally and awaited key US data releases and corporate earnings. The rally may have run out of steam, with investors looking for fresh catalysts. The Federal Reserve's preferred gauge of inflation and jobless claims are due soon, and analysts warn that a big miss could cause concern. The start of corporate earnings releases next month could also impact sentiment, with analysts warning of potential market turbulence if expectations are not met.

site_title: China ‘very close’ to ending Australia wine tariffs, business chief says
summary: China is "very close" to lifting the heavy tariffs on Australian wine imports, according to the Australia China Business Council. The tariffs, which stood as high as 218%, were imposed during a period of heightened tensions between the two countries. Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi emphasized Beijing's openness to foreign investment during a visit to Australia, and the Australian government is hopeful the wine tariffs will be lifted by the end of March. However, not all wine producers are expected to return to the market immediately.

images.alt_text: “Dialogue leads to understanding and it leads to benefit for both of our nations. Australia will benefit from the economic activity that removal of these impediments will bring,” says Australia Prime Minister Anthony Albanese.

site_title: SK Hynix chief says HBM chips to be double-digit percentage of 2024 Dram chip sales
summary: SK Hynix CEO Kwak Noh-Jung predicts HBM chips will account for a double-digit percentage of its Dram chip sales in 2024, up from 8% in 2023. The company, a key supplier to Nvidia, is mass-producing next-generation HBM chips for use in AI chipsets. Analysts estimate HBM chips will reach 15% of industry-wide Dram sales this year, driven by growing demand for AI processing. SK Hynix has led the HBM chip market, supplying the HBM3 version to Nvidia, which dominates the AI chip market.

summary: Cordlife Group's CFO Thet Hnin Yi was arrested by the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) and released on bail amid a probe into potential breaches of disclosure obligations related to irregular temperatures of a cryogenic storage tank. The arrest follows the arrest of four company directors and its former group CEO, Tan Poh Lan, in connection with the issue. Cordlife maintains that Thet's continued presence as CFO would be beneficial to the company, citing her 17 years of experience and familiarity with financial numbers. A requisition notice from TransGlobal Real Estate Group was also issued, seeking to reject proposed resolutions and remove two non-independent directors.

site_title: S&P Global downgrades outlooks on five regional US banks to ‘negative’
summary: S&P Global downgraded the outlooks on five US regional banks to "negative" due to their commercial real estate (CRE) exposures, citing the possibility of stress in CRE markets affecting bank asset quality and performance. The downgrade comes a year after the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank, heightening investor concerns about US regional banks' health. The affected banks are First Commonwealth Financial, M&T Bank, Synovus Financial, Trustmark, and Valley National Bancorp. The move reflects the possibility of higher losses for these banks due to CRE loans.

images.alt_text: While just 4% of banks with 5,000 or more employees require full-time office attendance, nearly a third of the smallest banks in the cohort demand it, according to a survey of 137 US banks employing 4.4 million people from Scoop Technologies.
The new rating follows the bank’s announcement on Wednesday that it had raised US$1 billion from investors including former US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin’s Liberty Strategic Capital.

site_title: China’s Xi meets US business representatives in Beijing
summary: China President Xi Jinping met with US business representatives in Beijing, seeking to woo foreign investment and reassure American firms amid a slowing economy. The meeting, at the Great Hall of the People, was also attended by academics. This comes after the recent China Development Forum, which included top executives like Apple CEO Tim Cook. The meeting aims to boost China's economic prospects and counter US economic pressure, following a series of trade tensions.

site_title: China industrial profits rise in sign of stabilising economy
summary: China's industrial profits rose 10.2% in the first two months of 2024, extending a gaining streak since August, and adding to signs of a stabilizing economy. This increase was driven by a low base of comparison a year earlier and rebounding foreign demand, as well as policy stimulus by Beijing. However, deflationary pressures persist due to a property slump and subdued confidence, weighing on domestic demand. The government has pledged to provide funds to encourage consumer and business replacement of old goods, while the central bank is expected to deliver more liquidity injections.

images.alt_text: The central bank is likely to cut the rate on its medium-term lending facility in the second and third quarters.

site_title: Gold prices hold ground as investors seek more Fed cues
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $2,178.31 per ounce on Wednesday, supported by lower US Treasury yields, as investors awaited more cues on the Federal Reserve policy. Spot gold had surged to a record high last week after Fed policymakers indicated a possible interest rate cut. Investors now await US core personal consumption expenditure price index data on Friday to gauge when the Fed may begin cutting interest rates.

site_title: Hong Kong homebuyers flock to new projects, shunning used flats
summary: Hong Kong homebuyers are snapping up new properties after the government cut taxes, leading to increased demand and pressure on developers to offload inventory. New project launches have sped up, with Wheelock Properties selling 368 units in a few hours at discounted prices. In contrast, used home sales have weakened, with transactions declining for the second week. Analysts estimate 800-2,500 new home transactions in March and April, with prices likely to weaken due to the glut of unsold apartments.

images.alt_text: By 2046, more than one in three Hong Kong residents will be 65 or older.

site_title: Musk’s xAI to enable chatbot Grok for all premium subscribers of X
summary: Elon Musk announced that his AI startup xAI's chatbot, Grok, will be made available to all premium subscribers of X, a social media platform, effective immediately. This move aims to reduce the company's reliance on advertising and focus on subscription plans. The chatbot was previously only available to Premium+ subscribers. Musk also stated that xAI will open-source Grok, aligning with companies like Meta and France's Mistral that have open-source AI models.

site_title: ‘Titanic’ door prop that saved Rose (Sorry, Jack) sells for US$718,750

The item was one of 1,600 pieces, including items from popular movies like Indiana Jones and The Shining, and was sold by Heritage Auctions.

site_title: EV maker VinFast signs partnership agreements with 15 dealers in Thailand

As Thailand aims to convert 30% of its annual vehicle production to EVs by 2030, VinFast plans to expand to 50 countries. The deals were made at the Bangkok International Motor Show, fueling competition among EV makers seeking to use Thailand as a manufacturing base. This move is part of VinFast's strategy to tap growing demand in South-east Asia.

Investigators will interview the ship's crew and examine the twisted remains of the bridge to determine the cause and circumstances of the incident.

summary: Phillips 66 is exploring the sale of its 25% stake in the Rockies Express Pipeline, a 2730km interstate natural gas pipeline, worth potentially over $1 billion, including debt. The Houston-based company aims to raise $3 billion from asset sales this year. Talks with potential buyers, including private equity firms and infrastructure funds, are underway. Phillips 66 hopes to command a premium to the stake's current book value of $451 million, with debt obligations worth over $500 million to be assumed.

site_title: Australia’s inflation holds steady for third straight month
summary: Australia's inflation remained steady for the third consecutive month in February, with the consumer price indicator advancing 3.4% from the previous year, slightly less than economists' estimates. The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) kept interest rates unchanged at a 12-year high, citing aggregate demand remaining above the economy's supply potential. Economists predict the RBA will embark on an easing cycle in the third quarter, with some expecting a rate cut as early as August.

The ship had passed two overseas inspections in 2023, with a faulty fuel pressure gauge rectified in June. Authorities say the bridge was up to code and there's no evidence of foul play. The port closure is expected to have a significant impact on supply chains, but logistics experts doubt it will trigger a major crisis.

summary: The UK is at risk of losing up to eight million jobs due to artificial intelligence, with part-time, entry-level, and back-office jobs like customer service being most affected. According to the Institute for Public Policy Research, AI already impacts 11% of tasks in UK staff, and this figure could rise to 60% if the technology is integrated more deeply. The government's reliance on AI to boost productivity has raised concerns about the impact on jobs.

site_title: KuCoin used for US$9 billion in suspect crypto trades, US says
summary: US prosecutors charged KuCoin, one of the world's largest cryptocurrency exchanges, and two of its founders for failing to comply with American anti-money laundering rules. The exchange "wilfully failed" to establish and maintain anti-money laundering policies, allowing it to be used for illicit activity, including terrorist financing. The company received over $9 billion in suspicious and criminal funds, with over $5 billion of that sent to illicit destinations. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission also brought a case against the firm, with KuCoin stating its assets are safe and it respects laws and regulations.

summary: Applecrumby, a Malaysia-based baby-care brand, has raised US$4.2 million in funding from 500 Global. The funding will be used to expand into new markets, including Indonesia and the UAE, and to develop new products under its PureBasics mass-market line. Applecrumby's revenue rose to RM48.7 million in 2022, with the company turning a profit for the first time, reversing from a loss in 2021. site_title: Thailand can lift tourism revenue by legalising casinos: study
summary: Thailand can potentially lift tourism revenue by $12 billion by legalizing casinos within large entertainment complexes, according to a study. Average tourist spending may surge 52% to $65,050 per trip, generating an additional $448.8 billion in earnings. The proposed move, backed by Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin, aims to tackle chronic illegal gambling and bolster GDP growth by 1.16 percentage points. Lawmakers are expected to submit a bill to parliament, following a recommendation by a panel of lawmakers led by Deputy Finance Minister Julapun Amornvivat.

site_title: Tsingshan unit plans Indonesian battery plant as trade frictions mount
summary: Tsingshan Holding Group, the world's top nickel producer, plans to build a battery factory in Indonesia, its first overseas facility, to produce batteries for electric vehicles. The plant, to be built alongside existing operations in Weda Bay, could begin operating as soon as next year. The move aims to capitalize on Indonesia's abundant raw materials and infrastructure, while mitigating concerns over trade frictions with China, which is one of Indonesia's top investors. The factory will help Indonesia step up from commodities production to more lucrative processing and manufacturing.

site_title: Using your premium credit card may cost more after Visa-Mastercard deal
summary: A landmark agreement between Visa and Mastercard has been reached, allowing US merchants to charge customers extra for using certain types of Visa and Mastercard credit cards. The deal, worth at least $30 billion, will enable merchants to surcharge customers for premium cards with higher interchange fees, potentially impacting luxury credit card programs. The agreement also reduces swipe fees by at least 4 basis points for three years and sets a minimum average systemwide swipe fee below current levels for five years. The move is expected to increase competition between the two networks, but some trade groups argue it still does not go far enough.

site_title: Not even high mortgage rates make it worth renting London houses
summary: Owning a home in London remains more affordable than renting, even with high mortgage rates, according to data from Halifax. The monthly cost of owning a home in London is £2,241, £12 cheaper than renting an equivalent property. Private rents in London have surged 11% to £2,000 a month, driven by supply constraints and strong demand. The financial squeeze on younger tenants in London highlights the difficulty in securing a deposit to buy a home, despite favorable arithmetic for buying.
