British consumer price inflation slowed to 3.4 per cent in February.
Public sector net borrowing, excluding state-owned banks, was £8.401 billion (S$14.4 billion) last month, down from £11.843 billion a year ago.

site_title: Hong Kong’s elderly increasingly retiring in mainland China
summary: Hong Kong's elderly population is increasingly relocating to mainland China's retirement homes due to the city's acute shortage of accommodation and improved transport networks. By 2046, over one-third of Hong Kong residents will be 65 or older. Many are drawn by cheaper and better homes, as well as government policies allowing them to use medical expense vouchers at mainland healthcare facilities. The move aims to alleviate pressure on Hong Kong's aging population, with over 16,000 on a waiting list for subsidized residential care services.

images.alt_text: Housing prices have plunged more than 20 per cent from their 2021 peak due to higher mortgage rates, an outflow of talent and a weak market outlook.
Investment-banking-deal flows out of China have been muted across the tech sector and other industries amid a deteriorating macroeconomy and stricter regulations for new listings.
Hong Kong developers have been selling new homes at low prices to clear an abundant supply.
The number of licensed finance professionals dropped by more than 600 since the end of 2021.
Nearly 300 people have been arrested under the 2020 law so far.

Hong Kong’s retail outlets, restaurants and bars have been hammered by a record number of residents heading across the border, where there’s a booming array of entertainment and dining options at low prices.

site_title: Chinese TikTok sellers complain of under-fire platform tightening US rule enforcement
summary: Chinese e-commerce vendors on TikTok are upset by the platform's tightened rules for overseas sellers, requiring US entities to be 51% US-owned and chaired by a US passport holder. This change affects over 3,000 Chinese stores, which will need to re-register as overseas sellers, potentially putting them at a disadvantage compared to US sellers. The move comes as TikTok faces regulatory risks in the US, where it has been criticized for security and privacy concerns. The platform has seen significant growth from Chinese sellers since its US launch, with US$1.67 billion in gross merchandise value.

images.alt_text: EU industry chief Thierry Breton says the investigations should not be a surprise.
GoTo Financial wants to be the preferred partner of TikTok Shop in Indonesia.
TikTok intends to exhaust all legal challenges if the latest US legislation targeting the app becomes law.
Efforts to remove Chinese corporate influence over the popular social-media platform is back on the political agenda in an election year.
Supporters of TikTok gather near the Capitol in Washington on March 13, 2024.
FILE PHOTO: The TikTok office building is shown in Culver City, California, U.S., April 26, 2023. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

site_title: Ahead of Easter, Trump selling ‘God Bless the USA’ Bibles
summary: Former US President Donald Trump is selling Bibles ahead of Easter, featuring a US flag embossed cover, in a partnership with country music singer Lee Greenwood. The Bibles, containing the US Constitution and Declaration of Independence, are priced at $59.99 and will not fund Trump's campaign. Trump, a rare church attendee, has advertised the Bibles during Holy Week, saying "Christians are under siege" and encouraging supporters to "Make America Pray Again."

images.alt_text: Donald Trump, 77, has been rich all his life.
The decision eases an acute cash crunch brought on by Trump’s mounting legal expenses.
The deal values Trump’s majority stake in the company that holds his app Truth Social at about US$3.6 billion.

US President Joe Biden listens to an opening speaker during a campaign event at El Portal restaurant in Phoenix, Arizona, March 19, 2024. Biden holds a widening lead over Donald Trump in the fundraising stakes, while Trump is burning through legal fees as he battles multiple criminal and civil cases.
Despite Donald Trump’s US$2.6 billion net worth, his lawyers say that it’s been impossible so far to come up with the US$454 million bond, due on Monday.

Peter Navarro talks to the media before turning himself in at a federal correctional institution to begin his prison sentence for defying a subpoena from a panel that investigated the Jan 6, 2021, attack on the US Capitol, in Miami, Florida,  March 19, 2024.

site_title: UK businesses trim hiring and pay plans: Lloyds
summary: UK businesses have trimmed plans for staffing and wage increases, with the share of firms expecting to hire or increase wages by 3% or more falling to 33% from 35% in February. This comes as the impending 10% minimum wage rise in April may be weighing on employers, particularly smaller firms. The Lloyds Bank Business Barometer also showed that overall business confidence remains at a net 42% and the Bank of England is watching for signs that inflation pressures are abating enough for interest rate cuts later this year.

images.alt_text: Homes in Britain have less floor space per person than many other developed economies, trailing France, Germany, Japan, the United States and Taiwan.
The cost of UK housing and rentals has been sent surging by the lack of supply along with an upswing in demand, particularly in the post-pandemic period.

A nuclear submarine at the Royal Navy's submarine base at Faslane, Scotland, August 31, 2015. British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak will on Monday announce £200 million (S$340.1 million) of public investment to boost the UK’s nuclear deterrent programme and its civil nuclear industry.
A man carrying a child in his arms is followed by a migrant pregnant woman (second right), as they walk on the beach at Dungeness on the south-east coast of England, on August 16, 2023.
The UK’s inflation rate has tumbled since striking a 41-year peak of 11.1 per cent in October 2022.

FILE PHOTO: Signage the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA), the Britain's financial regulatory body, and the Payment Systems Regulator (PSR) is seen at their head offices in London, Britain March 10, 2022. REUTERS/Toby Melville/File Photo
Consumer prices in the UK are up by 3.4 per cent in annual terms, official data shows.

site_title: Hershey hit with downgrade as cocoa prices touch record
summary: Hershey's shares were downgraded to neutral from outperform by BNP Paribas Exane due to the surge in cocoa prices, which have more than doubled this year, exceeding $10,000 per tonne. Analyst Max Gumport cited the EU Deforestation Regulation as a structural cost adding to the system, reducing his 2025 EPS estimate by 9% to $9.59. The downgrade follows previous downgrades by Morgan Stanley, citing risks to Hershey's mid-term outlook.

images.alt_text: Cocoa prices have roughly doubled over the past year, hitting a series of record highs in recent weeks due to shrinking supplies.
Hershey expects net sales to grow 2 to 3 per cent in 2024, mostly driven by higher prices the company has already planned.

site_title: Tencent’s next big gaming bets draw on viral phenom ‘Palworld’
summary: Tencent is developing mobile games in the style of viral hit "Palworld" to reboot its core gaming business. The company's creative studios, Timi and Lightspeed, are working on genre-blending games with pet companions and stylised violence, hoping to recreate the success of "Honor of Kings". Tencent is also investing in its talent pool, including acquiring assets from ByteDance's reduced gaming division, and is focusing on developing in-house hits to drive growth amid a 2% decline in games revenue in the holiday quarter.

images.alt_text: Tencent says revenue reached 155.19 billion yuan (S$29 billion) for the three months ended Dec 31.
Tencent Music Entertainment reports revenue of 6.89 billion yuan (S$1.3 billion) for the quarter.
The company has made strides with so-called mini-games  and a livestreaming video platform that competes with TikTok’s local language service in China.

site_title: Universal Music to distribute BTS, rappers in new Hybe deal
summary: Universal Music Group has signed a 10-year distribution deal with Hybe, gaining rights to distribute the South Korean company's roster of stars including BTS, Lil Baby, and Thomas Rhett, as well as promoting artists on the Weverse social media app. The agreement will expand both companies' global market share, with Universal to distribute physical and digital music worldwide except in certain Asian markets. The deal also includes investments in Weverse and collaborations on artist promotions and marketing activities in North America.

images.alt_text: Kakao fought an intense battle for SM with Hybe, the label behind boyband sensation BTS, electrifying South Korea as two of the best-known K-pop labels slugged it out over for control of their destinies.
Hybe is doubling efforts to sign up new artists to the Weverse app, seeking to draw fans from around the globe and pursue profitability.

site_title: Vietnam’s stable economic policies a saving grace for investors amid leadership turmoil
summary: Vietnam's stable economic policies are expected to shield investor sentiment despite the recent ouster of its state president, Vo Van Thuong. Analysts predict that the country's consistent economic policies will not shift, despite leadership changes. Investor interest remains resilient, driven by Vietnam's growing economy, low-cost workforce, and robust manufacturing sector. The country's one-party state is seen as effective in managing geopolitics, and analysts believe the business-friendly environment will continue, with the government working to address domestic issues and enhance governance.

images.alt_text: Ousted: Vo Van Thuong was removed as president of Vietnam last week for "violations and wrongdoing".

site_title: Robert Kennedy Jr names wealthy lawyer as running mate for US presidential bid
summary: US presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has named Nicole Shanahan, a wealthy Silicon Valley lawyer, as his running mate in an anti-establishment campaign. Shanahan, 38, has no political experience but founded a tech law firm and donated $4 million to a political group to support Kennedy. Kennedy's campaign has sparked concern among Democrats, who fear his nostalgia for the Kennedy dynasty could dent President Joe Biden's vote count. The duo's platform focuses on issues like tech censorship, surveillance, and vaccine safety, with Shanahan expressing concerns about vaccine-related injuries.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - US presidential candidate Robert F Kennedy Jr. (R) announces his running mate Nicole Shanahan (L) in Oakland, California on March 26, 2024. Independent US presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr. announced wealthy Silicon Valley lawyer and political newcomer Nicole Shanahan as his running mate March 26, 2024, as he pursues an anti-establishment campaign seen as an increasing threat to Democrat Joe Biden. (Photo by JOSH EDELSON / AFP)
Green-energy and cannabis stocks briefly became market darlings as the odds of a victory for Joe Biden rose in 2020.
The funding package increases defence appropriations by 3 per cent while keeping overall domestic spending flat.
Israeli officials are expected to meet with their US counterparts next week in Washington to hash out opposing opinions on plans to invade Rafah.

Donald Trump, who unlike most US presidents rarely attends church except during public political events, has advertised the Bibles, which feature a cover embossed with an American flag, during what Christians call Holy Week.
Donald Trump, 77, has been rich all his life.
The decision eases an acute cash crunch brought on by Trump’s mounting legal expenses.

site_title: Oil settles lower as markets weigh Russian supply woes
summary: Oil prices settled lower on Tuesday as investors weighed the impact of Russian refinery capacity losses due to Ukrainian attacks. Russian oil refining capacity is down 14% of the country's total capacity, and oil prices edged lower after Russia ordered companies to cut output to meet a 9 million barrels per day target. Despite a slightly weaker US dollar, oil prices remain supported by rising geopolitical premiums, including the Israel-Gaza conflict, and are expected to remain muted ahead of data on US interest rate cuts.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled US$1.32 higher or 1.55 per cent, at US$86.75 a barrel.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Tuesday, March 26, 2024 (Ep 30)
summary: Asian stocks are mixed on Tuesday as traders remain cautious over US inflation data and earnings forecasts. Economists expect the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to maintain its monetary policy in April. Meanwhile, Lum Chang shares sink on the involvement of its managing director in an Iswaran probe. The Singapore stock market opens largely flat after a surprise inflation reading, with the STI up 0.04%.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, losers outnumber gainers 57 to 54.
Asia fluctuated, with Hong Kong, Singapore, Seoul and Taipei all rising but Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Wellington, Manila and Jakarta in the red.
The Land Transport Authority says it has not awarded any contract to Lum Chang Building Contractors since 2019.

site_title: Apple set to unveil AI strategy at Jun 10 developers conference
summary: Apple is set to unveil its long-awaited AI strategy at the Worldwide Developers Conference on June 10, with new proactive features to assist users in their daily lives. The company will not debut its own generative AI chatbot but will instead partner with Google and OpenAI to supply AI services. The iOS 18 update, expected to be the most ambitious overhaul of the iPhone's software, will also be a major focus. Additionally, Apple plans to release a minor refresh of the Apple Watch's software and the first major update to the operating system running on the Vision Pro headset.

site_title: Mastercard, Visa reach US$30 billion settlement over credit card fees
summary: Visa and Mastercard have reached a US$30 billion settlement with US retailers over alleged overcharging on interchange fees. The settlement, one of the largest in US history, would lower interchange rates by 4 basis points for three years and cap rates for five years. It would also remove anti-steering restrictions, enabling competitive pricing and estimated savings of US$30 billion over five years.

site_title: McDonald’s to sell Krispy Kreme doughnuts across the US
summary: McDonald's is set to start selling Krispy Kreme doughnuts across the US, with the first availability expected later this year and a nationwide rollout by the end of 2026. The deal, which includes three of Krispy Kreme's most popular doughnuts, is seen as a way for McDonald's to attract diners for breakfast and all-day snacking. The partnership is expected to more than double the locations where Krispy Kreme products can be bought, with the doughnut chain's CEO stating that the deal will be a significant opportunity for the company.

images.alt_text: On Friday, system outages plagued McDonald’s locations across some of its biggest global markets, including Japan, Australia and the UK, forcing many stores to temporarily take only cash or shut down entirely.
The outage appears to have affected some electronic kiosks at outlets here.
Firms including Mubadala Investment, Qatar Investment Authority (QIA) and China Investment Corp (CIC) are in talks to jointly invest in McDonald’s China operations as minority shareholders.

site_title: Europe: Shares end higher on financials boost; Rubis shimmers
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index closed at a record high, up 0.2% at 511.09, driven by banks and tech stocks. Analysts predict a 25 basis point interest rate cut by the European Central Bank in June, with 60% of traders betting on this. French liquid products distributor Rubis soared 12.5% after its stake increased, while German consumer sentiment is expected to slow in April. European markets will be closed on Friday and Monday for Easter holidays.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended 0.1 per cent lower at 39,282.33 on Tuesday.

site_title: US: Stocks end lower after tepid consumer data
summary: US stocks ended lower on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.1% to 39,282.33, the S&P 500 declining 0.3%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index dropping 0.4%. Consumer confidence in the US dipped slightly in March, citing concerns about inflation and the US political environment. Boeing fell 2.0% after a downgrade review, while UPS sank 8.2% due to disappointing outlooks. In contrast, Trump Media & Technology Group surged 16.1% on its Nasdaq debut.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., March 20, 2024.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: US consumer confidence holds steady while outlook deteriorates
summary: US consumer confidence remained steady in March at 104.7, but expectations fell to 73.8, the lowest since October, while current conditions improved to 151. Despite high prices and borrowing costs, consumers are optimistic about their current situations, but pessimistic about the outlook due to concerns about the election and the labour market. The labour market appears robust, but the gradual cooling of the market may limit optimism. Consumers remain unfazed by inflation, with the average anticipated inflation rate holding near the lowest level in four years.

images.alt_text: Orders for durable goods, items ranging from toasters to aircraft meant to last three years or more, rose 1.4 per cent last month amid increases in transportation equipment and machinery orders.
The survey suggests that the US economy ended the first quarter on solid ground.
Initial claims for state unemployment benefits dropped 2,000 to a seasonally adjusted 210,000 for the week ended Mar 16.
Much of February’s rise was down to a 0.8 percent rise in manufacturing output, and a 2.2 increase in the index for mining.
In the 12 months through February, import prices dropped 0.8 per cent after declining 1.3 per cent in January.
Retail inventories increased 0.4 per cent in January, instead of the 0.5 per cent estimated in an advance report published last month.

site_title: Russia’s vulnerability showcased again after Putin presidential win
summary: Russia's President Vladimir Putin has won a new presidential term, potentially lasting until 2030, but recent attacks in Moscow have highlighted the vulnerability of the Russian state. The March 22 attacks, claimed by the Islamic State in Khorasan Province, resulted in the deaths of over 150 people, raising questions about the Russian security apparatus's ability to prevent such attacks. Key Western intelligence veterans believe Putin may still be vulnerable to a coup, but his authority is more likely to decay than be deposed in the immediate term. The attacks may also lead to a shift in Russia's war effort in Ukraine, with potential key economic implications.

images.alt_text: “ISIS-K has been fixated on Russia for the past two years” and frequently criticizes President Vladimir Putin in its propaganda, says a counterterrorism analyst.
Putin dismissed prospects for a halt to the war in a televised interview last week, saying he is not interested in a “pause” that would allow Ukraine to re-arm.

site_title: US home-price growth picks up with ‘healthy gains’ across cities
summary: US home-price growth accelerated at the fastest rate since 2022, increasing pressure on buyers with a 6% national price gain in January compared to the previous year, according to S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller data. This surpasses the 5.6% annual gain in December. The tight supply of homes for sale, combined with rising borrowing costs since 2022, has driven up prices. Despite rising inventory, homes remain listed at historically low levels, contributing to the high prices.

site_title:
Singapore’s money laundering 
accused slapped with 
6 new fraud, forgery charges
summary: Vang Shuiming, a Turkish national and one of 10 accused in Singapore's biggest money-laundering case, has been slapped with six new charges related to fraud and forgery. The charges stem from allegedly submitting forged financial statements for two companies to a private bank in 2022. This brings the total number of charges against Vang to 22. He has been denied bail twice due to concerns over his significant overseas wealth and multiple passports.

images.alt_text: Vang Shuiming and his family have various passports from countries that they received through financial contributions. He is one of the accused embroiled in the S$2.4 billion-dollar money laundering case.
Paige Lim

site_title: It’s time to employ innovative strategies to boost valuations in Singapore stocks
summary: Singapore's stock market is undervalued, with only about a third of listed stocks trading above book value. The median counter has a price-to-book ratio of around 0.6 times, significantly lower than the US market. Insufficient liquidity and lack of institutional investment are major factors contributing to this issue. To address this, experts suggest implementing corporate governance reforms, similar to those in Japan, which led to a market rally. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has also introduced fund tax incentives to encourage investment in local equities. However, more needs to be done to improve the market's attractiveness and drive valuations up.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
While regulators and experts in the field often focus on the minutiae of rules and controls that guide the behaviour of companies, ordinary investors often react to the behaviour itself.

site_title: Wing Tai prices S$100 million 5-year notes at 4.38%
summary: Wing Tai priced S$100 million 5-year notes at 4.38% to finance working capital and investments, and refinance existing borrowings. The notes were issued under the company's S$1 billion multicurrency debt-issuance programme. DBS Bank, HSBC, and OCBC were joint book runners and global coordinators. The proceeds will be used to meet the company's financial requirements.

images.alt_text: CMG20231215-HengYY01 / 王彦燕 / SGX Centre 新加坡交易所 [Shenton Way] SGX logo in front of the SGX Centre building at Shenton Way.
Claudia Chong

site_title: Norway’s US$1.6 trillion fund voices concern over UK IPO proposals
summary: Norway's $1.6 trillion sovereign wealth fund has expressed concerns over the UK's plans to simplify rules around public listings, fearing it may undermine investor confidence in the market. The fund warned that lowering corporate governance requirements could drive up investor costs and erode the UK's reputation for robust investor protection. The Financial Conduct Authority's plan aims to boost interest in London's stock markets, but the fund urges the regulator to reconsider its decision to remove protections such as mandatory time-based sunset clauses and shareholder votes on related party transactions.

site_title: Minority shareholders astir; time for independent directors to respond
summary: Singapore's minority shareholders are demanding changes at several listed companies, including Best World International, after growing frustrated with long-languishing valuations and lack of accountability. A group of shareholders sent a letter to Best World International, requesting an extraordinary general meeting to remove three directors, review director remuneration, and increase cash extraction. This comes as Singapore's stock market rises, partly due to a new emphasis on corporate governance.

images.alt_text: Stephen Butt in 2005..
Japan's Nikkei 225 has breached 40,000 for the first time earlier this month, following years of corporate governance reform efforts.

site_title: Have McKinsey and its consulting rivals got too big?
summary: McKinsey, one of the world's top consulting firms, is facing growth slowdown and internal discontent. An anonymous memo from former partners criticized the firm's pursuit of unchecked growth and lack of strategic focus. The memo came amid a power struggle, where managing partner Bob Sternfels was forced into an internal contest for the top job. The consulting industry, once considered indestructible, has seen growth slow to around 5% in 2023, down from previous years.

images.alt_text: Big Four public accounting firm EY has called off a plan to break up its audit and consulting businesses, after resistance from its US branch.
The best management gurus have shown a genius not only for identifying management problems but also for helping to solve them.

site_title: Alibaba dumps logistics arm IPO; to buy rest of Cainiao stake for up to US$3.8 billion
summary: Alibaba has withdrawn the initial public offering of its logistics unit, Cainiao Smart Logistics Network, from the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. The company, which holds a 64% stake in Cainiao, is offering to acquire the remaining shares for up to $3.75 billion. Minority shareholders will be allowed to sell their shares to Alibaba for $0.62 per share. This decision comes after Alibaba initially planned to list the logistics arm in Hong Kong in September last year as part of its restructuring efforts.

site_title: Sri Lanka Cabinet approves 40% hike to minimum wage
summary: Sri Lanka's Cabinet has approved a 40% increase in the minimum wage, from 12,500 rupees to 17,500 rupees, to support workers struggling with living costs amid the country's economic recovery. The move aims to help those living in poverty, with the national daily wage also set to increase by 200 rupees. The decision comes as the country slowly recovers from its worst financial crisis in decades, with inflation reducing to 5.9% in February. The increase is expected to benefit the poorest 20% of the population, who have seen their average monthly household income increase to 17,572 rupees.

images.alt_text: Sri Lanka is due to start talks with private bondholders to restructure US$12 billion of debt.
The IMF says it had reached a staff-level agreement with Sri Lanka to clear the way for the release of US$337 million, the third instalment out of a four-year US$2.9 billion bailout.

site_title: China’s Citic Securities posts 7.5% fall in 2023 profit
summary: China's Citic Securities reported a 7.49% fall in its annual net profit to 19.72 billion yuan (S$3.7 billion) in 2023, citing shrinking investment returns and market turbulence. The company's investment returns fell 40.84% to 18.9 billion yuan, while revenue from its brokerage business decreased 7.81% to 15.2 billion yuan. Chinese stock markets were among the worst-performing globally last year, and regulators have increased efforts to revive investors' confidence. The company's shares rose 0.61% on the announcement.

images.alt_text: The logo of CITIC Securities is seen at its branch in Beijing, China, March 22, 2016.REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon

site_title: Good time to begin to get out of cash and invest, say strategists
summary: US Federal Reserve is expected to reduce interest rates, causing lower-risk options like deposits to move down rapidly. Strategists advise investors to consider moving out of cash into fixed income or equity investments. A significant amount of money, around $9 trillion, is invested in money market funds globally, with US assets declining by $60.9 billion in the recent week. This shift is seen as a major opportunity for investors to diversify their portfolios.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua
This year, the financial and industrial sectors are up 10.1 per cent and 9.9 per cent, respectively, while energy has gained 10.3 per cent.
Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan are some of the most pessimistic strategists at major Wall Street banks.
The ebbs and flows of generative AI growth do not necessarily signal severe market instability; these fluctuations are inherent characteristics of technological evolution within a market economy.

site_title: Ford reaffirms annual core profit outlook
summary: Ford reaffirmed its annual core profit outlook, expecting a profit between $10 billion and $12 billion. This comes amid higher expenses for legacy automakers due to electrifying lineups and varying demand for battery electric vehicles. Peer General Motors also expects to meet its annualized EV production target, while Chrysler parent Stellantis plans to cut costs and boost electric vehicle production. Ford and GM will provide more details at the BofA automotive summit conference later in the day.

images.alt_text: Ford is recalibrating its EV strategy as mainstream US consumers baulk at the high price of battery-powered models and the spotty charging infrastructure

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 26)
summary: Singapore's factory output grew 3.8% year on year in February, beating estimates of 0.5%, according to data from the Economic Development Board (EDB). This extends the gains from January's revised figure of 0.6% growth, easing from the 4.7% growth posted in the previous month.

site_title: US durable goods orders rebound in February
summary: US durable goods orders rose 1.4% in February, exceeding expectations, amid increases in transportation equipment and machinery orders. The revision of January data showed orders plummeting 6.9% instead of 6.2%. The sector's outlook is improving as interest rates are expected to decrease this year, and a recent survey from the Institute for Supply Management showed manufacturers being fairly upbeat about sales and business conditions.

images.alt_text: The survey suggests that the US economy ended the first quarter on solid ground.
Initial claims for state unemployment benefits dropped 2,000 to a seasonally adjusted 210,000 for the week ended Mar 16.
Much of February’s rise was down to a 0.8 percent rise in manufacturing output, and a 2.2 increase in the index for mining.
In the 12 months through February, import prices dropped 0.8 per cent after declining 1.3 per cent in January.
Retail inventories increased 0.4 per cent in January, instead of the 0.5 per cent estimated in an advance report published last month.
The producer price index (PPI) rose 0.6 per cent in February, after rising by a higher-than-expected 0.3 per cent a month earlier.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as chipmakers, megacap growth stocks rebound
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 24.68 points, or 0.06%, to 39,338.32, and the S&P 500 gaining 10.66 points, or 0.20%, to 5,228.85. Megacap growth stocks and chipmakers led the gains, while investors awaited economic data to assess the Federal Reserve's interest-rate path. The Nasdaq Composite rose 62.38 points, or 0.38%, to 16,446.85.

site_title: Stellantis signs deals to cut at least 2,500 jobs in Italy
summary: Stellantis has agreed to voluntary job cuts of at least 2,500 employees in Italy, with up to 1,520 employees eligible to leave with financial incentives. The carmaker aims to adapt to the industry's transition to clean energy. The job cuts are mostly aimed at employees close to retirement age or willing to take new opportunities, and are seen as a necessary step for the company's future.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Stellantis is seen on the company's building in Velizy-Villacoublay near Paris, France, March 19, 2024. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes/File Photo

site_title: Lessons from past bubbles for the AI revolution
summary: The CFA Society Singapore advises investors to adopt a cautious approach when investing in artificial intelligence due to its rapid growth and associated challenges. Market volatility and convoluted regulations, particularly for generative AI and large language models, are significant hurdles. Lessons from past market bubbles can help investors navigate the AI revolution, emphasizing the need for a clear-sighted approach. The AI revolution marks a dramatic shift away from traditional innovation models, with concurrent risks and opportunities arising from its expansion into novel fields.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An AI (Artificial Intelligence) sign is seen at the World Artificial Intelligence Conference (WAIC) in Shanghai, China July 6, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
George Gatch, CEO of JP Morgan Asset Management, believes active management is key to outperformance going forward, given the dispersion in stock valuations in the S&P 500.

site_title: Vodafone Germany to cut 2,000 jobs in revamp
summary: Vodafone Germany plans to reduce personnel costs by 400 million euros over the next two years through job cuts and automation. Around 2,000 jobs will be affected, with the goal of saving 11,000 jobs worldwide as part of a larger cost-cutting drive announced last year. The company attributes the cost reduction to increased automation in manual tasks, aiming to improve efficiency and competitiveness.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Branding is displayed for Vodafone at one of its stores in London, Britain, June 14, 2023. REUTERS/Toby Melville/File Photo

(FILES) A pedestrian walks past a Vodafone store in central London on May 16, 2023. Vodafone has agreed to merge its British operations with rival Three UK, owned by Hong Kong-based CK Hutchison, the pair announced June 14, 2023. The long-awaited deal is aimed at accelerating rollout of faster 5G connectivity in the UK. (Photo by Adrian DENNIS / AFP)

As part of the agreement, Vodafone will use OpenAI technology running on Azure to enhance customer service operations including its consumer chatbot, and Vodafone employees will have access to Microsoft Copilot.

site_title: A tale of two IRs: MBS edges out Genting’s RWS in mass-market appeal
summary: Marina Bay Sands' (MBS) upcoming fourth tower expansion may not significantly impact rival Resorts World Sentosa (RWS) due to factors like location and casino operations. Analysts suggest that MBS tends to draw a higher proportion of non-staying visitors, while RWS relies on its hotel capacity for casino traffic. MBS' casino net revenue grew 84.3% to US$741 million in the fourth quarter, while RWS' revenue increased 64.2% to S$244.4 million. The expansion may give MBS an edge, but RWS' planned expansions, including a new waterfront lifestyle complex, could also benefit the company.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
An artist's impression of Marina Bay Sands' fourth tower.
Construction deadline for MBS’ S$4.5 billion extension pushed back again to April 2024
Construction of the new facilities has been pushed back more than once by Marina Bay Sands due to the onset of the pandemic.
MBS's casino segment maintained its position as the largest revenue contributor in the quarter.
Genting Singapore said Resorts World Sentosa has bounced back to levels nearing the pre-pandemic period.
Genting Singapore’s shares fell as much as S$0.105 to S$0.925 as at 9.52 am, with 75.8 million shares changing hands.
Citi expects Genting Singapore's Resorts World Sentosa to "enjoy a similar but slightly lower recovery" than Marina Bay Sands.
Resorts World Sentosa Singapore
Singapore IRs bet on S$9b expansion; exclusive licences extended to 2030

site_title: China files WTO complaint over US electric-vehicle subsidies
summary: China has filed a complaint with the World Trade Organization (WTO) over US electric-vehicle subsidies, citing "discriminatory" and "seriously distorted" rules that discourage Chinese manufacturers from sourcing battery materials. The US restrictions, part of the Inflation Reduction Act, limit tax credits for electric cars sourced from "foreign entities of concern" (FEOC), including China. The complaint is seen as a response to US resistance to world-leading Chinese battery firms. China calls on the US to reverse the policy, amid escalating tensions over trade and geopolitics.

site_title: China’s Xi Jinping to meet with American executives on Wednesday: sources
summary: China's President Xi Jinping will meet with American business leaders in Beijing on Wednesday, following a November dinner with US investors in San Francisco. The meeting was proposed by US insurer Chubb's CEO Evan Greenberg, and includes Stephen Orlins and Craig Allen. The event comes amid concerns over transparency in China's economy, with Xi seen as maintaining control. Xi's public overtures towards overseas investment have been met with skepticism due to China's anti-espionage law and exit bans.

site_title: Toyota plans to mass produce battery Hilux pickup truck by 2025, official says
summary: Toyota plans to mass-produce a battery electric Hilux pickup truck by the end of 2025, according to the president of its Thailand unit. This announcement comes just days after rival automaker Isuzu Motors stated it would manufacture its battery D-MAX pickup in Thailand by 2025. Thailand is a regional automaking hub, with pickup trucks among the vehicles produced for domestic sale and export. The move is part of Toyota's efforts to expand its electric vehicle offerings and compete in the growing market.

site_title: Fed’s operating losses swelled to record US$114.3 billion in 2023
summary: The US Federal Reserve reported a record operating loss of $114.3 billion in 2023, as interest expenses nearly tripled to $281.1 billion, exceeding its earnings of $163.8 billion. The loss forced the Fed to forgo remittances to the Treasury, citing elevated interest rates. The Fed's deferred asset, which represents the amount it must send to the Treasury, grew to a record $133.3 billion. This is the largest operating loss in the Fed's history, resulting from its efforts to combat inflation through interest rate hikes.

site_title: OCBC aims to quadruple number of cross-border QR payments in 2024
summary: OCBC Bank expects to facilitate 250,000 cross-border QR payments in 2024, a four-fold increase from last year. The bank has integrated five cross-border payment platforms into its digital app, enabling users to make seamless QR payments abroad. OCBC attributes the growth to the post-pandemic boom of QR code payments and the anticipated increase in travelers to mainland China. The bank's partnerships with Alipay+ and UnionPay International have expanded coverage for its customers, particularly in mainland China, where QR payments account for over half of the total number made through the app in 2023.

Customers of participating financial institutions in Singapore and Indonesia will now be able to make cross-border retail payments when making purchases.

site_title: Singapore stocks gain on Tuesday as regional markets end mixed; STI up 1.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 1.1% on Tuesday, driven by gains from Seatrium and Keppel, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,233.33. The region saw mixed trading, with Kospi and Hang Seng Index rising, while Nikkei 225 and ASX 200 fell. Investors are adjusting to the possibility of no US rate cuts, leading to potential market volatility in the short term.

site_title: China EV giant BYD posts slowest quarterly profit growth in 2 years
summary: China's electric vehicle giant BYD reported its slowest quarterly profit growth in 2 years, with a 15.1% revenue increase but an 18.6% profit rise. The company's aggressive discounting strategy has taken a toll on domestic profit margins, but its strong cost control and growing exports may offset this. BYD exported over 240,000 cars in 2023, and forecasts exports of 300,000 to 400,000 units this year. The company also unveiled a new electric SUV, the Yuan Up, with a starting price of 96,800 yuan.

site_title: MPA investigating after Singapore-flagged ship hits Baltimore bridge
summary: A Singapore-registered container ship, the Dali, struck the Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore, causing it to partially collapse. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) is investigating the incident, which also resulted in six construction workers going missing. The ship's crew of 22 is safe, and the vessel is currently holding its position at the site. Rescue efforts are ongoing, and the US Coast Guard and National Transportation Safety Board are also investigating the incident. The ship was en route from Baltimore to Colombo when the incident occurred.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

US Coast Guard and Maryland State Police officials said that based on the frigid temperature of the water and the length of time that had elapsed since the bridge came down there was little if any chance that the six workers missing could be found alive.

site_title: Investors can’t always trust the data, and that’s okay
summary: Investors and economists are reminded that data is often unreliable due to noise and the subjective nature of data collection. An academic paper questions the benefits of factor investing, which relies on "factors" such as company size or share price comparison. The paper found that the data used to estimate these factors changed over time, affecting the estimates. This controversy highlights the limitations of data, even with the increasing availability of big data and AI tools, and emphasizes the need for human judgment to temper data-driven decisions.

images.alt_text: Every individual in the company, including the CEO, should have immediate access to an accurate view into the business whenever he needs it.

Integrating AI and ML into data management systems facilitates the development of advanced smart data fabric architectures, enabling fintechs to analyse and visualise data from various sources effortlessly.

site_title: China manufacturing drive risks higher US inflation, NY Fed says
summary: China's efforts to boost manufacturing and shore up its economy may put "meaningful upward pressure" on US inflation, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. China's credit flows to factories have accelerated, potentially boosting economic growth and pushing up prices for commodities and intermediate goods, which could result in a weaker dollar. This could delay US monetary easing, as the extra demand from Chinese manufacturers would likely tilt the balance of risks for US inflation to the upside.

site_title: Argentina’s economic reforms hold out hope
summary: Argentina's President Javier Milei has introduced a sweeping economic reform program, dubbed "chainsaw austerity," aimed at cutting bureaucracy and deregulating the economy to bring down inflation. The program includes measures such as privatizing state-owned companies and reducing regulations in areas like housing and export customs. While facing opposition from unions and Congress, the International Monetary Fund has praised the package. Early signs of success include a monthly budget surplus and an increase in foreign exchange reserves, but the path to recovery remains uncertain and challenging. Milei's efforts have sparked cautious optimism among businesses and the public.

images.alt_text: View of a fruit and vegetables stall at the Central Market in Buenos Aires, on January 9, 2024. Argentina, a country of 46 million inhabitants, registers a poverty rate of XXX%, according to official figures. (Photo by Luis ROBAYO / AFP)
More than 50 of those borrowers have active loan or guarantee programmes – about a quarter of the fund’s members.
Prime Minister Narendra Modi has been accused of weakening Indian democracy’s secular and liberal foundations.

site_title: China’s Comac wide-body C929 jet in ‘detailed design stage’, official says
summary: China's Comac has entered the detailed design stage for its wide-body C929 jet, with the fuselage manufacturer aiming to deliver the first fuselage section by September 2027. The C929, which will have around 280-400 seats and a range of 12,000 km, is part of Comac's long-haul wide-body programme, which has experienced delays. The jet's development comes as China seeks to advance its domestic and international aviation industry amid a global shortage of new aircraft.

images.alt_text: A China's Comac C919 aircraft performs during a preview of the Singapore Airshow in Singapore on February 18, 2024. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)
A C919 performs during a preview of the Singapore Airshow in Singapore on Feb 18.
The Comac C919 is China's first international airliner and could gain sales as aviation giants Airbus and Boeing grapple with supply-chain disruptions.

A China Comac C919 aircraft during a preview of the Singapore Airshow in Singapore, Feb 18, 2024. Beijing wants to challenge the decades-long dominance of top plane-makers Airbus and Boeing while reducing its reliance on foreign technology.

site_title: Five-party consortium places 2 bids for Jurong Lake District site
summary: A five-party consortium comprising CapitaLand Development, City Developments, Frasers Property, Mitsubishi Estate, and Mitsui Fudosan (Asia) has submitted two bids for the Jurong Lake District site, with different concept proposals. The consortium, which holds a 25% stake each, submitted bids for a 99-year leasehold site with a minimum of 1.57 million sq ft for office use and up to 1.79 million sq ft for residential use. Analysts were not surprised by the lack of other contenders, citing the risks of the mega project and high interest rates. The successful bidder will have flexibility to phase out the remaining supply according to market demand.

site_title: Singapore-flagged ship collides with Baltimore bridge, causing it to collapse
summary: A Singapore-flagged container ship collided with the Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore, causing it to collapse into the Patapsco River. The ship, the Dali, lost propulsion and crew notified Maryland officials they had lost control. At least seven people are believed to have been thrown into the water, with two survivors pulled out in serious condition. Rescuers are searching for more victims. The incident has closed the Port of Baltimore, which handles car shipments and exports, potentially disrupting supplies and creating bottlenecks.

site_title: Thai tycoon’s property unit sees earnings jump on tourism boom
summary: Thai tycoon Asset World's hotel properties have seen record-high revenue per available room, driven by a surge in international tourists, particularly Chinese visitors. Average occupancy rates are over 80%, exceeding the normal peak period for Thailand tourism. The company's hotels, including those under Marriott International and Banyan Tree Holdings, are expected to boost first quarter earnings. CEO Wallapa Traisorat attributes the growth to the return of Chinese visitors and sustained room demand in March.

images.alt_text: Concerns over the funding have dogged the controversial digital wallet scheme to transfer 10,000 baht to 50 million Thais to spend within six months, with some experts having called it fiscally irresponsible.

The BOT has maintained that the current rate is at a neutral level, where it is supportive of growth while also helping check inflation.

site_title: UBS to boost Asia-sourced assets to 20% in five to six years: CEO
summary: UBS plans to increase its Asia-sourced assets to 20% of its $5.2 trillion global assets in 5-6 years, CEO Sergio Ermotti said. This would be up from the current 15%. Ermotti attributes the growth to "secular trends" such as demographic change in Asia. The integration of UBS and Credit Suisse, completed last year, is expected to capture growth in various geographic areas.

site_title: Using AI to reduce collisions at sea is a good idea, up to a point
summary: A recent maritime incident in northern European waters highlights the need for improved situational awareness to prevent collisions at sea. The ships involved were not maintaining proper lookout, leading to a potentially disastrous situation. The use of AI-powered automated situational awareness solutions, such as Orca AI, may help mitigate such incidents, but addressing manning levels and fatigue are crucial to ensuring effective implementation. Insurers are incentivizing the adoption of such technologies, recognizing the potential to reduce claims and save money. However, the underlying issue of insufficient staffing and overworked bridge officers must be addressed to fully realize the benefits of AI-powered safety solutions.

images.alt_text: The issue of harassment and bullying should not be looked at in isolation – the culture onboard a ship is also crucial.

site_title: UOB appoints new global markets head and Hong Kong chief
summary: UOB appoints Kelvin Ng as head of group global markets, replacing Leslie Foo, who is retiring. Ng will oversee treasury solutions, financial products, and funding/liquidity. Meanwhile, Adaline Zheng took over as CEO of UOB's Hong Kong branch on March 25, succeeding Christine Ip. Zheng has over two decades of experience in the banking sector, previously holding leadership roles in wholesale banking and UOB China.

site_title: How to manage stock market volatility
summary: Investors can navigate stock market volatility by diversifying their portfolios, maintaining a long-term outlook, and adopting a systematic approach. Diversification across various asset classes, industries, and geographical areas can help mitigate price fluctuations. Long-term investors can disregard short-term market fluctuations by focusing on fundamental business attributes such as earnings, dividend consistency, and growth prospects. Dollar-cost averaging, or investing fixed sums of money at regular intervals, can also help mitigate market volatility. By embracing volatility and focusing on fundamentally sound businesses, investors can accumulate shares in robust companies for the long haul, potentially leading to attractive investment opportunities.

images.alt_text: Green-energy and cannabis stocks briefly became market darlings as the odds of a victory for Joe Biden rose in 2020.
This year, the financial and industrial sectors are up 10.1 per cent and 9.9 per cent, respectively, while energy has gained 10.3 per cent.

site_title: World Gold Council chief aims to make gold as attractive and liquid as swaps
summary: World Gold Council chief David Tait aims to make gold as attractive and liquid as swaps, a key factor deterring investors. The current funding ratio for gold stands at around 85%, with investors seeking higher returns on capital. To increase gold's visibility and usability, Tait plans to make it more accessible and comparable to other liquid assets. This goal aligns with the WGC's objective of making gold a "high-quality liquid asset".

site_title: France’s Atos opens debt restructuring talks after posting record losses
summary: France's Atos opens debt restructuring talks after posting record losses of 3.44 billion euros, citing an unsustainable debt burden of 4.65 billion euros. The group aims to restructure its debt by July, potentially leading to a capital increase and dilution of existing shareholders. A global refinancing agreement could result in new equity, but talks with creditors and bondholders are ongoing, with a court-supervised amicable conciliation procedure set to begin. Atos faces significant challenges, including a loss-making business and the collapse of negotiations with Airbus and Czech billionaire Daniel Kretinsky.

site_title: China, battling low birth rates and high costs, encourages frugal weddings
summary: China is encouraging frugal weddings to combat low birth rates and high costs. The All China Women's Federation has promoted simple weddings, with couples opting for small-scale parties instead of traditional banquets. This shift is expected to develop good customs and help policymakers reverse the fall in new births. In 2023, new marriages in China jumped 12.4% after a decade of declines, and the government has pledged to work towards a "birth-friendly society" and reduce the cost of childbirth, parenting, and education.

site_title: Sri Lanka unexpectedly cuts policy rates by 50 bps to spur growth
summary: Sri Lanka's central bank unexpectedly cut policy rates by 50 basis points to boost growth and steer the economy out of its worst financial crisis in decades. The rate reductions bring the total interest rate cuts to 700 bps since last year, aiming to maintain inflation at 5% over the medium term while enabling the economy to reach its potential. The decision is seen as driven by a desire to support demand conditions and boost growth, despite subdued demand conditions and a lower-than-expected impact of recent tax policy changes.

images.alt_text: The IMF says it had reached a staff-level agreement with Sri Lanka to clear the way for the release of US$337 million, the third instalment out of a four-year US$2.9 billion bailout.

site_title: Malaysia braces for worst as heat wave to run through mid-April
summary: Malaysia is bracing for a severe heat wave expected to last until mid-April, with temperatures reaching up to 40 degrees Celsius. The extreme heat has claimed a life, heightened water shortages, and caused crop losses. The government is deploying drones to monitor peatlands and water levels, and will consider measures to protect construction workers. Climate change is expected to exacerbate the situation, and the government plans to invest in heat-resistant crops and develop a National Adaptation Plan to address water security and public health issues.

site_title: Condo resale volumes post slight improvement in February amid CNY lull: SRX, 99.co
summary: Singapore's condo resale volumes posted a slight improvement in February, rising 1.2% month-on-month to 760 units, driven by the absence of new project launches. Resale prices edged up 0.2% on the month but rose 6.1% year-on-year. Analysts attribute the uptick to buyers shifting to the secondary market, with demand expected to strengthen if interest rates moderate and housing affordability improves.

site_title: Hot stock: Lum Chang shares sink on MD’s involvement in Iswaran probe
summary: Lum Chang shares plummeted over 10% on Tuesday after the company's managing director, David Lum, attended interviews with the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau to assist with charges filed against former transport minister S Iswaran. The Land Transport Authority stated it has not awarded any contract to Lum Chang since 2019. The company's stock price recovered slightly but ended the day down 10.4% at S$0.26.

The latest prosecution brings the total counts that Iswaran is facing to 35.
Lum Chang said that the pandemic has led to higher materials, labour and subcontractor costs.

site_title: MAS’ digital platform ties up with Ant International to simplify sustainability reporting for MSMEs
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) digital platform Gprnt has partnered with Ant International to simplify sustainability reporting for micro, small, and medium enterprises (MSMEs). The collaboration aims to provide a technology-enabled sustainability reporting solution, allowing MSMEs to disclose basic environmental, social, and governance (ESG) metrics. The partnership is part of Programme Sirius, a sustainability initiative that brings together 13 Asia-Pacific fintechs and banks. The solution will help automate ESG reporting processes, enabling banks and companies to make informed sustainability-related decisions.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Areas where SMEs can adopt AI include marketing and customer engagement, says Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling.
Fu’s comments come as countries around the world explore sustainability regulations, some of which could hit SMEs in global supply chains.

site_title: America needs more immigration
summary: The US needs more immigration to sustain economic growth due to declining birth rates. A shrinking population and labor force can impede economic growth by reducing investment in new capital goods and affecting productivity. In contrast, immigration has boosted the US workforce, with the Congressional Budget Office estimating that high immigration rates could add 0.2 percentage points to average annual GDP growth. Experts warn that opposing immigration can lead to Japan-style economic stagnation, and the US should focus on determining its optimal immigration rate, ensuring legality, and fostering integration.

site_title: Gold firms on softer dollar, focus on US inflation data
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $2,172.82 per ounce, boosted by a weaker US dollar. The US dollar index slipped 0.3% against its rivals, making gold less expensive for other currency holders. Investors await US inflation data later this week, which could indicate the timing of the Federal Reserve's first interest rate cut this year.

images.alt_text: Gold prices rose to an all-time high on Thursday after Fed policymakers indicated they still expected to reduce interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point by the end of 2024 despite recent high inflation readings.

site_title: Vietnam boosts coal imports as it promises investors no more power cuts
summary: Vietnam has nearly doubled its coal imports this year, reaching 88% more than the same period in 2023, as the country aims to reassure foreign investors that it will not experience power shortages. The government, which hosts major manufacturing operations, has vowed to guarantee continuous power supplies, but critics say the commitments are vague on measures to achieve this goal. Despite a 61% increase in coal imports last year, Vietnam still expects peak use of coal to be reached this decade, and coal supply is projected to rise further in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: Ousted: Vo Van Thuong was removed as president of Vietnam last week for "violations and wrongdoing".
Vo Van Thuong, 53, stands accused of having violated party rules, according to the Communist Party, which did not clarify what exactly he did wrong.

site_title: Mahathir sons say 98-year-old father focus of Malaysia probe
summary: Malaysia's 98-year-old former premier Mahathir Mohamad is the focus of a probe by the country's anti-graft agency. His sons, Mokhzani and Mirzan, have been ordered to assist in the investigation, which began after offshore business records revealed by a journalism consortium were investigated. The sons claim they are witnesses to the alleged wrongdoing and are working to declare their assets dating back to 1981. The investigation has sparked a political wrangling, with Anwar Ibrahim, Mahathir's former protege and current prime minister, denying any interference in the case.

images.alt_text: The Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission has granted businessman Mokhzani Mahathir an additional 30 days to reveal his assets.

site_title: Chinese cities to close local financial asset exchanges to defuse risks
summary: China's four provinces and cities, Hunan, Liaoning, Xian, and Chongqing, are shutting down their financial asset exchanges to crack down on illegal fundraising and rising risks in local government finances. The exchanges, initially set up for local financial transactions, have been used for banned wealth management products and local government private debt. The move aims to strengthen financial regulation and reduce local government debt. China's central bank and securities regulators have vowed to crack down on such activities, and the closure marks the beginning of the end of such markets, with nearly 30 exchanges currently operating.

site_title: Asia: Markets fluctuate as traders weigh US rate outlook
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Tuesday, with some stocks rising while others fell. Investors are weighing the US Federal Reserve's interest rate outlook ahead of a key inflation reading and the start of the corporate earnings season. Despite previous concerns, the Fed's guidance still suggests three interest rate cuts this year, but mixed signals from officials have created uncertainty. Markets are also reacting to geopolitical concerns, including the latest attack on a Russian crude refinery and Israel's planned assault on Gaza.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Taipei and Wellington stocks rose in early trade on Monday, but Tokyo, Seoul, Singapore, Manila and Jakarta stocks were in the red.

site_title: China seen delivering more RRR cuts this year to boost economy
summary: China is expected to release more cash into the banking system this year to boost its economy, with the People's Bank of China (PBOC) likely to cut the rate on its medium-term lending facility in the second and third quarters. The central bank is projected to deliver two more cuts, totaling 50 basis points, to the reserve requirement ratio (RRR) to stimulate growth. China's economy is expected to expand by 5% this year, with factory output and investment gaining momentum, but consumption remains uncertain due to a property slump and gloomy job outlook.

images.alt_text: The world’s second-largest economy has reported solid data to 2024, with growth in exports, industrial production and investment beating expectations.
China's Vice Commerce Minister Guo Tingting speaks at the China Development Forum in Beijing, China, March 25, 2024.

China’s industry ministry in January issued draft guidelines for standardising the AI industry, with the aim to have national and industry-wide standards in place by 2026.

site_title: Morgan Stanley’s ETFs break US$1 billion with fund conversions
summary: Morgan Stanley has converted two mutual funds into exchange-traded funds (ETFs), bringing its total ETF lineup to 14 funds, with assets exceeding US$1 billion. The conversions follow the firm's expansion into the US$9 trillion ETF market, where it aims to increase its footprint through net new organic launches. The new ETFs, Eaton Vance Total Return Bond ETF and Eaton Vance Short Duration Municipal Income ETF, will charge 32 basis points and 19 basis points, respectively, and are actively managed.

images.alt_text: This would be the first time Morgan Stanley has cut staff at the China fund unit since it bought out its local partner’s 36 per cent stake in the loss-making business for about US$54 million in 2023.

site_title: Australia plans first stress test of financial system in 2025
summary: Australia's financial regulator, APRA, plans to conduct a system-wide stress test in 2025 to gauge the impact of unexpected events that can destabilize the financial system. The test aims to sharpen APRA's response to systemic risks by understanding the transmission mechanisms between industries. The test will be carried out over a year, following the launch in 2025, and will help the regulator better prepare for potential shocks beyond the banking industry, given the significant growth and interconnectedness of the Australian financial system.

site_title: Singapore’s factory output extends growth in February with 3.8% rise, beating estimates of 0.5%
summary: Singapore's factory output rose 3.8% in February, beating economists' estimates of 0.5%, driven by the pharmaceutical segment under the biomedical manufacturing cluster. Output in the electronics sector rebounded with a 2.6% gain, reversing a 4.7% decline in January. The rebound in electronics and biomedical clusters marked the second consecutive month of expansion. Economists predict a year-on-year growth improvement of 2% for 2024, driven by global demand and potential rate cuts in major advanced economies.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Half of the manufacturing clusters in EDB's report record falls in output, including the key electronics cluster and the volatile biomedical cluster.

site_title: Behind the plot to break Nvidia’s grip on AI by targeting software
summary: A coalition of tech companies, including Google, Intel, and Qualcomm, plans to loosen Nvidia's grip on AI by developing an open-source software platform, UXL, that can power multiple AI accelerator chips. The project aims to create an open ecosystem, promoting productivity and choice in hardware. UXL will be developed by a technical steering committee and will be refined by the end of the year. The initiative is part of a broader effort to chip away at Nvidia's dominance in AI, with venture financiers pouring over $4 billion into 93 separate efforts.

images.alt_text: Key Samsung rival SK Hynix is already supplying Nvidia with the latest version of high-bandwidth memory, HBM3E.
The chip maker says the B200 is 30 times speedier at tasks such as serving up answers from chatbots.
Jensen Huang, co-founder and chief executive officer of Nvidia, during the Nvidia GPU Technology Conference (GTC) in San Jose, California, March 19, 2024.

site_title: Canva strikes biggest acquisition yet in chase to take on Adobe
summary: Canva, an Australian startup, has acquired Serif's Affinity suite of creative software for a "several hundred million pounds" in cash and stock, marking its largest acquisition to date. The deal complements Canva's AI-powered tools and bolsters its online workspaces, positioning it as a competitor to Adobe. Canva has grown into a $2.1 billion annualized revenue company with 175 million users, and has acquired several European companies to expand its presence on the continent.

site_title: China off to good start on 2024 goals, says premier
summary: China's economy has reported solid data for 2024, with growth in exports, industrial production, and investment beating expectations. Premier Li Qiang stated that the nation is on track to achieve its full-year development goals. The fundamentals of China's long-term economic growth remain unchanged, according to Li. The property market has a "solid foundation" for healthy development, and efforts to resolve local debt risks are showing results. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, but policymakers may still need to provide additional policy support to reach the ambitious 5% growth target.

images.alt_text: China's Vice Commerce Minister Guo Tingting speaks at the China Development Forum in Beijing, China, March 25, 2024.
The change in operating mode signals officials are stepping up efforts to boost confidence in China’s economy, as a property crisis and weak domestic demand drag on sentiment at home.
China’s industry ministry in January issued draft guidelines for standardising the AI industry, with the aim to have national and industry-wide standards in place by 2026.

site_title: Yen stabilises after finance minister comments, dollar dips
summary: The yen stabilised at 151.39 yen per dollar after finance minister comments, reversing a 1% slide since the Bank of Japan's rate hike last week. The euro and pound rose 0.18% and 0.17% respectively, as verbal intervention by Japanese officials continued. The dollar dipped, with the yen's strength partly attributed to the finance minister's comments.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Banknotes of Japanese yen and U.S. dollar are seen in this illustration picture taken September 23, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo//File Photo
A rise in the yen helped push the US dollar index down 0.16 per cent to 104.26, after a weekly gain of nearly 1 per cent last week.

site_title: CATL to keep expanding in the face of slower EV growth, chairman says
summary: China's leading battery manufacturer, Contemporary Amperex Technology (CATL), plans to expand despite a slowdown in electric vehicle (EV) sales growth. The company, which supplies batteries to major automakers like Tesla, Volkswagen, and Toyota, will focus on developing more advanced technologies, such as sodium-ion batteries and faster charging systems. CATL's president and chairman, Robin Zeng, believes market forces are driving the Chinese EV market, and the company is well-positioned to capitalize on this trend. With its dominant market share and growing sales, CATL is not concerned about overcapacity and is confident in its ability to adapt to changing market conditions.

images.alt_text: The Chinese company’s existing partnership with Ford Motor will be the model for similar cooperation with other US carmakers, the report says.
The partnership will leverage technologies from both companies seeking to lower the so-called “full life cycle” costs of batteries.

The potential R&D expansion in Hong Kong aligns with CATL’s strategy to place greater emphasis on exporting battery technologies, not just batteries, as Chinese electric vehicles (EVs) and batteries face intensifying scrutiny from foreign governments.
CATL says Yichun lithium mine is producing normally as planned after the holiday.

site_title: Moody’s, Fitch upgrade Singlife’s ratings on stable outlook
summary: Moody's and Fitch have upgraded Singlife's ratings to Baa1 and A respectively, citing the strategic importance of Singlife to Sumitomo Life, with a one-notch and two-notch uplift to the Singapore insurer's credit profile. Both rating agencies expect Singlife to maintain its "solid" capitalisation and foresee no significant change to its business and financial strategies following the full ownership by Sumitomo Life. The upgrades reflect the benefits of Sumitomo Life's stronger credit profile and the company's growth prospects in South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
Singapore is a key market within its growth strategy in South-east Asia.
The move comes after regulators in Singapore and Japan green-lit the transaction, which values Singlife at S$4.6 billion.
The acquisition of Singlife by Sumitomo Life is just one of many deals Japanese corporates in South-east Asia, with their banks looking to leverage their low cost of funds.
The transactions, subject to regulatory approvals in Japan and Singapore, are expected to complete in Q1 of 2024.

site_title: Ten years from home World Cup, Saudi sizes up ‘huge challenge’
summary: Saudi Arabia has been appointed as the host of the 2034 FIFA World Cup, with a decade to prepare the country's infrastructure, including 14 new stadiums, hotels, and transport links. The oil-rich kingdom aims to use the event to revamp its conservative image and attract foreign investment, as part of Crown Prince Mohammed Salman's Vision 2030 economic diversification plan. However, the country faces significant challenges, including upgrading its workforce, dealing with extreme heat, and addressing concerns over women's rights and migrant labor.

images.alt_text: Saudi blockade vexes Qatar's US$200b World Cup projects

site_title: Cocoa powers toward US$10,000 as shortages drive relentless rally
summary: Cocoa futures have reached an all-time high of over $10,000 a ton due to a global shortage, driven by poor crops in key West African growers. This puts the world on course for a third consecutive annual supply deficit, raising concerns about the cost of chocolate and impacting consumers. The shortage is attributed to poor returns paid to cocoa farmers, and the looming Easter holiday will see the brunt of the impact. The legacy of these issues is expected to continue affecting the market in the coming years.

images.alt_text: CHICAGO, ILLINOIS - FEBRUARY 02: In this photo illustration, chocolates packaged for Valentine's Day sit on a table on February 02, 2024 in Chicago, Illinois. Cocoa prices have surged over the past several years, recently reaching near record levels and driving up the cost of chocolate. (Photo Illustration by Scott Olson/Getty Images) (Photo by SCOTT OLSON / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Prices of Singapore GCBs, luxury apartments remain stable as sales volume declines
summary: Luxury apartment and Good Class Bungalow (GCB) sales in Singapore declined in 2023 due to rising interest rates, global economic uncertainties, and the ongoing money laundering crackdown. Despite lower transaction volumes, prices for these segments remained stable. In 2023, 23 GCBs were sold, with a total transaction value of S$777.32 million, and average GCB prices grew 23.8% year-over-year to S$2,417 per square foot. Luxury apartment prices rose 2.2% to S$3,417 per square foot, driven by limited premium stock and demand for a safe haven.

images.alt_text: Monies that go into buying and sprucing up houses in GCB Areas can be productively used in many other areas.

One of the trio of bungalows in Nassim Road that changed hands for a total of S$206.7 million this year. The transaction is among at least S$700 million of deals in GCB Areas for which buyers did not lodge caveats.
Su Haijin faces one charge of unlawfully evading arrest and another charge of money laundering.
Just 64 prime non-landed residential properties were sold in the second half of 2023, with prices averaging at S$2,302 per square feet.

site_title: Blackstone-owned Crown Resorts found fit to hold Melbourne casino license
summary: Blackstone-owned Crown Resorts has been allowed to keep its Melbourne casino license, despite breaking anti-money laundering laws. The Victorian Gambling and Casino Control Commission stated it was in the public interest for the license to remain in force, citing the company's transformation plan and compliance with industry regulations. Crown Resorts has submitted over 10,000 pages of documentation and completed 770 remediation activities. The company has agreed to pay a $450 million fine and has committed to ongoing compliance. The decision comes after a two-year period under government supervision.

images.alt_text: Crown Resorts has faced years of regulatory challenges, including a royal commission in Victoria around money-laundering charges.

site_title: Bonuses shrink at global banks in Japan despite booming markets
summary: Japan's booming markets have failed to translate into higher pay for international bankers, with bonuses shrinking by 10% on average in 2023. Despite a surge in corporate deals, including a 55% increase in mergers and acquisitions, compensation remains low compared to other financial hubs like Hong Kong and New York. Top performers in Japan's rates trading niche saw a doubling in compensation, but this is an outlier. The country's efforts to become a global financial hub are hindered by its lower pay, which risks luring talent away from Tokyo.

images.alt_text: Confidence is growing that the world’s fourth-largest economy is exiting decades of price declines and subdued growth.
Inflation in Japan has proven stickier than expected over the last year.

The flash au Jibun Bank Japan manufacturing PMI rose to 48.2 in March from 47.2 in February. While the index has remained below the 50 index level that separates growth from contraction since June, the pace of deterioration was the softest in four months.

site_title: Madonna to end ‘Celebration’ tour with free Copacabana show
summary: Madonna will perform a free, mega-concert on Rio de Janeiro's Copacabana beach in May to close out her "Celebration" tour. The concert, described as her "biggest show yet," is a thank-you to her fans for celebrating over four decades of her music. The 65-year-old singer last performed in Brazil in 2012, and the event marks a rare free performance for her fans.

images.alt_text: Madonna is on the road for the first time since 2020 with her global Celebration Tour, a stage spectacle touching on more than 40 of her hits across four decades.

Madonna will have 24 onstage performers, four of her children will also be on stage, and she will be  transported high up around the arena “in an illuminated portal frame that acts as a time machine”.

site_title: Citigroup to end sweeping overhaul this week after 5,000 layoffs
summary: Citigroup is completing its restructuring overhaul after 5,000 layoffs, aiming to trim its global workforce of 239,000 by 20,000 over the next two years. The bank's CEO, Jane Fraser, stated that the changes are intended to improve competitiveness. The latest reshuffle finalizes Citi's new structure, marking the end of the sweeping overhaul.

images.alt_text: At Citigroup, the cuts come as chief executive officer Jane Fraser is in the middle of initiating a massive restructuring of the banking behemoth
The company has employed 239,000 employees in 90 countries as at December 2023.
Citi is working to address problems laid out by regulators in enforcement actions, called consent orders, that date back to October 2020.

A pedestrian walks past a Citibank branch in the ground floor of Citigroup Inc. headquarters in New York, U.S., on Tuesday, March 8, 2011. Citigroup, the third-largest U.S. lender by assets, now earns more than half of its profit from emerging markets, Chief Executive Officer Vikram Pandit said last month. Photographer: Jin Lee/Bloomberg

site_title: Sabana Reit trustee’s first meeting with internalisation committee fails; unitholders requisition EGM
summary: Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit) failed to hold its first meeting with the internalisation committee due to disagreements over proposed amendments to the trust deed and the Reit's internalisation process. Unitholders, including activist investor Quarz Capital, have requisitioned an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to consider proposed amendments. The trustee, HSBC Institutional Trust Services, urged unitholders to respect the ongoing court process and allow the issues to be "appropriately heard by the court and decided in an orderly manner." A date for the EGM has yet to be fixed.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
While having more internally-managed listed-Reits can be welcomed, Sabana Reit should explore exit options instead of pursuing internalisation of its management.
New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio.
Sabana Reit's manager said it is convening the EGM in accordance with its duty to do so under the trust deed.
New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio.
New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio.
A group of unitholders led by activist investor Quarz are looking to pass 12 resolutions at the EGM.

site_title: Hong Kong February home prices ease for the 10th month, down 1.7%
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices fell 1.7% in February, marking the 10th consecutive month of decline, the lowest since September 2016. Despite the government's recent removal of curbs on the property market, prices are expected to remain suppressed due to higher mortgage rates, talent outflow, and weak market outlook. Mainland Chinese buyers, accounting for up to a third of new sales, are driving demand, with luxury properties seeing a significant rebound. Transaction volumes are expected to recover moderately this year, but prices are likely to remain low.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A general view of the construction site for housing buildings in Hong Kong, China October 24, 2023. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo
Hong Kong developers have been selling new homes at low prices to clear an abundant supply.
The number of licensed finance professionals dropped by more than 600 since the end of 2021.
Nearly 300 people have been arrested under the 2020 law so far.

site_title: Japan’s corporate service inflation steady in February
summary: Japan's annual business-to-business service inflation held steady at 2.1% in February, indicating companies are passing on rising labor costs. This data supports the Bank of Japan's view that service prices will drive inflation, replacing cost-push inflation. The BOJ's decision to end eight years of negative interest rates marks a shift away from its unorthodox policy, as the central bank seeks to sustain inflation around its 2% target.

site_title: UK homes have worst value for money in developed world: study
summary: A new study by the Resolution Foundation has found that UK homes offer the poorest value for money among developed economies, with less floor space per person than many other countries, including France, Germany, Japan, the US, and Taiwan. UK homes are also older, less energy-efficient, and further from jobs than in many other European nations.
