The study's findings come as the UK faces a general election in the second half of 2024, with the housing crisis expected to be a major topic of debate.

images.alt_text: The cost of UK housing and rentals has been sent surging by the lack of supply along with an upswing in demand, particularly in the post-pandemic period.
FILE PHOTO: Painted rows of houses are seen in Bristol, Britain, August 11, 2023. REUTERS/Toby Melville/File Photo
Homeowners in the UK generally do not pay capital gains on their main residence, so the changes will mainly affect private landlords and second homeowners.

site_title: Donald Trump’s net worth hits US$6.5 billion, making him one of world’s 500 richest people
summary: Donald Trump's net worth has surged to $6.5 billion, making him one of the world's 500 richest people, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. The former president's wealth increased by over $4 billion after a New York state appeals court reduced the bond amount in a fraud lawsuit to $175 million. Trump's social media company, Trump Media & Technology Group, also completed a merger with Digital World Acquisition Corp, adding billions to his net worth.

images.alt_text: The decision eases an acute cash crunch brought on by Trump’s mounting legal expenses.
The deal values Trump’s majority stake in the company that holds his app Truth Social at about US$3.6 billion.

US President Joe Biden listens to an opening speaker during a campaign event at El Portal restaurant in Phoenix, Arizona, March 19, 2024. Biden holds a widening lead over Donald Trump in the fundraising stakes, while Trump is burning through legal fees as he battles multiple criminal and civil cases.

site_title: South Korea consumer sentiment drops on worries about food inflation
summary: South Korea's consumer sentiment dropped to 100.7 in March, the largest monthly decline since October, due to growing worries about higher agricultural prices. Consumer inflation expectations rose to 3.2% for the next 12 months, with 63.4% of respondents citing agricultural prices as a major driver of inflation. This follows a three-month easing in consumer inflation in February. The decline in consumer sentiment comes ahead of South Korea's legislative election.

site_title: Has fashion cancelled cancelling?
summary: A new documentary "JOHN Galliano, High & Low" explores the career and re-emergence of fashion designer John Galliano, who was fired from Dior after a drunken antisemitic rant in 2011. The film marks a shift away from the era of outrage in fashion, with Galliano's return to the industry suggesting a trend of forgiveness. Industry expert Achim Berg notes that it appears everyone is allowed back in, reflecting a change in the fashion world's approach to transgressions and atonement. The documentary serves as a coda to Galliano's period of atonement and re-emergence.

site_title: Australia bank CEOs call for a fix to housing shortage
summary: Australia's housing shortage is driving up prices but also locking out first-time homeowners and migrants needed to fill skills shortages. The CEOs of Australia's three largest banks, Commonwealth Bank, National Australia Bank, and Westpac, have called for local governments to speed up planning approvals to address the issue. A 2023 government report warned of a long-term drop in younger people buying homes, which could lead to more retirees in weaker financial positions. The shortage may also exacerbate labor shortages and impact the country's economic growth.

images.alt_text: Most economists now believe the RBA is done hiking – and that the next move will see rates move down.
The aim is to gauge the impact of unexpected events that can destabilise the financial system.

site_title: Dell reduces workforce as part of broader cost cuts
summary: Dell Technologies reduced its workforce by nearly 6,000 employees, bringing the total to around 120,000, as part of a broader cost-cutting initiative. The layoffs follow sluggish demand for personal computers, resulting in an 11% drop in revenue in the fourth quarter. Despite this, Dell expects net revenue in its client solutions group to grow for the entire year, with demand and pricing expected to improve in FY 2025. The company also announced a $150 million hardware deal with AI startup Imbue.

images.alt_text: Dell has attracted investor interest over the last year due to a spike in demand for high-powered servers needed to run AI workloads.

The Nokia Oyj headquarters in Espoo, Finland, on Thursday, Oct. 19, 2023. Nokia Oyj plans to cut as many as 14,000 jobs, or 16% of its workforce, as a dearth of investment in fifth-generation mobile infrastructure forces it to take cost-cutting measures. Photographer: Roni Rekomaa/Bloomberg
Dell’s shares soar nearly 90 per cent to a record through the end of November, amid expectations of a boost from artificial intelligence demand.
Dell is supplying Imbue with servers to enable the startup to process the vast amount of data needed to develop its AI systems and build models with advanced reasoning capabilities.

site_title: CATL in talks with Tesla, global automakers for US licensing: report
summary: Chinese battery maker CATL is in talks with Tesla and other US automakers to license its battery technology in the US instead of building its own plant. The partnership, modeled after CATL's existing deal with Ford Motor, would allow Tesla to access low-cost lithium-iron batteries. The scale of cooperation and details are still being discussed, with CATL chairman Robin Zeng citing cash flow as a factor. The move comes as the US government tightens regulations on Chinese battery companies to prevent them from winning EV tax credits.

images.alt_text: The partnership will leverage technologies from both companies seeking to lower the so-called “full life cycle” costs of batteries.

The potential R&D expansion in Hong Kong aligns with CATL’s strategy to place greater emphasis on exporting battery technologies, not just batteries, as Chinese electric vehicles (EVs) and batteries face intensifying scrutiny from foreign governments.
CATL says Yichun lithium mine is producing normally as planned after the holiday.

site_title: Europe: Stocks eke out gains at start of holiday-shortened week
summary: European stocks rose 0.1% on Monday, driven by a 0.9% gain in energy stocks, despite media companies being among the top losers. The Stoxx 600 index reached record high levels, boosted by recent dovish views from major central banks, including the Federal Reserve's 75 basis point interest rate cut projection by year-end. The Bank of England also signaled potential rate cuts for the economy.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index ends flat but notched its ninth straight weekly gain after logging another intraday all-time high earlier in the day.

site_title: Lens on Singapore: Not everyone is thriving in Singapore (Ep 7)
summary: Singapore faces a growing issue of low-income families struggling to make ends meet amidst rising living costs. Despite the country's reputation for success, some citizens are living in poverty. DPM Lawrence Wong's Reimagined Singapore Dream aims to address this issue, but the question remains whether it will be effective. The government's efforts to support low-income families are crucial, but the average Singaporean should care about the issue to bring about meaningful change. The rising cost of living poses a significant challenge to Singapore's social cohesion and economic stability.

images.alt_text: Currently, higher pre-school subsidies are given to children with working mothers. They will be extended to all children from lower-income families, including those with non-working mothers.

The seven key policy shifts outlined in the Forward Singapore report provide a roadmap for the government and "all of Singapore" to chart their way forward in an environment that will be more uncertain, said Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong (fourth from left) during a press conference fronted by the fourth-generation leadership.
Why does it still not feel alright to talk about mental health issues at work?

site_title: US new home sales unexpectedly fall in February
summary: US new home sales unexpectedly fell 0.3% in February to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 662,000 units, defying 525 basis points of interest rate hikes since March 2022. The sales pace for January was revised higher to 664,000 units. Economists had forecast a rise to 675,000 units. Despite the drop, new home sales have advanced 5.9% on a year-on-year basis, and builders are increasing construction and offering incentives to make housing more affordable.

site_title: MAS expected to stand pat in April review despite surprise bump in February’s core inflation
summary: Singapore's core inflation rose 3.6% in February, higher than the 3.1% in January and above the 3.4% median forecast. Economists expect the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to maintain its policy parameters unchanged in April, citing seasonal effects from Chinese New Year celebrations and expected labor market tightness. Despite this, some economists believe MAS may ease monetary policy settings in October, while others expect the central bank to keep policy unchanged throughout 2024, citing smoldering inflation pressures and a desire to balance economic growth risks.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
MAS and MTI said February's higher core prices was driven by higher services and food inflation, partly reflecting seasonal effects associated with Chinese New Year.

Simulations by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) have showed that even if the nominal exchange rate had not been raised, the Singapore dollar would still have appreciated similarly in real terms, chief economist Edward Robinson said.
xxx

site_title: Singapore stocks open Tuesday largely flat after inflation surprise, STI up 0.04%
summary: Singapore stocks opened flat on Tuesday, March 26, after inflation data exceeded expectations, with headline inflation rising 3.4% year-over-year. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.04% to 3,199.44, despite 57 losers outnumbering 54 gainers. Banking stocks were mixed, with DBS and OCBC advancing, while UOB declined. Global markets also saw dips, with the Nasdaq Composite and S&P 500 falling 0.3% and the Dow Jones shedding 0.4%.

images.alt_text: Generics of SGX [Raffles Place]

site_title: Trouble looms for developers who post tepid sales take-up at home launches
summary: Singapore's private housing market is experiencing a moderation in sales, with some developers struggling to sell out units within prescribed timelines. Recent sales data shows that developers such as GuocoLand and Hong Leong Holdings achieved high sales take-up rates, while others, like TID, sold only 19% of their units at launch. This trend may lead to risks for developers, including lower profit margins, reduced returns, and potential clawback of Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) remission. The market is expected to remain stable, with home prices remaining relatively unchanged, and developers should focus on offering the right product to thrive.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Lentor Mansion’s launch was the first under the Urban Redevelopment Authority’s new guidelines, where units sold are based on liveable space.
Of the 50 Lentoria units sold during its launch weekend, over 70 per cent were for two- and three-bedroom units, said TID.

site_title: Australia’s consumer sentiment drops as rate-cut prospects dim
summary: Australia's consumer confidence fell 1.8% to 84.4 points in March, with pessimists outweighing optimists, as households remain concerned about finances and the economy. The decline follows a Westpac survey showing sentiment was stronger before the Reserve Bank of Australia's decision to keep interest rates at a 12-year high of 4.35%. Most economists now believe the RBA is done hiking and expect rates to move down, with the next meeting on May 6-7 likely to leave borrowing costs unchanged.

images.alt_text: The aim is to gauge the impact of unexpected events that can destabilise the financial system.
The Reserve Bank of Australia sees inflation edging down to 3.3 per cent by June 2024.
The RBA has estimated less than 1 per cent of all housing loans are 90 or more days in arrears and less than 2 per cent of high-leveraged borrowers are in arrears.
Australia is one of the world's largest exporters of coal and gas, and the largest producer of iron ore – a mineral that is essential for making steel.

site_title: Adam Neumann bids over US$500 million to buy back WeWork: source
summary: Adam Neumann has submitted a bid of over US$500 million to buy back WeWork, the office-sharing company he co-founded, following its bankruptcy filing in November. WeWork remains focused on restructuring efforts to emerge as a financially strong and profitable company in the second quarter. Neumann's bid comes after his ouster in 2019 and despite the company scrapping its initial public offering (IPO) due to concerns over valuation and corporate governance. The company's board reviews expressions of interest, including Neumann's, to ensure the best long-term interests of the company.

images.alt_text: The beleaguered company needs the funds mainly to pay rent on office spaces used by its customers.
Under Neumann, WeWork grew to be the most valuable US startup worth US$47 billion.
WeWork expanded at breakneck speed but racked up losses on its long-term lease obligations as more people began working from home during the pandemic and demand for office space plunged.
The deal with 1440 Broadway allows WeWork to maintain a foothold in a New York City building that’s in the heart of Times Square.

site_title: Wall Street bears say stock rally will end if profits underwhelm
summary: Wall Street's Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan strategists warn that the current stock rally is at risk of stalling if company earnings fail to meet expectations. Despite the S&P 500 reaching new highs, analysts are concerned that profit growth is not keeping pace with share prices. Consensus earnings estimates have been revised lower, and the market's reliance on a few "Magnificent Seven" tech companies is a concern. The strategists predict a potential 20% drop in the S&P 500 by year-end if earnings underwhelm.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average falls 7.31 points, or 0.02 per cent, at the open to 39,774.06.
This year, the financial and industrial sectors are up 10.1 per cent and 9.9 per cent, respectively, while energy has gained 10.3 per cent.

site_title: Oil settles higher as Russia orders output cuts, geopolitical tensions persist
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, with Brent crude futures settling $1.32 higher or 1.55% at $86.75 a barrel, and US crude futures rising $1.32 or 1.64% to $81.95. The increase was driven by Russia's order to cut oil output to 9 million barrels per day by the end of June, as well as attacks on energy infrastructure in Russia and Ukraine. Geopolitical tensions in eastern Europe and the Middle East have contributed to the rise, with some analysts warning of a potential price shock.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures had climbed 24 cents, or 0.3 per cent, to US$85.67 a barrel at 0029 GMT on Monday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sabana Reit, CSE Global, Multi-Chem, OKP
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Sabana Reit's trustee meeting with the internalisation committee was postponed due to lack of attendance, with proposed amendments and a court application discussed. CSE Global raised S$24 million from a share placement to fund strategic acquisitions. Multi-Chem's shares resumed trading after a trading halt, following an auditors' review of a S$1.6 million payment. OKP secured a S$17.7 million contract from PUB for improving roadside drains, boosting its net construction order book to a record high. Trading halted for Hatten Land pending an announcement. The companies' shares closed flat or unchanged on Monday.

site_title: US: Stocks pull back as tech giants hit by EU probe
summary: US stocks pulled back on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.4% to 39,313.64, amid signs of market fatigue and stepped-up regulatory scrutiny in Europe. Tech heavyweights faced increased scrutiny, and analysts attributed the retreat to the relatively light economic news schedule. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq also edged to fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions and tariff uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average falls 65.36 points, or 0.17 per cent, at the open, to 39,410.54.

site_title: Trump wins pause of US$454 million civil fraud ruling, avoiding asset seizures
summary: A US mid-level state appellate court granted Donald Trump's request to pause a $454 million civil fraud judgment, blocking asset seizures until a $175 million bond is posted within 10 days. The decision eases Trump's cash crunch due to mounting legal expenses, including four upcoming criminal trials. Trump was found liable for fraudulently inflating his net worth by billions of dollars to secure better loan and insurance terms in a New York civil case.

images.alt_text: The action could potentially provide Trump some US$3 billion, as he faces a US$454 million court payment for his New York fraud case
The deal values Trump’s majority stake in the company that holds his app Truth Social at about US$3.6 billion.

US President Joe Biden listens to an opening speaker during a campaign event at El Portal restaurant in Phoenix, Arizona, March 19, 2024. Biden holds a widening lead over Donald Trump in the fundraising stakes, while Trump is burning through legal fees as he battles multiple criminal and civil cases.
Despite Donald Trump’s US$2.6 billion net worth, his lawyers say that it’s been impossible so far to come up with the US$454 million bond, due on Monday.

site_title: Goldman Sachs mulls 3.5 billion euro sale of B&B Hotels chain
summary: Goldman Sachs is exploring the sale of its B&B Hotels chain, valued at approximately 3.5 billion euros (S$5.1 billion). The European budget hotel chain, which opened its first hotel in France in 1990, has drawn interest from hospitality groups and private equity bidders. Goldman Sachs acquired B&B in 2019 and has since added over 170 new hotels. The sale is part of the company's expansion plans, and deliberations are in the early stages. The potential sale aims to capitalize on the growing demand for hospitality investments following the pandemic.

images.alt_text: The Goldman Sachs & Co. logo is displayed at the company's booth on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., on Friday, July 19, 2013. U.S. stocks fell after benchmark equities gauges rose to records yesterday, after disappointing earnings from Google Inc. and Microsoft Corp. overshadowed better-than-forecast results from General Electric Co. Photographer: Scott Eells/Bloomberg

site_title: UN Security Council demands immediate Gaza ceasefire after US abstains
summary: The UN Security Council adopted a resolution demanding an immediate ceasefire between Israel and Hamas militants in Gaza, with 14 council members voting in favor and the US abstaining. The resolution also calls for the release of all hostages and the lifting of barriers to humanitarian aid. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu cancelled a visit to Washington due to the US abstention, calling it a "clear retreat" from its previous position. The resolution's passage comes amid growing global pressure for a truce in the war, which has killed over 32,000 people and is expected to lead to famine in Gaza by May.

images.alt_text: Israeli officials are expected to meet with their US counterparts next week in Washington to hash out opposing opinions on plans to invade Rafah.
Before the vote, the US ambassador says it would be a "historic mistake" for the council not to adopt the resolution.

A close confidant of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Israeli Strategic Affairs Minister Ron Dermer is headed to Washington early next week to listen to concerns from the Biden administration that such an invasion would cause many more civilian casualties at a time when famine and disease are spreading in Gaza.
US top diplomat Antony Blinken says any immediate truce must be linked to the release of hostages from the Oct 7 attack by Hamas.

A truck containing humanitarian aid from the World Food Organization at a location given as northern Gaza Strip, March 12, 2024. Oxfam said that “unjustifiably inefficient” inspection rules were causing aid trucks trying to get into Gaza to be stuck in queues for 20 days on average.

site_title: Unity is Europe’s greatest asset
summary: The European Union faces persistent economic and geopolitical crises, necessitating a unified approach. Ahead of June's European parliament elections, the EPP's decision to nominate Ursula von der Leyen for a second term could have profound implications for Europe. The EU has steered through challenges such as the Covid-19 pandemic, Russia's invasion of Ukraine, and energy crisis, highlighting the importance of unity and preserving the current coalition. The bloc must uphold the intergenerational contract and foundational values, countering simplistic, short-term fixes from extremists and populists.

images.alt_text: A person stands next to a banner which reads as "European Elections", displayed on the building of the European Parliament in Brussels, on February 21, 2024, ahead of the European elections scheduled between June 6 and June 9, 2024. (Photo by Kenzo TRIBOUILLARD / AFP)

site_title: Embracing insurance commissions – with caveats
summary: Financial advisory firm Providend has launched a new sister company, Havend, which will sell insurance plans and retain product commissions. Despite this, Providend claims to mitigate conflicts of interest with measures such as salaried staff, transparent commission payments, and a distinctive insurance philosophy that prioritizes protection over savings and investment. Havend also offers a money-back guarantee, refunding clients if they believe they were over-sold a policy within 365 days. The company aims to serve 11,000 lives by 2030 and has six advisers on board, with plans to grow to 50-60 by then.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua
MoneyOwl is winding down operations, as low revenues and high operating costs made financial viability a stiff challenge.

“At the end of the day, we are part of a social enterprise group, and it remains vital that we continue to steward resources wisely to better serve the broader interest of the Singapore community,” said Chuin Ting Weber, chief executive and chief investment officer of MoneyOwl.
Temasek Trust's proposed acquisition of MoneyOwl from NTUC Enterprise gives it a new lease of life and potential to drive more impact.

site_title: Brazil’s big G20 agenda for 2024
summary: Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva is promoting an ambitious G20 agenda for 2024, aiming to reform key multilateral bodies such as the UN, World Trade Organisation, and IMF. Lula argues that the changing global economic power balance and numerous conflicts necessitate a shift in the multilateral order. However, forging a consensus around specific proposals is challenging, with many countries agreeing on the need for change but differing on specifics. The Brazilian G20 year is in its fourth month, with Lula seeking to stamp his mark as a key leader of the Global South.

images.alt_text: Gabriel Zucman, director at the EU Tax Observatory, speaks during the G20 finance ministers and central bank governors meeting in Sao Paulo, Brazil, Feb 29, 2024.

Shipping containers at the Port of Taicang in Taicang, Jiangsu Province, China, on Thursday, Aug. 24, 2023. China’s economy was meant to drive a third of global economic growth this year, so its dramatic slowdown in recent months is sounding alarm bells across the world. Source: Bloomberg

epa11147146 Managing Director of International Monetary Fund (IMF) Kristalina Georgieva attends a session at the World Governments Summit in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, 12 February 2024. The World Governments Summit Organization is an international, impartial, nonprofit group whose goal is to influence how governments operate in the future. The summit is held in Dubai between 12-14 February.  EPA-EFE/STRINGER
Leaders of the G20 nations attend the second working session of the G20 Leaders' Summit at Bharat Mandapam in New Delhi on September 9, 2023. (Photo by Ludovic MARIN / POOL / AFP)

site_title: Swift planning launch of new central bank digital currency platform in 12-24 months
summary: Swift, a global bank messaging network, plans to launch a new platform connecting central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) to the existing finance system within the next 12-24 months. The platform aims to enable seamless use of different countries' CBDCs, even if built on different technologies, reducing payment system fragmentation risks. The move is significant, given Swift's key role in global banking and its existing network connecting over 11,500 banks and funds across 200 countries. The platform is expected to boost Swift's dominance in the bank-to-bank plumbing network and facilitate the use of digital assets.

images.alt_text: The West blocked access to Swift for several Russian banks, including Sberbank and VTB, soon after Moscow invaded Ukraine in February last year to target Russian trade.
China is well advanced with real-life trials of an e-yuan.
As a global financial artery, Swift delivers secure messages among 11,000 companies in over 200 countries and territories, directing trillions of dollars in transactions.
The remittances market, where it costs US$13 on average to send US$200 across borders, is ripe for disruption, according to Ritesh Shukla.

site_title: Ex-Swiber CEO fined S$100,000 over untrue announcement of project
summary: Former Swiber CEO Francis Wong Chin Sing was fined S$100,000 for making a false statement under the Securities & Futures Act. In 2014, Swiber announced a US$710 million award, but investigations revealed the company's wholly owned subsidiary had only signed a letter of intent for up to US$2 million. Wong admitted to the offence and was also disqualified from holding director roles for five years. The fine and disqualification follow a series of charges brought against Swiber's directors for their roles in releasing the false statement, which overstated the company's business prospects and induced investor purchases.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Swiber does not have the means to make an exit offer to its shareholders, say the liquidators.

site_title: US dollar dips as Japan and China fortify their currencies
summary: The US dollar slipped 0.16% to 104.26, its lowest level since last week, amid a rise in the Japanese yen and a government-driven rally in China's yuan. Japan's top currency diplomat dismissed the yen's weakness as not reflecting fundamentals, while Chinese state-owned banks were seen selling US dollars for yuan. The US dollar index fell after a weekly gain of nearly 1%, while European currencies regained some ground after investors bought the US dollar on concerns about rate easing.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) is seen before a news conference in Bern, Switzerland December 14, 2023. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo
The US dollar rises against all G10 currencies except the yen, as the relatively strong US economy and high interest rates draw investment flows.

site_title: US sanctions Chinese cyberespionage firm, saying it hacked US energy industry
summary: The US Treasury Department imposed sanctions on Wuhan Xiaoruizhi Science and Technology, a Chinese firm allegedly used as a cover for cyber operations targeting US critical infrastructure. The sanctions also target two Chinese nationals. The US claims Wuhan Xiaoruizhi Science and Technology is a Ministry of State Security front company, accused of serving as a cover for multiple malicious cyber operations. The move is part of a whole-of-government effort to disrupt malicious cyber actors and protect US citizens and critical infrastructure.

images.alt_text: The rules have been changed to facilitate data flows and cut business costs, the Cyberspace Administration of China says.
In the age of cyberwarfare, passive defence is a losing game. Preparedness, fuelled by self-knowledge and a keen understanding of adversaries, is a better strategy.
Lockbit and its affiliates have hacked some of the world’s largest organisations like Boeing and ICBC in recent months.

site_title: A little turbulence in a Vietnamese teacup? Or a Haiphong hurricane?
summary: Vietnam's President Vo Van Thuong was removed from office last week due to "violations and wrongdoing", marking the second president to resign in two years. Thuong's dismissal comes amid a widening anti-corruption campaign and follows a similar fate as his predecessor Nguyen Xuan Phuc. The move may signal escalating political instability, but could also be a step towards reforming the country's troubled economic system. Thuong's removal sets a precedent for the ruling Communist Party, which holds the most powerful post in the country.

images.alt_text: Vo Van Thuong, 53, stands accused of having violated party rules, according to the Communist Party, which did not clarify what exactly he did wrong.

Vietnam government says President Vo Van Thuong (above) violated party rules, adding that those “shortcomings had negatively impacted public opinion, affecting the reputation of the Party, State and him personally.”
Phuc, a former prime minister, has held the largely ceremonial position for less than two years.

site_title: China says relations with Philippines at ‘crossroads’ amid maritime incidents
summary: China has warned the Philippines to behave cautiously and seek dialogue amid escalating tensions over maritime claims in the South China Sea. The warning came after China's coast guard allegedly used a water cannon to damage a Philippine supply vessel, and China accused the Philippines of violating a promise to tow away a warship at the Second Thomas Shoal. The dispute has deepened tensions between the two countries, with the US and other nations condemning China's actions. China claims nearly the entire South China Sea, while the Philippines asserts its sovereignty over the area.

images.alt_text: Chinese Coast Guard vessels fire water cannons towards a Philippine resupply vessel Unaizah on its way to a resupply mission at Second Thomas Shoal in the South China Sea, March 5, 2024.
The Red Sea supply chain disruptions could cut as much as 0.5 percentage points off Asia’s economic growth this year, and add up to 0.4 percentage points to the inflation rate.

site_title: Luxury EV maker Lucid to raise US$1 billion from Saudi’s PIF affiliate
summary: Lucid, a luxury electric vehicle maker, is raising US$1 billion in capital from an affiliate of Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF). The investment, valued at nearly 20% of Lucid's shares, will be used for corporate purposes and capital expenditure. This deal underscores Lucid's advantage in the struggling EV startup market and is part of Saudi Arabia's strategy to diversify its economy. The Saudi government, which holds a 60% stake in Lucid, has invested billions in the company's success.

images.alt_text: BYD says that its premium Denza brand, which is 10 per cent owned by Mercedes, will launch in Europe in the fourth quarter.
Rivian tanked 25 per cent to a record low after it forecast flat growth in annual production, also hurt by a shutdown of its assembly line for upgrades.
The Public Investment Fund (PIF) could buy into the Human Horizons at a US$3 billion valuation.

site_title: Fed’s Goolsbee says he sees three rate cuts this year
summary: US Federal Reserve Bank president Austan Goolsbee predicted three rate cuts for this year, aligning with the median estimate of policymakers. Goolsbee attributed higher-than-expected price increase readings for January and February to housing inflation, indicating the central bank is still working to return to its target. Despite this, Goolsbee does not believe the story has fundamentally changed, suggesting the economy is not yet back on track.

site_title: Ericsson to lay off 1,200 staff in Sweden as 5G spending slows
summary: Ericsson plans to lay off approximately 1,200 employees in Sweden as part of cost-cutting measures amid slowing 5G spending. The move follows thousands of staff cuts last year and is expected to continue into 2025 due to a challenging mobile infrastructure market. The company declined to provide a specific cash savings figure, citing ongoing negotiations with unions. Shares in Ericsson fell 0.75% after the announcement. Analysts predict further layoffs and challenges in the 5G market, with some describing it as a "slow-burner" rather than a runaway success.

images.alt_text: A committee at the European parliament tasked with preparing lawmakers’ position backs the proposals on Wednesday (Jan 24).

The Ericsson AB stand on the opening day of the Mobile World Congress at the Fira de Barcelona venue in Barcelona, Spain, on Monday, Feb. 27, 2023. The annual flagship mobile industry and technology event runs from Feb. 27 to March 2. Photographer: Angel Garcia/Bloomberg
Ericsson says it expects current quarter results to be similar to the third quarter.

site_title: Chinese developer Shimao lays out restructuring proposal
summary: Chinese developer Shimao Group has proposed a restructuring plan to repay its $11.7 billion offshore debt, following discontent among creditors over earlier terms. The proposal offers four options, including short-term and long-term notes, zero-coupon mandatory convertible bonds, and a combination of them. The plan aims to address the debt default that occurred after Shimao missed a $1 billion offshore bond payment in July 2022. The proposal comes after 18 months of negotiations and is part of a series of restructuring efforts by Chinese property firms to revamp their debt.

images.alt_text: Investors have become more cautious about acquisitions after the country’s real estate sector failed to sustain a recovery.

site_title: Multi-Chem auditors question S$1.6 million payment for CapitaLand vouchers
summary: Auditors of Multi-Chem, a mainboard-listed cybersecurity distributor, have questioned a S$1.6 million payment for CapitaLand vouchers used for marketing and promotional purposes. The payment was made to two employees' personal bank accounts, and the auditors are seeking supporting evidence to verify the use of the funds. This review may impact Multi-Chem's financial statements for 2023. The company's Audit and Risk Committee will review any future marketing and promotional payments for vendor services.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
The contract, secured by OKP's wholly owned subsidiary Eng Lam Contractors, is for the improvement of old roadside drains at the Sunrise and Cactus Estates in Cheng San.

site_title: OKP unit gets S$17.7 million contract from PUB
summary: OKP Holdings, a Singapore-based infrastructure and civil engineering company, has secured a S$17.7 million contract from PUB to improve old roadside drains at the Sunrise and Cactus Estates in Cheng San. The 30-month contract began on March 22, 2024, and is expected to be completed by September 21, 2026. This marks OKP's fourth consecutive contract win in just three months, boosting its net construction order book to a record high of S$660.4 million.

images.alt_text: People walk along an uneven and damaged pavement along Jalan Bukit Merah on April 24, 2023.
Claudia Chong

site_title: Back in black
summary: Tech majors are doubling down on Buy Now, Pay Later (BNPL) services despite the decline of pure-play providers. GoTo and Shopee are expanding their offerings to attract younger customers, while BNPL is effective when part of a larger ecosystem. Meanwhile, the Bitcoin rally continues due to institutional demand, with the price gaining nearly 150% in the last year, and venture capitalists are racing back into crypto.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
AI’s position at the very tip of cutting edge tech means that the scope of currently available talent here is too narrow for what the industry seeks, writes Garage correspondent Benjamin Cher.
Most things point to Sea having righted its ship, writes Garage correspondent Claudia Chong.
One of the early movers in South-east Asia’s e-commerce space, Qoo10 got its start a good 14 years ago as Gmarket.
The financial viability of digital wealth platforms has been a sticky issue, writes BT Garage correspondent Claudia Chong.
Insects as a source of alternative proteins aren’t for everyone, as some startups in South-east Asia have found out over the years, writes Garage correspondent Claudia Chong.

site_title: US: Wall St slips at open, Boeing rally caps losses on Dow
summary: US stocks fell at the open on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 65.36 points, or 0.17%, to 39,410.54. The decline was attributed to investors' anticipation of US Federal Reserve officials' commentary and key inflation data. Boeing, however, rose after its CEO announced his departure, limiting losses on the Dow. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened lower, with the S&P 500 down 14.66 points, or 0.3%, and the Nasdaq down 93.52 points, or 0.6%.

site_title: What makes Musk tick? It’s time to care
summary: Elon Musk's recent interview with Don Lemon sparked controversy after Musk grew increasingly defensive and hostile, lashing out at Lemon's questions about moderation on his platform X. The exchange, which included Musk's assertion that "we are all descended from slaves," culminated in Musk cancelling a partnership deal with Lemon's talk show and calling Lemon profanity on X. Critics argue that Musk's extreme capitalism has led to demagoguery, as he has given oxygen to conspiracy theories and normalised ill-founded statements, posing threats to humanity.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk, who runs SpaceX and Tesla, and owns social media platform X, denied abusing ketamine and said he used “a small amount once every other week or something like that."
In December, xAI rolled out its ChatGPT competitor Grok for Premium+ subscribers of social media platform X, aiming to create what Musk has said would be a “maximum truth-seeking AI”.

site_title: Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun to step down in management shakeup amid safety crisis
summary: Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun will step down by year-end amid the company's sprawling safety crisis, following a January mid-air panel blowout on a 737 MAX plane. Board chair Larry Kellner and head of commercial planes business Stan Deal are also leaving. The shakeup comes after a series of safety crises that have shaken industry confidence and led to a quarter of Boeing's value loss since the incident. A new chair, Steve Mollenkopf, and a search for the next CEO have begun, with Spirit AeroSystems CEO Patrick Shanahan being considered a possible successor.

images.alt_text: Boeing is seeking a preliminary injunction requiring Virgin Galactic to destroy, or at least sequester, all copies of the documents as well as any work derived from the proprietary information.
Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun (above) supports the meetings with major airline chiefs but will not attend, a company official said.
Korean Air picks 27 A350-1000 planes and six A350-900 jets.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 25)
summary: Singapore's inflation rose more than expected in February, with headline inflation at 3.4% and core inflation at 3.6%, driven by higher services and food prices. The share of newly created job vacancies in Singapore reached a six-year high of 47.3% in 2023. Iswaran, the former transport minister, faces 8 new charges for obtaining luxury items worth S$18,956.94. Singapore climbed to 6th place in the global resilient cities index, while office rents in the Raffles Place/Marina Bay area rose in Q1 2024, supported by renewals and demand from multinational corporations.

site_title: ECB confident wage growth slowdown on track, says its chief economist
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is increasingly confident that wage growth is slowing towards normal levels, potentially paving the way for rate cuts. According to ECB chief economist Philip Lane, rapid wage growth is a source of concern and will allow for interest rate reductions once data shows moderation in wage demands. Lane stated that several years of wage increases above normal levels are necessary before they return to normal, making rate cuts possible. This suggests a potential shift in the ECB's monetary policy stance.

images.alt_text: “Our decisions will have to remain data dependent and meeting-by-meeting, responding to new information as it comes in,” European Central Bank president Christine Lagarde says.
The Swiss National Bank has become the first major central bank to ease its policy with a surprise 25 basis point cut to its key rate.

site_title: Lufthansa, ITA Airways deal may hurt competition: EU watchdog
summary: The European Commission has expressed concerns that Lufthansa's bid for a minority stake in ITA Airways may harm competition, particularly in Italy's short-haul and long-haul routes, as well as at Milan's main airport. The Commission warns that the deal could lead to higher prices and strengthen ITA's dominant position, negatively affecting competition in already concentrated markets.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Lufthansa's aircrafts are seen on the tarmac the day before VERDI union called airport workers at Frankfurt, Munich, Stuttgart, Hamburg, Dortmund, Hanover and Bremen airports to go on a 24-hour strike on Friday, at the Munich International Airport, Germany, February 16, 2023. REUTERS/Leonhard Simon///File Photo
The union wants a 12.5 per cent salary increase and an extra 3,000 euros (S$4,373.47) inflation bonus for Lufthansa ground staff.

site_title: CSE Global raises S$24 million from share placement
summary: CSE Global, a Singapore-listed automation solutions provider, has raised S$24 million from a share placement to fund strategic acquisitions and investments in the US, Australia, and New Zealand. The group issued 60 million new ordinary shares at S$0.40 apiece, a 6.6% discount from the volume weighted average price. The placement aims to capitalize on growth opportunities in the group's core markets.

images.alt_text: 新加坡交易所（Singapore Exchange，SGX）标志。
Claudia Chong

site_title: ‘Flavour wizard:’ Japanese chocolatier conquers Belgium
summary: Japanese chocolatier Yasushi Sasaki, 52, has been named Brussels' chocolatier of the year by Gault&Millau, despite having no prior knowledge of French. Sasaki, who moved to Belgium at 19, creates unique Japanese-inspired chocolates that have gained popularity in Japan, particularly around Valentine's Day. His workshop produces high-quality chocolates with careful selection of suppliers and attention to detail, allowing him to maintain his independence and unique taste. With a 20-30% increase in turnover, Sasaki plans to continue producing good things, without expansion plans.

images.alt_text: The wagyu katsu sando is the Porsche of sandwiches, with its luxurious combination of elite beef, ethereal milk bread slices, and a brush of tangy-sweet tare sauce.
Zeniya has introduced S$88 lunch sets.

site_title:
Tides have turned for fixed income: Merits 
of
 investing in shorter-dated bonds
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to make its first interest rate cut this year, marking a pivot in the market. As interest rates fall, fixed deposits become less attractive, while traditional fixed-income assets with duration risk benefit. With the yield curve becoming flatter, investors should consider shorter-dated bonds for stable risk-adjusted returns, potentially offering diversification benefits amidst interest rate fluctuations.

images.alt_text: The Morningstar report found that diversifying into areas including emerging markets stocks, high-yield bonds and global bonds generally hurt returns last year, when the S&P 500 gained 24 per cent.
Commodities have made a modest advance in the first quarter, with crude strengthening, gold hitting a record, and copper topping US$9,000 a tonne.

site_title: Prime office rents grow in Q1 on renewals but may plateau in H2 2024: Knight Frank
summary: Office rents in Singapore's Raffles Place/Marina Bay area rose 0.6% quarter-over-quarter to S$11.20 per square foot in Q1 2024, with occupancy levels remaining tight at 95.6%. The growth is attributed to renewals from businesses occupying quality spaces and demand from multinational corporations. However, rents may plateau in H2 2024 due to potential staff layoffs and consolidations among technology companies and banks. Knight Frank expects rents to grow moderately between 1-3% for 2024.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Office demand strong in Downtown Core; rosier hopes for 2018

site_title: Binance to end support for USDC stablecoin on Tron blockchain network
summary: Binance will stop supporting USDC stablecoin on the Tron blockchain network, allowing users to continue trading on the platform but ending deposits and withdrawals via Tron. This decision follows Circle's similar move last month, citing efforts to ensure USDC's trustworthiness and transparency.

images.alt_text: Binance’s prime brokerage partners can plug investors into the liquidity available on the exchange.
The world’s largest cryptocurrency has surged 56 per cent this year, reaching an all-time high of almost US$73,798 last week.
FILE PHOTO: Smartphone with displayed Binance logo and representation of cryptocurrencies are placed on a keyboard in this illustration taken, June 8, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Tether issues a stablecoin which is designed to maintain a constant value of US$1.
The UK Treasury pledged in October to provide more clarity on specific areas of crypto by some point in 2024.
Tether’s USDT token is on the verge of surpassing US$100 billion in circulation for the first time.
Stablecoins are typically pegged 1-1 to fiat currencies and backed by reserves of cash and bonds.

site_title: China vows to treat foreign firms equally amid industrial upgrade push
summary: China has pledged to treat foreign companies equally amid its push to upgrade and strengthen its industrial chains. Vice-Commerce Minister Guo Tingting promised "national treatment" for foreign companies, aiming to attract more foreign investment and expertise. China will lift restrictions on foreign investment access to its manufacturing sector and deepen cooperation with firms from all countries. The move aims to counter concerns of unequal access and "economic coercion" from Western firms, which have considered "de-risking" supply chains and operations away from China.

images.alt_text: Customers at an Apple Store in Shanghai, March 15, 2024. Apple has deep ties in the country, its second-largest market. But there are signs that Chinese consumers are becoming a harder sell.
TPG early next month plans to announce the final close of the Asia VIII fund. A spokesperson declined to comment on the details.
The change in operating mode signals officials are stepping up efforts to boost confidence in China’s economy, as a property crisis and weak domestic demand drag on sentiment at home.
The US has been aiming to boost domestic semiconductor output and reduce reliance on China and Taiwan with the Biden administration’s 2022 Chips and Science Act.
China’s industry ministry in January issued draft guidelines for standardising the AI industry, with the aim to have national and industry-wide standards in place by 2026.

site_title: Singapore stocks start week in red; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks ended Monday in the red, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.6% to 3,198.10 points. The decline followed the release of official inflation data, which showed a rise in headline and core inflation in February. Most regional markets also fell, with the Nikkei 225 and Hang Seng Index down 1.2% and 0.2% respectively. Despite this, the US Nasdaq edged to a fresh record and the Dow pulled back.

images.alt_text: Gold prices rose to an all-time high on Thursday after Fed policymakers indicated they still expected to reduce interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point by the end of 2024 despite recent high inflation readings.
Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Taipei and Wellington stocks rose in early trade on Monday, but Tokyo, Seoul, Singapore, Manila and Jakarta stocks were in the red.
Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 79 to 75.

site_title: From bankers to technocrats, all eyes on Indonesia president-elect Prabowo’s Cabinet line-up
summary: Indonesian President-elect Prabowo Subianto is focusing on assembling his Cabinet, with a focus on identifying candidates for key economic ministerial positions and seeking professionals in the coming months. Unlike outgoing President Joko Widodo, Prabowo will not establish a transition team, instead relying on the Golkar party to assist in the process. The exact Cabinet line-up remains uncertain, with various lists circulating on social media, but Prabowo's team is expected to prioritize economic expertise.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
Incoming President Prabowo Subianto's spending spree could amount to 460 trillion rupiah (S$39.3 billion), more than the entire 2023 budget deficit.

site_title: Head of leading Atos shareholder Onepoint says ready to lead rescue plan
summary: Atos, a French tech group, faces a rescue plan after a deal to sell its cybersecurity assets to Airbus fell through. Onepoint, the company's leading shareholder, is prepared to lead a rescue plan to protect Atos' strategic assets, according to its CEO David Layani. The French Finance Ministry has pledged to use all means to safeguard Atos' assets. Atos has stated it has not discussed any rescue plan with Onepoint, and will analyze any proposed plan before commenting. The company will release its 2023 results on March 26.

images.alt_text: Atos is analysing the resulting situation and actively evaluating strategic alternatives that will take into consideration the sovereign imperatives of the French state.
The embattled Atos says conditions for the rights offering were “no longer applicable” and that a standby underwriting commitment from BNP Paribas and JPMorgan was also no longer in effect.

site_title: Christie’s, Sotheby’s announce opening dates for new Hong Kong spaces
summary: Major auction houses Christie's and Sotheby's have announced opening dates for their new spaces in Hong Kong. Christie's will open its new headquarters at The Henderson in September, occupying 50,000 sq ft, while Sotheby's will open its 24,000-sq-ft space at Landmark Chater in July. The openings come ahead of Art Basel, which returns to its pre-pandemic scale, with Hong Kong remaining Asia's art hub despite economic challenges. Both companies express strong commitment to the market, navigating current economic conditions.

images.alt_text: The evening sale of work from the estate of Emily Fisher Landau at Sotheby’s in New York.
The timepieces include a unique FP Journe Vagabondage one Model from 2004 that commemorates each of Schumacher’s F1 championship wins.

site_title: PetroChina’s 2023 net income up 8.3% on strong fuel, gas sales
summary: PetroChina reported a 8.3% increase in net profit to 161.1 billion yuan (S$30.1 billion) in 2023, driven by strong sales of fuel and gas, with operating profit in the natural gas segment tripling to 43 billion yuan. Revenue fell 7.0% to 3,239 billion yuan. The company's marketing segment saw a 66.7% rise in operating profit.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A PetroChina petrol station is pictured in Beijing, China, March 21, 2016.  REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo

site_title: Jera, ExxonMobil to explore development of hydrogen and ammonia production project in US
summary: ExxonMobil and Jera, Japan's top power generator, have agreed to jointly explore the development of a low-carbon hydrogen and ammonia production project in the US. The project, set to start in 2028, will have an annual output capacity of 900,000 tonnes of hydrogen and over 1 million tonnes of ammonia. Jera may invest in the project and purchase 500,000 tonnes of ammonia annually for Japan. The partnership aims to reduce CO2 emissions and support Japan's goal of becoming carbon neutral by 2050.

images.alt_text: ExxonMobil’s pay model is moving closer to that employed by the broader industry, which typically pays traders large bonuses tied to profit, and lower base salaries.

The New York State Common Retirement Fund has holdings of nearly US$26.8 million as of Dec 31, 2023 from the companies to be divested and restricted, which include Exxon Mobil, Guanghui Energy Company, Echo Energy, IOG, Oil and Natural Gas, Delek Group, Dana Gas, and Unit Corp.

Exxon’s unusual legal action has been closely watched by investor activists worried that the move could lead other companies to block shareholder resolutions in court, rather than through the usual process of appealing to regulators.

site_title: Apple, Google, Meta targeted in EU’s first Digital Markets Act probes
summary: The European Union has launched investigations into Apple, Google, and Meta for potential breaches of the Digital Markets Act, which aims to challenge the power of tech giants and promote competition. The investigations, which could result in fines of up to 10% of the companies' global annual turnover, are focused on issues such as allowing users to uninstall software applications, changing default settings, and favoring vertical search engines. The EU industry chief, Thierry Breton, emphasized that the investigations are necessary to ensure compliance with the law and avoid complacency, despite the fact that the law has only been in effect for two weeks.

images.alt_text: If any of the six tech giants are not compliant with the Digital Markets Act (DMA) by the EU’s Thursday deadline, they could ultimately face investigations and potentially fines of up to 10 per cent of their global turnover.

This photo taken on February 12, 2023 in Brussels shows reflexions on a smartphone screen of logos of online platforms google, facebook, linkedin, Amazon, Apple store and Tiktok as the European Commission announced last September the world's biggest digital firms, identified as "gatekeepers" by the EU, must comply from March 6, 2024, with strict do's and don'ts under a landmark law, the Digital Markets Act (DMA). The EU has built a powerful legal arsenal to take on the internet giants, including the DMA which seeks to encourage competition in the digital world, and its sister milestone law, the Digital Services Act (DSA). The DSA demands the most popular social networks and websites police content online more aggressively and protect consumers while they shop. (Photo by Kenzo TRIBOUILLARD / AFP)

site_title:
Water: Solutions and opportunities 
in a thirsty world
summary: A global water crisis is looming, with demand expected to surpass supply by 40% by 2030, displacing 700 million people. Climate change, urbanization, and ageing infrastructure contribute to the imbalance. Innovative technologies, such as semiconductor manufacturing and smart irrigation, drive water-intensive industries. Investing in water solutions, including infrastructure, treatment, and utilities, offers opportunities for growth and environmental impact measurement. Companies like George Fischer and Ferguson offer defensive and growth-oriented opportunities, with some projects saving millions of litres of water annually.

images.alt_text: The US$2.1 billion Invesco Water Resources exchange-traded fund is by far the industry’s largest fund. Other offerings that make Morningstar’s list of highest-rated funds are Calvert Global Water, Invesco S&P Global Water ETF, Virtus Duff & Phelps Water and Ecofin Global Water.

People filling up buckets with safe drinking water in Kuwadzana, Zimbabwe, January 2024. Against the backdrop of a worsening climate crisis, the need to scale collective water action has never been more pressing.

site_title: Xiaomi CEO teases price on upcoming car, showrooms begin displaying vehicle
summary: Xiaomi CEO Lei Jun has teased the price of its upcoming electric vehicle, the SU7, which is expected to be under 500,000 yuan (S$93,420). The company will announce the official price range and start taking orders on Thursday. The SU7 will have a driving range of up to 800 km and will be available in two versions. Xiaomi has been seeking to diversify into EVs amid stagnating smartphone demand and has pledged to invest US$10 billion in autos over a decade.

images.alt_text: Xiaomi's revenue reached 73.24 billion yuan (S$13.7 billion) in October-to-December quarter.
The SU7 has “super electric motor” technology capable of delivering acceleration speeds faster than Tesla and Porsche’s EVs.
Xiaomi last year was placed third globally for share of the smartphone market, accounting for 12.5 per cent of global shipments.
Xiaomi is also asking India to reduce import tariffs on sub-components used in batteries, USB cables and phone covers.

site_title: How to trade an election
summary: Markets are increasingly influenced by politics, particularly in the lead-up to elections. Investors can profit from understanding the economic stakes and potential winners and losers. In the 2020 US presidential election, green-energy and cannabis stocks surged before later dropping as investor optimism waned. This year's US election, as well as British and other elections, will likely see similar market fluctuations. Investors can bet on the outcome by investing in companies that benefit from a Trump win or short-selling those that lose out, with broader asset classes also being affected by the consequences of a Trump presidency.

images.alt_text: At the COP28 climate summit last week, around 110 countries pledged to treble renewable energy capacity by 2030.
From falling interest rates to the impact of global geopolitics: Investment outlook for 2024

site_title: Thailand delays 500 billion baht handout scheme to fourth quarter
summary: Thailand's government has delayed a 500 billion baht handout scheme, initially planned for the second half of this year, to the fourth quarter. The scheme aims to transfer 10,000 baht to 50 million Thais to boost weak growth. Concerns over funding have led to criticism from experts, who have called the scheme fiscally irresponsible. The government will hold further discussions on the program and plan to register eligible recipients and distribute funds in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Gold firms on hopes for Fed rate cut in June, softer US dollar
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to an all-time high on Monday, driven by renewed bets that the US Federal Reserve will cut interest rates in June, making gold more appealing to investors. The US dollar weakened, making gold cheaper for other currency holders. Traders now see a 74% probability of a rate cut in June, according to the CME Group's FedWatch Tool.

images.alt_text: Gold prices rose to an all-time high on Thursday.
Commodities have made a modest advance in the first quarter, with crude strengthening, gold hitting a record, and copper topping US$9,000 a tonne.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, March 25, 2024 (Ep 29)
summary: Singapore's inflation rose 3.4% in February, exceeding expectations, while core inflation remained at 3.6%. Tokyo stocks ended their winning streak, falling due to profit-taking. Private equity deals in Asia plummeted to a decade low. Best World International, a Singapore-based company, plans to delist by implementing selective capital reduction, prompting a shareholder requisition for an emergency general meeting to discuss cash reserves, dividends, and directors' pay.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 79 to 75.
MAS and MTI said February's higher core prices was driven by higher services and food inflation, partly reflecting seasonal effects associated with Chinese New Year.
The benchmark Nikkei 225 index lost 1.2 per cent, or 474.31 points, to end at 40,414.12, while the broader Topix index dropped 1.3 per cent, or 35.58 points, to 2,777.64.
In a bourse filing, Best World said it intends to obtain approval for the selective capital reduction at an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: Hyflux’s civil suits against founder Olivia Lum, ex-auditor KPMG to be jointly tried
summary: Hyflux's civil lawsuits against founder Olivia Lum and former auditor KPMG will be jointly tried by the same High Court judge at the same time, after Justice Goh Yihan granted Lum's application. The judge agreed that a joint trial will "save costs, time and effort, as well as promote convenience" due to overlapping facts and claims. The suits, filed in 2022, seek over S$1.3 billion in damages, with Lum claiming breach of fiduciary duty and KPMG accused of breaching its duty to exercise reasonable skill and care in auditing Hyflux's financial statements.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
The three charges levelled against Olivia Lum on Friday pertain to Section 157(1) of the Companies Act,

site_title: Chinese EV makers take centre stage at Bangkok motor show, to unveil new models
summary: Chinese electric vehicle (EV) makers Geely's Zeekr and state-owned Xpeng Motors are set to unveil new models at the Bangkok motor show, marking a significant challenge to Japanese auto giants in Thailand's vehicle market. The companies plan to expand their presence in the country, with Zeekr launching two EV models and opening 10 showrooms, while Xpeng plans to open five showrooms to offer higher-end EVs. Chinese automakers have committed to investing over $1.4 billion in production facilities in Thailand, aiming to convert 30% of annual vehicle production into EVs by 2030.

images.alt_text: The company will on Thursday evening announce its official price range and start taking orders for the car, dubbed the SU7, with the SU short for Speed Ultra.
The automaker is currently discounting almost every electric and hybrid car model it sells, as part of a marketing campaign declaring “electricity is cheaper than oil”.
Stellantis said last year it was buying a 21 per cent stake in Leapmotor in a US$1.6 billion deal that would give it a fresh shot at China.
Tesla is up against increasingly stiff competition in China, not only from homegrown competitor BYD but a raft of other EV manufacturers churning out more affordable, tech-laden vehicles.

site_title: Indonesia cuts the ribbon on Prabowo; Vietnam’s Thuong bows out
summary: Indonesia's outgoing leader Joko Widodo has handed over the presidency to Prabowo Subianto, marking the country's transition. Meanwhile, Vietnam's President Vo Van Thuong has resigned. The handovers come as the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) continues to navigate regional challenges. The World Bank has warned of emerging challenges for the region, while Indonesia's new capital has welcomed its first foreign investor. These developments underscore the shifting dynamics in Southeast Asia's politics and economies.

images.alt_text: Goh Ruoxue
Singapore has long relied on the fame of its shopping street to draw visitors, but the tourist belt needs to really up its game.
US pop music sensation Taylor Swift kicks off the Asia-Pacific leg of her "Eras" world tour in Japan. Singapore will be her only stop in South-east Asia.
A helicopter flies over Indonesia's capital Jakarta. The nation’s housing market is expected to remain strong for the rest of 2024.
The Langkawi archipelago, one of Malaysia’s best-known holiday destinations, is also a popular choice among retired expatriates.

site_title: Has China lost its taste for the iPhone?
summary: Apple's iPhone sales in China have fallen 24% from last year, with Huawei experiencing a 64% surge in sales. The decline is attributed to a slowdown in consumer spending, pressure from Beijing to shun US-made devices, and Huawei's resurgence with its own operating system and advanced computer chip. Analysts say the rising tension between the US and China is also a factor, making it difficult for Apple to retain its position. The company's efforts to expand its research and development labs in Shanghai and promote its latest products have been overshadowed by Huawei's success.

images.alt_text: The US has been aiming to boost domestic semiconductor output and reduce reliance on China and Taiwan with the Biden administration’s 2022 Chips and Science Act.
The US lawsuit alleges that Apple has used its power over app distribution on the iPhone to thwart innovations that would have made it easier for consumers to switch phones.

Tim Cook, chief executive officer of Apple Inc., center, and Deirdre O'Brien, senior vice president of retail, left, during the opening of the new Apple Inc. Jingan store in Shanghai, China, on Thursday, March 21, 2024. Cook opened an expansive new store in central Shanghai Thursday, signaling his company's commitment to China as a market and production base. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
The China Daily reported that Cook had said in an interview that “there’s no supply chain in the world that’s more critical to us than China”.

site_title: Singapore climbs to sixth place in global resilient cities index
summary: Singapore has climbed six notches to become the world's 6th most resilient city, according to Savills' annual global index. The city-state improved its ranking from 12th place in 2021, thanks to an influx of people choosing to live and work there. New York topped the list for the second consecutive year, while the global index tracks the resilience of 490 cities worldwide.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Stay awhile: How long-stay serviced apartments may change the housing landscape
Laguna Lakelands by the Banyan Group is expected to be Phuket's largest private residential community.
PGIM Real Estate has put three floors for sale at a guide price of S$54.6 million.

site_title: Nissan to launch 30 new models by 2027, boost global sales volumes
summary: Nissan plans to launch 30 new models by 2027, aiming to boost global sales by 1 million vehicles and improve profitability. The automaker targets an operating profit margin of over 6% by March 2027 and total shareholder returns of more than 30%. Nissan expects electrified vehicles to make up 60% of global sales by the end of the decade, with 16 of the new models being electrified. The company also plans to reduce the cost of electric vehicles by 30% by 2030.

images.alt_text: This photo taken on December 8, 2023 shows workers inspecting a car on the production line during a media tour of the "Nissan Intelligent Factory" at the Nissan Motor Tochigi plant, the company's largest in Japan, in Kaminokawa, Tochigi prefecture, some 105 kms (65 miles) north of Tokyo. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)
Both Honda and Nissan are considering cutting production capacity in China as sales decline.
The Japanese carmakers are struggling in the face of increased local competition from manufacturers such as BYD as electric vehicles take hold in China.

site_title: Thailand starts aid deliveries to Myanmar under plan aimed at managing conflict
summary: Thailand has started delivering aid to Myanmar, aiming to manage the conflict by providing humanitarian assistance. The UN reports at least 2.6 million people displaced and 18 million in need of aid. The Thai Red Cross delivered 4,000 relief bags to Myanmar's border crossing, with plans to expand aid distribution. Thailand hopes to play a role in bringing fighting to a manageable level and encouraging talks, as the 10-member Asean bloc's peace initiative has yet to advance.

images.alt_text: Asean foreign ministers support efforts by the new special envoy on the crisis, from Laos, in “reaching out to parties concerned” and expressed confidence in his resolve to help the Myanmar people.
Governments and policymakers must prioritise preparedness and resilience-building at national and regional levels to address food security issues and mitigate future impacts.

site_title: Big hotel chains and unbranded hotel owners find they need each other
summary: Hotel chains and independent operators are forming franchise agreements as high interest rates slow new hotel construction. Big chains benefit from short-term openings, while independents access cheaper financing and potential bookings. The trend is driven by the need for capital borrowing, with approximately $217 billion in hotel loans set to mature globally by 2025. Brands like Hilton and Marriott are launching "soft" and conversion brands to attract independent operators, offering them a way to boost net unit growth.

images.alt_text: Shangri-La Singapore is one of the group's hotels.
Google together with five other tech giants have to be fully compliant with a list of dos and don’ts set out under the DMA on Mar 7.
The Hilton Paris Opera hotel is located next to the Paris Saint-Lazare train station.
Hotel average room rates were mixed across categories in January, with the luxury, upscale and mid-tier segments recording sequential increases, but the economy segment rate falling.

site_title: Goldman’s hedge-fund clients get more active in crypto options
summary: Goldman Sachs' hedge fund clients are becoming more active in cryptocurrency markets, with a resurgence of interest triggered by the recent ETF approval. The bank, which launched its crypto trading desk in 2021, provides cash-settled Bitcoin and Ether option trading, as well as CME-listed futures. Clients are using crypto derivatives for directional bets, yield enhancement, and hedging purposes, with Bitcoin-related products still commanding the majority of focus. Goldman is also expanding into a wider universe of clients and exploring tokenizing traditional assets using blockchain.

images.alt_text: The closed-end fund is part of Goldman Sachs Asset Management's US$340 billion External Investing Group.
The looting of the 1MDB investment fund by officials in Malaysia after Goldman helped it raise money spawned a multibillion-dollar scandal and probes across continents.

A view of an empty office floor in downtown San Francisco as the city struggles to return to its pre-pandemic commercial real estate occupancy rates, falling behind many other major cities around the country, hitting a vacancy rate of over 30%, according to local media, in California, U.S., February 23, 2024. REUTERS/Carlos Barria

site_title: Achieving the twin goals of vibrancy and sustainability
summary: Singapore aims to rejuvenate ageing office buildings to meet its ESG-driven development goals, with a 56% deficit in ESG-focused office stock expected by 2030. The Urban Redevelopment Authority's (URA) CBD Incentive Scheme and Strategic Development Incentive Scheme have been successful, with over 4.7 million sq ft of office space earmarked for renewal. These schemes have also boosted the stock of ESG-focused office inventory, with over 3.3 million sq ft already withdrawn. The schemes' extension is proposed to maintain momentum and support Singapore's ESG ambitions.

images.alt_text: As more companies commit to reach net-zero emissions by 2050, most will be looking to cut those tied to their offices and factories, yet demand for low-carbon buildings is set to outstrip supply.

site_title: Singapore’s inflation rises more than expected in February; core inflation at 3.6%, headline at 3.4%
summary: Singapore's inflation rose more than expected in February, with headline inflation at 3.4% and core inflation at 3.6%. The higher inflation was driven by services and food inflation, partly due to seasonal effects from Chinese New Year. Accommodation inflation increased to 3.9%, while services inflation rose to 4.2%. Despite this, the Monetary Authority and Ministry of Trade and Industry maintained their full-year inflation forecasts, expecting headline and core inflation to average between 2.5 and 3.5%.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
xxx

Simulations by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) have showed that even if the nominal exchange rate had not been raised, the Singapore dollar would still have appreciated similarly in real terms, chief economist Edward Robinson said.

site_title: Cutting the cord?: Events leading up to and after Cordlife’s MOH suspension and arrests of its directors, ex-group CEO
summary: Cordlife, a private cord-blood bank, faces ongoing investigations into alleged breaches-of-disclosure obligations regarding storage tanks' exposure to irregular temperatures. In November 2023, the Ministry of Health (MOH) suspended the company for six months due to lapses in temperature control, resulting in potential damage to stored cord blood units. Following a series of arrests of directors and former executives, including group CEO Yiu Pang Fai and CFO Thet Hnin Yi, the company is working to introduce "stringent measures" to enhance operational standards and rectify the issues.

images.alt_text: 康盛人生将脐带血干细胞低温保存，有助长期保存干细胞的活力与功能。
Megan Cheah

site_title: Japan sees more global interest in its financial hub ambition
summary: Japan's financial hub ambitions are gaining global interest as foreign asset managers become more confident in the country's economic transformation. Vice-minister for international affairs Shigeru Ariizumi attributed this shift to the government's efforts to remake Tokyo into a major financial hub, driven by Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's administration. The Bank of Japan's decision to end negative interest rates also underscores confidence in Japan's recovery. To support this growth, the government is promoting corporate governance reforms and corporate efficiency improvements, including the unwinding of cross-shareholdings.

site_title: Tokyo stocks end lower on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks ended lower on Monday, snapping a four-day winning streak, due to profit-taking after the Nikkei index hit record highs last week. The Nikkei 225 index fell 1.2% and the Topix index dropped 1.3%. Investors took profits amid concerns over the rapid rise of the Nikkei index and the yen's depreciation after the Bank of Japan raised interest rates. Japanese finance ministry officials hinted at potential intervention in the currency market to curb speculation.

images.alt_text: Nikkei 225 Stock Average’s jump above 40,000 to all-time highs has led to Japanese individuals betting on more gains.
The benchmark Nikkei 225 index jumps 2.67 per cent or 1,032.80 points to 39,740.44.

site_title: HSBC’s top tech banker exits to join tech firm
summary: HSBC's global co-head of technology, media and telecom Winston Cheng is leaving the bank to join a Fortune 500 tech firm. Cheng joined HSBC in 2021 and built the TMT team with key hires in Asia. Dan Bailey will continue to lead the team globally. The move is part of a trend of muted deal flows in China amid a deteriorating macroeconomy and stricter regulations.

site_title: Declining Indonesian palm oil exports may affect domestic supply, officials say
summary: Indonesian palm oil exports declined in January and February, falling short of the monthly target of 300,000 tonnes under the Domestic Market Obligation (DMO) scheme. The country's palm oil production slipped, with 1.9 million tonnes shipped in January and 1 million tonnes in February, mainly due to less competitive pricing compared to rivals such as soy and canola oils. The weaker exports may impact domestic supply and lower mandatory sales to the government's cheap cooking oil programme, affecting poorer Indonesian consumers. Officials are considering changing the DMO allotment to production instead of export quotas.

images.alt_text: Bursa Malaysia-listed crude palm oil futures are up about 20.8 per cent this year as at Mar 4 at RM4,345 per tonne. This is the highest price CPO futures have reached in a one-year period.

Palm oil output in Indonesia and Malaysia, which account for a bulk of global production, is likely to either rise marginally in 2024 or decline from last year’s level, as ageing plantations and a lack of expansion caps output.
Output from Central America and Africa is seen moderately higher.

site_title: New Zealand and EU trade agreement to take effect on May 1
summary: New Zealand's free trade agreement with the European Union will come into effect on May 1, benefiting its beef, lamb, and dairy industries, as well as removing tariffs on exports like kiwi fruit and EU imports like clothing and cars. The agreement, signed in July 2023, is New Zealand's fourth-largest trade partner, with a two-way trade worth NZ$20.2 billion in 2022. The EU will also lift tariffs on its exports, including wine and confectionery.

site_title: BYD takes on EV laggards Toyota, VW with steep China price cuts
summary: BYD, a Chinese automaker, has launched a marketing campaign in China, offering steep price cuts on most of its electric and hybrid car models. The discounts aim to persuade drivers to switch from petrol cars to electric vehicles, targeting both first-time buyers and those in smaller cities and rural areas. This aggressive pricing strategy threatens Toyota, Volkswagen, and Nissan, which have been slow to transition to electric vehicles. BYD's price cuts have already led to significant sales, with its most affordable EV and top-selling sedan cracking the top five selling models in China.

images.alt_text: Attendees at the BYD Co. stand on the opening day of the Geneva International Motor Show in Geneva, Switzerland, on Monday, Feb. 26, 2024. The show runs until Sunday, March 3. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

site_title: Sweden’s SBB to buy back debt at 60% discount
summary: Sweden's property group SBB will buy back 407.7 million euros' worth of debt at a 60% discount, trimming its debt pile of 62 billion Swedish crowns. The move aims to calm investors' nerves amid high debt levels and a struggling economy. SBB will pay 162.7 million euros for the debt, generating a profit of around 2.8 billion Swedish crowns. The company's share price is expected to rise, but analysts remain cautious.

images.alt_text: Loss-making SBB, at the epicentre of a Swedish property crash, late last year spent 403.8 million euros (S$589 million) to buy back debt at a small discount to the nominal value.

site_title: Oil prices rise as heightened geopolitical risk exacerbates supply concern
summary: Oil prices rose 0.3% to $85.67 a barrel, driven by heightened geopolitical risk and supply concerns. Escalating conflict in the Middle East, between Russia and Ukraine, and a shrinking US rig count added to upward pressure. Russia struck critical infrastructure in Ukraine's Lviv region with missiles, and tensions in the region raised concerns over global oil supply. The US oil rig count fell to 509, indicating lower future supply.

images.alt_text: Crude oil tanker Nevskiy Prospect owned by Russia's leading tanker group Sovcomflot; Sovcomflot transported about a fifth of all Russia’s crude deliveries to India last year.
FILE PHOTO: A view shows an oil pump jack outside Almetyevsk in the Republic of Tatarstan, Russia June 4, 2023. REUTERS/Alexander Manzyuk//File Photo
The energy sector accounted for about two-thirds of the US$5.5 trillion sum, particularly in the electric utilities  and oil and gas segments.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as key US inflation data looms
summary: Asian markets are mixed ahead of US inflation data, with key stocks in Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Taipei, and Wellington rising, while Tokyo, Seoul, Singapore, Manila, and Jakarta fell.
