Investors are optimistic about the outlook for equities due to the Federal Reserve's interest rate cut projections, but concerns remain about the central bank's ability to control inflation. The release of the personal consumption expenditures (PCE) index, the Fed's preferred gauge of inflation, is expected to provide further insight into the economic outlook.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 79 to 75.

site_title: Share of newly created job vacancies in Singapore at six-year high
summary: Singapore's job market saw a six-year high in newly created job vacancies in 2023, with 47.3% of positions being newly created, up from 38.7% in 2022. Employers' increased flexibility and openness to a wider talent pool led to a decline in harder-to-fill vacancies, and the proportion of PMET vacancies continued to rise, driven by higher demand for skilled workers. Job openings for tech-focused roles, such as software developers, remained in demand, while non-PMET vacancies, including those in construction and services industries, also saw increased hiring.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
The ratio of job vacancies to unemployed persons, at 1.74, has been rising since March 2021 when it was 0.96, indicating a “moderately tight labour market”, said MOM.
Areas where SMEs can adopt AI include marketing and customer engagement, says Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling.

From left: Vicky Hwang, CEO, Chyau Fwu Wine & Spirits; Koren Wines, managing director, Xero Asia; Low Yen Ling, Minister of State for Trade and Industry; Anita Gabriel, senior correspondent, The Business Times.

(L-R) Vicky Hwang, CEO, Chyau Fwu Wine & Spirits; Koren Wines, managing director, Xero Asia; Low Yen Ling, Minister of State for Trade and Industry; Anita Gabriel, Senior Correspondent, The Business Times.

site_title: Serious money is fuelling the Bitcoin rally
summary: Bitcoin reached a new high of $73,797.68 in mid-March, driven by institutional capital flows and interest in Bitcoin exchange-traded funds (ETFs). Capital inflows to spot Bitcoin ETFs hit $2.5 billion, surpassing the previous record. This institutional demand is expected to reduce volatility in the cryptocurrency market, according to cryptocurrency exchange CEO Lasanka Perera.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
The world’s largest cryptocurrency is set for one of its worst weeks of the year after a 4 per cent retreat.
The largest digital asset has shed about 3 per cent to trade at US$65,380 as at 1 pm on Tuesday in Singapore.
The world’s largest cryptocurrency has surged 56 per cent this year, reaching an all-time high of almost US$73,798 last week.

site_title: TPG will halve China investments in new US$5 billion Asia fund
summary: TPG Capital is set to announce the final close of its Asia VIII fund, valued at around US$5 billion. The new portfolio will reduce its China allocation by more than half, allocating around 10% of its capital in China, down from 25% in previous funds. The majority of the fund will be invested in Australia, India, and South-east Asia, with around 70% of initial investments made in India and Australia. The fund's strong start has seen a net internal rate of return of 129%, with zero investment in China so far.

images.alt_text: The company operates clinics and hospitals in locations including Singapore, Hong Kong, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand and Indonesia.
TPG and Francisco Partners have offered New Relic shareholders US$87 per share held, representing a premium of 17.5 per cent to the stock’s closing price on Friday.

site_title: MUST or bust?: Looking back at Manulife US Reit’s pivotal events
summary: Manulife US Reit has experienced a tumultuous two years due to shifting office trends post-pandemic and rising interest rates. The real estate investment trust's stock market performance has been impacted by a mass exodus of key executives, including the departure of its former CEO and CFO. The company's H2 distributable income fell 13.3%, further exacerbating concerns. As the real estate sector continues to face challenges, Singapore REITs may be at risk of suspending distributions, and more companies may follow suit. The company's leadership is undergoing a significant overhaul, with a new CEO and CFO appointed.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Apac private equity deals plunge as macro uncertainties unsettle investors: Bain & Co
summary: Private equity dealmaking activities in Asia-Pacific (Apac) plummeted in 2023, with total deal value and fundraising dropping to decade lows. The region's deal value fell 35% from the previous five-year average, and Apac-focused funds raised only 26% of their 2022 level. Japan bucked the trend, with deal value rising 183% over the prior five-year average. The region's top 20 funds' share of deal value increased to 47%, but underperforming funds struggled due to fewer deals and a slowdown in fundraising. Successful funds are adapting by using pre-sales strategies to exit successfully.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
TPG early next month plans to announce the final close of the Asia VIII fund. A spokesperson declined to comment on the details.
The number of licensed finance professionals dropped by more than 600 since the end of 2021.
Money is pouring into private credit funds from wealthy investors, retirement plans, sovereign wealth funds, and even the banks that compete with them.
Global demand for Japanese commercial real estate remains robust, given attractive terms, including low borrowing costs and stable rents.

Mutual funds manage nearly US$20 trillion in US assets and about US$63 trillion worldwide, but their dominance is under threat from newer rivals that promise tax advantages, lower fees and rapid trading.

site_title: Goldman says commodities to benefit as central banks cut rates
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts commodities will advance 15% in 2024 due to central banks' interest rate cuts, supporting industrial and consumer demand. Crude oil, copper, aluminium, and gold are expected to rise, with copper forecasted to reach $10,000 a tonne, aluminium $2,600 a tonne, and gold $2,300 an ounce by year-end. This is attributed to tighter supplies and an upturn in the global economy, with policymakers aiming to reduce borrowing costs as inflation ebbs.

site_title: Sumitomo Life Insurance forecasts higher overseas earnings
summary: Sumitomo Life Insurance forecasts higher overseas earnings, aiming to reach 100 billion yen (S$891 million) this fiscal year, driven by its acquisition of Singapore Life Holdings. The company, led by President Yukinori Takada, is open to further acquisitions in Southeast Asia and values learning from Singlife's digital prowess. Takada also stated that the company will expand its holdings of Japanese government bonds if interest rates continue to rise, but believes a large increase in rates would be difficult to implement.

images.alt_text: The transactions, subject to regulatory approvals in Japan and Singapore, are expected to complete in Q1 of 2024.

site_title: BT Podcasts: Disability insurance is good for everyone, regardless of age
summary: David Yip, head of accident and health business at Great Eastern, and Willis Lau, financial representative and financial influencer, discuss the importance of disability insurance. Despite common misconceptions, disability can strike at any age, and having insurance can provide financial security. GREAT CareShield, underwritten by The Great Eastern Life Assurance Company Limited, offers coverage for long-term care insurance and can help individuals prepare for unexpected expenses. Experts emphasize that disability is not permanent and that insurance can help alleviate financial burdens, making it beneficial for everyone, regardless of age.

images.alt_text: GIA president Ronak Shah says protecting and supporting the motoring public will remain a key focus for the general insurance sector in the coming year.

site_title: Swiftonomics boosts card billings by 35%; UOB cardholders spent over S$30 million on tickets
summary: UOB reports a 35% increase in card billings for the week of March 4 to March 10, driven by a surge in spending at tourism-related categories such as clothing retailers, transportation, and amusement. Notably, UOB cardholders spent over S$30 million on concert tickets for Taylor Swift's The Eras Tour in Singapore. Credit card applications among 25- to 29-year-olds have also seen a 4% increase from June 21 to July 7.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
The Langkawi archipelago, one of Malaysia’s best-known holiday destinations, is also a popular choice among retired expatriates.

Indonesia Minister of Tourism and Creative Economy Sandiaga Uno wants to strive for more incentives to hold more international-scale music, sports, and cultural events to attract tourists to Indonesia.

Taylor Swift took to the stage on Mar 2, 2024, at the National Stadium for The Eras Tour.
US pop music sensation Taylor Swift kicks off the Asia-Pacific leg of her "Eras" world tour in Japan. Singapore will be her only stop in South-east Asia.
The billionaire singer has made economic waves throughout her record-shattering global tour, in a phenomenon dubbed “Swiftonomics”.

site_title: Hong Kong’s big estates post 32% slump in weekend transactions
summary: Hong Kong's secondhand home market is cooling down after a brief rebound, with the 10 biggest residential estates posting a 32% slump in weekend transactions. This is the second drop in a row, as buyers remain deterred by high interest rates and competing new offers. Developers are selling new homes at low prices to clear an abundant supply, with prices dropping 8% below secondary units in the same area since mid-2019. The property industry is expected to remain under pressure until the fourth quarter, when some of the inventory is absorbed.

site_title: China blocks use of Intel and AMD chips in government computers: report
summary: China has introduced guidelines to phase out US-made Intel and AMD chips from government computers and servers, and to favor domestic options. The move aims to reduce reliance on US semiconductor output and follows the Biden administration's 2022 Chips and Science Act. Government agencies must now include criteria for "safe and reliable" processors and operating systems when making purchases. This is part of China's push to bolster domestic industry, which has been flagged as a geopolitical risk by a China adviser.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A central processing unit (CPU) semiconductor chip is displayed among flags of China and U.S., in this illustration picture taken February 17, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Singapore shares little changed at Monday’s open; STI down 0.01%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.45 point, or 0.01%, to 3,217.52 at 9:02 am on Monday, following subdued global market performances. Gainers outnumbered losers 79 to 75, with Seatrium rising 1.3% and Thai Beverage and Golden Agri-Resources also seeing gains. Banking stocks declined, with DBS and OCBC falling 0.1% and 0.5%, respectively.

images.alt_text: Shangri-La Asia proposes a final dividend of HK$0.15 for the full year.

site_title: England’s homes found more cramped than those in New York City
summary: Homes in England are more cramped than those in New York City, with an average of 38 square meters per person, according to a new analysis by the Resolution Foundation. The UK's housing stock is also aging, with 38% of homes built before 1946, leading to higher energy bills. The lack of supply and surge in demand have driven up housing costs, with UK housing costs being the most expensive relative to general prices in any OECD country. The issue is exacerbating the housing crisis in Britain, making it difficult for younger Britons to get on the property ladder.

images.alt_text: British consumer price inflation slowed to 3.4 per cent in February.
Public sector net borrowing, excluding state-owned banks, was £8.401 billion (S$14.4 billion) last month, down from £11.843 billion a year ago.
Homeowners in the UK generally do not pay capital gains on their main residence, so the changes will mainly affect private landlords and second homeowners.

site_title: Australia to recommend minimum wage rise in line with inflation
summary: The Australian government will recommend a minimum wage increase in line with inflation, aiming to prevent low-income families from experiencing a decrease in real wages. The expected 3.3% inflation rate by June 2024 is lower than initially feared, allowing for a smaller wage rise. The move aims to support low-paid workers and address cost-of-living pressures, with the government also pledging tax cuts for every taxpayer in the upcoming budget.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Two women walk next to the Reserve Bank of Australia headquarters in central Sydney, Australia February 6, 2018. REUTERS/Daniel Munoz/File Photo

site_title: Stocks to watch: Shangri-La Asia, Sabana Reit, Best World, Cordlife
summary: Shangri-La Asia proposed a final dividend of HK$0.15 per share for the full year after recording a net profit of US$184.1 million, a significant improvement from a US$158.5 million loss the previous year. Sabana Reit established an internalization committee to internalize the Reit manager, while Best World International announced its intention to delist from the Singapore Exchange. Cordlife Group will table seven ordinary resolutions at its next general meeting, and its CEO plans to focus on lifting the group's six-month suspension.

site_title: Iswaran faces 8 new charges for obtaining S$19,000 in items including Brompton bike, golf clubs, whisky
summary: S Iswaran, 61, faces 35 charges for obtaining items worth S$19,000, including a Brompton bike, golf clubs, and whisky, from former colleague David Lum Kok Seng between 2021 and 2022. This latest prosecution adds eight counts to his existing charges, bringing the total to 35. The items were allegedly obtained during Lum Chang Holdings' "addition and alteration works" with the Land Transport Authority.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
The former minister, who was granted S$800,000 bail after he was charged on Jan 18, was originally slated to be in Australia from Feb 16 to Mar 4.
Former transport minister S. Iswaran is facing corruption charges and is currently out on S$800,000 bail.
The former transport minister is under probe for corruption.

The prosecution has no objections in principle to Iswaran’s application to travel, but has imposed certain conditions, including a cash bail of S$500,000, in addition to the present agency bail of S$800,000.

site_title: Gold flat after Fed-driven rally, focus on US inflation data
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $2,163.99 per ounce on Monday, awaiting US inflation data due this week. The Federal Reserve's three rate cut projections for 2024 remain intact despite recent high inflation readings. Gold prices rose to an all-time high on Thursday after Fed policymakers indicated continued interest rate reductions. The focus now shifts to Friday's US core PCE price index data, which is expected to show a 0.3% increase in February, keeping the annual pace at 2.8%.

images.alt_text: Gold, which pays no interest, tends to benefit when interest rates fall as this reduces the opportunity cost of holding bullion.

site_title: Investors are underestimating the physical risks of climate change
summary: Investors are underestimating the physical risks of climate change, with a growing disconnect between climate science and financial modeling. Rising natural catastrophes, severe droughts, and declining food production are disrupting trade routes and economies. A quarter of the global population experienced drought conditions in 2022-2023, and heat stress is expected to impact global crop markets. To meet the 1.5°C temperature limit, reducing carbon emissions by 43% by 2030 is crucial, but current climate-scenario models significantly underestimate climate risk, and adaptation efforts are essential for countries most vulnerable to climate change.

images.alt_text: Absence of ice impacts everything from businesses that rely on outdoor sports, to fish that use ice to protect themselves from predators during spawning season.
The impression that the barrage of catastrophe on the news gives us is wildly misleading, and makes it harder to get climate change policy right.

Ski slopes in a snowless landscape at the French Jura ski resort of Metabief, France, Feb 20, 2024. While the El Nino and other effects have played a role in the unprecedented recent heat, scientists stressed that the greenhouse gas emissions that humans continue to pump into the atmosphere were the main culprit.

site_title: China could grow faster with pro-market reforms, IMF managing director says
summary: IMF managing director Kristalina Georgieva suggests that China could experience faster growth with a comprehensive package of pro-market reforms. This could add $3.5 trillion to the Chinese economy over the next 15 years, equivalent to a 20% expansion of the real economy. Georgieva recommends steps to improve the sustainability of the property sector, reduce debt risks, and focus on domestic consumption. China should also establish a robust AI regulatory framework and expand its emissions trading system to the industrial sector to advance its green economy.

images.alt_text: Of the foreign investment in the first two months, 71.44 billion yuan, or a third of the total, went into China’s high-tech industries, including high-tech manufacturing.
With the overall jobless rate rising again at the start of the year, China’s gloomy employment situation could become a risk to social stability.

The State Council called on local authorities and government departments to come up with timetables and roadmaps to allow foreign investment in more sectors, and loosen visa rules, to make doing business easier in the world’s second-largest economy.

site_title: Vividthree affirms chairman Ho Choon Hou’s suitability after his arrest in relation to Cordlife probe
summary: Vividthree Holdings confirmed that Chairman Ho Choon Hou remains suitable for his role despite being arrested by the Commercial Affairs Department in relation to alleged breaches of disclosure obligations by Cordlife Group. Ho has been released on bail and has surrendered his passport. The board and nominating committee assessed the situation and found that Ho can fulfill his duties as an independent director. Vividthree will continue to monitor the situation and provide updates as necessary.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
Cordlife is serving a six-month suspension from collecting, testing, processing and/or storing new cord blood and human tissue.

site_title: Japan private equity deals jump in otherwise gloomy year for Asia
summary: Japan's private equity deals jumped 183% in 2023, the only Asia-Pacific market to see growth, driven by low interest rates and an ample supply of targets. This contrasts with a global decline in private equity dealmaking. Bain & Co reports that deal value in Japan nearly tripled compared to the annual average from 2018-2022. The momentum is expected to continue into 2024, with companies facing pressure to improve shareholder value and work with buyout firms.

images.alt_text: Inflation in Japan has proven stickier than expected over the last year.

The flash au Jibun Bank Japan manufacturing PMI rose to 48.2 in March from 47.2 in February. While the index has remained below the 50 index level that separates growth from contraction since June, the pace of deterioration was the softest in four months.
Japanese stocks have been booming—the Nikkei 225 recently passed its December 1989 record—and investors are optimistic about the economy.
The central bank’s decision to hike rates was preceded by news of stronger-than-expected pay rises by companies.

site_title: WealthBT: What’s next when shielding of Special Account is barred? (Ep 36)
summary: Singaporean CPF members are concerned about the closure of the Special Account shielding practice due to ageing and inflation. Investing CPF savings is crucial, and experts from Endowus discuss alternatives to consider. Key takeaways include understanding the tradeoffs of not investing the Ordinary Account and the challenges of outperforming the SA 4% rate. Ultimately, CPF members must weigh the risks and benefits of investing to secure their financial future.

images.alt_text: A larger balance in the Enhanced Retirement Sum enablre the distribution of a higher amount from CPF Life in retirement. This goes a long way to ensure a safe and basic income stream.
Investing our CPF savings is an increasingly important way to build a bigger nest egg.
In addition to leveraging government schemes to grow one's nest egg, reaching out to professional wealth planning managers can help close gaps and boost financial resilience.
With interest rates possibly reducing in 2024, how should you position your portfolio?

site_title: Russia mourns as toll from concert hall massacre climbs to 137
summary: Russia observed a national day of mourning after a massacre in a Moscow concert hall killed 137 people, with the Islamic State group claiming responsibility. The first suspect, Dalerdjon Barotovich Mirzoyev, a citizen of Tajikistan, has admitted his guilt and is being held in custody pending a terrorism investigation.

images.alt_text: Several Ukrainian regions suffer power outages on Friday, prompting President Volodymyr Zelenskiy to again urge foreign allies to accelerate military aid.
Putin dismissed prospects for a halt to the war in a televised interview last week, saying he is not interested in a “pause” that would allow Ukraine to re-arm.
Crude oil tanker Nevskiy Prospect owned by Russia's leading tanker group Sovcomflot; Sovcomflot transported about a fifth of all Russia’s crude deliveries to India last year.
“ISIS-K has been fixated on Russia for the past two years” and frequently criticizes President Vladimir Putin in its propaganda, says a counterterrorism analyst.
The attack appears to be one of the deadliest in Russia in decades.

site_title: UK government to unveil £200 million nuclear investment
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak will announce £200 million in public investment to boost the UK's nuclear deterrent programme and civil nuclear industry, supporting 40,000 new jobs. The investment will be partnered with industry leaders, aiming to make Barrow-in-Furness a hub for nuclear submarine-building by 2030, with a total commitment of £763 million.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A nuclear submarine is seen at the Royal Navy's submarine base at Faslane, Scotland, Britain August 31, 2015. REUTERS/Russell Cheyne/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: China’s younger steel industry slows net zero path, BHP CEO says
summary: China's steel industry, which produces approximately 50% of the world's steel, is expected to transition to net zero at a slower pace due to its younger blast furnaces. According to BHP CEO Mike Henry, China's unique path to decarbonization may hinder its ability to reach government-mandated goals, as European steelmakers have made faster plans to carbon neutrality. China aims to replace 15% of its steel output with electric arc furnaces by 2025.

images.alt_text: The global steel industry is responsible for around 8 per cent of the world’s carbon dioxide emissions, and more than half of all production takes place in China.

site_title: ‘Ghostbusters’ ices out competition as ‘Dune’ worms its way above US$570 million
summary: Ghostbusters: Frozen Empire took the top spot at the North American box office with an estimated $45.2 million, beating sci-fi epic Dune: Part Two, which earned $17.6 million. Kung Fu Panda 4 came in third, while Immaculate and Arthur the King rounded out the top 5. The film's $100 million budget has yet to reach profitability, but its unique and impressive opening has set it apart from other comedic series.

images.alt_text: “Art Talent Show” is both a sendup and a tribute to the complexity of contemporary art.
Disney’s annual meeting, when voting will end, is scheduled for April 3.
Rendering of the Dragon Ball theme park.
'Panda' has now taken in US$107.7 million in theatres in the United States and Canada plus an additional US$176.5 million internationally.

site_title: China uses surprise data announcements to counter economic gloom
summary: China's officials are using surprise data announcements to counter economic gloom, signaling efforts to boost confidence in the country's economy. This new strategy follows a call from top leaders to amplify bullish views about the economy. Officials have made early disclosures on flattering economic news, including a surge in export numbers and a record-fast execution of budget spending. While the impact on the market has been muted, these moves aim to steady confidence in the economy ahead of an ambitious growth goal of 5% this year.

images.alt_text: The Oriental Pearl Tower, center left, Shanghai World Financial Center, center, and the Shanghai Tower, center right, stand among other buildings in the Lujiazui Financial District along the Pudong riverside in this aerial photograph taken above Shanghai, China, on Monday, April 2, 2018. China's sprawling local government financing system needs "crucial" reforms to increase consumption, build prosperity and encourage economic rebalancing, the International Monetary Fund said. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Gucci’s China shock reverberates across the luxury landscape
summary: Gucci's sales slump in China has sent shockwaves across the luxury industry, with French group Kering's market value dropping $9 billion after the brand's sales fell nearly 20% this quarter. The slowdown is affecting other luxury brands, including Swiss watches, with exports to China and Hong Kong plummeting. Analysts predict China's luxury demand will cool further this year, with growth forecast to slow to mid-single-digits. Some luxury labels, such as Prada, have bucked the trend, while others are reconsidering their Asia strategy to look beyond China for future growth.

images.alt_text: Kering has struggled to keep up with rivals such as LVMH and Hermes International as luxury sales have come off the boil over the past year, especially in China.

Pedestrians pass a Gucci luxury clothing boutique, operated by Kering SA, in central Paris, France, on Monday Feb. 5, 2024. Kering report full year earnings on Feb. 8. Photographer: Benjamin Girette/Bloomberg
Kering joins others snapping up buildings in New York instead of leasing space.

site_title: Australian taxi operator A2B shareholders vote in favour of ComfortDelGro acquisition
summary: Australian taxi operator A2B shareholders voted 97.7% in favour of ComfortDelGro's acquisition, approving the proposed deal to acquire A2B's 8,000-vehicle network for A$1.45 per share, valued at A$165.1 million. The acquisition is expected to be completed in April 2024, subject to satisfaction of all conditions, and will expand ComfortDelGro's global taxi fleet to 21,300 vehicles. The deal is seen as a strategic move to grow ComfortDelGro's point-to-point offering and deepen its presence in the Australian market.

images.alt_text: ComfortDelGro head office located along Braddell Road on Nov 25, 2021.
Mia Pei

site_title: Cordlife to table resolutions from Nanjing Xinjiekou Department Store, says TransGlobal ‘not entitled’ to table resolutions
summary: Cordlife, a private cord-blood bank, is at the center of a shareholder dispute. Separate requisition letters from Phillip Securities (acting as a nominee for Nanjing Xinjiekou Department Store) and TransGlobal Real Estate Group sought to remove directors from its board. However, Cordlife will table seven ordinary resolutions from the Nanjing Xinjiekou notice but not from the TransGlobal notice, as TransGlobal is not considered a "member" of the company. The dispute follows recent arrests of directors and former executives related to alleged breaches of disclosure obligations.

images.alt_text: Cordlife Group's lab where corneal lenticule samples will be processed and stored.
Megan Cheah

site_title: Strong US dollar hits Thai baht, Malaysian ringgit hardest among Asean currencies
summary: The Thai baht and Malaysian ringgit have been the hardest hit among Asean currencies, falling 5% and 26% respectively against the US dollar since the start of the year. The Thai baht is now trading at 36.3 to the greenback, while the ringgit is trading at 4.7. The US dollar's robust start to the year, fueled by stubborn inflation and jobs data, is expected to maintain its strength, with economists predicting the Fed will cut rates in June, offering some respite for currencies in the region.

images.alt_text: Goh Ruoxue
A bank employee gathers Thai baht notes at a Kasikornbank in Bangkok, Thailand. The baht is one of the biggest decliners of the region. It has depreciated 5.8 per cent since the start of 2023.

site_title: China’s yuan a standout funder for emerging-market carry trade
summary: China's yuan has become an attractive funding currency for emerging-market carry trades amid a pause in dollar-funded trades and signs the Federal Reserve may not ease monetary policy as aggressively. The yuan's low volatility and stable trading range make it suitable for carry trades, while a surprise rate hike in Taiwan has strengthened its appeal. China's managed currency has been kept in a tight range, with little scope for appreciation, and officials appear comfortable with further depreciation. The yuan's implied volatility has hit its lowest since 2017, and offshore yuan interest rates have fallen to around 3%.

images.alt_text: The US dollar rises against all G10 currencies except the yen, as the relatively strong US economy and high interest rates draw investment flows.

site_title: Japan’s top currency diplomat says yen weakness doesn’t reflect fundamentals
summary: Japan's top currency diplomat, Masato Kanda, stated that the yen's current weakness doesn't reflect its fundamentals, describing recent fluctuations as "speculative." The yen has weakened to 151.27 to the dollar, nearing a 32-year-low. Kanda warned that yen weakness could harm people's livelihoods through higher import costs, and he's prepared to respond to the currency's move. He emphasized that yen weakness has a negative effect on the economy, but didn't specify a target exchange level.

images.alt_text: The island nation’s active dealmaking scene runs counter to the doldrums private equity is facing around the world.
China’s managed currency has been kept in a tight range by Beijing this year, with little scope for appreciation given the sluggish economic conditions.
FILE PHOTO: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) is seen before a news conference in Bern, Switzerland December 14, 2023. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo
Nikkei 225 Stock Average’s jump above 40,000 to all-time highs has led to Japanese individuals betting on more gains.
The firm now expects USD/JPY to trade around 155, 150, and 145 in three, six and 12 months, compared with previous forecasts of 145, 142 and 140.
The US dollar rises against all G10 currencies except the yen, as the relatively strong US economy and high interest rates draw investment flows.
FILE PHOTO: Members of the Japanese union group Rengo, gather at their annual May Day rally to demand higher pay and better working conditions, in Tokyo on Apr 29, 2023.

site_title: Small banks demand full-time office work more than bigger peers
summary: Small banks are more likely to require full-time office attendance, with nearly a third demanding it, compared to 4% of larger banks, according to a survey of 137 US lenders. This contrasts with larger banks' hybrid arrangements, where workers are on-site a few days a week. The smaller banks' stricter policies may be due to less competition for talent and adherence to traditional workplace norms. Meanwhile, bigger banks like Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase have been leading the charge to get employees into the office more often.

images.alt_text: The divide in who gets the flexibility to work remotely also reflects the US' racial inequalities.

site_title: Will AI help or hurt workers? At SXSW, the answer depends on who you ask
summary: At SXSW, opinions on AI's impact on workers vary, with some companies presenting it as a job-creating opportunity to modernize industries. IBM's chief human resources officer, Nickle LaMoreaux, claimed AI will alleviate labor shortages, while others, like Peter Deng of OpenAI, face booed reactions from audiences. Despite only a small percentage of jobs being fully automated, the majority will change dramatically, according to experts. The debate highlights the complexity of AI's role in the workforce.

images.alt_text: The skills needed for jobs will change by at least 68 per cent by 2030 due to the impact of AI.

site_title: ‘Buy now, pay later’ is not dead
summary: Key players in the "buy now, pay later" (BNPL) market are doubling down on the service despite its recent struggles. Indonesian tech company GoTo and e-commerce platform TikTok are launching a BNPL product, while Shopee plans to expand its BNPL service to all users and physical stores. Despite the challenges faced by other BNPL players, large marketplaces with large transaction volumes and recurring users may find value in offering the service. TikTok's captive audience of young consumers makes its foray into BNPL particularly potent, and the company may become a challenger in the fintech arena.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
GoTo Financial wants to be the preferred partner of TikTok Shop in Indonesia.
GoTo expects to achieve group adjusted Ebitda breakeven for the full year in 2024.

site_title: Once high-flying bankers in Hong Kong become a lost generation
summary: Hong Kong's finance industry is struggling due to US-China geopolitical tensions, leading to a decline in IPOs, stock prices, and economic prospects. The number of finance professionals in Hong Kong has dropped by over 600 since 2021, with many considering a career change or relocation to the mainland. Layoffs by Wall Street firms and a retreat of global capital into China have exacerbated the situation. Experts predict a 20% drop in compensation for bankers, with some considering lifestyle adjustments and re-evaluating their self-worth. The city's economy is expected to slow, with GDP growth forecast to 1.8% this year.

images.alt_text: hong kong hkex Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg

site_title:
US dollar strengthens after big shift 
in global rate outlook
summary: The US dollar strengthened against other major currencies, including the yen and euro, following a shift in global monetary policy as the Swiss National Bank and central banks in developing countries cut rates. The dollar rose 0.45% in the dollar index and 0.12% against the yen, while the euro fell 0.5% and the Swiss franc lost 1.7% against the dollar. The Swiss rate cut marked a definitive shift in interest rate policy, with expectations of policy easing in China also contributing to the dollar's gains.

images.alt_text: S-E Asian currencies hammered in wobbly quarter, woes persist

site_title: Sinopec 2023 profit falls 13% on oil prices, refining record
summary: China's largest fuel processor, Sinopec, reported a 13% decline in annual profits to 58.3 billion yuan (S$11 billion) due to lower oil prices and a record year for refining and imports. Global oil prices fell 17% in 2023, reducing drilling costs and crude prices. This decline offset the increased refining output, leading to a lower net income compared to 2022.

site_title: Mentors are valuable co-pilots in today’s turbulent job market
summary: The job market has become increasingly competitive, with many professionals citing career progression as a key need. However, traditional education may not keep pace with rapid industry changes, leading to skills gaps. Mentorship is seen as a solution to help individuals navigate this competitive landscape, with 55% of mature professionals stating it would improve their employability. The government has also recognized the need to support workers in upgrading their skills, with the top-up of SkillsFuture credits. A personalized and trusted guide, such as mentorship, can provide emotional support, coping strategies, and a realistic perspective on achieving work-life harmony, particularly during times of job insecurity.

images.alt_text: Workers have turned to job-hopping as a mean to hopefully fast-track their career, but experts warn that some downsides persist, especially in today's economy.
Google is increasing its reliance on its trust and safety staff, even if it’s doing so with fewer people.
Several top technology companies including Microsoft have announced head-count reductions in recent weeks.

site_title: S-Reits gain on Fed chair Powell reaffirming three rate cuts to come this year
summary: Singapore-listed Reits and property trusts gained after the Federal Reserve reaffirmed its projection of three interest rate cuts this year, with institutions net buying S$5.7 million and retail investors net selling S$12.3 million. The Reit sector is expected to continue outperforming due to the Fed's more accommodative stance, with diversified and industrial Reits seeing the most institutional inflows. The top gainers among S-Reits and property trusts were hospitality trusts, which reported year-on-year growth in distribution per unit in FY2023.

images.alt_text: ST20190726_201954166463  Kua Chee Siong/ pixgeneric/ Generic scenes as seen from level 17 of the Mapletree Business City located on Pasir Panjang Road.

site_title: Taka Jewellery sets sights on overseas trade shows for post-pandemic growth revival
summary: Taka Jewellery is pinning its hopes on overseas trade shows for post-pandemic growth revival, driven by a surge in demand from new trade buyers in South-east Asia and South Asia. The group's wholesale and exhibition segment posted revenue of S$27.1 million in the first half of 2023, a 6.2% decline from the same period a year earlier. Despite a 1.6% decline in total revenue and a 14% decline in net profit, the company expects its overall revenue for FY2024 to surpass that of FY2023 and FY2020.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
No final dividend has been declared, as the company said it strives to conserve cash for working capital purposes.
TLV Holdings has changed its name to Taka Jewellery Holdings

site_title: Biden signs US$1.2 trillion funding Bill, ends shutdown threat
summary: US President Joe Biden signed a $1.2 trillion funding package, averting a partial government shutdown. The package increases defense appropriations by 3% while keeping overall domestic spending flat. The White House announced the signing after the Senate approved the package, ending a partisan tug-of-war over amendments. Biden praised the passage but urged lawmakers to approve stalled assistance for Ukraine, Israel, and Indo-Pacific allies, as well as border security measures. The package keeps the government running until September 30.

images.alt_text: The U.S. Capitol in Washington, March 22, 2024. President Joe Biden signed a $1.2 trillion spending package on Saturday, putting an end to the prospect of a government shutdown after the legislation passed a rushed series of congressional votes with bipartisan support and landed on his desk just after 2 a.m. on March 23, 2024. (Kent Nishimura/The New York Times)

site_title: Thai opposition figure widens lead over prime minister in poll
summary: Thai opposition leader Pita Limjaroenrat of the Move Forward Party has widened his lead over Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin, with an approval rating of 42.75% in a quarterly survey, up from 39.4% in the previous poll. Srettha's rating fell to 17.75% from 22.35%. The Move Forward Party faces challenges, including a potential dissolution by the Election Commission, which could ban its leaders for 10 years. The party's progressive agenda has sparked opposition from the pro-military royalist establishment.

site_title: More middle managers are being laid off
summary: Middle managers are facing increased layoffs, with nearly a third of corporate cuts in 2024 being attributed to them, up from 20% in 2018. The trend is attributed to companies seeking to boost efficiency, with Cody Sandell, a former middle manager, stating that the position is "the most dangerous" due to the uncertainty it creates. As a result, middle managers are being reassessed, and companies are reevaluating their organizational structures to reduce costs and increase productivity.

images.alt_text: Several top technology companies including Microsoft have announced head-count reductions in recent weeks.

site_title: AI expected to continue driving Taiwanese stock market
summary: Taiwan's stock market is expected to continue driving growth, driven by the artificial intelligence (AI) frenzy, with the FTSE Taiwan Index Futures contract up 9.74% year-to-date. The contract is expected to trade within a range of 1,720 to 1,770, with a key psychological resistance level of 1,700. TSMC, a major semiconductor manufacturer, accounts for 43% of the uncapped index and 22.43% of the capped index, reducing concentration risk. The contract has been on an uptrend since October 2022, with a recent "Golden Cross" and bullish RSI indicator supporting the bullish thesis.

images.alt_text: Bull statues are placed in font of screens showing the Hang Seng stock index and stock prices outside Exchange Square, in Hong Kong, China, August 18, 2023. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu

site_title: Manulife US Reit’s new leaders will have to meet asset disposition targets, win back investor trust
summary: Manulife US Reit (MUST) has seen a leadership change with the departure of key executives, including CEO Tripp Gantt and CFO Robert Wong. The new leadership, led by CEO John Casasante and CFO Mushtaque Muhammad Ali, aims to execute the trust's recapitalisation plan, which includes raising at least $328.7 million from asset sales by June 2025. MUST's units have seen a 1.8% dip, but recent purchases by board members suggest optimism. The trust is now viewed as an event-driven counter, rather than an income-oriented investment, and its depressed market value may rebound if the US office property market recovers.

site_title: Japan’s stock boom gets broader support than just exporters
summary: Japan's stock market has reached record highs, with the Nikkei 225 Stock Average exceeding 40,000, despite a first interest-rate hike since 2007. The Bank of Japan's decision to end its negative interest-rate regime has boosted investors' confidence in the economy, with Morgan Stanley maintaining its target for the Topix equity gauge to reach 3,100. Foreign investors, including Warren Buffett, have also contributed to the surge, with individual investors returning to the market. Analysts predict further gains, with some forecasting the Nikkei could reach 45,000 by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: In January and February, India’s startups raised about US$900 million – a pace that signals another slow year after a six-year low of just US$8 billion in 2023, Venture Intelligence data showed.
What sets Shein apart from rivals is a hyper-efficient supply chain and product development process, analysts say.
Hong Kong lost two per cent and Shanghai gave back more than one per cent, with Sydney, Singapore, Seoul, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta also down at mid day on Friday.
The Nikkei marks a record closing high of 40,815.66, up more than 2 per cent on the day, after also setting a fresh all-time intraday peak of 40,823.32.

site_title: Best World International seeks to delist by selective capital reduction; shareholders requisition EGM on cash reserves, dividends, directors’ pay
summary: Best World International is seeking to delist from the Singapore Exchange by way of a selective capital reduction due to poor consumer sentiment and growth headwinds in its China market. Shareholders have requisitioned an extraordinary general meeting to approve the proposal, which also requires confirmation from the High Court. If approved, shareholders will receive cash for their cancelled shares, with the company citing the need for a more capital-efficient structure.

images.alt_text: CMG20190510-KwongKC01/拍摄全美世界控股总部的外观（BestWorld International )[26 Tai Seng Street]
Megan Cheah

site_title: Boeing asks court to block Virgin Galactic from using its data
summary: Boeing has filed a lawsuit against Virgin Galactic, seeking a preliminary injunction to block the use of proprietary data shared during a space tourism project. Boeing claims Virgin Galactic failed to destroy the documents and continue using the information, which it says would expose Boeing's trade secrets to competitors. The lawsuit seeks destruction of all copies of the documents, any work derived from the information, and a halt to further use of the data. Virgin Galactic has stated it will vigorously defend itself in court.

site_title: 60/40 portfolio mix bounces back after taking a hit in 2022
summary: A 60/40 portfolio mix, which combines stocks and bonds, rebounded in 2023 after a poor performance in 2022, with Morningstar's 60/40 portfolio gaining 18% compared to the S&P 500's 24% gain. The report found that diversifying into emerging markets stocks, high-yield bonds, and global bonds generally hurt returns in 2023, contradicting the notion that a simple 60/40 portfolio is outdated. The 60/40 portfolio outperformed in 87% of rolling 10-year periods since 1976, according to Morningstar's analysis.

site_title: China to issue new rules on market access, cross-border data flows, Premier Li tells global CEOs
summary: China's Premier Li Qiang announced plans to issue new rules on market access and cross-border data flows, aiming to boost emerging industries such as biological manufacturing and artificial intelligence. The country is also pushing to develop a data economy. Li stated that China's inflation rate and debt burden are relatively low, allowing for further macro policy measures. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) managing director Kristalina Georgieva urged China to reinvent itself with economic policies to address its property market crisis and boost domestic consumption and productivity.

images.alt_text: World Bank president Ajay Banga says that the bank and a consortium of development institutions will start publishing private sector recovery data by county income level, as a step to inspire investor confidence.

site_title: Russia’s oil is finally getting snarled by sanctions
summary: US sanctions on Russian oil tankers, owned by state-run Sovcomflot, have started to take effect, as Indian oil refiners refuse to accept tankers due to the risk posed by sanctions. Since October, dozens of targeted tankers have been stuck, with at least seven vessels having come to a halt in the Black Sea. While this may not lead to drastic supply cuts, western regulators are considering further tightening of sanctions, which could further constrict Russian petroleum revenues.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Crude oil tanker Nevskiy Prospect, owned by Russia's leading tanker group Sovcomflot, transits the Bosphorus in Istanbul, Turkey September 6, 2020. REUTERS/Yoruk Isik/File Photo

site_title: Patients hate ‘forever’ drugs. Is Wegovy different?
summary: Patients with obesity are taking "forever" drugs like Wegovy and Zepbound more faithfully than most patients take other chronic medications, reversing the trend of non-adherence. In one small study, patients stopped refilling prescriptions for months due to side effects or insurance issues, but most continued taking the drugs. Doctors report that patients intend to take the obesity drugs forever and are thrilled when they stop needing other medications. A national survey found that patients were more likely to start taking the drugs when told they would gain weight back if they stopped, highlighting the stigma associated with obesity.

images.alt_text: Study after study shows that most people don’t take the medicines prescribed for them, but doctors are saying that with the blockbuster obesity drugs Wegovy and Zepbound, patients seem to take them faithfully, week in and week out. (Matt Chase/The New York Times) -- FOR EDITORIAL USE ONLY WITH  OBESITY DRUGS BY  GINA KOLATA FOR MARCH 24, 2024. ALL OTHER USE PROHIBITED.
Novo’s widely-used diabetes drug Ozempic and weight-loss drug Wegovy belong to a class of drugs called GLP-1 agonists.
Novo's share price soared on Thursday after it announced positive news around a trial for the pill version of its amycretin drug.
Ozempic, made by Novo Nordisk, is a huge boon to the Danish economy.
The pharmaceutical giant has applied to build a campus covering 147,192 square metres in Clondalkin which would create up to 1,100 jobs in the region.

site_title: ESG lens will keep Temasek on the front foot, says sustainability MD
summary: Temasek's head of ESG investment management, Park Kyung-ah, remains committed to pressing an advantage in the ESG lens, despite recent waves of discontent. The Singapore state-owned investor believes that sustainable business models are becoming the bedrock for future economic growth, and that ESG investment is not just about reducing environmental impact but also about future-proofing portfolio companies. Temasek has developed a climate transition readiness framework and engages with portfolio companies to ensure they are on the right track. The investor aims to reduce emissions to half of its 2010 level by 2030, and expects carbon intensity to at least fall, even if there are blips in certain years.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
The fund receives support from existing investors such as Temasek and Temasek Trust.
Dr Steve Howard, Chief Sustainability Officer, Temasek

The partnership will deploy blended finance, crowding in both concessional capital from the philanthropic and public sectors, as well as private capital towards green and sustainable projects in Asia.
The new investment will focus on green solutions such as rooftop solar.
Singapore aims to reach net-zero emissions by 2050.  Asia accounts for more than half of the world's carbon emissions and represents a US$5 trillion climate investment opportunity.

site_title: Real estate investors sitting on ‘huge’ CO2 risk turn to lawyers
summary: European Union lawmakers passed the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive, requiring property owners to invest in large-scale renovations to improve building energy efficiency and reduce carbon emissions. The directive aims to meet the bloc's Paris Agreement commitment, but real estate investors face significant writedowns due to high interest rates. The rollout will be gradual, lasting over a decade, and property owners that fall behind risk being saddled with assets that can no longer be sold or rented. The EU estimates a 275 billion euro annual investment need to meet its climate requirements.

images.alt_text: Singapore aims to reach net-zero emissions by 2050.  Asia accounts for more than half of the world's carbon emissions and represents a US$5 trillion climate investment opportunity.

site_title: Why private credit is booming and banks are fighting back
summary: Private credit funds are booming, attracting billions from wealthy investors, retirement plans, and even banks. With US$1.7 trillion in assets under management, private credit has become a rival to mainstream lending for businesses. Funds offer flexible terms, lower pricing, and the ability to defer interest payments, making them appealing to companies struggling with financial strain. However, the lack of transparency, liquidity, and potential for defaults during a recession raise concerns. Regulators are taking steps to increase oversight, but the industry remains largely unregulated, leaving its long-term viability uncertain.

site_title: What you need to know about the fight over the abortion pill
summary: The US Supreme Court is set to hear arguments on March 26 in a case that could limit access to the abortion pill mifepristone, which is used by 63% of US women to terminate pregnancies. The FDA approved mifepristone in 2000, but anti-abortion groups argue that the approval process was rushed and that the agency's subsequent decisions to expand access to the drug were unlawful. The court's decision could further restrict access to abortion at a time when it is already significantly reduced in the US.

images.alt_text: Musk in December asks the justices to take up his appeal after a lower court upheld his consent decree with the SEC that arose after he posted on Twitter, now called X, in 2018 that he had “funding secured” to take his electric car company Tesla private.

Peter Navarro talks to the media before turning himself in at a federal correctional institution to begin his prison sentence for defying a subpoena from a panel that investigated the Jan 6, 2021, attack on the US Capitol, in Miami, Florida,  March 19, 2024.

site_title: Chinese city seizes on spicy food frenzy, before crowds fade
summary: A Chinese city, Tianshui, has capitalized on a viral food trend, "malatang," a spicy soup-like dish, to attract tourists, with online travel agency searches increasing 616% and hotel bookings jumping 76% in a week. The city's efforts seem to be paying off, with local businesses seeing a surge in revenue, but experts warn that the trend may be short-lived, and the city needs to create more tourism activities for a sustainable economic boost.

images.alt_text: Singapore remains a top draw for Chinese travellers who consider crime one of their main concerns.
Asean-5 economies are set to benefit from recovering tourism and trends including supply chain diversification.
Real estate remains a major challenge.

site_title: A documentary that gets how tricky it is to understand art
summary: A documentary titled "Art Talent Show" explores the complexities of contemporary art through a sendup and tribute to the process of selecting students for Prague's Academy of Fine Arts. The film follows hopeful applicants as they face grueling entrance exams, including faculty who challenge their views on art and society. With a witty and patient observational style, "Art Talent Show" shines a light on the intricate relationships between identity, craft, and art, offering a humorous yet thought-provoking look at the art world.

site_title: China’s Didi swings to profit in fourth quarter
summary: China's largest ride-hailing company, Didi Global, reported a fourth-quarter profit of 818 million yuan (S$152.6 million) in the three months ending Dec 31, reversing a year-ago loss. Revenues jumped 55.4% to 49.4 billion yuan. The company's recovery is seen as a gradual improvement after prolonged regulatory scrutiny.

site_title: Goldman Sachs sees Germany’s investment allure coming back
summary: Goldman Sachs analysts predict Germany's economy will recover from its recession, driven by improving investor confidence, lower interest rates, and growing startup activity. Despite struggling with structural challenges, German industrial companies are exploring expansion options, and tech startups are promising to spur deal flow and massive investments in infrastructure. The European Central Bank's potential interest rate cut could further boost the economy, with global deal values up 24% this year.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index ends flat but notched its ninth straight weekly gain after logging another intraday all-time high earlier in the day.
Germany is broadly expected to enter another technical recession in the first quarter of this year, after its economy shrank by 0.3 per cent in the final quarter of last year.
The Swiss National Bank has become the first major central bank to ease its policy with a surprise 25 basis point cut to its key rate.

site_title: Investors are underestimating the physical risks of climate change
summary: Investors are underestimating the physical risks of climate change, according to a growing disconnect between climate science and financial modeling. Rising natural catastrophes, severe droughts, and heat stress are disrupting global markets, with a quarter of the global population experiencing drought conditions in 2022-2023. The urgency to reduce emissions by 43% by 2030 to limit global warming to 1.5°C is becoming increasingly obvious, but financial markets may experience elevated volatility sooner than expected due to disorderly transitions or more severe physical risks.

images.alt_text: Absence of ice impacts everything from businesses that rely on outdoor sports, to fish that use ice to protect themselves from predators during spawning season.
The impression that the barrage of catastrophe on the news gives us is wildly misleading, and makes it harder to get climate change policy right.

Ski slopes in a snowless landscape at the French Jura ski resort of Metabief, France, Feb 20, 2024. While the El Nino and other effects have played a role in the unprecedented recent heat, scientists stressed that the greenhouse gas emissions that humans continue to pump into the atmosphere were the main culprit.

site_title: US Congress averts government shutdown, passing US$1.2 trillion bill
summary: US Congress has passed a $1.2 trillion budget bill, averting a government shutdown. The 1,012-page bill funds the Defense Department with $886 billion, including a raise for US troops. President Joe Biden is expected to sign the bill, keeping federal agencies, including Homeland Security, Justice, and State, funded through September 30. The bill passed with a vote of 74-24 in the Democratic-majority Senate.

images.alt_text: The funding would add to the fast-growing national debt that now totals nearly US$34.6 trillion.
The Swiss National Bank has become the first major central bank to ease its policy with a surprise 25 basis point cut to its key rate.
The non-binding resolution, proposed by the United States and co-sponsored by China and over 120 other nations, also advocates the strengthening of privacy policies.
The US national debt stands at US$34.5 trillion, representing about 99 per cent of GDP, and could rise to 166 per cent of GDP by 2054.

site_title: Sabana Reit trustee sets up internalisation committee with Quarz Capital staff among members
summary: The trustee of Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit) has established an internalisation committee, including Quarz Capital staff, to implement resolutions passed at the March 8 extraordinary general meeting (EGM). Unitholders voted in favour of eight out of 10 resolutions, which include directing the trustee to form the committee and acquiring the existing external manager within a month for a maximum price of S$10 million. The trustee has made progress on implementing the resolutions, including contacting the committee members and seeking guidance from the Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Singapore Exchange.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio.
Japan's Nikkei 225 has breached 40,000 for the first time earlier this month, following years of corporate governance reform efforts.
While having more internally-managed listed-Reits can be welcomed, Sabana Reit should explore exit options instead of pursuing internalisation of its management.

site_title: Barren fields and empty stomachs: Afghanistan’s long, punishing drought
summary: Afghanistan is experiencing a prolonged drought, displacing entire villages and leaving millions of children malnourished. The country, highly vulnerable to climate change, has seen half of one village and the entirety of another depart in search of survival. The drought has resulted in scarce water, with salt-laced water sources cracking hands and clothes. With no relief in sight, impoverished families are facing deeper desperation, exacerbating the nation's already dire situation.

images.alt_text: Governments and policymakers must prioritise preparedness and resilience-building at national and regional levels to address food security issues and mitigate future impacts.
The World Meteorological Organization confirmed that 2023 was by far the hottest year ever recorded.
Last year, BP said its carbon emissions would not fall as quickly as anticipated, as it posted record annual profit thanks to soaring oil and gas prices.

site_title: China commerce minister meets Apple’s Cook
summary: China's commerce minister Wang Wentao met with Apple CEO Tim Cook to discuss Apple's development in China, Sino-US economic and trade relations, and rising competition from domestic rivals. Wang emphasized the importance of a stable business environment for bilateral relations, while Cook opened a new Apple store in Shanghai. The meeting comes as Apple battles falling iPhone sales in China.

images.alt_text: This photo taken on October 30, 2023 shows a poster for the new iPhone 15 at an Apple store in Shenyang, in China's northeastern Liaoning province. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: How Biden could try to coerce Israel to change its war strategy
summary: US President Joe Biden may try to exert pressure on Israel to change its war strategy in the Gaza Strip, amid a growing humanitarian crisis. Critics argue that the US should use harder leverage to force Israel to scale back its military campaign, allow more humanitarian aid into Gaza, and refrain from invading the city of Rafah. The Biden administration has already presented a draft UN resolution calling for an immediate and sustained ceasefire, but it was vetoed by Russia and China. The US has significant influence over Israel through military aid, diplomatic support, and sanctions, and some former officials suggest that Biden should declare Israel in violation of international law to limit US aid.

site_title: Sustainable aviation fuel costs must be lower, Exxon VP says
summary: Exxon Mobil Senior Vice President Jack Williams stated that the high cost of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) is a major obstacle to its widespread adoption. SAF, made from plant or animal materials, is up to five times more expensive than regular fuel, hindering its use despite the Biden administration's goal of meeting carbon emission reduction targets. Williams emphasized the need to minimize SAF costs to meet projected demand, which could increase from 7 million barrels to 12 million barrels per day by 2050.

images.alt_text: The greener fuel is essential to reduce emissions from long-haul flights, the source of most air-travel pollution, because electric planes do not have sufficient range.
Australia’s biggest businesses are increasingly asking when Qantas will obtain larger quantities of the cleaner-burning fuel.
Market analysts are bullish on the uptrend of FBM KLCI to continue, as they anticipate Malaysia’s economic condition will keep improving this year.
Greenwashing is something travellers need to be aware of when searching for deals.

site_title: Why is Modi so nervous if he’s winning a third term?
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi appears nervous despite being favored to win a third term in the upcoming general election. The Enforcement Directorate's arrest of Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal for alleged bribery has raised eyebrows, particularly since Kejriwal's Aam Aadmi Party is part of an anti-Modi coalition. The arrest has been seen as a tactic to divert attention from a recent legal defeat for the government's electoral bond program, but experts warn that Modi's grip on power may be weakening. The Supreme Court has ruled that Kejriwal can be released on bail, but the outcome is uncertain, and Modi's reputation as the "Mother of Democracy" is under scrutiny.

images.alt_text: In January and February, India’s startups raised about US$900 million – a pace that signals another slow year after a six-year low of just US$8 billion in 2023, Venture Intelligence data showed.
India has now signed four FTAs in quick succession since 2021 after a gap of about nine years where no agreements were inked.

site_title: US government on track to shut down as senate GOP slows spending bill
summary: US lawmakers are on track to resolve their differences for a final vote Sunday, potentially averting a brief partial government shutdown. The Senate had resisted a $1.2 trillion spending bill, but Democrats are expected to provide support, clearing the way for passage. The bill's passage came at a steep price for House Speaker Mike Johnson, who was forced to defy his conservative colleagues. A brief shutdown would not have significant impacts, according to federal budget officials, but highlights the challenges in spending negotiations.

images.alt_text: Musk in December asks the justices to take up his appeal after a lower court upheld his consent decree with the SEC that arose after he posted on Twitter, now called X, in 2018 that he had “funding secured” to take his electric car company Tesla private.
The funding would add to the fast-growing national debt that now totals nearly US$34.6 trillion.
This year, the financial and industrial sectors are up 10.1 per cent and 9.9 per cent, respectively, while energy has gained 10.3 per cent.

site_title: Video-game executives lament lost creativity at developer’s show
summary: Game developers and executives expressed concerns about the industry's focus on playing it safe, citing rising development costs and slow growth as major factors. The pressure to deliver hits has led to a decrease in edginess, with many top titles relying on well-known franchises. The industry's slow growth, predicted to be less than 1% this year, has resulted in layoffs and product cancellations, with over 6,000 workers losing their jobs recently. Some executives believe the industry's focus on predictability may stifle innovation and creativity.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on January 16, 2019, a gamer of the eSports outfit Team Vitality types on a keyboard in the training room  at a "Gaming House" in Berlin's western suburb Halensee. - Berlin, which is hosting the European championships of the world's most popular online video game "League of Legends" until the end of March, is a hotbed of eSports talent with several European teams making their base in Berlin for the championships. The idea of a "Gaming House" allows team-mates to live and play together under one roof, with hours dedicated to improving on-line performances. (Photo by Tobias SCHWARZ / AFP)

site_title: Modi’s party doesn’t control all of India, but he’s working on it
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is well-positioned to win a third term in a national election starting April 19, but his efforts to consolidate power have created tensions with state governments. Modi's Hindu nationalist vision has dominated the country, but some of India's richest states, which drive economic growth, remain resistant. The central government's heavy-handed approach has led to accusations of delaying federal funds, jailing opposition leaders, and obstructing basic services. Analysts warn that Modi's push for a "double engine" government could hurt India's overall growth and lead to a collapse of the federal structure.

images.alt_text: In January and February, India’s startups raised about US$900 million – a pace that signals another slow year after a six-year low of just US$8 billion in 2023, Venture Intelligence data showed.
India has now signed four FTAs in quick succession since 2021 after a gap of about nine years where no agreements were inked.

SBI had been asked to share names of the donors, the beneficiaries and the amounts with the independent Election Commission of India (ECI) by Mar 6 and the poll panel was directed to make it public by Mar 13.

site_title: What we know about ISIS-K, the group that claimed responsibility for the Moscow attack
summary: ISIS-K, the Islamic State affiliate in Afghanistan, claimed responsibility for the Moscow attack, which killed at least 40 people. The group, founded in 2015, has been fixated on Russia for two years, frequently criticizing President Vladimir Putin in its propaganda. ISIS-K was severely weakened by US airstrikes and Afghan commando raids in 2021 but regained momentum after the Taliban's takeover of Afghanistan. The group has carried out attacks in Iran and is seen as a threat to the Taliban's ability to govern, with the US vowing to take "over-the-horizon" strikes against it.

images.alt_text: The attack appears to be one of the deadliest in Russia in decades.
Several Ukrainian regions suffer power outages on Friday, prompting President Volodymyr Zelenskiy to again urge foreign allies to accelerate military aid.
Putin dismissed prospects for a halt to the war in a televised interview last week, saying he is not interested in a “pause” that would allow Ukraine to re-arm.

site_title: Disney criticises Peltz remarks about casting of ‘Black Panther,’ ‘The Marvels’
summary: Disney criticizes activist investor Nelson Peltz for comments on the company's focus on casting diverse actors in films like "Black Panther" and "The Marvels." Peltz questioned the need for all-female or all-Black casts, stating that Marvels should have both. Disney sees this as evidence that Peltz shouldn't be on the board, citing concerns over quality storytelling. The company's CEO, Bob Iger, has previously pushed for diversity in Marvel films, and the company has released 33 successful films grossing nearly $30 billion globally.

Filmmaker George Lucas, who received 37.1 million Disney shares as part of the company’s US$4.05 billion purchase of his Lucasfilm studio in 2012, is currently the largest individual investor in the company.
Disney has received powerful endorsements from hedge fund ValueAct Capital, and JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon.

site_title: China loosens cross-border data rules to ease business pressure
summary: China's Cyberspace Administration announced changes to cross-border data rules, easing business pressure by narrowing the types of data requiring security evaluations. Effective immediately, data without personal information or "important data" will be exempt from security evaluations when transferred out of the country. The changes also retain some previous restrictions, requiring "critical infrastructure operators" and those handling over 1 million people's data to pass security assessments. The move aims to facilitate data flows and cut business costs, following pressure from foreign business lobby groups and EU leaders.

site_title: Crypto fund Hack VC looks to raise even more capital for seed stage digital-asset bets
summary: Hack VC, a New York-based venture capital firm, is raising at least $100 million for a seed-stage digital-asset fund, following the recent decline in digital asset prices. The firm has previously raised $150 million and $200 million in previous funds, backing startups like Mysten Labs and Amber Group. This move reflects growing optimism in the crypto market, as venture capital firms continue to invest in blockchain startups, with some firms like Hivemind Capital and Framework Ventures also raising funds for crypto-specific investments.

images.alt_text: The US dollar rises against all G10 currencies except the yen, as the relatively strong US economy and high interest rates draw investment flows.
The world’s largest cryptocurrency is set for one of its worst weeks of the year after a 4 per cent retreat.
The latest twist may open way for Do Kwon’s extradition to the US, as preferred by Montenegro’s government officials.

site_title: Cocoa processor Blommer to close Chicago chocolate factory
summary: Blommer Chocolate, the largest cocoa processor and ingredient chocolate supplier in North America, will close its 1939 Chicago factory due to high operating costs and production reliability issues. The company will instead focus on its facilities in Pennsylvania, California, and Ontario, Canada, investing $100 million in the three facilities over the next several years. This move comes as cocoa prices have more than doubled this year due to lower production from key West African growers.

images.alt_text: The target cut comes after Delfi reports lower-than-expected FY2023 revenue growth and operating margins.

Sugar contracts in New York and London contracts were sent back toward the lows seen at the start of the year amid improvements in production of the commodity over the past fortnight, a market watcher said.
Cocoa prices have roughly doubled over the past year, hitting a series of record highs in recent weeks due to shrinking supplies.

site_title: Gunmen kill at least 40 at Moscow Concert Hall, Russian officials say
summary: Gunmen killed at least 40 people and wounded over 100 at the Crocus City Hall concert venue in Moscow, Russia, on Friday, in what appears to be one of the deadliest attacks in the capital region in years. The Islamic State group claimed responsibility, and US officials confirmed the claim, citing intelligence that the group's Afghanistan affiliate had been planning an attack. The attack occurred minutes before a sold-out concert by the veteran rock band Piknik, and emergency services dispatched helicopters to rescue people from the burning building.

images.alt_text: Putin dismissed prospects for a halt to the war in a televised interview last week, saying he is not interested in a “pause” that would allow Ukraine to re-arm.

site_title: Raffles Medical chair continues purchases; Sam Goi ups PSC stake
summary: Institutional investors bought S$257 million worth of Singapore stocks from Mar 15 to Mar 21, with 23 primary-listed companies conducting buybacks. The bulk of the buying occurred on Mar 15, following the FTSE Index rebalancing. Leading the net institutional inflow were DBS, OCBC, and Singtel. Meanwhile, Seatrium, CapitaLand Investment, and Suntec Reit led the net institutional outflow. Raffles Medical Group executive chairman Loo Choon Yong continued his share acquisitions, while PSC Corp executive chairman Sam Goi increased his stake in the company.

site_title: Valentino’s creative director is departing
summary: Valentino's creative director, Pierpaolo Piccioli, is departing after over 25 years with the brand. Piccioli, 56, cited a desire to continue his "beautiful story" and express his gratitude to the company. His departure has sent shockwaves through the fashion industry, with some speculating about potential shake-ups by the brand's parent group, Mayhoola. Kering, which acquired a 30% stake in Valentino last year, is expected to announce a new creative organization and may attempt to acquire the remaining shares. Piccioli's exit follows another major designer departure, Dries Van Noten, and raises concerns about the talent pool of great designers in the industry.

images.alt_text: Linda Neo started collecting art as a means of sharing a common interest with her husband, Albert Lim.
Customers line up outside a Louis Vuitton store in Hangzhou. Since 2022, the likes of Louis Vuitton and Hermes have been expanding in China's biggest cities.

site_title: In the markets, a tug of war between Big Tech and the Fed
summary: The US economy and stock market are at a crossroads, with the fate of the nation potentially determined by the Federal Reserve's meetings on interest rates and inflation. The tech industry is optimistic about the future of artificial intelligence, with Nvidia's recent AI Woodstock conference generating excitement, but this enthusiasm may be tempered by concerns about inflation and interest rates. The Fed has signaled that short-term interest rates will remain high, potentially delaying rate cuts and affecting consumer debt, which is already high. The stock market has soared this year, but the Fed's actions may slow its momentum.

site_title: ‘Strike madness’ hits Germany while its economy stumbles
summary: Germany is experiencing "strike madness," with the longest strike in postwar history at a scrap metal plant in Leipzig, lasting 136 days. The country, once an economic powerhouse, is now the slowest-growing among the 20 eurozone countries. Workers, including 56-year-old Jonny Bohne, are protesting poor working conditions and wages, with some vowing not to return to work until their demands are met. The strike has become a symbol of the nation's labor unrest, a rare phenomenon in a country known for harmonious labor relations.

site_title: The mystery of US interest rates
summary: US interest rates are significantly higher than anticipated five years ago, with the 30-year Treasury rate currently around two percentage points. This surge is attributed to the Federal Reserve's efforts to curb inflation and slow down the economy, despite a strong labor market. The neutral interest rate, the level necessary to bring about an adjustment between consumption and investment, is estimated to be lower than previously thought. The Fed is cautious about cutting rates, fearing that a slowdown could lead to a recession, and instead focuses on monitoring labor market growth.

images.alt_text: America might be described as a large, bureaucratic corporation, a conglomerate that is so massive, complex, diversified and self-interested that it’s difficult for it to work effectively or productively.
The dollar index is on pace to post a weekly gain of 0.7 per cent, the largest since mid-January.

site_title: Goldman revises dollar-yen forecast upward on benign macro risks
summary: Goldman Sachs has revised its forecast for the US dollar versus the Japanese yen, expecting USD/JPY to trade around 155, 150, and 145 in three, six, and 12 months, respectively. This is an upward revision from previous forecasts of 145, 142, and 140. The move comes after the Bank of Japan scrapped negative interest rates and indicated that monetary policy conditions will remain accommodative. The yen has fallen near its lowest levels since 1990 versus the US dollar.

site_title: Walmart-backed Ibotta files for IPO showing profitability
summary: Ibotta, a digital marketing software firm backed by Walmart, has filed for an initial public offering (IPO) after turning a profit in 2023, reversing earlier losses. The company, which handles promotions for over 2,400 brands, reported net income of $38 million on revenue of $320 million in 2023. Ibotta's IPO is being led by Goldman Sachs, Citigroup, and Bank of America, and the company plans to trade on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol IBTA.

images.alt_text: The company, run by billionaire founder Vijay Shekhar Sharma, has pledged no disruption to its users even as the curbs on Paytm Payments Bank kick in.
Tens of thousands of people – many from Hong Kong – lined up for more than three hours in January to enter a newly opened Costco in the neighbouring tech hub of Shenzhen.
Ebay has been losing United States market share for years to the likes of Amazon.com and Walmart.
