site_title: Hong Kong’s new national security law comes into force
summary: Hong Kong's new national security law has come into effect, imposing penalties of up to life imprisonment for crimes including treason and insurrection. The law, which targets five categories of national security crimes, was swiftly passed by Hong Kong's opposition-free legislature and has been criticized by the US, EU, Japan, and Britain. The law expands police powers and allows the government to create new offenses, including sedition, and imposes restrictions on protesters. Nearly 300 people have been arrested under a similar law passed in 2020, and protests are expected worldwide from Australia, Canada, and Britain.

images.alt_text: Shangri-La Singapore is one of the group's hotels.

Hong Kong’s retail outlets, restaurants and bars have been hammered by a record number of residents heading across the border, where there’s a booming array of entertainment and dining options at low prices.

Beijing’s fresh revelations of Evergrande’s fraud come at a difficult time for PwC, which is dealing with the fallout of scandals in other parts of its global network.

site_title: US House passes US$1.2 trillion spending Bill, sends to Senate
summary: The US House of Representatives passed a $1.2 trillion spending bill, sending it to the Senate for approval, to fund the government through September and avoid a partial shutdown. The bill, which includes $886 billion for the Defense Department, was passed with a 286-134 vote. The national debt now totals nearly $34.6 trillion. A separate security assistance package for Ukraine, Israel, and Taiwan is also pending in Congress, with some Republicans opposing continued support for Ukraine.

images.alt_text: The US national debt stands at US$34.5 trillion, representing about 99 per cent of GDP, and could rise to 166 per cent of GDP by 2054.

site_title: Startup Stability AI CEO Emad Mostaque steps down
summary: Stability AI CEO Emad Mostaque steps down amid quarrels with investors and senior staff departures. The company, known for Stable Diffusion, a popular image generation tool, will be led by interim co-CEOs Shan Shan Wong and Christian Laforte. Stability, founded in 2019, was valued at $1 billion in 2022 and had expanded into generative AI features for text and video. The move follows a period of instability for the company, which had seen significant growth and investment in its AI technology.

site_title: General Motors quits sharing driving behavior with data brokers
summary: General Motors has stopped sharing driving behavior data with data brokers LexisNexis Risk Solutions and Verisk, following a New York Times report that revealed the company had shared the data with the insurance industry for years. The data, collected through OnStar Smart Driver, included mileage, braking, acceleration, and speed, and was used to create risk profiles for insurance companies, leading some drivers to report increased insurance rates. GM says customer trust is a priority and is evaluating its privacy processes and policies.

site_title: Gates-backed reactor company’s planned application needs work: US regulators
summary: US regulators have told TerraPower, a company backed by Bill Gates, that its planned US$4 billion Natrium nuclear reactor in Wyoming needs more work before it can proceed with its construction permit application. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) cited issues with references to technical reports that have not yet been reviewed. Critics, including physicist Edwin Lyman, say the delay could lead to costly delays, while TerraPower claims its timeline is on track and the NRC's confidence in its ability to provide additional information is sufficient.

site_title: Netflix’s ‘3 Body Problem’ leaves jaws dropped among Chinese viewers
summary: The Netflix series "3 Body Problem" has left Chinese viewers in awe, despite being inaccessible in China due to a VPN or pirate site. The show, an adaptation of Chinese author Liu Cixin's novel, has sparked debate on social media with its depiction of China's Cultural Revolution and an impending alien invasion. Viewers praised the show's "jaw-dropping" moments, including a violent scene where a scientist is beaten to death. A Chinese language adaptation was released last year, with some online commentators favoring it over the Netflix version, which shifts the action to British physicists.

Netflix says it will continue to boost revenue at a double-digit rate, in part by raising prices, as it has done for many years now.

Much of Netflix’s 65 per cent stock advance in 2023 was tied to its efforts to boost sales. The risk is that Netflix shares may have already priced in much of the anticipated good news – potentially putting them in a perilous position if results disappoint.

site_title: US: Nasdaq edges to record while Dow pulls back
summary: US stock markets experienced a mixed session, with the Nasdaq Composite Index reaching a record high, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average pulled back. The S&P 500 slipped 0.1% to a record close. The tech-rich Nasdaq climbed 0.2% to 16,428.82, its third straight record close. Profit-taking may be behind the decline in major indices, with individual companies such as Nike falling 6.9% and FedEx rising 7.4% after reporting better-than-expected results.

site_title: Broadening US market rally gets boost from dovish Fed
summary: The US stock market is experiencing a broadening rally, driven by dovish signals from the Federal Reserve and a reassuring economic outlook. The financial, industrial, and energy sectors are outperforming the S&P 500, with gains of 10.1%, 9.9%, and 10.3%, respectively. This shift away from megacap stocks such as Nvidia and Meta Platforms is seen as a positive sign, as investors seek diversification and comfort in the Fed's ability to manage inflation. The rally contrasts with last year's market, when uncertainty prompted investors to focus on a small group of dominant stocks.

images.alt_text: On Wall Street, which is closely monitoring both the tech economy and the Fed, excitement over the possibilities of AI riches outweighs concerns about interest rates and inflation.

site_title: Stock listing offers windfall for Trump as bond deadline looms
summary: Donald Trump's social media venture, Truth Social, is set to list on the US stock market after shareholders approved a merger with Digital World Acquisition. The deal could provide Trump with a potential $3 billion, but he may not have access to the funds for several months due to a 6-month equity holding requirement. Trump faces a $454 million court payment in a New York fraud case and a looming deadline to pay the bond, which his lawyers claim has been impossible to secure.

site_title: Do tougher laws hamper or aid financial hubs?
summary: Hong Kong has gazetted its Safeguarding National Security Bill, which grants authorities greater power to address national security threats. The proposed legislation has raised concerns among the business community, fearing it will disrupt Hong Kong's position as an international financial center. In contrast, Singapore's tougher laws on external interference have not sparked similar backlash. The difference lies in Singapore's high level of political trust with its populace, whereas Hong Kong's erosion of civil liberties and perceived instability are major concerns. Financial hubs thrive on political stability and trust, and Hong Kong's proposed security law may ultimately harm its status as a global financial center.

images.alt_text: Authorities say the legislation – which will come into effect on Mar 23 – is necessary to plug loopholes in the national security regime.

Hong Kong's proposed national security law – known as Article 23 – will exist alongside the Beijing-imposed national security law, which covers four major crimes: secession, subversion, terrorism and collusion with foreign forces.

site_title: Chrysler to recall about 286,000 US vehicles over airbag inflator issue
summary: Chrysler is recalling approximately 286,000 US vehicles due to a potential airbag inflator issue. The affected models, produced between 2018 and 2021, may have been equipped with Sabic inflators that had moisture introduced during manufacturing, leading to stress corrosion and potential rupture. If the inflators rupture, they can cause sharp metal fragments to strike occupants, resulting in injury or death. The recall affects Dodge Charger and Chrysler 300 models.

site_title: Bosch, Lennox, Samsung vie for Johnson Controls HVAC assets, sources say
summary: Bosch, Lennox, and Samsung are competing to acquire Johnson Controls' residential and light commercial businesses, worth over $6 billion, according to sources. Johnson Controls has been working with advisers to sell these businesses, which include a 60% stake in a joint venture with Hitachi. The sale is confidential, but the companies are vying for the assets, which could be a significant deal.

site_title: Wealth in Vietnam growing fast, but low productivity tests high-income goal
summary: Vietnam is expected to experience a sharp surge in wealth over the next decade, with its number of millionaires projected to grow faster than any other country. The country's wealth per capita is forecast to more than double by 2033, driven by its growing middle class and foreign investment. Luxury brands have seen significant sales growth, and retail properties in major cities are experiencing solid rental growth. However, Vietnam's absolute labor productivity levels remain below those of its regional peers, hindering its goal to become a high-income nation by 2045.

site_title: Missile barrage raises new worries on Ukraine’s nuclear safety
summary: Ukraine's energy infrastructure was hit by a massive Russian missile attack, causing power outages in several regions. The Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant lost its connection to the grid for five hours due to the attacks on power lines. EU officials expressed concerns over nuclear safety in Ukraine, with the energy minister briefing officials on possible nuclear threats. President Volodymyr Zelenskiy urged foreign allies to accelerate military aid amid the crisis.

site_title: Oil prices slip on Gaza ceasefire talks
summary: Oil prices slipped on Friday, settling at US$85.43 a barrel for Brent futures, losing 35 cents, as talks for a Gaza ceasefire weakened crude benchmarks. A possible ceasefire would allow oil tankers to pass through the Red Sea, but a lower US oil rig count and easing interest rates supported prices. The US dollar's gain also made oil more expensive for investors holding other currencies, dampening demand.

site_title: UN Security Council fails to pass US resolution calling for immediate ceasefire in Gaza
summary: The UN Security Council failed to pass a resolution calling for an immediate ceasefire in Gaza as part of a hostage deal, with Russia and China vetoing the measure proposed by the US. The resolution, which would have protected civilians and allowed for humanitarian assistance, was opposed by Russia, citing it would give Israel a "green light" to launch a military operation in Rafah. Despite the US ambassador's warning of a "historic mistake," the resolution fell short of the necessary votes.

summary: Slovaks voted in a presidential election that could strengthen Prime Minister Robert Fico's grip on power, with his ally Peter Pellegrini leading the race to replace President Zuzana Caputova. The election, held on March 23, may allow Fico to gain more control over public media, soften anti-corruption laws, and have a dissenting voice on EU support for Ukraine. A run-off between the top two candidates is scheduled for April 6 if no one wins a majority.

site_title: Europe: Shares notch ninth straight week of gains; Italy, UK, Germany shares shine
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index ended flat but notched its ninth straight weekly gain, reaching an all-time high. British and German stocks outperformed regional peers after central banks' dovish cues. UK's FTSE 100 rose 0.6% to a one-year high, while German stocks firmed 0.2% after a business morale survey showed improvement. Italy's IBEX 35 also rose 0.7% after a bank announced dividend and buyback plans. European Central Bank head Christine Lagarde stated the eurozone's inflation rate will continue to fall, boosting economic growth.

site_title: Biden administration urges US Supreme Court to reject Musk appeal in SEC dispute
summary: The Biden administration is urging the US Supreme Court to reject Elon Musk's appeal in a dispute with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) over a 2018 tweet where Musk claimed he had secured funding for Tesla's private sale. A lower court upheld a consent decree that Musk and Tesla each paid $20 million fines, Musk gave up his chairman role, and a Tesla lawyer would approve some tweets. The SEC accused Musk of defrauding investors. The administration is urging the court to reject Musk's appeal, which was filed in December.

site_title: AI’s brave new world is going nowhere without the old
summary: Artificial intelligence's growth is driving a surge in demand for data centres, which in turn requires significant amounts of energy, often from carbon-intensive sources. To meet this demand, the use of uranium and copper, essential for data centres, is expected to grow exponentially. The European Union and other countries are investing in renewable energy, but the AI-driven economy is also likely to rely on nuclear energy, which provides a steady source of zero-emissions energy. As the demand for energy and computing capacity continues to rise, investors should look to these old-world commodities to support the growth of the AI era.

site_title: Reddit may need to ramp up spending on content moderation, analysts say
summary: Reddit, a newly listed public company, may need to increase spending on content moderation to address regulatory scrutiny and maintain a safe environment for users. Analysts warn that relying solely on volunteer moderators is unsustainable and could lead to a "dramatic" rise in expenses. The company's revenue of $804 million in 2023 could be used to fund substantial investments in trust and safety. This move comes as other social media platforms, like Elon Musk's X, have faced backlash from advertisers over loose moderation policies.

site_title: Cordlife new CEO to focus on introducing ‘stringent measures’ to enhance operational standards
summary: Cordlife, a Singaporean cord-blood bank, has been serving a six-month suspension from collecting, testing, and storing new cord blood and human tissue. The suspension was issued after an audit found suboptimal temperatures in cryopreserved cord-blood units. The company's new CEO, Yiu Pang Fai, aims to introduce "stringent measures" to enhance operational standards, including a more advanced lab monitoring system and training staff to follow standard operating procedures. The company plans to lift the suspension and resume operations once the measures are implemented.

site_title: Money laundering accused Su Haijin to plead guilty on Apr 4
summary: Su Haijin, a 41-year-old Cypriot national, is scheduled to plead guilty on April 4 to two charges: unlawfully evading arrest and money laundering. He faces up to 10 years in prison and a fine of up to S$500,000 if convicted. Haijin, a former director of restaurant operator No Signboard Holdings, allegedly refused to open his room door on a balcony instead of a door in August 2023, and had approximately S$4.06 million in a bank account linked to illegal remote gambling offenses.

summary: Antonio Belloni, LVMH's group managing director and chairman of the executive committee, is stepping down and will be replaced by Stephane Bianchi, head of LVMH's watches and jewelry unit. Bianchi, 59, will oversee 75 brands including Louis Vuitton and Tiffany. The move is part of LVMH's succession planning as Bernard Arnault prepares to hand over leadership. site_title: 2024 Hyundai Avante Hybrid review: Avante advantage
summary: The 2024 Hyundai Avante Hybrid is a full-hybrid sedan eligible for a Category A COE, offering a sharp and sleek design. Its aggressive grille and slender headlights evoke a sports car feel, while its rakish lines and crisp silhouette give it a torpedo-like appearance. The Hyundai Avante Hybrid is the only full-hybrid four-door to be eligible for a Category A COE, making it an attractive option for those seeking a petrol-electric powertrain and a lower price tag.

site_title: ‘Dragon Ball’ goes to the desert with Saudi Arabian theme park
summary: A Saudi Arabian theme park, Qiddiya Investment, is set to open a "Dragon Ball" themed park with 30 rides featuring Goku and other characters. Spanning 500,000 square meters, the park will be part of the Qiddiya City development, a 40-minute drive from Riyadh. The project is backed by Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund and aims to boost tourism, with the country targeting 150 million tourists by 2030. The park's announcement comes after the death of "Dragon Ball" creator Akira Toriyama, who sold over 260 million copies worldwide.

The deal could provide a vital cash infusion of $300 million to the social media company, which has lost millions in operations. Trump will own between 58.1% and 69.4% of the combined company, pending resolution of these cases.

site_title: Tesla trims output of cars in China amid slower EV sales growth
summary: Tesla has reduced electric car production at its Shanghai plant in China due to slower sales growth and increased competition from homegrown and international EV manufacturers. The company instructed employees to lower production of the Model Y and Model 3 sedans by working five days a week instead of six, and production lines may remain suspended through April. Tesla's shipments to China dropped 6% year-over-year, with only 53% of vehicles sold locally, amid a slowdown in electric car sales growth in the country.

site_title: Better returns for Keppel, Sembcorp following portfolio overhauls, strategic shifts
summary: Keppel and Sembcorp Industries have seen significant returns following their strategic shifts to alternative asset management and clean energy. Keppel, which aims to manage S$100 billion in assets under management by 2026, has delivered a 142.3% return to shareholders since 2021, while Sembcorp has seen a 165.8% return. The companies have made significant acquisitions in renewable energy, including wind and solar assets, and have reported record profits. summary: The US dollar is poised for a second week of gains against all G10 currencies except the yen, driven by a strong US economy and high interest rates. The Swiss National Bank's surprise rate cut highlighted the gap in interest rate policy between the Federal Reserve and other central banks, shifting global monetary policy. The US dollar rose 0.26% against the US dollar index and 0.26% against the Japanese yen, while the euro hit a three-week low. site_title: Malaysia drops controversial citizenship plan after backlash
summary: Malaysia's Cabinet rejected a proposal to amend the constitution, which would have required foundlings and abandoned children to apply for citizenship. The decision comes amid public criticism and protests from civil society groups, including Undi18. The Home Ministry had initially planned to present a Bill on the matter to parliament. The Cabinet's rejection marks a shift in the government's stance on the issue, which had sparked controversy earlier this year.

site_title: SGX seeks views on proposed cap refinement on clearing member liability for multiple defaults
summary: SGX is seeking market feedback on proposed changes to refine the cap on clearing member liability for multiple defaults. The cap aims to limit a non-defaulting clearing member's liability to meet multiple default losses within 30 days to three times its funded and unfunded clearing fund contributions. This change is intended to align the interests of non-defaulting clearing members and the market, providing greater certainty and strengthening the recovery process for central counterparties. The public consultation will run until April 24.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
SGX RegCo says that its proposals are to help issuers prepare for a low-carbon future.

For breaching SGX's listing rules, the former group chief executive officer of Eneco Energy is not allowed to seek any directorship on the board of directors or role as a key executive officer on SGX-listed issuers.

site_title: US: Wall Street muted at open, but still on track for sharp weekly gains
summary: US stocks remained muted at the open on Friday, March 22, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 7.31 points, or 0.02%, to 39,774.06. Despite this, investors were optimistic about the Federal Reserve's rate-easing stance, putting the market on track for strong weekly gains. The S&P 500 opened higher by 0.95 point, or 0.02%, at 5,242.48, while the Nasdaq Composite dropped 14.01 points, or 0.09%, to 16,387.83.

site_title: PSA International’s FY2023 net profit drops 6.3% to S$1.5 billion on lower revenue
summary: PSA International's FY2023 net profit dropped 6.3% to S$1.5 billion due to lower revenue of 11.2% to S$7.1 billion. The company handled 94.8 million TEUs, a 4.3% increase from the previous year, with Singapore operations contributing 38.8 million TEUs and terminals outside the Republic delivering 56 million TEUs. Despite the decline, the company's balance sheet remains strong with a gross debt equity ratio of 0.46 times. PSA Chairman Peter Voser attributed the year's challenges to global trade uncertainty, with the company focusing on expanding its core business in 2024.

Delivering his remarks at the conference on Friday, Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat said that while Singapore has served as a “key node in global supply chains”, the trade sector is facing new pressures including growing protectionist measures in countries and supply chain disruptions.
Potential buyers in China also have shown interest.

site_title: India’s forex reserves hit record high
summary: India's foreign exchange reserves reached a record high of $642.49 billion as of March 15, covering over 11 months of imports. The reserves rose $6.4 billion in the reporting week, driven by the maturity of a $5 billion US dollar/rupee swap and additional dollar purchases by the Reserve Bank of India. This boost, combined with expected growth of 7.6% this year, has drawn $20.7 billion in overseas equity flows in 2023 and $1.85 billion so far this year.

images.alt_text: In January and February, India’s startups raised about US$900 million – a pace that signals another slow year after a six-year low of just US$8 billion in 2023, Venture Intelligence data showed.

site_title: FedEx jumps on profit beat, improved margins in its Express unit
summary: FedEx reported a beat on quarterly profit, with adjusted profit rising to $966 million, or $3.86 per share, topping estimates. The company's Express unit saw a 2.5% increase in operating margin, driven by cost-cutting measures. FedEx also announced a $500 million share buyback and a $5 billion repurchase program. The company now expects earnings in the range of $17.25 to $18.25 per share, up from its prior forecast. Shares rose 12.4% to $297.75 before the bell, with rival UPS also gaining 3.5%.

images.alt_text: The new buyback plan comes in addition to an existing US$600 million that remains under its 2021 initiative.

site_title: Foreign investment flows into China shrink 19.9% in Jan-Feb
summary: China's foreign investment shrank 19.9% in the January-to-February period to 215.1 billion yuan, a third of which went to high-tech industries. The decline follows a series of regulatory crackdowns and concerns over the business environment, economic recovery, and geopolitical tensions. China's Cabinet has unveiled new steps to attract foreign investment, including expanding market access and relaxing rules. The decline in foreign investment follows a 8% year-on-year decline in 2023, with US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo stating that China was becoming "uninvestible".

images.alt_text: The State Council called on local authorities and government departments to come up with timetables and roadmaps to allow foreign investment in more sectors, and loosen visa rules, to make doing business easier in the world’s second-largest economy.
The strong industrial and investment figures add to evidence of more traction for the world’s second-largest economy after policymakers ramped up stimulus late last year.
Foreign institutions held 3.95 trillion yuan (S$751 billion) in bonds traded on China’s interbank market as of the end of February.
The stock of yuan loans grew 9.7 per cent in February from a year ago, the lowest in data going back to 2003, PBOC data shows.
China has kept its official budget deficit target unchanged at 3 per cent of gross domestic product.

site_title: Hong Kongers flocking to China spur CK Hutchison retail revamp
summary: CK Hutchison Holdings' retail businesses in Hong Kong are facing pressure due to a record number of residents heading to mainland China for entertainment and dining options. The company is re-thinking its consumer offerings, adding health-related products in tourist-heavy districts and sourcing more international products to attract mainland Chinese shoppers. Despite this, the conglomerate reported a 13% increase in earnings last year, mainly due to favourable performances in Europe and Asia.

images.alt_text: A exterior view of Cheung Kong Centre is seen in the Central district of Hong Kong, China, on Saturday, July 29, 2017. Photographer: Anthony Kwan/Bloomberg

site_title: Football chiefs aware of concussion risk for decades, court told
summary: The English Football Association was aware of the risk of concussion and brain injury to players as early as the 1980s, but failed to take steps to improve safety, a London High Court has been told. Ten former professional footballers and seven families of deceased players are suing the FA, the Football Association of Wales, the English Football League, and the International Football Association Board, alleging negligence and breach of duty of care. Up to 75 players could be involved in the legal action, with the court hearing expected later this year.

images.alt_text: Singapore's Jacob Mahler celebrates after scoring the equaliser in his side's 2-2 draw with China at the National Stadium on Mar 21, 2024.

site_title: Japan’s union group Rengo announces biggest wage hikes on record
summary: Japan's union group Rengo announced the biggest wage hikes on record, with firms agreeing to raise pay by 5.25% this year, the largest rise since 2013. This corresponds to an average monthly rise of 16,379 yen. The results of annual labor talks are announced in stages, with more small firms expected to follow, indicating the strength of wage growth. The government hopes the wage hikes will trickle down to smaller and medium-sized firms, which account for 99.7% of enterprises and 70% of Japan's workforce.

images.alt_text: Inflation in Japan has proven stickier than expected over the last year.
The BOJ also scrapped the yield curve control programme while pledging to keep buying long-term government bonds as needed.
Inflation in the island nation appears to be holding near the BOJ’s target of 2 per cent, thanks to higher energy and raw material prices, as well as a tight labour market.

Members of the Japanese Trade Union Confederation, commonly known as Rengo. Rengo chief Tomoko Yoshino said rising income inequality, inflation and a labour crunch were among the factors behind the big increase, adding part-time workers would see pay hikes of 6 per cent this fiscal year.

site_title: China’s Leapmotor to start production of small EV in Polish Stellantis plant
summary: Leapmotor, a Chinese electric vehicle (EV) manufacturer, will start producing its small EV, the T03, at a Stellantis plant in Poland. The production is part of a joint venture between the two companies, following a $1.6 billion deal last year. The production is expected to begin as early as the second quarter of this year using the semi-knocked down (SKD) technique. The T03 will be manufactured at Stellantis' Polish facility in Tychy.

site_title: Issue 93: Healthcare’s environmental disclosure deficit disorder; nickel miners raise production despite glut
summary: Singapore-listed clinical companies lack transparency on their environmental impact, failing to report key emissions and waste metrics. A study by the National University of Singapore's Centre for Sustainable Medicine aims to fill this gap, with a 2025 timeline for completion. The healthcare sector's carbon footprint accounts for 4-5% of global greenhouse gas emissions, and Singapore regulators are mandating reporting of emissions from fiscal 2025. The industry's lack of disclosure is attributed to a focus on profit, customer care, and compliance, but external pressure from regulators and investors may prompt change.

CapitaLand Investment views its latest bond issuance as an opportunity to access lower-cost yuan-denominated capital, and further expand its domestic channels and investor base.
In addition to seeking new investment opportunities, KIT's new CEO Kevin Neo plans to focus on increasing the value of its existing assets.

site_title: Thai parliament approves delayed 3.48 billion baht budget for 2024 fiscal year
summary: Thailand's parliament approved a 3.48 trillion baht (S$129.1 billion) budget bill for the 2024 fiscal year, aiming to boost the country's economy, which shrank unexpectedly in the final quarter of 2023 with full-year growth at 1.9%. The budget includes a 9.3% increase in spending and a 0.3% drop in the budget deficit. The government aims to revive the economy, which Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin describes as at a "critical" stage, and implement stimulus measures and interest rate cuts to counter high household debt and interest rates.

images.alt_text: The BOT has maintained that the current rate is at a neutral level, where it is supportive of growth while also helping check inflation.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 22)
summary: Cordlife Group directors, including its former CEO, Tan Poh Lan, have been arrested and released on bail amid a probe into the company's CAD (cash advance deposit) practices. The arrest comes as the company considers appointing new independent directors to serve as additional checks and balances. Meanwhile, Singapore Airlines will suspend flights to Chengdu and Chongqing from March 31, and a luxury penthouse sale in Singapore failed to attract bidders. Singapore shares closed little changed on Friday despite overnight rallies in the US and European markets.

images.alt_text: In letters seen by ST, parents who have been paying their storage fee annually have been offered refunds of $537.50.

site_title: Once a beacon of stability, Vietnam to name third president in a year
summary: Vietnam is set to name its third president in under a year after the resignation of Vo Van Thuong, who was only elected last year. Thuong's successor, Vice-President Vo Thi Anh Xuan, will serve as acting president until the party decides on a permanent candidate. The move comes amid a "blazing furnace" anti-bribery campaign launched by the Communist Party, which has been linked to recent leadership changes. Analysts say the current leadership change will not impact Vietnam's key policies, including its "bamboo diplomacy" with the US and China.

images.alt_text: One beverage manufacturing factory will be in southern Long An province in Vietnam and cost over US$300 million, and another for food processing will be in northern Ha Nam province with an investment of US$90 million.

Vietnam government says President Vo Van Thuong (above) violated party rules, adding that those “shortcomings had negatively impacted public opinion, affecting the reputation of the Party, State and him personally.”

site_title: Singapore Airlines to suspend flights to Chengdu and Chongqing from Mar 31
summary: Singapore Airlines will suspend flights to Chengdu and Chongqing from March 31 due to regulatory reasons. The suspension, which affects daily flights to Chengdu and thrice-weekly flights to Chongqing, is less than five months after the cities' routes resumed in November 2023. The airline will continue to work with authorities to adjust its network and capacity in China, with both cities serving as important regional connections for Changi Airport.

images.alt_text: IndiGo plans to add 10 new destinations in fiscal 2025 and manage a fleet of more than 600 aircraft by 2030.
Cathay’s mitigation measures include increasing the number of pilots in reserve by almost 40 per cent to up to 110 pilots a day.

site_title: Global fixed income market still heavy on carbon-intensive financing
summary: A study by the London Stock Exchange Group found that almost a third of non-financial corporate debt issued by carbon-intensive companies and their related entities totals US$5.5 trillion, surpassing the debt of any other non-financial sector. The majority of this debt is held by private companies and state-owned enterprises, which are often subject to less scrutiny. The study also highlighted the "hidden" nature of some carbon-intensive debt instruments, issued by subsidiaries and special purpose vehicles outside of carbon-intensive sectors. The report suggests that carbon-intensive issuers are relying more on shorter-term debt and that refinancing poses "increasingly urgent and complex challenges" for investors and issuers.

site_title: Clothing giant Shein in focus as France targets fast fashion
summary: France is targeting fast fashion giant Shein, citing concerns over labor exploitation, environmental harm, and hyperconsumerism. Shein's hyper-efficient supply chain and product development process set it apart from rivals, allowing it to offer a vast array of trendy items at low prices. The company has been accused of using underpaid and overworked garment makers and causing widespread waste. Despite this, Shein has developed an army of fans who praise it for making fashion accessible to those on tight budgets, and the company has cultivated an inclusive image through social media influencers.

images.alt_text: Nike is shifting its sneaker offerings as it tries to find sweet spots across categories.
Lululemon’s performance has slowed in recent quarters following a stellar post-pandemic run.

site_title: German business sentiment rises in March: Ifo
summary: Germany's business morale improved in March, with the Ifo institute's business climate index rising to 87.8, beating analyst expectations. Companies' expectations turned less pessimistic, and assessments of the current business situation also improved. While this suggests a possible end to the recession, experts caution that a genuine upturn is unlikely, and the economy is still expected to enter another technical recession in the first quarter of this year.

site_title: Shangri-La Asia returns to black in FY2023 with US$184.1 million net profit
summary: Shangri-La Asia reported a net profit of US$184.1 million for FY2023, reversing a US$158.5 million loss the previous year. Revenue rose 46.5% to US$2.1 billion, driven by a "strong recovery" of its hotel business, mainly in mainland China and Hong Kong. The group's earnings per share increased to 5.17 US cents, and a final dividend of 15 Hong Kong cents per share was proposed for shareholders' approval. The company's strategy to serve guests and customers in a more holistic way was affirmed.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
The combined effects of rebounding travel activities, relaxed pandemic related restrictions, and pent-up consumer demand catalysed the revenue growth during the period, said Shangri-La Asia.

site_title: UK’s Legal & General shelves China business licence plan, cuts headcount: sources
summary: Legal & General, a British insurer and asset manager, has shelved its plan to obtain a China business licence, which would have allowed it to sell offshore products to Chinese investors. The company has also cut its local headcount to two people from around 10, as it scales back its China business ambitions amid market and economic uncertainties. Despite this, Legal & General remains committed to growing its presence in Asia through its representative office in Singapore and Hong Kong.

Ping An Insurance Group posted net profit of 85.67 billion yuan (S$15.9 billion) in 2023, versus 111.01 billion yuan a year earlier.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Friday, March 22, 2024 (Ep 28)
summary: Asian markets fell on Friday as the Chinese yuan hit a four-month low, while Australia's central bank warned of another tough year for borrowers and businesses. In Singapore, the STI index dropped 0.2%. Separately, four Cordlife directors and the former group CEO were arrested for breaches of disclosure obligations amid a probe into the company's CAD. These market updates and news provide insight into the current economic landscape in the region.

site_title: At major China chip fair, firms ramp up call to buy domestic
summary: China's semiconductor industry is ramping up calls for domestic buying, with over a dozen exhibitors at the SEMICON China show in Shanghai showcasing products that could replace foreign-made ones. Despite US export curbs and geopolitical strains, Chinese companies are rapidly catching up with foreign rivals in terms of quality and efficacy. Beijing's push for self-reliance has led to billions of dollars in investment, but a significant gap in the global chip supply chain remains.

site_title: Insead makes big push to meet demand for sustainability-focused leaders
summary: Insead, a business school with campuses in Europe, Asia, the Middle East, and North America, is making a push to meet the growing demand for sustainability-focused leaders. Under the leadership of Dean Francisco Veloso, the school has introduced a refreshed MBA curriculum that embeds sustainability in all its courses and a mandatory capstone that integrates sustainability learnings across management areas. The school aims to train students to be successful professionals and transform their companies, as more people realize they need to develop the skills to navigate and lead through challenging times.

site_title: Stay awhile: How long-stay serviced apartments may change the housing landscape
summary: The Singapore government has introduced a new category of long-stay serviced apartments with a minimum stay requirement of three months, aiming to address rental demand. This new format will serve a niche segment between the minimum seven-day stay for prevailing serviced apartments and one- to two-year leases for private residential rentals. Developers are expected to benefit from this new rental housing option, providing recurring rental income and mitigating risks from developing residential units for sale. The URA has revealed three sites for long-stay serviced apartments, and developers may also submit proposals for their existing properties.

site_title: BOE’s Bailey says rate cuts in play
summary: Bank of England governor Andrew Bailey stated that expectations of interest rate cuts this year are "not unreasonable" due to easing inflation. Bailey expressed optimism about the UK economy, citing recent signs of declining inflation. He also stated that the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) meetings are "in play" for possible rate cuts, indicating a potential shift in interest rates. Bailey's comments came after the BOE kept its benchmark interest rate at a 16-year high of 5.25% on Thursday.

site_title: Malaysia government rejects offer to host 2026 Commonwealth Games
summary: Malaysia's government has rejected an offer to host the 2026 Commonwealth Games due to uncertainty over the economic impact and insufficient funding. The Commonwealth Games Federation offered £100 million (S$170.6 million) to support the event, but Malaysia's sports ministry stated that the funds would not cover the overall cost of hosting the event. The decision comes amid concerns over spending costs and lack of preparation time, following Victoria's withdrawal as host.

site_title: Once burnt, investors curb enthusiasm for India's startups
summary: India's startup funding has slowed down, with $900 million raised in January and February, marking another slow year after a six-year low in 2023. Investors, burned by ignominious falls from grace for companies like Paytm, Byju, and Ola Cabs, are now focusing on potential profitability and stable brick-and-mortar businesses. This shift in focus has led to a two-thirds drop in funding for Indian startups, steeper than the declines seen in US and Chinese startups. Venture capital firms are becoming more cautious, with some firms broadening their bets beyond tech startups to capture a larger portion of the economy.

site_title: Meituan’s revenue beats estimates after staving off ByteDance
summary: Meituan's revenue in the December quarter exceeded estimates, reaching 73.7 billion yuan (S$13.8 billion), a 23% increase. The company's net income was 2.22 billion yuan, beating projections. Meituan's shares have risen this year after losing over half their value in 2023. The company is exploring international expansion, with billionaire founder Wang Xing taking over its overseas businesses. Despite a slowdown in Chinese consumption, Meituan is expected to cede margin gains to curb further market-share loss and return more cash to shareholders.

site_title: United Nations adopts first global artificial intelligence resolution
summary: The United Nations General Assembly has adopted the first global resolution on artificial intelligence, encouraging countries to safeguard human rights, protect personal data, and monitor AI for risks. The non-binding resolution, co-sponsored by the US, China, and over 120 nations, advocates for strengthening privacy policies. The move aims to mitigate AI's potential harms, including disrupting democratic processes and job losses. The resolution provides a baseline set of principles to guide AI development and use, with the US, Britain, and other countries pushing for companies to create secure AI systems by design.

site_title: Alibaba-backed fintech Akulaku secures HSBC financing, aims for double-digit growth
summary: Akulaku, a China-backed fintech firm, secured $100 million in debt financing from HSBC to boost profitability. The company aims to increase revenue by 16-25% this year, driven by Indonesia's 5% economic growth outlook. Akulaku plans to expand its physical presence in Indonesia, a key market contributing 90% of its revenue, and hire local senior bankers to support operations. The firm disbursed $3.5 billion in loans last year, a 25% increase from the previous year, and saw "mild growth" in revenue of around 20% to $500 million.

site_title: Singapore shares little changed; STI falls 0.07%
summary: Singapore shares closed little changed on Friday, with the Straits Times Index dipping 0.07% to 3,217.97, following an overnight US and European market rally. The decline was attributed to rising funding costs and possible rate cuts affecting banking earnings momentum. DBS rose 0.5%, while OCBC and UOB fell 0.3% and 0.5% respectively. Despite this, the index still gained 1.4% for the week.

site_title: Australia’s Star Entertainment top brass steps down amid Sydney casino inquiry
summary: Star Entertainment's CEO Robbie Cooke and CFO Christina Katsibouba are stepping down amid a second inquiry into the company's Sydney casino operations. The licence to operate the casino was suspended in October 2022. Cooke's departure is seen as a response to the inquiry, while Katsibouba left to pursue other interests. Neale O'Connell will take over as interim CFO. The company is facing increased scrutiny from regulators due to poor management of money-laundering risks.

site_title: India’s biggest airline sees capacity growth slowing next year
summary: India's largest airline, IndiGo, expects slower capacity growth in the fiscal year starting April 1, with an "early double-digit" increase in the number of destinations and passengers flown. This slower pace is compared to a 27% capacity growth in the last quarter. IndiGo aims to add 10 new destinations in fiscal 2025 and manage a fleet of over 600 aircraft by 2030. The airline's current fleet of 366 planes is expected to grow, with over 960 on order.

site_title: Japan’s Seibu considers sale of Tokyo office building for 300 billion yen: sources
summary: Seibu Holdings, a Japanese property and railway company, is considering selling its 36-storey Tokyo Garden Terrace Kioicho office and hotel complex for at least 300 billion yen (S$2.7 billion). The sale aims to free up the company's balance sheet and capitalize on robust global demand for Japanese commercial real estate. The complex, launched in 2016, has attracted interest from developers and global investment funds such as Blackstone and GIC. A deal could be one of the country's biggest property deals on record, surpassing the 436 billion yen sale of the Otemachi Place office tower in 2022.

site_title: The great central bank policy reversal kicks off
summary: The Swiss National Bank has become the first major central bank to ease its policy with a 25 basis point cut to its key rate, marking the start of a reversal in a record string of interest rate hikes. This move is expected to be gradual, with incremental cuts and periodic pauses, due to concerns about ultra-low unemployment potentially rekindling inflation. The eventual bottom for interest rates is expected to be higher than historic lows, and mega-shifts in the global economy could lead to higher borrowing costs for years to come.

images.alt_text: Fed chairman Jerome Powell did not make any promises about his next move, and said it was unlikely that the days of ultra-low monetary policy would return any time in the foreseeable future.

US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell’s remarks, the most explicit so far about plans to slow a process that has seen about US$1.4 trillion of bonds roll off the Fed‘s balance sheet, was seen by several Wall Street analysts as a signal that a tapering plan will be unveiled as early as the Fed‘s next meeting on April 30-May 1.

site_title: China securities regulator launches inspections of mutual funds
summary: China's securities regulator, the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC), has launched a comprehensive inspection of some mutual fund companies as part of efforts to strengthen industry management. The inspections, conducted without notice, cover daily operations, training, and internal Communist Party functions. The move aims to regulate China's $3.8 trillion mutual fund industry, which has been criticized for pursuing short-term interests. The inspections follow guidelines published last month, which vowed to toughen supervision and reduce costs. The CSRC has vowed to carry out supervision "with teeth and horns."

LGFVs’ financing activities have come under increasing scrutiny in recent months as the government seeks to rein in debt risks.

site_title: Asia: Markets struggle as US data dents Fed rate cut optimism
summary: Asian markets declined on Friday following US data indicating a still-strong economy, raising concerns about inflation and dampening interest rate cut optimism. Despite the Fed's dot plot projection of three rate cuts this year, data showed sales of existing homes in the US climbed the most in a year and initial jobless applications remained low. This reinforced the view that the labor market remains tight, potentially leading to slower interest rate cuts.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index ended up 0.9 per cent at a record closing high and also hit an all-time intraday peak of 510.25 points earlier in the day.
All three major indices climbed to fresh records on Thursday, led by the Dow Jones Industrial Average, which moved nearer to 40,000 points.
Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers

site_title: India’s biggest budget airline nears decision on widebody jets
summary: IndiGo, India's largest budget airline, is near a decision on purchasing widebody jets, which would enhance its international reach and intensify competition with Air India. The airline is considering an order for around 30 Airbus A350s, with a potential announcement in the next few weeks. This move would allow IndiGo to expand its long-haul services to destinations like the UK and Europe, but also comes with risks similar to those faced by other budget airlines in the past.

images.alt_text: The greener fuel is essential to reduce emissions from long-haul flights, the source of most air-travel pollution, because electric planes do not have sufficient range.
IndiGo is ramping up capacity to seize a bigger chunk of what is one of the world’s fastest-growing aviation markets.

site_title: Australia’s central bank warns of another tough year for borrowers, businesses
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has warned that another tough year lies ahead for households and businesses, with conditions remaining challenging despite decade-high interest rates and inflation. Despite a drop in the unemployment rate to 3.7% in February, around 5% of borrowers with variable rate mortgages are struggling to make ends meet. However, the RBA expects that most borrowers will be able to service their debts, even if interest rates rise further. The bank has signaled little rate relief in the months ahead, but has dropped its tightening bias, indicating a possible rate cut in August or September.

images.alt_text: Australia is one of the world's largest exporters of coal and gas, and the largest producer of iron ore – a mineral that is essential for making steel.
The RBA expects employment growth to slow, sending the jobless rate to 4.4 per cent by mid-2025. The central bank will publish updated forecasts in May.

Wrapping up its two-day March policy meeting, the Reserve Bank of Australia kept rates at a 12-year high of 4.35 per cent for a third straight meeting, and said it was not ruling anything in or out on policy.

site_title: Samsonite slumps as dual-listing plan dents buyout speculation
summary: Samsonite International shares dropped 12% in Hong Kong trading after the company announced plans to pursue a dual listing, which may hurt hopes for a potential takeover by global buyout firms. The move, which would increase liquidity and help the firm reach global investors, comes as the company faces growing economic headwinds in China. The dual listing is at an early stage, with Samsonite chairman Timothy Charles Parker stating it would not affect the company's acquisition plans. The announcement follows interest from buyout firms like Carlyle Group and KKR & Co, which had considered acquiring the company.

site_title: S$15.5 million St Regis penthouse sale in Singapore flops after three auctions
summary: A luxury penthouse in Singapore's St Regis Residences sold for S$15.5 million after three failed auctions, with the price lowered by 14% from earlier this year. The five-bedroom suite, with a private pool and 180-degree view, failed to attract any bidders, amidst a market hit by a 60% stamp duty on foreign buyers and crackdown on money laundering. The sale will now need to be sold privately, following two previous offers below the guide price.

images.alt_text: The rising level of unsold stock may signal bad news for some projects, such as the 99-year leasehold Cuscaden Reserve (above), with an impending sales deadline this year.
The 192-unit Cuscaden Reserve has 180 unsold units.
As planning is in the early stages, there is currently no timeline for when construction will begin and more details will be shared later.

site_title: China scrutinises PwC role in US$78 billion Evergrande fraud case
summary: Chinese authorities are scrutinizing PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) over its role in auditing China Evergrande Group, which was accused of a US$78 billion fraud. The country's securities regulator accused Evergrande's main subsidiary of recognizing sales in advance and overstating revenue. PwC is being investigated as part of the probe into Evergrande's founder, Hui Ka Yan, and the auditor has faced criticism for its handling of the audit. The scandal raises concerns about PwC's reputation and its role in the global accounting industry.

images.alt_text: (FILES) A general view shows the Evergrande Center building in Shanghai on September 22, 2021. Troubled Chinese real estate giant Evergrande will have until January to put together a restructuring plan, a Hong Kong court ruled on Monday, extending a deadline previously set for December. (Photo by Hector RETAMAL / AFP)
Hui Ka Yan, chairman of Evergrande Real Estate Group, will be banned from entering the China’s securities market for life.
FILE PHOTO: The company logo is seen on the headquarters of China Evergrande Group in Shenzhen, Guangdong province, China September 26, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
The three-storey house, spanning 4,933 square feet, has a private garden and an internal elevator.
FILE PHOTO: China Evergrande Group Chairman Hui Ka Yan attends a news conference on the property developer's annual results in Hong Kong, China March 28, 2017. REUTERS/Bobby Yip/File Photo

site_title: Bank of Japan’s Ueda eyes future decline in bond buying
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda stated that the central bank will eventually scale back its government bond purchases but is holding off for now. The BOJ ended its eight-year period of negative interest rates and other unorthodox policies aimed at reviving Japan's economy. Ueda cited the move's success in arresting sharp yen rises that hurt the economy in 2013. The central bank will take a wait-and-see approach to assess market reactions to its new policy.

images.alt_text: Inflation in Japan has proven stickier than expected over the last year.
The Nikkei marks a record closing high of 40,815.66, up more than 2 per cent on the day, after also setting a fresh all-time intraday peak of 40,823.32.
While cost-push pressures on inflation from past rises in raw material prices were easing, service-related prices continued to increase gradually, Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda said.

The flash au Jibun Bank Japan manufacturing PMI rose to 48.2 in March from 47.2 in February. While the index has remained below the 50 index level that separates growth from contraction since June, the pace of deterioration was the softest in four months.
Japanese stocks have been booming—the Nikkei 225 recently passed its December 1989 record—and investors are optimistic about the economy.

site_title: Four Cordlife directors, ex-group CEO arrested amid CAD probe
summary: Four Cordlife directors, including former group CEO Tan Poh Lan, were arrested and released on bail by the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) amid a probe into alleged breaches of disclosure obligations related to irregular temperatures in a cryogenic storage tank. The directors, Ho Choon Hou, Yeo Hwee Tiong, Titus Cheong, and Chow Wai Leong, were arrested for suspected offences under Section 203 of the Securities and Futures Act 2001. Cordlife will consider appointing new independent directors to serve as additional checks and balances while awaiting the development of CAD's investigations.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Cordlife had called for a trading halt on Thursday. As at 3.10 pm, before the trading halt, the counter was trading down 6.3 per cent, or S$0.015, to S$0.225.

site_title: China’s state banks step in to arrest yuan slide after key level breached, sources say
summary: Chinese state banks intervened in the foreign exchange market to arrest a weakening yuan, selling dollars to support the currency after it dropped to 7.24 per dollar, its lowest level in four months. The move came as markets expect further monetary easing to boost China's growth and followed a surprise interest rate cut by the Swiss National Bank. The onshore yuan trimmed losses and last traded at 7.2228 per dollar.

site_title: Thai central bank to weigh recalibrating neutral stance in April
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, will consider recalibrating its neutral interest-rate stance at its April meeting, according to assistant governor Piti Disyatat. The decision comes amid rising bets for a rate cut, driven by weak economic readings, including negative consumer prices and sluggish demand. The economy is recovering, but expansion remains slow, with the nation's lawmakers set to pass a $100 billion annual spending plan to support growth through fiscal steps.

site_title: Thai scientists breed coral in labs to restore degraded reefs
summary: Thai scientists have successfully bred coral in labs to restore degraded reefs, a project initiated in 2016 after a mass bleaching event in 2010 left 90% of Thailand's coral reefs affected. Over 4,000 coral colonies have been restored on Mun Nai Island, and researchers hope to revive the reefs' former beauty. The breeding process is time-consuming, taking up to five years, but the project aims to save Thailand's extensive reefs from degradation caused by warming oceans and human activity.

images.alt_text: Artist's impression of the Lagoon tidal pool, which is supported by a S$1 million donation by Singtel.
Indonesia’s roughly 5 million hectares of coral reefs account for a fifth of the world’s total, according to Greenpeace.

site_title: Japan’s speedier inflation pace keeps BOJ’s next move in focus
summary: Japan's consumer inflation accelerated to 2.8% in February, the quickest pace in four months, exceeding expectations. This data will keep markets focused on the Bank of Japan's next move, potentially including its first interest rate hike since 2007 later this year. The 23rd consecutive month of inflation above the BOJ's price target has raised concerns about the central bank's decision-making.

images.alt_text: While cost-push pressures on inflation from past rises in raw material prices were easing, service-related prices continued to increase gradually, Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda said.

The flash au Jibun Bank Japan manufacturing PMI rose to 48.2 in March from 47.2 in February. While the index has remained below the 50 index level that separates growth from contraction since June, the pace of deterioration was the softest in four months.
Japanese stocks have been booming—the Nikkei 225 recently passed its December 1989 record—and investors are optimistic about the economy.
The central bank’s decision to hike rates was preceded by news of stronger-than-expected pay rises by companies.

site_title: Cathay Pacific pledges full summer schedule, normal prices within a year
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways has pledged to maintain its full summer schedule without major cancellations, with CEO Ronald Lam expressing confidence in this plan. The airline also expects air ticket prices to return to normal within a year. To address the shortage of reserve pilots, Cathay has increased its pilot reserve by 40% to up to 110 pilots per day and implemented special flying allowances. The airline has delayed its recovery to pre-Covid flight volumes by three months to stabilize its schedule.

images.alt_text: cathay Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg

site_title: PetroChina set to take Venezuelan oil after US sanctions eased
summary: China's state-owned oil company PetroChina is set to receive a cargo of Venezuelan oil, its first since 2019, after the US eased sanctions on the Opec producer. The Merey crude will be used at PetroChina's mega refinery in Guangdong. However, the company is unlikely to make further purchases if US sanctions are reinstated. China officially resumed imports from Venezuela in February, with the cargo expected to be discharged over the weekend. The move comes after the US suspended sanctions in response to democratic developments in Venezuela.

images.alt_text: PetroChina has offered yuan payment for about 265,000 barrels per day (bpd) of Venezuelan crude through its joint ventures with PDVSA.
PetroChina's net profit reaches 46.38 billion yuan (S$8.7 billion).

Electric vehicle chargers at a BYD Co. factory in Chongqing, China, on Tuesday, Sept. 5, 2023. Led by BYD, Chinese carmakers will almost double their share of the auto market to 33% by the end of the decade, UBS analysts including Patrick Hummel and Paul Gong wrote in an Aug. 31 report. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Global sugar supply surplus rises on India, Thailand, says broker
summary: The global sugar market is expected to have a larger-than-expected supply surplus in the 2023/24 season, with global production projected to exceed total demand by 3.9 million tonnes. This is due to higher-than-expected production in India and Thailand, offsetting cuts in Mexico and Brazil. India's production is revised up to 32.8 million tonnes, while Thailand's is increased to 9.1 million tonnes. Brazil's sugar production is expected to be 42.3 million tonnes, down from a previous projection of 43.1 million tonnes.

images.alt_text: Thai millers have produced 4.9 million tonnes of the sweetener from about 49.6 million tonnes of cane crushed since the season started on Dec 10.
Palm oil is one of the only agri commodities that has booked a fall in price so far this year, which has pressured the margins of companies in the palm oil production sector.
Allowing lower-sugar drinks to be marked as a healthier choice creates a false sense of security and endangers consumers.

site_title: PepsiCo to invest US$400 million more in two new plants in Vietnam
summary: PepsiCo Inc has committed to investing an additional US$400 million in Vietnam to build two new plants, one for beverage manufacturing in Long An province (over US$300 million) and another for food processing in Ha Nam province (US$90 million). The factories are expected to be powered by renewable energy. This investment follows a previous grant of an investment certificate for the Ha Nam factory, scheduled to enter operation in the third quarter of 2025.

images.alt_text: Pepsi products at a store in San Francisco, California, US, on Wednesday, March 20, 2024. PepsiCo Inc. has reached an agreement to become the exclusive provider of beverages at all Subway sandwich shops in the US, replacing rival Coca-Cola Co. as the drink supplier to one of the nation's largest chains. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

site_title: What makes a coincidence meaningful?
summary: A person's perception of a coincidence can greatly impact how they react to it. While some see coincidences as meaningful and surprising, others dismiss them as mere chance. Research suggests that our brains are wired to overreact to coincidences, and this can be due to a deep-seated bias to look for patterns and ultimate causes. However, not all coincidences are meaningful, and dismissing every surprising outcome as just a coincidence can also be a mistake. Ultimately, the line between coincidence and meaningful connection can be blurry, and individuals' reactions to coincidences can vary greatly.

images.alt_text: Laptop, work, communication, work from home.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Friday’s open; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.2% at the opening of Friday's trading, with the Straits Times Index (STI) at 3,215.3. Despite overnight gains in US and European markets, the STI declined due to mixed local trading. Gainers outnumbered losers 52 to 50, with Thai Beverage being the most heavily traded counter. US equities rose 0.7-0.9% on Thursday, driven by interest rate cut optimism.

images.alt_text: Marco Polo Marine's framework agreement with Siemens Gamesa is expected to contribute positively to its revenue and profits.

site_title: Meta’s Instagram down for thousands in US, Downdetector shows
summary: Meta's Instagram was down for thousands of users in the US, with over 5,000 reported issues at its peak, according to Downdetector. The outage affected users in the US, but no further information is available as Meta did not immediately respond to a Reuters request for comment.

site_title: Gold set for fourth weekly gain in five on Fed rate-cut optimism
summary: Gold prices rose for a fourth weekly gain in five, edging higher on Friday, March 22, after the US Federal Reserve maintained interest rate cut projections for the year, boosting investor sentiment. Spot gold was up 0.1% at $2,183.93 per ounce, with US gold futures also rising 0.1% at $2,186 per ounce. The Fed's decision, despite recent high inflation readings, indicated a 74% probability of rate cuts in June, further supporting gold prices.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was up 0.5 per cent at US$2,196.69 per ounce after hitting an all-time high of US$2,222.39 earlier in the session.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Marco Polo Marine, Cordlife, No Signboard
summary: Marco Polo Marine's framework agreement with Siemens Gamesa is expected to positively impact its revenue and profits. Cordlife Group's shares declined 6.3% after four directors and its former CEO were arrested and released on bail. No Signboard will sell its trademarks under a settlement agreement with former executive chairman and shareholders.

site_title: South Korea targets multi-country talks for chip export controls
summary: South Korea is exploring a multilateral approach to review export controls for sensitive semiconductor-related equipment through the Wassenaar Arrangement, a 42-country organization established in 1996. This move may complicate US efforts to restrict China's access to advanced chip-making gear. Trade Minister Cheong Inkyo emphasized that South Korea is not targeting any country, including China, and aims to minimize repercussions on domestic industries while fulfilling international obligations. Implementation of any curbs is expected to take months, and the country seeks to leverage its strengths to navigate geopolitical risks and "choke points" in the global supply chain.

images.alt_text: South Korean companies are positioned widely across global supply chains, especially semiconductors, automobiles and batteries.
The Bank of Korea said a premature shift away from tighter monetary settings could undermine policy credibility and send the wrong message to financial markets about debt and risk-taking.

site_title: FedEx plans US$5 billion buyback as CEO’s overhaul takes hold
summary: FedEx plans to buy back US$5 billion of its shares as part of its cost-cutting efforts, which have boosted the company's profits. The move comes as CEO Raj Subramaniam's overhaul of the company's delivery networks continues, with tens of thousands of job cuts and permanent cost reductions of US$1.8 billion. Adjusted earnings for the period ending February 29 topped Wall Street's expectations, and FedEx narrowed its profit forecast for this fiscal year, now expecting US$17.25 to US$18.25 a share.

images.alt_text: From left: EDB chairman Png Cheong Boon; FedEx president and CEO for airline and international Richard W Smith; Minister for Foreign Affairs Vivian Balakrishnan; Raj FedEx Corporation president and CEO Raj Subramaniam; US Ambassador to Singapore Jonathan Kaplan; and FedEx Express president for AMEA Kawal Preet.
Iran-backed Houthi militia attacks on container ships in the Red Sea have forced some retailers to stock up on goods before China's Chinese New Year holiday.

The inquiry by India’s antitrust body began in Oct 2022 after  the Federation of Indian Publishers complained that DHL, FedEx, UPS and Dubai’s Aramex, along with
some domestic firms, were deciding charges together
and controlling customer discounts.
FedEx now expects a low single-digit percentage decline in revenue from last year, compared with its prior forecast of roughly flat results.

site_title: Malaysia’s brain drain conundrum
summary: Malaysia is experiencing a brain drain, with several factors luring citizens to work abroad beyond higher pay. The country's goal to become a global medtech hub is being hindered by a talent crunch. Economic indicators show a decline in the ringgit to a 26-year low, while industrial production rose 0.3% in May. The central bank maintains a positive economic outlook despite rate cuts. Foreign investors are also returning to the region, with Vietnam's stocks experiencing a surge.

site_title: Alibaba sells ADRs in streaming site Bilibili for US$357.8 million
summary: Alibaba Group Holding raised US$357.8 million by selling 30.85 million American depositary receipts (ADRs) in Chinese streaming platform Bilibili at US$11.60 each. This represents a 5.5% discount from Bilibili's closing price on March 20. The sale comes as Alibaba seeks to refocus on its core retailing and cloud arms amid competitive pressures. This is the latest move by Alibaba, which has also trimmed its investment portfolio and cut back its stake in Hong Kong-listed ride-sharing firm GogoX Holdings.

images.alt_text: Alibaba has sold 25 million of XPeng’s shares in December

The leadership reshuffle at Freshippo is the latest one at e-commerce giant Alibaba Group, which has seen a number of its senior leaders depart or move into new roles as the company undergoes a restructuring and strategy rethink.

site_title: ‘Sorry, Donald’: Biden trolls Trump over campaign cash lead
summary: US President Joe Biden holds a widening lead over Donald Trump in fundraising, with Biden's campaign cash surpassing Trump's. The Democrat's numbers are bolstered by Trump's mounting financial woes due to multiple criminal and civil cases, causing him to burn through legal fees. Biden has used this to mock Trump's self-proclaimed billionaire status on the campaign trail.

images.alt_text: Despite Donald Trump’s US$2.6 billion net worth, his lawyers say that it’s been impossible so far to come up with the US$454 million bond, due on Monday.

Peter Navarro talks to the media before turning himself in at a federal correctional institution to begin his prison sentence for defying a subpoena from a panel that investigated the Jan 6, 2021, attack on the US Capitol, in Miami, Florida,  March 19, 2024.
The package is expected to cover about three-quarters of discretionary government spending for the fiscal year ending Sep 30.

Supporters of TikTok gather near the Capitol in Washington on March 13, 2024.

site_title: UK consumers turn positive about their finances, GfK survey shows
summary: UK consumers have turned positive about their finances for the first time in over two years, according to a GfK survey. The consumer confidence index remained at -21 in March, but households' expectations for their personal finances rose to +2 from 0 in February. This is the highest score since December 2021, and is seen as a welcome sign given the challenges faced by Britons due to rising costs and stagnant wages. The Bank of England expects inflation to temporarily fall below its 2% target due to the impact of a fuel duty freeze.

images.alt_text: Public sector net borrowing, excluding state-owned banks, was £8.401 billion (S$14.4 billion) last month, down from £11.843 billion a year ago.
The UK’s inflation rate has tumbled since striking a 41-year peak of 11.1 per cent in October 2022.
The Aslef union says its drivers would walk out across 16 major rail companies on Apr 5, 6 and 8.

site_title: Lululemon falls on cautious outlook, challenges in US market
summary: Lululemon Athletica reported a sales outlook that fell short of Wall Street's expectations, driving down its shares. The company expects net revenue of $10.7-$10.8 billion for the current fiscal year, a 11-12% growth rate below last year's 19%. Challenges in the US market, including slower traffic at stores, have been cited by executives. However, performance remains strong in other markets, particularly internationally, where net revenue jumped 54% and sales in the Americas increased 12%. The company plans to expand its international presence, particularly in China, and boost e-commerce sales.

images.alt_text: The pandemic-era appetite for comfortable clothing and activewear has turned into a habit for most Americans

site_title: Montenegro prosecutor challenges Do Kwon’s extradition to South Korea
summary: Montenegro's top prosecutor is challenging court decisions to extradite Terraform Labs co-founder Do Kwon to South Korea, citing procedural errors. The decision, which initially favored South Korea, may now pave the way for Do Kwon's extradition to the US, as preferred by Montenegro's government officials. Do Kwon's defense team had sought handover to South Korea, where penalties are lower than in the US, but a potential deal could be reached with the US to have him tried in New York first. The case's outcome remains uncertain.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500, Nasdaq end at records, extending rally
summary: US stocks reached all-time highs for the second consecutive day, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average nearing 40,000 points. The Dow Jones finished at 39,781.37, up 0.7%, while the S&P 500 advanced 0.3% to 5,241.53. The Nasdaq Composite Index added 0.2% to 16,401.84, despite a 4.1% drop in Apple shares. Analysts attributed the gains to optimism over the economy and Federal Reserve policy, as well as strong economic fundamentals.

images.alt_text: Fed chairman Jerome Powell did not make any promises about his next move, and said it was unlikely that the days of ultra-low monetary policy would return any time in the foreseeable future.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average rises 148.90 points, or 0.38 per cent, at the open to 39,661.03.

site_title: Expensive flights become new normal on US$5 trillion green transition
summary: The global airline industry is facing a significant increase in costs as it transitions to sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) to reduce emissions. The US$5 trillion cost of decarbonizing air travel is being passed on to passengers, with Singapore introducing a tax on airfares and Malaysia authorizing carriers to charge a carbon levy. In Europe, airlines will lose a quarter of their free emissions allowance, adding to ticket prices. The industry's shift towards SAF, which can cut emissions by up to 80%, is seen as essential to reducing air-travel pollution.

images.alt_text: perfomance, power, cockpit
Korean Air picks 27 A350-1000 planes and six A350-900 jets.
Malaysia Airlines carried 14.5 million passengers in 2023, up 46 per cent from a year earlier.
Japan Airlines says the new aircraft should enhance and expand the capacity of its international operations., with a focus on North America, Asia and India.
The airline’s flight attendants had been demanding higher pay and better work rules in the new contract.

site_title: Bitcoin set for one of worst weeks in 2024 as ETF demand falters
summary: Bitcoin is expected to have one of its worst weeks in 2024 after a 4% retreat, with the cryptocurrency's value dropping to $65,415. The decline is attributed to moderating demand for spot Bitcoin exchange-traded funds (ETFs), with a record 10 spot Bitcoin ETFs experiencing a 3-day outflow since their debut. JPMorgan strategists warn that the retreat has room to run and that Bitcoin remains "overbought", predicting further declines leading up to April's halving event.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrency Bitcoin are seen in this illustration, August 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo
The rise of many AI crypto tokens has outpaced even that of Bitcoin over the past year as the world’s biggest cryptocurrency has surged to record levels.
The largest digital asset has shed about 3 per cent to trade at US$65,380 as at 1 pm on Tuesday in Singapore.

site_title: Reddit shares end trading up 48% in market debut
summary: Reddit's shares ended trading up 48% on their first day, valuing the company at $6.4 billion, after pricing at $34. The IPO, which raised $748 million, shows investors are willing to overlook the company's losses due to its growth potential. Reddit's entry into public markets is seen as a sign that investor appetite for IPOs of promising yet loss-making companies is returning. The company's valuation is higher than its private valuation in 2021, indicating that investors may not have needed to curb valuation expectations to get the IPO off the ground.

images.alt_text: The IPO priced 22 million shares sold by Reddit and its existing shareholders at US$34 a share, giving the company a valuation of about US$6.4 billion.

To tap retail investors, Reddit has reserved 8 per cent of the total shares on offer for eligible users and moderators on its platform, certain board members and friends and family members of its employees and directors.
Reddit plans for its shares to trade on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol RDDT.
Reddit says that it and its investors are planning to sell 22 million shares for US$31 to US$34 each.

site_title: Record number of UK children in poverty: figures
summary: The UK has seen a record number of children living in poverty, with an estimated 4.33 million children in low-income households as of March 2023, up from 4.22 million the previous year. This represents a rise in absolute poverty for the second consecutive year, with 600,000 more people, half of them children, falling into poverty. The figures are attributed to steep energy price increases following Russia's invasion of Ukraine, which pushed more Britons into poverty despite a cost-of-living package worth £3,800 per household.

New research has found that as the poor become richer, they become more likely to understate their income.

site_title: Samsung still lacking in AI investors’ eyes after Nvidia boost
summary: Samsung Electronics' prospects in the artificial intelligence (AI) market remain uncertain despite a surprise endorsement from Nvidia, with investors still questioning the company's lead in high-bandwidth memory (HBM) chips. SK Hynix, a rival, has secured a significant lead in HBM chips, which work alongside processors crucial for large language models. Samsung's shares have surged 10% after Nvidia's CEO indicated the company may buy Samsung memory, but options traders remain divided, with some betting on a 70% drop and others on a 300% surge.

images.alt_text: The Toronto-headquartered startup helps its 775 healthcare-provider clients exchange images covering some 1.5 million patients, aiming to cut down on delays and costs.

The clash will take place on Friday at the annual general meeting of Samsung C&T, which serves as the holding company of the Samsung Group.

site_title: Former Zouk morphs into mod-Asian Jiak Kim House, serving laksa pasta and mushroom bak kut teh
summary: Jiak Kim House, the new incarnation of the former Zouk, has opened its doors in a colonial-style eatery. The restaurant serves mod-Asian cuisine, with dishes like laksa fettucine and mushroom bak kut teh. While the food is promising, it often veers into kitchen sink overkill. Highlights include the Tingkat of Memories snacks, which feature authentic Asian flavors, and the Garden of Naomi dessert, which offers an intriguing combination of fruit and sorrel granita. The restaurant has the potential to be a place to come home to, but consistency issues need to be addressed.
