site_title: Alibaba raises US$317 million from sale of stake in EV maker XPeng
summary: Alibaba has sold US$317 million from the sale of about 33 million shares of XPeng, a Chinese electric vehicle maker, at a price of US$9.60 each. This represents a 2.9% discount from XPeng's closing price on Tuesday. The sale marks the second time Alibaba has sold shares in XPeng, following a December sale of 25 million shares. The EV maker will continue collaborating with Alibaba in various areas despite terminating its agreement to nominate an Alibaba-chosen director.

site_title: Jurong Lake District: Examining the master-developer model
summary: The Jurong Lake District (JLD) tender for a 6.5-hectare white site will close on March 26, with a successful tenderer expected to build at least 70,000 sq m of office space and 600 housing units over 10-15 years. The development will kick-start JLD's transformation into Singapore's largest business district outside the city centre. A master-developer approach is expected to help the government achieve its objectives faster, with benefits including reduced upfront land costs and increased influence over pricing. Bids are expected to be low, with one to two bids anticipated, and prices may reflect heightened risks and elevated construction costs.

site_title: Oil slips as investors weigh Fed rate decision
summary: Oil prices fell on Wednesday as the US Federal Reserve held interest rates steady, with Brent crude futures settling down 1.64% to $85.95 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate futures falling 2.14% to $81.68. Despite the Fed's rate decision, demand concerns continue to weigh, and the US Energy Information Administration reported a surprise draw in crude oil inventories. Ukrainian attacks on Russian refining assets have also contributed to higher crude prices, with potential disruptions forcing Russian producers to reduce supply if exports are halted.

Global benchmark Brent crude settled 0.6 per cent higher at US$87.38 a barrel on Tuesday, the highest since Oct 31.

site_title: Institutional investors cool on private market investments: Nuveen survey
summary: Institutional investors have become slightly less enthusiastic about private investments, according to a Nuveen survey of 800 investors across 27 countries. While 55% plan to increase their private markets allocations over the next five years, a decrease from 72% in the previous survey. This shift comes as institutional investors reap the benefits of private investments, while high-net-worth individuals continue to show growing interest. The California Public Employees' Retirement System plans to increase its private markets allocation to "maximise returns from the highest-performing asset classes".

images.alt_text: Joan Ng
Private asset managers seeking to win over individual investors must make more of an effort to educate clients and distributors, industry observers said.
Antoine Flamarion (left) and Mathieu Chabran, co-founders of Tikehau Capital, want hope to be among the early movers in Asia's private credit space.
Market data shows private equity and private credit have significantly outperformed traditional asset classes in recent years.

site_title: Apollo offers US$11 billion for Paramount’s Hollywood studio: source
summary: Apollo Global Management has offered US$11 billion for Paramount Pictures, a private equity firm's bid to acquire the film studio. Paramount Global's controlling shareholder, Shari Redstone, has been reluctant to part with the studio, but the offer comes amid a deteriorating global entertainment business. The Redstone family considers the media asset undervalued by investors and is exploring options. This latest bid follows earlier interest from media entrepreneur Byron Allen and Skydance Media CEO David Ellison.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Tata Group is seen at a business meeting organised by the Confederation of Indian Industry (CII) in New Delhi March 23, 2009. REUTERS/Vijay Mathur (INDIA BUSINESS)/File Photo
Paramount Nickelodeon and other networks, has been looking to reduce its debt by selling noncore assets such as its Simon & Schuster book publishing arm.
Paramount, the parent of CBS, MTV and other networks, has been selling assets, such as its Simon & Schuster book publishing arm, to reduce debt.

site_title: Citi cuts London investment bankers as drought in deals persists
summary: Citigroup is cutting approximately 20 investment banking jobs in London, primarily affecting junior staff and managing directors, amid a slump in global dealmaking. The move comes as CEO Jane Fraser initiates a massive restructuring of the bank, with the goal of holding individual business leaders accountable. This is the latest in a series of job cuts by major Wall Street firms, including JPMorgan Chase & Co, Barclays, and Goldman Sachs, as they seek to contain costs during the economic uncertainty caused by rising interest rates.

images.alt_text: The logo of Citigroup Inc. at the entrance to the bank's office in Paris, France, on Monday, Feb. 27, 2023. Citigroup is building a new trading floor in Paris as the Wall Street giant prepares to nearly double its staff in the French city. Photographer Benjamin Girette/Bloomberg

site_title: Reddit prices IPO at top of indicated range to raise US$748 million
summary: Reddit priced its initial public offering (IPO) at the top of its targeted range, raising US$748 million with a valuation of about US$6.4 billion. The company priced 22 million shares at US$34 per share, exceeding its lower end valuation of US$10 billion from a private fundraising round in 2021. This successful IPO marks a boost to the lackluster tech IPO market, following two years of subdued activity.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Reddit logos are seen displayed in this illustration taken February 2, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Japanese groups, Ikea-linked investor win first Norway offshore wind tender
summary: Norway has awarded its first North Sea wind farm license to a group consisting of Ikea-linked investor Ingka Group and a Japanese power joint venture, Ventyr, to develop 1.5 gigawatts of offshore wind capacity. The government hopes this will be the starting point for massive offshore power developments in the years leading up to 2040, aiming for 30 gigawatts of installed capacity. The winning bid beat a joint offer from Equinor and RWE, and Ventyr's owners have formed a "solid group" with necessary funds and expertise.

images.alt_text: Wind turbines in New South Wales, Australia. Statkraft, Norway's state-owned utility, aims to develop and build 300 to 500 megawatts (MW) of wind and solar power capacity in Germany per year from 2027.

site_title: Undervalued Singtel needs boost from stronger  Optus performance: analysts
summary: Singtel's shares rose 4.2% on March 13 after the company denied plans to sell its Australian subsidiary Optus for the second time in two months. Analysts believe Singtel's shares remain undervalued, citing Optus's low return on invested capital (ROIC) and recent incidents affecting the company. To boost confidence, analysts suggest a stronger recovery from Optus is needed. Meanwhile, Singtel is exploring asset recycling and private equity investments to establish a valuation basis and unlock value for the company.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
This is the second time the appeal on the case has been dismissed; the case is related to Singtel’s intra-group cross-border financing to acquire Optus in 2001.
Singtel says it intends to remain invested in Airtel over the long term.
Optus' spokesperson apologise for the non-compliance and says the telco has agreed to undergo an independent review under a court-enforcable undertaking.
Singtel said that it views its stake in Optus as “strategic” and believes in the long-term outlook of the business.

site_title: US Federal Reserve’s Powell says balance sheet drawdown taper coming soon
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell said the central bank is nearing a decision to slow its balance sheet run-off, a process that has seen about $1.4 trillion of bonds roll off the Fed's balance sheet. This move, known as tapering, may allow the Fed to shed more bonds than expected and could be announced as early as the Fed's next meeting on April 30-May 1. The Fed aims to reduce its holdings to ensure the financial system has enough liquidity and to allow for normal levels of volatility in money market rates.

images.alt_text: Mortgage rates have fallen from an October peak near 8 per cent, but remain more than twice as high as they were in 2021.
The three major US indices pushed to all-time closing records on Wednesday, with the Nasdaq gaining the most at 1.3 per cent.

US Federal Reserve Board Chair Jerome Powell announced the central bank stayed on track for three interest rate cuts this year and affirmed that solid economic growth will continue, Washington, DC, March 20, 2024.

site_title: Manulife faces 40% decline in US office investments from peak
summary: Manulife Financial is facing a significant decline in US office investments, with values plummeting by up to 40% from pre-pandemic peaks. The North American market has been impacted by the shift to remote work, with US office vacancy rates reaching a record 19.7%. Despite owning high-quality properties, Manulife's CFO Colin Simpson attributes the decline to structural forces such as higher interest rates and the trend towards return-to-office.

images.alt_text: Asia, where Manulife operates in 13 markets with about 13 million customers, has been a strong point for the company’s earnings largely benefiting from a resurgence in mainland Chinese tourists returning to Hong Kong after pandemic restrictions were lifted.

site_title: Hermes faces US lawsuit over ‘refusal’ to sell Birkin bag
summary: Hermes is facing a class-action lawsuit in California alleging the company's practice of requiring customers to purchase other luxury products before being sold a Birkin handbag artificially inflates the product's cost. The lawsuit claims sales associates are instructed to use Birkin handbags as a way to coerce consumers into buying ancillary products. The suit seeks unspecified damages and alleges this practice violates antitrust laws. The extremely limited edition handbag, which can cost from $10,000 to over $1 million, is only available to those deemed "worthy" by the company.

images.alt_text: Kering has struggled to keep up with rivals such as LVMH and Hermes International as luxury sales have come off the boil over the past year, especially in China.
Quiet luxury brands such as Hermes have outperformed in terms of operating margins, revenue growth and return on equity.
Luxury authenticators are like detectives gathering evidence to solve a mystery, says Carousell's Heloise Meyer.
French shoe designer Christian Louboutin poses with some of his famous footwear while preparing for an exhibition of his work in Toronto.

site_title: Sri Lanka to start restructuring talks with investors next week
summary: Sri Lanka will start restructuring talks with investors next week, aiming to rework $12 billion in defaulted global bonds. The talks, led by a steering committee of bondholders, come amid a bid to complete the debt revamp within the first half of the year. The goal is to reach a deal quickly, particularly ahead of presidential elections later this year and the IMF's meetings of world leaders in Washington, DC. This breakthrough is seen as a victory for the IMF and G-20 leaders, who are pushing for debt relief for poor countries.

site_title: US: Indices end at records as Federal Reserve confirms plant for 2024 rate cuts
summary: US stocks reached all-time closing records on Wednesday as the Federal Reserve reaffirmed plans for three interest rate cuts in 2024, despite recent inflation data. The Fed kept interest rates unchanged for a fifth consecutive meeting and maintained its growth outlook for the year at 2.1%. The Nasdaq gained 1.3% and the dollar retreated against the euro and the pound. The market welcomed the Fed's characterization of the economy as relatively strong, allowing investors to "breathe a sigh of relief."

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average falls 38.71 points, or 0.1 per cent, at the open to 39,072.05.

US Federal Reserve Board Chair Jerome Powell announced the central bank stayed on track for three interest rate cuts this year and affirmed that solid economic growth will continue, Washington, DC, March 20, 2024.

site_title: US: Muted start for Wall Street as attention turns to Fed
summary: US stocks opened with a muted start on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 38.71 points, or 0.1%, to 39,072.05. Investors await the Federal Reserve's meeting conclusion, expecting unchanged interest rates and clues on monetary policy. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with the S&P 500 up 3.18 points and the Nasdaq Composite up 18.97 points. The market's cautious tone reflects anticipation of the Fed's decision, which is expected to set the stage for its monetary policy trajectory.

site_title: Indonesia’s Prabowo Subianto wins presidency: elections commission
summary: Indonesian Defence Minister Prabowo Subianto has been elected as president, securing a first-round majority with over 96 million votes (58.6% of the total count). He will take over the presidency in October after a transition period, following a campaign marked by nationalist rhetoric and backing from outgoing leader Joko Widodo. Prabowo's rivals, Anies Baswedan and Ganjar Pranowo, have vowed to file a complaint about alleged irregularities and fraud, but Prabowo's legal team is confident the result will not be challenged.

images.alt_text: Prabowo Subianto is most likely to become Indonesia’s next president after securing close to 60 per cent of the votes, based on quick counts.
Indonesia's Prabowo Subianto won’t involve the finance minister position in any political bargaining, as he sees the post as above politics and requiring acumen in managing the budget, sources said.
During his campaign, Prabowo managed to turn his image into one that appealed to the young as a likeable uncle.
Indonesia's Prabowo Subianto gestures after casting his ballot to vote in Indonesia’s presidential and legislative elections in Bogor, Indonesia, Feb 14, 2024.

site_title: IBM eyes first record since 2013 as AI optimism fuels 19% rally
summary: IBM recently hit its highest price since 2013, with a 19% gain this year, driven by optimism over a turnaround in the company's growth and share-price returns. The stock has made significant investments in cloud and AI, with a strong AI business expected to drive growth. Despite a higher-than-expected dividend yield, the stock remains undervalued relative to other big-tech companies, with a multiple of 19 times estimated earnings near its highest in 20 years.

images.alt_text: IBM said it was using Adobe’s tools, which can generate images from text-based prompts, to help with marketing campaigns.
Singapore domestic tax law allows a company, including a local subsidiary of a foreign corporation, to deduct interest payments on debt from their taxable income in the nation state.
IBM has slimmed its operations to focus on software and services in recent years.
IBM has focused on streamlining its operations around software and services in recent years, divesting managed infrastructure, weather and health businesses.

site_title: US Federal Reserve sees three rate cuts in 2024 but a more shallow easing path
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell announced the central bank will stick to its plan for three interest rate cuts in 2024, affirming solid economic growth and a 2.1% growth forecast for this year. The Fed also expects the unemployment rate to hit 4% by the end of 2024 and inflation to fall to 2.6%. Powell emphasized the need for more data to confirm the easing of price pressures, and the Fed will maintain high interest rates if inflation does not decline. The updated economic projections show a slightly shallower pace of easing in 2025 and 2026.

images.alt_text: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell’s remarks, the most explicit so far about plans to slow a process that has seen about US$1.4 trillion of bonds roll off the Fed‘s balance sheet, was seen by several Wall Street analysts as a signal that a tapering plan will be unveiled as early as the Fed‘s next meeting on April 30-May 1.
The three major US indices pushed to all-time closing records on Wednesday, with the Nasdaq gaining the most at 1.3 per cent.
The US Federal Reserve is holding its two-day policy meeting this week, and all eyes are on chairman Jerome Powell's press conference on Wednesday.
Mortgage rates have fallen from an October peak near 8 per cent, but remain more than twice as high as they were in 2021.

site_title: Haun Ventures names first new general partner as crypto climbs
summary: Haun Ventures, a prominent crypto-focused venture capital firm, has appointed Diogo Monica, Anchorage Digital president and co-founder, as its first new general partner. Monica brings over 125 angel investments experience and a focus on backing projects using crypto solutions to protect data and startups working on stablecoins. This addition aims to enhance Haun Ventures' capabilities and capitalize on the upward trend in the crypto market.

images.alt_text: Katie Haun's crypto VC fund raises US$1.5b to target Web3 startups

site_title: Yen close to intervention levels, dollar gains before Fed meet
summary: The yen weakened to a fresh four-month low of 151.77 against the US dollar after the Bank of Japan announced an exit from years of ultra-easy monetary policies. Analysts expect the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates unchanged, but a potentially hawkish Fed Open Market Committee could lead to further downside risks for the yen, potentially triggering Japanese intervention to support it. Barclays and Bank of America have identified "intervention levels" of 152-155 yen to the dollar.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Examples of Japanese yen banknotes are displayed at a factory of the National Printing Bureau producing Bank of Japan notes at a media event about a new series of banknotes scheduled to be introduced in 2024, in Tokyo, Japan, November 21, 2022. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo
Japanese stocks have been booming—the Nikkei 225 recently passed its December 1989 record—and investors are optimistic about the economy.

site_title: Japan’s factory activity declines slow, service sector picks up
summary: Japan's factory activity declined at a slower pace in March, with the manufacturing PMI rising to 48.2 from 47.2 in February. The service sector, however, expanded at the fastest pace in 10 months, with the services PMI reaching 54.9. Despite a slower decline in production, spare capacity remains in the sector. Renewed price pressures were reported, with input cost inflation strengthening to the highest since last September. Overall, the composite PMI rose to 52.3, the highest level since last August, indicating growth in the private sector.

images.alt_text: A worker inside Ando Manufacturing Co. in the Ota district of Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, March 15, 2024. Early results of annual wage negotiations indicate many Japanese workers will secure the biggest increases in decades, in a positive development for the Bank of Japan just days before it meets to decide whether to end the world’s last negative rate regime. Photographer: Soichiro Koriyama/Bloomberg

site_title: US broadband providers to begin providing new comparison labels
summary: US broadband providers will begin displaying new comparison labels, similar to nutrition labels, starting April 10, as mandated by the Federal Communications Commission (FCC). The labels will show prices, speeds, fees, and data allowances for both wireless and wired products. Verizon will start providing the labels on March 20, while smaller providers will begin in October. The labels aim to help consumers make informed choices and avoid junk fees, with FCC chair Jessica Rosenworcel stating that consumers will finally have access to the information they need to comparison shop.

images.alt_text: The Biden administration has set a goal of getting 500,000 chargers in place by 2030 to ensure EVs are accessible.

site_title: Building stakeholder confidence at the AGM
summary: Singapore-listed companies can build stakeholder confidence at the annual general meeting (AGM) by showcasing their ability to navigate complex challenges and articulate a strategic direction for the future. This includes discussing environmental, social, and governance (ESG) risks, climate reporting, and generative artificial intelligence (AI) strategy, as well as cyberdefence approaches. Companies should highlight their plans to tackle material ESG risks, demonstrate their commitment to sustainability, and address the skills gap and talent challenges associated with technological transformation. By sharing information strategically, companies can balance transparency with safeguarding of trade secrets and preserve their competitive edge.

images.alt_text: Post-pandemic, allowing hybrid AGMs demonstrates that the board is flexible in meeting shareholders’ preferences, whether they value face-to-face interactions or the convenience of virtual sessions.
A growing cohort of investors today are looking for convenience, and appear to take a light-touch approach to portfolio management.
At DBS' AGM, Piyush Gupta, DBS Group Holdings chief executive, promised to set up a special committee to investigate the disruption to DBS' digital services.

site_title: Hindenburg shorts data centre firm Equinix alleging inflated profit metric
summary: Equinix, a data centre firm, is allegedly misclassifying capital expenditure as expansion spending to boost profitability, according to Hindenburg Research. The firm's shares fell 2% after the short seller disclosed a short position, estimating a $3 billion boost to adjusted funds from operations since 2015. Hindenburg claims Equinix is selling an "AI pipe dream" to investors, warning of a surge in electricity consumption and competition from large cloud players.

images.alt_text: Indian billionaire Gautam Adani in  an inauguration ceremony after India's the Adani Group completed the purchase of Haifa Port in Haifa port, Haifa, Israel on January 31, 2023 photographer : Kobi Wolf for Bloomberg

site_title: China to pass new rules for labelling of GM crops used in food: media reports
summary: China is set to pass new rules this year for labelling genetically-modified (GM) crops used in food products, shifting from "qualitative labelling" to "quantitative labelling" that requires disclosure of GM material exceeding 3% of the product's mass. The new rules will apply to soybeans, corn, rapeseed cottonseed, alfalfa, and papaya, aiming to protect consumers' right to know and choose. The regulation is part of China's efforts to secure its food security through commercial planting of higher-yielding GM varieties.

images.alt_text: Imported soybeans are transported from a cargo ship at a port in Nantong, Jiangsu province, China August 21, 2018. Picture taken August 21, 2018. REUTERS/Stringer ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. CHINA OUT.

site_title: ‘Arc of instability’ has red lights flashing in Europe
summary: Growing concerns in Europe over the possibility of a new migration crisis if conflicts in the Middle East and Africa spill over into neighboring countries are prompting calls for increased cooperation and security measures. The European Union's 27 presidents and prime ministers will discuss these issues at a summit this week, amid tensions in the Middle East, a catastrophic famine in Sudan, and ongoing conflicts in the region. EU leaders are also expected to focus on strengthening the bloc's defense capabilities and building resilience in the face of rising security challenges, including the threat posed by Russia.

images.alt_text: A core uncertainty regarding Europe’s future is whether it can boost its economic competitiveness and close its growth gap with the US.

French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz at a news conference as part of a Franco-German joint Cabinet meeting, during the celebration of the 60th anniversary of the signing of the Elysee Treaty, at the Elysee Palace in Paris, France, Jan 22, 2023.
The Russia-Ukraine war has affected food security and energy prices, and it has been accompanied by massive disinformation and political destabilisation campaigns.

site_title: China youth unemployment edges up in February: official data
summary: China's youth unemployment rate for 16-24-year-olds increased to 15.3% in February, up from 14.6% in January, according to National Bureau of Statistics data. This rise follows a previous peak of 21.3% in June last year. The data highlights ongoing economic challenges, including a struggling property sector and weaker exports, as policymakers work to ease mounting fears of a downturn in the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: Rewards startup Fetch taps private credit boom, raising US$50 million from Morgan Stanley
summary: Fetch, a rewards startup, has raised US$50 million in debt from Morgan Stanley Private Credit. The funding comes after the company turned profitable for the first time in the fourth quarter of 2023. Fetch positions itself as a one-stop digital loyalty and marketing platform, partnering with retailers and consumer packaged goods brands. With over 10 million monthly active households, the company has seen significant growth, and this funding highlights the boom in private credit for late-stage startups seeking profitability.

images.alt_text: SoftBank has been offloading Paytm shares regularly since at least November 2022 through last month, according to a Bloomberg analysis of company filings.

site_title: European airline CEOs say industry consolidation vital
summary: European airline CEOs, IAG's Luis Gallego and Ryanair's Michael O'Leary, emphasized the need for industry consolidation to maintain competitiveness. They cited examples of airlines like TAP and Aer Lingus, which have thrived as part of larger airlines. The European Commission is set to evaluate Lufthansa's bid to acquire a 41% minority stake in state-owned ITA for 325 million euros. Regulators have warned that the deal could reduce competition in flights to and from Italy, prompting potential remedies such as opening up slots and traffic rights.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: British Airways tail fins are pictured at Heathrow Airport in London, Britain, May 17, 2021. REUTERS/John Sibley/File Photo/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: A British Airways aircraft parks next to an EasyJet plane at Cointrin airport in Geneva, Switzerland June 24, 2021.  REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo

FILE PHOTO: Lufthansa's aircrafts are seen on the tarmac the day before VERDI union called airport workers at Frankfurt, Munich, Stuttgart, Hamburg, Dortmund, Hanover and Bremen airports to go on a 24-hour strike on Friday, at the Munich International Airport, Germany, February 16, 2023. REUTERS/Leonhard Simon///File Photo

site_title: World ‘losing the battle’ against electronic waste: UN
summary: The world is losing the battle against electronic waste, with e-waste generation rising by 2.6 million tonnes annually, reaching 82 million tonnes by 2030. The UN reports that 62 million tonnes of mobile phones and devices were dumped on the planet in 2022, with the vast majority not being managed well, ending up in landfills. Experts attribute the increase to factors such as higher consumption, lack of repair options, and inadequate infrastructure, and call for manufacturers to take responsibility for standardizing products with longer lifecycles.

images.alt_text: The World Meteorological Organization confirmed that 2023 was by far the hottest year ever recorded.
The cereal index fell 5 per cent month on month in February to stand 22.3 per cent below its level a year ago.
A total of 272,600 international patents were filed in 2023, marking a 1.8 per cent decline from a year earlier, the United Nations’ World Intellectual Property Organisation (WIPO) says.

site_title: Temu operator PDD Holdings beats revenue estimates as e-commerce flourishes
summary: PDD Holdings, the operator of e-commerce platform Temu, has beaten revenue estimates for the fourth quarter with a 123% year-over-year growth, driven by robust user growth and sales on its global platform. The company's revenue reached 88.88 billion yuan, exceeding analysts' expectations. Temu, launched in 2022, is now operating in 51 global markets and has gained market share with highly competitive pricing in China and overseas, attracting customers from rivals such as US dollar Tree and brick-and-mortar retailers.

images.alt_text: The Personal Information Protection Commission says it has been investigating overseas e-commerce platforms since last month, after a parliament audit last year raised questions about data handling by platforms such as AliExpress and Temu.
The iPhone 15 launch came at a time of slowing sales for Apple in China where it faces rising competitive pressure from domestic rivals like Huawei and Xiaomi.
In Temu’s first full year of operation in the US, Gen Xers and Baby Boomers shopped there more frequently and spent more than younger shoppers.
The latest suit comes as Temu has widened its gap with Shein in US transactions since surpassing it in May.
PDD has only been around for eight years, about a third of the time Alibaba has been operating.
PDD’s revenue was 68.84 billion yuan (S$13 billion) in the quarter ended Sep 30.

site_title: Southwest Airlines reaches tentative agreement with flight attendants' union
summary: Southwest Airlines reached a tentative agreement with its flight attendants' union for a new contract covering nearly 20,000 cabin crew members. The agreement addresses higher pay and better work rules, following a strike mandate vote in January. This is the airline's 10th contract ratification since October 2022, as it seeks to improve labor relations with its workforce. The Transport Workers Union will present details of the agreement to flight attendants for a ratification vote.

site_title: Gender-neutral dressing is the new look
summary: Fashion designers are embracing gender-neutral dressing, creating clothes that can be worn by both men and women. This trend is driven by shifting generational perspectives on gender roles and a focus on sustainability. Brands such as Graye, Issey Miyake, and Christophe Lemaire are leading the charge, with the inaugural Fashion For All festival showcasing inclusive and diverse designs. The trend is seen as a response to the need for greater inclusivity and diversity in fashion.

site_title: Apple boss Tim Cook visits Shanghai with China sales under pressure
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook visited Shanghai, China, amid declining iPhone sales in the country. Cook emphasized China's importance in Apple's supply chain, stating it's "critical to us." He met with suppliers, including BYD Electronics, and officials from Lens Technology. The visit comes after Apple announced a new retail store in Shanghai and battles rising competition from domestic rivals like Huawei. Cook's visit is his third to China this year, following a similar trip to Beijing last year.

site_title: The post-Covid run in hospitality Reits may look tired but don’t discount it getting a second wind
summary: Singapore-listed hospitality-focused real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) have bucked the downtrend of other S-Reits, posting an average growth of 21% in distribution-per-unit (DPU) for FY2023. Despite high interest rates weighing on distributions, these trusts have shown resilience. The upcoming mutual visa-free travel arrangement with China, which has not yet seen a significant return of Chinese visitors to Singapore, presents an opportunity for the hospitality sector to regain momentum. Conditions are in place for a potential second wind in the post-Covid hospitality Reits market.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan
Loh Chin Hua, chief executive of Keppel (left) and Takayuki Miki, managing director of Mitsui Fudosan, signed a Memorandum of Understanding.
The Singapore data centre in Keppel DC REIT's portfolio. Investors should consider investing in line with structural, secular trends of suburban retail, logistics and data centres.
Net proceeds arising from the issue of the notes will be used for refinancing the existing borrowings of CapitaLand Ascott Reit and its subsidiaries.
The research team continues to like the Reit for its strong earnings visibility.

site_title: Big names back Disney at critical time in activists' battle
summary: Disney CEO Bob Iger has received backing from prominent figures, including creator of Star Wars George Lucas, JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon, and descendants of Walt Disney's founders. They have expressed faith in Iger's leadership and plans to reinvigorate the company, urging shareholders to reject activist investors' demands for board seats. This public endorsement, rare in proxy fights, may sway retail investors and institutional shareholders, potentially giving Iger's side an advantage in the upcoming proxy battle.

images.alt_text: Filmmaker George Lucas, who received 37.1 million Disney shares as part of the company’s US$4.05 billion purchase of his Lucasfilm studio in 2012, is currently the largest individual investor in the company.

site_title: US 30-year mortgage rate nears 7%, restraining home purchases
summary: US mortgage rates reached 7% last week, a significant increase from the October peak near 8%. This rise led to a decline in home purchase applications, with the MBA's index falling 1.2% to 146. Despite the current high rates, mortgage rates are expected to fall in mid-year, potentially boosting demand in the housing market. The MBA's overall index for mortgage applications decreased 1.6% to 198.2, with refinancing applications also declining.

site_title: UK train drivers to strike on tube and rail network in April and May
summary: UK train drivers from the Aslef union will strike on April 5, 6, and 8, and on May 4, affecting 16 major rail companies and the London Underground network. The strike is over pay and working conditions, with managers trying to impose longer shifts. The union claims the government has ignored their demands, and the Transport Secretary has not spoken with the union since December 2022. The strikes will impact major commuter lines, including Thameslink and Southeastern, and will cause disruptions to the rail network and London Underground.

site_title: Apple’s new TV show pits Palm Beach society against the arrivistes
summary: Apple TV+ has released "Palm Royale," a lavish limited series set in 1969 Palm Beach, Florida, following Kristen Wiig's character Maxine Simmons, a former pageant queen trying to infiltrate high society. The show, loosely based on Juliet McDaniel's novel "Mr and Mrs American Pie," features a star-studded cast, including Allison Janney, Laura Dern, and Carol Burnett. Maxine's mission to secure her spouse's inheritance leads her to become embroiled in a complex web of relationships and scandals, but the show's tone is sometimes uneven, with underwritten characters and an abrupt finale. Despite this, Wiig shines in her role, bringing both pathos and humor to the character.

images.alt_text: Triangle Of Sadness, a sharp satire of the moneyed class, has earned several awards and nominations, including the Oscar for Best Picture.

site_title: AI can write, but is it any good at picking stocks?
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) is being explored for its potential to improve stock market investing, but its ability to accurately predict market trends remains uncertain. Generative AI, which mimics human thought processes, is being used to create new material such as reports and summaries, while predictive AI analyzes large amounts of data to make predictions about market movements. While AI has disrupted some finance roles, it is unlikely to replace human traders and market strategists due to the complexity of markets and the need for coherent explanations of investment decisions. Many money managers are using machine learning in their investing processes, but the performance of AI-powered funds remains mixed, with some underperforming the broader market.

images.alt_text: The hope is that AI can take a rule like "buy stocks with the lowest price-to-book ratios" and figure out what specific sectors and market conditions the rule works best in.

site_title: Woman guilty of laundering Bitcoin in UK from US$6.3 billion China fraud
summary: A UK court convicted Wen Jian, a woman, of one count of money laundering, related to a £5 billion (S$8.5 billion) China-based fraud that targeted nearly 130,000 Chinese investors between 2014 and 2017. Wen allegedly converted Bitcoin into cash and property to hide the proceeds. She was not accused of participating in the underlying fraud, which was masterminded by Zhang Yadi, whose real name is Qian Zhimin. Wen's conviction marks a significant step in the UK's efforts to combat international financial crimes.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrency Bitcoin are seen in this illustration, August 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Dutch court finds KLM ads misleading in greenwashing case
summary: A Dutch court ruled that KLM misled customers with its "Fly Responsibly" campaign, stating that all aviation contributes to greenhouse gas emissions. The court deemed the ads "misleading and therefore illegal." Although KLM won't be forced to issue rectifications, the company must be honest and concrete about environmental claims in the future. This decision is seen as a symbolic victory for environmentalists who criticized the campaign for greenwashing.

site_title: As market concentration rises, diversification is a must
summary: Market concentration is on the rise, making diversification crucial for investors. The "Magnificent Seven" stocks, including Meta, Amazon, and Apple, account for over 30% of the S&P 500 and powered half of US stock returns in 2023. While valuations are high, these companies have strong earnings capacity, and some pay dividends. To mitigate risk, investors should consider fixed income assets, alternative investments, and diversifying globally, particularly in Asia, to stay the course despite volatility and reap long-term returns.

images.alt_text: The reduced willingness of shipping companies to sail through the Red Sea and the Suez Canal raises the risk that the regional conflict would have global consequences.
financial, planning, report
Lenders are shovelling money towards risky high-yield corporate borrowers, narrowing the spread they pay above the yield on government debt.

site_title: Philippine central bank says its policy decisions not dependent on Fed's
summary: The Philippine central bank, Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, stated that its monetary policy decisions are not dependent on the US Federal Reserve's actions. Despite this, the bank's governor, Eli Remolona, described the central bank as "hawkish" due to inflation still near the target range of 2-4%. Annual inflation is expected to accelerate to 3.9% in March. The bank will review its policy at its next meeting on April 4, with no changes to the benchmark rate of 6.5% expected. Remolona emphasized the bank's independence in making decisions.

site_title: JSW Group-MG Motor venture aims to sell 1 million EVs in India by 2030
summary: JSW Group's joint venture with MG Motor aims to sell 1 million electric vehicles in India by 2030, targeting the premium passenger vehicle segment. The venture has two electric car offerings, the Comet EV and the ZS EV, in India. This move is part of the companies' efforts to expand their presence in the Indian EV market. The joint statement did not provide further details on the venture's plans or production capacity.

site_title: Singapore stocks close slightly higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.1% higher at 3,177.48 points on Wednesday, despite a record-high S&P 500 in the US. Top Glove, a glove maker, rose 8.9% after reporting a significant year-on-year loss due to cost-cutting. Wilmar International fell 0.3% after announcing plans to increase its stake in a Pakistani company. The market saw a trading volume of 2.1 billion securities worth S$876.5 million, with Seatrium accounting for most trading volume.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Wilmar International unit intends to make further investment in Pakistan-listed Unity Foods
Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei and Manila were slightly higher at mid day on Wednesday but there were losses in Jakarta and Wellington.
Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 80 to 23.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Wednesday, March 20, 2024 (Ep 26)
summary: Market Focus Daily reported on Wednesday, March 20, 2024, that Wall Street was upbeat despite the Federal Reserve's interest rate policy meeting today. The Japanese yen hit a four-month low against the euro after the Bank of Japan ended negative interest rates. China maintained its benchmark lending rates, and Seatrium was the most traded stock on the SGX. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) rose 0.2% at the open.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Wednesday.

site_title: Private healthcare providers brace for higher costs amid global shortage of nurses
summary: Private healthcare providers in Singapore are bracing for higher operating costs due to a global shortage of nurses. Analysts predict that retaining current staff through increased salaries may not be as costly as hiring and training new nurses. The government's upcoming retention scheme for public healthcare nurses, offering up to S$100,000 payouts, is also expected to impact private healthcare providers. As a result, private healthcare players may need to reassess their compensation for nurses to maintain competitiveness.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah

site_title: UK house prices fall by 0.6% in annual terms in January
summary: UK house prices fell by 0.6% in January, reversing a revised 2.2% decrease in December, according to the Office for National Statistics. This contrasts with other data showing house prices rose in January due to easing mortgage costs and weaker inflation. Meanwhile, private rents rose 9% in the year to February, the largest increase since 2015. The slowdown in consumer price inflation has bolstered expectations of a first interest rate cut by the Bank of England in August.

site_title: ERA steps up push for ‘eventual full digitalisation’
summary: ERA Realty is intensifying its push for digitalization, aiming to achieve "eventual full digitalization" of real estate transaction documentations within the next two years. The agency has launched digital signature apps for property submissions and training programs for agents on digital marketing skills. These initiatives support the Council for Estate Agencies' goal to eliminate scams and provide more secure property listings. ERA's efforts are also seen as crucial in countering money-laundering and terrorism funding, with Second Minister Indranee Rajah emphasizing the need for agencies to leverage technology to boost productivity and combat scams.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Close to a third of the respondents who took part in the survey felt that there is an oversupply of property agents in the market.

Held this week in Cannes on the French Riviera (top), the MIPIM property conference unfolds against a backdrop of falling commercial real estate (CRE) prices and developers wondering what to do with offices emptied out by the pandemic.
The rising level of unsold stock may signal bad news for some projects, such as the 99-year leasehold Cuscaden Reserve (above), with an impending sales deadline this year.

site_title: ECB tries to dampen bets on streak of rate cuts
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) attempted to calm speculation about a potential streak of interest rate cuts, with President Christine Lagarde stating that the ECB cannot commit to a certain number of rate cuts even after starting to reduce borrowing costs. This comes as policymakers are debating the possibility of a rate cut in June, with the focus shifting to how many more cuts would follow. The ECB acknowledged encouraging data on slowing price and wage rises, but Lagarde emphasized the need for caution in monetary policy decisions.

images.alt_text: Lenders currently need to hold 1 per cent of certain liabilities – mostly customer deposits – at the ECB.
Lending growth has been hovering around zero since the autumn but is expected to slowly recover in the coming months as the ECB likely begins cutting interest rates.
Inflation comes down rapidly last year and now stands just below 3 per cent, but the ECB says it could take more than another year to get it down to its 2 per cent target.
While still high, fourth-quarter pay growth is down from a eurozone record of 4.7 per cent, notched in the previous three months, the ECB’s negotiated wage indicator shows.

site_title: Ferrari sued for failing to fix ‘dangerous’ brake defect
summary: Ferrari is facing a lawsuit in the US over a "dangerous safety defect" in its luxury sports cars, allegedly failing to fix brake issues despite multiple recalls. California resident Iliya Nechev claims his 2010 Ferrari 458 Italia had "brake issues" from the start, which could cause partial or total loss of braking capability. Ferrari issued a recall in 2021 for leaking brake fluid that could impair braking, but allegedly didn't notify customers of the full extent of the defect.

images.alt_text: The upbeat forecasts has sent Ferrari’s shares roaring ahead by as much as 9.5 per cent, putting the company’s market value in sight of a record US$100 billion mark.

site_title: French competition watchdog hits Google with 250 million euro fine
summary: France's competition watchdog fined Google 250 million euros for breaching EU intellectual property rules in its relationship with media publishers, citing concerns over Google's AI-powered chatbot Bard. The fine is linked to a copyright dispute over online content in France. Google has accepted the settlement and proposed remedy measures, stating it wants to focus on connecting people with quality content. The company claims the fine is disproportionate and its efforts were not sufficiently considered by the watchdog.

images.alt_text: Apple and Google have not decided on the terms of an AI agreement or finalised how it would be implemented.
Indian startups have been at odds with Google for months over the fee it charges for in-app payments.
Rachel Teo, head of sustainability and head of total portfolio sustainable investing, at GIC.

If any of the six tech giants are not compliant with the Digital Markets Act (DMA) by the EU’s Thursday deadline, they could ultimately face investigations and potentially fines of up to 10 per cent of their global turnover.
Google together with five other tech giants have to be fully compliant with a list of dos and don’ts set out under the DMA on Mar 7.

site_title: Intel wins almost US$20 billion in chips incentives for US plants
summary: The US Commerce Department has awarded Intel $8.5 billion in grants and up to $11 billion in loans to support the expansion of its semiconductor factories in Arizona and Ohio, as part of the 2022 Chips and Science Act. The package, valued at over $100 billion, will help Intel produce cutting-edge semiconductors and create over 30,000 jobs. Intel's CEO Pat Gelsinger has said the funding will help reverse the decades-long shift of semiconductor production to Asia, with the goal of producing one-fifth of the world's advanced logic chips by the end of the decade.

images.alt_text: Beyond the defence money, Intel has been seeking incentives worth more than US$10 billion from the Chips and Science Act.
Astera plans to sell about 14.8 million shares, while existing shareholders are offering another three million.
The parent company plans to hold a stock offering for Altera over the next two to three years.
The parent company plans to hold a stock offering for Altera over the next two to three years.

site_title: Unilever said to weigh sale of water purification unit Truliva in China
summary: Unilever is reportedly exploring the sale of its majority stake in Qinyuan Group, a Chinese water purification equipment manufacturer it acquired in 2014 for an undisclosed sum. A sale could value Qinyuan at around $300 million, according to people familiar with the situation. Unilever is working with an adviser to gauge interest from potential buyers, but a representative for the company declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 20)
summary: Bank Negara Malaysia forecasts Malaysia's economy to grow between 4-5% in 2024, with a cautious anticipation of a better year ahead. Governor Abdul Rasheed Ghaffour stated that upcoming reforms may cause short-term pain, but overall prospects are good.

images.alt_text: Bank Negara Malaysia governor Abdul Rasheed Ghaffour said: "Our prospects are good. We have reason to cautiously anticipate a better year ahead."

site_title: Why Japan’s economy remains a warning to others
summary: Japan's economy, once seen as a model for low growth and high debt, is undergoing significant changes. The Bank of Japan raised interest rates for the first time since 2007, and scrapped yield-curve control, signaling a shift towards a more inflationary path. However, the economy's real growth and debt remain concerns, with a shrinking population, limited immigration, and high public debt. Despite these challenges, the economy is expected to maintain a respectable pace of 0.5% annual GDP growth, but it is unlikely to "de-Japanify" and become more like the rest of the world.

images.alt_text: Japan’s currency has dropped as much as 0.3 per cent to 164.35 per euro before trimming some of the losses.
The central bank’s decision to hike rates was preceded by news of stronger-than-expected pay rises by companies.
Under Governor Kazuo Ueda, the BOJ is unwinding its ultra-loose monetary policy.
Almost a year into his leadership, BOJ governor Kazuo Ueda (above) has dismantled the paraphernalia erected by his predecessor.

site_title: CEOs rarely win in the game of geopolitics
summary: CEOs must navigate a complex relationship between corporate strategy and geostrategy as companies face a world fragmenting along ideological lines. Companies are increasingly being treated as instruments of national power, with governments exerting control over industries and technologies. This shift has led to a surge of serious thinking about the proper relationship between corporate strategy and geostrategy. Companies must balance their primary responsibility to shareholders with the need to comply with laws and regulations, and beware of becoming instruments of national foreign policy, which can invite retaliation and undermine global cooperation.

images.alt_text: Even if ByteDance puts the TikTok app up for sale, the Chinese government is unlikely to allow the company’s most valuable asset, its recommendation algorithm, to be included.
Many CEOs and executives foresee an upbeat US economy in 2024, but are concerned about China and Europe, and the impact of unexpected global shocks on inflation.
Optimism booms among Davos CEOs despite geopolitical storm clouds

site_title: COE prices rise across the board except for commercial vehicles
summary: COE prices rose across the board except for commercial vehicles, with cars and motorcycles seeing increases of 3% and 3.1% respectively. The price of Open category COEs also edged up 0.9%. In contrast, the COE premium for commercial vehicles decreased 7.3% to S$70,112. The price increases are expected to lead to higher car prices.

images.alt_text: Generic photo of vehicles for COE bidding, car pollution, carbon tax related stories.
Certificate of entitlement (COE) premiums for passenger cars rose, while those for commercial vehicles and motorcycles remained flat.
The price for Category A rose to S$83,000, eclipsing the previous high of S$81,589 in January’s first round of bidding.
The government says that having a separate Certificate of Entitlement (COE) category for private hire cars is possible, but the trade-offs must be studied carefully.

site_title: Samsung, Deloitte units back medical AI startup PocketHealth
summary: Toronto-based medical AI startup PocketHealth has raised US$33 million in Series B funding from investors including Deloitte Ventures and Samsung Next. The startup, which helps 775 healthcare providers exchange medical images for 1.5 million patients, aims to cut delays and costs. It plans to use the funding to advance its image-sharing platform, which employs AI to personalize patient care, and double its workforce in two years. PocketHealth already claims to be the largest medical-image exchange in North America, and its technology tracks patient returns and provides personalized insights to help patients better understand medical reports.

images.alt_text: Marqo's platform lets firms harness unstructured data such as e-mails, allowing them to analyse it and use it for purposes such as e-commerce personalisation.

site_title: Volkswagen, Mobileye to bring new automated driving functions to series production
summary: Volkswagen is partnering with Mobileye to integrate automated driving technologies into its luxury brands, such as Audi, Bentley, and Porsche. The partnership will provide driving assistance software for highway and urban driving, including automated overtaking and automatic stopping at red lights. Volkswagen's chief executive, Oliver Blume, stated that the new technologies will significantly boost convenience and safety. Mobileye will also supply automated driving software to Volkswagen's commercial vehicles unit.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Volkswagen's ID.7 vehicle is pictured during the 63rd Annual General Meeting of Volkswagen AG in Berlin, Germany, May 10, 2023. REUTERS/Annegret Hilse/File Photo

site_title: Swiss financial regulator plans to stress-test UBS this year
summary: Swiss financial regulator Finma plans to conduct 40 on-site supervisory reviews and two stress tests of UBS this year, focusing on operational stability and capital and liquidity planning following the bank's 2023 takeover of Credit Suisse. The regulator aims to strengthen UBS's financial position to avoid future crises and has identified shortcomings in areas such as money laundering, mortgage lending, and cyber risks. Finma's actions follow calls from the Swiss National Bank for an overhaul of bank capital regulations and a review of options for resolving a systemically important bank.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The company's logo is seen at a branch of Swiss bank UBS in Zurich, Switzerland February 2, 2016. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann

site_title: China to use public auctions for sale of special ultra-long debt
summary: China plans to sell its special ultra-long sovereign notes through public auctions in the interbank market, starting from the second quarter, with tenors potentially as long as 50 years. The government aims to issue one trillion yuan ($189.3 billion) of debt, sparking concerns about liquidity pressure and a potential surge in supply that could threaten the current bond rally. The move may also lead to a wider pool of banks setting aside cash, reducing the money market's supply.

images.alt_text: China aims to issue such ultra long-term special bonds for several consecutive years, though Li Qiang's report did not include a target beyond 2024.

site_title: Vietnam’s president resigns, raising questions over stability
summary: Vietnam's President Vo Van Thuong has resigned, citing violations of party rules, amid a period of political turmoil that may impact foreign investors' confidence in the country. The move comes as the country grapples with widespread corruption and a multi-billion-dollar financial scam in Ho Chi Minh City. The resignation is seen as a result of the anti-bribery campaign, which has been linked to political infighting and may slow down business decisions. Foreign investors have expressed concerns over the country's stability and predictability, but experts note that Vietnam's foreign policy and governance system remain stable.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Vietnam's President Vo Van Thuong speaks as he attends the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework (IPEF) Leaders event at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) CEO Summit in San Francisco, California, U.S. November 16, 2023. REUTERS/Brittany Hosea-Small/File Photo

site_title: Using data to farm fish more efficiently
summary: Singaporean aquaculture company The Fish Farmer is using sensors and artificial intelligence (AI) to farm fish more efficiently due to space constraints and rising costs. The company, which produces 1,000 tonnes of fish annually, has developed an IoT farm management software that monitors water quality, temperature, and fish inventory. The software includes an AI-based fish counting application that uses videos to accurately count fish stocks, and an improved water quality monitoring sensor that alerts farm employees to changes in water conditions. This technology has helped The Fish Farmer reduce incidents of depleted fish stocks and freed up farm employees' time for higher-value tasks.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
The Fish Farmer looks to reduce food waste, make aquaculture industry more sustainable

site_title: Seoul allocates new medical school slots despite doctors' strike
summary: South Korea's government has allocated 2,000 new medical school slots nationwide, despite a month-long strike by trainee doctors protesting proposed training reforms. The move aims to address the country's low doctor-to-population ratio and ageing population. Most new slots were awarded to universities outside the Seoul capital region to boost capacity in rural areas. The Korean Medical Association criticized the allocation, calling it a "catastrophic consequence" that will erode the quality of service and medical education.

images.alt_text: South Korean medical professors holding up signs protesting the government's plan to augment medical student admissions at Jeonbuk National University.  The health ministry this week reiterated that negotiations over the reform plans were out of the question.

site_title: China’s property crisis pushes private credit to tech sectors
summary: China's property debt crisis has led private credit investors to shift focus from the property market to technology sectors, including green-solution businesses. Financial technology and healthcare are expected to be key sectors to watch in the next 18 months. Investors are diversifying their views on China, with yields in private credit still insufficient for many. Some firms, like Schroders, are focusing on Chinese consumption businesses and internet platforms. Despite geopolitical tensions, private credit firms see a yield pickup across opportunities in private credit, with China potentially becoming more attractive for investors in 2025 and 2026.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo for Goldman Sachs is seen on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, New York, U.S., November 17, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly

site_title: Biotech firm Valneva guides for nearly double product sales by 2026
summary: Valneva, a France-based biotech firm, expects to nearly double its annual product sales by 2026, driven by growth from its travel vaccines, including Ixiaro and Dukoral, and the launch of its Ixchiq vaccine for chikungunya. The company forecasts 2024 revenue of 170-190 million euros and product sales of 160-180 million euros, with third-party sales expected to drop 20-30% this year. Valneva's shares were down 3% after the announcement, but analysts say the company is "sufficiently financed towards sustainable profitability."

images.alt_text: Vials of the R21 malaria vaccine are seen before they are packaged inside a lab at the Serum Institute of India, Pune, India, February 27, 2024. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas
Biotech Valneva eyes growth inflection with Covid vaccine
FILE PHOTO: A view shows GlaxoSmithKline headquarters in London, Britain, January 17, 2022.REUTERS/Hannah McKay/File Photo

site_title: Sweden’s troubled home construction sector shows signs of life
summary: Sweden's home construction sector shows tentative signs of recovery after shrinking due to a drop in housing prices, increased construction costs, and interest rates. A housing-start indicator from Byggfakta rose 3.3% in March, indicating increased activity after a trough in August last year. However, the gauge remains 57% below its peak in August 2021, with only about 20,000 homes expected to be started annually, which is less than a third of what authorities estimate would avoid exacerbating existing shortages.

site_title: Chinese robotic vacuum maker Dreame Tech is said to consider IPO
summary: Chinese robotic vacuum maker Dreame Tech is considering an initial public offering (IPO) that could raise at least $300 million. The company, which also produces smart home appliances, is working with China International Capital, Goldman Sachs Group, and Morgan Stanley on a potential share sale. A listing venue in the US is also being considered, pending market conditions.

site_title: Thai tycoons heat up virtual bank bids as applications open
summary: Thai tycoons are vying for the country's new virtual bank licenses as the Bank of Thailand opens applications. True Corp and its partners, including Ant Group, are preparing a bid, while CHAROEN Pokmhand Group and Gulf Energy Development are also in the running. The move aims to boost competition and provide greater access to loans for under-served consumers. More than three virtual bank licenses may be granted, and the winning bidders will be announced next year. The new virtual banks are expected to accelerate expansion into online businesses such as cryptocurrency trading and digital lending.

images.alt_text: After the debate on the second and third readings of the budget, the budget will need further approval from the senate and the king.
The central bank will conduct unscheduled visits to make sure that lenders are offering reasonable and realistic debt solutions to their customers.

site_title: China’s Tencent posts weak revenue growth, plans to double buybacks
summary: Tencent Holdings reported a 7% rise in fourth-quarter revenue to 155.19 billion yuan ($29 billion), beating analyst estimates. The company's gaming revenue declined 3% in China and 1% internationally, while online ads and fintech revenue rose 21% and 15%, respectively. Tencent plans to double its share buybacks to over $100 billion this year and has a pipeline of new games to boost domestic revenue. Net income declined 74% due to a stake sale in Meituan.

images.alt_text: Tencent Music Entertainment reports revenue of 6.89 billion yuan (S$1.3 billion) for the quarter.
The company has made strides with so-called mini-games  and a livestreaming video platform that competes with TikTok’s local language service in China.
The approval will make Tenpay the non-bank payment institution with the highest registered capital in China.
The two teams Tencent has acquired involve one Shenzhen-based studio working on an action game and another East-China-based studio working on an anime game.
The title’s approval is a big boost for Tencent’s 2024 pipeline, which still relies in part on years-old titles and is hungry for new blockbusters.

site_title: China’s exports of graphite for batteries rise from December low
summary: China's graphite exports for electric vehicle batteries rebounded from a low in December, with 6,275 tonnes in January and 10,722 tonnes in February, according to customs data. The exports averaged about 17,000 tonnes a month from October, suggesting the government's approvals process continues to impede trade flows. The restrictions are seen as a response to Western trade barriers and tensions are escalating with the Biden administration considering blacklisting Chinese semiconductor firms linked to Huawei Technologies.

site_title: Indonesia VAT hike in question as lawmakers show emerging rifts
summary: Indonesian lawmakers have urged the government to delay the planned VAT hike from next year, citing concerns it may dampen consumers' purchasing power. The planned 12% VAT rate, set to replace the current 11%, is set to be implemented as stated in a 2021 law. The move has sparked emerging rifts in parliament, with the largest ruling party set to fall to opposition, potentially threatening the government's stability. Lawmakers' calls for delay may complicate the government's plans for the VAT increase.

images.alt_text: Indonesia passes major tax overhaul bill, VAT to rise next year

site_title: Indonesia central bank keeps rates unchanged, eyes rupiah stability
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, kept interest rates unchanged at 6% to maintain foreign exchange stability amid a narrowing trade surplus and widening current account deficit. The decision, made for the fifth consecutive month since October's rate hike, aims to control inflation and stabilize the rupiah. Governor Perry Warjiyo expressed hope for policy rate cuts later this year if the rupiah stabilizes and inflation moderates, but emphasized the need for the US Federal Reserve's rate-cutting cycle to unfold.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
