The central bank has a 2024 inflation target of 1.5 per cent to 3.5 per cent, lower than 2023’s target.

site_title: Prudential posts 43% rise in FY2023 new business profit
summary: Prudential reports a 43% increase in new business profit to US$3.1 billion for FY2023, exceeding expectations. The company also declares a second interim dividend of US$0.1421 per share, bringing the full-year dividend to US$0.2047 per share. On a constant exchange rate basis, new business profit would be up 45%, while excluding interest rate and economic movements, it would be up 47%. The results reflect a strong performance by the company.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Mia Pei
LIA also announced the upcoming launch of an enhanced protection gap calculator, which should be available in the upcoming weeks.
As sentiment weakens, investors are pulling money out of richly valued larger shares as well.
Given the rising numbers, insurers in Singapore have increasingly been looking to extend their services to reach the growing segment of individuals.

site_title: Beyonce is riding into her country era. Here’s what to know
summary: Beyoncé is releasing her eighth solo album, "Cowboy Carter", a country music project that marks her first foray into the genre. The album, set for release on March 29, is expected to blend Southern twang and country instrumentation with Beyoncé's Houston upbringing and Black origins of country music. The album features collaborations with respected country musicians, including Dolly Parton, Raphael Saadiq, and Rhiannon Giddens, who has spoken out against the genre's traditional white establishment. The album's release follows a series of promotional teasers, including a Super Bowl commercial and two singles, "Texas Hold 'Em" and "16 Carriages".

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Beyonce accepts the award for Best Dance/Electronic Music Album for "Renaissance" during the 65th Annual Grammy Awards in Los Angeles, California, U.S., February 5, 2023. REUTERS/Mario Anzuoni/File Photo

site_title: Geely profit beats estimates even as China’s price war rages on
summary: Geely Automobile Holdings reported a 1% increase in net income to 5.3 billion yuan (S$1 billion) in 2023, beating analyst estimates, despite a slowing Chinese car market and intense price wars. Revenue rose 21% to 179.2 billion yuan. The company reiterated a sales goal of 1.9 million vehicles for 2024, citing a record high in new energy vehicle sales and export sales. Geely's transition to electric vehicles is showing positive results, with battery-powered vehicles making up almost 30% of sales.

images.alt_text: The Renault-Geely venture will supply both the groups’ brands as well as third-party manufacturers.
Geespace, a subsidiary of Zhejiang Geely Holding Group, wants to deploy a network of satellites some 600 km above the Earth.
The probe, launched in October and scheduled to last 13 months, seeks to determine whether cheaper, Chinese-made EVs benefit unfairly from state subsidies.

site_title: Easing UK inflation keeps BOE on track for rate cuts later in 2024
summary: The UK's inflation rate slowed to 3.4% in February, the weakest rate since September 2021, according to official data. This easing of inflation keeps the Bank of England on track to cut interest rates later in 2024, offering some economic relief to Prime Minister Rishi Sunak ahead of the expected election later this year. The slowdown was driven by decreases in food and restaurant prices, while motor fuels prices rose. Core inflation also slowed, dropping to 4.5% from 5.1% in January.

images.alt_text: The BOE forecasts that inflation will return to its 2 per cent target for the first time in three years in the second quarter of this year, but it also expects inflation will rise back towards 3 per cent later in the year.

site_title: China, Australia face tricky diplomatic road after trade row
summary: China and Australia are taking tentative steps to improve their diplomatic relations after a three-year trade war, but experts caution that fundamental differences remain. Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi's visit to Australia comes after China announced lifting trade tariffs as high as 218% on Australian wine, and despite a recent release of an Australian journalist and a visit by the Australian Prime Minister to Beijing. However, ongoing disputes over the South China Sea and increased competition with the US threaten to derail progress, with experts warning that the relationship remains fragile.

images.alt_text: “Dialogue leads to understanding and it leads to benefit for both of our nations. Australia will benefit from the economic activity that removal of these impediments will bring,” says Australia Prime Minister Anthony Albanese.

site_title: Malaysia economy expected to grow 4-5% in 2024: Bank Negara
summary: Malaysia's central bank forecasts the country's economy to grow 4-5% in 2024, driven by resilient domestic demand and improved external demand. The bank also expects headline inflation to average 2-3.5% this year, despite potential upside risks. Governor Abdul Rasheed Ghaffour cautions that structural reforms may cause short-term pain but believes they will ultimately benefit the country's prosperity. The central bank maintains its overnight policy rate at 3% and expects the ringgit to appreciate further in 2024.

images.alt_text: Bank Negara Malaysia governor Abdul Rasheed Ghaffour said: "Our prospects are good. We have reason to cautiously anticipate a better year ahead."

site_title: Lonza to buy US biologics site from Roche for US$1.2 billion
summary: Lonza to acquire Roche's Genentech manufacturing facility in Vacaville, California for $1.2 billion in cash. The Swiss contract drug manufacturer plans to invest $754.8 million to upgrade the facility and enhance capabilities for next-generation mammalian biologics therapies. The Vacaville site, one of the largest biologics manufacturing sites worldwide by volume, will accommodate Lonza's growth in the biologics industry.

images.alt_text: The company, which is a key supplier of vaccine maker Moderna, is banking on long-term growth in the biopharmaceuticals sector well beyond the pandemic.

site_title: Malaysia says Goldman lawsuit is a chance to review 1MDB deal
summary: Malaysia views a Goldman Sachs lawsuit as an opportunity to review a settlement related to the 1MDB scandal. The country's Second Finance Minister, Amir Hamzah Azizan, stated that the arbitration suit allows parties to reassess the deal and work to recover assets. The 2020 settlement required Goldman to make an interim payment of $250 million if Malaysia didn't receive $500 million of 1MDB assets by August 2022. Goldman has disputed the requirement, prompting the lawsuit. Malaysia has paid $13.7 billion in 1MDB debt and is probing lawyers involved in the settlement.

site_title: Real estate execs concerned about oversupply of property agents: NUS survey
summary: A survey by the National University of Singapore found that 65% of real estate executives believe there is an oversupply of property agents in the market, despite a slowing domestic property market. The population of salespersons has risen to 35,251, up from 32,414 in 2022. The survey also found that high commission fees are expected to attract more new salespersons, but regulatory intervention may be needed to better allocate scarce labor resources and prevent a shortage in other industries.

images.alt_text: Samuel Oh
Maybe there can be less reliance on using agents for sale of homes, with ensuing cost savings going to the pockets of buyers.
Under the best practices guide laid out by SEAA, property agents should agree upon how commission is shared before engaging with clients.
Agencies agree that the housing market is getting more competitive, with buyers feeling cautious and purchases being held back.
Kucing's co-founders Guillaume Garagnon (left) and Mathieu Goarant said its new app is agent-free and offers P2P platform for users.

site_title: Zombie Chinese EV makers resurrected in ‘productive force’ push
summary: Three defunct Chinese electric vehicle (EV) makers, Zhidou Electric Vehicle, Haima Automobile, and another unnamed entity, have been revived as part of China's push for advanced technology development. Zhidou Electric Vehicle completed restructuring and will launch a new EV in April, while Haima Automobile transferred its management and assets to a government-backed entity. The revival is seen as a risky bet in China's crowded EV market, where the industry is touted as a "new productive force" by President Xi Jinping.

images.alt_text: Geely’s transition towards EVs is showing positive early results, with battery-powered vehicles including plug-in hybrids now making up almost 30 per cent of its sales.
Chinese firms has put US$28.2 billion into EV-related industries last year.

site_title: Former transport minister Iswaran surrenders passport after returning to Singapore: AGC
summary: Former Singapore transport minister S Iswaran has returned to the country after being discharged from a hospital in Melbourne. He surrendered his passport to the authorities, following his discharge on Jan 18, when he was charged with corruption. Iswaran was originally scheduled to be in Australia from Feb 16 to Mar 4.

images.alt_text: Former transport minister S. Iswaran is facing corruption charges and is currently out on S$800,000 bail.
The former transport minister is under probe for corruption.

The prosecution has no objections in principle to Iswaran’s application to travel, but has imposed certain conditions, including a cash bail of S$500,000, in addition to the present agency bail of S$800,000.
While the government will review its contracts to safeguard Singapore's interest, it remains committed to the F1 Singapore Grand Prix, said Minister-in-charge of Trade Relations Grace Fu.

site_title: Top Glove trims Q2 loss to RM51.2 million, aims to return to profit in 2 quarters
summary: Top Glove Corporation has reported a Q2 loss of RM51.2 million, narrowing by 68.9% from the same period last year. The company attributes the improved results to its quality- and cost-optimisation initiatives, coupled with operational enhancements. Executive Chairman Lim Wee Chai expects the company to return to profit by FY2025, driven by increasing glove prices and expected softening of raw material costs. The company aims to achieve a monthly sales volume of 2.5-3 billion to achieve profitability in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah

An employee handles latex gloves at an automated production line at a Top Glove Corp. factory in Setia Alam, Selangor, Malaysia, on Tuesday, Feb. 18, 2020. The world’s biggest glovemaker got a vote of confidence from investors in the credit market, as the coronavirus fuels demand for the Malaysian company’s rubber products. The World Health Organization is taking an unprecedented step of negotiating directly with suppliers to improve access to gloves, face masks and other forms of protective equipment. Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg
Sri
Market analysts are bullish on the uptrend of FBM KLCI to continue, as they anticipate Malaysia’s economic condition will keep improving this year.

site_title: ECB plans to give investors a glimpse of key wage indicators
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) plans to make its wage trackers, used to gauge inflation risks, openly available "later this year". These internal pay measures, developed with national central banks, will provide investors with a fuller picture of pay pressures in the economy. The trackers are seen as crucial to policymakers' assessment of inflation, with ECB President Christine Lagarde citing salaries as an increasingly important driver of inflation dynamics. This move may coincide with the start or continuation of an ECB rate-cutting cycle, depending on market bets.

images.alt_text: “Wage growth continues to be strong and is expected to become an increasingly important driver of inflation dynamics in the coming quarters,” ECB president Christine Lagarde says.

site_title: Michael Schumacher’s Journe, Rolex may fetch millions at auction
summary: A collection of eight watches from Michael Schumacher's collection, including a unique FP Journe Vagabondage 1 Model commemorating his F1 championships, will be auctioned by Christie's in Geneva on May 13. The watches, including an Audemars Piguet Royal Oak and Schumacher's 'Paul Newman' Rolex Daytona, are expected to fetch millions, with estimates ranging from $1.5 million to $400,000. The sale is a rare opportunity for collectors to own pieces from the seven-time F1 champion's personal collection, which was valued by Christie's over a year ago.

images.alt_text: Exports dropped 3.8 per cent by value in February to 2.15 billion Swiss francs (S$3.3 billion) from a year earlier, the Federation of the Swiss Watch Industry says.
The Rolex GMT with a red and blue ceramic bezel remains an outlier.
Total watch sales at the top auction houses fell 13 per cent to 610 million Swiss francs (S$926.7 million) in 2023 from record levels hit in 2022.
Linda Neo started collecting art as a means of sharing a common interest with her husband, Albert Lim.

site_title: US weighs sanctioning Huawei’s secretive Chinese chip network
summary: The US is considering blacklisting several Chinese semiconductor firms linked to Huawei Technologies, a move that would escalate pressure on Beijing's artificial intelligence and semiconductor ambitions. The companies, including Qingdao Si'En, SwaySure, and Shenzhen Pensun Technology, could be added to the US Entity List, which restricts their access to American technology. The move comes after Huawei made significant technological breakthroughs, including producing a smartphone processor last year. The decision is part of the US campaign to ringfence China's AI and semiconductor ambitions, with the Commerce Department weighing sanctions on other Chinese companies, including ChangXin Memory Technologies and Shenzhen Pengjin High-Tech.

images.alt_text: Apple began subsidising certain iPhone models by as much as 1,300 yuan (S$242.64) last week through flagship stores on Tmall, Alibaba’s major marketplace platform.
Huawei has similar patent agreements with Chinese smartphone manufacturers Xiaomi and Oppo.
A China's Comac C919 aircraft performs during a preview of the Singapore Airshow in Singapore on February 18, 2024. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)

site_title: Samsung Electronics expects US$100 million or more sales from advanced chip packaging business
summary: Samsung Electronics expects to generate $100 million or more in revenue from its advanced chip packaging business this year, according to co-CEO Kyung Kye-hyun. The company aims to secure a competitive advantage in high-end memory chips required by booming artificial intelligence demand, including mass-producing a 12-stack version of high-bandwidth memory (HBM) chips. Samsung's market share in Dram chips reached 45.5% in the fourth quarter last year, and the company expects tangible results from other memory products being developed for AI use, including compute express link and processing-in-memory products.

images.alt_text: Health tracking is already a key selling point of smartphones and watches, with Samsung, Apple and Alphabet’s Google using the features to attract and retain customers.
Samsung's new Galaxy S24 Ultra unveiled at the event is said to have the capability to translate foreign language phone calls and texts while they were taking place.

The iPhone stole Samsung’s crown in 2023 with 234.6 million units sold, compared to the South Korean firm’s 226.6 million units, according to data from the International Data Corporation released on Monday.

site_title: Thailand forges ahead with ‘digital wallet’ handout scheme, official says
summary: Thailand is moving forward with a 500 billion baht (S$18.6 billion) handout scheme, despite concerns over funding. Deputy Finance Minister Julapun Amornvivat said the project will go ahead, possibly with a loan, and aims to transfer 10,000 baht to 50 million Thais. The budget for the 2024 fiscal year includes a 9.3% rise in spending and a 0.3% drop in the budget deficit. The scheme has been criticized as fiscally irresponsible, and further approval from the senate and king is required.

site_title: Asia: Markets swing as traders await Federal Reserve policy decision
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Wednesday as traders awaited the Federal Reserve's policy decision, with some expecting interest rates to remain at a two-decade high. The focus was on the Fed's "dot plot" of projected interest rate cuts, which has been revised down from up to six to three, due to strong data on sticky inflation. Despite the uncertainty, Wall Street investors remained upbeat, pushing indexes higher, and Asian markets were slightly higher, except for Jakarta and Wellington, which saw losses.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 80 to 23.
The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.3 per cent higher on Tuesday, snapping a three-day losing streak.
All three major indices advanced on Tuesday, with the S&P 500 at 5,178.51, up 0.6 per cent, topping a record set a week ago.

site_title: New Zealand government to ban disposable e-cigarettes
summary: New Zealand's government has announced plans to ban the sale of disposable e-cigarettes, increasing fines on retailers selling to those under 18 and regulating vaping retailers. The move aims to tackle youth vaping and reduce smoking rates, with a goal of achieving a Smokefree population of less than 5% by 2025. The ban on disposable e-cigarettes is part of a broader approach to reduce smoking, following criticism of a previous law banning tobacco sales for future generations.

site_title: Kaya Founders hits second close of latest funds at 1 billion pesos
summary: Kaya Founders, a Philippines-based venture capital firm, has secured $24 million in its second close of funds, bringing its total assets under management to $22.5 million. The firm will invest in 30-40 early-stage startups in the Philippines and Southeast Asia over the next four years, focusing on its Zero to One and One to Ten funds. Pavilion Capital and Concentric Equity Partners, among others, participated in the round, marking a significant milestone for the venture capital firm.

images.alt_text: The Philippines faced the most severe inflation and the most aggressive monetary tightening cycle among all Asean members in 2023. However, the country emerged as Southeast Asia’s fastest-growing economy with a growth rate of 5.6 per cent.

site_title: Gold range-bound as investors brace for Fed decision, Powell speech
summary: Gold prices remained range-bound on Wednesday ahead of the US Federal Reserve's policy decision and remarks from Fed chair Jerome Powell. Spot gold rose 0.1% to $2,159.50 per ounce, while US gold futures edged 0.1% higher to $2,162.60. The Fed is expected to hold interest rates steady, but traders await its economic and interest rate projections for the rest of the year. A stronger US dollar makes gold more expensive for other currency holders, reducing hopes for rate cuts.

images.alt_text: Higher interest rates reduce the appeal of holding non-yielding gold.

site_title: Vientiane Logistics Park – the new kid on the Asean bloc
summary: The Thanaleng Dry Port in Laos has seen significant upgrades, becoming a key economic hub for the country. The dry port, operated by Sitthi Logistics Lao, has handled 3.1 million tonnes of cargo since its opening in December 2021, with revenue from customs procedures tripling. The port's relocation of customs procedures has allowed the Lao government to control revenue collection. The dry port is part of the Vientiane Logistics Park, a US$727 million project that will include an export processing zone and other facilities. The project has been supported by a US$46 million loan from the International Financial Corp.

images.alt_text: A rendering of the new Techo International Airport in Phnom Penh that is due to be the ninth-largest in the world when it opens its doors next year.
People at an HSR exhibition during the groundbreaking ceremony on the cooperation between Thailand and China on the Bangkok-Nong Khai HSR development in Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand.
Tourists walk down the mountain through a night market in Luang Prabang, Laos. The country's public debt stands at 122 per cent of GDP.
Passengers ready to board the Laos-China Railway in Luang Prabang, Laos. The 420 km link was built at a cost of US$6 billion.

site_title: New Banksy mural depicting tree foliage appears in north London
summary: A new Banksy mural has appeared in north London, depicting a tree with green paint lines that align with the bare branches to represent leaves. The artwork was posted on Banksy's Instagram account, where the artist typically claims responsibility for his works. The piece includes a stencil of a person holding a spraying device, characteristic of Banksy's style. The mural's location and details have not been disclosed, but it has been viewed by Banksy's over 12 million followers.

images.alt_text: The Mercer Labs Museum of Art and Technology features works by Roy Nachum, a painter, sculptor and sound and light designer.

site_title: Singapore scores early win in race for Chinese tourist dollars
summary: Singapore has seen a significant increase in Chinese tourist arrivals, with over 327,000 visitors in February, a 96% rebound from 2019 levels. The city-state's decision to drop visa requirements, focus on safety, and unique cultural events have positioned it as a top destination for Chinese travelers. Average spending per visitor has also risen 30% from last year, with direct flights from China remaining popular. Singapore's strong cultural ties with China, as well as its conservative government's focus on safety, have contributed to its appeal, with the country expected to see a surge in visitors in the months ahead.

images.alt_text: Tourists walk on the Supertree skywalk at Gardens by the Bay in Singapore on March 8, 2024. (Photo by Mohd RASFAN / AFP)
The February passenger traffic was also 33.7 per cent higher than that for February 2023.
Taylor Swift held the first of six shows here on Mar 2, with over 300,000 tickets sold.

site_title: China banks hold lending rates as PBOC refrains from easing
summary: China's benchmark lending rates remained unchanged as the People's Bank of China (PBOC) refrained from easing monetary policy. The one-year loan prime rate (LPR) stayed at 3.45% and the five-year rate remained at 3.95%, as expected. Despite robust economic growth data, loans grew at the slowest pace on record in February, offsetting concerns over credit expansion. The PBOC is likely to maintain a loose monetary policy this year, with some economists divided on the timing of the next rate cut.

images.alt_text: The stock of yuan loans grew 9.7 per cent in February from a year ago, the lowest in data going back to 2003, PBOC data shows.

The People’s Bank of China said it was keeping the rate on 387 billion yuan (S$72 billion) worth of one-year medium-term lending facility (MLF) loans to some financial institutions unchanged at 2.50 per cent.

PBOC says foreign entities owned 2.8 trillion yuan (S$523.3 billion) of onshore Chinese equities at the end of last year, down 13 per cent from 12 months earlier, and a drop of almost 30 per cent from the peak at the end of 2021.

site_title: The Philippines’ growth to stay ‘stronger for longer’ in 2024: economists
summary: The Philippines' economy is expected to maintain its growth momentum in 2024, driven by consumer spending, favorable demographics, and rising income per capita. The country's solid 5.6% growth in 2023, the highest among South-east Asian peers, has led economists to forecast a "stronger for longer" growth trajectory. Factors such as a resumption in commercial activities, public infrastructure spending, and growth in digital financial services are expected to support growth. However, lingering inflation risks and a cautious central bank may slow down private sector spending, with economists forecasting a growth rate of 5.3-6% in 2024.

images.alt_text: Zhao Yifan
The BSP has kept interest rates at 6.50 per cent for three straight meetings since late last year and will next review policy on Apr 4.
US President Joe Biden will host his Philippines counterpart Ferdinand Marcos (left) and Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida (right) on April 11 .
Philippines President Ferdinand Marcos Jr, who is on a three-day working visit in Germany, secured US$4 billion worth of investment pledges from German companies.

site_title: China launches satellite critical for mission to moon’s far side
summary: China successfully launched the Queqiao-2 relay satellite, a critical component for its mission to collect samples from the moon's far side. The 1.2-tonne satellite will relay signals to and from the spacecraft, Chang'e-6, which is scheduled to travel to the far side in the first half of 2024. This launch marks the latest step in China's ambitious space program, with over 100 missions planned for the year, including a record 70 launches by state-owned space contractor China Aerospace Science and Technology.

images.alt_text: Kairos, which in ancient Greek means “the right moment”, was carrying a government satellite, according to Space One.
A record 100 Chinese missions are expected in 2024, state media reported recently, up more than 40 per cent from last year.

Khaldoon Mubarak, the CEO and Managing Director of Mubadala Investment, says that sovereign wealth funds have an opportunity and responsibility to transform from asset investors to enablers of global progress.

site_title: ‘AI doesn’t worry me at all’: photographer Annie Leibovitz
summary: Annie Leibovitz, the world's most famous living photographer, will be inducted into the French Academy of Fine Arts, recognizing her 50-year career. Leibovitz, known for iconic figures such as John Lennon and Demi Moore, believes AI-generated images pose no threat to her trade, seeing it as a new artistic tool. She views editing and control as inherent to photography, regardless of technology. Leibovitz, who began her career in 1970, praises the honor, noting it's a bigger honor for photography itself, and will be presented with a ceremonial sword by Vogue boss Anna Wintour.

images.alt_text: (FILES) US photographer Annie Leibovitz arrives for the 2022 Met Gala at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on May 2, 2022, in New York. Photographer to the stars Annie Leibovitz, inducted in the French Academy of Fine Arts on March 20, 2024, told AFP that AI was not a threat to her trade -- just another artistic tool. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

site_title: No bids as house of Myanmar’s Suu Kyi auctioned
summary: Myanmar's lakeside mansion, where democracy leader Aung San Suu Kyi spent years under house arrest, was auctioned for a minimum price of $150 million but attracted no bids. The property, owned by Suu Kyi and her brother, was put up for sale following a decades-long dispute. The auction took place on March 20, 2024, with a small crowd of journalists present. The outcome of the auction highlights the ongoing dispute and Suu Kyi's continued detention since the 2021 military coup.

images.alt_text: PM Lee Hsien Loong (third from left) and other Asean leaders, as well as Australian PM Anthony Albanese (sixth from right), at the Asean-Australia Special Summit in Melbourne on Mar 6.
A rendering of the new Techo International Airport in Phnom Penh that is due to be the ninth-largest in the world when it opens its doors next year.

epa10845478 Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese speaks at a press conference on the sideline of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Summit in Jakarta, Indonesia, 07 September 2023.  EPA-EFE/MICK TSIKAS AUSTRALIA AND NEW ZEALAND OUT
Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong says Canberra is providing A$286.5 million in funding for Asean projects in areas including maritime security.

A Filipino fisherman (front) sailing past a Chinese coast guard ship near the China-controlled Scarborough Shoal, in disputed waters of the South China Sea, Feb 16, 2024. Maritime security - and China’s increasingly aggressive behaviour in the South China Sea - figures to be one of Asean's major focal points.

The Thai embassy in Yangon has been swamped with young men and women seeking visas to get out of Myanmar since the announcement last Saturday that the “People’s Military Service Law” would be brought into force.

Since October, the Tatmadaw, as the military is known, has suffered personnel losses while battling a coordinated offensive by an alliance of three ethnic minority insurgent groups, as well as allied pro-democracy fighters who have taken up arms against the junta.

epa10779215 (FILE) - Myanmar State Counselor Aung San Suu Kyi (R) waits for the arrival of Chinese President Xi at the presidential house in Naypyitaw, Myanmar, 17 January 2020 (reissued 01 August 2023). According to state media, Myanmar's Chairman of the State Administration Council granted amnesty on 01 August 2023 to ousted civilian leader Aung San Suu Kyi for a number of offenses, more than two years after she was detained in the 2021 military coup.  EPA-EFE/NYEIN CHAN NAING

site_title: China’s builders tackle restructuring as crisis enters new phase
summary: China's property-debt crisis has entered a new phase, with at least 23 builders or related companies receiving wind-up petitions from creditors since the crisis began. Five have been ordered to wind up, including China Evergrande Group, which faces a liquidation order and a fine for falsely inflating revenue. Smaller peers, such as Redsun Properties Group and Kaisa Group Holdings, will face court battles in the coming weeks. The crisis has resulted in $111 billion of defaults on onshore and offshore bonds since 2021, with debt restructuring efforts ongoing for several major developers.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People sit on a bench at a park near residential buildings in Beijing, China January 15, 2024. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo

site_title: Boeing mulls shedding Airbus work in potential Spirit Aero deal
summary: Boeing is exploring the possibility of shedding or redeploying Spirit AeroSystems' Airbus component supply business if it reaches a deal with Spirit. The US planemaker is looking to offload or redeploy specific Spirit businesses that supply key Airbus components to avoid complications in a potential acquisition. Boeing is fine-tuning a defensive strategy in case European regulators object to Airbus relying on its main rival for key components, and has also considered selling the Airbus business to other companies.

images.alt_text: Boeing has come under intense scrutiny since the accident and as multiple reviews detailed problems with the planemaker’s safety culture and quality practices.
Boeing was rocked in January by a door plug blowout on one of its 737 MAX 9 jets during an Alaska Airlines flight.
Korean Air does not operate the A350 but does fly the older generation 777, while Asiana has 15 A350s with a further 15 on order.
Boeing’s recent problems are further widening the gap between supply and demand.
An LATAM Airlines 787 plane, which was heading from Sydney to Auckland on Monday, dropped abruptly before stabilising, causing those on board to be thrown about the cabin.

This photograph taken on June 7, 2023, shows an Qatar Airways Airbus A320 aircraft landing at the newly opened runway of Belgrade Nikola Tesla airport. The opening of Belgrade airport's new runway marked the completion of one of the major infrastructure projects undertaken by French operator Vinci, since taking over the concession in late 2018. (Photo by Andrej ISAKOVIC / AFP)

site_title: JAL nears decision on potential wide-body jet order: sources
summary: JAPAN Airlines is nearing a decision on a potential order of about two dozen wide-body jets, with Boeing expected to win at least part of the multi-billion-dollar deal. The carrier is reviewing its medium-term plans, following a prolonged downturn in demand for long-haul aircraft. This comes as international travel recovers from the pandemic, driving demand for wide-body jets and engine/maintenance contracts. Boeing and Airbus declined to comment, while Korean Air plans to buy around 20 A350 jets from Airbus as it gears up for a pending merger.

images.alt_text: Korean Air does not operate the A350 but does fly the older generation 777, while Asiana has 15 A350s with a further 15 on order.

site_title: Oil rises to multi-month highs on Russian supply concerns
summary: Global oil prices rose to multi-month highs on Tuesday, with Brent crude reaching $87.38 a barrel, the highest since October 31. The increase follows recent attacks on Russian refineries by Ukraine, which have shut down 7% of Russian refining capacity. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures also rose, settling at $83.47 a barrel, amid concerns about global petroleum supplies. The price surge marks the second straight session of gains, as traders assess the impact of the attacks on global oil production.

images.alt_text: Fossil fuels accounted for 82 per cent of global consumption last year, according to a report from consultancy KPMG cited by Saudi Aramco chief executive Amin Nasser, who noted that the International Energy Agency has said oil demand could hit a record high this year.
Brent futures rose US$1.55, or 1.8 per cent, to settle at US$86.89 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude rose US$1.68, or 2.1 per cent, to settle at US$82.72 on Monday.

site_title: Yen falls to lowest since 2008 against euro as BOJ path seen gradual
summary: Japan's currency, the yen, has dropped 0.3% to 164.35 per euro, its weakest level since 2008, amid speculation the Bank of Japan will keep monetary policy accommodative despite ending negative interest rates. The yen is also falling towards a level unseen since 1990 against the US dollar, extending its 7% loss this year. The Bank of Japan's governor, Kazuo Ueda, has insisted that financial conditions will stay loose, despite recent interest rate hikes. This weakening yen is attributed to Japan's large yield discount to other developed economies, particularly the US.

site_title: Finland is world’s happiest country for seventh year: study
summary: Finland remains the world's happiest country for a seventh consecutive year, according to the UN-sponsored World Happiness Report. Nordic countries, including Denmark, Iceland, and Sweden, also rank among the top 10 happiest nations. The report notes that the happiest countries no longer include any of the world's largest nations, with Finland's close connection to nature, healthy work-life balance, and strong welfare society contributing to its high life satisfaction. In contrast, Afghanistan, plagued by a humanitarian catastrophe, remains the least happy country.

images.alt_text: Finland’s Framery is one of the biggest worldwide sellers of privacy booths. Its engineers have found a way to embed sensors into the booths’ seats that track the vital signs of those who sit inside, to detect if, say, the salespeople are getting frazzled.

As Chinese travellers gear up for the Lunar New Year holiday, more are eschewing group tours and shop-till-you-drop holidays and opting for more adventurous, experience-based trips, industry experts say.

site_title: JetBlue cuts unprofitable routes in overhaul of flight network
summary: JetBlue Airways will cut nearly a third of its flights out of Los Angeles International Airport in June, including routes to Las Vegas, Miami, and San Francisco, due to unprofitable routes. The airline will also eliminate flights between Fort Lauderdale and several cities, and end service in South America. This overhaul comes after failed attempts to save an operating partnership with American Airlines and preserve an acquisition of Spirit Airlines. JetBlue's CEO Joanna Geraghty prioritizes consistent profits, and the changes aim to boost shareholder value.

images.alt_text: Jet Blue planes docked at the gates at the Jet Blue Terminal, terminal number 5 at JFK Airport in New York, U.S., on Tuesday, Jan. 28, 2014. Photographer: Craig Warga/Bloomberg *** Local Caption ***

site_title: Stocks to watch: Wilmar, CLI, FLCT, Frasers Hospitality Trust, Second Chance
summary: Wilmar International plans to increase its stake in Pakistan-listed Unity Foods by acquiring up to 277.1 million shares through a public offer. CapitaLand Investment raised one billion yuan from its sustainability-linked bond, while Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust is offering S$175 million in fixed-rate notes. Frasers Hospitality Trust will not acquire interests in Capri by Fraser at Changi City due to its prevailing investment strategy. Second Chance Properties expects a significant decrease in net profit for the first half of 2024.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, there were more decliners than gainers 275 to 227 as 1.7 billion securities valued at S$966.5 million in total were transacted.

site_title: Citigroup has sold most non-US consumer businesses as revamp progresses
summary: Citigroup has sold most of its non-US consumer businesses in nine regions and "substantially wound down" three more, as part of its largest overhaul in over two decades. The bank aims to simplify its structure into five businesses, reduce duplication in roles, and lower its global headcount by 20,000 over the next two years. The company has also lowered CFO Mark Mason's pay by 5% to $13.3 million and is on track to launch an initial public offering for its Mexican consumer business in 2025. The restructuring is expected to be completed by the end of March.

site_title: Meta does not expect new Nvidia chips to arrive until at least next year
summary: Meta Platforms is not expecting to receive shipments of Nvidia's new B200 "Blackwell" AI chip until at least next year, according to a Meta spokesperson. The B200 is 30 times faster than previous Nvidia chips in tasks like serving chatbot answers. Nvidia's chief financial officer Colette Kress stated that shipment volume for the new GPUs won't ramp up until 2025, despite plans to use the B200 to train Meta's Llama models. Meta had previously planned to use the B200 to train its Llama 3 model by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: NVIDIA logo is seen near computer motherboard in this illustration taken January 8, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration//File Photo
In December, Turkey authority launched an investigation into Facebook parent Meta over a possible violation of competition law by linking its social media platforms Instagram and the newer Threads.
The suggested partnership with Google has the potential to thwart Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg's plan to 'own the next computational platform for AR, VR, and mixed reality.'
Meta is, however, not obligated to pay news publishers if it implements a ban that prevents users from reposting news articles

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Wednesday’s open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% at the opening bell on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) increasing 7.39 points to 3,180.94. Gainers outnumbered losers 80 to 23, driven by gains in Seatrium, Singtel, and Thai Beverage. Banking stocks were mixed, with DBS falling and OCBC and UOB rising. The move followed overnight gains on global markets, as investors awaited the Federal Reserve interest rate decision.

images.alt_text: Wilmar International unit intends to make further investment in Pakistan-listed Unity Foods

site_title: Saudi Arabia plans US$40 billion push into artificial intelligence: NYT
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to create a $40 billion fund to invest in artificial intelligence (AI), with the Public Investment Fund (PIF) partnering with US venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz. The fund is expected to support tech start-ups in AI, including chip makers and data centers. PIF governor Yasir Al-Rumayyan has discussed the potential partnership and the role of Andreessen Horowitz, which may set up an office in Riyadh. The fund is expected to start in the second half of 2024 and could attract other venture capitalists.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Figurines with computers and smartphones are seen in front of the words "Artificial Intelligence AI" in this illustration taken, February 19, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Planet ‘on the brink’, with new heat records likely in 2024: UN
summary: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) confirmed that 2023 was the hottest year ever recorded, with global temperatures "smashed" heat records. The UN's State of the Climate report warns that 2024 is likely to be even hotter, with the planet on the brink of catastrophic climate change. Average near-surface temperatures were 1.45°C above pre-industrial levels, nearing the 1.5°C threshold agreed upon in the 2015 Paris Climate Accords. Marine heatwaves gripped nearly a third of the global ocean, and glaciers suffered record ice loss, with the Antarctic sea ice extent at its lowest on record. The report calls for urgent action to stop burning fossil fuels and limit damage.

images.alt_text: Last year, BP said its carbon emissions would not fall as quickly as anticipated, as it posted record annual profit thanks to soaring oil and gas prices.
A pineapple farm on burnt peatland in Indonesia's Riau province. New research shows that the carbon emissions generated from draining out peatlands may be more than previously estimated.

site_title: FLCT prices S$175 million notes due 2029 at 3.83%
summary: Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) is issuing S$175 million in fixed-rate notes due 2029 at 3.83% under its S$1 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme. The notes will be issued on March 26 and have been assigned a "BBB+" rating by S&P Global Ratings. The proceeds will be used to refinance existing borrowings or fund acquisitions, including a proposed German logistics acquisition. DBS and OCBC have been appointed as joint lead managers and bookrunners for the Series 002 notes.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Frasers Logistics and Commercial Trust is acquiring an 89.9 per cent interest in four properties in Germany from its sponsor, Frasers Property, including a leasehold asset in Hamburg (pictured).
FLCT expects e-commerce demand to drive demand for quality warehousing.
Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust's property operating expenses are up for the half-year ended September mainly due to higher energy and utility expenses.

site_title: Boeing needs more focus on safety and quality, FAA chief says
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) chief, Michael Whitaker, has expressed concerns that Boeing needs to prioritize safety and quality over production. Following the January failure of a fuselage panel on an Alaska Airlines 737 Max 9 flight, Whitaker stated that Boeing's focus on production has led to issues with its safety culture. The FAA is now shifting its focus to ensure the manufacturer addresses these concerns, with the goal of improving safety and quality practices.

images.alt_text: Boeing was rocked in January by a door plug blowout on one of its 737 MAX 9 jets during an Alaska Airlines flight.
Boeing’s recent problems are further widening the gap between supply and demand.
An LATAM Airlines 787 plane, which was heading from Sydney to Auckland on Monday, dropped abruptly before stabilising, causing those on board to be thrown about the cabin.

site_title: CLI issues 1 billion yuan of 3.5% sustainability-linked bonds in China
summary: CapitaLand Investment (CLI) has issued 1 billion yuan of 3.5% sustainability-linked bonds in China, raising 1.65 times subscribed funds from institutional investors. The bond, the first sustainability-linked "panda" bond by a Singapore company, aims to lower CLI's energy consumption by 6% by 2024. The issuance provides access to lower-cost yuan-denominated capital and expands domestic channels, diversifying CLI's capital sources and increasing financial flexibility. The bond is rated "AAA" by China Chengxin International Credit Rating.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
CLI holds a 5.1 per cent interest in Gallileo while the CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) owns the remaining majority stake
CLI had recorded S$600 million in revaluation and impairment losses during the period.

site_title: JPMorgan boosts quarterly dividend 9.5% after record profit
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co announced a 9.5% increase in its quarterly dividend to $1.15 a share, following a record annual profit. The move comes amid regulators signaling a potential rethink of proposals to tighten capital rules, which JPMorgan had estimated could cost it $50 billion. The firm has sent $60 billion to shareholders through dividends and stock buybacks over the past three years, with its stock price climbing 14% this year to $193.79.

images.alt_text: A view of the exterior of the JP Morgan Chase & Co. corporate headquarters in New York City May 20, 2015.  REUTERS/Mike Segar/Files/

site_title: Ex-Trump aide Navarro reports to prison to serve contempt sentence
summary: Peter Navarro, former Trump White House trade advisor, reported to a Florida prison to begin serving a four-month sentence for contempt of Congress. Navarro, 74, was found guilty of two counts of contempt in September for refusing to comply with a subpoena to testify before a congressional panel investigating the January 6, 2021 US Capitol attack. This marks the highest-ranking former Trump administration member to serve prison time for actions related to the 2020 election.

images.alt_text: The package is expected to cover about three-quarters of discretionary government spending for the fiscal year ending Sep 30.

Donald Trump's cash crunch raises the possibility that the state of New York could begin seizing the former president’s property as soon as next Monday unless the court - known as the First Department of the Appellate Division - agrees to a delay.

China on March 14, 2024 slammed the approval of a US bill that would ban TikTok unless it severs ties with its Chinese parent company, blasting Washington's "bandit" mentality and vowing Beijing would "take all necessary measures" to protect the interests of its companies overseas. “The government is attempting to strip 170 million Americans of their Constitutional right to free expression,” Tiktok says.
In 2020, Donald Trump sought to ban TikTok and Chinese-owned WeChat but was blocked by the courts.

site_title: No oil and gas majors aligned with climate targets: report
summary: A new report by Carbon Tracker found that none of the 25 largest listed oil and gas companies align with internationally agreed climate goals to limit warming to 1.5°C. The assessment, which evaluates the firms' fossil fuel expansion plans, concludes that all major oil and gas companies plan to increase fossil fuel production, incompatible with meeting the 1.5°C target. This report highlights the need for investors to reassess their investments in these companies.

images.alt_text: The three banks have proposed to help finance the accelerated closing of the Cirebon-1 coal-fired power station in West Java.
(From left) Nato Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg and Azerbaijani President Ilham Aliyev deliver press statements following their talks in Baku, Azerbaijan on March 17, 2024.

site_title: US single-family housing starts, permits near two-year highs
summary: US single-family housing starts surged 11.6% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.129 million units in February, the highest level since April 2022, boosted by mild temperatures and a housing shortage. Despite higher mortgage rates, builders are cutting prices and offering incentives to increase sales. Permits for single-family housing units rose 1.0% to a rate of 1.031 million units, the highest level since May 2022. Economists expect homebuilding to contribute to economic growth this year as mortgage rates are expected to decrease.

images.alt_text: Builder sentiment has been improving so far this year, though it’s still well below prepandemic levels.
New listings have been rising, which could motivate more buyers to jump into the market.
The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage decreased 18 basis points, the biggest decline in nearly three months, to 6.84 per cent in the week ended Mar 8.
A gauge of contract signings from the National Association of Realtors (NAR) decreases 4.9 per cent to 74.3, after surging to an eight-month high in December.
Mortgage rates stay above 7% as Fed in no rush to ease policy.

Though their 2 per cent inflation target uses an index that is less sensitive to shelter costs, Fed officials still see housing and rent dynamics as an important, unresolved part of their inflation battle.

The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage increases 19 basis points in the week ended Feb 16 to 7.06 per cent
Builder sentiment began rebounding late last year as mortgage rates declined, falling below 7% in December.
The Commerce Department says that construction spending rose 0.9 per cent.

site_title: Ted Baker to go into administration: statement
summary: British clothing chain Ted Baker is going into administration across Europe due to outstanding debt and a challenging retail environment. Founded in 1987, the brand faced a sexual harassment scandal in 2019 that led to its founder's resignation. The company's parent, Authentic Brands Group, has released a statement expressing regret and focusing on securing a new partner to grow the brand. The move is expected to impact Ted Baker employees and stakeholders.

images.alt_text: Ted Baker is owned by Authentic Brands Group, the US company which is also behind brands such as Reebok.
UK fashion retailer Ted Baker puts itself up for sale as buyers show interest
UK's Ted Baker rebuffs US PE firm's takeover proposals

site_title: Nvidia expects no ‘doomsday’ in US vs China tensions
summary: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang expressed confidence that a "doomsday scenario" between the US and China over technology exports is unlikely, but is preparing for the worst. The company is ensuring its China-bound chips comply with US restrictions and diversifying its supply chain. Despite US export curbs, Nvidia is expanding its ties with Chinese electric vehicle makers, including BYD, and has unveiled new AI-powered computing systems. Huang noted that parts for these systems come from various countries, including China, and that the auto and defense industries also rely on global suppliers.

images.alt_text: The new type of chip – called the HBM3E – is a focal point of intense competition.

BYD, which overtook Tesla last year as the world’s No. 1 electric vehicle manufacturer, will use Nvidia’s next generation of in-vehicle chips, called Drive Thor, to enable increased levels of autonomous driving and other digital functions, Nvidia said.
Nvidia is no stranger to triple-digit gains after soaring 231 per cent in 2023 on optimism for its semiconductors used in artificial intelligence technology.

Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang unveils the flagship B200 AI chip which takes two chips the size of Nvidia‘s previous offering and binds them together into a single chip, San Jose, California, March 18, 2024.

site_title: Greater urgency for peatland protection in South-east Asia
summary: New research highlights the urgent need to protect South-east Asia's peatlands, which store about a third of the world's carbon, due to their degradation and carbon emissions. Over 25 million hectares of peatlands have been destroyed in the region over the past 30 years, primarily for palm oil plantations and agricultural activities. Draining peatlands releases carbon dioxide and contributes to greenhouse gas emissions, with new research suggesting the emissions may be more than previously estimated. Regional governments and organizations are launching efforts to map and rehabilitate peatlands, but more action is needed to balance protection with farmer livelihoods.

images.alt_text: Transition finance is crucial for South-east Asia as it has yet to wean itself off fossil fuels

site_title: China releases action plan to attract foreign investment
summary: China's State Council has released an action plan to attract foreign investment, following a record low in overseas investment last year. The plan aims to loosen visa rules, support data flow, and implement preferential tax policies for foreign investors. It also calls for the selection of foreign firms to expand into areas such as genetic diagnosis and treatment technologies, and promotes the resumption of international flights. The plan is part of efforts to boost foreign investment, despite concerns over China's long-term growth prospects and "promise fatigue" among global CEOs.

site_title: Gucci sales to plunge 20% in first quarter on Asia slowdown, Kering says
summary: Kering warned that Gucci sales will plummet 20% in the first quarter due to a decline in the Asia-Pacific region, widening the gap with luxury rivals LVMH and Hermes International. This comes as Gucci struggles to attract wealthy shoppers and Kering's shares have dropped 22% over the past year. Comparable sales at Kering are expected to decline 10% in the period, with early ready-to-wear products from Gucci meeting with a favorable reception. The company's quarterly results are set to be released on April 23.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians pass a Gucci luxury clothing boutique, operated by Kering SA, in central Paris, France, on Monday Feb. 5, 2024. Kering report full year earnings on Feb. 8. Photographer: Benjamin Girette/Bloomberg
Kering joins others snapping up buildings in New York instead of leasing space.
Gucci said in October it was transferring 153 of its 219 design employees from Rome to Milan, a move the strikers claim is “a mass redundancy in disguise”.
Gucci partnered with Christie’s to sell the three bags, with the proceeds going to Save Venice, a charity which seeks “to preserve the artistic heritage” of the Italian city.

site_title: Microsoft hires DeepMind co-founder to lead AI unit
summary: Microsoft hires Mustafa Suleyman, co-founder of DeepMind, as the head of its newly created consumer AI unit. Suleyman's hiring marks a major move by Microsoft, which already partners with ChatGPT creator OpenAI. Suleyman is a key figure in the artificial intelligence revolution, and his integration with Microsoft aims to further accelerate the company's adoption of generative AI, as seen in its Copilot chatbot.

images.alt_text: (FILES) Mustafa Suleyman, CEO of Inflection AI, speaks during The Wall Street Journal's WSJ Tech Live Conference in Laguna Beach, California on October 17, 2023. DeepMind co-founder Mustafa Suleyman will become the head of a newly created consumer AI unit at Microsoft, the scientist and entrepreneur said on MArch 19, 2024. Suleyman is one of the biggest names in the artificial intelligence revolution that is taking the technology world by storm and his hiring is a major move by Microsoft, which already partners with ChatGPT creator OpenAI. (Photo by Patrick T. Fallon / AFP)

site_title: Is Asean truly a winner in globalisation 2.0?
summary: Asean countries are emerging as key beneficiaries of the global shift towards de-risking, with a surge in high-tech foreign direct investment from the US and China. However, the region's intermediate exports, such as critical minerals and semiconductors, remain vulnerable to the fallout. To mitigate these risks, Asean countries are focusing on intra-regional integration, particularly through a more connected digital economy. The ongoing negotiations for the Asean Digital Economy Framework Agreement aim to facilitate digital trade, cross-border e-commerce, and promote digital payments. An integrated Asean can strengthen its voice in the world's geo-economic arena and influence global economic discourse.

images.alt_text: Asia-Pacific CEOs, in contrast to other regions, place sustainability initiatives on par with or above other business priorities when it comes to capital allocation.
There are fears that rising geopolitical strife will undermine growth, not least by shattering global supply chains.
The World Trade Organization estimates that a disintegration of the global economy into separate blocs could reduce global gross domestic product by about 5 per cent over the long term.
The United States and 17 allies agreed to collaborate on solutions to short-term issues including transportation and “supply chain disruptions and bottlenecks,” as well as long-term challenges.
Overseas companies last year invest 1.13 trillion yuan (S$209 billion) in the world’s second-largest economy.
In his speech at the Nikkei forum in Tokyo, DPM Wong HAS reiterated that Asean will continue to grow its links with both the US and China.

site_title: PepsiCo to replace Coca-Cola at Subway’s US locations
summary: Subway has agreed to a 10-year pact with PepsiCo to serve their products, including Mountain Dew, Tropicana, and Gatorade, replacing Coca-Cola as the exclusive beverage provider at its US locations. The change is set to begin in January 2025, with Coca-Cola brands disappearing from Subway restaurants during this period. This marks a significant shift for Subway, which previously relied on Coca-Cola for its beverages.

images.alt_text: Subway has been owned by its founding families since its first outlet opened in 1965 as “Pete’s Super Submarines” at Bridgeport, Connecticut.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust not acquiring interest in Capri by Fraser at Changi City from sponsor
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT) will not acquire interests in Capri by Fraser at Changi City from its sponsor, Frasers Property, due to not meeting the Reit's prevailing investment strategy. The managers of FHT received a notice from Frasers Property of its intention to divest its interest to a third party, citing the right of first refusal. The decision not to pursue the acquisition was made in accordance with FHT's investment strategy, according to a bourse filing.

site_title: US: S&P 500 finishes at new record as stocks advance
summary: US stocks advanced on Tuesday, with the S&P 500 reaching a new record at 5,178.51, up 0.6%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average jumped 0.8% to 39,110.76, while the Nasdaq Composite Index climbed 0.4% to 16,166.79. The gains came ahead of a Federal Reserve decision, with investors focusing on interest rate expectations and Nvidia's artificial intelligence offerings. Despite a lackluster open, stocks rebounded as investors digested the Bank of Japan's interest rate hike and other market news.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rises 29.18 points or 0.08 per cent at the open to 38,819.61.

site_title: Facebook co-founder Saverin’s B Capital raises US$750 million in new fund
summary: Eduardo Saverin's B Capital has raised US$750 million in its second Opportunities Fund, nearly doubling the size of its predecessor. The fund will focus on late-stage startups in sectors like technology, healthcare, and climate tech, primarily investing in existing portfolio companies. B Capital now has over US$6 billion in assets under management across various funds.

images.alt_text: Mr Eduardo Saverin, co-founder of Meta Platforms (formerly Facebook) and a Singapore resident, topped the 2023 Forbes list of Singapore's 50 Richest.

site_title: New regulations won’t halt decline in taxi population, say industry watchers
summary: New regulations for Singapore's point-to-point transport sector aim to reduce operating costs for taxis, including a longer statutory lifespan and less frequent inspections. However, industry watchers say these changes won't halt the decline in taxi population, as ride-hailing platforms remain dominant. The shift in commuter preferences towards ride-hailing is the underlying reason for the fall in taxis, with smaller operators no longer required to maintain call-booking services. While taxis play a role in providing a stable supply of rides, their competitiveness against ride-hailing platforms is limited, and operators must develop their own ride-hailing platforms to remain viable.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
Certificate of entitlement (COE) premiums for passenger cars rose, while those for commercial vehicles and motorcycles remained flat.
The government says that having a separate Certificate of Entitlement (COE) category for private hire cars is possible, but the trade-offs must be studied carefully.
The trade-offs of a one-time rise will need to be studied carefully, says Transport Minister Chee Hong Tat.

site_title: A win for automakers as US softens EV mileage rule
summary: US regulators have softened their proposal to slash electric vehicles' mileage ratings, easing the impact on automakers. The new rules reduce mileage reductions from 72% to 65% by 2030, allowing automakers to build more gas-powered vehicles while meeting Corporate Average Fuel Economy requirements. This decision is a win for Detroit Three automakers and the United Auto Workers union, avoiding US$10.5 billion in fines through 2032. The revised rules phase in changes gradually, giving automakers more time to adjust.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A bronze seal for the Department of the Treasury is shown at the U.S. Treasury building in Washington, U.S., January 20, 2023.  REUTERS/Kevin Lamarque/File Photo

site_title: Petronas looking at new LNG investments in Atlantic Basin
summary: Petronas, Malaysia's state energy firm, is considering new LNG investments in the Atlantic Basin. The company aims to increase its global LNG market share to 10% and is looking at taking an equity stake in the second phase of LNG Canada's gas-export plant in Kitimat, British Columbia. This move is part of Petronas' efforts to expand its LNG business and keep pace with growing demand.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 19)
summary: SingPost plans to reorganize into three business units to generate a spread above the cost of capital. The company considers divesting its flagship SingPost Centre and floating its Australian business as options. Meanwhile, the private rental market in Singapore declined in February, with HDB rents reaching a new all-time high. The manager of Manulife US Reit appointed John Casasante as CEO and CFO, and WP chief Pritam Singh was charged with lying to Parliament over Raeesah Khan's case. ShopBack cut 195 employees to become more sustainable, and Singtel launched a cloud computing offering with Nvidia AI chips.

site_title: Singapore shares end flat on Tuesday as investors await Fed’s policy meeting
summary: Singapore shares ended flat on Tuesday as investors await the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting on Wednesday. The Straits Times Index rose 0.05% to 3,173.55, driven by gains in SingPost, which closed 6.6% higher after announcing a strategic review aimed at unlocking value. Decliners surpassed gainers 275 to 227, with 1.7 billion securities worth S$966.5 million changing hands. Investors await the Fed's policy meeting, which could impact market sentiment.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
In early trade, Tokyo stocks were lower, while the yen weakened slightly against the dollar, with observers pointing out that the decision had largely been priced in by markets.

SingPost announces the completion of its strategic review which was initiated in May 2023.

site_title: JP Morgan Asset Management aims for US$1 trillion in active ETFs assets
summary: JP Morgan Asset Management (JPMAM) aims to expand its active exchange-traded funds (ETF) assets to US$1 trillion by 2029, from the current US$164 billion. CEO George Gatch believes active management is key to outperforming passive index trackers, particularly in fixed income ETFs, where actively managed funds have historically outperformed indices. JPMAM invests over US$500 million annually in technology and plans to increase this investment by 10% this year. The company sees opportunities in actively managed ETFs, which currently account for 6% of the overall ETF market but attracted 20% of net flows in 2023.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua
JP Morgan strategists say while there is concern over the strong outperformance of the Magnificent 7 stocks, trading is less stretched than a few years ago.
Generative AI is likely to touch all areas of the economy, and productivity is likely to be enhanced across many industries.

site_title: SpaceX says it plans to sell satellite laser links commercially
summary: SpaceX is selling satellite laser links commercially, enabling faster in-space data transfer between its thousands of Starlink satellites. The technology, used to pass data at the speed of light, will be sold to other satellite firms, allowing for broader global internet coverage with fewer ground stations. SpaceX president Gwynne Shotwell announced the plan at the Satellite Show conference in Washington, with the technology set to be rolled out with the Polaris Dawn mission later this summer.

site_title: Shell appoints Joiner in reshuffle of gas, power trading unit
summary: Shell appoints Greg Joiner to head its Shell Energy unit, effective April 1, following Steve Hill's departure. Joiner, currently European business head, will oversee renewable generation, gas, and power marketing. Tom Summers will lead LNG trading and David Wells will head power, gas, and environmental products trading. This reshuffle is part of Shell's broader trading division restructuring.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of British multinational oil and gas company Shell is displayed during the LNG 2023 energy trade show in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, July 12, 2023. REUTERS/Chris Helgren//File Photo

site_title: Stopping bullying and harassment at sea by being kind
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) is developing training requirements to combat bullying and harassment at sea, following a survey by ship manager Danica that found one in 20 seafarers reported experiencing bullying, with 4% feeling discriminated against due to race and 1% experiencing sexual harassment. The International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) has launched industry principles to combat and eliminate harassment and bullying, emphasizing the need for suitable policies and measures. The IMO's Maritime Safety Committee will consider the ICS's recommendations, and seafarers' unions are urged to raise awareness and set expectations for their members.

The container ship, MSC Luciana, approaches the port of Felixstowe in the UK on Monday (Mar 4).

site_title: Amid tight valuations, stay active in Asian investment-grade bonds
summary: Asian investment-grade (IG) bonds delivered a 7.4% return in 2023, rebounding from 2022's sharp rate hikes. Despite robust macro and issuer fundamentals, valuations are now tight, with the Asian IG Bond index trading at a spread of just under 90 basis points, 2 standard deviations below historical averages. Active credit selection is key to unlocking alpha in this environment, with investors considering factors such as issuer fundamentals and duration exposure.

images.alt_text: The market remains divided on how severe the slowdown will be in the US and globally, once tighter financial conditions take hold.
Philippines President Ferdinand Marcos Jr, who is on a three-day working visit in Germany, secured US$4 billion worth of investment pledges from German companies.
KKR sees opportunities in select sectors in China, such as large technology firms with positive net cash flows, and investment-grade insurers

site_title: Apollo launches new private credit fund seeded by Mubadala
summary: Apollo Global Management has launched a new private credit fund, Middle Market Apollo Institutional Private Lending, seeded by Mubadala Investment with over $790 million in assets. The fund offers a fee waiver for the first year and half of the fees the following year, structured as a business development company. Apollo and Mubadala contributed $290 million to the fund, which will invest 70-80% in US middle market loans. If the fund doesn't double its investment commitments in five years, Apollo will distribute cash back to investors.

images.alt_text: The report follows an earlier FT story that said Singapore’s Temasek Holdings was in talks to invest in OpenAI.
Since 2020, Manipal has acquired three hospital chains,  adding nearly 2,750 beds to its network.

Khaldoon Mubarak, the CEO and Managing Director of Mubadala Investment, says that sovereign wealth funds have an opportunity and responsibility to transform from asset investors to enablers of global progress.

site_title: Deutsche Bank hires ex-Morgan Stanley Asia banker Michael Hufton
summary: Deutsche Bank has hired Michael Hufton, a former Morgan Stanley Asia banker, as co-head of its infrastructure and utilities division for Asia Pacific. Hufton joins Deutsche Bank from Morgan Stanley, where he led infrastructure coverage in Apac, and will be based in Hong Kong. His hire continues Deutsche Bank's efforts to boost its ranks and take market share from Wall Street rivals in the region, following a hiring spree since last year. Hufton will work alongside Roshan Menon, who will relocate to Melbourne.

site_title: BlackRock files with SEC to offer fund with tokenisation firm Securitize
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, is launching a fund through a partnership with digital asset specialist Securitize, offering a tokenised fund on the Ethereum blockchain. The fund, "BlackRock USD Institutional Digital Liquidity Fund," has a minimum investment of $100,000. This marks the latest move by a Wall Street behemoth to experiment with putting money on blockchains, following similar efforts by firms like KKR and Hamilton Lane.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The BlackRock logo is seen outside of its offices in New York City, U.S., October 17, 2016.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Top US congressional Republican, Democrat say deal reached on spending
summary: US congressional leaders, Republican House Speaker Mike Johnson and Democratic Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer, announced a deal to fund the government through the fiscal year's end, covering about three-quarters of discretionary spending. The $1.66 trillion package includes funding for the military, transportation, and other functions, but more fights lie ahead as the nation's growing $34.5 trillion national debt remains unresolved. A weekend shutdown deadline remains, with the agreement's legislative text still being finalized.

images.alt_text: The easing of mortgage rates has also allowed builders to hold off on slashing home prices.

site_title: Second Chance Properties expects H1 net profit to ‘decrease significantly’
summary: Second Chance Properties expects its first-half net profit to decrease significantly, down from S$9.2 million in the same period last year. The decline is attributed to lower gains from disposal of investment properties, with only two disposals in H1 2024 compared to seven in 2023. The company also expects unrealised foreign exchange losses in H1 2024. Its unaudited financial statements are expected to be released on or around March 27.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

site_title: Airbus CEO says Boeing’s problems are bad for whole industry
summary: Airbus CEO Guillaume Faury stated that Boeing's technical problems are detrimental to the entire aerospace industry, as quality and safety remain top priorities. A recent door plug blowout on a 737 MAX 9 jet during an Alaska Airlines flight has raised concerns. Faury expressed dissatisfaction with Boeing's issues, emphasizing the importance of maintaining industry standards.

images.alt_text: Korean Air does not operate the A350 but does fly the older generation 777, while Asiana has 15 A350s with a further 15 on order.
Boeing’s recent problems are further widening the gap between supply and demand.
An LATAM Airlines 787 plane, which was heading from Sydney to Auckland on Monday, dropped abruptly before stabilising, causing those on board to be thrown about the cabin.

site_title: US: Nasdaq, S&P 500 slide at open as focus shifts to Fed
summary: US stocks slid at the open on Tuesday as investors focused on the Federal Reserve's two-day meeting, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite opening lower. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.08% to 38,819.61. The S&P 500 fell 0.20% to 5,139.09 and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.44% to 16,031.93. The shift in focus from economic and interest rate projections overshadowed other market news, including a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a new funding round for eSIM platform Airalo.

site_title: Yen falls in defiance of historic BOJ shift
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) ended its eight-year negative-interest-rate policy and implemented its first interest-rate hike in 17 years, guiding the overnight call rate in the range of zero to 0.1%. The yen fell by as much as 1% after the decision, while the US dollar rose ahead of the Federal Reserve's upcoming rate decision. The BOJ's cautious forward guidance was seen as a "green light" for investors to increase short yen positioning, and the market expects "accommodative financial conditions" to be maintained.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index, which measures the US currency against six other major currencies, was last down 0.12 per cent at 103.35.

site_title: Japanese business groups welcome BOJ’s first rate-hike in 17 years
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) raised interest rates for the first time in 17 years, welcoming the move by Governor Kazuo Ueda. The decision was preceded by stronger-than-expected pay rises by companies. Business groups praised the BOJ's move, citing a virtuous cycle between wages and prices. Analysts expect the BOJ to keep interest rates around zero for a while due to a fragile economic recovery. The move aims to control inflation and stabilize the economy.

images.alt_text: Under Governor Kazuo Ueda, the BOJ is unwinding its ultra-loose monetary policy.
Almost a year into his leadership, BOJ governor Kazuo Ueda (above) has dismantled the paraphernalia erected by his predecessor.

site_title: GoTo, TikTok to launch ‘buy now, pay later’ service in Indonesia
summary: GoTo, an Indonesian tech company, is set to launch a "buy now, pay later" (BNPL) service with TikTok in Indonesia. The move aims to drive topline growth and convince investors of its long-term earnings potential. GoTo Financial, the fintech unit, has seen promising growth prospects in BNPL, with gross revenue from the financial technology business rising 26% in the fourth quarter. The company is also focusing on product integrations with TikTok Shop and ensuring compliance with Indonesian regulations.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
GoTo expects to achieve group adjusted Ebitda breakeven for the full year in 2024.
BNPL player Atome has seen its CEO leave for GoTo Financial, as players retreat and refocus away from BNPL.

site_title: Hong Kong legislature unanimously passes new national security law
summary: Hong Kong's legislature has unanimously passed a new national security law, which will come into effect on March 23. The law punishes offenses such as treason, sabotage, and espionage with sentences ranging from several years to life imprisonment. Authorities claim the legislation is necessary to plug loopholes in the national security regime, but critics say it further threatens the city's freedoms. Hong Kong's leader John Lee hailed the law as a "historic moment" for the city.

images.alt_text: The draft includes new laws encompassing treason, espionage and external interference.

site_title: FCT’s inclusion in STI a reminder to investors that quality matters amid higher interest rates
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) has been included in the Straits Times Index (STI) after acquiring a 24.5% interest in Nex shopping mall for S$523.1 million. This move is seen as a reminder to investors that quality matters in the Reit sector, particularly amid rising interest rates. FCT's inclusion in the STI, along with other Reits such as Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) and Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT), suggests that some Reits are resilient and continue to raise capital and expand their portfolios.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
Kore will suspend its distributions from H2 2023 until H2 2025
Outgoing CEO Tripp Gant (pictured) is resigning due to “pressing family needs that require his full time and attention”, the manager says.

Manulife US Reit's Centerpointe property.  
The US office sector, which has faced a double whammy of changing work patterns and a higher interest rate environment.
Manulife US Reit’s Centerpointe I & II, in Fairfax, Virginia. The Reit halted distributions last year, following a breach in loan covenants after valuations fell.
CapitaLand Ascott Trust, ComfortDelGro, Keppel DC Reit, Keppel Reit and Suntec Reit are in the STI reserve list.
