site_title: Mainland Chinese surge into Hong Kong property after stamp duties scrapped
summary: Mainland Chinese buyers surged into Hong Kong's property market after the city removed additional stamp duties on foreign buyers. The share of purchases by mainland Chinese climbed to 20-30% of new home sales, with some buyers purchasing up to eight apartments at once. The move comes amid a battered confidence in the mainland's housing market and as Hong Kong seeks to attract talent with a new citizenship policy. Despite rising sales, prices remain suppressed due to developers offering discounts to clear inventory.

images.alt_text: As more companies commit to reach net-zero emissions by 2050, most will be looking to cut those tied to their offices and factories, yet demand for low-carbon buildings is set to outstrip supply.

A sell-out crowd paid from HK$880 (S$137.23) to see Lionel Messi in action on Feb 4 in an Inter Miami tour match against a Hong Kong select XI, but he remained glued to the bench with an injury, drawing boos from the crowd.

site_title: Wilmar unit to make further investment in Pakistan-listed Unity Foods
summary: Wilmar Pakistan Holdings, a subsidiary of Wilmar International, plans to acquire up to 277.1 million shares of Pakistan-listed Unity Foods, increasing its stake to 28.97% through a public offer. The shares will be acquired at a price determined by a pricing formula and applicable Pakistan laws. This move is part of Wilmar's existing 52% ownership of Unity Wilmar Agro, a Pakistani company.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Wilmar International's chairman and chief executive, Kuok Khoon Hong, expects tough operating conditions to continue into FY2024.

Wilmar International headquarters at 28 Biopolis Road. The agribusiness group says its unit disagrees with the facts and charges in the indictment and will actively defend its rights to protect the legal interests of the company and all shareholders.
DBS says recovering sales volumes for consumer products will also propel higher profitability for Wilmar.
Wilmar makes additional investment in Pakistan-listed Unity Foods

site_title: Will 2024 continue to be the year for the Magnificent Seven?
summary: The Magnificent Seven, a group of mega-cap tech stocks, drove the S&P 500's 26.3% return in 2023, but their high performance is unlikely to be repeated this year. Instead, Citi Research expects a shift towards growth and margin expansion across the broader Internet sector, driven by the emergence of generative artificial intelligence (GenAI). Key sectors to watch include online advertising, e-commerce, and cybersecurity, which are expected to grow 12.4%, 9%, and 12% year-over-year, respectively. The semiconductor sector is also poised for a resurgent year, driven by memory chip sales and AI spending.

images.alt_text: Lenders are shovelling money towards risky high-yield corporate borrowers, narrowing the spread they pay above the yield on government debt.
JP Morgan strategists say while there is concern over the strong outperformance of the Magnificent 7 stocks, trading is less stretched than a few years ago.

site_title: Ted Baker’s UK shops to tip into insolvency, risking jobs
summary: Ted Baker is preparing to place its UK stores into insolvency, putting hundreds of jobs at risk. The fashion chain, owned by Authentic Brands Group, has filed a notice of intention to appoint insolvency administrators. Despite this, Ted Baker will continue to operate online and in stores during the administration. Authentic Brands aims to find a new partner to grow the brand in the UK and Europe, where it began. This move follows the recent administration of The Body Shop's UK business, highlighting the challenges faced by UK retailers in an intensely competitive marketplace.

images.alt_text: Ted Baker Menswear Pop-Up at Takashimaya Shopping Centre

site_title: Tipping point for low-carbon buildings demand in sight: JLL
summary: Demand for low-carbon buildings is expected to surge over the next two years as companies with emissions-reduction commitments seek greener alternatives. Despite this, the supply is set to outstrip demand, with 30% of future demand projected to be met by 2030. In cities like London, Paris, and New York, the gap is even wider, with 35%, 54%, and 65% of demand expected to go unmet, respectively. Companies with net-zero emissions commitments will face price friction and a "race for low-carbon buildings" as the real estate industry adapts to the growing need for environmentally friendly spaces.

images.alt_text: Construction work at what will become Form Energy’s battery manufacturing facility, on the site of a former steel plant in Weirton, W.Va., Feb. 9, 2024. To decarbonize the electrical grid, companies are finding creative ways to store energy during periods of low demand. (Kristian Thacker/The New York Times)
It is important that Singapore takes stock of the entire country’s emissions, said Prof Watts (pictured).
Anorthosite deposits near the Qeqertarsuatsiaat fjord, Greenland. The island's vast natural resources include coal, zinc, copper, iron ore and rare earths.
A prototype of Phoenix, Icon’s next-generation robot, builds a two-story structure in Austin.
UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak says Britain needs to reach its net-zero target “in a sustainable way that doesn’t leave people without energy on a cloudy, windless day”.
The pressure to adopt greener materials may eventually have to come from end-users of these buildings.
Vopak owns and operates Singapore’s only ammonia tank currently. The tank is situated at its Banyan terminal, the biggest of the three terminals it operates on Jurong Island.

site_title: China’s Ant Group appoints new president in biggest reshuffle since regulatory revamp
summary: China's Ant Group has appointed new president Han Xinyi, marking the biggest reshuffle since a regulatory overhaul in mid-2023. Han will oversee digital payments, connectivity, and finance businesses, reporting to CEO Eric Jing. Three divisions will establish independent boards of directors to operate more independently. The changes come after a US$984 million fine by Chinese authorities last July, which ended a years-long regulatory overhaul.

images.alt_text: Alipay caters to more than a billion consumers in China.
The bid by Ant Group to build a securities business using Credit Suisse’s operations will face a thorough review because China favours a foreign buyer, people familiar with the matter said.
China’s Ant Group made net profit of 24.5 million yuan (S$4.6 million) in the three months to Sep 31, down 92 per cent from a year earlier.
Visitors walk past an Ant Group exhibition booth at the 2022 World AI Conference (WAIC) in Shanghai,  China, on Friday, September 02 2022.  Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Tuesday, March 19, 2024 (Ep 25)
summary: Japan ended its 17-year period of negative interest rates, while South Korea promised tax cuts to boost shareholder returns. Vietnam's stock trading volume reached a record high amid speculation of President's resignation. These market developments occurred as Singapore shares remained unchanged at the Tuesday open, with the STI up 0.01%.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market,
The BOJ also scrapped the yield curve control programme while pledging to keep buying long-term government bonds as needed.
South Korea last month unveiled a corporate reform plan aimed at lifting the value of Seoul-listed companies.
The surge in trading volume comes before Vietnam parliament’s special session on Thursday, which may include the possible resignation of President Vo Van Thuong.

site_title: Unilever to spin off ice cream unit, cut 7,500 jobs for cost savings
summary: Unilever plans to spin off its ice cream unit, including brands Magnum and Ben & Jerry's, into a standalone business by the end of 2025, resulting in the loss of 7,500 jobs globally. The move aims to deliver mid-single-digit underlying sales growth and modest margin improvement. Unilever also launched a cost-saving program to save around 800 million euros over three years, with total restructuring costs expected to be around 1.2% of its turnover.

images.alt_text: Investors have criticised Unilever for not recovering margins in the wake of the pandemic.

(FILES) This photograph taken on August 3, 2007 in Rueil-Malmaison, shows the logo of Unilever at the headquarters of Unilever France. Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch maker of consumer goods and food products announced 02 August 2007 that it would cut 20.000 jobs worldwide, 11 percent of its total workforce, over the next four years. Two million for late payment to suppliers to Unilever France, a multinational company of consumer goods and food products, the Agency for the Repression of Frauds (DGCCRF) said on its website, in Paris, on December 18, 2023. (Photo by Eric Feferberg / AFP)
Unilever first attempted to divest Elida in 2021 but pulled the process later that year. It then revived the sale process in September 2023.

New Unilever CEO Hein Schumacher poses for a photograph in this undated handout picture. site_title: Novo Foundation, Nvidia team up to build Danish AI supercomputer
summary: Novo Foundation and Nvidia have partnered to build a Danish AI supercomputer, one of the world's most powerful machines. The supercomputer, named Gefion, will run on Nvidia's artificial intelligence technology and be available for use by researchers from Denmark's public and private sectors. The project is funded by a 600 million kroner (S$117.1 million) commitment from Novo Foundation and 100 million kroner from the Export and Investment Fund of Denmark. The machine is expected to be delivered and installed by Eviden, a unit of Atos Group, later in 2024.

site_title: All eyes on whether US Federal Reserve will make explicit promise to cut interest rates
summary: The US Federal Reserve is holding a two-day policy meeting, with Chairman Jerome Powell's press conference on Wednesday expected to determine interest rates. Despite likely keeping rates unchanged, an explicit promise to cut rates in June could significantly impact markets. Recent inflation data has cast doubt on the Fed's resolve, but Powell's statements may still provide clarity. A sell-off in the stock market is possible if the Fed's "dot plot" projections are seen as ambiguous, with futures markets currently pricing in a 50-50 chance of a June cut.

images.alt_text: Higher interest rates reduce the appeal of holding non-yielding gold.
Builder sentiment has been improving so far this year, though it’s still well below prepandemic levels.
When a recession or substantial slowdown comes, all will depend on whether the Fed recognises the approaching weakness in time to cut rates and achieve a “soft landing”.

site_title: Atos says Airbus ends discussions over BDS cybersecurity unit sale
summary: Airbus has ended discussions with Atos over the potential sale of the French software company's BDS cybersecurity unit. Atos shares fell by almost 20% following the news. The company is now analyzing the situation and evaluating strategic alternatives, taking into consideration the sovereign imperatives of the French state. This development poses a liquidity problem and debt restructuring concerns for Atos, which has been grappling with profit warnings and high debt levels.

images.alt_text: The embattled Atos says conditions for the rights offering were “no longer applicable” and that a standby underwriting commitment from BNP Paribas and JPMorgan was also no longer in effect.
Atos’ big data and security unit  could help to speed up Airbus' digital transformation and enhance its defence and security portfolio.

site_title: Messi fans to get 50% refund for Hong Kong fiasco
summary: Lionel Messi fans who purchased tickets to watch him play in Hong Kong will receive a 50% refund, as long as they don't pursue legal action. The refund is being offered by event organizer Tatler Asia for the February 4 match, which was marred by Messi's injury and subsequent absence from the field. The move comes after the event organizer withdrew its application for a HK$16 million government grant.

site_title: Vietnam’s stock trading volume jumps to record as investors sell
summary: Vietnam's stock trading volume reached a record high of 1.74 billion shares on March 18, driven by speculation surrounding President Vo Van Thuong's possible resignation. The benchmark VN Index dropped for a fourth session, paring this year's advance to 10%. Investors are selling shares ahead of a special parliament session on Thursday, which may include the president's resignation. Foreign investors have been net sellers of Vietnamese stocks this year, with outflows totaling US$158 million, and the dong is trading near its lowest level since November 2022.

site_title: Shopee to bet on delivery options, BNPL and video to attract younger customers
summary: Shopee, the e-commerce arm of Sea Ltd, aims to attract younger customers (32 years and below) by expanding delivery options, buy-now-pay-later (BNPL) services, and video content. A survey found that 68% of younger users spend an average of 30 minutes daily on Shopee, and 52% abandon shopping carts due to budget constraints. Shopee plans to raise credit limits for BNPL users, introduce next-day delivery, and expand video content, including live-streaming and short-form videos. The platform also aims to improve return and refund policies, with refunds available in an average of three days.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Sea's results were buoyed by Shopee's profit bookings earlier in 2023.
Sea's chairman Forrest Li says that the company will continue to put its users first.
The offices leased to Sea are in the upper part of the 17-storey tower at Rochester Commons; The project was completed in phases in the second half of 2022.

site_title: GoTo hits operational profit in Q4, plans share buyback
summary: GoTo, Indonesia's largest tech company, achieved operational profit in its fourth quarter of 2023, with adjusted earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) turning positive at 77 billion rupiah (S$6.6 million). The company plans a share buyback of up to US$200 million, aiming to achieve group adjusted Ebitda breakeven for the full year 2024. Q4 net revenue rose 26% to 4.3 trillion rupiah, driven by improvements in the consumer lending business and a joint e-commerce deal with TikTok.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Short video app TikTok acquired in December majority shares in GoTo’s e-commerce unit Tokopedia after the Indonesian trade ministry banned transactions on its TikTok Shop e-commerce unit.
At US$15.6 billion, TikTok Shop's estimated gross merchandise value for 2023 is more than twice as much as Tokopedia’s US$6.6 billion.

site_title: Easy does it: The Bank of Japan's experiment
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) raised interest rates for the first time in 17 years, marking a shift in its ultra-loose monetary policy under Governor Kazuo Ueda. The move aims to combat deflation and achieve a 2% inflation target, but economists warn of potential risks, including a lack of fiscal discipline and exacerbating social inequality. The BOJ's previous measures, including negative interest rates and yield-curve control, have been credited with helping Japan escape deflation, but some experts question the long-term sustainability of the policy, citing weak consumption and wage growth.

images.alt_text: Almost a year into his leadership, BOJ governor Kazuo Ueda (above) has dismantled the paraphernalia erected by his predecessor.
BOJ nine-member board likely remains divided on how much support the fragile economy will need to sustain a recovery.
The BOJ also scrapped the yield curve control programme while pledging to keep buying long-term government bonds as needed.

site_title: Swiss watch exports slump on lower shipments to China, Hong Kong
summary: Swiss watch exports declined 3.8% in February to 2.15 billion Swiss francs, marking the second consecutive monthly drop. Lower shipments to China and Hong Kong, with declines of 25% and 19% respectively, contributed to the decline. The US remained the top market, with exports rising 5.5%. The slump is attributed to a cooling demand for luxury timepieces, partly due to economic pressures and supply chain issues stemming from wars in Ukraine and the Middle East.

images.alt_text: The Rolex GMT with a red and blue ceramic bezel remains an outlier.
Are luxury watches worth their lofty price tag?
Total watch sales at the top auction houses fell 13 per cent to 610 million Swiss francs (S$926.7 million) in 2023 from record levels hit in 2022.
Linda Neo started collecting art as a means of sharing a common interest with her husband, Albert Lim.
The Morgan Stanley and LuxeConsult figures are estimates, as Swiss watch brands including Rolex do not disclose their individual annual sales.
A MoonSwatch Moonshine Gold suitcase.
Monthly exports increase 3.1 per cent to 1.9 billion Swiss francs (S$2.9 billion) by value.

site_title: Wall Street bonuses decline slightly amid an influx of bankers
summary: Wall Street bonuses declined 2% to $176,500 in 2023, the lowest since 2019, due to continued market volatility and a slowdown in mergers and initial public offerings. The industry's total bonus pool remained unchanged at $33.8 billion. Despite this, the securities industry saw a 3.6% increase in employment to 198,500, the highest level in over two decades.

images.alt_text: Through the end of February, the three major indexes notch their fourth straight month of gains in a rally largely fueled by growth prospects related to AI.
A screen tracks Nvidia's stock price as a trader works on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange. Nvidia is already worth as much as the entire Chinese stock market.
Wall Street giants are endorsing India as the prime investment destination for the coming decade.

site_title: China’s Xiaomi posts 11% revenue rise on strong smartphone sales
summary: Xiaomi reported a 10.9% rise in fourth-quarter revenue to 73.24 billion yuan (S$13.7 billion) beating analyst estimates, driven by strong smartphone sales. The company attributed the improvement to better-than-expected smartphone shipments in the second half of 2023. Xiaomi president Lu Weibing stated that the overall smartphone shipments in the second half were better than in the first half. This marks a sign of recovery for the sector.

images.alt_text: The SU7 has “super electric motor” technology capable of delivering acceleration speeds faster than Tesla and Porsche’s EVs.
Xiaomi last year was placed third globally for share of the smartphone market, accounting for 12.5 per cent of global shipments.
Xiaomi is also asking India to reduce import tariffs on sub-components used in batteries, USB cables and phone covers.

site_title: Just how rich are businesses getting in the AI gold rush?
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

The AI boom has created immense value for companies, with the 100 companies examined having created $8 trillion in value since October 2022. Hardware companies, particularly Nvidia, have dominated the market, with Nvidia's market capitalization increasing by 57% in the past year. Independent model-makers, such as OpenAI and Anthropic, have also seen significant growth, with their collective value increasing by 375% in the past 16 months. However, fierce competition in the model-making layer may lead to lower profits, and the cloud layer's value creation is expected to be lower than hardware and model-making.

images.alt_text: The new type of chip – called the HBM3E – is a focal point of intense competition.

BYD, which overtook Tesla last year as the world’s No. 1 electric vehicle manufacturer, will use Nvidia’s next generation of in-vehicle chips, called Drive Thor, to enable increased levels of autonomous driving and other digital functions, Nvidia said.

Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang unveils the flagship B200 AI chip which takes two chips the size of Nvidia‘s previous offering and binds them together into a single chip, San Jose, California, March 18, 2024.

site_title: AstraZeneca bets on new cancer treatments with US$2 billion Fusion Pharma purchase
summary: AstraZeneca has agreed to purchase clinical-stage biopharmaceutical company Fusion Pharmaceuticals for approximately $2 billion in cash. Fusion is developing "next-generation" radioconjugates (RCs) to treat cancer, a promising modality in cancer treatment. The acquisition aims to further AstraZeneca's ambition to transform cancer care with targeted treatments. Fusion's most advanced programme, FPI-2265, is currently in a mid-stage trial to treat metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer. The deal is AstraZeneca's second this month, following its $1.05 billion acquisition of Amolyt Pharma.

images.alt_text: The FDA’s label does not stipulate a liver biopsy requirement for diagnosis of NASH, a key concern among experts that could have hit demand.
Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat at the groundbreaking ceremony for Novartis' groundbreaking ceremony for its biopharmaceutical plant expansion.

site_title: Indonesia’s giant nickel miners double down on output even as prices slump
summary: Indonesia's giant nickel miners, including government-backed Vale Indonesia, plan to increase production despite a slump in nickel prices, which have nearly halved in the last year. The country aims to double its output, with Harita Nickel targeting 120,000 tonnes of mixed hydroxide precipitate (MHP) nickel production this year. The prolonged oversupply is attributed to overzealous Indonesian miners, and the global price of nickel is expected to rebound later this year.

images.alt_text: Excavators transfer soil to transport trucks at a nickel mine operated by nickel mining company Vale Indonesia in Sorowako on July 28, 2023. (Photo by HARIANDI HAFID / AFP)
Elisa Valenta

site_title: Sentiment up among real estate players in Q4 2023 amid economic growth, anticipated rate cuts: poll
summary: Singapore's property market sentiment improved in Q4 2023, driven by economic growth and anticipated interest-rate cuts. Nearly 90% of respondents cited a slowdown in the global economy as a top risk, while 44.7% expressed concerns over rising inflation and interest rates. Hotel and serviced apartments were the best-performing sector, with positive current and future net balances. The Composite Sentiment Index rose to 4.7, below the neutral score of 5.0, indicating a cautiously optimistic market heading into the new year.

images.alt_text: Samuel Oh
Luqman Hakim, chief data and analytics officer at 99.co, says the price growth in February 2024 is "much more modest" compared to the previous month.
Condominiums along Alexandra Road at night on Feb 26, 2022.
Rents of HDB flats have grown 1 per cent month on month, but volumes are down 19.1 per cent.

site_title: Bitcoin retreats as Grayscale ETF posts biggest daily outflow
summary: Bitcoin retreated 3% to $65,380, following a record $643 million outflow from the Grayscale Bitcoin Trust, the world's largest ETF. Investors are scaling back expectations for US Federal Reserve interest-rate cuts amid persistent inflationary pressures. This comes as investors also pulled money from other major tokens and scaled back flows into new spot-Bitcoin ETFs. A net negative flow from ETFs could be a bearish signal, according to QCP Capital.

images.alt_text: The world’s largest cryptocurrency has surged 56 per cent this year, reaching an all-time high of almost US$73,798 last week.
Craig Wright has long claimed to have been the author of a 2008 white paper, the foundational text of Bitcoin, published under the pseudonym.
Michael Saylor started buying Bitcoin in 2020 as an inflation hedge and alternative to holding cash.

site_title: Top Japan banks weigh first rate-hikes on ordinary deposits in 17 years
summary: Japan's major banks, Mizuho and Sumitomo Mitsui, are set to raise interest rates on ordinary yen deposits for the first time in 17 years, following the Bank of Japan's end of its negative interest rate policy. The move is seen as a positive for the banks' business, as it improves interest income. The interest rate hike is the first since February 2007, and comes after the central bank loosened its grip on long-term interest rates in October.

site_title: South Korea to cut corporate, dividend income tax to boost shareholder returns
summary: South Korea plans to cut corporate and dividend income tax to boost shareholder returns. The move follows criticism from investors that the country's corporate reform plan did not go far enough. Finance Minister Choi Sang-mok announced the tax cuts, which will be finalized by early May, and will provide guidelines for listed firms to refer to. The plan aims to encourage firms to boost shareholder returns, such as dividends, and lift the value of Seoul-listed companies.

images.alt_text: epa11221723 South Korean dealers talk in front of monitors at the Hana Bank in Seoul, South Korea, 15 March 2024. The benchmark South Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) dropped 51.92 points, or 1.91 percent, to 2,666.84 ending a three-session winning streak.  EPA-EFE/JEON HEON-KYUN

site_title: Qantas under pressure from big business to find more clean fuel
summary: Qantas is under pressure from big business to secure cleaner-burning sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) for key routes, as corporate customers seek to cut carbon emissions from travel. The airline's head of sustainable aviation fuel, Graeme Potger, stated that sectors like professional services are keen on SAF to maintain business travel without increased emissions. Despite SAF being less than 1% of global requirements, it can cut emissions by up to 80%. Qantas aims to secure SAF for routes to the US, Europe, New Zealand, Singapore, and the Americas, including the ultra-long London-Perth service.

images.alt_text: The pilots at QantasLink and Network Aviation will stop work on Thursday and Friday, the Australian Federation of Air Pilots said in a statement.
The airline is still waiting to learn how much it must pay after losing a separate lawsuit accusing it of illegally firing 1700 ground staff in 2020.
Qantas posted an underlying profit before tax of A$1.25 billion (S$1.06 billion) for the six months ended Dec 31, compared with A$1.43 billion a year earlier.

site_title: ShopBack cuts 195 employees in push for sustainability
summary: ShopBack, a Singapore-based cashback and rewards platform, has cut 195 employees (24% of its workforce) to become more focused and sustainable. The layoffs, announced by CEO Henry Chan, were part of a restructuring effort to align the company's organizational structure with its strategy for sustainable growth. Laid-off employees will receive pay for two months of notice, severance payments, and career transition support. The company's revenue declined 20% to US$87.7 million in FY23, and it reported wider losses before tax due to one-off expenses.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
ShopeBack will be shuttering its BNPL offering PayLater after a periodic review of its business units.
ShopBack gives its customers a fraction of their money spent each time they shop with its partner merchants.
"Organisations cannot place sole reliance on their employees to perform their duties properly as a security arrangement to protect personal data," said the Personal Data Protection Commission.
ShopBack has scored a further US$80 million in funding from 65 Equity Partners as a public listing appears to be on the cards.
ShopBack's Singapore headquarters in Pasir Panjang.

site_title: In Paris, the Olympics clean up their act
summary: The Paris 2024 Olympics are taking steps to reduce their environmental impact, aiming to generate no more than half the greenhouse gas emissions of recent Olympics. The event is repurposing existing attractions and using sustainable materials, such as solar panels and recycled plastic. The organizers are also limiting new construction, using less cement and more wood, and implementing measures to reduce energy consumption, including a water-based cooling system. However, critics argue that more drastic measures are needed to address the climate crisis, and the event poses logistical challenges, including heat and transportation issues.

images.alt_text: These 222,000 spots are in addition to the 104,000 paying spectators who will watch the ceremony from the lower quays.

site_title: Nvidia supplier SK Hynix begins mass production of next generation memory chip
summary: SK Hynix has begun mass production of next-generation high-bandwidth memory (HBM) chips, called HBM3E, which offer a 10% improvement in heat dissipation and process up to 1.18 terabytes of data per second. The new chip is a focal point of intense competition in the AI chip market, with SK Hynix seeking to cement its leadership in the AI memory space. Initial shipments will go to Nvidia, which has 80% of the market for AI chips, and SK Hynix's capacity is fully booked for 2024 due to explosive demand.

images.alt_text: The demand for high bandwidth memory chips has boomed with the growing popularity of generative AI.
Stacking chips to derive greater performance has long been  Lee Kang-wook’s passion.
SK Hynix is looking to maintain its lead over Samsung and Micron in AI.
Semiconductor firms have pledged to invest more than US$230 billion on American soil since President Joe Biden took office, spurred by the 2022 Chips Act.

site_title: Japan sees record 2.79 million visitors in February due to Chinese New Year boost
summary: Japan welcomed a record 2.79 million visitors in February, a 7.1% increase from 2019, driven by the Chinese New Year holidays. This marks the highest number of visitors for any month since the COVID-19 pandemic began. The boost in tourism is attributed to a weak yen, making Japan a bargain destination for foreign travelers. The industry has seen a significant recovery, with visitors spending over 5 trillion yen (S$44.9 billion) in the country last year, exceeding the government's goal.

images.alt_text: People visit Sensoji Temple in Tokyo on March 19, 2024. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)

site_title: Indonesia proposes injecting US$3.7 billion into state firms in 2024, 2025
summary: Indonesia's government has proposed injecting US$3.7 billion into state firms in 2024 and 2025, including for construction companies to complete infrastructure projects. The proposals, totaling 13.6 trillion rupiah (S$1.2 billion) for seven companies in 2024 and 44.25 trillion rupiah for 16 companies in 2025, aim to sustain ongoing programs and complete projects. Four major construction firms, including Hutama Karya and Adhi Karya, are among the intended recipients. The proposals, despite a potential change in presidency, aim to ensure the completion of projects.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Bank Indonesia's logo is seen at Bank Indonesia headquarters in Jakarta, Indonesia, September 2, 2020. REUTERS/Ajeng Dinar Ulfiana/file photo/File Photo

site_title: Broker’s take: Lim & Tan initiates Dyna-Mac with ‘buy’, S$0.45 target price
summary: Lim & Tan Securities initiated coverage on Dyna-Mac with a "buy" call and target price of S$0.45, citing the company's expected top-line growth and profitability in FY2024 and FY2025. Analyst Nicholas Yon attributes this to the oil and gas industry's "super cycle" and Dyna-Mac's strong demand for topside module fabrication. The brokerage expects a dividend payout of S$0.94 in FY2024 and 3.4% in FY2025, with valuations deemed "undemanding" given the company's strong net cash position.

images.alt_text: RHB Research raises its price target on SGX to S$10 from S$9.60 on Monday (Mar 18).
The target cut comes after Delfi reports lower-than-expected FY2023 revenue growth and operating margins.
ISDN anticipates demand in the China market and the South-east Asian semiconductor industry to recover.

site_title: Tencent Music beats quarterly revenue estimates
summary: Tencent Music Entertainment reported revenue of 6.89 billion yuan (S$1.3 billion) for the fourth quarter, beating estimates by 2.3%. Paid subscription growth drove the increase, with the number of paying users rising 21% to 106.7 million. However, the company still suffered a year-on-year revenue decline due to China's regulatory crackdown on music platforms' chance-based features. Online music service revenue jumped 41.1% year-over-year, with earnings per ADS at 0.83 yuan.

images.alt_text: The company has made strides with so-called mini-games  and a livestreaming video platform that competes with TikTok’s local language service in China.
The approval will make Tenpay the non-bank payment institution with the highest registered capital in China.
The two teams Tencent has acquired involve one Shenzhen-based studio working on an action game and another East-China-based studio working on an anime game.

site_title: BOJ has hiked at last, but this tiny step is no lift-off
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has removed negative interest rates, a move seen as a significant step towards the end of a prolonged period of deflation. However, the rate hike is minimal, from minus 0.1% to around zero, and is not expected to be the start of a hiking cycle. BOJ Governor Kazuo Ueda has dismantled the policies of his predecessor, Haruhiko Kuroda, and has vowed to maintain accommodative financial conditions for the time being. The move is seen as a positive step for the economy, with wage increases and inflation near the target, but does not signal a shift towards tighter policy.

images.alt_text: Mizuho and other major Japanese banks raised interest rates on long-term deposits last year after the central bank loosened its grip on long-term interest rates in October.
The BOJ also scrapped the yield curve control programme while pledging to keep buying long-term government bonds as needed.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS upgrades ISDN to ‘hold’ on demand rebound expectations
summary: CGS International Securities upgraded its rating on ISDN to "hold" from "reduce" due to a cautiously optimistic outlook for demand recovery in key markets. Analyst William Tng expects improved demand conditions to provide earnings upside for the company over FY2024 to FY2025. The brokerage lowered its target price to S$0.32 from S$0.36, citing a weaker gross profit margin and disappointing earnings. ISDN anticipates demand recovery in the China market and South-east Asian semiconductor industry, driven by a slowing cyclical headwind and growth in industrial automation.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
ISDN Holdings' president, Teo Cher Koon. CGS-CIMB is upgrading its call on the stock back to "add" with the view that prospects have improved for the engineering solutions group.
The research house expects ISDN’s foreign exchange losses to rise, with the yuan weakening against the US dollar and Singapore dollar.
ISDN sees demand from Asian businesses seeking industrial automation to relieve labour wage pressure, advance manufacturing capabilities and reduce business risk.

site_title: Manulife US Reit manager names new CEO, CFO amid leadership exodus
summary: Manulife US Reit has appointed John Casasante as CEO and CIO, replacing Tripp Gantt, who is resigning due to pressing family needs. Casasante joins from DWS, bringing over 25 years of commercial real estate experience. Deputy CEO Caroline Fong, CIO Patrick Arthur Browne, and CFO Robert Wong are also stepping down to pursue other opportunities. Mushtaque Ali has been appointed as CFO designate to replace Wong. Casasante will lead the Reit's move to dispose of assets and maximize proceeds to pare down debt.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

Tripp Gantt, chief executive of Manulife US Reit's manager, says priorities for 2024 will focus on asset dispositions and maximising proceeds to further reduce indebtedness and fund capital expenditure.
The four properties with the largest percentage valuation declines are namely Figueroa (pictured), Plaza, Penn, and Diablo.
MUST has completed the divestment of the Park Place property in Arizona, US, as part of the master restructuring plan.
The first resolution, which was to approve the divestment of the Reit’s Park Place property to the sponsor for US$98.7 million, saw 97.7 per cent or 545.6 million votes in favour.
The Reit will obtain around US$235 million in funding from its sponsor, comprising the sale of its Park Place property to the sponsor and a sponsor-lender loan.
The Reit will obtain around US$235 million in funding from its sponsor, comprising the sale of its Park Place property to the sponsor and a sponsor-lender loan.

site_title: Japan ends era of negative rates with few clues on further hikes
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) ended its era of negative interest rates, shifting to a policy rate range of zero to 0.1% and scrapping its complex yield curve control programme. Governor Kazuo Ueda stated that the goal of achieving 2% inflation has been reached, and the large-scale monetary easing policy has served its purpose. While there are no clear indications of future rate hikes, Ueda emphasized the importance of maintaining an accommodative financial environment. The yen slid past the 150 mark versus the US dollar, while benchmark government bond yields edged lower, supporting Japanese equities.

images.alt_text: Japan's negative interest rate policy has sharply weakened the yen against the dollar, which is good news for exporters but unwelcome for consumers as it has made imports more expensive.
BOJ nine-member board likely remains divided on how much support the fragile economy will need to sustain a recovery.
The board is weighing whether to end an era that saw the most aggressive monetary easing in modern history.

BOJ officials, including governor Kazuo Ueda, have recently stressed the timing of a shift away from negative rates would depend on the outcome of this year’s annual wage negotiations between workers and employers.

site_title: Tencent may surprise with margin, shareholder return
summary: Tencent Holdings' upcoming earnings report may surprise investors with positive catalysts, despite a 60% decline in shares from their record high three years ago. The company's fourth-quarter sales growth is expected to be the slowest in a year, but analysts anticipate its profit margins will beat market consensus due to a shift towards high-margin segments. Tencent's mini-games and livestreaming video platform may also contribute to a positive advertising revenue surprise. The company is expected to increase dividends or share buybacks, potentially pushing its share price up, and aiming for a shareholder yield comparable to Alibaba's 7% target.

images.alt_text: The approval will make Tenpay the non-bank payment institution with the highest registered capital in China.
The two teams Tencent has acquired involve one Shenzhen-based studio working on an action game and another East-China-based studio working on an anime game.

site_title: Condo leasing market continues decline in February, HDB rents hit new all-time high: SRX, 99.co
summary: Singapore's private rental market continued its decline in February, with condominium rental prices falling 1% from January, marking 13 consecutive months of net negative growth. In contrast, HDB housing rents reached a new all-time high, growing 1% from the previous month, despite a 19.1% decline in rental volumes. Experts attribute the HDB rent increase to strong demand for relief from inflation and the limited supply of new flats. Condo rental volumes fell 21% from the previous month, while HDB rental volumes declined 8.4% year-on-year.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Some young couples are concerned their HDB housing loan amounts will be assessed based on the new HFE letters, with no reassessments possible in the future.
Owner-occupiers of pricier private homes may wish to factor in higher property taxes in their retirement planning.
The S$300 rental voucher is part of a new scheme for couples eligible for the existing Parenthood Provisional Housing Scheme.
January 2024 marks the sixth straight month of declines for condominium rental prices.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed ahead of Bank of Japan decision
summary: Asian markets are mixed ahead of the Bank of Japan's decision on monetary policy, with Tokyo stocks lower and the yen weakening against the dollar. Analysts expect the BoJ to shift away from ultra-loose monetary policy, potentially introducing a first rate hike in 17 years to combat inflation above the 2% target. While a hike could disrupt financial markets, officials are expected to engineer a dovish hike to maintain market stability. The decision comes as investors await the Federal Reserve's policy decision on Wednesday, which is forecast to keep rates on hold but release its "dot plot" outlook for the rest of the year.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index was down 0.1 per cent, with Ireland’s ISEQ index rising 0.1 per cent to outperform European peers.
The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index finished 0.8 per cent higher at 16,103.45 on Monday.
Across the broader market,

site_title: Blinken to meet Philippine leader on bolstering alliance
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken is set to meet with Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos on Tuesday, as part of a brief Asia tour, to bolster security and economic ties against Chinese influence. Blinken's visit is his second since Marcos took office in June 2022, following a similar tour in South Korea. The meeting aims to deter China and North Korea in the South China Sea, over Taiwan, and on the Korean peninsula, highlighting Washington's efforts to improve relations with regional allies amidst rising tensions.

images.alt_text: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken speaks to the media as he tours Amkor Technology in Manila on March 19, 2024. (Photo by EVELYN HOCKSTEIN / POOL / AFP)

site_title: Australia’s central bank holds rates as expected, waters down tightening bias
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) kept interest rates steady at a 12-year high of 4.35% for a third straight meeting, downplaying the possibility of further rate hikes. This decision was seen as a sign of greater confidence that inflation is moving back to its target, despite slowing economic growth and rising joblessness. The RBA stated it is not ruling out any policy changes, but is instead focusing on ensuring inflation returns to its target in a reasonable timeframe.

images.alt_text: “Dialogue leads to understanding and it leads to benefit for both of our nations. Australia will benefit from the economic activity that removal of these impediments will bring,” says Australia Prime Minister Anthony Albanese.

site_title: GuocoLand shows its mettle at Lentor
summary: GuocoLand's latest project, Lentor Mansion, achieved strong sales with 75% of units sold at its launch, despite a challenging market. This boost in sales comes after a tepid February, where developers sold 47% fewer units than the previous month. GuocoLand's management is executing well in Singapore, with the company also behind award-winning projects and integrated developments. However, GuocoLand's share price trades below book value, and some analysts suggest the company should consider share buybacks to address this anomaly.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Senior correspondent Leslie Yee has been following developments surrounding the push to internalise the management of Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust.

New home sales at the year’s first few project launches have gone much slower than they used to, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
Wealthy people have been busy property shopping, writes BT senior correspondent Leslie Yee.
Private property owners have baulked at seeing their property tax bills shoot up this year, after a two-tiered tax hike designed as a de facto wealth tax kicked in
Is Meta’s exit from a grade A office building in downtown Singapore a foreshadowing of more vacancies to come?

site_title: Vietnam luxury property boss on trial in US$355 million bond scam
summary: Vietnamese luxury property tycoon Do Anh Dung, head of Tan Hoang Minh group, went on trial in Hanoi on March 19, 2024, accused of cheating thousands of investors in a US$355 million bond scam. He faces fraud charges alongside his son Do Hoang Viet and 13 others. This trial marks one of several high-profile cases targeting corrupt officials and senior business figures in Vietnam, where 4,400 people have been indicted in over 1,700 cases since 2021.

images.alt_text: The nation plans to introduce a platform that can handle three to five million orders per day.
The central bank targets a credit growth of 15 per cent for this year.
The deal comes as the group is investing billions of dollars to develop loss-making VinFast, the fledgling electric-vehicle maker.
Vinfast boasts a network of 150,000 charging ports installed all across Vietnam.

site_title: WP chief Pritam Singh charged with lying to Parliament over Raeesah Khan’s case, pleads not guilty
summary: Workers' Party (WP) chief Pritam Singh was charged with two counts of lying to Parliament over Raeesah Khan's case on March 19, 2024. Singh, 47, pleaded not guilty and requested a four-week adjournment to engage a lawyer. The charges relate to his testimony before the Committee of Privileges in 2021, where he was found to have not been truthful under oath. If convicted, Singh could face a fine of up to $7,000 and a jail term of up to three years.

images.alt_text: PM-in-waiting Lawrence Wong will be taking over Singapore at a critical juncture, said watchers.
Parliament refers Pritam Singh, Faisal Manap to Public Prosecutor
Pritam Singh rejects Committee of Privileges' findings, says Raeesah was disenchanted with WP

site_title: Nippon Steel pledges to move US HQ to US Steel’s Pittsburgh
summary: Nippon Steel, the world's fourth-largest steelmaker, has pledged to move its US headquarters to Pittsburgh if its proposed $15-billion takeover of US Steel goes through. The Japanese company's executive, Tahahiro Mori, said this in comments released to the US Securities and Exchange Commission. Nippon Steel also promised to honor existing agreements with the US Steel and USW labor union, including job security and investments. The move is in response to criticism from US President Joe Biden and his opponent Donald Trump, who oppose the deal.

site_title: Mastercard expands remittances reach in new pact with Alipay
summary: Mastercard has partnered with Alipay, a mobile payments super-app in China, to expand its reach in cross-border remittances. The agreement allows consumers to receive money in their digital wallets in near real-time, catering to over 1 billion Alipay users. This partnership comes as Mastercard seeks to tap into China's large and growing market for international remittances. With this expansion, financial institutions can now facilitate consumer payments to over 180 countries, further solidifying Mastercard's position in the global payments industry.

site_title: Paul Simon faced unexpected struggles. Cameras were rolling.
summary: Singer-songwriter Paul Simon, now 82, released his latest album Seven Psalms in 2023. A documentary about his life, "In Restless Dreams," premiered on MGM+ on March 17, showcasing Simon's life, from his early days growing up in Queens, New York, to his struggles with hearing loss while creating the album. Director-producer Alex Gibney, who has previously made documentaries about musical legends, worked closely with Simon, who shared his trials and tribulations with his health. The film offers a wealth of interesting trivia and features many of Simon's hit songs, including "The Sound of Silence," "Bridge Over Troubled Water," and "Cecilia."

images.alt_text: Singer-songwriter Paul Simon performing at Fort Canning Park on 22 March 2013 as part of the Timbre Rock & Roots Music Festival 2013.
Tom Jones continues to reinvent him musically both on stage and in the studio.

site_title: Robinhood rolls out app in UK, pauses margin lending addition
summary: Robinhood has launched its app in the UK, offering commission-free trading on over 6,000 US-listed stocks. UK customers can now access the app, but margin lending, a feature allowing users to borrow money to purchase securities, has been paused as the company discusses with regulators. The company aims to expand into new markets and deliver local products that meet customer needs, with a 5% interest rate on uninvested cash and zero trading commission.

images.alt_text: A higher-for-longer interest rate environment has benefited lenders across the financial spectrum, including Robinhood, with the industry capitalising on interest payments.
The app will allow European investors to buy and sell more than 25 cryptocurrencies, including Bitcoin, Ether and Solana’s SOL.
Robinhood’s transaction-based revenue decreased 11 per cent year-over-year to US$185 million amid a 13 per cent decline in equities and a 55 per cent decrease in cryptocurrencies.

site_title: Mitsubishi, 7 others to form coalition to promote electric natural gas
summary: Mitsubishi has formed an international coalition with seven other companies, including TotalEnergies and Tokyo Gas, to promote the development and production of electric natural gas (e-NG). E-NG is a synthetic gas produced from renewable hydrogen and carbon dioxide, which can be transported and stored using existing infrastructures. The companies aim to accelerate e-NG development in a reliable, affordable, and sustainable way to contribute to a net-zero carbon future and combat climate change.

site_title: Brokers’ take: RHB cuts Delfi target on narrowing margin amid cocoa price hikes
summary: RHB has cut its target price for Delfi to S$1.33 from S$1.55 due to lower-than-expected FY2023 revenue growth and narrower operating margins. Analyst Alfie Yeo attributes the cut to rising cocoa prices, but maintains a "buy" call, citing the company's growth strategies and market leadership in Indonesia. Despite lowered earnings forecasts, Delfi still has a compound annual growth rate of 7.5% for FY2023 to FY2026, and shares were trading flat at S$0.905.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei

Analysts expect staples such as food and beverages as well as fast-moving consumer goods to benefit the most from measures introduced by the government to preserve the purchasing power of low to middle-income families.
Interest in Orchard Road malls has revived, with Far East Shopping Centre changing hands at S$908 million.
The FTSE ST All-Share Index – which tracks the performance of the top 98 per cent of companies listed on the SGX, ended the year down 1 per cent.

site_title: Fidelity weighs cutting 20 China jobs as part of global layoffs
summary: Fidelity International plans to cut approximately 20 positions in China as part of its global job reductions, aiming to trim costs amid a challenging economic environment. The asset manager, which has a local staff of nearly 2,000 people in China, is slashing 1,000 jobs globally, or about 9% of its staff. Despite this, Fidelity remains committed to the Chinese market and has been expanding its presence in the country, with plans to add branches and hire more people in the coming years.

images.alt_text: Fidelity’s ETF conversions include funds focused on large-cap growth, value and core portfolios, as well as mid-cap small-cap, and international stocks.
The continued decline of nature will pose material financial risks to the economy and financial markets, Fidelity said.

site_title: US homebuilder confidence rises to highest level since July: NAHB
summary: US homebuilder confidence rose to 51 in March, the highest level since July, due to lower mortgage rates and an improved pricing environment. The easing of mortgage rates allowed builders to hold off on slashing home prices, despite a continued existing home inventory shortage. NAHB chairman Carl Harris expects more consumers to enter the market if mortgage rates continue to fall later this year.

images.alt_text: Relatively low unemployment has boosted the market, and many house hunters are stuck renting as high mortgage rates make buying a property tougher.

site_title: Binance tasks prime brokers with checks to root out US investors
summary: Binance has asked its prime brokerage partners to conduct more stringent checks on US investors, following a plea deal with US authorities last year. The checks include verifying office addresses, employee and founder information, and require signed attestations. This move comes after Binance pleaded guilty to US anti-money-laundering and sanctions laws violations, resulting in a $4.3 billion penalty. The company aims to rebuild its reputation and maintain compliance with US regulations, which has led to a tightening of requirements for listing new digital tokens and stricter checks on prime brokers.

images.alt_text: The world’s largest cryptocurrency has surged 56 per cent this year, reaching an all-time high of almost US$73,798 last week.

The SEC under chair Gary Gensler has argued that most crypto assets fall under the agency’s jurisdiction and are subject to its rules.

site_title: Longi layoffs speed shift in solar production away from China
summary: Longi Green Energy Technology, the world's largest solar manufacturer, is laying off about 5% of its workforce, potentially accelerating a global shift in solar production capacity away from China. This move follows years of consolidation and rapid expansion by Chinese firms, which have made China the center of global solar manufacturing. The layoffs are a reversal of the success of Chinese manufacturers, which have aided efforts to slow global warming, but also resulted in negative consequences for Chinese manufacturers, including price wars and declining profit margins.

images.alt_text: Fidelity has been in China since 2004 and has a local staff of almost 2,000 people, mostly in technology and operations.

site_title: Gold flat as market focus turns to US Federal Reserve meeting
summary: Gold prices remained flat on Tuesday as investors awaited the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting, which may provide further clues on interest rate cuts this year. Spot gold was steady at US$2,160.97 per ounce, and traders are pricing in a 51% chance of a rate cut in June. Higher interest rates reduce the appeal of holding non-yielding gold, and the US dollar hovered near a two-week high against its rivals, making gold more expensive for other currency holders. The Fed is expected to hold rates steady, with no rate cuts anticipated in the near future.

images.alt_text: Higher interest rates reduce the appeal of holding non-yielding gold.

site_title: US standards body says ByteDance researcher wrongly added to AI safety groupchat
summary: The US National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) said a researcher from ByteDance, the owner of TikTok, was wrongly added to a groupchat for American AI safety experts. The researcher was added by a member of NIST's US Artificial Intelligence Safety Institute Consortium as a volunteer, but NIST stated they were not a member and did not participate in the discussions. The incident highlights the need for proper vetting and verification of individuals in AI safety discussions.

images.alt_text: Efforts to remove Chinese corporate influence over the popular social-media platform is back on the political agenda in an election year.
Even if ByteDance puts the TikTok app up for sale, the Chinese government is unlikely to allow the company’s most valuable asset, its recommendation algorithm, to be included.

site_title: SMEs can seek government help to embark on AI, sustainability journey: panellists
summary: Singapore's government is launching schemes to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) adopt artificial intelligence (AI) and pursue sustainability. Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling said the government will support SMEs by addressing their fears and concerns, lowering barriers to entry, and reducing costs. SMEs can access AI tools for marketing and customer engagement, such as generative AI solutions, and the government will fund 70% of eligible costs for SMEs producing their first sustainability report.

site_title: BlackRock-backed commodities exchange startup Abaxx raises cash
summary: Abaxx Technologies, a commodities exchange startup backed by BlackRock, is raising C$10 million in a bought deal to fund operations and growth. The Canadian company plans to launch trading in commodities futures, including liquefied natural gas and nickel sulphate, in the next few weeks. Abaxx has been working for five years to set up its technology and regulatory approvals, and expects to handle its first trades after securing the equity raise. The company's CEO, Josh Crumb, says it will take a year or so to build liquidity in these markets.

images.alt_text: Fisker flagged substantial doubt about its ability to continue as a going concern in February and paused investments in future projects until it secured a partnership with an automaker.
Key founding members of 21 United Holdings, which formed UCars, pictured in April 2019; over the last 12 months or so, more than 20 staff in the UCars team have left.

site_title: SingPost considers divesting S$1.1 billion SingPost Centre and floating Australian business
summary: SingPost considers divesting its S$1.1 billion SingPost Centre in Singapore and floating its Australian business as part of a strategic review to reorganize into three business units. The company aims to generate a spread above the cost of capital. CEO Vincent Phang did not provide a timeline for the divestment of non-core assets, focusing on becoming a pure-play logistics player.

site_title: Singtel to launch cloud computing offering with Nvidia AI chips
summary: Singtel is launching a cloud computing offering in Singapore and South-east Asia, utilizing Nvidia's GB200 Grace Blackwell Superchips, expected to arrive in early 2025. The GPU-as-a-Service (GPUaaS) solution provides on-demand access to graphics processing units, commonly used in AI model training, for applications such as machine learning, graphics rendering, and data processing. The service is set to launch in the third quarter of 2024, expanding Singtel's cloud offerings and leveraging the power of AI chips.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

Singtel intends to move its customers to its first new artificial intelligence data centre in Tuas.

site_title: Transforming for growth against global headwinds
summary: Singapore's government has introduced a budget to support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) amid global headwinds. The Enterprise Support Package includes a corporate income tax rebate, a $2,000 cash grant for micro-enterprises, and an extension of the SkillsFuture Enterprise Credit. The government aims to encourage digitalization, automation, and artificial intelligence (AI) adoption to help SMEs transform and grow. Key areas of focus include sustainability, workforce development, and supply chain resilience. The government will also provide support for SMEs to develop their first sustainability reports and roll out a grant to encourage digitalization and AI adoption.

images.alt_text: From left: Vicky Hwang, CEO, Chyau Fwu Wine & Spirits; Koren Wines, managing director, Xero Asia; Low Yen Ling, Minister of State for Trade and Industry; Anita Gabriel, senior correspondent, The Business Times.
Areas where SMEs can adopt AI include marketing and customer engagement, says Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling.

site_title: Singapore shares little changed at Tuesday’s open; STI up 0.01%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.01% to 3,172.38, with gainers outnumbering losers 65 to 35. Seatrium declined 2.5% due to heavy trading, while SMI Vantage and Singtel gained 6.5% and 1.2%, respectively. Banking stocks were mixed, with DBS nearly flat and OCBC falling 0.1%. The rise follows mixed global markets, with US indices boosted by investor buzz on artificial intelligence and European stocks edging lower due to a slump in the telecommunications sector.

images.alt_text: SingPost announces the completion of its strategic review which was initiated in May 2023.

site_title: Will raising EP salary thresholds lead to better outcomes for local PMETs?
summary: The Employment Pass (EP) salary threshold in Singapore will increase to S$5,600 from January 1, 2025. This rise is faster than the previous decade, mainly due to rising nominal wages and inflation. Industry watchers suggest that many companies already pay their EP holders market rates, and small and medium enterprises (SMEs) are likely priced out of the EP market. The government's aim is to improve the quality of foreign workers, not reduce intake. The higher threshold may lead to a dilemma for companies, with some opting to raise EP holders' pay and others considering layoffs.

images.alt_text: Singapore businesses may become increasingly "multi-city" or "multi-region", as they engage more workers abroad.

site_title: Economic competitiveness becoming top European concern
summary: European Union leaders are increasingly concerned about the region's economic competitiveness, which has been declining compared to other major world powers, particularly the US. The EU's economy, which was larger than the US in 2008, has since fallen behind, with the US economy growing to over $25 trillion while the EU and UK economies together reached around $20 trillion. The challenges include flatlining labor productivity, failure to match US levels of investment, and regulatory burdens. European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen has commissioned a report to address these issues, which will be led by former ECB chief Mario Draghi.

images.alt_text: A core uncertainty regarding Europe’s future is whether it can boost its economic competitiveness and close its growth gap with the US.

site_title: China lags in efforts to achieve 2025 green steel goals, analysts say
summary: China is falling short in achieving its 2025 green steel goals due to slowing demand, low recycling rates, and lingering overcapacity concerns. The global steel industry, primarily based in China, accounts for around 8% of the world's carbon dioxide emissions. China has promised to transition from coal-fired blast furnaces to cleaner electric arc furnace technology, but is lagging behind in replacing these older facilities with cleaner alternatives. This setback highlights the challenges in decarbonizing China's massive steel industry.

images.alt_text: A worker polishes steel rims at a factory producing bicycle parts for export in Hangzhou, in eastern China's Zhejiang province on February 18, 2024. (Photo by AFP) / China Out

site_title: DOJ to push for TikTok divestiture in Senate briefings
summary: The US Department of Justice will hold closed-door briefings in the Senate to advance legislation that would allow TikTok to continue operating in the US while being severed from its Chinese owner, ByteDance. The bill would require TikTok to be divested within six months, potentially bought by US investors or an American entity. Deputy Attorney General Lisa Monaco aims to prevent China from using technology and data for illegal or harmful purposes, citing concerns over data security and national security laws. TikTok disputes the claim that it collects sensitive user information, stating that the data is collected for online services and stored on US servers.

images.alt_text: Efforts to remove Chinese corporate influence over the popular social-media platform is back on the political agenda in an election year.
Supporters of TikTok gather near the Capitol in Washington on March 13, 2024.
FILE PHOTO: The TikTok office building is shown in Culver City, California, U.S., April 26, 2023. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

site_title: Nvidia expands ties with Chinese EV makers as auto AI race heats up
summary: Nvidia is expanding its partnerships with Chinese electric vehicle (EV) manufacturers, including BYD, to enable autonomous driving and AI-augmented infotainment technology. BYD will use Nvidia's Drive Thor chips, while Chinese automakers Xpeng, GAC Aion, and Zeekr have also partnered with Nvidia. The collaborations aim to boost global market presence and compete with established Western brands, particularly Tesla, as Chinese automakers drive to expand sales in Europe, Southeast Asia, and other markets.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Visitors view a BYD Dolphin EV car at the 44th Bangkok International Motor Show in Bangkok, Thailand, March 23, 2023. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha/File Photo

site_title: Bank of Japan expected to end negative rates
summary: The Bank of Japan is expected to end its 17-year negative interest rate policy and hike borrowing costs for the first time, following similar moves by the US Federal Reserve and other central banks to combat inflation. This decision is seen as a positive move for exporters but a negative one for consumers, as it makes imports more expensive. The BoJ has kept its main rate negative since 2016 to stimulate the economy, but inflation has been at or above its 2% target for almost two years, prompting the central bank to reassess its policy.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index, which measures the US currency against six other major currencies, was last down 0.12 per cent at 103.35.
BOJ nine-member board likely remains divided on how much support the fragile economy will need to sustain a recovery.

site_title: Audi unveils long-delayed Q6 e-tron just as electric-vehicle growth cools
summary: Audi unveiled its long-delayed Q6 e-tron, a luxury mid-size SUV, as electric vehicle growth cools in Europe. The €74,700 vehicle features fast-charging technology and will be the first fully electric model produced at Audi's headquarters in Germany. Deliveries are set to begin in the third quarter, but the Q6 e-tron faces stiff competition from rivals like Mercedes-Benz and Tesla. Audi plans to introduce 20 models by 2026, with half of them fully electric, as the brand seeks to rejuvenate its offerings after a slowdown in EV sales.

site_title: Government schemes have ‘something for everyone’ to help SMEs transform and grow
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 offers various government support schemes to ease burdens and boost growth for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The S$1.3 billion Enterprise Support Package includes a 50% income tax rebate and cash payouts for hiring local staff. The SkillsFuture Enterprise Credit and Enterprise Financing Scheme also provide support. SMEs can also benefit from the Progressive Wage Credit Scheme and digitalisation initiatives. Despite challenges such as cash flow issues and the tight labour market, the government encourages SMEs to evolve and make deliberate decisions to protect themselves.

site_title: Biden to host Philippines, Japan leaders on April 11: White House
summary: US President Joe Biden will host his counterparts from the Philippines and Japan, Ferdinand Marcos and Fumio Kishida, on April 11 for a three-way summit. The leaders aim to promote a "shared vision for a free and open Indo-Pacific" amid rising regional tensions with China. This marks the first time a US leader has hosted a summit with both countries simultaneously. The meeting is seen as a key step in strengthening US alliances in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Trump unable to post US$464 million bond in New York civil case: lawyers
summary: Donald Trump's lawyers acknowledged he cannot post a $464 million bond in a New York civil case, raising the possibility of his assets being seized. Trump's company was found guilty of fraudulently inflating his wealth, resulting in a $464 million fine. With 30 insurance underwriters rejecting his pleas for assistance, Trump must either deposit the full fine into a court-managed account or secure a bond in the full amount. If no delay is granted, the state of New York could begin seizing his property as early as next Monday.

summary: Nvidia unveiled its flagship AI chip, the Blackwell B200, at its annual developer conference, boasting speeds up to 30 times faster than its previous chip. The single-chip design, combining two chips the size of its previous offering, aims to maintain Nvidia's dominance in the data centre AI chip market. With an 80% market share last year, the new chip and software tools aim to further solidify Nvidia's leadership in the AI equipment market.

site_title: US: Tech shares lifted by artificial intelligence boom
summary: US tech shares rose 0.8% on Monday, led by the Nasdaq Composite Index, as investors remained optimistic about the artificial intelligence boom. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also gained, with Apple's shares rising 0.6% after a report of talks to integrate Google's AI platform into its smartphones. The upcoming Federal Reserve meeting is expected to influence investor sentiment, with markets anticipating three interest rate cuts in 2024.

site_title: Saudi Aramco CEO calls energy transition strategy a failure
summary: Saudi Aramco CEO Amin Nasser described the current energy transition strategy as a "misguided failure" due to the continued dominance of fossil fuels, which accounted for 82% of global consumption last year. He warned that oil demand could hit a record high this year and questioned the feasibility of reaching net zero emissions by 2050. Nasser called for policies that reflect the "real world" and suggested investing in fossil fuels rather than phasing them out. ExxonMobil CEO Darren Woods also expressed skepticism about the pace of emissions reductions, citing the need for economic incentives.

site_title: Oil prices climb 2% to 4-month high on lower Iraq, Saudi exports
summary: Oil prices rose 2% to a four-month high on Monday, driven by lower crude exports from Iraq and Saudi Arabia, and signs of stronger demand and economic growth in China and the US. Brent futures reached $86.89 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude rose to $82.72 a barrel. Iraq plans to reduce exports by 130,000 barrels per day, while Saudi Arabia's crude exports fell for a second straight month. Stronger-than-expected US economic growth and higher oil demand in China are also contributing to the price increase.

site_title: Singapore’s single family offices likely to merge, find alternative models
summary: Singapore's single family offices are likely to merge or adopt alternative models due to rising operational costs. Industry players expect wealthy families to share resources or seek cheaper wealth management options. This shift is driven by the need to balance costs with the need for specialized services, as Singapore remains an attractive global financial hub.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

Singapore’s robust regulatory framework, stable economy, favourable tax and regulatory conditions, talented workforce, and strategic geographical location are key draw factors for family offices in Asia.

site_title: IMF is lending near record US$150 billion to counter debt and wars
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is lending near a record $150 billion to nearly 100 countries to counter debt and conflicts, with over 50 borrowers having active loan or guarantee programs. The IMF's managing director, Kristalina Georgieva, warns that the widening income gap between rich and poor countries and geopolitical tensions are fuelling instability. The fund's lending is largely driven by US interests, with many borrowers overlapping with Washington's top geopolitical priorities, such as Ukraine and Egypt. The IMF's liquidity support, including its $1 trillion in funds, aims to promote global financial stability and security.

summary: European shares fell 0.1% on Monday, led by a 1.4% decline in the telecoms sector, while Ireland's ISEQ index rose 0.1% to outperform peers. Euro zone inflation remained steady at 2.6% in February, and interest rates are expected to be cut by the European Central Bank in June. Oil and gas stocks rose 0.5% after Brent crude briefly topped $86 per barrel, while technology shares advanced 0.4% ahead of Nvidia's developer conference.

images.alt_text: The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index finished 0.8 per cent higher at 16,103.45 on Monday.

site_title: Canadian home sales dip; prices snap 5-month streak of declines
summary: Canadian home sales decreased 3.1% in February from January, reversing a 12.7% increase in the previous two months. Despite this, prices stopped falling for the first time in five months, suggesting a potential market revival ahead of anticipated interest rate cuts by the Bank of Canada. Annual sales were up 19.7%, while the Home Price Index remained flat, up 0.8% annually.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SingPost, Manulife US Reit
summary: SingPost announced a corporate restructuring into three business units, with plans to pay out 30-50% of underlying net profit from FY2024 to FY2025. Manulife US Reit's management team is set to step down, with new executives taking over by June 30, 2024. The companies' shares closed flat and 5% lower, respectively, on Monday.

site_title: Nasdaq resolves technical glitch that impacted premarket trading
summary: Nasdaq resolved a technical glitch that impacted premarket trading for over two hours on Monday, affecting orders sent using the "RASH FIX" order handling system. The issue was related to the matching engine and did not significantly impact overall trading volume, with a 0.8% impact on exchange-traded volume. Some stocks showed unusually wide spreads, indicating poor market liquidity. The glitch was resolved, and all systems are now operating normally, with Nasdaq promising a full postmortem when available.

site_title: No competition: Dubai complements Singapore’s fight for family offices, industry watchers say
summary: Dubai is emerging as a complementary financial hub to Singapore, attracting wealthy families despite increased scrutiny of family offices in Singapore. Industry players say Dubai's low tax regime, stability, and strong regulatory support make it an attractive destination for diversifying investments. As Singapore tightens checks on single-family offices, Dubai's growing popularity is expected to continue, with some families opting for the city's Golden Visa and faster processing times. Despite competition, experts believe both hubs will benefit from global wealth migration towards the East.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

site_title: Cisco closes US$28 billion Splunk deal without antitrust drama
summary: Cisco Systems closed its $28 billion acquisition of data-crunching software maker Splunk in six months without attracting regulatory scrutiny. The deal, announced in September 2023, aims to diversify Cisco's business and provide tools for monitoring network health and cybersecurity risks. Unlike other large mergers, Cisco and Splunk have distinct businesses, making the transaction less likely to raise antitrust concerns. CEO Chuck Robbins credited the companies' different businesses for avoiding regulatory hurdles, saying the deal will be "good for customers." The deal did not require approval in China, a previous hurdle for other companies.

site_title: Pressure builds for charge on global shipping sector’s CO2 emissions
summary: The European Union, Canada, Japan, and climate-vulnerable Pacific Island states are rallying support for a global charge on the shipping sector's greenhouse gas emissions, with 47 countries backing proposals. The charge could raise over $80 billion annually, funding low-carbon shipping fuels and supporting poorer countries. However, China, Brazil, and Argentina oppose the idea, citing potential economic disruption. The International Maritime Organization (IMO) is set to make a decision by September, with a fuel standard likely to be taken forward, but disagreements remain over the charge's details.

Traders bought over 24,000 call contracts, with some speculating it could be a tail-risk hedge. site_title: UBS powers past US$100 billion one year after Credit Suisse shock
summary: UBS Group has surpassed US$100 billion in market capitalization one year after acquiring Credit Suisse, marking a significant growth in scale and ambitions. The bank's core wealth management business has seen a significant boost, with client funds increasing by one-fifth to US$3.4 trillion. UBS aims to expand its invested assets to over US$5 trillion by 2028, with a focus on catching up with Wall Street rivals. site_title: Team Hugo Boss sweeps first leg of BT Corporate Golf League
summary: The Team Hugo Boss, led by captain Marilyn Lum, swept the first leg of the BT Corporate Golf League, claiming both the team and individual titles. Inclement weather reduced the competition to 11 holes, but the all-woman team played conservatively to top the leaderboard. Lum won the individual title with 24 points, while her teammates Denise Ng and Rebecca De Foe combined for 65 points. site_title: FDIC offloads US$10.5 billion of SVB loans that hung over market
summary: The FDIC has sold US$10.5 billion of Ginnie Mae project loan securities, a type of debt backed by apartment loans, after holding them since the 2023 banking crisis. The securities, valued at US$13 billion, were a risk of a fire sale that could have disrupted the market. The sale, made to trusts tied to the Federal Financing Bank, eliminates the possibility of the securities flowing into private markets, according to strategists at Santander US Capital Markets. The transaction was seen as a way to tie up loose ends from the bank failures.

site_title: SEC sues money managers for bogus artificial intelligence claims
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has sued two money managers, Delphia and Global Predictions, for making false and misleading statements about their use of artificial intelligence (AI) in their investment strategies. The SEC has been warning firms about over-hyped AI claims, and this is part of a crackdown by the regulator. The agency has specific authorities to oversee statements made to investors. The lawsuit follows warnings from SEC Chair Gary Gensler about "AI washing" in public statements about AI use.

site_title: Goldman boosts US 2024 GDP growth, jobs forecasts on immigration
summary: Goldman Sachs has raised its US economic growth forecast for 2024 to 2.7% year-over-year, citing higher consumption and immigration. The bank now expects 175,000 monthly payroll gains and an unemployment rate of 3.8%. Immigration is seen as a key factor, with Goldman estimating it was around 2.5 million in 2023, above historical averages. This boost is expected to continue, with immigration remaining about 1 million above trend for this year.

site_title: US dollar dips, yen steadies as BOJ policy shift beckons
summary: The US dollar fell 0.12% to 103.35 against a basket of six major currencies, as traders awaited central bank meetings, including the Bank of Japan's potential policy shift. The yen steadied against the dollar at 149.07 yen per dollar, after weakening in the previous month and rebounding in March. The US dollar index has risen 2% this year, with investors reassessing their bets on the Federal Reserve's rate cuts. Markets now expect 73 basis points of cuts this year, down from 140 bps at the start of the year.
