site_title: International trade: The anti-money laundering Achilles’ heel
summary: International trade vulnerabilities have led to widespread money laundering schemes, with billions of dollars moving through Singapore's financial system. Trade fraud and money laundering often co-exist due to paper-based documentation and the ease of manipulation. A ground-up solution involves focusing on nominee directors and whistleblowing, as they can create the illusion of arms' length dealings. Proposed legislation in Singapore aims to address these vulnerabilities, including introducing a Corporate Service Providers Bill and requiring nominee directors and shareholders to disclose their nominee status. Empowering whistleblowers with a protected avenue to report wrongdoing could also reduce vulnerabilities in the corporate regime.

site_title: America (still) has no industrial policy
summary: The US lacks an effective industrial policy, despite the Biden administration's efforts to support re-industrialization, subsidize strategic industries, and boost unions. Rana Foroohar argues that these policies are separate from a fundamentally new operating system, and that real connections between stakeholders are needed to achieve desired outcomes such as rebalancing consumption and production, reducing inequality, and promoting sustainable growth.

images.alt_text: Today’s semiconductor industry is so globally interdependent that almost no chips can be produced without machines and materials from multiple international sources.

site_title: China sets higher bar for consumer finance companies
summary: China has implemented stricter measures for consumer finance companies, effective April 18, amid regulatory tightening in the financial sector. The revised rules require non-bank financial businesses to have a minimum registered capital of 1 billion yuan, up from 300 million yuan, and a major investor to hold at least 50% stake, up from 30%. Financial institutions must also have total assets of 500 billion yuan and a non-financial major investor must have at least 60 billion yuan in operating income. These measures aim to deter new players and maintain financial stability.

images.alt_text: Foreign institutions held 3.95 trillion yuan (S$751 billion) in bonds traded on China’s interbank market as of the end of February.
Cash-strapped firms are reversing course after global expansion.
China's February year-on-year consumer price growth of 0.7 per cent outpaces Reuters economists' forecasted 0.3 per cent uptick.

site_title: EV startup Fisker to raise up to US$150 million, pauses production
summary: Fisker, an electric vehicle startup, will pause production for six weeks and raise up to $150 million in funding by selling convertible notes to address a cash crunch and weak demand for its cars. The company had previously flagged substantial doubt about its ability to continue as a going concern and paused investments until securing a partnership with an automaker.

images.alt_text: Nissan may invest as much as US$400 million in Fisker’s truck platform and building a planned pickup starting in 2026 at one of its US assembly plants.

site_title: Disney receives endorsement from proxy advisory firm in board battle
summary: Disney received a critical endorsement from Glass Lewis, a proxy advisory firm, urging shareholders to re-elect all of the company's directors. The recommendation comes after Disney's recent earnings reports showed progress, including the company's streaming business becoming profitable. Glass Lewis rejected proposals from hedge funds Trian Fund Management and Blackwells Capital to replace the board, citing better ideas for improvement. The company's board has 12 members and will vote at Disney's annual meeting on April 3.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Tata Group is seen at a business meeting organised by the Confederation of Indian Industry (CII) in New Delhi March 23, 2009. REUTERS/Vijay Mathur (INDIA BUSINESS)/File Photo

site_title: Sabana should lead smaller Reits with underperforming unit prices to look for an exit
summary: Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit) is considering an exit strategy after its internalization of management was met with resistance from unitholders. Despite posting year-on-year growth in gross revenue and net property income, the trust's manager faced challenges in attracting and retaining talent due to internalization push. With a lack of size and trading liquidity, Sabana Reit may benefit from selling its assets, with a valuation of around its net asset value (NAV) potentially attracting suitors. The trust's unitholders may be better off exploring exit options rather than pursuing internalization of management.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio.
New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio.

site_title: Alibaba groceries arm Freshippo CEO to retire, to be replaced by CFO
summary: Freshippo, Alibaba's groceries arm, has announced the retirement of its CEO Hou Yi and his replacement by CFO Yan Xiaolei. Hou, 60, joined Alibaba in 2015 and created Freshippo in 2016 as part of the company's "new retail" revolution. The leadership change comes amid a restructuring and strategy rethink at Alibaba, which has seen several senior leaders depart or move into new roles. Alibaba had initially planned to list Freshippo but halted the plan in November, and the company's chairman has stated that its physical retail businesses are not its core focus.

images.alt_text: EU officials are concerned about the potential dissemination of illegal products such as fake medicines, non-compliant food, and ineffective dietary supplements on AliExpress.

Alibaba plans to spend US$200 million this year on building the logistics centre and US$100 million to help small and mid-sized South Korean firms sell their products overseas, the Yonhap report said.
People walk past an Alibaba booth during the China International Supply Chain Expo (CISCE) in Beijing on December 1, 2023. (Photo by JADE GAO / AFP)

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 18)
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports fell 0.1% in February, driven by a decline in the non-electronics sector. The general insurance sector posted a 10.1% year-on-year increase in gross written premiums to S$10.2 billion in 2023. Tong Lee Building, a prime freehold industrial property, will be put up for collective sale with a guide price of S$410 million. The National University of Singapore is investing S$20 million to turn deep-tech research into market solutions. Singapore stocks closed flat on Monday ahead of the Fed interest rate announcement.

site_title: Singapore stocks end flat on Monday ahead of Fed interest rate announcement
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) closed flat on Monday, March 18, ahead of the US Federal Reserve's interest rate announcement. The STI fell 1.03 points or 0.03% to 3,171.93. Seatrium, a shipbuilder, saw its stock drop to a 52-week low despite some brokerages recommending a "buy" due to its balance sheet and liquidity. Meanwhile, Emperador, a Philippine alcohol maker, rose 8.8% after being dropped from the STI.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
SIA flies 28.2% more passengers in February year-on-year.
In morning trade on Monday, Tokyo was up 2.1 per cent, while other Asian stocks were mixed.
Across the broader market, losers outnumber gainers 52 to 36.

site_title: Pakistan’s central bank keeps interest rate on hold at 22%
summary: Pakistan's central bank held its key interest rate at 22% for a sixth consecutive policy meeting, in line with expectations. Despite a slight easing of inflation in February, the bank maintained a cautious approach due to ongoing inflation risks. The decision aims to bring inflation down to the target range of 5-7% by September 2025, with the bank citing risks from further administered price increases or fiscal measures. The decision comes ahead of the April expiry of a $3 billion IMF standby arrangement.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) logo is seen outside the headquarters building in Washington, U.S., September 4, 2018. REUTERS/Yuri Gripas/File Photo

The election took place in the shadow of a month’s long military campaign to gut the party of former Prime Minister Imran Khan, a former international cricket star and populist leader who was ousted by parliament in 2022 after falling out with the generals.
The State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) has raised its key policy rate by 12.25 percentage points since April 2022, to curb soaring inflation.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, March 18, 2024 (Ep 24)
summary: The Bank of Japan is widely expected to raise interest rates on Tuesday, while Vietnam announces a new trading platform, boosting stocks in the region. The Ringgit currency bounces back from a February low due to government efforts. In contrast, Singapore's non-oil exports decreased 0.1% in February. Despite these mixed signals, the market remains optimistic, with stocks rallying overall.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, losers outnumber gainers 52 to 36.
The benchmark Nikkei 225 index jumps 2.67 per cent or 1,032.80 points to 39,740.44.
The nation plans to introduce a platform that can handle three to five million orders per day.

site_title: Here’s a prudent retirement plan amid the latest CPF changes
summary: A prudent retirement plan involves crafting a spending strategy and matching assets to fund essential expenses. Those aged 55 and older should consider CPF Life and other assets, such as private annuities, to mitigate longevity risk and ensure a stable income. After the Special Account (SA) closes next year, money will be transferred to the Ordinary Account (OA), and a spending plan will help determine how to allocate it. To maximize retirement income, consider supplementing CPF Life with other instruments, such as retirement income insurance plans, and regularly review and adjust the plan to account for changing financial circumstances.

images.alt_text: In addition to leveraging government schemes to grow one's nest egg, reaching out to professional wealth planning managers can help close gaps and boost financial resilience.
Owner-occupiers of pricier private homes may wish to factor in higher property taxes in their retirement planning.

site_title: Sumitomo Life completes Singlife acquisition following regulatory approval
summary: Sumitomo Life has completed the acquisition of Singlife, a Singaporean life insurer, after receiving regulatory approval. The deal values Singlife at S$4.6 billion, following a stake increase from 23.2% to 27% by Sumitomo Life. The acquisition will not affect Singlife's operations, including its name, brand, management team, and products. Aviva sold its 25.9% stake in Singlife to Sumitomo Life for £937 million (S$1.6 billion).

The transactions, subject to regulatory approvals in Japan and Singapore, are expected to complete in Q1 of 2024.

The issue comprises 23.7 million new shares, representing 4.92 per cent of the increased share capital of Singlife, which stood at S$2.26 billion post transaction.
GIA president Ronak Shah says protecting and supporting the motoring public will remain a key focus for the general insurance sector in the coming year.

site_title: Founder of Vietnam EV maker VinFast launches global charging stations venture
summary: Vietnamese billionaire Pham Nhat Vuong has spun off a new company, V-Green, from VinFast, focusing on building and managing the company's charging network. V-Green will invest $404 million over two years to expand and upgrade the network, which already boasts 150,000 charging ports across Vietnam. This move allows VinFast to focus on its global expansion, with Vuong stating that the increased investment will help the company "rev up its global game."

images.alt_text: A VinFast charging station in Da Nang, Vietnam

site_title: China urges citizens in Singapore to ‘stay away’ from gambling
summary: China's embassy in Singapore urged its citizens to stay away from gambling, citing strict laws prohibiting the activity in China. The embassy warned that even if overseas casinos are legal, cross-border gambling by Chinese citizens could violate Chinese laws and may not receive consular protection.

site_title: Apac real estate values emerge after ‘the great reset’
summary: The Asia-Pacific (Apac) real estate market is set to begin its recovery in 2024, driven by stabilised capital values and resilient income returns. The region's structural growth, driven by demographics, digitalisation, and decarbonisation, is fuelling occupier demand across real estate sectors and geographies. Key markets such as Sydney, Seoul, and Singapore offer compelling entry prices and rental growth prospects, while Japan's low interest rates have supported real estate prices. Investors should focus on income, digitalisation, and decarbonisation themes, and consider real estate debt as a diversification opportunity.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand Development held the groundbreaking ceremony of Lumi Hanoi on Mar 1, 2024.
architecture, modern, building

site_title: Dubai royal nephew opens US$500 million family office in Hong Kong
summary: Sheikh Ali Al Maktoum, the nephew of Dubai ruler Sheikh Mohammed Bin Rashid Al Maktoum, has opened a US$500 million family office in Hong Kong, marking the city's efforts to attract foreign capital. The office will focus on investments in Asia's sectors such as AI, construction, and fintech. Sheikh Ali cited Hong Kong's "advanced" business environment and investment opportunities, and plans to engage in talks with potential target companies, aiming to build long-term growth. This move comes as Hong Kong seeks to rebound from an economic slump and exodus of international firms.

images.alt_text: Dubai can provide complementary benefits to Singapore, even as competition spurs both on to become leading financial hubs in Asia, say industry players.
Nakheel, the group behind Dubai’s palm-shaped islands, was taken over by the government in 2011 as part of a US$16 billion rescue plan in the aftermath of a 2009-2010 real estate crash.
Dubai has seen a surge in demand for property over the past couple years, aided by an influx of a people from around the world.

site_title: Swedish property group SBB offers to buy back more debt
summary: Swedish property group SBB is offering to buy back hybrid and senior securities to reduce its overall debt level. The company, which was at the center of a Swedish property crash, spent 403.8 million euros last year to buy back debt at a discount. SBB aims to proactively manage its balance sheet, optimize its future interest expense, and better manage its wholesale funding level. Bids are due by March 22.

site_title: China’s property investment declines slow but sector still shaky
summary: China's property sector continues to face challenges, with property investment and sales showing slower declines in the first two months of 2024. However, analysts remain cautious, citing a liquidity crisis and ongoing regulatory efforts to support the sector. Despite government measures, including a "whitelist" mechanism and reduced mortgage rates, property firms continue to struggle with cash flow, and market participants remain skeptical about a rapid recovery. Experts warn that the sector needs further support to stabilize, with potential policy interventions including lifting home purchase restrictions and increasing public housing supply.

images.alt_text: Policymakers have increased pressure on banks to boost their property loans through so-called white lists, as developers struggle to complete projects.
Cash-strapped firms are reversing course after global expansion.
Buildings under construction in Hangzhou.

site_title: NUS invests S$20 million to turn deep-tech research into market solutions
summary: The National University of Singapore (NUS) is investing S$20 million to support deep-tech research commercialization. The investment includes S$10 million for the existing NUS Graduate Research Innovation Programme (Grip) and S$10 million for a new Innovation Fellowship and Venture Creation Awards. The awards will provide a two-year grant and guidance to support researchers in translating their research into market solutions. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat hopes the awards will foster a culture of faculty-industry collaboration, aligning with Singapore's Research, Innovation and Enterprise 2025 plan.

images.alt_text: Members of deep tech spin-off Amperesand with the solid state transformer prototype developed at NTU's Energy Research Institute.

From left: NTU president Ho Teck Hua, NUS president Tan Eng Chye, and Temasek head of emerging technologies Russell Tham at the MOU signing ceremony. Temasek, NUS and NTU will provide startups with access to their networks of businesses and mentors.

site_title: Hong Kong’s Dec-Feb unemployment holds steady at 2.9%
summary: Hong Kong's unemployment rate remained steady at 2.9% from December to February, unchanged from the previous three-month period. This holds true since the August-to-October period, which was slightly up from 2.8% in the July-to-September period. The labour market is expected to remain tight in the near term, driven by the local economy's continued growth.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close sharply higher amid potential BOJ rate hike
summary: Tokyo stocks surged 2.67% on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index jumping 1,032.80 points to 39,740.44, driven by speculation of a potential interest rate hike from the Bank of Japan. The central bank's two-day policy meeting starts today, with a press conference scheduled for Tuesday. Despite expectations of a rate increase, Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda is expected to maintain easy monetary conditions to support Japan's fragile growth. Shares of Fast Retailing, Tokyo Electron, and Advantest also saw significant gains.

images.alt_text: The board is weighing whether to end an era that saw the most aggressive monetary easing in modern history.
Japan’s economy avoided a technical recession at the end of last year, even though the upward change in the fourth quarter was weaker than expected.

site_title: Consortium led by Gear seeks private credit for mine deal: sources
summary: A consortium led by Golden Energy & Resources (Gear) is seeking private credit funds and banks to finance its US$1.65 billion acquisition of a coal mine in Australia. The deal includes an upfront cash payment of US$1.05 billion and a contingent price-linked cash component of up to US$350 million. Gear is no stranger to the private credit market, having previously secured a US$1.1 billion loan for an Australian metallurgical company's bid on a coal mine. The sale is expected to close in the first half of 2025, subject to regulatory approvals.

images.alt_text: The three banks have proposed to help finance the accelerated closing of the Cirebon-1 coal-fired power station in West Java.

site_title: Vingroup sells 41.5% of its stake in retail unit
summary: Vingroup sells 41.5% stake in Vincom Retail to an undisclosed partner for an undisclosed sum, worth almost US$1 billion. The stake sale comes as the group invests billions to develop loss-making VinFast and expand globally. Vincom Retail, which owns 83 shopping malls in Vietnam, will no longer be a Vingroup unit after the transaction. The deal is expected to conclude by the third quarter of this year, following initial discussions in March last year.

site_title: Turkey moves against Meta over Threads-Instagram data sharing
summary: Turkey's competition authority has imposed an interim measure on Meta Platforms to hinder data sharing between Instagram and Threads, as it investigates possible abuse of Meta's dominant market position. The authority also fined Meta 4.8 million lira (S$198,805) daily for a notification message that failed to provide sufficient information on data sharing between Meta's Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp services. The investigation was launched in December, and the interim measure will remain in place until a final decision is made.

images.alt_text: If any of the six tech giants are not compliant with the Digital Markets Act (DMA) by the EU’s Thursday deadline, they could ultimately face investigations and potentially fines of up to 10 per cent of their global turnover.
The suggested partnership with Google has the potential to thwart Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg's plan to 'own the next computational platform for AR, VR, and mixed reality.'
Meta is, however, not obligated to pay news publishers if it implements a ban that prevents users from reposting news articles
Meta has said subscription for no ads addresses the latest regulatory developments, guidance and judgments shared by European regulators and the courts in recent years.

site_title: ANZ CEO looks for India, China growth as customer focus shifts
summary: ANZ CEO Shayne Elliott is shifting the bank's focus towards growing its presence in India, Vietnam, and China as clients require services in multiple locations. The institutional bank's return-on-equity has grown to mid-single digits, driven by Asia-Pacific business. Elliott expects China business to continue growing, with demand remaining "enormous." The bank is also exiting positions in Bank of Tianjin and Bank Pan Indonesia. Elliott's hawkish tone on interest rates differs from the bank's economists, predicting rate cuts may not materialize until the end of the year due to inflation concerns.

site_title: Genting Singapore investors unfazed by Beijing’s warning to its citizens to stay away from gambling
summary: Genting Singapore's Q4 gaming revenue for FY2023 is "very respectable" despite a public warning from the Chinese embassy in Singapore to its citizens to "stay away from gambling". The Chinese government reminded its nationals that cross-border gambling is breaking China's laws, but Genting Singapore shares barely shifted after the warning. The integrated resort operator reported its Q4 gaming revenue, but no further details were provided. The company's response to the warning suggests investors are unfazed.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
An artist's impression of Marina Bay Sands' fourth tower.
MBS's casino segment maintained its position as the largest revenue contributor in the quarter.
CGS-CIMB likes Genting Singapore for its growing market share of VIP gamers.
Genting Singapore’s Resorts World casino fined S$2.25 million for due diligence lapses

site_title: Washington vs TikTok: Wide bipartisan push against Chinese ownership
summary: The US Congress has passed a bipartisan bill to ban TikTok from US devices unless it divests from its Chinese owner, ByteDance, amid concerns over national security and data sharing. The bill, which has been endorsed by the Biden administration, would prohibit social media apps controlled by foreign adversaries, allowing the US president to prohibit such apps. The move comes after the House approved the bill 352-65, with the Senate's fate remaining unclear. TikTok's executives have vowed to challenge the bill in courts, claiming it is unconstitutional, while the company has denied complying with Chinese government demands.

images.alt_text: Even if ByteDance puts the TikTok app up for sale, the Chinese government is unlikely to allow the company’s most valuable asset, its recommendation algorithm, to be included.

site_title: Pfizer to cut stake in Sensodyne toothpaste-maker Haleon to 24%
summary: Pfizer, the top shareholder of Haleon, a consumer healthcare firm, plans to sell 630 million shares, valued at approximately £2.03 billion (S$3.5 billion), reducing its stake to about 24%. This is part of a previously announced plan to cut its ownership in a "slow and methodical" manner within months. The offer price per share is expected to be announced on or around March 19.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Pfizer company logo is seen at a Pfizer office in Puurs, Belgium, December 2, 2022. REUTERS/Johanna Geron/File Photo

site_title: Vietnam brokers may rally more on trading boost, retail boom
summary: Vietnamese brokerage stocks are expected to continue their rally as the nation plans to introduce a new platform capable of handling 3-5 million orders per day, increasing trading capacity and settling trades more smoothly. Low borrowing costs and a retail boom have fueled the surge in individual investors, with securities stocks rising 24% in 2024 and the VN Index outperforming its peers in South-east Asia. The central bank's policy easing has also contributed to the economic rebound, with brokerage shares and the overall market benefiting from the increased liquidity.

site_title: Sony hits pause on PSVR2 production as unsold inventory piles up
summary: Sony has paused production of its PSVR2 headset due to a backlog of unsold units, which have built up since the product's launch in February last year. The company has produced over two million units, with shipments declining every quarter since its debut. Despite this, industry analyst Francisco Jeronimo forecasts a 31.5% annual growth in the VR market between 2023 and 2028, citing Apple's entry as a potential catalyst. The high price of VR hardware and limited content are seen as major hurdles to its expansion.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Zee Entertainment and SONY logos are displayed in this illustration taken, September 1, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

Sony Honda Mobility plans a global roll-out that includes Europe, parts of Asia and the Middle East.

site_title: China’s CNOOC discovers 100 million tonnes oilfield in Bohai Sea
summary: China's state-owned oil and gas giant CNOOC has discovered a significant oilfield in the Bohai Sea, adding over 100 million tonnes of oil equivalent proved in-place volume. The discovery was made at the Qinhuangdao 27-3 oilfield, which has been tested to produce 742 barrels of crude oil per day from a single well. This is the second major oil discovery announced by CNOOC in recent months, following a discovery in the South China Sea.

site_title: Gold prices retreat from historical highs, but analysts still bullish about near-term outlook
summary: Gold prices retreated from historical highs, falling 1.3% week-over-week to around $2,149 per troy ounce, but analysts remain bullish about the near-term outlook. Market volatility and macroeconomic uncertainty continue to channel investor flows into the commodity. Despite a pullback, gold prices are still up 8.4% year-on-year, and year-to-date gains are 4.1% for spot prices and 3.3% for futures. Analysts expect a dovish US monetary policy and a softening US dollar to keep gold prices supported, with some predicting prices could reach $2,400 per ounce in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Higher interest rates reduce the appeal of holding non-yielding gold.

An employee assists a customer inside a Luk Fook Holdings International Ltd. jewelry store in Shanghai, China, on Wednesday, March 13, 2024. Higher inflation adds pressure on the US Fed to keep interest rates elevated, weighing on non-yielding assets such as gold.

site_title: Apple in talks to let Google’s Gemini power iPhone AI features: sources
summary: Apple is in talks with Google to license its Gemini AI engine to power new features on the iPhone, including generative AI capabilities. Apple is also exploring options with Microsoft-backed OpenAI. The talks are ongoing, with no final agreement or implementation details disclosed. Apple plans to unveil its upcoming iPhone iOS 18, which will include its own AI models, but is seeking a partner for its generative AI features. A deal is unlikely until Apple's Worldwide Developers Conference in June.

images.alt_text: Nvidia says the H100 is four times faster than the chip’s predecessor, the A100, at training large language models, or LLMs, and is 30 times faster when replying to user prompts.
Sony is still working on expanding the range of material available on the headset, and it said in February that it is testing the ability for PSVR2 players to access PC titles.

site_title: Beyond weak Q4 earnings, analysts sanguine over Malaysia’s earnings growth in 2024
summary: Malaysia's economic conditions are expected to improve in 2024, with analysts forecasting growth in key sectors such as banking, consumer services, and technology. Despite a 7.4% decline in Q4 earnings, analysts remain bullish on the FBM KLCI index, citing robust infrastructure development and resilient consumer spending. Analysts expect the index to reach 1,755 points by end-2024, driven by a turnaround in the global electronic cycle and emerging signs of a tourism recovery. The Malaysian ringgit is also expected to stabilize, attracting foreign investors.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
Malaysia is already the world’s sixth-largest exporter of semiconductors and packages 23 per cent of all American chips.
Economists expect Bank Negara to keep rates steady at 3 per cent until the end-2024 or even longer.

site_title: South Korea’s Yoon warns of tech threat to democracy at summit
summary: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol warned at the Summit for Democracy that fake news and disinformation based on artificial intelligence and digital technology pose a significant threat to democracy. Yoon emphasized the need for countries to share experiences and wisdom to promote democracy through technology. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken and European Commission vice-president Vera Jourova also addressed the summit, highlighting the importance of safeguarding democracy and promoting free and fair elections in the face of digital threats.

images.alt_text: The Nikkei 225 index jumped 2.05 per cent or 793.92 points to 39,501.56 in early trade on Monday.
Across the broader market, losers outnumber gainers 52 to 36.

site_title: ‘Kung Fu Panda 4’ again beats sandworms in North America box office
summary: Kung Fu Panda 4 has taken the top spot in the North American box office for a second weekend, earning an estimated US$30 million from Friday to Sunday. The film has now grossed US$107.7 million in the US and Canada, and US$176.5 million internationally, beating Dune: Part Two by a narrow margin. The film's success is attributed to its martial arts comedy genre, which appeals to a broad audience.

images.alt_text: KUNG Fu Panda 4 , a martial-arts comedy from DreamWorks and Universal, took in an estimated US$58.3 million for the Friday-through-Sunday period.

site_title: China coal output posts first decline since Beijing ordered more
summary: China's thermal coal output declined 4.2% year-over-year to 705 million tonnes in January and February, marking the first decline since September 2021. This drop comes as mine safety concerns and government scrutiny have slowed output in some coal hubs. Despite the decline, coal-fired power generation expanded 9.7% in the first two months of the year, largely due to increased imports. The data reflects China's efforts to bolster energy security, which has become a top priority under President Xi Jinping, following a 2021 energy crisis and Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

Indonesia is the third-largest coal producer in the world after China and India, and is the world’s largest thermal coal exporter.

site_title: Indonesia central bank expected to hold benchmark rate steady at upcoming meeting
summary: Indonesia's central bank is expected to keep its benchmark interest rate steady at 6% for a fifth consecutive meeting, as economists polled by Bloomberg predict stability in the rupiah remains a key concern. The decision follows a surprise rate hike in October last year, and economists warn that prolonged geopolitical tensions and weaker demand from major trading partners could delay rate cuts. The Bank of Indonesia is also monitoring inflation risks, with food prices on the rise, and has signaled that it may loosen monetary policy in the second half of the year as global uncertainty eases.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
Transition finance is crucial for South-east Asia as it has yet to wean itself off fossil fuels

site_title: Used Patek Philippe and Rolex prices stabilise for a second month
summary: Prices for second-hand Rolex and Patek Philippe watches have stabilized for a second month, suggesting a possible end to a two-year slump. The Bloomberg Subdial Watch Index declined 0.1% to $33,628, down 42% since April 2022. Stable prices may be attributed to low borrowing costs and investors waiting for new models to be released in April. The Rolex GMT with a red and blue ceramic bezel remains an outlier, increasing in price by 1.9% to $20,600.

images.alt_text: Total watch sales at the top auction houses fell 13 per cent to 610 million Swiss francs (S$926.7 million) in 2023 from record levels hit in 2022.
The Morgan Stanley and LuxeConsult figures are estimates, as Swiss watch brands including Rolex do not disclose their individual annual sales.

site_title: Broker’s take: RHB raises SGX target price but says valuation, dividends ‘still unexciting’
summary: RHB Research raises its target price on Singapore Exchange (SGX) to S$10 from S$9.60, citing improved earnings estimates and a 21 times price-to-earnings ratio. Analyst Shekhar Jaiswal expects SGX's earnings to benefit from lower capital expenditure and operating cost increases. Despite a 6% environmental, social, and governance premium, Jaiswal remains "neutral" on the stock due to unexciting valuation and dividends.

images.alt_text: Aviation-related counters added to gains, as they continued to ride on the tailwinds of a return in air travel post-pandemic.
Mainland China and Taiwan index futures on Singapore Exchange had deep liquidity.

site_title: UK landlords face higher taxes on home sales despite Hunt’s budget relief
summary: UK landlords selling homes from April will face higher taxes on profits despite Chancellor Jeremy Hunt's budget pledge to reduce capital gains levy. The tax reduction won't benefit sellers due to a shrinking personal tax-free allowance, with 89% of higher-rate payers expected to see a rise in capital gains tax. The changes will disproportionately affect private landlords, second homeowners, and those selling in cheaper markets.

images.alt_text: Experts expect a stronger year for the property market after a stagnant 2023 caused by the surge in mortgage rates.

A pedestrian passes a row of terraced houses in southeast London, U.K., on Thursday, July 21, 2016. London's seven-year housing boom may be about to end after the U.K. voted to leave the European Union. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

A British Union flag near residential properties in a suburb of Brighton, UK, on Wednesday, May 31, 2023. UK house prices resumed their decline, with Nationwide Building Society warning that headwinds for property sellers are increasing. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: Japan core machinery orders fall more than expected, fuel economic uncertainty
summary: Japan's core machinery orders fell more than expected in January, prompting the government to downgrade its view on the indicator for the first time in over a year. The data, released by the Cabinet Office, follows recent data highlighting concerns about the sluggish recovery in the country's economy. This weak data comes as the Bank of Japan begins its two-day monetary policy meeting, although it is unlikely to impact the central bank's decision.

images.alt_text: A Nissan’s Ariya electric crossover sport utility vehicle (SUV) assembled at the Nissan Intelligent Factory in Kaminokawa, Tochigi Prefecture, Japan. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg
Inflation in the island nation appears to be holding near the BOJ’s target of 2 per cent, thanks to higher energy and raw material prices, as well as a tight labour market.
On a quarter-on-quarter basis, Japan's GDP grew 0.1 per cent, compared with the initial 0.1 per cent drop reading and a median forecast for a 0.3 per cent rise.

Japan's household outlays declined by 6.3 per cent in January from a year earlier, the biggest drop since February of 2021, the ministry of internal affairs reported on Friday. It was the 11th straight decline, and it was steeper than economists’ estimate of a 4.1 per cent retreat.

site_title: Who are the BOJ’s doves and hawks?
summary: The Bank of Japan's (BOJ) nine-member board is divided on how much support the fragile economy needs to sustain a recovery, with some members advocating for an early exit from negative interest rates. Hawks, including Naoki Tamura and Ryozo Himino, favor swift policy normalization, while doves, such as Toyoaki Nakamura and Asahi Noguchi, are cautious of acting too soon. Neutrals, like Deputy Governor Shinichi Uchida and Governor Kazuo Ueda, are seen as leaning towards a post-negative rate monetary policy, with Ueda's stance likely to influence the timing and pace of an exit. The BOJ is likely to end its eight-year negative interest rate policy, with a rate hike expected soon.

images.alt_text: The Japanese national flag waves at the Bank of Japan building in Tokyo, Japan March 18, 2024. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon
The board is weighing whether to end an era that saw the most aggressive monetary easing in modern history.

BOJ officials, including governor Kazuo Ueda, have recently stressed the timing of a shift away from negative rates would depend on the outcome of this year’s annual wage negotiations between workers and employers.

site_title: China growth mixed as factory output jumps, consumption lags
summary: China's economy showed mixed growth in the first two months of the year, with factory output and investment increasing, but consumption lagging. Industrial output rose 7% and fixed-asset investment accelerated to 4.2%, while retail sales increased 5.5%. However, consumer demand remained weak, and the urban jobless rate increased to 5.3%. The government's stimulus efforts are helping to stabilize the economy, but achieving its growth target of 5% this year will be challenging due to a less favorable comparison base.

images.alt_text: Foreign institutions held 3.95 trillion yuan (S$751 billion) in bonds traded on China’s interbank market as of the end of February.
The stock of yuan loans grew 9.7 per cent in February from a year ago, the lowest in data going back to 2003, PBOC data shows.
China has kept its official budget deficit target unchanged at 3 per cent of gross domestic product.

site_title: Tong Lee Building up for collective sale at S$410 million guide price
summary: The Tong Lee Building, a 11,678 sq m freehold industrial property in Kallang, Singapore, is up for collective sale at a guide price of S$410 million. The site is zoned for clean and light industry use and currently houses two multi-storey towers with 189 units. The sale is expected to attract foreign investors, with no additional buyer stamp duty for commercial and industrial properties. The tender will close on May 23, with the land rate at S$769 per square foot per plot ratio.

images.alt_text: Samuel Oh
The facility, on a massive site of 997,330 square feet, is ideally suited for semiconductor, wafer fabrication, and electronics industries.
The freehold property was sold for S$840 psf ppr to a local company, says Savills.
The 8-storey development has been sold for S$81 million and will be use as a food factory, says Edmund Tie.

site_title: Hong Kong has 2,700 single family offices in wealth hub boost
summary: Hong Kong has seen a surge in single family offices, with over 2,700 based in the city, according to a Deloitte survey. These offices manage at least $10 million in assets, with 885 having over $100 million. The city aims to establish 200 large family offices by 2025, following a push to bolster its status as an Asian wealth hub. Hong Kong's assets total $30.5 trillion, and the government plans to launch a new capital investment scheme for those investing at least $30 million.

images.alt_text: Even if ByteDance puts the TikTok app up for sale, the Chinese government is unlikely to allow the company’s most valuable asset, its recommendation algorithm, to be included.
The property industry will remain under pressure due to an abundant supply of homes in both firsthand and secondary markets.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open 2.05% higher as yen slides
summary: Tokyo stocks jumped 2.05% on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising to 39,501.56, driven by a stronger yen and gains in large-cap shares. The Bank of Japan's two-day policy board meeting begins Monday, with speculation of a possible interest rate hike. Despite this, investors expect the central bank to maintain easy monetary conditions to support Japan's fragile growth. Shares in companies like Fast Retailing, Tokyo Electron, and Sony Group also rose, with semiconductor stocks enjoying healthy gains.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, losers outnumber gainers 52 to 36.

site_title: Singapore stocks open flat on Monday after key exports surprise; STI down 0.04%
summary: Singapore stocks opened flat on Monday, March 18, 2024, after data showed non-oil domestic exports fell 0.1% year-on-year in February, missing the 4.7% median growth forecast. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.04% to 3,171.76. Banking stocks were mixed, with DBS gaining 0.2%, while OCBC declined 0.1%. The broader market saw losers outnumber gainers 52 to 36.

images.alt_text: SIA flies 28.2% more passengers in February year-on-year.

site_title: Hong Kong housing rebound starts to cool as weekend sales fall
summary: Hong Kong's home sales are showing signs of slowing down after a rebound triggered by the scrapping of extra property taxes. Last weekend's sales of secondhand apartments at major estates fell 24% to 28 units, down from 37 the previous week. Developers are maintaining low prices for new projects, attracting buyers from the secondary market, and analysts predict prices will rise in the fourth quarter when inventory is absorbed. Existing home prices fell 0.8% in the first week after the government scrapped property curbs. The property industry remains under pressure due to abundant supply and high borrowing costs.

site_title: Asia: Trade cautious ahead of key rate decisions
summary: Asian stocks were mixed on Monday, with Tokyo rising 2.1% and Seoul gaining 0.4%, while Wellington and Sydney fell. The Bank of Japan is set to announce its policy decision on Tuesday, with expectations that it will raise interest rates for the first time since 2007. Despite this, analysts expect the Bank of Japan's governor Kazuo Ueda to provide dovish guidance, tempering market activity. The US Federal Reserve, Reserve Bank of Australia, and Bank of England are also set to make policy decisions this week, with traders cautious ahead of these events.

images.alt_text: The Nikkei 225 index jumped 2.05 per cent or 793.92 points to 39,501.56 in early trade on Monday.
Across the broader market, losers outnumber gainers 52 to 36.

site_title: BOJ rate hike on Tuesday is now widely expected after wages jump
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is expected to raise interest rates for the first time in 17 years after wages jumped, with 90% of analysts predicting a decision. The move comes as the BOJ weighs ending an era of aggressive monetary easing. The BOJ is also considering ending yield curve control and massive asset purchases. The decision is seen as a monumental moment for Japan, which has been navigating a challenging economic environment.

images.alt_text: BOJ officials, including governor Kazuo Ueda, have recently stressed the timing of a shift away from negative rates would depend on the outcome of this year’s annual wage negotiations between workers and employers.
The outlook for monetary policy will define future capital flows after billions of US dollars have poured in over the past year.

Kazuo Ueda, governor of the Bank of Japan (BOJ), during a press conference at Hotel Tivoli after the Group of 20 (G-20) finance ministers and central bank governors meeting in Sao Paulo, Brazil, on Thursday, Feb. 29, 2024. Splits over the conflicts in Gaza and Ukraine prevented Group of 20 finance chiefs from issuing a closing communique after their meetings in Sao Paulo. Photographer: Maira Erlich/Bloomberg

site_title: Malaysia’s February exports down 0.8%, imports up 8.4%
summary: Malaysia's exports declined 0.8% in February to RM111.3 billion, missing a 2.4% growth projection. The decline was due to lower shipments of electronic and petroleum products. The Ministry of Investment, Trade and Industry expects global trade to improve this year, driven by better growth prospects for the US and China.

images.alt_text: Malaysia recorded a trade surplus of RM10.12 billion (S$2.84 billion) in January.
Output from Central America and Africa is seen moderately higher.

site_title: Malaysian bonds beat emerging Asia peers as ringgit bounces back
summary: Malaysia's ringgit has strengthened 0.8% in March, outperforming emerging Asian peers, amid improving exports and stable inflation. The currency's bounce back from a 26-year low is attributed to government and central bank efforts to support it. Local-currency sovereign bonds have returned 1.1% to US dollar-based investors, beating emerging Asian debt as a whole. Economists predict further gains in exports, supporting the nation's positive economic outlook.

images.alt_text: Abdul Rasheed Ghaffour, governor of Bank Negara Malaysia, during a news conference at Sasana Kijang Center, which houses Bank Negara Malaysia facilities, in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Friday, Nov. 17, 2023. Malaysia’s economic growth accelerated in the third quarter as consumer spending along with the services and construction sectors helped counter the impact of faltering exports. Photographer: Annice Lyn/Bloomberg
The ringgit has been the best performer in Asia in the past week.
The ringgit has fallen about 3.7 per cent this year so far and briefly hit a 26-year low last week.

site_title:
Singapore’s healthcare industry moving 
to measure carbon emissions
summary: Singapore is conducting the first assessment of carbon emissions in its healthcare industry, which includes hospitals, polyclinics, and primary care clinics. The study will analyze healthcare operators' expenditure data to estimate their carbon footprint, with the goal of shaping the industry's decarbonization strategy. The sector accounts for 4% of global carbon emissions, more than aviation and shipping. The findings will provide a baseline for measuring progress and help the industry reduce emissions. The study is expected to conclude early next year, with potential benefits including improved patient welfare and quality of care.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Pressure is growing on food companies to make their range of products healthier.
Generic pictures of property landscape in Singapore.

site_title: Gold listless as central bank meetings loom, US dollar holds firm
summary: Gold prices remained steady at US$2,156.69 per ounce as investors awaited central bank policy meetings, including the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision this week. The US dollar held firm near a two-week high, making gold more expensive for other currency holders. Higher interest rates are expected to reduce the appeal of holding non-yielding gold. The Bank of Japan is expected to exit its ultra-dovish monetary policies, while the Bank of England is expected to keep rates unchanged.

images.alt_text: Higher inflation adds pressure on the US Fed to keep interest rates elevated, weighing on non-yielding assets such as gold.

site_title: Binance CEO Teng sees Bitcoin topping US$80,000 on ETF inflows
summary: Binance CEO Richard Teng predicts Bitcoin will surpass US$80,000 due to increasing institutional investor interest in crypto-backed ETFs. The cryptocurrency has surged 56% this year, reaching an all-time high of US$73,798 last week. Teng believes the rally will continue as supply reduces and demand remains strong, despite concerns of a bubble and volatility. He notes the market will experience ups and downs but sees it as beneficial for the market.

site_title: Uber to pay A$272 million to settle lawsuit with Australia taxi drivers, law firm says
summary: Uber has agreed to pay A$271.8 million to settle a lawsuit in Australia brought by taxi operators and drivers who claimed they lost income when Uber entered the country. The lawsuit, filed in 2019, involved over 8,000 taxi and hire car owners and drivers. The proposed settlement resolves "legacy issues" between Uber and the affected parties. Uber had previously fought the lawsuit, but the company has now accepted the outcome, stating that the settlement will "firmly put these legacy issues in our past."

site_title: North Korea fires ballistic missile as Blinken visits Seoul
summary: North Korea fired a ballistic missile towards the East Sea on Monday, as US Secretary of State Antony Blinken visited Seoul for the third Summit for Democracy. The launch comes amid heightened tensions between North Korea and the US-South Korea alliance, following the recent Freedom Shield joint military exercises. The missile test is the North's second this year, and comes as Blinken meets with South Korean officials to discuss boosting deterrence against North Korea's nuclear and missile threats.

images.alt_text:

North Korea has said it now considers the South as an enemy at war and last year scrapped a military pact signed in 2018 aimed at de-escalating tension near the military border drawn up under a truce ending the 1950-53 Korean War.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, Sats, UOL, SingLand, GuocoLand, Dasin Retail Trust
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported a 28.2% increase in passenger traffic in February year-over-year, driven by a 20.7% capacity increase. Sats sold its ground handler unit Maytag Aircraft for $46 million. UOL Group and SingLand sold 74% of units at their jointly developed Watten House project. GuocoLand achieved 75% sales of its high-end residential project Lentor Mansion. Dasin Retail Trust took legal action against its former CEO and creditor.

site_title: BT Future of Finance: Empowering young entrepreneurs for tomorrow (Ep 9)
summary: Paul Kan, country head of Business Banking Singapore at UOB, discusses the challenges faced by young entrepreneurs in the startup landscape. Rising costs and cash flow management are major obstacles, and UOB offers integrated solutions for business efficiency. The bank also supports women entrepreneurs and provides advice for young entrepreneurs. Kan emphasizes the importance of resources and support for budding entrepreneurs to overcome the hurdles of starting a business.

images.alt_text: Christine Ip, head of group strategic communications and brand, UOB, paints a picture of UOB’s long history as a patron of the arts.
Wholesale CBDCs are a more efficient way to make cross border payments, less painless, less cumbersome, more real-time, according to Janet Young from UOB.

site_title: UK property asking prices rise at fastest pace in 10 months
summary: The UK property market has seen a 1.5% increase in asking prices, with the average price rising to £368,118, marking the fastest pace in 10 months. Experts expect a stronger year for the market, driven by lower mortgage rates, which have led to a 0.8% year-on-year increase in prices. Buyer demand is up 8% and sales are 13% higher, indicating a thawing in the market. However, mortgage rates have climbed to 4.84%, potentially limiting the bounce back.

images.alt_text: A pedestrian passes a row of terraced houses in southeast London, U.K., on Thursday, July 21, 2016. London's seven-year housing boom may be about to end after the U.K. voted to leave the European Union. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

A commercial office building in London, UK, on Wednesday, Nov. 22, 2023. A series of rapid interest rate hikes have sent shock waves through European property markets, reducing the prices that buyers are willing to pay as returns on lower risk assets like government bonds rise. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

A British Union flag near residential properties in a suburb of Brighton, UK, on Wednesday, May 31, 2023. UK house prices resumed their decline, with Nationwide Building Society warning that headwinds for property sellers are increasing. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg
Banks and building societies approve 55,227 home loans, up from 51,506 in December, the fourth straight monthly increase.

site_title: ECB could start rate cuts in June: De Cos
summary: The European Central Bank may start cutting interest rates in June, according to ECB policymaker Pablo Hernandez de Cos, following a reduction in eurozone inflation. The ECB has made progress in bringing down inflation and is discussing dialling back monetary tightening. If macroeconomic forecasts are met, rate cuts could begin soon, with June potentially being a good date to start.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view shows the board of the European Central Bank (ECB) building, on the day of the monthly news conference following the ECB's monetary policy meeting in Frankfurt, Germany, September 14, 2023. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo

site_title: General insurance sector grows 10.1% in 2023; domestic motor claims spike
summary: The general insurance sector in Singapore grew 10.1% in 2023, reaching S$10.2 billion in gross written premiums, led by a 7.3% increase in domestic premiums. Motor insurance saw the largest increase in claims, with a 73.3% spike to S$573.4 million, while health insurance reported a significant underwriting loss due to rising healthcare costs. Despite this, the sector still posted an underwriting profit of S$608.1 million.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
The newly issued best practices include cooperation among industry players to mitigate “rolling bad apples” – that is, to prevent individuals with prior misconduct from re-entering the industry.

The General Insurance Association (GIA) says the strong contributions from the health segment is reflective of the general insurance sector’s growing position in providing comprehensive protection through corporate health coverage.

GIA’s proposal is not a viable alternative to the Advisory Committee on Platform Workers' recommendation of requiring platform companies to provide the same scope and level of compensation as employees under the Work Injury Compensation Act (Wica), says Senior Minister of State for Manpower Koh Poh Koon.
Underwriting profit up for general insurance sector
General insurance sector posts underwriting profit of S$262.7m despite more claims paid out

site_title: Oxfam says Israel ‘deliberately’ blocking aid to Gaza
summary: Oxfam accused Israel of "deliberately" blocking aid to Gaza, citing "unjustifiably inefficient" inspection rules causing aid trucks to be stuck in queues for 20 days. This is in violation of international humanitarian law and defies an ICJ order to boost aid in Gaza. Israel is also failing its legal responsibility to protect people in the land it occupies. The charity claims Israel systematically and deliberately blocks any meaningful international humanitarian response in Gaza, hindering efforts to alleviate the humanitarian crisis.

images.alt_text: Rafah is the last major population centre in Gaza yet to be subjected to a ground assault in the war, which was triggered by Hamas’s unprecedented Oct 7 attack on southern Israel.

A military vehicle near the Israel-Gaza border, March 13. Palestinian Islamist group Hamas showed a total disregard for the lives of Palestinians, not just Israelis -- it started the conflict on Oct 7 without any warnings, protections or shelters for Palestinian civilians.

(Centre) Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's comments came one day after US President Joe Biden said Netanyahu “must pay more attention to the innocent lives being lost as a consequence of the actions taken” in Gaza.

site_title: New Keppel Infrastructure Trust CEO wants to have his cake and eat it too
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust's new CEO Kevin Neo aims to balance growth and stability by focusing on increasing the value of existing assets while exploring new investment opportunities. The trust has completed phase one of its German solar portfolio acquisition and is set to acquire a majority stake in Ventura Motors, an Australian bus-service business. Neo seeks resilient assets with stable cash flows, a strong rule of law, and potential for network and sponsor value addition. He aims to maintain a track record of achieving growth while managing investor confidence, which has been impacted by the general weaker macroeconomic environment.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Ventura is said to be the largest bus service business in the State of Victoria in Australia.
KIT's FY2023 revenue sees greater contributions from City Energy.

site_title: BT reporters named Young Journalist and Journalist of the Year at annual SPH Media awards, Events & Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Singapore and the Netherlands identified key growth opportunities in transitioning to a greener and more digital economy, as well as in the circular economy sector. According to Grace Fu, Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry, these sectors offer significant potential for collaboration and growth between the two countries. The partnership aims to drive innovation, create jobs, and promote sustainable development, ultimately strengthening economic ties between Singapore and the Netherlands. This collaboration is expected to boost bilateral trade and investment, while addressing pressing global challenges such as climate change and environmental degradation.

site_title: Boeing’s pain spreads to travellers as airlines cut back on plans
summary: Airlines are cutting back on plans due to Boeing's production delays, exacerbating a shortage of single-aisle jets. United, Southwest, and Ryanair are trimming schedules and looking for alternatives to 737s they've ordered. Boeing's quality issues, including a recent accident, are hindering deliveries. Airlines are also dealing with issues affecting Airbus narrowbodies. The shortage will lead to fewer flight options and potentially higher prices, particularly on domestic and regional routes. Boeing's delivery timeline remains uncertain, with some models expected to return to production in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: An LATAM Airlines 787 plane, which was heading from Sydney to Auckland on Monday, dropped abruptly before stabilising, causing those on board to be thrown about the cabin.

This photograph taken on June 7, 2023, shows an Qatar Airways Airbus A320 aircraft landing at the newly opened runway of Belgrade Nikola Tesla airport. The opening of Belgrade airport's new runway marked the completion of one of the major infrastructure projects undertaken by French operator Vinci, since taking over the concession in late 2018. (Photo by Andrej ISAKOVIC / AFP)
Delays in certifying Boeing’s 737 Max 10 aircraft have jeopardised growth plans at United, which was slated to be the first major customer for the plane.
FILE PHOTO: A worker walks past Boeing's new 737 MAX-9 under construction at their production facility in Renton, Washington, U.S., February 13, 2017. REUTERS/Jason Redmond/File Photo

site_title: ByteDance investors could win in TikTok sale, Republican lawmaker says
summary: Republican lawmakers are pushing for a forced sale of TikTok to remove Chinese corporate influence over the popular social media platform. Representative Mike Gallagher said investors in ByteDance, TikTok's Chinese parent company, could benefit from a sale, citing improved user experience and increased value. The House bill has bipartisan backing, but its fate in the Senate is uncertain, with some senators expressing constitutional reservations about banning the platform. President Joe Biden has expressed willingness to sign the bill, but the National Security Council has stated it does not want to see TikTok banned.

images.alt_text: Even if ByteDance puts the TikTok app up for sale, the Chinese government is unlikely to allow the company’s most valuable asset, its recommendation algorithm, to be included.
FILE PHOTO: The TikTok office building is shown in Culver City, California, U.S., April 26, 2023. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo
The two teams Tencent has acquired involve one Shenzhen-based studio working on an action game and another East-China-based studio working on an anime game.

site_title: Australia set to extend rate pause as economy enters slow lane
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), is expected to hold interest rates at a 12-year high of 4.35% for a third consecutive meeting, amid signs of a slowing economy and rising unemployment. Economists predict the decision will maintain a hawkish bias, citing inflation concerns and a hot property market. The RBA is also expected to be mindful of global inflationary trends, particularly in the US, which has seen price pressures abate only gradually.

images.alt_text: “Dialogue leads to understanding and it leads to benefit for both of our nations. Australia will benefit from the economic activity that removal of these impediments will bring,” says Australia Prime Minister Anthony Albanese.
Australia banned TikTok from government devices in April 2023.
Weaker commodity prices, in particular for major export iron ore, and rising unemployment were behind the change, Treasurer Jim Chalmers says.

site_title: Venture Global buys LNG shipping fleet to market fuel worldwide
summary: Venture Global LNG, a US liquefied natural gas exporter, has acquired a fleet of nine South Korean-built ships to expand its sales operations and sell cargoes directly into the spot market. The company will add 50-100 staff to manage the fleet and expects to deliver the first two ships this year. Venture Global aims to boost profits and gain a competitive edge over competitors. The move follows a dispute with customers, including Shell, who have accused the company of selling profitable spot cargoes while dodging contracted obligations.

images.alt_text: A LNG tanker is seen at the Negishi LNG Terminal, which is jointly operated by Tokyo Gas and JERA, in Yokohama, Japan, Oct 17, 2019. LNG accounts for about a third of Japan’s power generation and it is the world’s second-largest importer behind China.
FILE PHOTO: Model of natural gas pipeline and rising stock graph, July 18, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Last week, Asia spot LNG prices hit their lowest levels in nearly three years as weak demand in Asia and Europe weighed on the market.

site_title: China police takes ‘coercive measures’ against staff at Zhongzhi
summary: Chinese police have taken "criminal coercive measures" against staff at Zhongzhi Enterprise Group, a money management business, following the bankruptcy filing in January. The recovery of "stolen goods" is underway, with executives and staff urged to cooperate and return gains. The move comes after Beijing police opened an investigation in November and identified a suspect, Xie Zhikun's relative, as an executive at the company. The action is part of China's efforts to limit the impact of Zhongzhi's bankruptcy on financial markets.

site_title: UCars lays off staff, replaces CEO after being served legal notice for debts
summary: UCars, a car portal that started in mid-2019, is facing an uncertain future after being served a notice of demand by its holding company, 21 United Holdings, to repay over S$400,000. The notice was served in January 2024 and UCars is verifying the amount before working out a repayment schedule. The company has also laid off more than 20 staff members over the last 12 months. Additionally, UCars has replaced its CEO following the legal notice.

images.alt_text: TreeDots founder Tyler Jong (left) says only 13 out of over 200 employees were dismissed.

site_title: Nato chief says climate change undermines global security
summary: NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg emphasized the need to combat climate change, calling it a "crisis multiplier" with implications for global security. He praised Azerbaijan for its efforts in transitioning to renewable energy and hosting the COP29 UN Climate Change Conference in November. However, the decision to hold the conference in an oil-producing country has been criticized by environmental groups. Stoltenberg acknowledged the need to reconcile energy needs with environmental concerns, stating that "climate change matters for security, matters for NATO."

images.alt_text: It is important that Singapore takes stock of the entire country’s emissions, said Prof Watts (pictured).
Some companies may see climate reporting merely as a compliance burden, with little incentive to do better.

AI development, with its high energy demands, faces a challenge. Companies involved in AI research and development must reconcile their pursuit of innovation with the need to maintain a favourable ESG score.
Absence of ice impacts everything from businesses that rely on outdoor sports, to fish that use ice to protect themselves from predators during spawning season.

site_title: Transition finance critical for South-east Asia to achieve net-zero goals: panel
summary: South-east Asia has the potential to lead the global effort to achieve net-zero emissions, but it faces a significant challenge in raising capital, estimated at over US$50 billion, to fund the green transition. Experts stress the need for "transition finance" to help businesses in the region, many of which are still reliant on fossil fuels, make the switch to clean energy. Industry leaders emphasize the importance of aligning green goals with profitability and commercial viability, and highlight the growing interest in ESG funds and green bonds in the region.

images.alt_text: Vehicles prepare land for new solar panels next to a field of solar panels during construction in China’s northern Ningxia region on Dec 9, 2023.

site_title: Singapore key exports surprise with 0.1% fall in February despite electronics growth
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) fell 0.1% in February, defying economists' 4.7% median growth forecast. The decline was largely due to a decrease in the non-electronics sector, while electronics growth offset the decline. Base effects from Chinese New Year also contributed to the decline, as the holiday fell in February this year, compared to January in 2023. The February decline reverses the 16.7% expansion in the previous month.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Generic photo of Pasir Panjang terminal pictured on Dec 26, 2023. Port, container, maritime, industry, economy, import, export, supply chain,

Simulations by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) have showed that even if the nominal exchange rate had not been raised, the Singapore dollar would still have appreciated similarly in real terms, chief economist Edward Robinson said.

site_title: Reddit’s IPO as much as five times oversubscribed, sources say
summary: Reddit's initial public offering (IPO) is between four and five times oversubscribed, according to sources, making it likely to reach its target valuation of US$6.5 billion. The company has reserved 8% of shares for eligible users, moderators, and certain board members to tap retail investors. The oversubscription does not guarantee a strong performance in the stock market debut, but it suggests the company is poised to meet its targeted price range of US$31 to US$34 per share. The IPO is set to price in New York on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: Reddit plans for its shares to trade on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol RDDT.
Reddit says that it and its investors are planning to sell 22 million shares for US$31 to US$34 each.
The restive atmosphere on r/wallstreetbets and elsewhere on Reddit showcases what happens when a price tag is put on something that did not explicitly have one before.
The company plans for its shares to trade on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol RDDT.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for March 15, 2024, highlights a turbulent week in the tanker and dry bulk market. Suezmax rates in West Africa dropped to WS102.41, while capesize rates in the Pacific saw a slight increase before a significant drop due to increased competition and a pessimistic FFA market. Panamax rates improved as a strong push from South and North America led the drive. Ultramax and Supramax rates saw a slight decrease, but the Atlantic side showed more positivity. Clean freight rates, including LR2 and MR, surged, with LR2 freight levels resurging and MR freight improving in the MEG. The market for Handymax and VLCC also saw significant increases. LNG rates remained relatively flat, with some tentative enquiries and a stable tonnage list. The LPG market made a miraculous turnaround, with rates fixed not seen since early January.

site_title: Localisation and niche markets: How Singapore’s AI startups can stay competitive
summary: Singapore's AI startups can compete with larger international players by focusing on niche markets and localizing AI applications, said industry players. Localizing large language models and computer vision for higher accuracy can give Singaporean startups an edge. Unlike big companies like Microsoft and Google, which serve a large user base, Singaporean startups can "dominate certain verticals" and create more accurate solutions with local data sets. This localization advantage can help Singaporean startups stay competitive in the AI market.

images.alt_text: Daphne Yow
Singapore had more than 800 AI startups in 2021, the latest year for which Enterprise Singapore has data, with the number having grown at a compounded 18 per cent a year since 2018.

Recent breakthroughs in generative AI have sparked renewed interest about the potential of AI, its risks and its implications for humanity, said Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong at the Singapore Conference on AI, which runs from Dec 4 to 6.
A new initiative named the Future Energy Fund will receive an initial injection of S$5 billion to build critical infrastructure and improve energy security.

site_title: Sats sells US military contractor unit Maytag Aircraft for US$46 million
summary: SATS has sold its US military contractor unit Maytag Aircraft for US$46 million to private investment firm Albion River. The sale is part of Sats' strategy to streamline operations and improve financial performance. Maytag provides services to the US Department of Defense and operates on a standalone basis. The sale will not impact Sats' core businesses, and the company will book a gain on disposal of approximately S$1.6 million.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
The Chinese New Year holiday season has boosted SIA's passenger demand in February.
The group records performance improvements among its business units and a seasonally stronger quarter for cargo, it says in its business update.

site_title: Starbucks drops executive pay package tied to inclusion goals amid conservative pressure
summary: Starbucks has dropped its executive pay package tied to diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) goals amid conservative pressure. The company replaced the specific goal with a more general workforce target, shifting 7.5% of bonuses to a broader metric, while increasing financial performance incentives to 75% of bonuses. The change was approved by 92% of shareholders, and Starbucks will continue to prioritize equality, social, and governance goals as part of its longer-term incentive program.

images.alt_text: Bain & Company surveyed more than 600 executives in oil and gas, utilities, chemicals, mining, and agribusiness during the 2023 United Nations Climate Change Conference in Dubai and the weeks after.

site_title: TSMC considering advanced chip packaging capacity in Japan, sources say
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) is considering expanding its advanced chip packaging capacity in Japan, according to sources. The company is exploring bringing its CoWoS (chip on wafer on substrate) packaging technology to Japan, which would boost processing power while saving space and reducing power consumption. This move would add momentum to Japan's efforts to reboot its semiconductor industry, which has been boosted by the artificial intelligence boom. TSMC has already established an advanced packaging research and development centre in Japan and is partnering with companies including Sony and Toyota, with a total investment expected to exceed $20 billion.

images.alt_text: TSMC’s shares have surged more than 110 per cent from an October 2022 low.
The pending announcement only represents a preliminary agreement that could still change, and no final decision has been made.
South Korea's transformation from economic minnow to industrial giant owes much to its sprawling, family-run conglomerates known as chaebols.

TSMC’s board on Thursday (Feb 29) approves the appointment of YJ Mii and YP Chyn as executive vice-presidents and co-chief operating officers.
