Because semiconductor chios are so difficult and costly to produce, there’s a worldwide reliance on just a handful of companies, a dependence that was brought into stark relief by shortages during the pandemic.
More Taiwanese chip sector firms are also looking at increasing their presence or making their first foray into Japan.

site_title: Putin gets record Russia election win to push war in Ukraine
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin secured a record 87.4% of the vote in his re-election, extending his nearly quarter-century rule. The election outcome is seen as a pre-determined result, with Putin's allies claiming high public support. The Kremlin is now expected to step up its war in Ukraine, with Putin dismissing prospects for a halt to the conflict. The election outcome has been criticized as a result of "electoral manipulation and fraud," and has emboldened Putin for a long confrontation with the West.

images.alt_text: An apartment building in Kupiansk, Kharkiv region, damaged by a Russian air strike; March 12, 2024. t makes little sense to protect Russian property when Russia itself is flagrantly destroying Ukraine.
Gas leaks from a damaged Nord Stream pipeline in the Baltic Sea in 2022.
Russian company Automotive Technologies is assembling the Citroen C5 Aircross at the Kaluga factory, according to two employees at different Russian car dealerships.

site_title: Australia to miss 2030 climate goal by couple years, Oxford says
summary: Australia is likely to miss its 2030 climate target, with carbon emissions not decreasing at a sufficient rate. Oxford Economics analysis suggests the country's emissions will not drop to 43% below 2005 levels by 2030, instead falling short by a couple of years. The delay is attributed to the slower-than-expected rollout of renewable energy, as well as the need for decades to electrify the vehicle fleet and decarbonize hard-to-abate industrial sectors.

images.alt_text: Australia’s labour market is also showing signs of loosening, although with the unemployment rate at 4.1 per cent, it is still healthy.

“Dialogue leads to understanding and it leads to benefit for both of our nations. Australia will benefit from the economic activity that removal of these impediments will bring,” says Australia Prime Minister Anthony Albanese.
Weaker commodity prices, in particular for major export iron ore, and rising unemployment were behind the change, Treasurer Jim Chalmers says.

site_title: The ‘everything rally’ comes to derivatives market
summary: The derivatives market has seen a surge in optimism, with credit investors buying up large amounts of new debt, pushing down the cost of protection against defaults. This trend is driven by bond fund managers using credit derivatives indexes to gain exposure, with some institutions seeking to put more money to work than available bonds. The recent "roll" of credit default swap contracts at the end of March is expected to boost the credit derivatives index market and lead to outperformance.

images.alt_text: The US system is highly responsive to democratic, political and often populist demands. SVB arguably got into so much trouble in part because in 2018, lobbying efforts by smaller banks allowed them to escape the tougher rules created only a few years earlier – with bipartisan support.

site_title: Singapore's Patience Capital Group to reopen fund for luxury Japan ski resort as weak yen beckons
summary: Patience Capital Group, a Singapore-based investor, is reopening its fund to invest in Japan's luxury ski resort, Myoko Kogen, which aims to transform the area into a winter sports destination comparable to Aspen and Whistler. The fund, initially set at 35 billion yen, may grow to 60 billion yen, driven by a weak yen that makes Japan a bargain for foreigners. The reopening comes as the Bank of Japan is expected to begin normalizing monetary policy, potentially driving the yen up.

images.alt_text: The Langkawi archipelago, one of Malaysia’s best-known holiday destinations, is also a popular choice among retired expatriates.

site_title: HSI hinting at potential turnaround
summary: The Hang Seng Index (HSI) experienced a significant turnaround in January 2024, reversing a prolonged decline attributed to technology clampdowns, economic contraction, and property developer defaults. The Chinese Communist Party's Politburo orchestrated a series of strategic interventions, including mobilizing a national team to inject capital into the market and directing Shanghai-listed firms to initiate share buybacks. These measures resulted in a notable resurgence, with the HSI surging 10.77% by March 4, 2024, and reaching a peak of 12.94% in 2024 Q1.

images.alt_text: A breach of its 1989 peak by the Mini Topix Futures contract is likely to have a huge psychological impact on investors that could take it even higher.

site_title: Japan CEOs see higher prices, wages with BOJ move ‘just a matter of time’
summary: Japan's CEOs are preparing for the first rate hike since 2007, with the Bank of Japan (BOJ) expected to end its negative interest rate policy soon. Inflation nears the BOJ's 2% target, driven by higher energy and raw material prices, and a tight labor market. Companies are expecting higher prices and wages, with unions securing their biggest wage hikes in decades. A slight majority of central bank watchers predict the end of negative rates in April, and some companies are already raising prices and cutting staff to prepare for a potential rate hike.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan will likely make a final decision on whether to pull the trigger next week, or hold off until April, after scrutinising a preliminary survey of big firms’ wage talk outcome to be released by labour umbrella Rengo later on Friday.

Speaking in parliament on Tuesday,  Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda said consumption was weakening for food and daily necessities amid higher prices. He said household spending was improving moderately on hopes for higher wages ahead.
On a quarter-on-quarter basis, Japan's GDP grew 0.1 per cent, compared with the initial 0.1 per cent drop reading and a median forecast for a 0.3 per cent rise.

site_title: Voluntary carbon markets are making progress – even if official ones aren’t
summary: The voluntary carbon market is making progress despite the lack of official adoption of rules and infrastructure at COP28. The private sector has established voluntary carbon market infrastructure, and over the next year, corporate participation is expected to increase as confidence in the market's integrity and efficacy grows. Key developments include an end-to-end integrity framework, standardized methodologies, and increased regulatory clarity. Countries like Singapore and the US are also implementing carbon markets and regulations to support climate action.

images.alt_text: Carbon removals seek to suck carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere and store it – ideally permanently underground or in the ocean.
East Kalimantan to protect forests and wildlife such as the orangutan.

site_title: Talent shortage a hurdle for Singapore’s AI startups as demand spreads across industries
summary: Singapore's AI startup industry faces a talent shortage as demand for AI talent spreads across industries. With over 800 AI startups in 2021, the industry has grown at a compounded 18% a year since 2018. However, hiring competition comes from both other startups and established companies incorporating AI into their businesses. To address the shortage, the government has allocated S$27 million for talent development programs, aiming to treble the local talent pool to 15,000 over five years. Startups are struggling to attract talent with lower resources, and the types of talent required are evolving, including ethics specialists and cross-trained employees.

images.alt_text: Daphne Yow
Some AI applications, such as large language models and computer vision, have to be localised for higher accuracy, say industry players.
A new initiative named the Future Energy Fund will receive an initial injection of S$5 billion to build critical infrastructure and improve energy security.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust trustee-manager files suit against former CEO, creditor
summary: Dasin Retail Trust Management, trustee-manager of China retail property trust Dasin Retail Trust, has filed a lawsuit against former CEO Wang Qiu and creditor Zhang Guiming. Wang claims $449,600 in owed salary, payments, and loan repayment, while DRTM contests these claims. A case conference is scheduled for April 24. The High Court has stayed winding-up applications against the trustee-manager pending the outcome of the disputes.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Ocean Metro Mall is one of the properties in  Dasin Retail Trust’s portfolio.

Wang Qiu's application came less than a week after Zhang Guiming, the nephew of Zhang Zhencheng, a non-executive director on the trust’s board, filed a similar winding-up application against the trustee-manager.
The trustee-manager is seeking legal advice over the letter, it says.

site_title: Israel PM says army will go into Gaza's Rafah despite international 'pressure'
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced that Israeli troops will proceed with a planned ground offensive in Rafah, Gaza, despite international pressure, stating that no amount of pressure will stop the war's goals of eliminating Hamas, releasing hostages, and ensuring Gaza's safety. The move has sparked fears of mass civilian casualties, with US President Joe Biden warning of a "red line" without credible civilian protection plans. The UN's World Health Organisation has also appealed to Israel not to launch an assault on Rafah.

images.alt_text: (Centre) Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's comments came one day after US President Joe Biden said Netanyahu “must pay more attention to the innocent lives being lost as a consequence of the actions taken” in Gaza.

site_title: What’s the H100, the chip driving generative AI?
summary: Nvidia's H100 chip is a data centre chip that is four times faster than its predecessor at training large language models and 30 times faster at replying to user prompts. The H100's performance edge can be critical for companies racing to train their language models. Nvidia controls 80% of the market for accelerators in AI data centres, and its rapid updates have outpaced competitors like AMD and Intel. The demand for the H100 is so great that customers are waiting up to six months to receive it, driving Nvidia's revenue to a 41% increase to $15 billion in 2022.

images.alt_text: The blistering rate of Nvidia’s gains – an increase of about 290 per cent over the past 12 months – has many Wall Street analysts wondering how sustainable the run is.

site_title: At sombre Cannes event, real estate elite look for hope amid gloom
summary: Europe's real estate market is showing signs of recovery, with some investors and analysts predicting a supply shortage and potential price increases. Despite a slump in construction and a rise in borrowing costs, the conference in Cannes saw optimism among dealmakers, with some believing that slower construction can lead to a market revival. Goldman Sachs predicts commercial real estate valuations are near a bottom, while Blackstone president Jon Gray sees buying real estate as a good opportunity. However, concerns remain about the impact of interest-rate cuts and the uncertainty surrounding property values in Germany.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The site in central Munich of a project planned by Euroboden, a property developer that has filed for insolvency, in Munich, Germany, August 29, 2023.     REUTERS/Tom Sims/File Photo
Policymakers have increased pressure on banks to boost their property loans through so-called white lists, as developers struggle to complete projects.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Are luxury watches a viable investment? (Ep 165)
summary: Luxury watches are a popular investment option among wealthy Singaporeans, but their value can be unpredictable. In a podcast, director of Chuan Watch, Nick Lim, discusses the pros and cons of watches as investments, including factors that influence their price, such as brand reputation, materials, and rarity. The Covid-19 pandemic led to a luxury watch boom, but recent auction sales have seen a decline, with some watches experiencing significant depreciation. Experts emphasize that watches should be evaluated based on their condition, rarity, and demand before investing.

images.alt_text: Total watch sales at the top auction houses fell 13 per cent to 610 million Swiss francs (S$926.7 million) in 2023 from record levels hit in 2022.
Linda Neo started collecting art as a means of sharing a common interest with her husband, Albert Lim.

site_title: Don’t bet on that marketing degree, Gen Z
summary: A new study from the Burning Glass Institute and Strada Education Foundation found that nearly six out of 10 marketing students in the US are working high school-level jobs five years after graduation. The glut of marketing graduates, coupled with the rise of artificial intelligence, has made it difficult for them to find employment. Many marketing majors now require additional technical skills, and some companies are prioritizing accounting and finance over marketing. This has led to frustration among recent graduates, with some considering going back to school for a master's degree to improve their job prospects.

images.alt_text: The widespread adoption of working from home, the use of new technologies and the increase in flexibility have profoundly transformed the way we work.

site_title: Collective siesta in Mexico City aims to promote the right to sleep
summary: In Mexico City, about 200 people participated in a collective siesta on March 15 to promote the right to sleep, as part of World Sleep Day. Organised by the Center for Sleep and Neuroscience, the event aimed to raise awareness about the importance of rest and potentially launch new public policies. Participants, including a doctor and a psychotherapist, slept or relaxed on synthetic mats, with some achieving deep sleep. The event highlighted the need for workplaces to provide spaces for siestas, with participants seeking advice on improving their sleep habits.

images.alt_text: People enjoy a nap while attending the World Sleep Day event at the Monumento a la Revolución in Mexico City, Mexico, on March 15, 2024. (Photo by Rodrigo Oropeza / AFP)
A study has found that workers who participate in wellness programmes provided by their employers are no better off than colleagues whose employers do not provide such programmes.

site_title: Stressed at work? Your office phone booth could tell your boss
summary: Finland's Framery, a leading seller of phone booth-like privacy pods, is testing sensors that track employees' vital signs to detect stress levels. The technology, embedded in the booths' seats, measures heart and breathing rates to provide early warnings of organizational stress. However, experts raise concerns about collecting medical information without consent and potential health-privacy laws violations. Framery's CEO is cautious, citing the need to address these concerns before rolling out the service to customers, amid growing legislation and regulatory hurdles.

images.alt_text: The office is a place to form professional networks and communities.

site_title: Winning the game of boardroom chess
summary: A study by Michael Jarrett, Andy J Yap, and Curtis LeBaron found that subtle actions in a corporate setting can shift the balance of power in favor of an individual. The researchers identified four key actions to gain and maintain power: (1) reading the room to anticipate dynamics and respond accordingly, (2) gaining attention by strategically positioning oneself and using body language, (3) picking the right moment to make a move, and (4) using objects to direct attention and convey messages. These tactics can be used by anyone, regardless of their position, to influence power dynamics and achieve successful outcomes.

images.alt_text: While it is true that individuals “hold” symbolic positions of authority, for organisations to flourish, the distance between authority figures and those executing important work needs to be greatly reduced.

site_title: Boosting data quality: How to make a plan for storage, usage and governance
summary: Businesses face significant challenges in managing their data, with up to 80% of an organization's data being offline or in a silo. Poor data governance can cost organizations an average of $12.9 million per year. To improve data governance, businesses must create a plan for data storage, usage, and governance, including data integration, access controls, and a centralized location. By doing so, organizations can unlock the true potential of their data, improve decision-making, and increase revenue. Effective data governance is a competitive advantage, and education and data literacy are key to maintaining data quality and security.

The next wave of network using Optical Fibre Patch cord.

Small companies are particularly attractive to hackers as they often have inadequate cybersecurity, making them easier targets.

site_title: GuocoLand’s Lentor Mansion achieves 75% sales at launch; prices from S$2,104 psf to S$2,478 psf
summary: GuocoLand's Lentor Mansion achieved 75% sales at launch, with 400 out of 533 units sold over the weekend. Prices ranged from S$1.149 million for a 527 sq ft two-bedroom unit to S$3.512 million for a 1,507 sq ft five-bedroom unit. The most popular layout was the two-bedroom unit, with 214 units sold, and 75% of units sold priced below S$2 million. The development is the first under the Urban Redevelopment Authority's new guidelines, which base unit sales on liveable space.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
The 99-year leasehold Lentor Mansion sits on 235,371.2 square feet of land, and will house 533 units across six blocks.

site_title: Palm islands developer Nakheel to merge with Meydan under Dubai Holding
summary: Dubai Holding, under the direction of Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum, has ordered the merger of real estate developers Nakheel and Meydan. The merged entity will aim to create a financially efficient entity owning assets worth hundreds of billions and comprising global expertise across various sectors. Nakheel, which was taken over by the government in 2011, has secured new financing for waterfront projects, while Meydan is a major developer of hospitality and entertainment facilities in Dubai. The merger is expected to enhance the group's capabilities and competitiveness in the market.

site_title: SGX listcos eke out 0.4% higher quarterly profits in Q4; analysts generally positive for 2024
summary: SGX-listed companies reported a 0.4% increase in quarterly profits, with 38 companies profitable and 26 in the red. Local lenders OCBC and UOB saw record profits, driven by higher interest rates, while DBS dipped 3% due to one-time costs. Aviation-related counters, such as Singapore Airlines and Sats, benefited from air travel recovery. Analysts expect banks to remain resilient despite macroeconomic risks, while IHH Healthcare's earnings soared due to strong operational performance. S-Reits saw mixed results, with most posting year-on-year declines in distributions, but analysts expect operational strength in 2024.

site_title: Employees seek flexibility in Singapore even as employers resist remote work
summary: Singaporean employees are seeking flexibility in hybrid work arrangements, with those working remotely or in a hybrid environment reporting higher job satisfaction. Conversely, employees required to work on-site are more likely to be job hunting. This trend is attributed to the remote rewind, exacerbated by challenging economic times and companies focusing on increasing productivity. Many Singaporeans are resistant to returning to the office, prompting employers to reevaluate their work policies to retain talent.

site_title: City Developments should explain how it will manage its buybacks as it grows its business
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) initiated a share buyback programme after its stock price tumbled below S$6.00, citing confidence in its strong fundamentals and growth potential. The programme allows CDL to buy 10% of its outstanding shares, equivalent to over 90 million shares. The move may pose a dilemma for the company, as it may choose to use divestment proceeds to repurchase depressed shares or acquire new assets.

City Developments will buy back 33.1 million of its preference shares at S$0.78 apiece on Dec 1.
City Developments Limited (CDL) headquarters along Robinson Road.

site_title: US dollar poised for biggest weekly gain since mid-January
summary: The US dollar is poised for its largest weekly gain since mid-January, with a 0.7% increase, according to the dollar index. This follows mixed data on the US economy, which showed a stable but weak sector, suggesting the Federal Reserve may keep interest rates higher or reduce planned rate cuts this year. A solid US manufacturing sector rebounded 0.8% in February, but analysts attribute the improvement to revisions and a reversal of weather-related factors.

images.alt_text: The greenback is on pace for its worst weekly showing against the euro this year.

site_title: Companies should be aggressive in going abroad despite global uncertainty: EnterpriseSG chairman
summary: Enterprise Singapore's outgoing chairman Peter Ong emphasizes the importance of Singapore companies going abroad for growth despite global uncertainty and deglobalization. He encourages companies to be aggressive in internationalization, citing the agency's support in helping companies pursue productivity, innovation, and internationalization. Ong highlights the success of the Scale-Up program and the Global Innovation Alliance, and introduces two new strategies: the Singapore Global Enterprises initiative and industry cluster development. He also stresses the importance of supporting small businesses, particularly those willing to upgrade and transform, and notes that the agency will continue to provide grants and funding to help companies grow.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Enterprise Singapore chief executive Lee Chuan Teck said the statutory board hopes revenue generated from its projects will reach pre-pandemic levels soon.
Lee Chuan Teck, current chief executive of EnterpriseSG, will take on the role of executive chairman from Apr 1.

EnterpriseSG chairman Peter Ong (centre) led a delegation to Kenya in March 2023. Also present are G Jayakrishnan (fourth from left), EnterpriseSG’s executive director for South Asia, Middle East and Africa; and Peter Munga (fourth from right), founder of Kenya-based bank Equity Group Holdings.

site_title: Copper surges on supply threat as iron ore shows economic risks
summary: Copper prices surged above $9,000 a tonne as supply cuts and disruptions in China's smelters led to a sharp drop in processing fees. This, combined with growing optimism about copper usage in electric vehicles and renewables, drove the rally. Meanwhile, iron ore futures fell below $100 a tonne for the first time in seven months, as investors bet on a continued slowdown in China's economy. The divergence in prices highlights the diverging economic risks, with copper seen as a more resilient commodity due to its increasing use in EVs and renewables.

images.alt_text: Ambassador Cong Peiwu says China’s investments provide much-needed funding to those firms at a time when metals have become an essential ingredient to the global transition away from fossil fuels.

site_title: UOL, SingLand sell 31 more Watten House units at public launch; project now 74% sold
summary: UOL Group and Singapore Land Group have sold 133 units of 180 units at Watten House, accounting for 74% of the project's total units. The sold units fetched an average price of S$3,250 per square foot, with the eight exclusive penthouses selling for between S$11.7 million to S$14.5 million. The majority of buyers, 95%, are Singaporean and permanent residents, while the remaining 5% are foreign buyers. The project now has 47 units remaining for sale.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

site_title: Americans invested billions in Chinese companies. Now their money is stuck
summary: US investors with billions of dollars in Chinese tech companies, including ByteDance and TikTok, face significant challenges in recouping their investments due to the Chinese government's export control rules and the companies' geopolitical entanglements. Even if ByteDance sells the TikTok app, the algorithm will likely remain off-limits. Chinese companies are also struggling to list on US exchanges, and investors are waiting for a more favorable environment to exit their investments. With China's slowing economy and depressed company valuations, investors are stuck, with some considering alternative routes to liquidity, such as borrowing or waiting for improved relations between China and the US.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The TikTok office building is shown in Culver City, California, U.S., April 26, 2023. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

site_title: Darwin’s Galapagos island species, protected yet still at risk
summary: The Galapagos Marine Reserve, a 200,000 sq km protected area off Ecuador's coast, is home to over 3,000 species, many found nowhere else. However, outside its boundaries, these species are vulnerable to industrial fishing and bycatch. To protect them, Greenpeace proposes creating a larger marine protected area on the high seas bordering the reserve, which would require at least 60 countries to ratify the High Seas Treaty. Currently, only two countries have done so, and scientists are working to connect the reserve with other protected areas to ensure species migration routes are safe.

images.alt_text: Data from luxury travel adviser network Virtuoso points to a spike in nature-based travel, including scientific expeditions to the Galapagos.

site_title: Tesla to raise US prices for Model Y vehicles by US$1,000 on Apr 1
summary: Tesla will increase prices for all Model Y cars in the US by $1,000 on April 1, following a $1,000 price hike on March 1 for rear-wheel drive and long-range vehicles. The company attributed the price increase to the need for continuous production efficiency. This comes after Tesla temporarily cut prices of some Model Y cars in the US in February. The price adjustment will apply to all Model Y trims in the US market.

site_title: If Nvidia keeps rising like this, it will be bigger than the global economy
summary: Nvidia's stock has surged 290% in the past 12 months, valuing the company at over $2.2 trillion, making it the third-largest public company in the world. Analysts are questioning the sustainability of this growth, with some AI chatbots warning that Nvidia's market value could reach quadrillions of dollars in a decade, dwarfing the global economy. However, traditional valuation measures also indicate that the company's share price is high and may eventually correct. The author advises against buying individual stocks, instead recommending broad low-cost index funds as a more stable investment option.

images.alt_text: Nvidia is the top gainer among Nasdaq 100 Index components this year, just as it was in 2023.

site_title: Venture capital: Lessons from the dot-com days
summary: Venture capital firms are adopting a market strategy similar to the dot-com era, focusing on launching innovative business ideas and rapidly growing top-line revenue while incurring significant losses. This approach relies on almost unlimited access to financing. The strategy is exemplified by unicorns such as Theranos and FTX, which experienced significant losses despite exponential growth.

images.alt_text: Investors are now mulling over how to sell their stakes in the unicorns of yesteryear.
Even with exits constrained, investors want to allocate more money because the returns justify it. That demand may be also be higher than it appears.
Because most credit deals in recent years applied floating rates, should the cost of credit remain high, zombie scenarios, Chapter 11 filings, and hostile takeovers by lenders could spike.
FILE PHOTO: A man walks past a Reliance Industries Limited sign board installed on a road divider in the western Indian city of Gandhinagar, January 17, 2014. REUTERS/Amit Dave/File Photo

site_title: Raffles Medical executive chair continues acquisitions, CDL leads buyback consideration
summary: Raffles Medical Group executive chairman Loo Choon Yong acquired 2.7 million shares between Mar 7 and 13, increasing his stake to 53.76%. CityDev conducted its first ordinary share buyback since October 2018, purchasing 4,167,400 shares at S$5.92. Institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks, with S$156 million of net institutional outflow. Digital Core Reit Management continued to buy back units of Digital Core Reit, while iFast Corp's non-executive director Lim Wee Kian acquired 25,000 shares. Other companies, including Boustead Singapore, LHT Holdings, JB Foods, and Intraco, also made acquisitions.

images.alt_text: Digital Core Reit’s data centre in Northern Virginia. Digital Core Reit Management continued to buy back units of Digital Core Reit over the week

site_title: In Chile, a lawyer and his dog ‘plog’ to raise recycling awareness
summary: A Chilean lawyer, Gonzalo Chiang, and his border collie, Sam, have been "plogging" – picking up garbage while jogging – for two years to raise recycling awareness in Chile, where recycling rates are low. Chiang has collected over 27,000 items and aims to demonstrate the impact of individual action. His efforts have gained popularity, with Sam being named the "superhero of the Parquemet" park in Santiago. Chiang's initiative aims to promote a zero-waste future and encourage others to join him in making a difference.

images.alt_text: Climate activists hold up a sign in Swedish  "Deadly fashion or living planet?" outside a H&M store in Stockholm, Sweden, Jan 31, 2024.

site_title: Hertz’s CEO to step down as car renter unwinds bet on EVs
summary: Hertz Global is replacing its CEO, Stephen Scherr, following a disastrous bet on electric vehicles that the company began unwinding in recent months. Scherr, who ran Hertz for over two years, will step down and be replaced by Gil West, the former chief operating officer of General Motors' Cruise unit. The move comes after Hertz announced plans to sell down its electric vehicle inventory due to lacklustre demand, costly depreciation, and expensive repairs. The change in leadership is part of Hertz's efforts to adapt to the changing automotive landscape.

images.alt_text: Apple exiting the EV market before it really revved up underscores just how tough the business has become.

site_title: The big number: US$40 billion
summary: Dating apps like Tinder have lost nearly US$40 billion in market value since 2021 due to declining user base and revenue. Millennials, who were the initial prime users, have since married and left the platforms. Gen Z users, who make up the primary user base, prefer finding love on social media platforms like TikTok and Snapchat, rather than paying for dating app subscriptions. This shift in user behavior has led to the decline of the dating app industry.

images.alt_text: A  2022 Swedish study showed that Tinder applied 36 different price levels, charging some users the equivalent of US$3 a month while others were asked to pay as much as US$36 per month.
Dating apps have increasingly undertaken the vetting and vouching that well-meaning mutual acquaintances used to shoulder.

site_title: Call it home; Bring it home
summary: The Malaysia My Second Home (MM2H) visa scheme, allowing non-Malaysians to retire, is on hold due to parliamentary approval issues, potentially dampening interest. Indonesia aims to collaborate with Singapore to host world-class events, including sports and cultural events, to boost tourism. The Philippines secured $5 billion in investment pledges from Germany and the US, targeting emerging sectors like healthcare and digital infrastructure. Meanwhile, Cambodia is set to open its new Techo International Airport, the world's 9th-largest airport, in 2025.

images.alt_text: Zhao Yifan
Defence Minister Prabowo Subianto celebrates on stage as unofficial vote counts show that he is poised to become Indonesia's next president.
Delegates convened at the fourth Asean Digital Senior Officials Meeting in Singapore on Jan 30 in preparation for the Feb 1-2 Asean Digital Ministers Meeting.
Indonesian President Joko Widodo paid a visit to VinFast manufacturing complex in Hai Phong on Jan 13, 2024.

site_title: Who still works from home?
summary: The US workplace has largely adopted a hybrid-work model, with roughly 1 in 10 workers combining in-office and remote work, and a similar portion working entirely remotely. This shift reflects the US' racial inequalities, with the divide in remote work flexibility mirroring existing racial disparities. The transition to a hybrid-work reality has been gradual, with periods of tension between workers and executives over return-to-office policies, which have largely subsided.

images.alt_text: Shoppers carry Uniqlo bags in the SoHo neighborhood of New York, US, on Friday, March 8, 2024. The US Census Bureau is scheduled to release retail sales figures on March 14. Photographer: John Taggart/Bloomberg
The office is a place to form professional networks and communities.

site_title: Big Mac goes Big Tech, with a few hiccups
summary: McDonald's experienced widespread system outages across Japan, Australia, and the UK, forcing some locations to temporarily take only cash or shut down entirely. The outages, caused by a third-party provider's configuration change, highlight the tech giant's reliance on technology systems, which can impact operations and customer experiences. Despite the incident, McDonald's plans to deepen its reliance on digital channels and technology, including its generative AI system, to boost sales and efficiencies.

images.alt_text: The outage appears to have affected some electronic kiosks at outlets here.

site_title: Gold beans all the rage with China’s Gen Z as deflation bites
summary: China's Gen Z is turning to gold as a low-risk investment option due to economic uncertainty, deflation, and low interest rates. Three-quarters of gold consumers are between 25-35 years old, believing investing in gold is a safe bet. The cost of gold beans, weighing as little as 1g, is relatively low at around 600 yuan (S$112) per gram, with 18-year-old Tina Hong buying over 2g worth. This trend is part of a broader consumer desire for gold, with many viewing it as a safe investment during economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Higher inflation adds pressure on the US Fed to keep interest rates elevated, weighing on non-yielding assets such as gold.

site_title: Eric Nam: The outsider who became a K-Pop star
summary: Eric Nam, a US-born K-Pop star, rose to fame despite barely speaking Korean when he joined a talent show in 2011. He landed a record deal and became a pop sensation, but missed out on the traditional K-Pop training process due to his outsider status. Nam's unique approach, producing songs in English, has led to international success, with his latest album "House on a Hill" combining poppy beats with personal, searching questions. Now 35, Nam has defied age stereotypes, embracing maturity and beauty, and paving the way for more open and honest K-Pop artists.

images.alt_text: Lisa will be credited on the HBO show under her full name, Lalisa Manobal, Variety said, but her role on the show, which focuses on intrigue at exotic resorts, has not been disclosed.

site_title: US: Stocks close lower as inflation remains in focus
summary: US stocks closed lower on Friday, March 15, as investors awaited the Federal Reserve's policy announcement next Wednesday. The Dow Jones fell 0.5%, the S&P 500 lost 0.7%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 1.0%. The Fed is expected to signal its first rate cut, but concerns about inflation remain, potentially pushing the timeline for rate cuts later than anticipated.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., March 5, 2024.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: What a breast cancer risk calculator can and can’t tell you
summary: A breast cancer risk calculator can provide a personalized picture of an individual's risk, but it's not a definitive prediction. Actress Olivia Munn credited a risk calculator with helping her doctor detect her breast cancer early. Medical experts emphasize that the results are rough estimates and should be interpreted with a doctor's guidance. The calculator assesses factors like family history, age, and genetic mutations, but it's not 100% accurate and should not be used as the sole decision-making tool for breast cancer screening.

images.alt_text: (FILES) US actress Olivia Munn attends the Vanity Fair Oscars Party at the Wallis Annenberg Center for the Performing Arts in Beverly Hills, California, on March 10, 2024. Actor Olivia Munn revealed March 13, 2024 that she had undergone a double mastectomy after being diagnosed with breast cancer. (Photo by Michael TRAN / AFP)

site_title: S-Reits continue to expand through DPU-accretive acquisitions
summary: Singapore's S-Reits sector continues to expand through DPU-accretive acquisitions, with Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) acquiring 89.9% interest in four German logistics properties for S$188.6 million. This acquisition will increase FLCT's logistics assets in Germany to 33, over a quarter of its total portfolio value. Other S-Reits, such as Digital Core Reit and Mapletree Logistics Trust, have also proposed similar acquisitions in Germany and India. The sector's combined market value has grown at a 6% compound annual rate over the past decade, driven by the challenging macroeconomic environment and the resilience of the German logistics sector.

images.alt_text: FCT’s portfolio has grown to nine suburban retail malls and an office building with a combined S$6.5 billion in assets under management as at Dec 31, 2023.

site_title: Europe: Stocks falter on US rate jitters but log weekly gains
summary: European stocks fell 0.2% on Friday, despite a weekly gain, due to concerns over the US Federal Reserve's interest rate cuts. The slowdown in eurozone inflation and ECB policymakers' backing of a June rate cut offered relief. Telecom stocks, however, helped stem losses, with Swisscom and Vodafone shares rising 4.9% and 5.7%, respectively. The Stoxx 600 index ended its eighth consecutive week of gains, supported by corporate updates and interest rate cut expectations.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 closed 0.2 per cent lower on Thursday, after notching an all-time peak for the third time in a row earlier in the session.

site_title: Australia PM to talk wine tariffs with China Foreign Minister in Canberra
summary: Australia Prime Minister Anthony Albanese will discuss wine tariffs with China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi during a meeting in Canberra next week. The removal of Chinese tariffs on Australian wine, imposed in 2020, is on the agenda. Albanese believes dialogue will lead to understanding and economic benefits for both nations. The meeting comes as China reviews the tariffs, and Wang's visit to Australia and New Zealand runs from March 17 to 21.

images.alt_text: China’s rapid return as the dominant buyer of Australian barley raises questions about the success of Canberra’s push to diversify export markets over the past three years.
Australia sent wine worth almost US$800 million to China in the year to November 2020.

site_title: South Korean senior doctors to resign in support of junior medics’ walkout
summary: South Korean senior doctors announced their resignation starting March 25 to support junior medics in a nearly month-long strike over government training reforms aimed at easing doctor shortages. The reforms, which include admitting 2,000 more students to medical schools annually, have been met with resistance from doctors claiming it will erode the quality of service and medical education. The government has reiterated its stance on the reforms, and thousands of trainee doctors have cancelled crucial surgeries and treatments. The move has plunged hospitals into chaos, with nurses and senior doctors stepping up to help, but the strike continues as doctors demand reconsideration of the reform plan.

images.alt_text: President Yoon Suk Yeol (R) has spearheaded a package of medical reform plans and taken a hard line against the protesters, moving to suspend their medical licences for defying return-to-work orders.

site_title: BOJ to end negative rate policy next week, says Nikkei
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is expected to end its negative interest rate policy next week, driven by substantial wage hikes in Japan's annual wage negotiations, according to the Nikkei newspaper. The BOJ officials, including Governor Kazuo Ueda, have stressed the timing of a shift away from negative rates depends on the outcome of these negotiations. Japan's largest companies agreed to raise wages by 5.28% for 2024, the heaviest pay hikes in 33 years, making it a key factor in the BOJ's decision to end the policy.

images.alt_text: Members of the Japanese Trade Union Confederation, commonly known as Rengo. Rengo chief Tomoko Yoshino said rising income inequality, inflation and a labour crunch were among the factors behind the big increase, adding part-time workers would see pay hikes of 6 per cent this fiscal year.

site_title: Boeing tells airlines to check 787 flight deck seat switches
summary: Boeing has advised airlines operating 787 Dreamliners to inspect flight deck seat switches after a LATAM Airlines plane experienced a sudden mid-air dive, injuring over 50 people. The incident, which occurred on Monday, was being investigated by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) and the New Zealand's Transport Accident Investigation Commission. Boeing had previously issued a 2017 service bulletin detailing instructions for inspecting and maintaining the switches. The FAA will review the bulletin and provide feedback to Boeing, which has seen its shares close up nearly 1% following the incident.

images.alt_text: This photograph taken on June 7, 2023, shows an Qatar Airways Airbus A320 aircraft landing at the newly opened runway of Belgrade Nikola Tesla airport. The opening of Belgrade airport's new runway marked the completion of one of the major infrastructure projects undertaken by French operator Vinci, since taking over the concession in late 2018. (Photo by Andrej ISAKOVIC / AFP)
FILE PHOTO: A worker walks past Boeing's new 737 MAX-9 under construction at their production facility in Renton, Washington, U.S., February 13, 2017. REUTERS/Jason Redmond/File Photo

site_title: Ikea plans to spend 300 million euros in South Korea to win market share
summary: Ikea plans to invest 300 million euros in South Korea over three years to increase market share. The company aims to expand its presence with another blue box store in Seoul and smaller formats. Ikea plans to cut prices globally, with 10-20% reductions in key products in South Korea. The company has seen declining revenue in South Korea, with operating profit plummeting to 2.59 billion won in 2023 from 21.8 billion won in 2022. Ikea's investment is part of its broader strategy to improve automation and accessibility.

images.alt_text: Ikea has cut costs and sees decreasing raw material prices, enabling it to bring prices down on some products, which will in turn boost sales volumes.

site_title: Malaysia’s visa-free policy attracts more tourists from China’s second-tier cities
summary: Malaysia's visa-free policy for Chinese citizens has attracted over 10,000 tourists during Chinese New Year, generating an estimated RM1 billion in tourism spend. The policy, which was introduced in December 2023, has seen a surge in interest from tourists in China's second-tier cities, with chartered flights from these cities to Malaysia's popular destinations. The weak ringgit and hassle-free travel have also contributed to the growth, with data showing that Malaysia ranked as the fifth most popular destination globally for Chinese tourists during CNY.

images.alt_text: epa11064243 Chinese tourists visit the Temple of the Emerald Buddha at the Grand Palace complex in Bangkok, Thailand, 08 January 2024. Thailand aims to welcome 8 million Chinese tourists in 2024, a 75 percent of recovery rate from before the 2019 coronavirus pandemic to boost the country's tourism industry after Thailand and China agreed to waive visa requirements permanently for Chinese and Thai citizens, which will come into effect on 01 March 2024, according to Chai Wacharonke, a Thai government spokesperson.  EPA-EFE/RUNGROJ YONGRIT

Shoppers at Petaling Street in Kuala Lumpur. The weakening of the ringgit has been a silver lining for Malaysia’s tourism sector, making it one of the most affordable destinations for travellers in the region.

site_title: India antitrust body to probe Google’s in-app billing amid dispute with startups
summary: India's Competition Commission of India (CCI) has ordered an investigation into Alphabet's Google over its in-app billing system, citing discriminatory practices. The dispute centers on Google's 11-26% fee on in-app payments, which Indian startups claim is excessive. The CCI has directed an investigation to be completed within 60 days. Google denies wrongdoing, stating it charges the fee to support investments in the Google Play app store and Android mobile operating system. The probe is the latest in a months-long dispute between Google and Indian startups.

images.alt_text: Rachel Teo, head of sustainability and head of total portfolio sustainable investing, at GIC.

If any of the six tech giants are not compliant with the Digital Markets Act (DMA) by the EU’s Thursday deadline, they could ultimately face investigations and potentially fines of up to 10 per cent of their global turnover.
Google together with five other tech giants have to be fully compliant with a list of dos and don’ts set out under the DMA on Mar 7.
Ding Linwei has been charged with four counts of trade secrets theft.

site_title: A global cash-transfer fund could end extreme poverty
summary: A global cash-transfer fund could end extreme poverty by providing lump-sum payments to the world's poorest people. Conditions are ripe for deploying direct cash transfers, which have proven effective in improving dozens of outcomes simultaneously, including boosting incomes, increasing school enrollment, and reducing poverty. Despite being a scalable solution, less than 5% of international development spending goes to cash transfers. Establishing a new global fund could help countries expand digital cash transfers, complementing other interventions and empowering families to invest in their well-being.

images.alt_text: World Bank president David Malpass called for major policy changes to boost growth and help jumpstart efforts to eradicate poverty.

Thousands of Indonesians at an election campaign rally in South Sulawesi on Jan 17, 2024. The three presidential candidates have each promised to roll out many policies to improve the lives of the people if they are successful at the Feb 14 poll.

site_title: TDCX minority shareholder wants MAS, SEC to scrutinise privatisation offer
summary: A minority shareholder of TDCX, a digital advertising solutions provider, has filed a complaint with the Monetary Authority of Singapore and the US Securities and Exchange Commission, requesting scrutiny of the company's privatisation deal. The shareholder, V Mittal, has raised concerns about Goldman Sachs' role in the transaction, citing the financial adviser's previous underwriting role in TDCX's initial public offering. The privatisation offer has been met with disappointment from shareholders, who had initially been drawn to the company's tech disruption potential.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
TDCX's employee benefits expenses are down 14.5 per cent in Q4 due to a reversal of equity-settled, share-based payment expenses.
Founder and chief executive officer of TDCX Laurent Junique's offer represents a 36.6 per cent premium over the last traded price.
TDCX's earnings per share for the third quarter stands at S$0.22, up from S$0.21 in the same period a year ago.

site_title: Thailand again considers legalising casinos, up to now a losing bet
summary: Thailand is considering legalizing casinos to attract investment and tourism, despite past proposals failing due to public disapproval. A study by a 60-member committee suggests that at least 10% of Thais are addicted to gambling. Industry experts believe a legal casino market would draw overseas visitors, competing with Macau, the world's largest gambling hub. The proposal aims to capitalize on the growing demand for casino tourism in Southeast Asia.

images.alt_text: A man stacks chips on a black jack table at Japan Casino School in Tokyo, Japan August 4, 2018. Picture taken August 4, 2018. REUTERS/Toru Hanai

site_title: China central bank approves Tencent’s Tenpay capital boost to 15.3 billion yuan
summary: China's central bank approved Tencent Holdings' online payment platform Tenpay's capital boost to 15.3 billion yuan, making it the non-bank payment institution with the highest registered capital in China. Tenpay's current registered capital was 1 billion yuan, and the approval significantly increases its capital.

site_title: Prime US Reit manager CEO Harmeet Singh Bedi resigns
summary: Prime US Reit's CEO Harmeet Singh Bedi is resigning at the end of March, citing "other opportunities". He will be replaced by Rahul Rana, a shareholder of the Reit's sponsor, KBS Asia Partners. Bedi's departure comes less than a month after the company announced its FY2023 financial results, which showed a 90% decline in its distribution per unit. The Reit's units fell 3.7% on Friday, before the announcement, and will issue new units to unitholders on a 1-for-10 basis.

images.alt_text: Manulife US Reit’s Centerpointe I & II, in Fairfax, Virginia. The Reit halted distributions last year, following a breach in loan covenants after valuations fell.
ST20230425_202396467392 Kua Chee Siong/ pixgeneric/ Generic pix of the buildings in the Central Business District lining the Singapore skyline on April 25, 2023.

The minority shareholders of Vard Holdings achieved a breakthrough on Thursday when Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) ordered the shipbuilder to hold another extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to get their approval on its delisting plan.
Prime US Reit's manager said demand for US office space “broadly strengthened” in Q4 2023 as reflected by an increase in active tenant requirements and leasing activity.
One Town Center, one of Prime US Reit's assets in Florida. Analysts are speculating that news of Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit's recapitalisation plan could pose a "contagion risk" to Prime.

site_title: Apac investment grade credit: Time to make it a core allocation
summary: Asia's growing economic heft and stellar returns on investment-grade bonds make it an attractive standalone asset class for investors. The region's economic cycle has diverged from developed markets, with inflation under control and expected to expand at 4.5% in 2024. Asia IG bonds offer attractive yields, with a yield-to-worst of 5.75%, and have delivered solid risk-adjusted returns across all time periods. With significant return dispersion expected in 2024, investors should consider a core allocation to Asia IG, particularly those with deep on-the-ground experience navigating Asia's debt markets.

images.alt_text: Stock market, portfolio.
Regardless of whether you think a downturn is imminent or not, there will always be pockets of opportunity in the market.
The current rally is just the latest turnaround in a volatile year for bonds.

site_title: Nvidia’s historic rally extends to a record-setting 10th straight week
summary: Nvidia's stock has reached a record 10th straight week of gains, with a 0.4% rise over the latest week, extending its historic 2024 rally. The company has gained about 80% over the 10-week rally, driven by high demand for chips used in artificial intelligence. Nvidia's market capitalization has reached around $2.2 trillion, making it the third-largest publicly traded stock, behind Microsoft and Apple. The next major test for the stock will come on March 18, when CEO Jensen Huang speaks at the company's annual GTC conference.

site_title: Oil: Prices dip, but set for weekly gain of over 3%
summary: US oil prices dipped on Friday, falling to $85.33 a barrel, but are expected to rise by over 3% for the week due to rising demand from US refiners. The oil rig count rose to its highest in six months, with energy firms adding the biggest number of oil and natural gas rigs in a week since September. Tightening supplies for motor fuels and disruptions to Red Sea shipping have driven up prices, with the International Energy Agency forecasting a 1.3 million barrel-per-day increase in world oil demand in 2024.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man works on the rig of an oil drilling pump site in McKenzie County outside of Williston, North Dakota, U.S., March 12, 2013.   REUTERS/Shannon Stapleton/File Photo
Brent crude oil futures for May climbed US$1.39, or 1.7 per cent, to settle at US$85.42 a barrel, the highest close since Nov 6.

site_title: Liverpool must end century-old Old Trafford jinx to stay in FA Cup hunt
summary: Manchester United and Liverpool, bitter rivals and two of the most successful teams in English football, face off at Old Trafford in the FA Cup quarterfinals. Liverpool, led by Jurgen Klopp, seeks to end a 103-year-old jinx of not winning an FA Cup tie at Old Trafford, while Manchester United, under Erik ten Hag, aims to salvage a disappointing season. The match will determine which team advances to the semifinals and could be a crucial moment in both teams' seasons.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
The Li Ning Sports Singapore retail outlet in Ion Orchard. Li Ning Sports Singapore ceased to exist by the end of 2012 – a victim of the parent firm’s radical cost-cutting amid fierce competition.
As planning is in the early stages, there is currently no timeline for when construction will begin and more details will be shared later.
Team Boss is fielding an all-female team at this year's BT Corporate Golf League. The event tees off on Thursday.

NAPLES, FLORIDA - NOVEMBER 17: Lilia Vu of the United States plays her shot from the third tee during the second round of the CME Group Tour Championship at Tiburon Golf Club on November 17, 2023 in Naples, Florida.   Michael Reaves/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Michael Reaves / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: US consumer sentiment holds steady as focus turns to election
summary: US consumer sentiment remained steady in early March, holding at 76.5, as inflation largely retreated and the job market remains strong. Americans are cautious about the outlook ahead of the presidential election, with a median estimate of 3% annual price increase over the next year and 2.9% over 5-10 years. Consumer sentiment improved among Republicans and Democrats but declined among independents, with many withholding judgment on the economy's trajectory until the election results are known.

images.alt_text: Much of February’s rise was down to a 0.8 percent rise in manufacturing output, and a 2.2 increase in the index for mining.
In the 12 months through February, import prices dropped 0.8 per cent after declining 1.3 per cent in January.

site_title: Apple reaches US$490 million settlement over CEO Cook’s China sales comments
summary: Apple has agreed to pay $490 million to settle a class-action lawsuit alleging CEO Tim Cook defrauded shareholders by concealing falling iPhone demand in China. The lawsuit stemmed from Cook's November 2018 comments downplaying sales pressure in certain markets, including China, and the subsequent reduction of production. Apple denied liability but settled to avoid the cost and distraction of litigation. The settlement requires approval by US District Judge Yvonne Gonzalez Rogers.

images.alt_text: Apple has long fought such changes, arguing that they will undermine the user experience and security of its software.

site_title: French parliament votes to slow down fast fashion
summary: The French parliament voted to slow down fast fashion, with measures including a ban on cheapest textile advertising and an environmental charge on low-cost items. This makes France the first country to "legislating to limit the excesses of ultra fast fashion." The goal is to reduce the environmental impact of the fashion industry, particularly from Chinese mass producers like Shein, which produces 7,200 new clothing items per day.

images.alt_text: Shein is seeking Beijing’s nod to go public in a listing that will likely face tough scrutiny from US regulators.

site_title: China tightens scrutiny over IPOs, listed firms to revive stock market
summary: China's China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) has published new rules to tighten scrutiny over stock listings, public companies, and underwriters, aiming to make the capital market "safe, regulated, transparent, open, vivid and resilient." The rules will vet initial public offerings (IPOs) more closely, crack down on securities fraud, and encourage listed firms to increase dividend payouts and buy back shares. The goal is to boost investor confidence and revive the stock market, which has rebounded from five-year lows.

images.alt_text: This would be the first time Morgan Stanley has cut staff at the China fund unit since it bought out its local partner’s 36 per cent stake in the loss-making business for about US$54 million in 2023.
Chinese stocks are wallowing near a five-year nadir while yields on the country’s 30-year treasury bonds have plumbed record lows.
Organised by the Shenzhen and Shanghai stock exchanges, the training was aimed at helping quant funds understand the regulatory mindset and work requirements, the Shenzhen bourse says.
China’s state-backed funds are buying into exchange-traded funds that track the benchmark to prop up the market.
China earlier this month broadly took aim at quant funds, which relied on computer-driven trading to outperform the market for much of the last three years.
China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) vows to strengthen the regulation of direct market access and guide funds in controlling the size and leverage of their DMA businesses.

site_title: China’s JD.com walks away from bidding for Currys
summary: JD.com, a Chinese online retailer, announced it will not pursue a bid for British electricals group Currys, following US investor Elliott Advisors' decision to withdraw its offer. Currys' shares plummeted 6% to 55.4 pence after the update. The move comes after Currys' board reportedly refused to engage with Elliott. JD.com cited "careful consideration" for its decision, stating it does not intend to make an offer for Currys.

site_title: US: Wall Street slides at open as inflation concerns hit rate-sensitive stocks
summary: US stocks slid at open on Friday, March 15, 2024, as concerns over inflation impacted rate-sensitive stocks ahead of the Federal Reserve's meeting. The Dow Jones fell 96.01 points, or 0.25%, to 38,809.65, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropped. The decline was attributed to worries over the timing of interest-rate cuts due to sticky inflation.

site_title: US import prices rise moderately in February
summary: US import prices rose 0.3% in February, moderating from a 0.8% increase in January, with petroleum products driving the gain. Core import prices, excluding fuels and food, rose 0.1%, while imported consumer goods prices excluding automotives increased 0.3%. The 12-month decline in import prices was 0.8%, down from a 1.3% drop in January, suggesting a relatively stable inflation outlook. The Federal Reserve is expected to start cutting interest rates by June, but sustained inflation could delay this move.

images.alt_text: Retail inventories increased 0.4 per cent in January, instead of the 0.5 per cent estimated in an advance report published last month.

site_title: US industrial production edges higher on rise in manufacturing, mining
summary: US industrial production edged higher in February, rising 0.1% after a revised 0.5% decline in January. The increase was driven by a 0.8% rise in manufacturing output and a 2.2% increase in mining. The Federal Reserve attributed the gains to recoveries from weather-related declines and warmer-than-typical weather. Despite the slight improvement, industrial production remains lower than it was a year ago.

images.alt_text: In the 12 months through February, import prices dropped 0.8 per cent after declining 1.3 per cent in January.

site_title: Pope Francis reflects on his life and mortality in memoir
summary: Pope Francis has released a memoir, "Life - My Story Through History," which reflects on his life and its intersection with major world events. The 230-page book, written with Italian journalist Fabio Marchese Ragona, offers little new but is a conversational-style read covering his childhood in Buenos Aires to the present. The book coincides with the 11th anniversary of Francis' installation as the first Latin American pope, set for release on March 19, 2024.

images.alt_text: Pope Francis (in white) during the weekly general audience at the Vatican on Wednesday (Aug 30). His latest writing, to be issued on Oct 4, will update his influential 2015 document, also on climate change.

site_title: Qatar Airways mulls up to 150 widebody orders from Boeing, Airbus
summary: Qatar Airways is in talks with Boeing and Airbus to order up to 150 widebody jets, aiming to modernize and expand its fleet. The airline is considering the Airbus A350 and Boeing 777X models, and the deal could be completed in the coming months. This order would follow major purchases by regional rival Emirates and Saudi Arabia's Riyadh Air, which is seeking to establish itself as a new force in the Middle East. The volume of the deal will depend on factors such as upgrades, replacements, and new-jet needs.

images.alt_text: Qatar Airways is leveraging its position as a connecting airline with its hub in Doha.

This photograph taken on June 7, 2023, shows an Qatar Airways Airbus A320 aircraft landing at the newly opened runway of Belgrade Nikola Tesla airport. site_title: Japan Inc set to step up outbound M&A
summary: Japan's corporate giants are set to accelerate their outbound mergers and acquisitions (M&A) as the country's central bank moves towards raising interest rates, boosting the yen and making overseas targets cheaper. The move is driven by pressure to boost capital efficiency and tap alternative revenue streams. Japan has seen a sharp contrast in M&A activity with the rest of the Asia-Pacific region, with nearly $17 billion worth of overseas acquisitions announced this year, up from $58 billion last year.

images.alt_text: US and Japan discuss speeding up bilateral trade talks

site_title: UK inflation expectations fall, easing pressure on Bank of England
summary: UK inflation expectations have fallen to their lowest in three months, easing pressure on the Bank of England. The median expectations for inflation over the next 12 months have dropped to 3% from 3.3% in November, and longer-term expectations have fallen to 3.1%. The BOE forecasts inflation will return to its 2% target in the second quarter but is expected to rise towards 3% later in the year. The survey also shows a rise in net satisfaction with the BOE's control of inflation, with a record low difference between satisfied and dissatisfied respondents.

images.alt_text: Workers on a Bellway Plc residential construction site in Tongham, UK, on Monday, Feb. 26, 2024. Britain’s top antitrust enforcer has opened an investigation into eight housebuilders to probe potential information sharing, sharpening scrutiny of a sector that’s failing to deliver enough affordable housing to meet demand. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg
Carnaby Street in London. The figures showthat the central bank’s efforts to slow demand in the economy are taking the heat out of the labour market, which has fanned upward pressure on prices.
British supermarkets’ most recent earnings have revealed solid growth over the Christmas period, with price cuts and customer loyalty initiatives boosting sales.
The Confederation of British Industry’s (CBI) monthly retail sales balance, a gauge of sales versus a year ago, rises to -7 from -50 in January, the slowest fall in 10 months.

site_title: Yangzijiang Financial combines compliance and risk functions, removes chief risk officer role
summary: Yangzijiang Financial has reorganized its compliance and risk functions, combining them under one department, effective April 1. The move aims to improve operational efficiencies and achieve a more robust risk management outcome. Chief Risk Officer Chiang Kheng Hong will be reassigned to run cash management operations and join investment committees to strengthen oversight of treasury and liquidity risk management. The reorganization follows changes to the senior management team, including the departure of CEO Toe Teow Heng on April 24.

images.alt_text: Vincent Toe, CEO of Yangzijiang Financial, says the proposed final cash dividend of S$0.022 per share comes as a “reward” for shareholders amid the group’s improved performance in FY2023.

Yangzijiang Shipbuilding attributes its gross profit margin improvement to the depreciation of the yuan against the US dollar, reduced raw material costs and improved new build price of vessels being constructed during H2 FY2023.
Yangzijiang, which specialises in dry-bulk carriers, has posted a 73 per cent jump in earnings to 719.9 million yuan (S$146 million) for the second quarter ended 30 June 2017.

News of Yangzijiang Financial's general counsel, Koh Boon Chiao, leaving comes less than two weeks after the company announced that its chief executive officer, Vincent Toe (above), will be leaving in April next year.
Vincent Toe, CEO, Yangzijiang Financial Holding, will step down from his position in April 2024.

site_title: US FDA approves first drug for fatty liver disease NASH
summary: The US FDA has approved Madrigal Pharmaceuticals' first treatment for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), a fatty liver disease affecting 1.5 million people in the US. The drug, Rezdiffra, is expected to generate annual sales of over $5 billion at peak. Despite concerns that the FDA's label does not require a liver biopsy for diagnosis, analysts expect high demand for the treatment. Madrigal Pharmaceuticals' shares surged 24% in extended trading following the approval.

images.alt_text: US panel urges approval of cutting-edge cancer therapy

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 15)
summary: Singapore's private home sales plummeted 47% in February to 149 units, the lowest since 2008. Novartis invested US$256 million to expand its Singapore biopharmaceutical plant. BYD, a China EV giant, is expanding in the region by partnering with dealers, taking a different approach from Tesla's direct-sales model. Frasers Logistics and Commercial Trust acquired a 89.9% interest in four German logistics assets. The Life Insurance Association Singapore launched a guide to explain the underwriting process to consumers. Singapore stocks declined 0.4% amid inflation concerns.

site_title: China loans grow at slowest pace on record amid weak demand
summary: China's bank loans expanded at the slowest pace on record in February, growing 9.7% year-over-year, the lowest in data since 2003. This underscores weakness in borrowing demand despite the central bank's efforts to ease policy. The stock of aggregate financing also declined near a record low, while the M1 money supply measure weakened to 1.2%. Economists warn that further credit growth may be needed to support the economy, and some suggest the central bank may still cut interest rates this year.

images.alt_text: Apartments buildings stand in Beijing, China, on Thursday, Feb. 17, 2011. Beijing will ban residents from buying more than two homes after the Chinese government extended property curbs to prevent a housing bubble, China Central Television reported. Photographer: Nelson Ching/Bloomberg

The People’s Bank of China said it was keeping the rate on 387 billion yuan (S$72 billion) worth of one-year medium-term lending facility (MLF) loans to some financial institutions unchanged at 2.50 per cent.

PBOC says foreign entities owned 2.8 trillion yuan (S$523.3 billion) of onshore Chinese equities at the end of last year, down 13 per cent from 12 months earlier, and a drop of almost 30 per cent from the peak at the end of 2021.
The People’s Bank of China (PBOC) in Beijing, China.
China's economy is flagging under the weight of a property crisis, weak confidence and deflation pressures.

site_title: Drahi agrees to 1.6 billion euro Altice Media sale as debt looms
summary: French-Israeli tycoon Patrick Drahi has agreed to sell Altice Media, including French news channel BFM TV, for 1.55 billion euros to the Saadé family's CMA CGM shipping firm and Merit France family office. The deal comes as Drahi seeks to cut a debt pile of over $60 billion, with Altice France facing 1.8 billion euros in debt due in 2025. The sale is subject to approval by employee representatives and regulators, and follows a series of challenges faced by Drahi's companies, including a corruption probe.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Patrick Drahi, Franco-Israeli businessman and founder of cable and mobile telecoms company Altice Group attends the inauguration of the Altice Campus in Paris, France, October 9, 2018.  REUTERS/Philippe Wojazer/File Photo
Patrick Drahi has a net worth of US$5.7 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index, down from US$22 billion in June 2015

site_title: SIA Group flies 28.2% more passengers in February; Sats makes acquisition in Sweden
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) carried 3.1 million passengers in February, a 28.2% increase from last year, driven by the Chinese New Year holiday season. This growth aligns with its 20.7% capacity increase. Passenger traffic was up 20.4% from the same period last year.

images.alt_text: xxx
Initial price guidance for the deal has been set at the 10-year US Treasury rate plus 150 basis points, a term sheet seen by Reuters showed. The size of the deal could reach US$500 million.
The tie-up is unlikely to reduce competition, said SIA and Garuda, as they will continue to face “intense” rivalry from low-cost carriers.
The February passenger traffic was also 33.7 per cent higher than that for February 2023.
China was Singapore's top tourist source market pre-pandemic.
Scoot's chief executive officer Leslie Thng says the airline will fly to five to seven more destinations in South-east Asia in FY2025, bringing the network points to as many as 74.

site_title: Hong Kong’s home prices drop in first full week after property curbs lifted
summary: Hong Kong's used home prices dropped 0.8% in the first full week after property curbs were lifted, marking a decline of over 2% since the beginning of the year. Despite a rebound in home transactions, the industry remains under pressure due to an abundant supply of apartments and expensive borrowing costs. Analysts expect prices to recover in the fourth quarter as some inventory is absorbed. Property developers are offering discounts to lure buyers, with Wheelock Properties marketing its apartments at the lowest price since 2019.

images.alt_text: The abundance of apartments for sale, together with high borrowing costs and a weak economy, is expected to stunt price growth in the coming months.
The real estate crisis in mainland China has made Hong Kong’s residential market seem like a safer bet, adding to its dramatic rebound.
Hong Kong, one of the most expensive property markets in the world, has seen its housing and commercial property prices plunge more than 20 per cent and 30 per cent, respectively, from their peaks.

site_title: Sri Lanka's economy shrank 2.3% in 2023
summary: Sri Lanka's economy contracted 2.3% in 2023, despite a 4.5% growth in the fourth quarter, driven by a stronger currency, higher remittances, and better tourism revenue. The country's agriculture sector grew 2.6%, while industrial output shrank 9.2% and services decreased 0.2%. Sri Lanka's economy contracted 7.8% in 2022 due to a foreign exchange crisis and political instability. The country expects to grow 1.8% in 2024, with a possible interest rate reduction and moderating inflation expected to boost consumption.

images.alt_text: Sri Lanka's President Ranil Wickremesinghe delivers a speech during the Nikkei Forum "Future of Asia" in Tokyo on May 25, 2023. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)

site_title: Singapore stocks slip on Friday amid inflation fears; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.4% on Friday, tracking a decline in regional markets due to inflation concerns. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,172.96. Key indices in Australia, Japan, South Korea, and Hong Kong also declined. Losers outnumbered gainers 335 to 225, with only three STI counters ending in the black, including DBS and Hongkong Land.

site_title: Thailand goes ahead with Bill to legalise same-sex marriage
summary: Thailand is moving forward with a bill to legalize same-sex marriage, becoming the first in South-east Asia to guarantee equal marital rights. The draft amendment to the Civil and Commercial Code, approved by a committee on March 14, proposes a change in the composition of marriage from "a man and a woman" to "two individuals" and a genderless "married couple." Lawmakers are set to approve the Bill on March 27, with a royal endorsement expected by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Participants march during the Tokyo Rainbow Pride parade, celebrating advances in LGBTQ rights and calling for marriage equality, in Tokyo, Japan, April 23, 2023. REUTERS/Issei Kato

site_title: Bankers in India to get higher salary increases than Singapore, Hong Kong
summary: Finance professionals in India are expected to receive a 10% salary hike in 2024, surpassing those in Hong Kong and Singapore, which are projected to see 4% increases. Analysts attribute this trend to India's economic boom, driven by China's slowdown, and the growing demand for financial services. Major firms such as HSBC, Julius Baer, and Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group are expanding their operations in India to tap into the nation's wealth.

site_title: TikTok's US revenue hits US$16 billion as Washington threatens ban
summary: TikTok's US revenue reached $16 billion in 2023, driven by the app's growth among 170 million American users. The company's overall revenue of $120 billion in 2023 was up 40% from the previous year, with TikTok's US sales contributing significantly to the figure. The US House of Representatives has passed a bill that would give ByteDance six months to divest TikTok's US assets or face a ban, posing a threat to the app's continued operation in the country.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this photo illustration the social media application logo for TikTok is displayed on the screen of an iPhone in front of a US flag and Chinese flag background in Washington, DC, on March 16, 2023. China on March 14, 2024 slammed the approval of a US bill that would ban TikTok unless it severs ties with its Chinese parent company, blasting Washington's "bandit" mentality and vowing Beijing would "take all necessary measures" to protect the interests of its companies overseas. (Photo by OLIVIER DOULIERY / AFP)

site_title: McDonald’s online services down in Singapore amid widespread outage
summary: McDonald's experienced a widespread technology outage across its outlets in multiple countries, including Singapore, Australia, Hong Kong, and Japan, on March 15. The outage affected mobile ordering services, electronic kiosks, and online platforms. Customers were advised to order from staff at store counters in Hong Kong, while in Australia, food and electronic payment were still available at physical outlets. McDonald's apologized for the inconvenience and stated the issue was not related to a cybersecurity event, with the problem being resolved.

images.alt_text: Firms including Mubadala Investment, Qatar Investment Authority (QIA) and China Investment Corp (CIC) are in talks to jointly invest in McDonald’s China operations as minority shareholders.
Companies are seeking new horizons on the mainland as the country’s economic woes lead shoppers to pull back.

site_title: Rivals Nissan and Honda sign MOU on EV partnership
summary: Japanese automakers Nissan and Honda are considering a strategic partnership to collaborate on producing electric vehicles and artificial intelligence in automotive software platforms. The potential partnership aims to develop economies of scale in producing EVs, helping the companies compete with China's BYD, Tesla, and others. Nissan and Honda have signed a non-binding memorandum of understanding, with no scope or timeline set for the collaboration. The companies will explore cost-cutting measures, joint procurement, and a common platform, with Honda aiming to increase its electric vehicle sales to 100% of all sales by 2040.

images.alt_text: The Japanese carmakers are struggling in the face of increased local competition from manufacturers such as BYD as electric vehicles take hold in China.

site_title: Malaysia’s Petronas Q4 profit falls, flags market uncertainty in 2024
summary: Malaysia's state energy firm Petronas reported a profit of RM16.6 billion (S$4.7 billion) in the fourth quarter, down from RM24.4 billion in the same quarter of 2022. The company attributed the decline to lower energy prices due to conflicts in Ukraine and Gaza, and slowing global growth. Petronas chief executive Tengku Muhammad Taufik warned that the oil and gas markets will face continued uncertainties in 2024, posing challenges to the company's growth.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Model of natural gas pipeline and rising stock graph, July 18, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Developers’ sales remain tepid in February, down nearly half amid lack of new condo launches
summary: Singapore's private home sales in February plummeted to 149 units, a 47% drop from January and the lowest figure since 2008. The lack of new condo launches during the Chinese New Year festivities was cited as the main reason for the decline. Analysts predict that sales momentum will recover in March with the launch of major projects, but overall, the market is expected to remain subdued due to cooling measures, elevated interest rates, and buyer fatigue.

The rising level of unsold stock may signal bad news for some projects, such as the 99-year leasehold Cuscaden Reserve (above), with an impending sales deadline this year.
