site_title: Market Focus Daily: Friday, March 15, 2024 (Ep 23)
summary: Markets experienced a slump on Friday, March 15, 2024, with US inflation beating expectations, causing a decline. Hong Kong stocks fell after China's central bank kept interest rates unchanged, and Japan's companies agreed on a 33-year-high wage hike. The Bank of Japan is likely to end its negative interest rate policy next week. No Signboard resumed trading, with shares dropping up to 90%. Singapore shares also fell, with the STI down 0.9%.

No Signboard's trading resumption comes ahead of the record date for its proposed six-to-one share consolidation.

site_title: Pessimism for ‘net zero by 2050’ grows as executives grapple with poor ROI prospects: Bain
summary: A survey of over 600 executives in the oil and gas, utilities, chemicals, mining, and agribusiness sectors found that 62% now believe the world will reach net zero by 2060 or later due to poor ROI prospects, down from 54% last year. Only 38% expect net zero by 2050, with 31% expecting it by 2060 and 31% by 2070 or later. The shift is attributed to growing concerns about customers' willingness to pay and generating adequate returns on investment in energy transition projects.

images.alt_text: Shell says it will target a 15 to 20 per cent reduction in net carbon intensity of its energy products by 2030 compared with 2016 intensity levels.
Market analysts are bullish on the uptrend of FBM KLCI to continue, as they anticipate Malaysia’s economic condition will keep improving this year.

site_title: China securities regulator to tighten regulations on listed firms, brokers
summary: China's top securities regulator, the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC), has vowed to strengthen regulations on listed firms and financial institutions to prevent risks in the stock market. The CSRC has introduced curbs on short selling, tightened scrutiny over quantitative trading, and vowed zero tolerance toward securities fraud. Initial public offering (IPO) applications will be strictly vetted, and accounting fraud and false statements will be severely punished. The moves aim to revive a sluggish market that hit five-year lows in early February, with China's benchmark CSI 300 Index up 4% this year but still 40% down from its peak in 2021.

images.alt_text: An investor looks at a screen showing stock market movements at a securities company in Hangzhou, in eastern China's Zhejiang province on February 8, 2024. (Photo by AFP) / China Out

site_title: Indonesia may block several foreign-owned OTAs this week
summary: Indonesia's Ministry of Communication and Information has given six foreign-owned online travel agents (OTAs) five working days to register as private electronic system providers. The OTAs, including Booking.com, Expedia, and Klook, were warned of punitive measures, including a block, if they fail to register. Only Agoda and Airbnb have registered as of March 12. The ministry has also registered other companies such as Line, Yahoo Indonesia, Meta, Instagram, and WhatsApp.

images.alt_text: Travellers are looking to cruises in 2024 because they are still cheaper than land-based alternatives.
Serving the needs of the uber-wealthy traveller boils down to understanding individual preferences and quirks and managing demands and expectations, which are “fluid on a case-to-case basis”.

site_title: Hot stock: Nam Cheong continues to fall post-share consolidation; shares are down 40.3%
summary: Nam Cheong's shares fell 40.3% to S$0.20 on their second day of trading after a four-year suspension, following a 100-to-1 share consolidation and capital reorganisation. The Malaysian offshore support vessel builder resumed trading on the Singapore Exchange after a voluntary suspension in April 2020 due to financial concerns. The company has been restructuring its trade payables since 2017, with total liabilities exceeding current assets.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Nam Cheong auditor issues disclaimer of opinion on FY2021 financial statements
Nam Cheong's current assets 'unlikely to adequately meet' RM1.38b in liabilities

site_title: Foreign investors raise China bond holdings despite low yields
summary: Foreign investors raised their holdings of China's onshore yuan bonds for the sixth straight month, with 3.95 trillion yuan (S$751 billion) held as of the end of February. Despite low yields, foreign institutions favor currency hedged returns, with a yield differential of 193 basis points between the US and China's 10-year treasuries. The popularity of long-dated bonds reflects mainland investors' desperation for safe assets amid plummeting confidence in the economy and stock market. China's central bank is promoting over-the-counter trades to attract more inflows and convert residents' savings into investments.

images.alt_text: An investor looks at a screen showing stock market movements at a securities company in Hangzhou, in eastern China's Zhejiang province on February 8, 2024. (Photo by AFP) / China Out

Foreign institutions hold 3.67 trillion yuan (S$686.4 billion) in bonds traded on China’s interbank market as of the end of 2023.

site_title: Novartis invests US$256 million to expand Singapore plant
summary: Novartis has invested US$256 million to expand its biopharmaceutical manufacturing plant in Singapore, with the goal of doubling production capacity and creating 100 new job openings. The expanded site is expected to be operational by early 2026 and will focus on manufacturing therapeutic antibody drugs. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of investing in biopharma innovation and encouraged Novartis to explore new frontiers in therapeutics and gene and cell therapy.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Novartis will offer shareholders 68 euros per share in cash and take MorphoSys private after the deal.
Novartis has so far prevailed over rival drug maker Incyte, which also made an offer for MorphoSys.

site_title: Japan’s largest union group announces biggest wage hikes in 33 years
summary: Japan's largest union group, Rengo, announced the country's largest wage hikes in 33 years, with major companies agreeing to increase wages by 5.28% for 2024. The move is seen as a strong signal that the country's central bank will soon shift away from a decade-long stimulus program. The wage hikes are also expected to boost household spending and produce more durable growth in the broader economy, which narrowly avoided recession last year. The decision comes as Japan faces a chronic labor shortage and rising income inequality.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan will likely make a final decision on whether to pull the trigger next week, or hold off until April, after scrutinising a preliminary survey of big firms’ wage talk outcome to be released by labour umbrella Rengo later on Friday.

site_title: What TikTok tells us about the paradox of markets right now
summary: The US House of Representatives has passed a bill to ban TikTok unless its Chinese-based parent ByteDance sells the social media app. The decision could lead to a sale, but antitrust issues and Beijing's opposition may hinder this. The vote highlights a paradox in markets, where investors are optimistic about short-term economic outlooks but uncertain about medium-term dangers, including geopolitical tensions, climate change, and innovation. The uncertain times also reflect investors' willingness to price Treasury bonds around a projected medium-to-long-term outlook, a shift from historical behavior.

images.alt_text: “The government is attempting to strip 170 million Americans of their Constitutional right to free expression,” Tiktok says.
Because TikTok is owned by a Chinese company, ByteDance, the short-form video platform's popularity among Americans carries implications beyond the mobile-phone screen.

site_title: Cash returns still ‘elusive’ for VC, PE investors in SEA startups: report
summary: A new report by US-based research firm PitchBook found that venture capital and private equity investors in South-east Asia (SEA) are struggling to secure cash returns for their investments in startups. Despite a tripling of venture capital deals between 2015 and 2021, exits have been rare, with only six exits valued over $1 billion generating nearly 87% of the region's exit value since 2015. The report highlights stringent regulations, limited funding for later-stage ventures, and a lack of comprehensive financing coverage as major challenges for the region's private capital market.

site_title: Issue 92: Singapore readies for climate auditing; Indonesia’s methane numbers under question
summary: Singapore is set to mandate climate reporting among listed and large non-listed companies, requiring external assurance starting from 2027 and 2029 respectively. The move has caused anxiety among accountants and auditors, who are concerned about the additional cost and complexity. Indonesia's methane emissions are under question, with a report by Ember suggesting they could be eight times the reported amount, and the International Energy Agency estimating that global methane emissions have increased by 50% in 2023. The coming climate reporting rules may also require companies to mix accounting and technical subject matter experts, raising operational challenges.

Vopak owns and operates Singapore’s only ammonia tank currently. The tank is situated at its Banyan terminal, the biggest of the three terminals it operates on Jurong Island.

Bambang Susantono, chairman of Indonesia Nusantara Capital Authority shows Indonesia's future capital Nusantara layout in a presentation.
Currently, Japan has less of 0.5 GW of offshore wind power installed and is developing a few floating offshore wind warms, mainly for demonstration purposes.

site_title: Swisscom buys Vodafone Italia in US$8.7 billion deal
summary: Swisscom has agreed to buy Vodafone Italia for $8.7 billion, merging the business with its Italian subsidiary Fastweb. The deal will create Italy's second-largest fixed-line broadband operator and a leading mobile player. The transaction is expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2025 and will be fully debt-financed. Swisscom CEO Christoph Aeschlimann said the merger will help achieve profitable growth in Italy and boost cash flow. The deal caps Vodafone CEO Margherita Della Valle's efforts to tackle unprofitable markets and improve the company's profitability.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Branding is displayed for Vodafone at one of its stores in London, Britain, June 14, 2023. REUTERS/Toby Melville/File Photo

site_title: 2024 Mini Countryman review: Friends, Roaming, Countrymen
summary: The 2024 Mini Countryman boasts a larger size, with a 13cm increase in length and 6cm in height, featuring a 12-inch touchscreen display. The new model also offers an electric power option, alongside a battery-powered Countryman SE version, set to arrive in Singapore in the second half of the year. The Countryman retains its recognizable Mini design, with styling cues such as wraparound windows and Union Jack tail-lights. The John Cooper Works version features 19-inch wheels, and the electric model is expected to cater to the growing demand for electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: Speculation is rife online that the exquisite two-seater Arcadia Droptail cost as much as £20 million (S$34.1 million) before taxes.
The EV9 is unashamedly boxy, with flat, vertical surfaces that exaggerate its size instead of playing it down.

site_title: Abu Dhabi-backed firm in talks to invest in OpenAI chip venture, FT reports
summary: Abu Dhabi's state-backed investment firm MGX is in early-stage discussions to invest in OpenAI's chip venture, according to a report by the Financial Times. This follows earlier reports of Singapore's Temasek Holdings and UAE's AI minister Omar Sultan Al Olama expressing interest in investing in OpenAI. The investment could further boost the adoption of generative AI technologies, which have attracted billions of dollars in investments in chips and servers.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Figurines with computers and smartphones are seen in front of the words "Artificial Intelligence AI" in this illustration taken, February 19, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: WorkWell Leaders to establish national benchmark for workplace well-being in Singapore
summary: WorkWell Leaders, a Singapore-based charity, is establishing a national benchmark to address workplace well-being and mental health. The new guidelines focus on organizational-level interventions, including leadership and manager behaviors, business risks, and investments that create long-term value. The benchmark aims to help boards and CEOs chart strategic road maps for more resilient and happier employees and work communities. With 46% of Singaporeans citing mental health as the "biggest" health problem, WorkWell hopes the guidelines will enable informed strategies and investments to improve employee well-being.

site_title: India’s Paytm wins payments approval it needs to stay in business
summary: India's Paytm wins approval to operate as a consumer digital payments platform, allowing it to continue its bulk of business despite its banking affiliate, Paytm Payments Bank, ceasing operations due to regulatory breaches. Lenders such as Axis Bank, HDFC Bank, and State Bank of India will power peer-to-peer or UPI payments for Paytm. The move is seen as a significant win for the beleaguered fintech, ensuring its survival despite the winding down of its banking arm.

images.alt_text: Paytm CEO Vijay Shekhar Sharma owns a 51 per cent stake in Paytm Payments Bank while Paytm owns the rest.
Paytm CEO Vijay Shekhar Sharma owns a 51 per cent stake in Paytm Payments Bank while Paytm owns the rest.
If approved, Paytm will be allowed to continue processing payments via India’s popular unified payments interface.

site_title: Gold on track for weekly drop as traders temper US rate-cut hopes
summary: Gold prices are on track for a weekly drop, marking the first since mid-February, due to the US Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hikes. Higher inflation readings have led the Fed to reconsider its rate-cut plans, pushing the first cut beyond June. Spot gold is up 0.1% at $2,162.66 per ounce, but a weekly fall of over 0.5% is expected.

images.alt_text: US gold futures has dipped 0.1 per cent to US$2,178.20.

site_title: Bitcoin retreats from record high as ‘bubble’ talk grows louder
summary: Bitcoin dropped 5.6% in Asian trading, paring some of the slide to US$67,300, amid debate about a potential 'bubble' in the cryptocurrency market. The token hit a fresh all-time peak of US$73,798 the previous day, but investors are reassessing bets on a looser Federal Reserve monetary policy following persistent inflationary pressure. Some analysts, including Bank of America's Michael Hartnett, warn of a market pullback, while others point to fundamental supports such as net inflows and supply growth reductions.

images.alt_text: (FILES) A picture taken on February 6, 2018 shows a person holding a visual representation of the digital crypto-currency Bitcoin, at the "Bitcoin Change" shop in the Israeli city of Tel Aviv. Bitcoin hit another record high Friday, March 8, smashing through $70,000 for the first time on growing investor demand amid speculation over when the United States may begin lowering interest rates. (Photo by JACK GUEZ / AFP)

site_title: Saudi Arabia banks embark on record bond binge for mega-projects
summary: Saudi Arabia's banks are expected to issue a record US$11.5 billion in bonds this year to fund mega projects under Vision 2030, a plan to diversify the economy. The funding requirement, coupled with slower deposit growth, will rely heavily on borrowing, with lenders needing to issue at least US$384 billion over the next five years to support construction spending. Despite the challenge, banks' balance sheets are still considered healthy, and the government and state companies are also expected to issue bonds to support the plan.

images.alt_text: The kingdom plans to hire JPMorgan as one of the main underwriters to the offering.
Tourists at the Harrat Viewpoint in AlUla, Saudi Arabia.

site_title: China asks banks, insurers in Hong Kong to reveal LGFV holdings
summary: China's banking regulator has requested the Hong Kong units of several Chinese banks and insurers to disclose their holdings of US dollar bonds issued by local government financing vehicles (LGFVs). The regulator, particularly interested in bonds with less than one-year tenor, is scrutinizing their exposure to high-risk debt. This move follows recent efforts to rein in debt risks and comes as LGFVs' financing activities face increasing scrutiny due to their estimated $9 trillion debt burden. No immediate action has been taken against the financial institutions.

site_title: Life Insurance Association launches guide to explain underwriting process to consumers
summary: The Life Insurance Association Singapore has launched an underwriting guide to explain the process to consumers, aiming for transparency and relatability. The industry's total sum assured in Singapore grew 1.9% to S$145.5 billion in 2023. An enhanced protection gap calculator will also be debuted in the coming weeks, following user feedback.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
In addition to leveraging government schemes to grow one's nest egg, reaching out to professional wealth planning managers can help close gaps and boost financial resilience.
MediShield Life is a basic, mandatory health insurance plan launched in November 2015 to protect all Singaporeans against large medical bills for life, regardless of pre-existing conditions .

In a consultation paper released on Friday (Feb 2), the MAS is proposing that consumers will not have to provide as much information for policies that are recommended based on the Basic Financial Planning Guide.
The newly issued best practices include cooperation among industry players to mitigate “rolling bad apples” – that is, to prevent individuals with prior misconduct from re-entering the industry.
Given the rising numbers, insurers in Singapore have increasingly been looking to extend their services to reach the growing segment of individuals.

site_title: Nippon Steel defends US deal after Biden comes out against bid
summary: Nippon Steel, Japan's largest steelmaker, has defended its US$14.1 billion acquisition bid of US Steel after President Joe Biden expressed opposition to the deal. Nippon Steel reiterated its offer of an additional $1.4 billion in investment and a promise of no layoffs or plant closures until at least September 2026. The US Steel deal has raised concerns about the future of the Japanese bid, with US Steel's shares plummeting 11% on Thursday. The US Steelworkers union also welcomed Biden's comments, calling for the company to remain domestically owned and operated.

images.alt_text: US Steel is based in Pittsburgh in the key battleground state of Pennsylvania, which Joe Biden won in the 2020 election and will fight Donald Trump for again this year.
Nippon Steel's acquisition represents a real opportunity to reverse US Steel's fortunes and improve the prospects of the American steel industry.

site_title: Indonesia’s February trade surplus smallest in nine months
summary: Indonesia recorded its smallest trade surplus in nine months in February, with a surplus of around $870 million, as imports increased 15.84% and exports dropped 9.45%. The country's exports, particularly coal and palm oil, declined due to delays in mining permit issuance and falling demand. Imports, mainly driven by machinery and cereal purchases, also rose higher than expected. The trade surplus is expected to narrow further this year, potentially leading to a modest widening of the current account gap.

images.alt_text: Indonesia Minister of Tourism and Creative Economy Sandiaga Uno wants to strive for more incentives to hold more international-scale music, sports, and cultural events to attract tourists to Indonesia.
Indonesia is the third-largest coal producer in the world after China and India, and is the world’s largest thermal coal exporter.

site_title: Asia: Markets sink on rate worries as US inflation surprises
summary: Asian markets declined on Friday as US wholesale prices unexpectedly rose, sparking concerns over interest rate cuts. The US Federal Reserve's next policy decision on March 19-20 will be closely watched. Despite a slowdown in retail sales, analysts expect the Fed to maintain its cautious stance on rates. The personal consumption expenditures (PCE) deflator, the Fed's preferred gauge of inflation, may come in higher than expected. This has led to a sharp drop in Hong Kong shares, with losses also seen in Tokyo, Sydney, and Singapore.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average retreated 0.4 per cent to 38,905.66, while the broad-based S&P 500 Index dropped 0.3 per cent to 5,150.48 on Thursday.
Across the broader market, outnumber
The Stoxx 600 closed 0.2 per cent lower on Thursday, after notching an all-time peak for the third time in a row earlier in the session.

site_title: Hot stock: No Signboard slumps 45.2% as trading resumes after more than 2 years
summary: No Signboard, a restaurant operator, resumed trading on Friday after a two-year suspension, with shares plummeting 45.2% to S$0.017. The counter rose and fell throughout the day, closing at S$0.014. The resumption comes ahead of the record date for its proposed six-to-one share consolidation on March 21.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
The Catalist-listed restaurant operator said in a bourse filing that the record date for the consolidation will be Mar 21 at 5 pm.
No Signboard has shuttered a few restaurants.
Shares of No Signboard have been suspended from trading since January 2022, as it was unable to demonstrate that it can continue as a going concern.
No Signboard’s board said it views the allegations against interim CEO Lim Teak-Ean “very seriously” and is looking into the allegations.
Facade of No Signboard Seafood restaurant.

site_title: Vanke’s sales drop most since 2018 amid mounting liquidity fear
summary: China Vanke reported a 53% drop in contracted sales for February, its largest decline in six years, amid mounting liquidity fears. The company's long-dated US dollar bonds have plunged below 50 cents on the dollar, indicating investors see a high risk of default. Moody's downgraded Vanke to junk territory, warning of further cuts. The developer is discussing a debt-swap plan with major creditors to avoid defaulting on public bonds, which include a US$600 million note due in June.

images.alt_text: Policymakers have increased pressure on banks to boost their property loans through so-called white lists, as developers struggle to complete projects.
Homebuyers in China are avoiding defaulted developers on concerns about their ability to complete housing projects.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of property developer China Vanke is seen on gates at a construction site in Shanghai, China, March 21, 2017. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the Moody's Corporation headquarters in Manhattan, New York, U.S., November 12, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly
The State Council – China’s Cabinet – is coordinating support efforts for China Vanke, sources say, adding that financial institutions have been requested to make swift progress.

“The government guarantees basic housing needs, and the market fulfils other diversified housing requirements and systems, establishing a market for both renting and buying,” says China’s Housing and Urban-Rural Development Minister Ni Hong.
Vanke, whose biggest shareholder is Shenzhen Metro Group, has faced concerns about its debt obligations since last year.
A mall operated by China Vanke Co. in Shanghai. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
Vanke is one of the few large property developers in China that hasn’t defaulted and is seen as a bellwether for the government’s support of the sector.

site_title: Cambodia’s Techo set to be main international airport next year
summary: Cambodia's Techo International Airport is set to open next year as the country's main international airport, replacing Phnom Penh International Airport. The greenfield airport, designed by British firm Foster + Partners, spans 2,600 hectares and will be the world's ninth-largest airport. The project aims to be a regional transit hub and boost Cambodia's economy, which Thierry Tea, vice-president of OCIC Group, says will help the country compete with other Southeast Asian nations for foreign investors.

images.alt_text: Goh Ruoxue

site_title: New York museum harnessing technology to spotlight art
summary: The Mercer Labs Museum of Art and Technology in New York's financial district is offering an "immersive and sensory" experience by combining art and technology. The museum, which opened in January, features works by painter, sculptor, and sound and light designer Roy Nachum. With an initial investment of $35 million, the museum aims to turn a profit by its formal grand opening on March 28. The museum is located in a former shopping mall and promises to reinvent the traditional art museum format.

images.alt_text: Young Chung, left, and Kibum Kim, owners of Commonwealth and Council gallery in Los Angeles, next to work by Carmen Argote and Jesse Chun on Feb. 23, 2024. Commonwealth and Council started in a one-bedroom apartment and now, their artists are heading to the Whitney Biennial, Venice Biennale and museums during Frieze. (Alex Welsh/The New York Times)
Attendees at the School of American BalletÕs 90th anniversary gala at Lincoln Center in New York, Feb. 26, 2024. (Dolly Faibyshev/The New York Times)
From Thursday, Yoko Ono’s impact on conceptual art will be on display in a retrospective exhibition at the Tate Modern in London.

site_title: Can EU’s gig worker rules tame management by algorithm?
summary: The European Union has reached a deal to regulate management by algorithm for gig workers, with draft rules requiring greater transparency over AI-powered decisions. The Platform Work Directive aims to protect workers from machine-made decisions, including random job assignments and account deactivation. The deal falls short of unions' demands for EU-wide employment criteria, but advocates hail it as a crucial step to address the risks of artificial intelligence in the workplace. The rules will set a standard for future legislation and could be used to establish whether structural injustices, such as racial or gender bias, are baked into the code used to allocate jobs or evaluate performance.

images.alt_text: The disappointing sales forecast overshadowed plans to buy back as much as US$500 million of stock
Delivery Hero, which owns foodpanda, has been trying to divest its loss-making South-east Asian business in a wider effort to reach profitability while maintaining growth.
The counter will start trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Mar 6 (10.30pm Singapore time) under the ticker symbol “RYDE”.
Deliveroo says total orders fell 3 per cent year on year but rebounded a touch in the final quarter to being unchanged on the year.
Food delivery is facing growth challenges as it comes off heady times during the pandemic.

site_title: ‘The genie’s out of the bottle’: When AI meets politics
summary: A record number of elections this year highlights the need for governments to address AI misuse, with major concerns of voter disenfranchisement and misinformation. AI-generated content can be difficult to distinguish from real content, and its misuse can compromise the democratic process. Experts warn that AI can be used to create convincing misinformation, with some companies already stepping in with safeguards. However, the opacity of AI algorithms and the existence of open-source models make it challenging to combat AI-generated misinformation. Regulators are struggling to balance innovation potential and risk, with some jurisdictions already implementing laws to address online falsehoods. Social media platforms are also being urged to detect and take down harmful content, but this may require additional resources.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Under the agreement, AI-generated content could be given a watermark or tagged in the metadata at source, although the signatories acknowledged that “all such solutions have limitations”.
TikTok's "election centres" are designed to better inform Europeans about the electoral process.
US regulators have been considering making AI-generated robocalls illegal, with the fake Joe Biden call giving the effort new impetus.

site_title: Top Philippine homebuilder Ayala Land targets the rich as high rates hammer middle class
summary: Philippine homebuilder Ayala Land is shifting its focus to high-end clients due to higher interest rates squeezing its middle-class buyers. CEO Anna Ma Margarita Bautista-Dy aims to double the company's earnings over the next five years by spending around 500 billion pesos, with a focus on premium projects priced at up to $10 million. This strategy targets customers earning up to three times the country's average annual household income, with 80-90% of new residential projects catering to high-end buyers who pay in full.

images.alt_text: Philippines President Ferdinand Marcos Jr, who is on a three-day working visit in Germany, secured US$4 billion worth of investment pledges from German companies.
China should support developers to finish the construction of homes and deliver to buyers on time, says Yi at the annual session of China’s top political advisory body.

A commercial office building in London, UK, on Wednesday, Nov. 22, 2023. A series of rapid interest rate hikes have sent shock waves through European property markets, reducing the prices that buyers are willing to pay as returns on lower risk assets like government bonds rise. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: TSMC’s 110% rally draws caution, even from the bulls
summary: TSMC's stock has surged over 110% from its October 2022 low, driven by investor enthusiasm for artificial intelligence (AI) and its role in supplying chips for data centers. Despite AI accounting for only 6% of TSMC's revenue last year, analysts are pricing in a significant increase. However, the stock's relative strength index has been in overbought territory, raising concerns about the rally going too far, too fast. The stock's premium over analyst price targets is at its biggest on record, sparking caution even among TSMC's strongest supporters.

images.alt_text: The Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. logo atop a building at the Hsinchu Science Park in Hsinchu, Taiwan, on Tuesday, Jan. 9, 2023. TSMC is scheduled to release earnings results on Jan. 18. Photographer: Mike Kai Chen/Bloomberg
The world’s top chip foundry jumped 5.2 per cent to close at NT$725 (S$30.89) in Taipei on Monday (Mar 4), a record since its stock listing in 1994.
TSMC’s board on Thursday (Feb 29) approves the appointment of YJ Mii and YP Chyn as executive vice-presidents and co-chief operating officers.

site_title: Japan on cusp of ending its negative interest rates experiment
summary: The Bank of Japan is poised to end its eight-year negative interest rate policy, with a final decision expected next week or in April, following a preliminary survey of big firms' wage talks outcome. The survey, set to be released by labour umbrella Rengo, is expected to show wage increases of around 4.5% or 5%, which could clear the way for the BOJ to phase out its massive stimulus programme. An end to negative rates would mark a significant shift away from the BOJ's stimulus programme, which has been in place since 2013.

images.alt_text: Kazuo Ueda, governor of the Bank of Japan (BOJ), during a press conference at Hotel Tivoli after the Group of 20 (G-20) finance ministers and central bank governors meeting in Sao Paulo, Brazil, on Thursday, Feb. 29, 2024. Splits over the conflicts in Gaza and Ukraine prevented Group of 20 finance chiefs from issuing a closing communique after their meetings in Sao Paulo. Photographer: Maira Erlich/Bloomberg
Market rates indicate that demand for yen bonds remains robust even as the BOJ is widely expected to raise interest rates for the first time since 2007 this month or in April.
Japan is now the alternative asset manager’s main focus for property in Asia, and KKR has the capacity to spend anywhere from US$20 million to more than US$1 billion on individual deals.

The UA Zensen, an umbrella group established in 2012 that represents 2,237 unions and 1.8 million workers, announced a weighted average 5.9 per cent wage increase this year for full-time workers and a 6.5 per cent hike for part-timers.
Currently, Japan has less of 0.5 GW of offshore wind power installed and is developing a few floating offshore wind warms, mainly for demonstration purposes.

site_title: BYD takes different route from Tesla by partnering for regional expansion, looking at plug-in hybrids
summary: BYD, the world's top-selling EV brand, is taking a different approach from Tesla in its regional expansion in South-east Asia. BYD is partnering with franchise dealers instead of using a direct-sales model, which is also being adopted by Tesla. This strategy allows BYD to reassure customers face-to-face and expand its retail presence in the region. BYD plans to increase its dealership network in Singapore and other countries, and will also offer plug-in hybrids, which are more expensive but cleaner than conventional petrol-electric hybrids. The company aims to capitalize on the growing demand for EVs in the region and expand its export business.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
BYD Auto Industry general manager Liu Xueliang oversees the Asia Pacific automotive markets at the Chinese maker.
Chinese mainstream electric vehicle (EV) brand BYD went from 12th to fifth in passenger car registrations for 2023.
Chinese automobile maker BYD pipped American counterpart Tesla to be the top electric vehicle seller in Singapore in 2023.
The Japanese carmakers are struggling in the face of increased local competition from manufacturers such as BYD as electric vehicles take hold in China.
Pratarnwong (left) and his sister are part of the Phornprapha family that established the Siam Motors Group.
BYD has been counting on overseas markets for higher profit margins.
To spur electric car demand, the government has introduced tax exemptions for EV car leasing/purchase agreements available to some consumers through their employers.
China-made vehicles are viewed by local customers as better suited to their extensive technology demands and preference for high levels of connectivity.

site_title: CSE Global proposes S$24 million placement to fund acquisitions, investments
summary: CSE Global, a Singapore-listed automation solutions provider, has proposed a S$24 million placement of 60 million new shares, priced at S$0.40, to fund strategic acquisitions and investments. The placement, which represents 9.8% of the existing shares, aims to pursue inorganic growth in its existing markets, including the US, Australia, and New Zealand. The company plans to use the net proceeds to pursue more acquisitions or investments, primarily in its existing markets, following a successful acquisition of Radio One for US$11 million in February 2023.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

CSE Global group managing director Lim Boon Kheng said: “These new contracts will strengthen our pursuit in the infrastructure sector, which is currently driven by the growing megatrends of urbanisation and electrification.”
Lim Boon Kheng, group managing director and chief executive officer of CSE Global.
CSE Global chief executive Lim Boon Kheng says that the group is actively expanding its electrification and critical communications businesses.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Friday’s open; STI down 0.9%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.9% on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 29.66 points to 3,156.74. Losers outnumbered gainers 82 to 34, with Seatrium and Singtel being the most heavily traded counters. Global equities were also down, following a higher-than-anticipated wholesale prices report that rekindled inflation worries. The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed 0.4% lower, while European shares declined 0.2%.

images.alt_text: Stocks to watch: SIA, FLCT, Frasers Property, CSE Global, No Signboard, Chemical Industries

site_title: China home prices fall at slower pace as policy support mounts
summary: China's home prices declined at a slower pace in February, easing slightly to 0.36% from January, as authorities stepped up support for the housing market. Policymakers urged banks to boost property loans through white lists, approving over 200 billion yuan (S$38 billion) in loans as of end-February. New-home sales slumped 60% from a year earlier, while existing home sales overtook new properties for the first time last year. Market watchers caution that stronger policies are needed for a sustainable sales rebound, with some cities removing home-buying restrictions.

images.alt_text: A worker walks along a road as residential buildings stand under construction in Qingdao, China, on Tuesday, May 8, 2018. China is scheduled to release new home price figures on May 16. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
Rising mortgage delinquencies in China could have negative spillovers on both property prices and consumer confidence, say analysts.
The launch of consumption-related Reits comes after China expanded the scope of Reits last year to commercial properties as part of efforts to prop up a battered property sector.

site_title: Byju’s must freeze US$533 million in win for lenders, judge says
summary: A US judge has ordered Byju's, an Indian education-tech firm, to freeze $533 million to protect it from disgruntled lenders who claim the cash should only be used to pay them. The decision, made by US bankruptcy judge John Dorsey, aims to prevent the cash from being spent by the company, which operates under the name Byju's. The order also requires Riju Ravindran, a company director and brother of founder Byju Raveendran, to help locate the missing funds.

images.alt_text: The job cuts are being implemented only at Byju’s parent, Think & Learn, and are not linked to any of its subsidiaries, the report says.
Parent Vedanta Resources faces about US$3 billion of bond repayments in the next two years, and having a professional with previous experience at the group will help Agarwal
Byju’s and its creditors have been mired in a prolonged restructuring conflict after the firm breached covenants on a US$1.2 billion loan.
The job cuts are being implemented only at Byju’s parent, Think & Learn, and are not linked to any of its subsidiaries, the report says.

site_title: Is this what happens when you build a real social safety net, then take it away?
summary: The US economy appears robust on paper, yet Americans are dissatisfied with it, despite having experienced a robust social safety net during the pandemic. The CARES Act increased unemployment benefits and eligibility, helping 5.5 million people avoid poverty in 2020. However, the benefits were abruptly cut off, leaving many feeling financially insecure and fearful of the future. The removal of the safety net has led to a rise in child poverty, family hunger, and evictions, with 17.8 million people losing Medicaid coverage. This has resulted in a sense of perpetual exhaustion and anxiety among Americans, eroding trust in the government's ability to support citizens.

images.alt_text: This MediSave Bonus is aimed at helping Singaporeans build up medical savings to defray rising healthcare costs.
The Majulah Package will cover 1.6 million older Singaporeans and is expected to cost S$8.2 billion in total.

site_title: China central bank leaves key policy rate unchanged, as expected
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, left the key policy rate unchanged at 2.50% as expected when rolling over maturing medium-term loans. The move was in line with market expectations, with 89% of polled market watchers predicting no change. The operation resulted in a net 94 billion yuan fund withdrawal from the banking system, while the central bank injected 13 billion yuan through seven-day reverse repos. This decision comes as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: China’s fiscal stimulus plan may be bigger than it appeared
summary: China's fiscal stimulus plan may be bigger than initially thought, despite an unchanged official budget deficit target of 3% of GDP. A closer look reveals a larger fiscal package, equivalent to 8.2% of GDP, due to a large investment spending component and leftover funds from prior years. The package could provide a significant boost to the economy, which aims to expand by 5% this year, but faces challenges from a persistent property crisis and weak domestic demand. Economists predict Beijing may add to the plan later this year to meet its growth goal.

images.alt_text: People cross an intersection near cranes standing at a construction site in Beijing, China January 15, 2024. REUTERS/Florence Lo

site_title: FLCT to acquire 89.9% interest in 4 logistics assets in Germany from sponsor
summary: FRASERS Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) is acquiring an 89.9% interest in four logistics assets in Germany from its sponsor, Frasers Property, for 129.5 million euros (S$188.9 million). The acquisition is expected to be distribution-per-unit and net-asset-value accretive, increasing FLCT's portfolio occupancy to 95.9% and weighted average lease expiry to 4.4 years. The deal, expected to complete by end-March, will be funded through external debt financing, with Frasers Property planning to use net proceeds for working capital and capital recycling.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Manulife US Reit’s Centerpointe I & II, in Fairfax, Virginia. The Reit halted distributions last year, following a breach in loan covenants after valuations fell.
FLCT expects e-commerce demand to drive demand for quality warehousing.
Frasers Property's unit FPT issues S$400 million of the perpetual securities in April 2019 and S$200 million more in July 2019.
Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust's property operating expenses are up for the half-year ended September mainly due to higher energy and utility expenses.

site_title: BlackRock, Man Group reveal big Japan bets before BOJ decision
summary: Big-name money managers BlackRock and Man Group are betting on Japan's economy to continue growing, with BlackRock expecting gradual rate increases to keep monetary conditions accommodative and supportive of stocks. Meanwhile, RBC BlueBay Asset Management is shorting 10-year Japanese government bonds, while abrdn is placing bullish bets on the yen. These moves are driven by the BOJ's decision on monetary policy, which is expected to define future capital flows and impact Japan's economy. The outcome will also influence the country's blue-chip share gauge, bond yields, and currency.

images.alt_text: Speaking in parliament on Tuesday,  Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda said consumption was weakening for food and daily necessities amid higher prices. He said household spending was improving moderately on hopes for higher wages ahead.
On a quarter-on-quarter basis, Japan's GDP grew 0.1 per cent, compared with the initial 0.1 per cent drop reading and a median forecast for a 0.3 per cent rise.

Japan's household outlays declined by 6.3 per cent in January from a year earlier, the biggest drop since February of 2021, the ministry of internal affairs reported on Friday. It was the 11th straight decline, and it was steeper than economists’ estimate of a 4.1 per cent retreat.

Exports grew 7.6 per cent year-on-year in January driven by demand for cars, car parts and chip-making equipment while imports fell 12.1 per cent reflecting declines of coal, liquefied natural gas and communications equipment.

site_title: New Zealand warns of ‘significantly slower’ growth over next few years
summary: New Zealand's economy unexpectedly contracted in the third quarter, leading to significant downward revisions in earlier quarters and slowing interest rate hike bets. Finance Minister Nicola Willis stated that the country's economic growth will be "significantly slower" over the next few years due to slower productivity growth. Treasury officials have reassessed growth projections, warning of slower growth, but the government plans to promote growth in sectors like space and biomedical engineering. A pre-Budget update is set to be released in two weeks.

images.alt_text: Under the proposed rules, banks must inform RBNZ of all cyber incidents.
While prices have climbed for five straight months, high mortgage rates continue to weigh on the market.

The Reserve Bank of New Zealand's decision was in line with expectations from 28 economists in a Reuters poll with all but one forecasting the central bank would leave the cash rate at a 15-year high for the fourth consecutive meeting.

site_title: China economy likely off to muted start as 5% GDP goal in focus
summary: China's economy is expected to start the year with a muted pace, with property development investment declining 8% in the first two months of 2024. Retail sales and industrial output are also expected to slow, with year-on-year growth rates likely to fall short of the government's 5% target. Despite some temporary boosts to consumption and tourism, economists warn that the overall domestic demand remains sluggish, and the economy will need to improve more in the coming months to hit the benchmark. The People's Bank of China is expected to keep interest rates unchanged on Friday.

images.alt_text: Cash-strapped firms are reversing course after global expansion.
Buildings under construction in Hangzhou.
US President Joe Biden has pledged this week to look into a petition from a group of unions asking his administration to review China’s subsidies for shipbuilders.
China’s 2024 growth target is seen as ambitious because the economy faces weak domestic demand.

site_title: Top Japanese bond managers see another strong year for sales
summary: Japan's top bond managers predict a strong fiscal year for corporate and Samurai bond sales, with total issuance expected to stay high at 15.5-17.6 trillion yen. Despite expected interest rate hikes by the Bank of Japan, demand for yen bonds remains robust. Cheaper borrowing costs, refinancing needs, and funding for mergers and acquisitions will drive new bond deals. Long-term interest rates are expected to remain stable, supporting tighter spreads, according to top brokerages.

images.alt_text: The UA Zensen, an umbrella group established in 2012 that represents 2,237 unions and 1.8 million workers, announced a weighted average 5.9 per cent wage increase this year for full-time workers and a 6.5 per cent hike for part-timers.
Currently, Japan has less of 0.5 GW of offshore wind power installed and is developing a few floating offshore wind warms, mainly for demonstration purposes.

Speaking in parliament on Tuesday,  Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda said consumption was weakening for food and daily necessities amid higher prices. He said household spending was improving moderately on hopes for higher wages ahead.

site_title: US mortgage rates decrease for second week, falling to 6.74%
summary: US mortgage rates decreased for the second consecutive week, falling to 6.74%, the lowest since mid-February. Despite this relief, buyers still face high borrowing costs near 7% and prices holding up in many areas. Experts predict mortgage rates may remain high due to sticky inflation, and the Federal Reserve's next move remains uncertain, potentially complicating purchase decisions for house hunters.

images.alt_text: The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage decreased 18 basis points, the biggest decline in nearly three months, to 6.84 per cent in the week ended Mar 8.
A gauge of contract signings from the National Association of Realtors (NAR) decreases 4.9 per cent to 74.3, after surging to an eight-month high in December.
Mortgage rates stay above 7% as Fed in no rush to ease policy.

Builder sentiment began rebounding late last year as mortgage rates declined, falling below 7% in December.
The Commerce Department says that construction spending rose 0.9 per cent.

site_title: Would it really be better to never see Gabriel Garcia Marquez’s final book?
summary: Gabriel Garcia Marquez's posthumous novel "Until August" has sparked controversy among scholars and fans due to the author's request to destroy the unfinished work. However, Garcia Marquez's sons, Rodrigo and Gonzalo, refused to comply, citing their responsibility to preserve and promote their father's legacy. The publication of the novel is seen as a positive step, making Garcia Marquez's works more available to readers and potentially inspiring future writers. The decision aligns with the example of Franz Kafka's friend Max Brod, who defied the author's request to burn Kafka's unfinished works, ultimately changing the course of literature.

site_title: Samsung poised to win over US$6 billion for expanded US investment
summary: The US Commerce Department is set to award Samsung Electronics more than $6 billion in federal funding as part of the 2022 Chips and Science Act, supporting the company's expanded US investment. This grant will be part of several major awards announced in the coming weeks, including a $5 billion grant to Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC). The funding will aid Samsung's $17 billion project in Texas and additional investments in the US. The announcement is a preliminary agreement that could change, and no final decision has been made.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, FLCT, Frasers Property, CSE Global, No Signboard, Chemical Industries
summary: Singapore Airlines priced US$500 million of 10-year fixed-rate notes at a yield of 5.296% per annum. Frasers Logistics and Commercial Trust (FLCT) acquired four logistics assets in Germany for S$173.1 million, expected to be accretive to its distribution and net asset value. CSE Global proposed a placement of 60 million new shares to raise S$24 million. No Signboard resumed trading after a two-year suspension, and Chemical Industries denied using its office for business linked to its co-founder.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, losers outnumbered gainers 286 to 270 after 1.6 billion securities worth S$1.5 billion changed hands.

site_title: Oil prices climb as revised IEA outlook signals tighter market
summary: Oil prices rose to four-month highs, with Brent crude settling at $85.42 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate ending at $81.26 a barrel. The International Energy Agency (IEA) predicted a tighter market in 2024, citing demand growth of 1.3 million barrels per day and a 800,000 bpd increase in oil supply. Refining margins are strong, incentivizing more crude processing, and Ukrainian drone strikes on Russian refineries may cut Russian gasoline production by over 10%.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of the logo of the International Energy Agency in Paris, France, December 15, 2023. REUTERS/Sarah Meyssonnier/File Photo
Shell says it will target a 15 to 20 per cent reduction in net carbon intensity of its energy products by 2030 compared with 2016 intensity levels.
Brent futures rose US$2.11, or 2.6 per cent, to settle at US$84.03 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude rose US$2.16, or 2.8 per cent, to settle at US$79.72 on Wednesday.

site_title: Need for legal clarity to scale the voluntary carbon market
summary: Singapore needs to provide clarity on the treatment of voluntary carbon credits (VCCs) to scale the voluntary carbon market. The lack of legal clarity hinders the market's growth, making it difficult for companies to buy, sell, and use VCCs as collateral for green financing. International agencies acknowledge the issue, and categorizing VCCs as intangible property would provide greater security and clarity. This would enable financial institutions to accept VCCs as collateral, potentially leading to more financing and a liquid market.

Singapore is well placed to become Asia’s biggest international carbon trading hub and is becoming a unique case study on how the voluntary carbon market can work well.

A female polar bear on the Hudson Bay shoreline, near Churchill, Manitoba, Canada, August 2022. Rising temperatures melt away the Arctic sea ice upon which the bears depend for survival.  Scientists can calculate how much new greenhouse gas emissions will increase the number of ice-free days in the bears' habitats, and how that in turn will affect the percentage of cubs that reach adulthood.

site_title: US: Stocks fall on renewed inflation concerns
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday due to renewed concerns over inflation, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 0.4% and the S&P 500 Index falling 0.3%. A hotter-than-expected wholesale prices report reignited worries about inflation, leading to higher Treasury yields. The Federal Reserve is set to announce its rate decision next week, with analysts expecting no dovish statements from policymakers.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) during morning trading on March 4, 2024 in New York City. site_title: Self-proclaimed Bitcoin inventor is not ‘Satoshi Nakamoto’, UK judge rules
summary: A UK judge has ruled that Australian computer scientist Craig Wright, who claims to be the inventor of Bitcoin under the pseudonym Satoshi Nakamoto, is not the actual author. The Crypto Open Patent Alliance (Copa) sued Wright, citing evidence that his claim was a "brazen lie, an elaborate false narrative supported by forgery on an industrial scale." The judge's ruling is seen as a win for the Bitcoin community, with Copa's spokesperson stating that it ends Wright's "bullying and intimidation" of developers. Wright's financial backers had claimed he was Satoshi, but the court found no evidence to support this claim.

images.alt_text: Michael Saylor started buying Bitcoin in 2020 as an inflation hedge and alternative to holding cash.
Memecoins have been a long-existing phenomenon in crypto.
Spot Bitcoin ETF offerings have attracted a majority of the inflows to crypto markets in 2024.

site_title: Adobe drops on weak forecast fuelled by AI competition fears
summary: Adobe's stock dropped 10% in extended trading after the company provided a weak forecast for the current quarter, citing concerns about competition from generative AI-based startups. The company expects $440 million in new recurring creative business, below analysts' expectations, and has faced anxieties about competition from OpenAI and Canva. Despite announcing a new $25 billion share buyback program and increasing efforts to monetize its AI features, investors remain cautious about the impact of new AI on Adobe's market share.

images.alt_text: IBM said it was using Adobe’s tools, which can generate images from text-based prompts, to help with marketing campaigns.

site_title: Rats in US police headquarters ‘high’ from eating seized marijuana
summary: US police in New Orleans are struggling with a rat infestation at their headquarters, where the rodents are consuming seized marijuana, causing them to become "high". The infestation is widespread, affecting multiple districts, and has been a long-standing issue, with the building originally constructed in 1968. Police Chief Anne Kirkpatrick described the situation as "uncleanable" and criticized the janitorial team for their efforts to clean the area. The city has been pushing for a new headquarters for years, citing the infestation as a major concern.

site_title: More S-Reits could be at risk of suspending distributions
summary: Six Singapore-listed S-Reits have halted or substantially halted distributions, citing worsening balance sheet metrics amid a high interest rate environment. Eight S-Reits have gearing above 42%, with six having already halted distributions, including Indonesia retail Reit Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust, China-based Dasin Retail Trust, and US office Reits Manulife US Reit, Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit, and Prime US Reit. Analysts warn that more players may be at risk, but some analysts believe the situation is contained to specific sectors and no further contagion effect is expected.

site_title: Singapore may see ‘short pause’ in investments as businesses await refundable credit details: PwC tax leader
summary: Singapore may experience a "short pause" in new investments due to uncertainty over refundable credit details following global tax changes, according to PwC global tax policy leader William Morris. The loss of tax incentives, including the Pioneer Certificate Incentive and Development and Expansion Incentive, may affect the amount of investment in the next year, but businesses are unlikely to leave Singapore.

site_title: Democratisation of private assets needs dedicated products, teams, more education
summary: Private asset managers are experimenting with strategies to win over high-net-worth investors. To succeed, they must educate clients and distributors, and build dedicated products, platforms, and teams. Industry observers believe that those who can build mind share among investors will have an advantage. Successful managers will focus on winning over go-betweens, or intermediaries, to expand their reach.

site_title: BlackRock, GIC consider sale of UK gas pipeline assets
summary: BlackRock and Singaporean sovereign wealth fund GIC are exploring the sale of UK gas pipeline assets, Kellas Midstream, valued at approximately $2 billion. The company owns a network of pipes, including the 404-kilometer undersea Central Area Transmission System. A formal sale process is yet to begin, and deliberations are in the early stages. The business is likely to draw interest from infrastructure funds and financial investors seeking exposure in the sector, with the owners considering retaining the asset if no suitable bidders are found.

site_title: Hospitality S-Reits set to continue ‘stellar’ run but at slower pace
summary: Hospitality-focused Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) have achieved positive distribution growth for FY2023, outperforming other sectors. On average, the five hospitality trusts recorded 21% year-on-year growth in distribution per unit (DPU). Notable examples include ARA US Hospitality Trust and CapitaLand Ascott Trust, which increased their DPU by 12.3% and 16% respectively. This marks a continuation of the 'stellar' run for hospitality S-Reits, although at a slower pace than previous years.

site_title: Russian diamond ban creates costly delays, Antwerp diamond dealers say
summary: Antwerp diamond dealers face costly delays due to an EU ban on Russian-origin diamonds, which took effect on March 1. Shipments have been held up for over a week at customs, even if the gems were straight from African producers. The delays threaten the competitive advantage of the centuries-old Antwerp diamond trade, with some dealers warning of the potential erosion of the industry. The EU ban aims to prevent the flow of diamonds from sanctioned states, but its implementation has caused disruptions to supply chains.

site_title: Zara owner Inditex slashes China stores in digital focus
summary: Inditex, the parent company of Zara, has scaled back its physical presence in China, closing a fifth of its stores, while still increasing pre-tax profits by more than 100% to €241 million in 2023. The company's focus on online sales is bearing fruit, with online sales growing 16% to €9.1 billion. Inditex has 192 stores in China, down from 570 in 2019, and plans to launch livestreams for its core brand Zara in the US and Britain this year.

images.alt_text: Zara-owner Inditex widened its lead over Swedish retailer H&M, thanks to its ability to deliver fashion trends faster from nearby suppliers and sell more clothes at higher prices to upmarket shoppers.

site_title:
Hong Kong and Greater Bay Area employers grow less 
optimistic on hiring in 2024
summary: Hong Kong and Greater Bay Area employers have become less optimistic about hiring in 2024, with only 26% expecting an increase in headcounts, down from 37% last year. Top-level executives were more upbeat, but still down from 48% last year. The survey, based on 1,103 respondents, also found that bonuses declined to an average of 2.3 months, and 73% of respondents would consider relocating for work in 2024. The decline in hiring and bonuses reflects the difficulties faced by the financial hub due to a prolonged sell-off in Chinese stocks and sluggish economic growth.

images.alt_text: Over 90 per cent of firms in Hong Kong are urging their workers to increase their office presence, compared with 56 per cent of employers doing so globally.

site_title: Didi Global must face US investor lawsuit over IPO
summary: US District Judge Lewis Kaplan ruled Didi Global must face a US investor lawsuit claiming the Chinese ride-hailing company defrauded investors by concealing a Chinese government order to postpone its 2021 IPO due to cybersecurity and privacy concerns. The IPO raised over $4.4 billion, valuing Didi at $67.5 billion. The judge found investors sufficiently pleaded that Didi and officials intended to defraud them. The case also involves banks that helped Didi go public, and Didi's market value has since dropped to $19 billion.

site_title: UOB aims to double private wealth assets by 2026
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) aims to double its private wealth assets under management to S$352 billion by 2026, driven by increased wealth inflows into Singapore and South-east Asia. The bank's total assets under management rose to a record S$176 billion as of end-December. Private wealth clients, who account for over half of the total assets, saw a 14% growth last year. UOB's presence in South-east Asia was bolstered by the acquisition of Citigroup's retail business in 2022.

images.alt_text: Wee Ee Cheong, 71, has led United Overseas Bank (UOB) since 2007.

site_title: US business inventories unchanged in January
summary: US business inventories remained unchanged in January, contrary to the 0.5% estimated increase in an advance report. Retail inventories rose 0.4%, while motor vehicle inventories climbed 0.8%. Wholesale inventories declined 0.3%, and business sales dropped 1.3%. This unexpected outcome may impact GDP growth estimates, which are converging around a 2% pace for the first quarter.

site_title: United Airlines close to gaining Airbus jets after Boeing Max 10 delays
summary: United Airlines is close to securing Airbus A321neo jets to replace Boeing 737 Max 10 aircraft, which are at least five years behind schedule due to certification delays. The airline is in final negotiations for 30-40 planes, with deliveries expected between 2025 and 2027. This move could give Airbus a rare opportunity to undercut Boeing's rival. United CEO Scott Kirby has stated that he will only do a deal if the economics work, and the airline is likely to end up with a mix of Max 9s and A321s.

site_title: Biden opposes Nippon Steel takeover of US Steel
summary: US President Joe Biden opposes the proposed $14.1 billion sale of US Steel to Japan's Nippon Steel, citing election-year considerations and concerns about national security. Biden's stance comes amid a federal review of the deal and amid a push to rebuild American manufacturing. US Steel is based in Pennsylvania, a key battleground state, and unions have joined in opposing the sale, citing concerns about jobs and economic security. The move is seen as a boost to Biden's election campaign against Donald Trump, who has also opposed the deal, calling it "horrible."

site_title: China to invest in Canada mining despite crackdown, envoy says
summary: China's ambassador to Canada, Cong Peiwu, stated that the country will continue to invest in Canada's mining sector despite Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's crackdown on foreign investment. Cong said China's investments provide much-needed funding to Canadian mining firms, which are essential for the global transition away from fossil fuels. He urged Canada's government to respect market laws and not over-stretch the concept of national security in its review of Chinese investments.

site_title: AliExpress targeted in EU probe over possibly illegal online products
summary: The European Commission launched an investigation into AliExpress, a popular online marketplace, over concerns about the potential dissemination of illegal products such as fake medicines and non-compliant food. The probe is under the EU's Digital Services Act, which requires large online platforms to tackle illegal and harmful content. AliExpress has been designated as a very large online platform and has until April 3 to respond to questions about its measures to tackle these issues. The company has stated it respects applicable rules and regulations and will work with authorities to comply with standards.

site_title: Chemical Industries says companies linked to co-founder do not use its office for business
summary: Chemical Industries, a Singapore-based chemical manufacturer, has clarified that several firms linked to its co-founder Lim Soo Peng do not use its office premises for business operations, contrary to concerns raised by the Securities Investors Association (Sias). The companies, which share the same address, use the premises solely as their registered office. Chemical Industries' board has been aware of the arrangement, and there is no conflict of interest. The company is currently in the process of appointing a new CEO, with a timeline to be determined.

site_title: US: Wall St ticks up as traders stick to rate-cut bets after data deluge
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, March 14, as investors stuck to rate-cut bets despite hotter-than-expected inflation data. The S&P 500 rose 0.19% to 5,175.14, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.19% to 16,209.19. The Dow Jones Industrial Average increased 0.20% to 39,122.39, driven by traders' expectations of a Fed interest rate cut in the coming months.

site_title: Europe: Shares ease from record high on rate cut uncertainty
summary: European shares closed 0.2% lower on Thursday, marking a third consecutive record high, amid uncertainty over US interest rate cuts due to sticky inflation data. The US producer price index (PPI) increased more than expected in February, fueling concerns about inflation and casting doubt on a June interest rate cut. Despite this, European Central Bank policymakers still back a June interest rate cut, while shares of miners and healthcare companies rose. The Stoxx 600 ended the day 5.7% higher for the year, with Encavis shares surging 25.2% on a takeover offer.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average retreated 0.4 per cent to 38,905.66, while the broad-based S&P 500 Index dropped 0.3 per cent to 5,150.48 on Thursday.

site_title: KKR to buy Japan real estate even after BOJ raises rates
summary: KKR plans to continue buying real estate assets in Japan despite the Bank of Japan's potential interest rate hike. The alternative asset manager can spend up to $1 billion on individual deals and views Japan's property sector as attractive due to low borrowing costs. With the BOJ expected to scrap its negative-rate policy, monetary conditions are expected to remain accommodative, making Japan a key focus for KKR's Asian property investments.

site_title: US wholesale prices jump again in February
summary: US wholesale prices jumped 0.6% in February, exceeding expectations, driven by higher petrol prices and other goods. The producer price index (PPI) rose, supporting a patient view on monetary policy from the Federal Reserve, which may consider cutting interest rates. The index for final demand goods rose 1.2%, with petrol prices increasing 6.8%. The data is closely watched by the Fed as it battles inflation, with a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index set by Citigroup.

site_title: Citigroup probes senior IPO banker over bullying claims
summary: Citigroup is investigating allegations of workplace harassment against a senior banker, Edward Ruff, who is accused of shouting insults at subordinates and intimidating an analyst. The incidents, including one on November 13, are being looked into as part of the bank's efforts to change its culture. Ruff, a managing director, has been on leave since January and a Citigroup spokesperson said the bank will take "appropriate action" if substantiated complaints are made. This comes after Citigroup's CEO, Jane Fraser, pledged to bring empathy to the bank's culture.

The fixed-rate notes will bear a coupon of 5.25% per annum until their maturity on March 21, 2034. DBS and Citigroup are joint global coordinators for the bond, alongside HSBC and JPMorgan.

site_title: SoftBank explores investment in French AI startup Mistral, sources say
summary: SoftBank is exploring a potential investment in French AI startup Mistral, which could value the company at over $2 billion. Mistral, founded by former Google and Meta engineers, has gained attention for its challenges to US dominance in AI. The investment would follow a $415 million funding round in December, valuing Mistral at $2 billion. SoftBank's interest in AI investments comes after the firm stayed out of recent funding rounds for generative AI startups like OpenAI.

site_title: Industry body launches salary guide to dispel notion that accountants are paid less than their peers
summary: The Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants (Isca) has launched a salary guide to promote wage transparency and dispel the myth that accountants in Singapore are paid less than their peers. The guide details typical remuneration figures for accountants at different stages of their careers and lists various career paths open to those with an accounting background. The move aims to encourage more people to consider accounting as a discipline, particularly during the yearly university application window in March, which has seen a decline in enrollment in accounting courses in Singapore.

site_title: Singapore AI startup Sqreem buys Australia-based Trade Indy
summary: Sqreem, a Singapore-based AI startup, has acquired Australia-based Trade Indy for US$30 million through a share swap. Trade Indy, founded in 2014, helps clients optimize multichannel digital marketing campaigns using data analysis. Sqreem, which already has a presence in 80 countries, plans to raise funding for acquisitions and organic growth, with CEO Ian Chapman-Banks eyeing European and UK opportunities. This acquisition expands Sqreem's global reach and enhances its AI-based marketing solutions, solidifying its position in the rapidly growing AI industry.
