site_title: Hyundai and Kia to recall nearly 170,000 EVs over software problem in South Korea
summary: Hyundai and Kia will recall nearly 170,000 electric vehicles in South Korea due to software issues in the charging systems. The affected models include Hyundai's Ioniq-series and Genesis models, and Kia's EVs. The errors could cause the vehicles to stop while driving. The voluntary recalls, starting on March 18, aim to prevent customer inconvenience and prioritize vehicle safety.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man rides a scooter past a Hyundai automobile showroom in Mumbai, India, February 9, 2022. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas//File Photo

site_title: Why world powers are wooing resource-rich Greenland
summary: Global powers are increasingly interested in Greenland due to its vast natural resources, including coal, zinc, copper, iron ore, and rare earths. The island's strategic location between North America and Eurasia makes it a critical point for trade and commerce. As the Arctic ice cap melts, Greenland is emerging as a major prize, with China being one of the key players. The island's unique position and resources have sparked a modern gold rush, with the potential for significant economic and geopolitical implications.

images.alt_text: The high sediment discharge caused by the intense ice melt in Godthabsfjord, in southwestern Greenland in a satellite image on July 22, 2022. The prolonged high temperatures in Greenland have triggered rapid melting of the ice sheet, releasing about 6 billion tonnes of water per day into the ocean between July 15 and 17, 2022.
The Ocean Explorer becomes stuck at about noon on Monday (Sep 11) in the Alpefjord, roughly 870 miles (1,400 kilometers) northeast of Greenland's capital, Nuuk.

site_title: IEA sees subdued oil demand growth as economic headwinds remain
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) forecasts oil demand growth this year at 1.3 million barrels per day (bpd), down from 2023, due to subdued economic growth and China's slowing oil demand. The forecast lags Opec's more bullish outlook by nearly 1 million bpd. Economic headwinds, including improving vehicle efficiencies and expanding electric vehicle fleets, are expected to weigh on demand. If Opec maintains voluntary cuts, the market is likely to be in a slight deficit, supporting oil prices.

images.alt_text: IEA's new office in Singapore will focus on scaling up the deployment of renewables and other clean energy technologies, among other things.

site_title: Long-term China LGFV bond makes rare comeback amid frenzy demand
summary: A Hangzhou Municipal Construction Investment Group issued a 20-year yuan bond priced at 3% yuan, marking a rare comeback for long-dated notes in the heavily indebted sector. The 300 million yuan bond had a subscription ratio of 3.57, indicating strong investor demand. This sale shows resilience in the local government financing vehicle sector amidst China's economic slowdown and rising debt pressure.

images.alt_text: The unusual decision for a state-owned enterprise to raise funds for an LGFV is a sign Guizhou province, one of the poorest and most indebted regions of China, is stepping up efforts to address the financing pressures brought on by maturing LGFV debt.
Banks are estimated to have issued 4.5 trillion yuan (S$844 billion) in net new yuan loans last month, more than tripling the 1.17 trillion yuan in December.
LGFVs have been in focus in China’s property slump as many have had severe cash-flow strains.
China has rolled out several measures to resolve local government debt risks, and new issuance of LGFV debt is tightly regulated.

site_title: Investment in Germany by foreign firms drops to decade low, study finds
summary: Foreign investment in Germany dropped to a decade low in 2023, totaling around 22 billion euros (S$32.05 billion), according to a study. This decline is attributed to high labor and other costs, driving companies to relocate to cheaper locations. The study warns that repeated high net outflows indicate the first symptoms of deindustrialization, which could accelerate significantly if the political framework conditions remain unchanged.

images.alt_text: Robotic arms weld parts to be used in an automobile chassis in the Volkswagen AG factory, as part of the Think Blue sustainability initiative in Wolfsburg, Germany, on Friday, May 19, 2017. European car sales fell the most in four years in April as the shift of Easter from March reduced buyers time for shopping, while registrations in the U.K. were further sapped by tax changes. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

site_title: No Signboard to resume trading on March 15
summary: No Signboard, a Singapore restaurant operator, will resume trading on March 15, nearly two years after voluntarily suspending its trading due to uncertainty over its ability to continue as a going concern. The company has satisfied the necessary conditions to resume trading, including a legal opinion on its November 2022 extraordinary general meeting resolutions and disclosure of pro forma financial statements. Trading will begin in consolidated shares of 100, with the record date set for March 21.

images.alt_text: The Catalist-listed restaurant operator said in a bourse filing that the record date for the consolidation will be Mar 21 at 5 pm.
No Signboard's interim chief executive Lim Teck-Ean said the company is in talks with “no less than six to seven parties” regarding mergers and acquisitions (M&A)
The group's shares have been suspended from trading since January 2022.
No Signboard has shuttered a few restaurants.
Shares of No Signboard have been suspended from trading since January 2022, as it was unable to demonstrate that it can continue as a going concern.
No Signboard’s board said it views the allegations against interim CEO Lim Teak-Ean “very seriously” and is looking into the allegations.
Facade of No Signboard Seafood restaurant.
In an Acra filing dated Jan 16, No SigbLim Teck-Ean owns 2 million shares in Gazelle Capital, translating to a 50 per cent stake in the entity’s share capital of 4 million shares

The funds provided by No Signboard's investor will be earmarked for the company’s general working capital and funding requirements, and or other purposes determined by the board and authorised by the investor.
It appears that No Signboard is banking all its hopes on a memorandum of understanding for up to S$5 million in investments.

site_title: Greenback rallies on US retail, producer price data
summary: The US dollar index rose 0.39% to 103.15 after the release of US retail sales and producer price data on March 14, 2024. The producer price data had a significant impact on the dollar's movement, with the greenback rallying in response. This marks a positive turn for the dollar, which had been under pressure in recent months due to economic concerns. The increase in the dollar index suggests a strengthening US economy and a potential decrease in inflation.

images.alt_text: Sheets of one hundred dollar bills sit in a roll before being sorted at the Bureau of Engraving and Printing in Washington, D.C., U.S., on Wednesday, Oct. 14, 2009. Goldman Sachs Group Inc. said the dollar is likely to extend drops against the euro and commodity backed currencies over the coming six months, based on the greenback's correlation with cyclical assets and capital flows. Photographer: Andrew Harrer/Bloomberg

site_title: European regulator says it would pull Boeing approval if needed
summary: European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) acting executive director Luc Tytgat stated that if necessary, EASA would suspend its indirect approval of Boeing's jet production. This comes after a door plug tore off a 737 MAX 9 jet in mid-air due to missing bolts, and an audit found multiple instances of poor controls. Tytgat expressed reassurance that Boeing is addressing the issue, but warned that more fatal accidents could prompt drastic action, including suspending recognition.

images.alt_text: The Boeing Co. logo is displayed outside of company offices near Los Angeles International Airport (LAX) in El Segundo, California on January 18, 2024. (Photo by Patrick T. Fallon / AFP)

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Thursday, March 14, 2024 (Ep 22)
summary: Market Focus Daily reports on Thursday's market movements, including a 0.3% rise in Singapore's STI index, and a US$80 billion crash in India's small-cap stocks, triggering worries of a bubble. Meanwhile, Singtel denied a report of an Optus sale, and traders await US producer prices data tonight.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Thursday.

site_title: Singapore stocks gain as regional markets end mixed; STI up 0.8%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.8% on Thursday, driven by gains from Sembcorp Industries, DBS, and Keppel. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,186.40, with Emperador being the worst performer. Analysts from DBS Group Research predict the STI will be range-bound between 3,030 and 3,300 in the coming months, citing attractive valuations and high dividend yields.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Hong Kong resumed its recent rally after Wednesday’s dip, while Shanghai saw much-needed gains, as did Singapore, Seoul, Taipei and Manila.

site_title: BNP Paribas cuts investment banking bonuses on weak trading
summary: BNP Paribas has cut investment banking bonuses by about 5% due to a weak year for deals and trading. The move mirrors decisions by other European investment banks, including Deutsche Bank, which reduced bonuses by 10%. The decision was made after considering a deeper cut but was influenced by US banks keeping bonuses largely unchanged. BNP Paribas' trading revenue fell 7% last year, with a 11% decline in its fixed income unit. The bank's Material Risk Takers received 593 million euros in variable compensation last year.

images.alt_text: BNPL player Atome has seen its CEO leave for GoTo Financial, as players retreat and refocus away from BNPL.
BNP Paribas intends to generate the additional savings this year, increasing its cumulated savings goal over the 2022-to-2025 period to 2.7 billion euros.

site_title: Cost-cutting programme at Volkswagen brand bears first fruit
summary: Volkswagen's core mass-market brands, including Volkswagen, Skoda, and SeaT/CUPRA, reported an 80% increase in operating profit to 7.3 billion euros in 2023, driven by higher unit sales. The success is attributed to closer cooperation between the brands, which has led to improved efficiency, competitiveness, and innovation. The company expects this trend to continue, bolstering results and sales this year, particularly due to better raw materials and components supply.

site_title: Tata said to consider buying Disney stake in India TV platform
summary: Tata Group is in preliminary talks with Walt Disney to acquire Disney's significant minority stake in Tata Play, a subscription television broadcaster in India, valued at about US$1 billion or more. The move comes as Disney signs a merger deal with Viacom 18 Media, creating an US$8.5 billion entertainment giant. This follows similar exits by other media giants, including Paramount Global's sale of its Indian TV business to Reliance Industries. The deal would give Tata Play full control and reflects a consolidation of the Indian media industry.

site_title: Cisco gains EU antitrust nod for US$28 billion Splunk acquisition
summary: Cisco Systems has received unconditional EU antitrust approval for its $28 billion acquisition of cybersecurity firm Splunk, its largest-ever deal. The European Commission found no competition issues, citing a sufficient number of alternative players and the merged entity's inability to shut out rivals. The deal aims to boost Cisco's software business amid a boom in artificial intelligence and help offset a post-pandemic slowdown in demand. The acquisition is expected to be completed without conditions.

site_title: Deliveroo beats earnings guidance, sees positive cash flow in 2024
summary: Deliveroo reported core earnings of £85 million for 2023, beating expectations, and expects further progress in 2024 with a move into positive cash flow. Total orders fell 3% year-over-year but rebounded in the final quarter, while total order value rose 3% due to inflation. Deliveroo's CEO, Will Shu, predicts core earnings to increase to £110-130 million and expects the company to break even on free cash flow in 2024. Shares rose 2.7% following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Food delivery is facing growth challenges as it comes off heady times during the pandemic.

A Deliveroo food delivery rider in Singapore. The UK Supreme Court has ruled that his counterparts in the UK are not entitled to undertake collective bargaining because these riders do not have an "employment relationship" with Deliveroo.
FILE PHOTO: A delivery worker with a backpack of Deliveroo rides a bike in Nice, France, October 25, 2022.  REUTERS/Eric Gaillard/File Photo

site_title: China conglomerates speed up asset sales to beat credit squeeze
summary: China's cash-strapped conglomerates are accelerating asset sales to beat a credit squeeze, reversing a trend of aggressive expansion. Companies like Fosun International and Alibaba Group are selling off assets, including international stakes, to raise cash and repay debt. The central government's scrutiny of debt-fuelled expansion has led to increased pressure on firms to offload assets. Big tech companies, including Alibaba, are also revamping portfolios and refocusing on core businesses. The move is expected to lead to more M&A activity, with companies looking to shore up balance sheets and boost growth.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden has pledged this week to look into a petition from a group of unions asking his administration to review China’s subsidies for shipbuilders.
China’s 2024 growth target is seen as ambitious because the economy faces weak domestic demand.
Trade data for the first two months of the year is typically combined to avoid distortions from the Chinese New Year holiday.
Zheng Shanjie, chair of the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC), says he expects the world’s second-largest economy to have a good first quarter.

site_title: Hapag-Lloyd to seek cost cuts after net profit slump
summary: Hapag-Lloyd, the world's fifth-largest container liner, reported an 83% drop in annual net profit to 3 billion euros, citing global vessel oversupply and the Red Sea crisis as major factors. To remain profitable, the company will cut expenses, including adapting sailings and ports, and saving on procurement. CEO Rolf Habben Jansen expects a difficult market environment, with earnings before interest and taxes forecasted to be between minus 1 billion euros to 1 billion euros. The company also cut its dividend to 9.25 euros per share from 63 euros.

images.alt_text: Hapag-Lloyd, the world’s fifth biggest container liner, has joined other shippers in taking longer, costlier journeys around Africa, after one of its ships was attacked on Dec 15.
“The conflict in the Red Sea negatively impacted transport volumes at the end of the year, as the rerouting of ships around the Cape of Good Hope extended voyage times,” Hapag-Lloyd says.

site_title: China’s Nio and CATL team up to develop longer life batteries
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker Nio has partnered with battery giant CATL to develop longer life batteries as part of efforts to lower overall EV costs. The partnership aims to leverage technologies from both companies to reduce "full life cycle" costs of batteries, a key factor for Nio's thousands of battery-swapping and charging stations. Nio's founder and CEO William Li stated that one of the most important problems unsolved is battery life, with the partnership seeking to address this issue. The partnership is expected to lower battery costs for Nio's EVs.

images.alt_text: Faster charging times are seen as key to persuading more customers to switch to EVs.

The potential R&D expansion in Hong Kong aligns with CATL’s strategy to place greater emphasis on exporting battery technologies, not just batteries, as Chinese electric vehicles (EVs) and batteries face intensifying scrutiny from foreign governments.
CATL says Yichun lithium mine is producing normally as planned after the holiday.
The cost to build the entire operation is estimated at about US$1.2 billion, and Nouveau Monde Graphite plans to raise US$725 million in debt and US$475 million in equity.

site_title: Singapore Airlines readies 10-year dollar bond issuance, term sheet shows
summary: Singapore Airlines is set to issue a 10-year dollar bond, with initial price guidance at the 10-year US Treasury rate plus 150 basis points. The deal size could reach $500 million, with orders worth over $1 billion already lodged. The company cited an "attractive" 10-year US dollar bond issuance, regularly reviewing its funding requirements.

site_title: US retail sales rebound in February; weekly jobless claims fall
summary: US retail sales rebounded 0.6% in February, driven by increases at auto dealerships and petrol service stations, but consumer spending is slowing due to inflation and higher borrowing costs. This follows a revised January sales drop of 1.1%, down from the initial 0.8% decline. Initial jobless claims fell 1,000 to 209,000 for the week ending March 2, a seasonally adjusted decrease. The Atlanta Federal Reserve forecasts GDP growth at a 2.5% annualized rate in Q1, with consumer spending supported by a tight labor market despite higher inflation.

images.alt_text: Housing costs are the single biggest contributor to the country’s ongoing inflation, Yellen told Fox Business while on a trip to Kentucky to highlight President Joe Biden’s efforts to boost economic growth.
Goldman Sachs Asset Management (GSAM) had begun to deploy more cash in real estate in Europe and Japan over the past three months, without quantifying its investment.
The US added 275,000 jobs last month, in an unexpected pickup after January's figure was revised significantly lower.
Imports of capital goods as well as those of motor vehicles parts and engines were the highest on record, which bodes well for business investment on equipment.
Nonfarm productivity, which measures hourly output per worker, increased at an unrevised 3.2 per cent annualised rate last quarter, the Labor Department’s Bureau of Labor Statistics says.
The US labour market is steadily loosening up, with 1.45 job openings per every unemployed person in January, government data showed on Wednesday.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 14)
summary: Singapore's job vacancies rose to 79,800 in the fourth quarter of 2023, indicating a "moderately tight labour market". The job vacancy to unemployed persons ratio has been increasing since March 2021, now at 1.74. Meanwhile, the re-entry rate of retrenched workers fell to 61.5% in Q4, down from 67.3% in Q3.

images.alt_text: Generic image of office workers crossing the road during lunchtime in the CBD; use for articles relevant to the working population in Singapore.

site_title: Shell weakens climate targets with growing bet on gas
summary: Shell has weakened its 2030 carbon reduction target, aiming for a 15-20% reduction in net carbon intensity compared to 2016 levels, down from its previous 2035 objective. The move follows a similar shift by rival BP and comes amid increased investor pressure on oil majors to focus on profitable businesses. Shell still plans to cut emissions to net zero by 2050, citing uncertainty in the energy transition and strong gas demand expectations. The company's retreat reflects a broader slowdown in climate policy rollouts and rising energy costs.

images.alt_text: The deals team is the latest to be affected by job cuts, following similar moves across business units such as low-carbon solutions, chemicals and IT.

Oil storage silos beyond waterlogged land at the Shell Plc Pernis refinery in Rotterdam, Netherlands, on Sunday, Feb. 11, 2024. Shell Pernis is located in Rotterdam in the heart of Europe’s oil-trading hub, with capacity to process around 400,000 barrels of crude a day. Photographer: Peter Boer/Bloomberg

PIXGENERIC
Temasek International office at Orchard Road, July 5, 2023.
India's Enforcement Directorate says 1.23 billion rupees have been frozen.

site_title: Two musicals take you back to the classroom
summary: Two new musicals are set to premiere in Singapore, tackling themes of education and personal growth. "Secondary: The Musical" by musician weish and Checkpoint Theatre explores the struggles and imperfections of the education system, while "Matilda The Musical" brings the beloved Roald Dahl children's book to the stage, boasting pitch-perfect music and lyrics. Both productions debut in April, offering unique perspectives on the challenges of growing up and the power of storytelling.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
In the participatory VR show Le Bal De Paris, audience get to be avatar dressed Chanel-designed fineries.
Dune: Part Two is a political sci-fi tale that holds a mirror to our current world.

site_title: 🌾 Does the grass keep getting greener for job-hoppers?
summary: Job-hopping among young adults, particularly Gen Z, has been a topic of discussion. While some argue that switching jobs regularly can help figure out career goals, others claim it can lead to a "jumpy" CV and prevent deep expertise in a particular field. Experts suggest that job-hopping is acceptable in the first seven years of one's career, but after that, it's essential to commit to a definite career path. However, with the current job market, job-hopping is at its lowest in six years, making it crucial to carefully consider the reasons behind a job change and whether it aligns with long-term career goals.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim
Workers have turned to job-hopping as a mean to hopefully fast-track their career, but experts warn that some downsides persist, especially in today's economy.

site_title: China’s Tencent takes over two ByteDance video game teams: source
summary: Tencent has acquired two video game teams from ByteDance, a Shenzhen-based studio working on an action game and an East-China-based studio working on an anime game. The move comes after ByteDance retreated from the gaming business last year. The two teams have formed a new company named "Saluosi", which is now 100% owned by a Tencent investment company. This acquisition is part of Reuters' earlier report that ByteDance was in talks with multiple prospective buyers, including Tencent, to sell its gaming assets.

site_title: Bank of Korea cautious in final stage of inflation fight
summary: The Bank of Korea has expressed caution about a potential policy shift amid persistent economic risks, including US interest rate cuts and uncertainty over the domestic housing market and debt. A premature shift away from tighter monetary settings could undermine policy credibility and send the wrong message to financial markets. The central bank cited risks related to home prices and household debt, as well as investments in commercial property markets abroad, and stated that it was too early for a pivot in monetary policy. The Bank of Korea will continue to monitor these risks closely.

images.alt_text: South Korea's transformation from economic minnow to industrial giant owes much to its sprawling, family-run conglomerates known as chaebols.
President Yoon Suk Yeol (R) has spearheaded a package of medical reform plans and taken a hard line against the protesters, moving to suspend their medical licences for defying return-to-work orders.

The Personal Information Protection Commission says it has been investigating overseas e-commerce platforms since last month, after a parliament audit last year raised questions about data handling by platforms such as AliExpress and Temu.

site_title: Japan high court says same-sex marriage bar is unconstitutional
summary: Japan's high court has ruled that the country's ban on same-sex marriage is unconstitutional. The ruling, made in the northern region of Sapporo, follows a split among lower courts on the matter. The decision does not grant same-sex couples the right to marry, but rather declares the ban unconstitutional. The ruling's impact on the country's laws and social policies remains to be seen, with one of the plaintiffs expressing surprise and relief at the outcome.

images.alt_text: Participants march during the Tokyo Rainbow Pride parade, celebrating advances in LGBTQ rights and calling for marriage equality, in Tokyo, Japan, April 23, 2023. REUTERS/Issei Kato

site_title: AstraZeneca to buy Amolyt Pharma for US$1.05 billion to boost rare-disease portfolio
summary: AstraZeneca agreed to acquire Amolyt Pharma for $1.05 billion, aiming to boost its rare-disease portfolio. The deal includes an $800 million upfront payment and a $250 million contingent payment upon achieving a regulatory milestone. The acquisition, expected to close by the third quarter of 2024, complements AstraZeneca's growing rare diseases portfolio, which reached $7.8 billion in revenue in 2023. This deal follows a string of acquisitions and licensing deals, solidifying AstraZeneca's position in the pharmaceutical industry.

site_title: Foxconn reports 33% rise in fourth-quarter net profit
summary: Foxconn, the world's largest contract electronics manufacturer, reported a 33% rise in net profit for the fourth quarter of 2023, reaching US$1.6 billion. This marks the second consecutive quarter of growth for the Apple supplier. The company's strong figures follow better-than-expected profits in its third quarter, driven by rising demand ahead of the holiday season. Foxconn has been diversifying its manufacturing supply chain and investing in artificial intelligence technology, but faces challenges, including a recent decline in iPhone sales in China.

images.alt_text: Foxconn poised to nominate chip boss as Taiwan group's next chairman

site_title: Saudi Arabia in talks to add top Wall Street banks to Aramco share sale
summary: Saudi Arabia is in talks to add top Wall Street banks to a secondary share sale of oil giant Aramco, which could raise up to $20 billion. JPMorgan is expected to be one of the main underwriters, along with Bank of America and Morgan Stanley. This follows the kingdom's previous IPO in 2020, which raised $30 billion. The proceeds from the new offering could help fund diversification initiatives by Crown Prince Mohammed Salman, as Aramco's market value stands at $2 trillion.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This picture shows Aramco tower at the King Abdullah Financial District (KAFD) in Riyadh on April 16, 2023. Saudi Arabia has ordered energy giant Aramco to maintain its oil production capacity at 12 million barrels per day, abandoning a planned increase, the firm said on January 30, 2024. "Aramco announces that it has received a directive from the ministry of energy to maintain its maximum sustainable capacity (MSC) at 12 million barrels per day" instead of ramping it up to 13 million bpd, the firm said in a statement. (Photo by Fayez Nureldine / AFP)

Signage above the Saudi Aramco booth on day two of the Abu Dhabi International Petroleum Exhibition and Conference (ADIPEC) in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates, on Tuesday, Oct. 3, 2023. The annual strategic energy conference runs from Oct 2-5. Photographer: Christopher Pike/Bloomberg

site_title: Swiftonomics: Indonesia seeks to work with Singapore for major events
summary: Indonesia is seeking to collaborate with Singapore to host international events, including concerts and sports events, to attract tourists. The country's Minister of Tourism and Creative Economy, Sandiaga Uno, met with Singapore's Minister-in-charge of Trade Relations, Grace Fu, to discuss potential areas for collaboration. Indonesia is open to offsetting the carbon footprint from events and is exploring alternatives to Singapore, such as its Batam and Bintan islands. The country aims to attract 14.3 million foreign visitors by 2024 and is offering incentives to attract more investors and travelers to the region.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
Goh Ruoxue
LMIRT units were unchanged at S$0.013 – its 52-week low – on Wednesday, before the non-payment of distribution on the 2016 perpetual securities was announced.

site_title: Hong Kong weighs scaling back plan to open stock market in typhoons
summary: Hong Kong is considering scaling back its plan to keep trading open during typhoons, with a possible step-back to closing markets during the highest typhoon alerts (typhoon signal 9 or 10). This would be a reversal of the city's goal to remain open despite extreme weather events. Hong Kong typically experiences six typhoons annually from June to October, and its markets have previously closed during severe storms. The decision aims to avoid trading halts and ensure market stability.

images.alt_text: The 69-year-old Carlson Tong, who is HKEX’s non-executive director, has emerged as the frontrunner to take over from current Chair Laura Cha, two sources say.
Spin-off listings have boosted Hong Kong’s competitiveness by increasing the number of new-economy listings.
Hong Kong’s imports of industrial metals such as copper and aluminium are a small fraction of global supplies.

site_title: Space reconfiguration: From cluttered to tidy, with plenty of storage thrown in
summary: A couple, the Ngs, renovated their 1,500 sq ft apartment in Tanah Merah, Singapore, after 10 years of living there. The renovation aimed to increase storage space and create a minimalist, Japanese-style aesthetic. Architect Zeeson Teoh reconfigured the apartment, removing walls to create a wider entrance, swapping the living and dining areas, and incorporating storage solutions. The renovation also included features such as a moveable banquette seating, a dry kitchen, and a second study-cum-dining counter. The result is a calm, orderly home with improved circulation and functionality, meeting the couple's needs for the next decade.

site_title: Deutsche Bank CEO's 2023 pay dips to 8.7 million euros
summary: Deutsche Bank CEO Christian Sewing's 2023 pay dropped to 8.7 million euros, down from 8.9 million euros in 2022, due to a fall in profit. The bank's 2023 profit fell to 4.21 billion euros, a decline from 5.03 billion euros the previous year. The Postbank unit's integration issue led to bonus reductions and a 6% shrinkage in variable staff compensation. The bank's supervisory board deemed the issue "unacceptable" and forced additional resources to fix it.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank laundering probe yields tax raids across Germany
New CDS nearly halves Deutsche Bank default protection costs
Deutsche Bank bosses set to face angry shareholders

site_title: Nissan, Honda weighing EV partnership in Japan, local media say
summary: Nissan Motor is reportedly considering a partnership with Honda Motor to jointly develop electric vehicles in Japan, amid declining sales in China. The move comes as both automakers weigh cutting production capacity in China. Nissan's CEO Makoto Uchida recently stated the company is facing a tough business environment, while Honda's spokesperson declined to comment on the partnership rumors. Analysts see the potential partnership as a positive development for both companies, but Honda's hesitation raises questions about its willingness to collaborate.

images.alt_text: Anhui Jianghuai Automobile (JAC Motors), Volkswagen’s partner in its third China JV, says the two sides will boost the JV’s registered capital to 13.9 billion yuan (S$2.6 billion) from 7.4 billion yuan.
FILE PHOTO: Tesla logo is seen on the steering wheel of an electric vehicle at a dealership in Durango, northern Spain, October 30, 2023. REUTERS/Vincent West
The SU7 has “super electric motor” technology capable of delivering acceleration speeds faster than Tesla and Porsche’s EVs.
China-made vehicles are viewed by local customers as better suited to their extensive technology demands and preference for high levels of connectivity.

site_title: Chinese foreign minister to visit Australia next week: The Guardian
summary: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi will visit Australia next week, amid efforts by the Anthony Albanese-led Labor government to repair ties with China, Australia's largest trading partner. The visit comes after China's Ministry of Commerce released an interim proposal to remove tariffs on Australian wine, raising hopes that nearly three years of duties will soon end. The move is seen as a positive step in patching up relations between the two countries, which have been strained since the Labor government came to office in 2022.

images.alt_text: Rising mortgage delinquencies in China could have negative spillovers on both property prices and consumer confidence, say analysts.
The latest DHL Global Connectedness Report reveals that despite the ongoing tension between the US and China, there is no evidence for a fracturing of global trade along geopolitical lines.
Schools in many districts have now been ordered to stay open longer so that students have somewhere to go because private tutoring schools have closed.

site_title: Vietnam PM meets top local businesses amid weak bank lending
summary: Vietnam's Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh met with top local businesses to discuss measures to boost economic activity amid weak bank lending. The central bank targets a 15% credit growth for this year, following a 0.72% decline in outstanding loans as of February. Weak global demand and inflationary pressure are cited as reasons for the weak credit growth, with the central bank planning to streamline its frameworks and cut banks' operation costs to increase businesses' accessibility to credit.

images.alt_text: Should Vietnam get an upgrade, the nation will join Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia and the Philippines from South-east Asia in the FTSE Advanced Emerging and Secondary Emerging universe.
Australia has been a key coal supplier to Vietnam, which is heavily reliant on the fossil fuels for power generation.
Hanoi topped air monitoring website IQAir’s table of the world’s most polluted cities.

site_title: Australia PM rules out US-style TikTok ban
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has ruled out banning TikTok from government devices, citing a need for the app to divest from its Chinese owner. This stance follows US lawmakers' approval of a bill threatening to exclude TikTok from the US market. Albanese stated that his government will take advice but has no plans to replicate the US move unless TikTok agrees to divest from its Chinese owner.

images.alt_text: Giovanna Gonzalez of Chicago demonstrates outside the US Capitol following a press conference by TikTok creators to voice their opposition to the “Protecting Americans from Foreign Adversary Controlled Applications Act" in Washington, US, March 12, 2024.
“The government is attempting to strip 170 million Americans of their Constitutional right to free expression,” Tiktok says.
The vote is expected around 10 am under fast-track rules that require support by two-thirds of House members for the measure to pass.
In 2020, Donald Trump sought to ban TikTok and Chinese-owned WeChat but was blocked by the courts.
Because TikTok is owned by a Chinese company, ByteDance, the short-form video platform's popularity among Americans carries implications beyond the mobile-phone screen.

The annual State of the Union address is a mainstay of the US political calendar, but the event has struggled to remain relevant in the social media age, especially among young people who largely tune out of traditional political coverage.

If any of the six tech giants are not compliant with the Digital Markets Act (DMA) by the EU’s Thursday deadline, they could ultimately face investigations and potentially fines of up to 10 per cent of their global turnover.

Representative Mike Gallagher, who chairs a House panel on China, introduced legislation on Tuesday with Representative Raja Krishnamoorthi, the panel’s top Democrat, that would give ByteDance about six months to sell TikTok or face a ban citing national security concerns.
Short video app TikTok acquired in December majority shares in GoTo’s e-commerce unit Tokopedia after the Indonesian trade ministry banned transactions on its TikTok Shop e-commerce unit.

site_title: Banyan Group bets big on branded residences
summary: Banyan Group, a property developer, reported a significant increase in branded residence sales in FY2023, with S$267.8 million in new sales and 432 deals closed. The company's total revenue rose to S$377.7 million, a 67% increase from the previous year. Banyan Group founder Ho Kwon Ping attributes the growth to Phuket's emerging status as a global hotspot, with the island being a popular destination for luxury branded residences. The company's new development, Laguna Lakelands, is expected to house the island's largest private residential community, with a total of 5,000 residences planned.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim

site_title: Thai contractor faces 108 billion baht debt crunch as some overseas projects fail
summary: Thai construction company Italian-Thai Development is facing a 108 billion baht debt crunch due to failed overseas projects and a series of corporate scandals. The company is in talks with banks for new loans to address a liquidity crisis that has led to delayed payments to workers and contractors. Italian-Thai has a cumulative loss of 6 billion baht and has requested a stock exchange extension on its financial statement filing deadline. The Securities and Exchange Commission is stepping up supervision of risky bond issuers to boost payment safeguards and investor confidence.

The government is aiming for a record 40 million foreign visitors this year, after recording 28.15 million arrivals last year.

site_title: Japanese printing group Toppan to build Singapore factory for high-end semiconductor material
summary: Toppan, a Japanese printing technologies group, is opening a factory in Singapore to produce high-end semiconductor substrates, the first such facility in the country. The facility, operated by Advanced Substrate Technologies, is expected to begin production by the end of 2026 and will produce flip chip ball grid array (FC-BGA) substrates used in AI and machine learning products. The investment is one of Japan's largest overseas in the past decade, and the factory will add to Singapore's semiconductor ecosystem, helping the country move into high-growth areas such as AI and advanced data centers.

images.alt_text: Singapore’s new centre for semiconductor material gallium nitride to be operational by 2025
For the advanced manufacturing cluster, the Refundable Investment Credit scheme seeks to encourage players to pursue R&D and innovation projects.

site_title: Biotech trade association to split with China’s WuXi AppTec
summary: A US-based biotech trade association, Biotechnology Innovation Organization (BIO), is separating from Chinese member WuXi AppTec amid growing national security concerns. BIO's new CEO, John Crowley, stated the organization will support proposed legislation restricting US business with WuXi AppTec and other biotech companies of concern. This decision comes after WuXi AppTec's shares dropped 7.7% in Hong Kong and 4.6% in Shanghai following US Senate approval of a bill that could prohibit federal agencies from contracting with the company.

images.alt_text: WuXi AppTec allegedly has ties to the Chinese military, according to the House version of the bill.

site_title: Chinese buyers cancel or postpone one million tonnes of Australian wheat: sources
summary: Chinese buyers have cancelled or postponed imports of approximately one million tonnes of Australian wheat, scheduled for February, March, and April, due to declining world wheat prices to their lowest point in about three and a half years. This decision is prompted by China's large worldwide purchases late last year and in early 2024, as well as Russia's flooding of the global market with cheap wheat ahead of an expected bumper harvest.

images.alt_text: It was the third straight session with such an announcement the most in USDA data going back to 1999.

site_title: Japanese firms offer biggest pay rise since 2013, largest industrial union says
summary: Japan's largest industrial union, UA Zensen, announced a 5.9% weighted average wage increase for full-time workers and a 6.5% hike for part-timers, the largest since 2013. This comes after major manufacturers such as Toyota and Panasonic agreed to meet union demands for pay hikes. Strong wage growth is expected to boost inflation, potentially leading to an end to negative interest rates and a policy change by the Bank of Japan at its upcoming meeting.

images.alt_text: Kazuo Ueda, governor of the Bank of Japan (BOJ), during a press conference at Hotel Tivoli after the Group of 20 (G-20) finance ministers and central bank governors meeting in Sao Paulo, Brazil, on Thursday, Feb. 29, 2024. Splits over the conflicts in Gaza and Ukraine prevented Group of 20 finance chiefs from issuing a closing communique after their meetings in Sao Paulo. Photographer: Maira Erlich/Bloomberg
Unions across industries, including automobiles, electronics, metals, heavy machinery and the service sector have all demanded hefty pay hikes.

site_title: China says US TikTok vote follows 'logic of a bandit'
summary: China has criticized the US House of Representatives' approval of a bill that would force TikTok to sever ties with its Chinese parent company or be banned in the US, calling it "entirely the logic of a bandit." The bill's passage puts the US on the opposite side of fair competition and international trade rules, according to China's foreign ministry spokesman Wang Wenbin. The bill still needs to pass the Senate before becoming law, and China is warning that the US' actions will reveal whether its rules are beneficial to the world or only serve US interests.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as traders eye US data, looming Fed meeting
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Thursday, with Hong Kong, Shanghai, Singapore, Seoul, Taipei, and Manila seeing gains, while Tokyo retreated. Traders are awaiting US data and the Federal Reserve's policy meeting next week, which may influence interest rates. Analysts expect the Fed to stand pat but are watching for producer price index data and a post-meeting statement, which could impact market movements.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 closed 0.2 per cent higher on Wednesday. The index earlier in the session hit an all-time high for the fifth time in the past six sessions.

site_title: Gold prices tepid as traders seek more US data
summary: Gold prices remained flat at US$2,173.89 per ounce, as traders awaited US economic data that may influence the Federal Reserve's rate cut decision. The Fed is expected to hold rates steady, but investors will focus on the 'dot plot' projections and data on retail sales, producer prices, and jobless claims. A 67% chance of a June rate cut remains, down from 72% after a slight increase in US consumer prices in February.

images.alt_text: Spot gold has edged 0.1 per cent up to US$2,158.26 per ounce.

site_title: Australia expects smaller revenue upgrade in budget due to falling commodity prices
summary: Australia's federal budget for the year ended June 30 is expected to report a smaller revenue upgrade than the prior year, primarily due to falling commodity prices and rising unemployment. Weaker commodity prices, particularly for major export iron ore, and a two-year high jobless rate are behind the change. Treasurer Jim Chalmers stated that the government aims to achieve a second consecutive budget surplus, with a greater portion of revenue upgrades being spent compared to last year. The revenue upgrades are expected to be less than A$69 billion, down from over A$100 billion in the previous year.

site_title: Cordlife halts trading after falling 6.3%, pending announcement
summary: Cordlife Group halted trading after falling 6.3% pending an announcement. The company is awaiting the final results of tests on its impacted cord-blood units, expected by end-March, following issues with temperature monitoring and process lapses discovered by the Ministry of Health. The decline in net profit for the second half of 2023 was also reported, with a 50.3% decrease to S$1.5 million.

site_title: Latest Singapore 6-month T-bill offering 3.78% cut-off yield
summary: Singapore's latest six-month Treasury bill (T-bill) offered a cut-off yield of 3.78%, slightly down from the previous auction's 3.8%. Demand rose, with S$14.4 billion in applications for the S$6.3 billion on offer, representing a bid-to-cover ratio of 2.29. Despite this, experts note that the cut-off yield remains elevated, with jitters ahead of the US Federal Open Market Committee meeting next week and ongoing inflation concerns.

site_title: Michelin unveils 2024 list of starred restaurants in Hong Kong, Macau
summary: Michelin has released its 2024 list of starred restaurants in Hong Kong and Macau, with one restaurant losing its three-star status. Noi in Hong Kong and The Huaiyang Garden in Macau each gained two stars. The total number of starred restaurants in the two cities remains at 95, with 79 in Hong Kong and 16 in Macau. Mora, a new one-star restaurant in Hong Kong, won Michelin's young chef award and also received the eco-friendly Green Star.

site_title: Goldman Sachs to resume bets on US property, other investors warn of more pain
summary: Goldman Sachs Asset Management plans to resume investing in US commercial property this year, citing a market bottom and a floor in prices set by buyers. The move comes as US office and commercial property prices have fallen sharply due to higher interest rates and soaring vacancy rates. Other investors warn that the market still has further to run, despite the expected shift in sentiment.

site_title: Nestle faces investor challenge over healthy food targets
summary: Nestle faces a formal demand from investors to improve the healthiness of its products. A coalition of investors, led by ShareAction, has filed a resolution asking the company to set targets to increase sales of healthier foods and implement internationally accepted standards for healthy food. The measure requires at least 50% plus one vote of the registered share capital to pass. This comes amid a global push for food companies to make healthier options.

images.alt_text: Nestle’s net profit rose sharply by about 20 per cent to US$12.76 billion.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, SIA, China Everbright Water, Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust
summary: Singtel resumes trading after denying reports of an Optus sale, with shares closing 3.8% higher. Singapore Airlines and Garuda Indonesia submit a joint cooperation application, which will split profits equally between Singapore and Indonesia. China Everbright Water is granted a 30-year concession right for a wastewater treatment plant in Qingdao, while Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust will not pay distributions on its perpetual securities. Trading halts are also announced for CSE Global.

site_title: MicroStrategy launches second note sale this month to buy more Bitcoin
summary: MicroStrategy, the largest publicly-traded corporate holder of Bitcoin, plans to sell $500 million of convertible notes to buy more Bitcoin. The company has already spent over $1 billion on Bitcoin in the first three months of 2024. This sale comes as Bitcoin surges to record highs, with the cryptocurrency up over 675% since chairman and co-founder Michael Saylor began buying in 2020. The proceeds from the sale may also be used for general corporate purposes.

site_title: Microsoft to release security AI product to help clients track hackers
summary: Microsoft plans to release its Copilot for Security AI tool on April 1, designed to help cybersecurity workers track hackers and explain their intentions. The tool combines Microsoft's security data with OpenAI's model to generate summaries and answer questions. It aims to free up experienced workers for more complex tasks and help newer ones get up to speed faster. In trials with corporate customers, including BP and Dow Chemical, the tool has shown improved accuracy and speed, with 26% faster performance and 35% more accuracy by newer security workers.

summary: No Signboard, a Catalist-listed restaurant operator, plans to resume trading before its record date for a six-to-one share consolidation on March 21 at 5 pm. Trading in consolidated shares will begin on March 20 at 9 am in board lots of 100 shares.

site_title: A US$6 billion tender offer key to Japan’s chip ambitions is slated to begin next week
summary: Japan's state-backed investment vehicle, Japan Investment Corporation (JIC), is set to launch a US$6 billion tender offer for chipmaking materials company JSR, a key supplier of photoresists used in advanced semiconductors. The deal, which offers shareholders 4,350 yen (S$39) per JSR share, aims to give Japan more control over the world's top supplier of photoresists. The tender offer, initially planned for December, has been delayed pending China's approval, which has been secured. The deal is seen as central to Japan's semiconductor ambitions and could help shore up its domestic chip manufacturing prowess.

site_title: One dead, 29 rescued after Australian gold mine collapse
summary: A gold mine collapse in Victoria, Australia, killed one miner and trapped 29 others, who were later rescued. A 37-year-old man's body was recovered from the rubble after a major rescue operation. The incident has raised questions about the mine's safety record, with a previous collapse in 2007 and concerns about the use of "air legging" drilling methods. The mine's owner faces a major workplace safety probe, and union officials are pushing for an investigation under "industrial manslaughter" legislation.

site_title: Not your grandfather’s suit: Local tailoring gets a refresh
summary: Local tailors in Singapore are experiencing a resurgence in demand for bespoke suits with a classic, relaxed silhouette, inspired by 1800s lounge suits and 1940s boxier cuts. The trend is driven by customers seeking comfort and a more relaxed fit, as well as a desire for understated elegance. Tailors are incorporating modern details, such as wider cuts, earthy tones, and unique linings, to create a unique look. The "old money" or "quiet luxury" aesthetic, popularized by HBO's Succession, is also gaining popularity, with customers seeking timeless, classic styles. Ultimately, bespoke tailoring is about creating a garment that reflects the individual's personality and needs, and tailors are working to achieve the perfect fit through a collaborative process.

site_title: Reddit sees more than 20% sales growth in 2024 in IPO roadshow
summary: Reddit expects to see over 20% sales growth in 2024, with revenue projected to reach US$967 million, up 20.5% from 2023. The company aims to break even in terms of adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization this year. Reddit's IPO, led by Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs, could raise up to US$748 million, valuing the company at up to US$6.5 billion.

site_title: A US$80 billion crash in India’s small caps flashes warning signs
summary: India's small-cap stocks have lost over $80 billion in value in less than two weeks due to regulatory concerns over overheating and valuation froth. The sell-off has deepened, with gauges of small- and mid-cap stocks plunging over 4% each. The MSCI India Index lags behind MSCI's Asia-Pacific index for the second straight month. Regulators have asked funds to limit purchases and consider holding more large-cap stocks to manage risk. The market's underperformance is also attributed to a decline in chip shares and artificial intelligence boom in other Asian markets.

site_title: China adviser flags geopolitical risks in Xi’s industry push
summary: China's industrial policy faces growing criticism from the US and Europe due to overcapacity, prompting two government-linked economists to advise the government to adjust its approach. Former advisor Huang Yiping warned that a widespread protectionist wave against Chinese products would harm China's future development and innovation. Experts suggest addressing domestic economic imbalances and improving residents' income and social welfare to lift overall consumption. China's reliance on investment-driven growth has led to overcapacity in sectors such as computer chips, steel, and household appliances.

site_title: Europe: Shares scale new record high, retailers pop
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 0.2% higher on Wednesday, reaching a new record high for the fifth time in six sessions, driven by upbeat corporate updates from retailers and utilities sectors. Zalando's 18.9% jump and Inditex's 7.7% rise in shares fueled the rally, while energy shares and miners also benefited from higher commodity prices. However, losses in automakers, led by Volkswagen's 5.9% decline, limited the advance.

images.alt_text: The Nasdaq Composite Index slumped 0.5 per cent to 16,177.77, while the S&P slipped 0.2 per cent to 5,165.31 on Wednesday.

site_title: A balancing act – Singapore’s tax policy in a brave new world
summary: Singapore's government faces a delicate balancing act between increased spending and taxation to maintain its position as a preferred location for business and talent. To achieve sustainable growth, the government aims to increase tax revenues without damaging competitiveness. Notable changes include a 9% goods and services tax rate, which is lower than other developed economies. The government has also declared no plans to raise GST until 2030. Retaining its position will require striking the right balance between economic growth and tax policies.

site_title: Paramount sells India TV stake to Reliance for US$517 million
summary: Paramount Global has agreed to sell its 13% stake in its Indian TV business to Reliance Industries for $517 million, reducing debt. The deal follows a merger between Reliance and Walt Disney's TV properties in India, valued at $8.5 billion. Paramount will continue to license its programming to Viacom 18, its Indian TV business partner.

site_title: Insurer AIA new business value up 33% for FY2023 on strong premium sales
summary: AIA Group, an Asia-focused insurer, reported a 33% increase in FY2023 value of new business (VONB) to US$4 billion, driven by strong sales growth across key markets. Annualized new premiums rose 45% to a record high of US$7.7 billion, driven by a shift towards protection business, resulting in a 10% VONB growth.

site_title: Memecoin trading at levels last seen before crypto bubble burst
summary: Memecoin trading volumes have surged to nearly US$80 billion, surpassing levels seen in October 2021, just before the last crypto bubble burst. The total market value of the memecoin sector has reached over US$60 billion. Memecoins like Dogwifhat and Pepe continue to rack up fresh highs, driven by speculation and idiosyncratic factors. Experts warn that the surge may signal a market top, but new capital entering the market complicates predictions.

site_title: Singapore’s job vacancies rise to 79,800, while re-entry rate of retrenched workers falls in Q4
summary: Singapore's job vacancies rose to 79,800 in Q4 2023, while the re-entry rate of retrenched workers fell to 61.5% among residents. The ratio of job vacancies to unemployed persons, at 1.74, indicates a "moderately tight labour market". Labour demand is expected to strengthen over the year, driven by higher-paying industries such as financial and insurance services. However, business restructuring and reorganisation may contribute to higher retrenchments.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise on Thursday; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.3% to 3,169.68 on Thursday, driven by gains in Seatrium and banking stocks like DBS and OCBC. Across the broader market, 56 gainers outnumbered 44 losers. Despite a mixed global market, the STI climbed 8.96 points, with 44.3 million securities worth S$67.8 million changing hands.

site_title: Alibaba plans to invest US$1.1 billion in South Korea: Yonhap
summary: Alibaba plans to invest US$1.1 billion in South Korea over three years to build a logistics centre and expand businesses. The company will spend US$200 million this year on logistics centre construction and US$100 million to help small and mid-sized firms sell products overseas. This investment aims to support South Korea's e-commerce growth and strengthen Alibaba's presence in the country.

site_title: UK housing market strengthens in February: RICS survey
summary: The UK housing market showed signs of stabilization in February, with the RICS survey indicating a net balance of +6 for new buyer enquiries, the strongest reading since February 2022. House prices rose to -10% from -18% in January, and new instructions to sell increased to a net balance of +21, the strongest reading since October 2020. However, surveyors remain cautious about the sector's outlook due to ongoing uncertainty about interest rate reductions.

site_title: Australian mega funds seen controlling A$13.6 trillion of pensions
summary: A group of massive Australian pension funds will control nearly 100% of the country's A$13.6 trillion retirement system by 2048, according to a Mercer report. Currently, there are five funds overseeing over A$100 billion each, but the number is expected to shrink to 77 over the next five years due to mergers and regulatory pressure. The system's growth is fueled by compulsory contributions, but it is expected to slow as baby boomers retire and demographics shift. The gap in coverage remains, with 21.5% of the working-age population lacking pension accounts.

site_title: Wang Learning Centre finds a winning linguistic edge in Chinese
summary: Wang Learning Centre, a Chinese-language tuition chain, is capitalizing on China's growing influence in the Asia-Pacific and globally. Founded by Wang Jie, who came to Singapore from China in the late 1990s, the centre has expanded to 11 branches and serves over 11,000 students. By developing proprietary teaching materials and pedagogy, and building a trusted team of educators, Wang Learning Centre has gained a competitive edge. The company has also adapted to the COVID-19 pandemic by embracing digitalization, and has received the Enterprise 50 Award for its business resilience.

Interim CEO Lim Teck-Ean stated the company is in talks with six to seven parties regarding mergers and acquisitions to improve profitability. The company aims to focus on organic growth and external growth, with the goal of increasing its industry participation and becoming a global brand. A dialogue session was held with the Securities Investors Association (Singapore) to address shareholder concerns and questions about the company's future plans.

site_title: Rich nations are leaving poor behind in risk to global stability, UN says
summary: The UN's Global Development Index shows that 20 years of narrowing global inequality between rich and poor nations is reversing, with the index projected to reach a record high last year. Only 17 of the 35 least-developed nations have recovered to pre-pandemic levels, while all 38 members of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development have surpassed it. The report warns that widening inequality risks stoking polarisation and gridlock, and that global development is no longer on track to reach a "very high" level of progress by 2030.
