site_title: US office market is world's most oversupplied, Brookfield tells MIPIM
summary: The US office market is the world's most oversupplied, with vacancy rates of around 20% in cities, according to Brookfield Asset Management's managing partner Bradley Weismiller. This is due to excessive construction and a surge in borrowing costs since 2022, which has led to a shift towards remote working and a decrease in demand for office space. The oversupply has resulted in a decrease in property values, with concerns about lenders and regional bank shares.

images.alt_text: A view of an empty office floor in downtown San Francisco as the city struggles to return to its pre-pandemic commercial real estate occupancy rates, falling behind many other major cities around the country, hitting a vacancy rate of over 30%, according to local media, in California, U.S., February 23, 2024. REUTERS/Carlos Barria

site_title: Disney focuses on division leaders in hunt for Iger’s successor
summary: Disney's board is focusing on four divisional heads, including TV chief Dana Walden, ESPN's Jimmy Pitaro, theme-parks boss Josh D'Amaro, and film business head Alan Bergman, as part of a formal search for Bob Iger's successor. The process involves Iger meeting with internal candidates and potentially appointing a No. 2 executive before he steps down in 2026. Dissident shareholders are seeking board seats, with Trian Fund Management's Nelson Peltz criticizing the company's succession planning. A search committee, led by Chairman Mark Parker, is reviewing internal and external candidates.

images.alt_text: Reliance will inject US$1.4 billion in the merged entity, with the company and its affiliates holding a more than 63 per cent stake, with Disney owning the rest.
Disney’s investment in streaming ad technology comes as advertisers are moving away from broadcast and cable TV, along with viewers.
Shares of Disney gained as much as 8.7 per cent to US$107.75 in extended trading after the results were announced, their highest in almost a year.

site_title: Goldman Sachs Asset Management to resume US commercial property investment
summary: Goldman Sachs Asset Management plans to resume actively investing in US commercial real estate this year, citing a bottoming-out market and a buying opportunity. The decision comes as US office and commercial property prices have fallen sharply due to higher interest rates and increased vacancy rates. The firm believes the US economy's underlying strength will support a rebound, but a sharp recovery is unlikely. This move follows GSAM's recent deployment of cash in European and Japanese real estate markets.

images.alt_text: The office sector, battered by remote work and declining tenant demand for space, “continued to be the driving force behind growing distress, providing 93 per cent of the additional balance for the quarter”, according to MCSI Real Assets.

site_title: Key Samsung shareholder vote to test South Korea’s commitment to corporate reforms
summary: South Korea's most valuable business group, Samsung, will face a shareholder vote on Friday at the annual general meeting of Samsung C&T, which serves as the holding company of the Samsung Group. Activist investors are demanding higher shareholder returns than the company has proposed, and proxy advisory firms have advised institutional funds to back their case. The outcome will test President Yoon Suk-yeol's commitment to corporate reforms, known as the "Corporate Value-up Program," which aims to narrow the wealth gap and stimulate growth.

images.alt_text: The demand for high bandwidth memory chips has boomed with the growing popularity of generative AI.

Samsung Electronics chairman Lee Jae-yong (C) arrives to court for his ruling on the controversial 2015 merger case, at the Seoul Central District Court in Seoul on February 5, 2024. A South Korean court was set to rule on February 5, on whether Samsung Electronics heir Lee Jae-yong committed a raft of crimes to shore up his succession from a controversial merger. (Photo by Jung Yeon-je / AFP)
Samsung is working to catch up to rival SK Hynix in high-bandwidth memory, or HBM, chips, which are used to help Nvidia’s accelerators in training artificial intelligence.
Samsung is making a push to expand its small share in China, the world’s largest smartphone market.
Health tracking is already a key selling point of smartphones and watches, with Samsung, Apple and Alphabet’s Google using the features to attract and retain customers.

site_title: Yellen says US economy unlikely to see ‘stagflation’
summary: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stated the US economy is unlikely to experience 'stagflation', a scenario of economic stagnation with rising costs. Housing costs are the primary contributor to ongoing inflation, but Yellen noted that rental prices for new apartments have declined in many areas. Most forecasters expect inflation to cool as housing costs decrease.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar banknotes are seen in this illustration taken March 10, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The Dow Jones Industrial Average has finished up 0.6 per cent at 39,005.49.
The annual consumer price index came in at 3.2 per cent last month, while the “core” measure stripping out volatile food and energy prices edged down slightly to 3.8 per cent.
JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon said the US economy was doing so well it could almost be characterised as a boom, but cautioned against the wholesale embrace of the soft landing narrative by markets.
New research has found that as the poor become richer, they become more likely to understate their income.

site_title: COEs: Signal of possible change of course does not guarantee a policy U-turn
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Transport has sparked discussions about potential policy changes, including a one-off increase in the vehicle population and higher charges for car use. Although the ministry mentioned considering these ideas, it does not guarantee their implementation. This subtle signal has raised hopes among motorists, who closely watch policy changes and COE bidding results. The government's intentions remain unclear, leaving room for speculation about future changes to car ownership policies in Singapore.

images.alt_text: The government says that having a separate Certificate of Entitlement (COE) category for private hire cars is possible, but the trade-offs must be studied carefully.
The trade-offs of a one-time rise will need to be studied carefully, says Transport Minister Chee Hong Tat.
Certificate of entitlement (COE) premiums for passenger cars rose, while those for commercial vehicles and motorcycles remained flat.

site_title: China pledges government funds for equipment upgrades
summary: China has pledged central government funds to encourage consumers and businesses to replace old equipment and goods, aiming to boost economic growth of about 5% in 2024. The plan includes equipment renewal projects, tax breaks, and targeted lending from banks, with a goal of increasing spending on equipment by 25% by 2027. The government did not specify the amount of funding, but estimates suggest it could induce an additional 800 billion yuan in spending, worth about 0.6% of last year's GDP.

images.alt_text: China's February year-on-year consumer price growth of 0.7 per cent outpaces Reuters economists' forecasted 0.3 per cent uptick.
Trade data for the first two months of the year is typically combined to avoid distortions from the Chinese New Year holiday.

site_title: UK to ban foreign state ownership of British newspapers
summary: The UK government plans to ban foreign state ownership of British newspapers, following pressure over the proposed takeover of the Daily Telegraph and Spectator magazine by a UAE-led joint venture. The move aims to deliver additional protections for a free press and prevent the influence of foreign governments on the media. The proposed legislation will prevent 75% foreign state ownership, effectively blocking the Abu Dhabi-led takeover. The government's move is seen as a response to concerns over the impact of foreign ownership on the UK's media landscape.

images.alt_text: The bid for the politically influential Telegraph has raised questions about the independence of the media and the role of foreign investors acquiring assets that could undermine press freedom.
Rupert Murdoch stepped down from his role at Fox in September last year, ending a seven-decade career that began at his father’s Australian newspaper business.

site_title: Hunter Biden trial on gun charges set for June 3
summary: US President Joe Biden's son Hunter Biden faces a June 3 trial on three felony gun charges stemming from his 2018 purchase of a .38-caliber revolver while he was addicted to drugs. He also faces tax evasion charges in California, with a potential trial starting on June 20. Hunter Biden could face up to 25 years in prison if convicted, amid ongoing controversies and Republican allegations of corrupt business practices in China and Ukraine.

images.alt_text: “The government is attempting to strip 170 million Americans of their Constitutional right to free expression,” Tiktok says.

GOFFSTOWN, NEW HAMPSHIRE - MARCH 11: President Joe Biden speaks during an event about lowering costs for American families at the Granite State YMCA Allard Center of Goffstown on March 11, 2024 in Goffstown, New Hampshire. Days after Biden delivered his last State of the Union address before the November general election, the President held the event to highlight his administration's achievements and vision going into the next eight months of his campaign.   Sophie Park/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Sophie Park / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
In 2020, Donald Trump sought to ban TikTok and Chinese-owned WeChat but was blocked by the courts.
US President Joe Biden wants to sharply raise taxes on corporations and high earners in his second four-year term.

Biden faces huge problems that undercut his chances of getting re-elected, including doubts about his physical and mental fitness for office, looming fears over the country’s immigration crisis at the southern border, and continuing gloom about inflation despite falling prices.

site_title: A simpler solution is needed in tracking financed emissions from early coal retirement
summary: Major banks HSBC, Standard Chartered, and Bank of America are working on a deal to finance the early retirement of Indonesia's Cirebon-1 coal-fired power plant. Singapore's DBS has also announced a similar deal, with plans to report emissions from coal phase-out projects on its balance sheet. A new metric, "expected emission reduction" (EER), proposed by the Glasgow Financial Alliance for Net Zero, aims to measure banks' contribution to decarbonization by calculating avoided emissions. However, climate finance non-profits have criticized EER as "fatally flawed" and argue it could be used to misrepresent emissions reductions. Industry experts emphasize the need for a standardized framework to govern emissions reporting from coal phase-out deals.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
DBS chief sustainability officer Helge Muenkel speaks during a media briefing on the DBS sustainability report, on March 5, 2024.
The three banks have proposed to help finance the accelerated closing of the Cirebon-1 coal-fired power station in West Java.
FILE PHOTO: A truck unloads tonnes of coal inside a warehouse in Tondo city, metro Manila January 11, 2016.  REUTERS/Romeo Ranoco/File Photo

site_title: Sydney faces growing pains as its housing crisis deepens
summary: Sydney's housing crisis deepens, with the city's lack of affordable housing driving an exodus of people in their 30s and 40s. Residents are opposing a proposal to boost density by allowing six-storey apartment blocks to be built around suburban train stations, citing environmental and heritage concerns. The crisis has led to a per-capita recession, with households going backwards despite the economy growing. The NSW government has called for proposals to boost supply, but opposition from communities and councillors is hindering progress. Experts argue that the city needs more apartments to address the issue.

images.alt_text: The RBA has lifted interest rates to a 12-year peak of 4.35 per cent in an effort to restrain inflation.
Australia has been a key coal supplier to Vietnam, which is heavily reliant on the fossil fuels for power generation.
The Australian Bureau of Statistics reported the balance on goods widened in January to A$11.03 billion (S$9.7 billion), from A$10.74 billion in December last year.

site_title: Thai ex-PM Thaksin makes first public appearance since release: AFP
summary: Thailand's former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra made his first public appearance since release from jail, visiting the Bangkok City Pillar Shrine on Thursday. Thaksin, 74, was freed early due to his age and health, and is now set to fly to Chiang Mai, his home city and traditional power base, to pray at the graves of his relatives. The move comes after a 15-year self-exile and a tumultuous return to the kingdom, with many speculating that a backroom deal may have been struck to cut his jail time.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Former Thai Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra, who is expected to be arrested upon his return as he ends almost two decades of self-imposed exile, walks at Don Mueang airport in Bangkok, Thailand August 22, 2023. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha/File Photo/File Photo

FILE PHOTO: U.S. Secretary of Commerce Gina Raimondo attends a press conference at the Boeing Shanghai Aviation Services near the Shanghai Pudong International Airport, in Shanghai, China August 30, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song//File Photo
The central bank will conduct unscheduled visits to make sure that lenders are offering reasonable and realistic debt solutions to their customers.

Thailand's Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin speaks alongside Cambodia's Prime Minister Hun Manet during a joint press conference at the Government House in Bangkok on February 7, 2024. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)

Move Forward Party leader Pita Limjaroenrat (C) speaks to the media after a meeting with the working group of seven party allies to form a coalition government on 06 June 2023. The election commission wants to disband the party for violating the constitution.
Talks on the Thai-EU FTA should be completed within 1.5 years, says Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin.

Jakarta International Stadium, Indonesia’s largest stadium with a capacity of 82,000 seats. The venue has hosted concerts by the South Korean K-pop group Twice and the British singer-songwriter Ed Sheeran.

site_title: Buyouts help Temasek-backed hospital firm vie for top India spot
summary: Manipal Health Enterprises, backed by Temasek Holdings, is in talks to acquire a smaller Indian hospital chain, aiming to become the country's No 1 healthcare provider. The deal, valued at 1,200 beds, would be the firm's fourth buyout since 2020, potentially toppling Apollo Hospitals Enterprise. Manipal is also expanding into smaller Indian towns, with plans to scout for deals in Hyderabad and Mumbai. A deal is expected to be finalized in six weeks, with no target or deal size specified.

images.alt_text: Seatrium's Floating Living Lab with the stacked energy storage system (left) and LNG tank, Oct 19, 2023. It is the first such offshore floating testbed in Singapore.
Temasek is "seriously considering" having inhouse operating specialists as it becomes a more active investor, said Nagi Hamiyeh, head of the portfolio development group.
Sam Altman, CEO of OpenAI, at 54th annual meeting of the World Economic Forum, in Davos, Switzerland in January 2024.

PIXGENERIC
Temasek International office at Orchard Road, July 5, 2023.

site_title: Saudi Arabia gets US$13 billion in investment in tourism boost
summary: Saudi Arabia has attracted $13 billion in private investment for its tourism industry, aiming to increase hotel rooms by 150,000-200,000 and raise tourism revenue to $85 billion this year. The kingdom aims to become a major travel destination, with 150 million tourists by 2030, and is spending $800 billion on the industry over the next decade. This investment is part of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's vision to diversify revenue streams away from oil and towards industries like sports and technology.

images.alt_text: Signage above the Saudi Aramco booth on day two of the Abu Dhabi International Petroleum Exhibition and Conference (ADIPEC) in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates, on Tuesday, Oct. 3, 2023. The annual strategic energy conference runs from Oct 2-5. Photographer: Christopher Pike/Bloomberg
FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: A general view of Riyadh city, Saudi Arabia, February 20, 2022. REUTERS/Mohammed Benmansour/File Photo/File Photo
CFA's push comes as Saudi Arabia reforms its financial system in an effort to advance the banking and insurance industries.

“If you look at the non-oil GDP, it is growing at very healthy numbers: 4 per cent and north of 4 per cent. We are expecting 5 per cent-plus in the medium term,” Jadaan told delegates at the Saudi Capital Markets Forum in Riyadh. “That is very strong growth.”

site_title: TikTok devotees say platform unfairly targeted for US ban
summary: The US House of Representatives has approved a bill that could force TikTok to divest from its Chinese owner or face a ban, citing alleged links to the Communist Party in Beijing. TikTok creators and users voiced outrage, saying the move defies common sense and financial wisdom. President Joe Biden has stated he would sign the bill into law if it reaches his desk, but it must first pass the Senate. The proposed legislation has sparked concerns about the impact on millions of users, including politicians, teenagers, and entrepreneurs, who rely on the platform for marketing and community.

images.alt_text: “The government is attempting to strip 170 million Americans of their Constitutional right to free expression,” Tiktok says.
In 2020, Donald Trump sought to ban TikTok and Chinese-owned WeChat but was blocked by the courts.
Because TikTok is owned by a Chinese company, ByteDance, the short-form video platform's popularity among Americans carries implications beyond the mobile-phone screen.
Shein is seeking Beijing’s nod to go public in a listing that will likely face tough scrutiny from US regulators.

The annual State of the Union address is a mainstay of the US political calendar, but the event has struggled to remain relevant in the social media age, especially among young people who largely tune out of traditional political coverage.

Representative Mike Gallagher, who chairs a House panel on China, introduced legislation on Tuesday with Representative Raja Krishnamoorthi, the panel’s top Democrat, that would give ByteDance about six months to sell TikTok or face a ban citing national security concerns.

site_title: Oil prices up 3% to 4-month high on US crude stock drop, Russian refinery attacks
summary: Oil prices rose 3% to a four-month high on Wednesday, driven by a surprise drop in US crude inventories and potential supply disruptions following Ukrainian attacks on Russian refineries. Brent futures rose $2.11 to $84.03 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose $2.16 to $79.72 a barrel, marking the highest close for Brent since November 6. The price increase was also attributed to a bigger-than-expected drop in US petrol stocks.

images.alt_text: (FILES) An oil pumpjack operates at dusk Willow Springs Park in Long Beach, California on April 21, 2020, a day after oil prices dropped to below zero as the oil industry suffers steep falls in benchmark crudes due to the ongoing global coronavirus pandemic. US energy company APA Corporation has agreed to buy competitor Callon Petroleum in a transaction valued around $4.5 billion including debt, the firms announced January 4, 2024, marking the latest deal in the sector. (Photo by Apu GOMES / AFP)

site_title: Competition watchdog seeks feedback on proposed SIA-Garuda cooperation
summary: Singapore's Competition and Consumer Commission is seeking public feedback on the proposed collaboration between Singapore Airlines (SIA) and Garuda Indonesia. The airlines aim to work together on scheduling, pricing, and sales, and will share profits from services between Singapore and Indonesia equally. Despite this, SIA and Garuda claim the tie-up will not reduce competition, citing "intense" rivalry from low-cost carriers on overlapping routes. The public consultation runs from March 14 to 27 to assess whether the collaboration would prevent or distort competition in the aviation market.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Across South-east Asia, pre-pandemic links with Europe have all but vanished as Philippine Airlines, Garuda Indonesia and Thai Airways cut flights.
The proposed joint venture builds on a memorandum of understanding inked in 2021 between the airlines.

site_title: Lloyds sells £6 billion of Scottish Widows annuities to Rothesay
summary: Lloyds Banking Group has agreed to sell a £6 billion portfolio of bulk annuities to Rothesay Life, a pensions insurance specialist. The portfolio, which covers about 42,000 people, will not have a financial impact on Lloyds. The deal will initially be structured as a reinsurance agreement and will be completed through a Part VII transfer next year, at which point policyholders will receive benefits from Rothesay. The sale marks Rothesay's sixth acquisition of in-force bulk annuities and will enable Lloyds to focus on growth in other markets.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Hiscox logo and stock graph seen displayed in this illustration taken, May 3, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Logo for Aviva plc, a British insurer.

site_title: China Everbright Water bags 30-year concession for treatment plant
summary: China Everbright Water has secured a 30-year concession for a wastewater treatment plant in Qingdao, worth 688.3 million yuan (S$129.4 million). The project, a joint venture with Qingdao Environmental Energy, will upgrade the Zhangcun River Waste Water Treatment Plant to a capacity of 40,000 cubic meters and build a new plant with a capacity of 60,000 cu m. China Everbright Water will hold a 49% stake in the project company. The company also announced the resignation of its CFO and executive director, Luo Junling, amid "changes in work arrangements".

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
China Everbright Water's board proposes a final dividend of HK$0.0581 per share.

site_title: ECB to wean banks off free cash at gentlest pace
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is introducing a new framework to gradually wean banks off free cash, which has been a result of nearly a decade of low inflation. The ECB aims to keep the interbank rate near its deposit rate of 4% by relying more on banks lending to each other as bonds mature and excess liquidity leaves the system. The new framework also includes lower interest rates for borrowing from the ECB, aiming to reduce financial tension and provide safety nets. The ECB plans to review the new system in two years or sooner if needed.

images.alt_text: Lenders currently need to hold 1 per cent of certain liabilities – mostly customer deposits – at the ECB.

site_title: Founders of daycare centre for kids with critical illnesses jointly named ST Singaporean of the Year 2023
summary: Former nurse Ronita Paul and volunteer coordinator Geraldine Lee, co-founders of Arc Children's Centre, a daycare centre for children with critical illnesses, were jointly named The Straits Times Singaporean of the Year 2023. The centre, established in 2011, provides emotional support and a normal childhood experience for these children. Paul and Lee received the award, along with a trophy and S$20,000 in cash, for their dedication and service to the community, which President Tharman Shanmugaratnam praised for its long-term impact.

site_title: US: Nasdaq slips as growth stocks retreat ahead of economic data
summary: The Nasdaq Composite dropped 45.53 points, or 0.28%, to 16,220.11 at the opening bell on Wednesday, as rate-sensitive growth stocks eased ahead of economic data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 49.09 points, or 0.13%, to 39,054.58, while the S&P 500 opened lower by 1.78 points, or 0.03%. The decline was attributed to anticipation of the Federal Reserve's interest-rate cuts, which would provide more insight into the timing of such cuts.

site_title: BNPL players losing steam as digital banking gains speed
summary: The "buy now, pay later" (BNPL) industry is experiencing a decline, with several players pulling out of the market, including ShopBack and Bukalapak. The sector's struggles are attributed to high interest rates, which have squeezed profit margins. In contrast, digital banking offers more avenues for monetization and reduced regulatory pressures. As fintechs pivot to digital banking, they face challenges in customer acquisition and technology barriers. Despite this, some BNPL players are acquiring banking licenses to launch digital banks, marking a shift away from the traditional BNPL model.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Digital banks are finding out that the unbanked potential in South-east Asia is a lot harder to tap than expected.
ShopeBack will be shuttering its BNPL offering PayLater after a periodic review of its business units.
David Chen will remain as co-founder of Advance Intelligence Group, the buy now, pay later service’s parent firm.

site_title: US House passes bill to force ByteDance to divest TikTok or face ban
summary: The US House of Representatives passed a bill requiring ByteDance, the Chinese owner of TikTok, to divest its US assets within six months or face a ban. The bill, which passed 352-65, is aimed at addressing national security concerns over China's ownership of the popular social media app used by 170 million Americans. The Senate's fate is uncertain, with some lawmakers favoring a different approach to regulating foreign-owned apps. If the bill becomes law, ByteDance would need to divest its US assets or face a ban, potentially leading to a legal challenge.

images.alt_text: The vote is expected around 10 am under fast-track rules that require support by two-thirds of House members for the measure to pass.
In 2020, Donald Trump sought to ban TikTok and Chinese-owned WeChat but was blocked by the courts.
Because TikTok is owned by a Chinese company, ByteDance, the short-form video platform's popularity among Americans carries implications beyond the mobile-phone screen.

site_title: Singapore pledges support for more global cooperation in helping fraud victims recover funds
summary: Singapore pledges support for global cooperation in helping fraud victims recover funds, following the inaugural Global Fraud Summit in London. Second Minister for Home Affairs Josephine Teo represented Singapore, highlighting the country's anti-fraud efforts and its recognition for strong asset recovery and international coordination. The summit aims to improve asset recovery, crack down on criminal networks, and facilitate information sharing across borders. Teo emphasized the need for international cooperation and public-private partnerships to combat the increasing challenges of fraud.

site_title: Number of ships sailing around Africa up 85% on Houthi attacks
summary: The number of ships sailing around Africa has increased by 85% due to Houthi rebel attacks in the Red Sea, forcing vessels to take a longer route. This rise in voyages coincides with a 70% decline in ships arriving in the Gulf of Aden to transit the Red Sea. Attacks have led to significant declines in container ship, natural gas carrier, and bulk commodity sailings, with drops of 58%, 32%, and 30% respectively. The attacks have resulted in confirmed deaths, with a missile strike killing three crew members last week.

images.alt_text: A Suez Canal Authority pilot vessel heads to shore after leaving the container ship Ebba Maersk, operated by A.P. Moeller-Maersk A/S, center, as it continues its passage through the Red Sea after exiting the Suez Canal in Suez, Egypt, on Saturday, April 6, 2013. Maersk Line, the world's biggest container shipping company, will stop plying through the Panama Canal to move goods from Asia to the U.S. east coast as bigger ships help the company move it profitably through Suez Canal. Photographer: Kristian Helgesen/Bloomberg

site_title: ABN Amro jumps on wealth management bandwagon in race for fees
summary: ABN Amro aims to increase wealth management fees to offset declining lending revenue. The Dutch bank's chief financial officer, Ferdinand Vaandrager, stated the ambition to make fees a more important part of income, cutting dependency on interest income. This move follows similar strategies by European peers, such as Intesa Sanpaolo and ING, as interest rates are expected to decrease. The goal is to diversify revenue streams and boost fee growth.

site_title: US 30-year mortgage rate drops below 7%, spurring home purchases
summary: US mortgage rates dropped 18 basis points to 6.84% in the week ended Mar 8, the biggest decline in nearly three months. This decrease spurred an increase in mortgage applications for home purchases, with the MBA's index rising 4.7% to a four-week high of 147.7. Although rates are still higher than in 2021, a sustained drop could help stabilize housing demand. The MBA's overall index climbed 7.1% to a four-week high, with refinancing applications also increasing.

site_title: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust not paying distribution on S$140m perp
summary: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) announced it will not pay its S$140 million distribution on its 7% perpetual securities due on March 27. The decision, made by Perpetual (Asia) as trustee, is non-cumulative and does not accrue distribution. As a result, LMIRT cannot declare or pay any dividends, distributions, or make other payments on its units or 2017 perpetual securities until certain requirements are met, including redeeming all outstanding perpetual securities. LMIRT's units were unchanged at S$0.013, its 52-week low, following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Cibubur Junction in East Jakarta, Indonesia, is a five-storey shopping centre with a basement level and a carpark.

site_title: Dollar holds steady after US inflation, Fed rate cut still in sight
summary: The US dollar index held steady on Wednesday, despite hotter-than-expected inflation data, as traders still expect a Federal Reserve interest rate cut in June. The dollar index fell 0.01% to 102.92, its biggest weekly decline since mid-December. Markets see a 67% likelihood of a Fed cut in June, down from 71% earlier in the week. Sterling edged higher against the dollar, while the euro rose 0.1% against the dollar. The European Central Bank is expected to start cutting rates in the spring, with a possible cut in April or June.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar banknotes are seen in this illustration taken March 10, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Chinese national who had Singaporeans front landed property purchases arrested
summary: A Chinese national, Zhan Guotuan, a Singapore permanent resident, has been arrested upon his return to Singapore for allegedly nominating a Singaporean couple to buy three restricted landed properties worth over S$6 million in 2007-2008. Zhan had been charged in 2017 with authorizing individuals to buy the properties and was believed to have absconded. He is now expected to plead guilty in court on April 18 and faces charges related to failing to attend court.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Megan Cheah
On Mar 5, Tan Hui Meng, 57, was sentenced to two years, three months and three weeks’ jail.
The rising level of unsold stock may signal bad news for some projects, such as the 99-year leasehold Cuscaden Reserve (above), with an impending sales deadline this year.
Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA) logo

site_title: Philippines gets US$5 billion in investment pledges from German, US companies
summary: Philippines President Ferdinand Marcos Jr secured US$5 billion in investment pledges from German and American companies during a three-day working visit in Germany. German companies pledged US$4 billion, while US firms committed over US$1 billion. The investments are in sectors such as healthcare, energy, and telecoms, and are seen as a significant boost for the country's economy, which has struggled to attract foreign capital due to issues like red tape and policy uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. speaks at a press conference, held with German Chancellor Olaf Scholz (not pictured), in Berlin, Germany, March 12, 2024. REUTERS/Liesa Johannssen

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Wednesday, March 13, 2024 (Ep 21)
summary: Higher US inflation data failed to dampen investor sentiment, with markets tracking global rallies. Economists raised their forecast for Singapore's 2024 economic growth to 2.4%. Seatrium received approval from the Singapore Exchange to consolidate its shares 20-to-1. Singapore shares rose 0.2% on Wednesday, following the global rally.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 70 to 44.
Hong Kong rose for a fourth straight day, while Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta were also in positive territory.
Seatrium logo at their office’s lobby, Oct 19, 2023.

site_title: Eurozone production slumps as economy starts 2024 with stumble
summary: Eurozone industrial production slumped 3.2% in January, worse than expected, with Germany's manufacturing base suffering the most. The decline raises concerns about the economy's growth prospects in the first quarter, with forecasters predicting only 0.1% expansion. European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde previously lowered her outlook for 2024, citing subdued growth. The biggest drop was seen in Ireland, with a 29% slump, and output of capital goods fell 14.5% in January.

site_title: India’s Tata Motors to build 90 billion rupee plant in Tamil Nadu
summary: Tata Motors, an Indian automaker, has signed a deal to build a 90 billion rupee (S$1.4 billion) manufacturing plant in Tamil Nadu. The investment, spread over five years, could create up to 5,000 jobs. This announcement comes days after VinFast, a Vietnamese electric vehicle maker, started building a factory in the state. Chennai, the capital of Tamil Nadu, is already home to factories of global carmakers including BMW, Daimler, and Hyundai.

site_title: Thailand to benefit from semiconductor production rejig, says US commerce secretary
summary: US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo announced that Thailand will benefit from a move to diversify semiconductor production, citing the need to reduce concentration in one or two countries worldwide. The US is pushing additional investments into countries like Thailand as part of the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework. Thailand's semiconductor industry, dominated by US firms, is seen as a key sector for the country's sluggish economy, with the US offering $52.7 billion for US semiconductor production and workforce development.

images.alt_text: The investments will span areas like AI, digital upskilling, solar, nuclear projects and a new airline route to Cebu province, US Secretary of Commerce Gina Raimondo says.

site_title: Deglobalisation is still only a risk, not a reality: DHL
summary: DHL's Global Connectedness Report 2024 finds that despite global conflicts and public policy headwinds, the level of global connectedness has never been higher. Trade growth has boosted global connectedness, with the share of global output traded internationally at a record high level in 2022. The report shows no evidence of a split of the world economy between rival geopolitical blocs, with US-China flows decreasing by 25% since 2016 but still remaining significantly connected. Deglobalisation remains a risk, not a reality, with international flows taking place over stable or longer distances.

Malaysia is already the world’s sixth-largest exporter of semiconductors and packages 23 per cent of all American chips.
Olaf Scholz also wants to discuss the security situation in the Indo-Pacific region, Russia’s war in Ukraine and the conflict in the Middle East with his Asian partners.
PM Lee Hsien Loong (third from left) and other Asean leaders, as well as Australian PM Anthony Albanese (sixth from right), at the Asean-Australia Special Summit in Melbourne on Mar 6.

site_title: Rising mortgage defaults bring more pain to Chinese households
summary: Rising mortgage delinquencies in China are causing financial distress for households, with many struggling to repay debts. The delinquencies could negatively impact property prices and consumer confidence. A former finance worker, Lei Xiaoyu, is facing foreclosure after losing her job and stopping mortgage payments seven years ago. The situation highlights the growing concern over China's housing market and the potential for spillover effects on the economy. Analysts warn that the issue could have far-reaching consequences for the country's financial stability.

images.alt_text: “The government guarantees basic housing needs, and the market fulfils other diversified housing requirements and systems, establishing a market for both renting and buying,” says China’s Housing and Urban-Rural Development Minister Ni Hong.
Homebuyers in China are avoiding defaulted developers on concerns about their ability to complete housing projects.

site_title: Stock investor with 1,900% gain breaks long silence in Japan
summary: Stephen Butt's investment firm, Silchester International Investors, has broken its long silence in Japan, urging companies to improve capital allocation and pay out more to shareholders. Silchester, which has a 1,900% gain on its Japanese investments, is urging regional banks to pay out half their profit and all dividend income. The firm has made proposals at several Japanese companies, including Kyoto Financial Group and Obayashi Corp., but has been met with resistance. Despite this, Silchester's Japanese stocks are rising, and the firm is seen as a deep value investor that is pushing for change in the country's corporate governance.

images.alt_text: BOJ has yet to buy ETFs this year to support the market. The previous time was on Oct 4, when it bought 70.1 billion yen (S$634.8 million) of ETFs.
A breach of its 1989 peak by the Mini Topix Futures contract is likely to have a huge psychological impact on investors that could take it even higher.

A screen displays the Nikkei 225 Stock Average figure on the trading floor at the Nomura Securities Co. headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Jan. 11, 2024. The Nikkei 225 rose 1.8% to the highest level in about 34 years on Thursday. Photographer: Nao Sano/Bloomberg

site_title: Young couples voice concerns over housing loan limits under new HDB protocols
summary: Young couples in Singapore are concerned about reassessments of their HDB housing loan amounts under new protocols. The change in HDB's assessment of flat applicants' incomes for loans and grants has left many uncertain. They fear that their loan amounts will be reassessed based on new HFE letters, with no possibility of future reassessments. This has caused anxiety among first-time homebuyers, who are seeking clarity on government policy. The uncertainty has sparked discussions in online chat groups, with some couples seeking feedback from the public and experts.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
The concessionary interest rate for HDB housing loans remains unchanged at 2.6 per cent per annum.
New homes will be built in Chencharu, Yishun and the authorities are studying the Gillman Barracks site for residential use.
The S$300 rental voucher is part of a new scheme for couples eligible for the existing Parenthood Provisional Housing Scheme.

site_title: Hong Kong firms toughest in enforcing back to office in Asia: survey
summary: Hong Kong firms have the highest proportion of employers urging workers to increase office presence, with over 90% compared to 56% globally. A survey by Morgan McKinley found that hybrid arrangements are preferred, and companies in Australia, Japan, and Singapore have lower rates of mandating a return-to-office policy. This trend could benefit Hong Kong's commercial landlords, who are dealing with a record-high office vacancy rate of over 16% in 2023. The study surveyed over 3,400 professionals and 650 employers globally.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 13)
summary: Singapore's private-sector economists raised their forecast for 2024 economic growth to 2.4%, a slight increase from previous expectations. Headline inflation is now expected to be 3.1%, down from previous forecasts. Changi Airport's February passenger movements surpassed pre-pandemic levels, reaching 5.3 million. Meanwhile, Surbana Jurong unveiled its global headquarters, and Singtel halted trading after reports of a potential sale of its Optus unit.

site_title: Changi Airport’s February passenger movements surpass pre-Covid level; China again top source of tourists
summary: Changi Airport's February passenger movements surpassed pre-Covid levels, with 5.3 million passengers, a 4.3% increase over pre-pandemic levels. This marks the first time the airport's monthly passenger traffic has exceeded pre-pandemic levels. The airport also saw a 33.7% increase in air freight movements compared to the same month last year. China remains Singapore's top source of tourists, with 326,970 arrivals, 825.9% higher than the previous year, followed by mainland Chinese carriers Singapore Airlines and Scoot.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Hotel average room rates were mixed across categories in January, with the luxury, upscale and mid-tier segments recording sequential increases, but the economy segment rate falling.

site_title: European shares scale new record highs on upbeat earnings
summary: European shares reached new record highs on Wednesday, driven by upbeat corporate earnings and optimism over interest rate cuts by the European Central Bank and the US Federal Reserve. The pan-European STOXX 600 gained 0.1% and the retail index surged 3.0%, led by Zalando's profit beat and share buy-back announcement. German stocks also hit a new record high, while the UK's blue-chip index held near recent highs.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 has closed up 1 per cent after paring gains following the release of US consumer price data.

site_title: Is the landing soft? Will it stay that way?
summary: US economist Paul Krugman argues that the US economy is likely to achieve a "soft landing" in 2024, characterized by low inflation and unemployment. Contrary to predictions of high unemployment, recent data shows inflation has been stable, with the core PCE index rising at a 2.8% annual rate and wages increasing at less than 4%. However, the unemployment rate has crept up, raising concerns about the Sahm rule, which suggests a recession is likely if the three-month average unemployment rate rises more than half a percentage point above a previous low.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon said the US economy was doing so well it could almost be characterised as a boom, but cautioned against the wholesale embrace of the soft landing narrative by markets.

Shipping containers at the Port of Taicang in Taicang, Jiangsu Province, China, on Thursday, Aug. 24, 2023. China’s economy was meant to drive a third of global economic growth this year, so its dramatic slowdown in recent months is sounding alarm bells across the world. Source: Bloomberg
Shoppers at Macy's store in Herald Square, New York, in December. The early readings on US consumers' holiday spending are encouraging.
If the Fed hits its inflation target without clear signs of impending recession, it would be safe to declare a soft landing.

site_title: Bitcoin tops US$73,000 to hit new record on insatiable ETF demand
summary: Bitcoin reached an all-time high of $73,664 on March 13, driven by record-breaking inflows into US exchange-traded funds tied to the cryptocurrency, with daily flows topping $1 billion. This surge is attributed to a low market depth backdrop, where issuers buy large piles of Bitcoin to support their ETFs, reducing the circulating supply. Other cryptocurrencies, such as Ether, also saw significant gains, with Ether trading 3.3% higher and hitting a one-day peak just shy of its record high.

site_title: Toyota agrees to biggest wage hike in 25 years in sign of Japan Inc’s big pay bump
summary: Toyota Motor agreed to its biggest pay increase in 25 years, with monthly pay hikes of up to 28,440 yen and record bonus payments, following a trend of other major Japanese firms. The move is expected to give the central bank leeway to end its years-long policy of negative interest rates as early as next week. Economists see substantial wage increases as a prerequisite for the Bank of Japan to declare its long-held goals of sustainable wage growth and stable prices are in sight.

images.alt_text: Toyota Motor becomes the most shorted large-cap stock by hedge funds in the Asia-Pacific region in February.
The investment plan also includes an expansion of its factories in the cities of Porto Feliz.
Toyota has issued three other recalls in the US over last two weeks.
Instead of reaching a pact on wages and bonuses, Toyota and union deepened their debate over workplace issues on Wednesday.

site_title: UBS starts job cuts at Asia wealth unit after profit slump
summary: UBS is cutting about 70 people, including relationship managers, mainly in Hong Kong and Singapore, due to a slump in profits in its Asia private banking division. The move comes as wealth generation in China stalls amid a property crisis and sell-off in equities. UBS's pretax profit for Asia-Pacific slumped 46% to US$97 million in the fourth quarter, its lowest globally. The cuts confirm an earlier report and include bankers who joined from Credit Suisse as part of the integration.

images.alt_text: UBS’s existing policy allows the bank to finance coal-fired power companies and miners, as long as production is not being expanded and no more than a fifth of revenue comes from coal.

Australian banknotes in various denominations are arranged for a photograph in Sydney, Australia, on Monday, May 24, 2010. The Australian and New Zealand currencies slid for the sixth time in seven days against the U.S. dollar on concern Europe's debt crisis will  spread. Photographer: Ian Waldie/Bloomberg
Ben Sung’s intra-company move comes after several Singapore-based bankers left Credit Suisse’s APAC Financing Group, following UBS’ takeover.
The market for new AT1s by European banks has been busy this week.
The bank is due to present its fourth-quarter earnings and results for all of 2023.
John McDonald, group chief marketing officer, UBS
The scale of the retrenchment in private banking is one of the biggest seen in Asia and comes as wealth from the Greater China region has tumbled amid a property crisis and the faltering economy.
UBS is making progress on a complex integration and restructuring of Credit Suisse, which it acquired in an emergency rescue.

site_title: Surbana Jurong unveils global headquarters in Jurong Innovation District
summary: Surbana Jurong has unveiled its global headquarters, SJ Campus, in Singapore's Jurong Innovation District. The 1.2 million sqft campus serves as a testing ground for sustainable urban solutions and can accommodate 4,000 employees. Designed by Safdie Architects, the campus features green spaces, rooftop gardens, and an inverted pyramid shape to reduce energy consumption. Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the need for Singaporean firms to stay at the forefront of innovation and explore growth opportunities overseas.

images.alt_text: Zhao Yifan
Kelvin Wong, chief executive officer, Building and Construction Authority
Sean Chiao, who grew up in Taiwan, assumed the role of group chief executive officer in April 2023.
A growing part of what will keep firms here globally competitive is hinging on the companies’ readiness to adapt to new ESG regulations, even if they may not necessarily apply yet, observers said.
The on‐campus EV charging hub is expected to be the largest in South-east Asia.
Surbana Jurong builds new campus in Jurong Innovation District

site_title: Shell to cut about 20% of jobs in deals team amid push for cost savings
summary: Shell to cut approximately 20% of jobs in its deals team as part of its restructuring efforts to reduce costs. The move follows similar job cuts in other business units, with further details to be communicated in April. The company aims to achieve cost savings of $2 billion to $3 billion and has already delivered $1.3 billion in structural savings. CEO Wael Sawan has pledged to improve performance and boost investor returns.

site_title: Property titans seek clues in Cannes for market turnaround
summary: Global real estate investors are cautiously optimistic about a market turnaround, despite the industry's biggest crash in over a decade. The MIPIM property conference in Cannes saw developers and investors discussing deal activity and sector resilience, with data centers and logistics performing better than commercial real estate. Key players, including LaSalle and Blackstone, reported tentative signs of recovery, but caution was also expressed. Experts warn that a broader crisis could unfold if banks and developers avoid crystallizing losses until borrowing costs fall or demand returns.

images.alt_text: Despite the tough conditions, LaSalle is targeting growing its overall property acquisitions in Europe to US$2 billion in 2024, up from US$1.8 billion last year.

site_title: IMDA chairman Chan Yeng Kit to join SPH Media board
summary: IMDA chairman Chan Yeng Kit will join the board of SPH Media Holdings on March 15, succeeding him as chairman of the Infocomm Media Development Authority. Chan, currently permanent secretary of the Ministry of Health, brings "vast experience" in addressing digital disruption challenges. He will be succeeded by Russell Tham, head of emerging technologies at Temasek. The move is seen as a boost to the media industry, with Khaw Boon Wan, chairman of SPH Media Trust, praising Chan's "deep appreciation" of the challenges facing the industry.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan
T Raja Segar will take over from Jawharilal Rajendran as editor of Tamil Murasu.
Patrick Daniel will join SBS Transit's board as an independent non-executive director from Jan 1, 2024.

site_title: Singapore stocks close higher on Wednesday, tracking US gains; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.6% on Wednesday, following overnight US gains, despite slightly higher-than-expected inflation data. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,160.72. Key gainers included Singtel, which rose 3.8%, and Seatrium, which rose 2.2% after announcing a proposed share consolidation. Investors largely shrugged off the inflation report, expecting potential rate cuts from the Federal Reserve this year.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Hong Kong rose for a fourth straight day, while Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta were also in positive territory.
Seatrium logo at their office’s lobby, Oct 19, 2023.

site_title: Sports and music lessons for China’s kids in sharp decline as purse strings tighten
summary: China's middle-class families are cutting back on after-school activities for their children due to economic uncertainty, with private tutoring schools and extracurricular programs closing or reducing services. Parents are reluctant to pay for long sets of lessons in advance, fearing financial instability. The education ministry's crackdown on the private tutoring industry in 2021 has led to a decline in extracurricular activities such as music, dance, and sports. Schools are now staying open longer, but with limited activities, and some have seen significant losses in revenue.

images.alt_text: China's February year-on-year consumer price growth of 0.7 per cent outpaces Reuters economists' forecasted 0.3 per cent uptick.
Trade data for the first two months of the year is typically combined to avoid distortions from the Chinese New Year holiday.
Zheng Shanjie, chair of the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC), says he expects the world’s second-largest economy to have a good first quarter.

site_title: A new-old look for suits
summary: Suits are experiencing a resurgence in style, but the new look is a departure from the tight fits of the 2010s. Instead, designers are embracing a relaxed, classic silhouette reminiscent of 1800s lounge suits and 1940s boxier cuts. This shift is seen as a move towards a more timeless and versatile approach to menswear, rather than a fleeting trend. Local suit makers are now offering bespoke services to cater to this new aesthetic, providing a fresh take on traditional menswear.

site_title: Netanyahu is making Israel radioactive
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's aggressive campaign in Gaza has led to widespread destruction, with over 30,000 Palestinians killed, including thousands of children. The conflict, sparked by Hamas' unprovoked attack on October 7, has resulted in a humanitarian crisis, with many Palestinian civilians left without shelter or protection. Netanyahu's government is criticized for its lack of a coherent plan for governing Gaza, instead opting to rely on local clan leaders, which is unlikely to succeed. The situation is likened to previous failed interventions, such as the US invasion of Iraq, and the environmental disaster caused by Hamas' mismanagement of Gaza's sewage system, which affects Israel's drinking water.

images.alt_text: (Centre) Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's comments came one day after US President Joe Biden said Netanyahu “must pay more attention to the innocent lives being lost as a consequence of the actions taken” in Gaza.
Demonstrators gather with signs during a protest outside the Kirya military base which houses the Defence Ministry in Tel Aviv, Israel, Feb 13, 2024.

site_title: BNP Paribas hikes cost cuts by 400 million euros after weak results
summary: BNP Paribas, the eurozone's largest bank, has increased its cost-cutting plan by 400 million euros to generate additional savings. The bank aims to reach a cumulative savings goal of 2.7 billion euros over the 2022-2025 period. The cost cuts will be achieved through automation, lower purchases, and better task management. The bank's net profit is expected to rise this year, but it will not meet its target for return on tangible equity until 2026.

images.alt_text: BNP Paribas expects a landing for the global economy in 2024, with a high likelihood of a soft landing as central banks initiate monetary easing cycles following subdued inflationary pressures.
“The EBA has advised that the instrument cannot count as fully eligible Tier 2 instrument of BNPP (BNP Paribas),” the watchdog says.

site_title: Singtel halts trading after rising 4.2%, denies media reports of Optus sale
summary: Singtel halted trading after its shares rose 4.2% following reports that the company was in talks to sell its Australian unit Optus to Canadian private equity firm Brookfield for A$16 billion. However, Singtel clarified that there is "no impending deal" and that Optus remains an "integral and strategic" part of the group. The company stated that it is committed to Australia for the long term and will explore options to maximize shareholder value.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
This is the second time the appeal on the case has been dismissed; the case is related to Singtel’s intra-group cross-border financing to acquire Optus in 2001.
Optus' spokesperson apologise for the non-compliance and says the telco has agreed to undergo an independent review under a court-enforcable undertaking.
Singtel says its third quarter net profit decline was due to a higher net exceptional loss that mainly came from Optus and Airtel.
Singtel said that it views its stake in Optus as “strategic” and believes in the long-term outlook of the business.

site_title: Shatec brings hospitality and culinary courses to Orchard Road – and the Middle East
summary: Shatec, a Singapore Hotel Association Training and Education Centre, is opening its first overseas institute in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, in the second half of 2024. The new campus will offer professional development courses in hospitality and culinary arts, customizing curricula for local culture and social norms. This venture is part of Shatec's mission to upskill talent and provide opportunities for a career switch. The partnership with Enterprise Singapore, the Saudi Arabian government, and a private Saudi Arabian company, Modern Food Company, aims to contribute to the growth of the consumer sectors in Saudi Arabia, including hospitality, food services, and retail.

images.alt_text: The Jobs Transformation Map identifies how job roles and skills in the hotel industry will be affected by technology, as well as global and local trends, over the next three years.
Shatec rebrands its mentoring programme
Singaporeans aged 40 and above will receive full government subsidies to pursue a second diploma at polytechnics, Institute of Technical Education, and arts institutions.

site_title: ECB more likely to cut rates in June than April, Villeroy says
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) is likely to cut interest rates in June rather than April, according to Bank of France governor Francois Villeroy de Galhau. Villeroy stated that victory is within sight on inflation and that the ECB will probably lower borrowing costs in the spring, with June being the more probable month. The ECB has policy decisions scheduled for April 11 and June 6, with a majority of policymakers indicating a likely rate cut at the June meeting.

images.alt_text: Lenders currently need to hold 1 per cent of certain liabilities – mostly customer deposits – at the ECB.

site_title: Volkswagen's 2023 profits rise, outlook for this year cautious
summary: Volkswagen reported a 13.1% increase in net profit to 17.9 billion euros in 2023, driven by higher vehicle deliveries. Sales rose 15% to 322.3 billion euros, with the company delivering 9.2 million cars to customers, a 12% improvement. However, the outlook for 2024 is cautious due to tougher international competition and potential supply chain problems. The company expects vehicle deliveries to advance by up to 3% in 2024, despite a strong sales performance in Europe and North America.

images.alt_text: Anhui Jianghuai Automobile (JAC Motors), Volkswagen’s partner in its third China JV, says the two sides will boost the JV’s registered capital to 13.9 billion yuan (S$2.6 billion) from 7.4 billion yuan.

site_title: BOJ views wage talks as key to timing of stimulus exit, Ueda says
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda views the outcome of this year's annual wage negotiations as critical in deciding the timing of an exit from massive stimulus. The central bank will consider tweaking its policy framework if sustained achievement of its 2% inflation target comes into sight. Toyota Motor's announcement of a 25-year-high pay increase for factory workers has heightened expectations for hefty pay hikes, which could give the central bank leeway to end its negative interest rate policy. The Bank of Japan will debate this at its policy meeting next week.

images.alt_text: Unions across industries, including automobiles, electronics, metals, heavy machinery and the service sector have all demanded hefty pay hikes.

site_title: Thai PM poised to step aside as finance chief, report says
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin is poised to step down as finance minister, according to a local report. He may appoint Pichai Chunhavajira, a close confidant and capital markets veteran, as the new finance minister. The change is expected to ease tension with the central bank over monetary policy and help implement the government's economic policies. Srettha's busy schedule has hindered the finance ministry's ability to carry out new economic policies, and the new finance minister will face challenges, including a plan to boost consumption by handing out cash to 50 million individuals.

images.alt_text: Thailand's Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin speaks alongside Cambodia's Prime Minister Hun Manet during a joint press conference at the Government House in Bangkok on February 7, 2024. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)

The stock exchange last month has revealed more details about proposed stricter measures on short selling and programme trading.

site_title: UK economy returns to growth at start of 2024
summary: The UK economy returned to growth in January, with a 0.2% month-on-month increase in gross domestic product, boosted by retailing and house-building. This marks a rebound from a 0.1% fall in December and a 0.3% decline in the fourth quarter of 2023, which met the technical definition of recession. While it's too early to determine if the economy is out of recession, the growth suggests progress in expanding the economy, with the government's Office for Budget Responsibility forecasting 0.8% growth in 2024.

images.alt_text: Carnaby Street in London. The figures showthat the central bank’s efforts to slow demand in the economy are taking the heat out of the labour market, which has fanned upward pressure on prices.

site_title: The future of ‘communist capitalism’ in China
summary: China's economic future under Xi Jinping is uncertain, with some experts fearing the regime's "communist capitalism" is fading away. A recent book by David Daokui Li suggests that Deng Xiaoping's reforms created a sustainable system, but Xi's centralization and reassertion of party control may be unsustainable. Li argues that China's system is paternal, providing stability and prosperity but not accountable to the people. The Xi regime's attempts to tackle Deng's legacy, including corruption and inequality, may ultimately be counterproductive, and China's 1.4 billion people's desire for a better life may continue to drive economic growth.

images.alt_text: The latest amendments to the State Council Organic Law is the latest in a series of measures that have gradually eroded the council's executive authority.
FILE PHOTO: People walk along Nanjing Pedestrian Road, a main shopping area, in Shanghai, China May 5, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song

China's five per cent target would be in line with its GDP growth last year, one of the country’s lowest in decades and a far cry from the double-digit growth that long drove its breakneck development in the nineties and 2000s.
Beijing is expected to announce the target at around 5 per cent, a fairly ambitious number for a government grappling with severe economic challenges.

site_title: Crypto exchange OKX snags major payment institution licence from MAS
summary: OKX, a major cryptocurrency exchange, has received an in-principle approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) for a major payment institution (MPI) licence. This approval allows OKX to provide digital payment token and cross-border money transfer services in Singapore. The exchange will focus on its spot crypto product line and work on bringing local banking connections to customers. OKX president Hong Fang stated that the approval is a validation of the exchange's commitment to regulatory compliance and a significant opportunity to contribute to the Singapore crypto ecosystem.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
FILE PHOTO: The logo of OKX cryptocurrency exchange is seen at Hong Kong Web3 Festival, in Hong Kong, China April 13, 2023. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

site_title: Adidas posts first loss in 30 years and warns on US
summary: German sportswear giant Adidas posted its first annual loss in over 30 years, with a net loss of 58 million euros, due to weak sales in North America. The company expects a 5% decline in US sales this year, attributed to high inventories and decreased demand. Despite this, Adidas expects its underlying business to improve in 2024, with double-digit growth in the second half, driven by a trend for low-rise suede sneakers. The company's board proposes an unchanged dividend of 0.7 euros per share.

images.alt_text: The offerings will include some of the most popular Yeezy designs, including the 350 V2 sneaker in steel gray.
Adidas forecast an operating profit of around 500 million euros (S$723 million) in 2024, against analysts’ estimate of 1.294 billion euros according to a company-compiled consensus.

site_title: Asia: Most markets track Wall Street gains as US data fails to damp rate hopes
summary: Asian markets rose for a fourth consecutive day, mirroring Wall Street gains, as forecast-beating US inflation data failed to dampen expectations of the Federal Reserve cutting interest rates this year. Analysts believe the data shows price rises are levelling out, supporting rate-cut expectations. Traders are pricing in three reductions by the end of 2024, with some predicting the first rate cut could occur in June.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks fell again at mid day on Tuesday as speculation swirls that the Bank of Japan will next week shift away from its ultra-loose monetary policy that has helped strengthen the yen.

site_title: Thai industrial sentiment falls slightly in February on slower domestic demand, exports
summary: Thai industrial sentiment index fell to 90 in February due to slower domestic demand and exports, despite tourism supporting sentiment. Domestic demand was weakened by concerns over high living costs and household debt, while exports slowed due to weak economies of trading partners. However, increased tourism, particularly from China, supported the sentiment. The government aims for a record 40 million foreign visitors this year, up from 28.2 million last year.

images.alt_text: Talks on the Thai-EU FTA should be completed within 1.5 years, says Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin.
The government is now aiming for a record of 40 million foreign visitors this year after welcoming 28 million visitors last year.
The group expects 34 million to 35 million foreign arrivals this year.

site_title: SG alt-meat makers Shiok Meats, Umami Bioworks set to merge
summary: Singapore-based cultivated seafood startups Shiok Meats and Umami Bioworks are merging in a stock deal, with Umami Bioworks acquiring Shiok Meats' assets. Mihir Pershad, founder and CEO of Umami Bioworks, will lead the merged entity, which will retain the Shiok Meats brand. The deal aims to provide a clearer path forward for Umami Bioworks, as its B2B model allows for growth without requiring a large capital raise. The merger is a significant development for Southeast Asia's alternative meat industry, which has seen growth driven by regulatory frameworks for novel foods.

images.alt_text: Golden Mall still goes heavy on regional Chinese cuisines.

site_title: PwC Australia cuts hundreds of jobs in overhaul to lower costs
summary: PwC Australia has cut 329 jobs, or 5% of its workforce, as part of a restructuring effort to lower costs. The move, aimed at saving A$100 million, affects all lines of service and support functions. Up to 37 partners will accelerate their retirement over the next nine months. The firm is also reconfiguring its management leadership team. CEO Kevin Burrowes acknowledged the difficulty of the process, assuring impacted individuals of support and next steps.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand Investment, CICT, Far East Orchard, Keong Hong, Seatrium
summary: The European Central Bank has secured a 10-year tenancy for a jointly owned office building in Frankfurt's banking district, with CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) and CapitaLand Investment (CLI) benefiting from the deal. CICT and CLI's shares rose 0.5% and 1.5% respectively, while Far East Orchard's shares traded flat after announcing a £3 million land acquisition for a 273-bed student accommodation. Keong Hong's shares ended flat after reporting consecutive years of losses, and Seatrium's shares rose 1.1% after receiving in-principle approval for a proposed share consolidation exercise.

site_title: Zara-owner Inditex gets spring season boost from upmarket fashion
summary: Inditex, the parent company of Zara, reported a 11% sales increase in the first half of its spring season, driven by upmarket fashion and higher prices sold to premium shoppers. This growth widened the lead over H&M, with Inditex's sales rising 10% to a record 36 billion euros. Despite slower price increases, Inditex maintained a gross margin of 57.8% and posted a 30% increase in annual net profit. The company plans to invest 900 million euros per year on logistics and expand its store space.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Shoppers walk past a Zara clothes store, part of the Spanish group Inditex, in Las Palmas de Gran Canaria, Spain, December 13, 2022. REUTERS/Borja Suarez/File Photo

site_title: Rocket explodes moments after Japan space startup’s launch
summary: A Japanese space startup, Space One, experienced a major setback after its first rocket launch, the Kairos, exploded just seconds after taking off from Space Port Kii. The 18-meter-long Kairos was carrying a government satellite and was supposed to be a niche filler in the local market with competitive prices and frequent missions. The explosion occurred after a vessel was found offshore in an evacuated area, delaying the launch from March 9. Canon Electronics shares plummeted 13% following the incident.

images.alt_text: A record 100 Chinese missions are expected in 2024, state media reported recently, up more than 40 per cent from last year.

Khaldoon Mubarak, the CEO and Managing Director of Mubadala Investment, says that sovereign wealth funds have an opportunity and responsibility to transform from asset investors to enablers of global progress.
A view from onboard the Odysseus mission in Earth's orbit on Feb 16, 2024. For the first time in more than 50 years, an American spacecraft has landed on the moon.
SpaceX's Falcon 9 rocket lifts off with Intuitive Machines' Nova-C moon lander on top.

site_title: KKR to invest US$400 million in Philippine telecoms tower business
summary: Private equity firm KKR & Co will invest US$400 million in the Philippines' telecoms tower business, developing and acquiring approximately 2,000 towers to support digital connectivity. The investment was announced during a US$1 billion trade mission led by US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo. This marks the latest deal from the mission, which also included investments from companies like Google, Visa, and Microsoft. The move aims to deepen US-Philippines economic ties amid rising tensions with China in the South China Sea.

images.alt_text: Broadcom closed the acquisition more than a year later, in November 2023, after receiving regulatory approval in China.
Broadcom is selling its so-called end-user computer unit, which it inherited as part of its US$61 billion acquisition of software maker VMware in 2023.
KKR is preparing to embark on a fundraising drive for its flagship strategies, including Americas private equity and Asia private equity.
FILE PHOTO: Trading information for KKR & Co is displayed on a screen on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., August 23, 2018. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: This AI architect will design your climate-friendly dream home
summary: Icon, an Austin startup, has introduced an AI architect named Vitruvius to design climate-friendly homes. The AI uses a chatbot to converse with users about their dream projects and generates multiple versions of a house, including exterior and interior renderings and floor plans. Vitruvius will eventually produce its own construction schematics, reducing construction costs by at least $100,000 per home. Icon's new robot, Phoenix, can build multi-story structures and automate construction. The company estimates that Phoenix will cut build time in half and reduce the cost of wall systems by 30% compared to conventional construction. Icon's low-carbon concrete formula, CarbonX, brings emissions down by 2-6% compared to wood-frame alternatives.

images.alt_text: In an undated photo provided by Riken Yamamoto & Field Shop/The Pritzker Architecture Prize shows, Saitama Prefectural University, 1999, Koshigaya, Japan. Yamamoto, whose understated buildings quietly emphasize community and connectivity, has been awarded this year’s Pritzker Prize, architecture’s highest honor.(Tom Welsh/The Pritzker Architecture Prize via The New York Times) -- NO SALES; FOR EDITORIAL USE ONLY WITH NYT STORY PRITZKER-PRIZE BY ROBIN POGREBIN FOR MARCH 5, 2024. ALL OTHER USE PROHIBITED. --

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts cut DFI Retail Group target on lower earnings forecast
summary: Analysts have reduced their price targets for DFI Retail Group after the company's core underlying earnings of $155 million missed street expectations. Despite this, analysts DBS Group Research and RHB maintained their "buy" calls due to the retailer's recovery momentum in the pan-Asian market. The analysts remain positive on the company's recovery amid changing consumer behaviors.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
The rise in Jardine Matheson's underlying profits is due to the reopening of markets post-pandemic, says its executive chairman.
DFI posts a full year net profit of US$32 million for FY2023.
Sheng Siong supermarket outlet in Yishun St 81 at 2.15pm on 13 May 2020, Day 2 of easing circuit breaker measures.

krmall - Jelita Shopping Centre

site_title: UK signs trade pact with Texas in effort to boost green industry
summary: The UK has signed a non-binding memorandum of understanding with Texas, the second-largest US state, to boost cooperation in green energy, aerospace, and advanced technologies. This is the eighth trade pact between the UK and a US state since Brexit, with combined GDP of £5.3 trillion. The deal aims to simplify business operations and recognize engineering qualifications, but falls short of a full Free Trade Agreement with the US. Texas Governor Greg Abbott and UK Business Secretary Kemi Badenoch will sign the deal in London.

images.alt_text: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak says Britain needs to reach its net-zero target “in a sustainable way that doesn’t leave people without energy on a cloudy, windless day”.
FILE PHOTO: Woman holds British Pound banknotes in this illustration taken May 30, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The latest budget cuts capital gains tax by 4 percentage points to 24 per cent. Landlords who wish to sell their apartments and houses will benefit from the reduction, Knight Frank says.

site_title: BT Mark to Market: Behind the minority-investor movement at Great Eastern (Ep 41)
summary: A group of minority shareholders at Great Eastern attempted to table three resolutions at the upcoming AGM, aiming to address their concerns and unlock value. However, their attempt was rejected. Independent investor Ong Chin Woo expressed his concerns and proposed resolutions to align interests and unlock value, but the board dismissed them on a legal technicality. This minority-investor movement may impact Great Eastern's shares, and investors may expect the company to address minority investors' concerns.

images.alt_text: Minority shareholders of Great Eastern want to put forward three resolutions, including one to end the practice of Great Eastern paying its executives with OCBC shares.
The Great Eastern logo on the facade of Great Eastern Centre located at Pickering Street on 4 Dec 2019.
Why Great Eastern’s undervalued shares still hold great potential.

site_title: Cathay Pacific reports first annual profit since 2019
summary: Cathay Pacific has reported its first annual profit since 2019, with a net profit of US$1.25 billion in 2023. The airline cited "significant pent-up demand for travel" following the pandemic as a major factor in its financial success. Cathay Pacific achieved its target of operating at 70% of pre-pandemic passenger flights and saw high yields contribute to its strong financial performance. The airline's profit surge marks a significant turnaround from its losses in 2022.

images.alt_text: Cathay Pacific Flight CX739 arriving at Changi Airport Terminal 4 on September 13, 2022.
The offer is just the latest in a growing list of incentives Cathay has rolled out to tackle a chronic shortage of aircrew.
Cathay Pacific aeroplanes at Hong Kong International Airport, 7 July 2019.

site_title: Hong Kong’s housing glut set to keep prices down despite tax cut
summary: Hong Kong's housing market is expected to remain sluggish despite a tax cut, as a supply glut persists. Property transactions have increased, but prices are not rising due to high borrowing costs and a weak economy. Developers are focusing on clearing inventory, with some offering discounts to avoid overpricing. Experts predict a slow rebound in prices, with a possible increase in the fourth quarter after the market absorbs some of the inventory.

images.alt_text: The draft includes new laws encompassing treason, espionage and external interference.
The real estate crisis in mainland China has made Hong Kong’s residential market seem like a safer bet, adding to its dramatic rebound.
Hong Kong, one of the most expensive property markets in the world, has seen its housing and commercial property prices plunge more than 20 per cent and 30 per cent, respectively, from their peaks.

site_title: South Korea moves closer to extending onshore won trading hours
summary: South Korea is testing after-hours trading of the won, allowing banks to exchange the US dollar-won pair in real-time without predetermined factors. This trial, part of a series of test pilots, aims to extend the onshore won's trading hours, set for July. The move is seen as a step towards enabling 24-hour trading, which could boost the case for South Korea's stocks and bonds to be added to global indexes. The trial began on March 14, marking the first time real-time trading occurred without predetermined factors.

images.alt_text: south korea won Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

site_title: Country Garden misses yuan bond coupon payment for first time
summary: Country Garden Holdings missed a coupon payment on a 96 million yuan yuan bond for the first time, adding to the developer's woes. The missed payment, due on March 12, comes after the company extended more than 10 billion yuan of yuan bonds by three years in September and paid off a 800 million yuan note in December. The developer's shares fell 4.9% and its US dollar bonds trade at deeply distressed levels. A Hong Kong court is considering a creditor's petition to wind up the company, which may add pressure on the developer to advance a debt restructuring plan.

images.alt_text: China’s housing market remains in a deep slump, even as authorities step up efforts to support the industry.
China’s property sector has lurched from one crisis to another since 2021 after a regulatory crackdown on debt-fuelled construction triggered a liquidity squeeze.
In a sign that Country Garden’s creditors are ready for further negotiations, an ad-hoc creditor group hired financial and legal advisers in recent months.

site_title: Gold subdued as sticky US inflation prompts rate-cut rethink
summary: Gold prices steadied after a 1.1% decline on Tuesday, edging 0.1% up to $2,158.26 per ounce.
