The US inflation report showed a 0.4% increase in consumer prices, boosting bond yields and tempering hopes for a June interest rate cut from the Federal Reserve. Market expectations for a rate cut were slightly reduced, with a 68% chance of a 25-basis-point cut in June. The inflation reading also boosted US 10-year Treasury yields and the US dollar.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Gold bars at the Austrian Gold and Silver Separating Plant 'Oegussa' in Vienna, Austria, March 18, 2016.   REUTERS/Leonhard Foeger/File Photo
Bullion hit a record peak of US$2,194.99 on Friday.

site_title: Porsche sees lower returns in year of major model launches
summary: Porsche expects its profit margins to dip this year as it funds the launch of four new models, with deliveries in China falling 15% year-over-year due to a "value over volume" strategy. The company maintains its medium-term margin outlook of 17-19% and targets an operating margin of 15-17% in 2024. This is below analysts' average forecast of 17.4%. Porsche's shares are up 3.2% despite the disappointing outlook, as investors anticipate a strong lineup for the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: The Porsche Studio, located at Guoco Midtown on Beach Road, will be the German luxury carmaker's sole retail outlet in Singapore.
The move marks a shift from Porsche’s previous reluctance to use Google software.
Porsche reports an 18.3 per cent return on sales with operating profit up 9 per cent to 5.5 billion euros in the first nine months of the year.

site_title: Chipmakers searching for ‘China plus 1’ are finding Malaysia
summary: Malaysia is becoming a hotspot for chipmakers seeking to diversify their supply chains, with Austrian tech giant AT&S already gearing up to produce semiconductors in the country. AT&S is just one of several European and American companies moving to or expanding operations in Malaysia, which is the world's sixth-largest exporter of semiconductors and packages 23% of all American chips. The influx of foreign investment is seen as a strategic move to mitigate the risks of tariffs and supply chain disruptions.

images.alt_text: The company said proceeds will be used for expansion of new outlets in Malaysia, establishment of new distribution centres and the purchase of delivery trucks, among other things.
Khazanah Nasional Berhad office which located in U.A.B building at Gat Lebuh China in George Town, Penang.
Economists expect Bank Negara to keep rates steady at 3 per cent until the end-2024 or even longer.

site_title: A new era for the Golden Mall
summary: The Golden Mall, a pioneering food hall in Flushing, Queens, is set to open its second location in Manhattan this summer. After a major renovation in 2023, the original mall reopened with a new food court featuring mainstays and trendy imports, catering to the neighborhood's Asian residents and maintaining its status as a top food destination. The new Manhattan location will offer pan-Asian dishes on a seven-floor, 32,000-square-feet space, with the Cheng family betting big on the city's growing demand for modern Asian food.

images.alt_text: Grocery-delivery service Instacart has deleted the bizarre image of “cheddar and cream cheese sauce for mac and cheese” and other recipes that don’t (or probably shouldn’t) exist.

site_title: Economists raise Singapore’s 2024 growth forecast to 2.4%; expect lower headline inflation of 3.1%: survey
summary: Singapore's private-sector economists have raised their forecast for 2024 economic growth to 2.4% from 2.3% in the latest quarterly survey. Headline inflation is now expected at 3.1%, down from 3.4% previously, while core inflation remains unchanged at 3%. Economists are more upbeat on the manufacturing outlook, with growth predicted at 4%, but expectations for accommodation and food services have worsened. Monetary policy loosening is expected to remain unchanged in April, with some forecasters anticipating a reduction in the S$NEER policy band in July and October. External growth remains the top risk to forecasts, with a slowdown and better-than-expected external growth being cited as major concerns.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Economists raise their inflation forecasts for 2024 to 3.4 per cent for headline inflation, up from their previous projection of 3.1 per cent, and 3 per cent for core inflation, up from 2.8 per cent.
On a month-on-month basis, headline inflation is down by 0.7 per cent in January, while core inflation is up 0.6 per cent.

Simulations by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) have showed that even if the nominal exchange rate had not been raised, the Singapore dollar would still have appreciated similarly in real terms, chief economist Edward Robinson said.
The Red Sea supply chain disruptions could cut as much as 0.5 percentage points off Asia’s economic growth this year, and add up to 0.4 percentage points to the inflation rate.

site_title: Seatrium gets SGX nod for 20-to-1 share consolidation
summary: Seatrium has received in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) for a 20-for-1 share consolidation, subject to shareholder approval at its annual general meeting in April. The consolidation aims to increase market interest and attractiveness in its listed shares, as many potential shareholders were unable to participate due to its penny-stock status. The SGX approval follows a proposal made in February.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei

site_title: STMicroelectronics CEO says China is a growth market despite US chip war
summary: STMicroelectronics CEO Jean-Marc Chery stated that China remains an important growth market for the company despite US-China tensions over semiconductors. Chery views being in the Chinese market for electric vehicles, digital power controls, and renewable energy as essential, citing China's massive investment in chip production and substantial government subsidies. The company plans to increase its local production and expects China to be the fastest growth market in silicon carbide, with its China penetration set to increase.

images.alt_text: STMicroelectronics says it expects fourth quarter sales to fall about 3 per cent year on year to US$4.30 billion.

site_title: Europe: Shares jump to fresh record after US inflation data
summary: European shares closed at a record high, up 1% after the US consumer price data showed a slight easing in core inflation, which traders believed would prompt the Federal Reserve to initiate rate cuts in June. The Stoxx 600 rallied on expectations of European Central Bank rate cuts and surged in key sectors such as automakers and banks.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 ended 0.4 per cent lower on Monday, coming off an all-time high hit in the prior session.

site_title: Far East Orchard to buy Glasgow site for purpose-built student accommodation
summary: Far East Orchard has agreed to buy a Glasgow site for £3 million to develop a 273-bed purpose-built student accommodation by 2026. The acquisition is a partnership between Far East Orchard and Woh Hup Holdings, with Osborne Street Development as the development manager. The £38.9 million development costs will be funded by the partners. The project marks Far East Orchard's maiden venture in Scotland, with no expected impact on its consolidated net earnings per share.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Far East Orchard's purpose-built student accommodation portfolio in the UK is the key driving force behind the group's revenue and net profit growth in FY2023.

site_title: Keong Hong files notice of three straight years of losses
summary: Keong Hong, a mainboard-listed construction player, has filed notice of pre-tax losses for the three most recently completed consecutive financial years. The company's six-month average daily market capitalization as of March 12 stood at S$35 million. This marks the second year in a row the company has filed notice of three straight years of losses, putting it at risk of being placed on the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) watch list.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Keong Hong chief executive Ronald Leo (pictured) is cautiously optimistic that the worst is behind the company.
Keong Hong's increase in revenue is a result of progress made in its various ongoing construction projects, as well as an increase in productivity of construction activities, the company says.
The tender, awarded by Solitaire Cecil, involves the proposed erection of a 20-storey office building.
Ronald Leo, chairman and chief executive of Keong Hong Holdings.
Keong Hong shareholder LJHB raises stake; triggers general offer for all shares at S$0.384 apiece

site_title: Global corporate dividends hit record US$1.66 trillion in 2023
summary: Global corporate dividends reached a record $1.66 trillion in 2023, with banks contributing half of the growth. 86% of listed companies increased or maintained dividends, and payouts are forecast to reach $1.72 trillion this year. Microsoft, Apple, and ExxonMobil were the top dividend payers. Higher interest rates boosted bank margins, but mining sector cuts offset some of the growth, with Japan and Europe being key contributors to the increase.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This picture shows Aramco tower at the King Abdullah Financial District (KAFD) in Riyadh on April 16, 2023. Saudi Arabia has ordered energy giant Aramco to maintain its oil production capacity at 12 million barrels per day, abandoning a planned increase, the firm said on January 30, 2024. "Aramco announces that it has received a directive from the ministry of energy to maintain its maximum sustainable capacity (MSC) at 12 million barrels per day" instead of ramping it up to 13 million bpd, the firm said in a statement. (Photo by Fayez Nureldine / AFP)
Investors should have much to cheer with DBS' strong financial performance, proposed bonus issue and plans to pay higher dividends.
FILE PHOTO: The BP logo is seen on gasoline pumps at a BP gas station in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., November 24, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: Property investor LaSalle says 30% of European office space may be ‘obsolete’
summary: LaSalle Investment Management's head of Europe, Philip La Pierre, predicts that 20-30% of European office space may be "obsolete" due to the tough commercial real estate market. Despite this, LaSalle aims to increase its property acquisitions in Europe to $2 billion in 2024, up from $1.8 billion last year, and sees opportunities in real estate debt. The firm acknowledges that investors are slowly adapting to lower prices, but it will take time for them to psychologically accept losses.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Lights are seen in windows of an office building early in the morning in Brussels, Belgium, October 28, 2022. REUTERS/Yves Herman/File Photo

site_title: Pentagon scraps plan to spend US$2.5 billion on Intel grant
summary: The Pentagon has scrapped its plan to spend up to $2.5 billion on a chip grant to Intel, leaving the Commerce Department to make up for the shortfall. Intel had been seeking incentives worth over $10 billion from the Chips and Science Act, including a $3.5 billion defense funding package. The decision may limit Intel's total funding and could lead to a greater share of the funds being devoted to military uses. The move has raised concerns about the dominance of Intel in the chip industry and the impact on other companies, including Globalfoundries.

images.alt_text: The parent company plans to hold a stock offering for Altera over the next two to three years.
The parent company plans to hold a stock offering for Altera over the next two to three years.
While AI is driving a boom in the chip sector, Intel seems to be an exception, analysts say.

site_title: Toyota becomes Asia’s most shorted large-cap stock: Hazeltree
summary: Toyota Motor has become the most shorted large-cap stock by hedge funds in the Asia-Pacific region, overtaking Takeda Pharmaceutical in February. US electric carmaker Tesla remains the most shorted stock in the Americas, while LVMH is the top short in the Europe, Middle East, and Africa (EMEA) region for the sixth consecutive month. This report from Hazeltree highlights shifts in the short-selling landscape among large-cap stocks in various regions.

site_title: US: Markets shrug off hot inflation report
summary: US stocks rose sharply on Tuesday, shrugging off a hotter-than-expected inflation report. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.6%, while the S&P 500 closed 1.1% higher. Tech shares led the rally, with the Nasdaq up 1.5% and companies like Nvidia and Meta rising 7.1% and 3.3% respectively. The inflation data is expected to keep the Federal Reserve on hold, as investors shift focus to earnings growth.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., March 5, 2024.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Samsung to use chipmaking tech favoured by SK Hynix as AI chip race heats up: sources
summary: Samsung Electronics plans to use chipmaking technology favored by SK Hynix, a move aimed at catching up in the high-end AI chip market. The decision comes as demand for high bandwidth memory chips has surged with the growth of generative AI. Samsung has stuck with non-conductive film (NCF) technology, while Hynix switched to mass reflow moulded underfill (MR-MUF) to address production issues. This shift is expected to help Samsung compete with Nvidia, the leader in AI chip production, and other players in the market.

images.alt_text: Samsung is working to catch up to rival SK Hynix in high-bandwidth memory, or HBM, chips, which are used to help Nvidia’s accelerators in training artificial intelligence.
Samsung is making a push to expand its small share in China, the world’s largest smartphone market.
Health tracking is already a key selling point of smartphones and watches, with Samsung, Apple and Alphabet’s Google using the features to attract and retain customers.

site_title: Unsold private housing stock on the rise ahead of ramp-up in new launches in 2024
summary: Singapore's unsold private housing stock rose 20% over the last two years, driven by a ramp-up in new launches coinciding with cautious market demand. New home sales dropped 9.6% in 2023, while 7,551 homes were launched, a 66.8% surge. Several projects, including the 99-year leasehold Cuscaden Reserve, face critical sales deadlines this year with significant unsold units remaining. Developers may offer discounts to clear remaining units, but analysts believe the rising unsold inventory is unlikely to pose an issue for these projects, as supply is catching up with demand.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Land betterment charge rates for non-landed residential use were raised by 0.1 per cent on average.
Median profit for non-landed private homes, including executive condominiums, with a holding period of five years or less doubled to S$247,000 in 2023, from S$123,241 in 2019.
One of two large sites awarded for over S$1 billion last year was a prime Marina Gardens Lane site.  The site is etched in red in this aerial view of Marina South.

site_title: Construction recovery paves the way for Singapore-listed concrete, steel producers
summary: Singapore-listed concrete and steel producers are experiencing a recovery in construction activity, driven by the lifting of a Heightened Safety Period in September 2022. Companies like Pan-United Corporation and BRC Asia have seen an increase in demand, with Pan-United holding a 40% local market share in ready-mix concrete and BRC Asia holding an 80% market share in steel rebars. This growth is expected to continue, with investor interest building in the construction material space.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
The pressure to adopt greener materials may eventually have to come from end-users of these buildings.
Sean Chiao, who grew up in Taiwan, assumed the role of group chief executive officer in April 2023.
The government has announced new updates and initiatives to accelerate transformation in the built environment sector.

site_title: US House to vote on TikTok crackdown; fate uncertain in Senate
summary: The US House of Representatives is set to vote on a bill that would give TikTok's Chinese owner ByteDance about six months to divest the app used by 170 million Americans or face a ban. The vote is expected under fast-track rules requiring two-thirds support. The bill has already passed the House Energy and Commerce Committee 50-0, but its fate is uncertain in the US Senate, where some senators want to take a different approach. A classified briefing was held for House members, and some lawmakers, including a Democrat, oppose the bill due to concerns about the process and First Amendment rights.

images.alt_text: In 2020, Donald Trump sought to ban TikTok and Chinese-owned WeChat but was blocked by the courts.
Because TikTok is owned by a Chinese company, ByteDance, the short-form video platform's popularity among Americans carries implications beyond the mobile-phone screen.

site_title: Mango adapts as climate change makes fashion less seasonal
summary: Spanish retailer Mango is adapting its clothing line to reflect the changing climate, with a focus on adaptable and performance fabrics that can handle varying temperatures. CEO Toni Ruiz stated that the industry must adjust to less seasonal fashion due to climate change, where customers are seeking pieces that can be worn in multiple temperatures. Mango is offering clothes for both men and women using these adaptable fabrics, catering to the changing needs of its customers.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An item of clothing by Spanish fashion retailer Mango. REUTERS/Albert Gea/File Photo

site_title: Coinbase Global plans to offer US$1 billion in convertible notes
summary: Coinbase Global plans to issue $1 billion in convertible senior notes to repay existing debt and for general corporate purposes. The notes, maturing in 2030, will be sold to institutional investors and have a 30-day option for additional $150 million to cover over-allotments. The proceeds will be used to repay existing debt and for working capital and capital expenditures. This move comes after the company's shares fell 3.6% after the announcement, despite a 47% year-to-date gain.

site_title: No Signboard to resume trading, subject to conditions
summary: No Signboard's shares have been suspended from trading since January 2022 due to concerns over the company's ability to continue as a going concern. The group has submitted a proposal to resume trading, subject to the Singapore Exchange's approval of several conditions. These include disclosing the validity of resolutions from an extraordinary general meeting, pro-forma financial statements for a new business acquisition, and confirmation of sufficient working capital. Once conditions are met, No Signboard will need to seek approval from the Singapore Exchange Regulation on the trading resumption date.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: Oil prices settle slightly down after US boosts crude output forecast
summary: Oil prices settled slightly down on Tuesday after a higher-than-expected forecast for US crude oil production and bearish economic data. Brent futures dropped 29 US cents to $81.92 a barrel, while US WTI crude declined 37 US cents to $77.56. The OPEC stuck to its forecast for strong global oil demand growth in 2024 and 2025, despite geopolitical tensions limiting declines. US consumer prices rose solidly in February, primarily driven by higher petrol and shelter costs.

images.alt_text: Brent futures for May delivery settled at US$82.21 a barrel, gaining 13 cents.

site_title: Funds trim positions in agri-commodities amid bearish outlook, uncertainty
summary: Funds in the agri-commodities market are trimming their positions due to a bearish outlook and uncertainty, with sugar, coffee, and cocoa contracts experiencing a pullback. The Commitments of Traders report showed declines in funds' net positions in corn, wheat, and soybeans, as well as cocoa and coffee futures. This is attributed to profit-taking and cautious sentiment, with some analysts expecting a fourth supply deficit in cocoa and potential harvest pressure in soybeans. Market watchers are also monitoring macroeconomic troubles and weather conditions that could impact agri-commodity production.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Aletheia Capital’ analyst Nirgunan Tiruchelvam said the conflicts, along with the ongoing El Nino phenomenon, make for a worrisome near-term outlook for commodities like palm oil and rubber.
Palm oil is one of the only agri commodities that has booked a fall in price so far this year, which has pressured the margins of companies in the palm oil production sector.

site_title: Arm’s shares rise as Wall Street eyes IPO lock-up expiration
summary: Arm Holdings shares rose 2.1% to $129.50 on Tuesday as the lockup period tied to its IPO expired, allowing more investors to sell their shares. The British chip designer's shares have surged 68% since beating analyst expectations in February. The expiration of the lockup period, which limits shares available for trading, is expected to lead to increased trading activity. Softbank owns 90% of Arm's outstanding shares, and its intentions regarding its remaining stake remain a major unknown factor.

images.alt_text: Arm’s technology for creating data centre processors is already in use by Amazon.com, Microsoft and Ampere Computing, which supplies chips to Oracle.

site_title: Europe should toughen up and support seizing Russian assets
summary: The US is ready to seize $300 billion of blocked Russian central bank assets and transfer them to Ukraine, but Europe is hesitant due to concerns about the potential impact on the euro's reserve role and potential retaliation from Russia. However, experts argue that seizing the assets is consistent with international law, particularly in response to Russia's unprovoked invasion of Ukraine and war crimes. Europe should "toughen up" and support seizing the assets to send a strong message to Russia and deter further aggression.

images.alt_text: US and British officials have worked in recent months to jumpstart efforts to confiscate Russian assets immobilised in Belgium and other European cities, to help reconstruction in Ukraine, parts of which lie in ruins.

With fighting now in its second year, the latest thinking is that prolonged sanctions will have a cumulative effect, eventually forcing President Vladimir Putin into deciding between continuing the war and saving his economy.

site_title: SMEs need to strategise on sustainability to stay competitive: Grace Fu
summary: Singapore's Minister for Sustainability and Environment, Grace Fu, emphasized the need for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to strategize on sustainability to stay competitive globally. Fu noted that international sustainability regulations may impact SMEs in global supply chains, and encouraged SMEs to adopt energy-efficient equipment, tap government schemes, and adapt to new reporting requirements. She also addressed resistance among accountants towards sustainability, urging them to focus on the potential career benefits.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Among the enhanced schemes for SMEs, the Energy Efficiency Grant has been expanded to include data centres and their users.

site_title: The WTO may be on its last legs
summary: The 13th ministerial meeting of the World Trade Organization (WTO) in Abu Dhabi ended without significant agreements, despite going into overtime. The meeting failed to reach consensus on key issues such as subsidies for unsustainable fishing practices, food stockpiling, and market access for farm produce. The US Trade Representative departed early, and the WTO's structure was also left unchanged due to blocked appointments to its appeals court. The only agreement reached was a moratorium on taxing digital content until 2026, marking a bleak outcome for the organization.

images.alt_text: Meetings in the capital of the United Arab Emirates were dominated by disorder and confusion.
FILE PHOTO: Delegates pose for a family photo during the 13th WTO ministerial conference in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates, February 26, 2024. REUTERS/Abdel Hadi Ramahi/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: Delegates pose for a family photo during the 13th WTO ministerial conference in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates, February 26, 2024. REUTERS/Abdel Hadi Ramahi/File Photo
World Trade Organization (WTO) Director-General Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala attends the Building Bridges conference in Geneva, Switzerland, October 2, 2023. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse

site_title: Elevating Singapore’s advanced manufacturing cluster
summary: Singapore aims to boost its advanced manufacturing sector, a key contributor to the country's economy, by 50% by 2030. The government has launched initiatives to encourage innovation, R&D, and workforce transformation. The Refundable Investment Credit scheme is one of the measures to encourage companies to pursue R&D and innovation projects. The government also plans to address energy transition, financing for growth, and other areas underpinned by tax and fiscal measures. This move is part of the Manufacturing 2030 initiative, which envisions Singapore as a global business innovation and talent hub for the advanced manufacturing cluster.

images.alt_text: Singapore can continue to secure growth by serving as a trusted node and connector, offer a strong innovation ecosystem, and transforming through tripartism, says Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat.
A new initiative named the Future Energy Fund will receive an initial injection of S$5 billion to build critical infrastructure and improve energy security.
Finance Minister Lawrence Wong noted that many companies have seen increases in the likes of wage bills, as well as rental and utilities costs.
Budget 2024 is a timely platform to drive initiatives that can strengthen enterprise digitalisation, sustainability, and internationalisation as levers for growth.

site_title: Singapore shares track global rally on Wednesday; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 7.53 points, or 0.2%, to 3,149, mirroring overnight gains in global markets following the release of Federal Reserve inflation data. Across the broader market, gainers outnumbered losers 70 to 44, with 36 million securities worth S$50.2 million changing hands. Seatrium was the most heavily traded counter, climbing 1.1% to S$0.093 after 4.9 million securities were transacted.

images.alt_text: The European Central bank signs a 10-year tenancy agreement with CICT and CLI, the owners of office building Gallileo in Frankfurt.

site_title: AJJ Medtech ventures into healthcare space; banks on acquisitions, portfolio expansion
summary: AJJ Medtech, a healthcare-focused company, has pivoted into the medical technology sector after being acquired by a new management team in 2020. The company, previously an offshore shipyard business, focused on "building its foundations" during the pandemic years. With borders reopened, AJJ Medtech is now ready to roll out its high-tech medical consumables and equipment to more customers in South-east Asia, offering over 6,000 products. The company has made strategic acquisitions, including a 70% stake in ultrasound distributor Quest Asia Technologies, to expand its portfolio and offerings.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
The S$180 million National Semiconductor Translation and Innovation Centre will be open in Fusionopolis from April this year.
Mirxes would be one of the rare biotech startups to go public on the Singapore bourse, amid a broader push by the government to have tech startups listed locally.

site_title: Boeing whistleblower found dead of apparent suicide
summary: A former Boeing employee, John Barnett, who had worked for 32 years, was found dead of an apparent suicide in South Carolina. Barnett had previously raised concerns about Boeing's production issues and was involved in a whistleblower lawsuit related to the 787 Dreamliner plane. The Charleston County coroner's office confirmed his death as a self-inflicted gunshot wound, and Boeing released a statement expressing sadness over his passing.

images.alt_text: The Boeing Co. logo is displayed outside of company offices near Los Angeles International Airport (LAX) in El Segundo, California on January 18, 2024. (Photo by Patrick T. Fallon / AFP)
Data from airline tracker FlightAware showed the Latam plane lost altitude about two hours into the three-hour flight from Sydney to Auckland.
FILE PHOTO: Workers walk by a 737 Max aircraft on the production line at the Boeing factory in Renton, Washington, U.S., March 27, 2019.  REUTERS/Lindsey Wasson

The problem with the Alaska Airlines jet is believed to stem from maintenance on the part performed at Boeing’s Renton, Washington factory in which the door plug is believed to have been removed and reinstalled.

US Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg says air travel is the safest mode of US travel but “keeping it that way is going to require Boeing to step up and the FAA to keep Boeing under a microscope, including limiting how many aircraft they can produce in a month until they can do it safely.”

site_title: Companies’ climate reporting must go beyond measuring numbers for reporting’s sake
summary: Singapore will require all listed companies to report Scope 1 and 2 emissions from 2025 and Scope 3 emissions from 2026, with external limited assurance for Scope 1 and 2 emissions from 2027. Large non-listed companies will also be required to report from 2027. However, only 53% of companies in a recent study reported climate transition plans, highlighting the need for companies to develop credible plans to address material climate risk. Regulatory efforts, such as Singapore's new climate reporting rules, aim to drive progress, but the success of these initiatives remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Kenneth Lim
Skyline of Singapore's Business District taken from Marina Bay Sands on Oct 17, 2023. For stories on sustainability, garden city, air quality and more.
SGX RegCo says that its proposals are to help issuers prepare for a low-carbon future.
Definitions of transition are still very much confined to the environment.

site_title: GE Aerospace to invest more than US$650 million in factories, supply chain in 2024
summary: GE Aerospace plans to invest over US$650 million in its US manufacturing plants and supply chain in 2024 to boost production capacity. The investment includes nearly US$450 million in 22 US facilities, US$100 million in international sites, and an additional US$100 million in US-based suppliers. This move aims to support demand from commercial and defense clients, including engine suppliers for Boeing and Airbus jets. Additionally, the company is hiring over 1,000 employees at its US factories.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of the GE Aerospace booth during the Singapore Airshow at Changi Exhibition Centre in Singapore February 21, 2024. REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo

site_title: Oracle surges to record high as AI demand helps reignite cloud business momentum
summary: Oracle surged to a record high, reaching a 13% gain, as the company's low-cost cloud provider strategy and tie-up with AI chip giant Nvidia appear to be paying off. The database megacorp is set to make joint announcements with Nvidia next week, potentially boosting its cloud-computing market share. Oracle's efforts to compete with industry heavyweights Amazon and Microsoft are gaining momentum.

images.alt_text: Oracle, known for its database software, is focused on expanding its cloud infrastructure business to compete with Amazon.com, Microsoft and Alphabet’s Google.
Oracle is focused on expanding its cloud infrastructure business to more forcefully compete with Amazon.com, Microsoft and Alphabet’s Google.
Some new features in Oracle's NetSuite are aimed at automating the mundane day-to-day tasks of a finance department.

site_title: Britain considering measures to stop foreign states from buying newspapers
summary: Britain is considering changing the law to prevent foreign states from owning news organizations, amid concerns about press freedom and editorial interference. The government is weighing whether to allow Abu-Dhabi-backed Redbird IMI to buy the Telegraph newspaper. Around 100 lawmakers have signed a letter opposing the takeover, citing concerns about censorship. Media Minister Lucy Frazer is deciding whether to allow the deal, with a possible amendment to the Digital Markets bill that would give ministers a veto over foreign state bids for British newspapers.

images.alt_text: The fate of Sports Illustrated, long the pinnacle of sports writing in the US, is up in the air after its publisher, Arena Group, defaulted on a licensing payment to Authentic Brands Group, which owns the name.

site_title: Halcyon Agri replaces CEO with controlling shareholder’s CFO
summary: Halcyon Agri, a mainboard-listed rubber producer, has appointed Sun Weiliang, CFO of its controlling shareholder Hainan Rubber Group (HRG), as CEO, replacing Li Xuetao with immediate effect. Li will relinquish executive director and CEO positions, and be assigned a post by HRG. The move is in line with HRG's "strategic development and needs."

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: US consumer inflation up unexpectedly in February
summary: US consumer inflation rose unexpectedly in February, climbing 3.2% from the previous year, slightly faster than economists' expectations. After stripping out volatile food and fuel costs, inflation came in at 3.8%, down from 3.9% in January. Core inflation increased slightly more than forecast, driven by airline fares and car insurance, but a closely watched housing measure remained moderate. The data suggests that bringing inflation back to a normal pace will be a bumpy process, and the Federal Reserve may proceed cautiously in lowering interest rates.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden wants to sharply raise taxes on corporations and high earners in his second four-year term.

site_title: US dollar flat after hot inflation data
summary: The US dollar remained flat at 102.83 after initially jumping following hotter-than-expected inflation data, which showed a 0.4% increase in the Consumer Price Index in February. The data, in line with forecasts, also showed a 3.2% year-on-year rise. Meanwhile, the euro was flat at $1.0928, and the yen fell 0.33% to $147.47. Analysts expect the European Central Bank to discuss a potential rate cut by June, while the Bank of Japan is set to meet next week, with market expectations of a possible rate hike.

images.alt_text: The US dollar was last down 0.2 per cent at 146.79 yen as the Japanese currency climbed.

site_title: US airlines warn of more Boeing delivery delays due to safety crisis
summary: US airlines have cut their expectations for Boeing deliveries this year due to the safety crisis affecting the planemaker. United Airlines CEO Scott Kirby stated that Boeing deliveries will be "way behind" this year, while Southwest Airlines expects 42% fewer MAX deliveries than previously estimated. The airline industry faces challenges in meeting record travel demand, with heavy backlogs making it hard to shift orders to rival Airbus. Boeing shares dropped 4% after an FAA audit found numerous problems with its 737 MAX production.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Workers walk by a 737 Max aircraft on the production line at the Boeing factory in Renton, Washington, U.S., March 27, 2019.  REUTERS/Lindsey Wasson

site_title: Construction material manufacturers mull green opportunities for growth
summary: Construction material manufacturers are exploring green opportunities for growth as awareness about environmental concerns rises. Companies like Pan-United Corporation, which has over 300 green-certified concrete solutions, are already benefiting from the shift towards low-carbon products. However, adoption of greener materials, such as low-carbon concrete and steel, is still limited, with the construction industry showing no appetite for greener steel. The pressure to adopt green materials may come from end-users of buildings, such as developers and governments, as they calculate their carbon footprint.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

site_title: Deutsche Bank CEO Sewing vows to keep expenses in check
summary: Deutsche Bank CEO Christian Sewing vowed to meet cost targets, aiming for 5 billion euros in first-quarter expenses and 20 billion euros for the full year. The lender has promised 2.5 billion euros in savings after announcing plans to cut 3,500 jobs. Sewing also mentioned a potential increase in fixed-income trading revenue in the first quarter. The announcement comes amid efforts to boost the share price, which has remained stagnant since Sewing took over.

site_title: New Bill proposes up to S$100,000 in fines for corporate service providers that breach anti-money laundering obligations
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Finance and Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) are proposing a new bill that could impose fines of up to S$100,000 on corporate service providers that breach anti-money laundering obligations. The bill aims to enhance the regulatory framework for corporate service providers, requiring them to register with Acra and have at least one registered qualified individual. Non-compliance could result in fines of up to S$100,000, imprisonment, or both. The bill also targets the misuse of nominee directorship arrangements and increases penalties for breaches of obligations related to the Register of Registrable Controllers and other registers.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Acra says its move to cancel LW Business Consultancy and Wang Junjie's registrations was in view of breaches of anti-money laundering and countering the financing of terrorism controls.

Acra is looking to table several proposals in 2024, which include enhancing the penalities on errant corporate service providers, and putting restrictions on directorships, such as limiting the number of nominee directorships one can hold.
The government said the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) will strengthen its AML regime for corporate service providers.

site_title: The Swift lift that Singapore malls need
summary: Singapore's tourist belt needs a boost to compete with neighboring cities. Taylor Swift's six-night concert in Singapore brought in estimated $300-400 million to the economy, despite costing around $20 million. The country's reliance on shopping streets and smaller malls is being outdone by larger malls in the region. Meanwhile, local businesses are optimistic, with the Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau's Business Optimism Index reaching its highest in a year. The Reits sector is expected to benefit from data center and retail investments, with Keppel and ESR making significant moves.

images.alt_text: Michelle Low
New home sales at the year’s first few project launches have gone much slower than they used to, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
Wealthy people have been busy property shopping, writes BT senior correspondent Leslie Yee.
Private property owners have baulked at seeing their property tax bills shoot up this year, after a two-tiered tax hike designed as a de facto wealth tax kicked in
Is Meta’s exit from a grade A office building in downtown Singapore a foreshadowing of more vacancies to come?
Wee Cho Yaw's accomplishments stretch far beyond banking, writes BT senior correspondent Leslie Yee.

site_title: US: Nasdaq leads Wall St higher as rate-sensitive growth stocks rally post CPI data
summary: The Nasdaq Composite rose 97.71 points, or 0.61%, to 16,116.98, driven by gains in rate-sensitive growth and chip stocks ahead of potential Federal Reserve rate cuts. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also opened higher, with the Dow gaining 113.66 points, or 0.29%, and the S&P 500 rising 16.36 points, or 0.32%. Traders are optimistic about future rate cuts following inflation data.

site_title: Shell considers slowing the pace of its carbon emissions cuts
summary: Shell is considering slowing its pace of carbon emissions cuts as it updates its energy-transition strategy, potentially altering its long-term climate targets. The move comes amid CEO Wael Sawan's plan to allocate more investments to oil and gas to boost shareholder returns. Shell initially pledged to decrease net carbon intensity by 20% by 2030, 45% by 2035, and reach net zero by 2050. An update to its plan is set to be published on March 14, which could include changes to its climate targets.

images.alt_text: Shell will cut 200 jobs in 2024 and has placed another 130 positions under review as part of a drive to reduce the headcount in the unit.

site_title: AI’s carbon footprint comes to a reckoning
summary: Artificial intelligence's growing environmental impact poses a significant challenge to the sector, as larger models require more computational power, leading to increased energy consumption and carbon emissions. Companies involved in AI research and development must reconcile innovation with maintaining a favorable environmental, social, and governance (ESG) score. To mitigate this, some companies are adopting "time-shifting" strategies, optimizing energy consumption during off-peak hours and synchronizing operations with renewable energy availability. The AI community is at a crossroads, requiring a balance between technological progress and environmental responsibility, with policymakers, investors, and end-users playing a crucial role in driving sustainability.

images.alt_text: The growth of AI is also requiring a rethink of data centre engineering and design, as more servers and components have to be packed into the same physical space to allow for greater computational power.
One of the walkway around Gardens by the Bay. At the ground is the Singapore Flyer.

site_title: CapitaLand secures European Central Bank as new anchor tenant
summary: CapitaLand Investment has secured the European Central Bank (ECB) as an anchor tenant for their jointly owned office building, Gallileo, in Frankfurt. The 10-year tenancy will see the ECB occupy over 90% of the building's total net lettable area. The deal is expected to exceed 95% occupancy when the City of Frankfurt signs a lease for the basement space. The ECB will begin occupying the space in phases starting from the second half of 2025, following a €180 million upgrade project.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Soh Kim Soon (left) will retire as chairman of CapitaLand China Trust Management's board from Apr 23. He is succeeded by Tan Tee How (right).

site_title: Government the most trusted institution in Singapore: Survey
summary: Singapore remains the most trusted institution in the country, with 77% of respondents trusting the government, up 1 percentage point from 2023. However, 93% of employed respondents are worried about job loss, and concerns about hackers and climate change have increased. The survey found that innovation is poorly managed, with 28% of respondents saying it is poorly managed, and that people expect institutions to protect core values and be transparent about new technologies. Despite this, the trust in Singapore's institutions is still higher than the global average, and the country is well-positioned to harness its innovation edge.

site_title: Manchester United profit rises as club looks to Ratcliffe for on-pitch success
summary: Manchester United reported a net income of £20.4 million for the three months ended Dec 31, up from £6.3 million a year earlier. The club's revenue rose 35% to nearly £226 million in the quarter, boosted by broadcasting revenue from the Uefa Champions League. New co-owner Jim Ratcliffe is expected to help deliver success on the pitch, with the club currently sixth in the Premier League table. Ratcliffe's investment aims to revive the club's fortunes, following a cut in annual profit and revenue forecast in January.

images.alt_text: Billionaire Jim Ratcliffe’s Ineos Automotive offers a first look at the Fusilier, a sport utility vehicle smaller than the Grenadier 4x4 that the closely held company started selling early last year.

Jim Ratcliffe’s US$1.25 billion deal for a 25 per cent stake in the club, in which he will also invest US$300 million into infrastructure and take charge of their soccer operations, was completed on Tuesday.
Jim Ratcliffe, who grew up a United fan, told reporters recently that ownership in the club is the most exciting endeavour of his life.

site_title: Tech CEOs are addicted to taking needless risks
summary: Tech CEOs, including Elon Musk, Mark Zuckerberg, and Sam Altman, are taking unnecessary and high-risk personal behaviors, despite their companies' dependence on them. This "key-person risk" has led to concerns about the companies' performance and value. Research suggests that power can lead to riskier behavior, as those with a higher sense of power believe they can avoid negative consequences. The article concludes that Silicon Valley's leaders are mistaking these risky behaviors for indicators of genius, and that corporate governance checks and balances have failed to hold them accountable.

images.alt_text: Feb 17, 2024; Anaheim, California, USA; Meta chief executive officer Mark Zuckerberg attends UFC 298 at Honda Center. Mandatory Credit: Gary A. Vasquez-USA TODAY Sports

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 12)
summary: MOF and Acra are seeking public feedback on a new Bill to enhance the regulatory framework for corporate service providers, with potential fines of up to S$100,000 for anti-money laundering breaches. Meanwhile, the Malaysia My Second Home residency visa programme faces a prolonged standstill in approvals, potentially deterring foreign interest. CPF interest rates for Special, MediSave, and Retirement accounts have dropped to 4.05% for Q2.

site_title: Britain vows to build new gas power stations
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's government has pledged to build new gas-fired power stations to boost energy security and avoid energy blackouts, despite criticism over its climate policies. The move aims to support Britain's net-zero target by 2050, but environmentalists argue it contradicts the nation's climate goals. The government claims the new gas power plants will provide a safe and reliable energy source, particularly on cloudy or windless days, while also reducing reliance on foreign dictators like Putin.

images.alt_text: The EU and its 27 member nations have signed around 120 new energy agreements in the last two years with foreign powers, with a large number being in the Middle East.
Nuclear power could be a crucial part of a clean-energy transition, but not if it comes with a high risk

India has set in motion a building blitz at its oil refineries to raise production of traditional transport fuels such as petrol and diesel, which could lift capacity by more than 20 per cent over the next five years.

site_title: Be cured or have kids: Tough choice for sickle-cell patients
summary: The US government has introduced a plan to help states cover the cost of gene therapies for sickle-cell disease, a condition that affects over 100,000 Americans. The therapies, which can cure the disease, require patients to take a toxic drug that can cause infertility. The new plan allows drugmakers to cover fertility preservation services for Medicaid patients, potentially increasing the number of people who can access the treatments. However, the plan is voluntary and does not take effect until next year, leaving some states without coverage.

images.alt_text: Novo’s widely-used diabetes drug Ozempic and weight-loss drug Wegovy belong to a class of drugs called GLP-1 agonists.

The Global Fund secures donations from governments, private companies and foundations and has disbursed US$60 billion, saved 59 million lives and cut the death rate from HIV Aids, tuberculosis and malaria by more than half in the nations where it invests.
President Yoon Suk Yeol (R) has spearheaded a package of medical reform plans and taken a hard line against the protesters, moving to suspend their medical licences for defying return-to-work orders.
Bayer swung to a 2.9-billion-euro loss (S$4.2 billion) in 2023 after booking a net profit of 4.15 billion euros a year earlier.

site_title: China Vanke in debt swap talks with banks to stave off default
summary: China Vanke, the country's second-largest real estate developer, is in talks with banks to swap bond holdings worth tens of billions of yuan into secured debt, potentially staving off its first-ever bond default. The plan, coordinated by China's financial regulators and the Shenzhen government, would help Vanke avoid a public default while giving banks collateral to protect against losses. Vanke's cash crunch has raised concerns about the government's support for the company, which has significant liabilities of over $181 billion.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the Moody's Corporation headquarters in Manhattan, New York, U.S., November 12, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly
The State Council – China’s Cabinet – is coordinating support efforts for China Vanke, sources say, adding that financial institutions have been requested to make swift progress.

site_title: Data centre firm GDS confirms investor talks on potential deals outside China
summary: GDS Holdings, a Chinese data centre developer and operator, has confirmed discussions with private equity investors Hillhouse, Boyu Capital, and CDH Investments to invest in its international business outside China. The potential deal could be worth US$500 million to US$600 million. GDS stated that no definitive agreements have been entered into, and there's uncertainty about the transaction's structure. This comes as infrastructure assets like data centres gain investor interest in Asia, following recent investments by firms such as KKR.

images.alt_text: Loh Chin Hua, chief executive of Keppel (left) and Takayuki Miki, managing director of Mitsui Fudosan, signed a Memorandum of Understanding.
The cloud region will enable customers to securely store content and run workloads while offering higher speed for its users.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Tuesday, March 12, 2024 (Ep 20)
summary: Hong Kong and China shares rose due to share buybacks and higher inflation, while the Bank of Japan is expected to raise interest rates next week. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) will launch short-term interest rate futures, and most Asian markets pushed higher ahead of US inflation data. The Straits Times Index (STI) increased 0.4% on Tuesday.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 58 to 31.
Tokyo stocks fell again at mid day on Tuesday as speculation swirls that the Bank of Japan will next week shift away from its ultra-loose monetary policy that has helped strengthen the yen.
CMG20231215-HengYY01 / 王彦燕 / SGX Centre 新加坡交易所 [Shenton Way] SGX logo in front of the SGX Centre building at Shenton Way.

site_title: Can a retiree afford to keep his pricey home in the era of rising annual values?
summary: Owner-occupiers of high-priced private homes in Singapore may need to consider higher property taxes in their retirement planning due to rising annual values. According to data from the Urban Redevelopment Authority, private home rentals fell 2.1% in Q4 2023, but residential landlords experienced a 8.7% increase in 2023. This moderation in private home rentals suggests that property owners should factor in higher property taxes when planning for their retirement.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Retirees who are owner-occupiers of private homes should be mindful that costs linked to home ownership such as property tax may rise over the long term.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise 0.1% on Tuesday ahead of US inflation data
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% on Tuesday, driven by gains from Jardine Matheson and Thai Beverage. The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,141.47. The top gainers were Jardine Matheson, Thai Beverage, and CapitaLand Investment, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding was the top decliner. Investors await US inflation data, which may impact market sentiment and Fed expectations.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Tokyo stocks fell again at mid day on Tuesday as speculation swirls that the Bank of Japan will next week shift away from its ultra-loose monetary policy that has helped strengthen the yen.

site_title: ‘Fingers of instability’ and the possible impact on global markets
summary: A series of minor escalations in the Middle East conflict could lead to a significant broadening of the conflict, potentially causing global instability. The reduced willingness of shipping companies to sail through the Red Sea and Suez Canal increases the risk of regional consequences. This could lead to stagflation, characterized by stalled growth and rising inflation, with potential negative impacts on financial markets. Investors are advised to factor in the possibility of an upside inflation shock and consider hedging strategies, such as inflation-protected bonds and diversification through alternative assets.

images.alt_text: The Red Sea supply chain disruptions could cut as much as 0.5 percentage points off Asia’s economic growth this year, and add up to 0.4 percentage points to the inflation rate.

site_title: Luxury watch boom fades as auction sales drop 13%
summary: Luxury watch sales declined 13% in 2023 to 610 million Swiss francs, down from record levels in 2022, amid geopolitical concerns and waning enthusiasm for pricey timepieces. Average lot prices fell 3% to 48,600 francs, with fewer watches sold above one million francs. Patek Philippe dominated the list of highest-priced watches, accounting for three out of five of the most expensive sold. The decline marks a severe downturn in the industry, attributed to global economic uncertainty and a shift in buyer behavior.

site_title: ASML’s threat to leave uncovers deeper concerns in Netherlands business climate
summary: The Netherlands' largest company ASML has threatened to leave the country if it cannot grow there due to immigration restrictions. The semiconductor equipment maker's CEO has since ruled out a total departure, but ASML is not alone in considering its options. A Reuters review of Dutch blue chip firms found that over a dozen companies are concerned about the national business climate and may consider relocating their operations. The concerns are driven by corporate tax increases, protests, and court cases, as well as plans to tax share buybacks and limit investment deductions. The government has launched an effort to persuade ASML to stay, including looking at ways to "undo the harm" of ending a tax break for skilled migrants.

images.alt_text: ASML's High NA EUV tools, which are the size of a double decker bus and cost more than US$350 million each, are expected to help enable new generations of smaller, faster chips.
ASML is the only maker of a key technology – extreme ultraviolet photolithography – needed to manufacture the most advanced chips.
The surge has allowed ASML to overtake Swiss food group Nestle as Europe’s third-largest listed company.
ASML registers strong orders of more than nine billion euros in the fourth quarter – more than triple third-quarter levels.

site_title: Honda, Nissan considering cutting China capacity, Nikkei reports
summary: Honda and Nissan are considering reducing their production capacity in China by 30% and 20% respectively, due to struggling sales and increased competition from local manufacturers such as BYD. The move aims to rationalize production and offset the lack of attractive electric-car offerings. Honda's current capacity is 1.49 million, while Nissan's is 1.6 million, and the cuts could result in a reduction of around 500,000 units annually. The decision is seen as a response to the growing competition in the Chinese market.

site_title: Volkswagen Group China plans to boost investment in majority-controlled JV
summary: Volkswagen Group China plans to boost its investment in its majority-controlled joint venture, Anhui Jianghuai Automobile (JAC Motors), by increasing the JV's registered capital to 13.9 billion yuan (S$2.6 billion) from 7.4 billion yuan. JAC Motors will contribute 1.6 billion yuan, while Volkswagen's China division will contribute 4.9 billion yuan, maintaining its 75% stake. This move is part of Volkswagen's efforts to expand its business in China and regain lost ground in the market, where it is exploring local tie-ups to accelerate electrification.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen, whose brands include Audi, VW and Lamborghini, expects sales to grow by up to 5 per cent in 2024.
Cars produced through the partnership will carry the VW logo.
VW says it takes allegations of human rights violations very seriously, and its investigations could result in the end of a supplier relationship if a serious violation is confirmed.

FILE PHOTO: A car stands at the production line for the electric Volkswagen cars, model ID.3 and model ID. 4, in Zwickau, Germany, September 18, 2020. Picture taken September 18. REUTERS/Matthias Rietschel/File Photo
Volkswagen Group’s focus on EVs comes down to their favourable taxation structure in India.

site_title: Japan to expand offshore wind development into exclusive economic zone
summary: Japan's government has approved a draft amendment to allow offshore wind power installation in its exclusive economic zones, a step towards the country's goal of carbon neutrality by 2050. The move aims to expand offshore wind development to 10 GW by 2030 and 45 GW by 2040, replacing fossil fuels. The new legislation would permit wind farms to be installed further out to sea, with installation criteria including marine environment protection and public consultations. Industry players, including global energy companies, have urged Japan to boost auctions and investments to attract more projects.

images.alt_text: On a quarter-on-quarter basis, Japan's GDP grew 0.1 per cent, compared with the initial 0.1 per cent drop reading and a median forecast for a 0.3 per cent rise.

Japan's household outlays declined by 6.3 per cent in January from a year earlier, the biggest drop since February of 2021, the ministry of internal affairs reported on Friday. It was the 11th straight decline, and it was steeper than economists’ estimate of a 4.1 per cent retreat.
The service sector has been a positive area for the economy, offsetting some of the weakness in manufacturing caused by subdued global demand.

site_title: StanChart CEO contender Cooper set to leave in broad overhaul
summary: Standard Chartered CEO contender Simon Cooper is set to leave the bank to pursue other interests, following a broader management reshuffle aimed at boosting returns. Cooper, who led the corporate, commercial, and institutional banking division for eight years, will be replaced by Roberto Hoornweg and Sunil Kaushal. The bank is also stripping out regional reporting lines, potentially leading to job losses. The changes follow a series of senior departures, including Paul Skelton and James Cameron, and come weeks after CEO Bill Winters said the bank's share price was "crap".

images.alt_text: StanChart’s move comes amid Beijing’s efforts to stem capital outflows as weaker yuan and a slowing economy have driven savers to move assets offshore.

site_title: Is diversification a blessing or curse?
summary: Warren Buffett and Peter Lynch, two successful investors, have differing views on diversification. Buffett believes that if you know what you're doing, diversification is unnecessary, while Lynch thinks holding multiple stocks increases the chances of finding winners. However, diversification is not just about the number of stocks, but also about the level of knowledge and expertise. Investors should diversify only if they want to boost their chances of finding more winning stocks, and should not diversify into areas where they lack expertise. A simple rule of thumb is to invest no more than 1-5% of the portfolio in new stocks within a year or five years of research.

images.alt_text: Buffett's letter is full of lessons on how to run a company and manage your investors.
Before designing your portfolio, define your objective and assess your risk tolerance. Investing in stable, blue-chip stocks should enable you to sleep at night.
Berkshire’s annual operating profit climbs 21 per cent to US$37.4 billion on improved underwriting and higher investment income from the insurance segment.

site_title: Red Sea could be a seafarer no-go area following crew killings
summary: The Red Sea has become a high-risk area for seafarers, following the recent attacks on vessels, including the sinking of the Rubymar and the killing of three crew members on the True Confidence. The Nautilus seafarers' union has called on shipowners to reassess the necessity of transiting the Red Sea, citing the need to prioritize seafarer safety over commercial interests. The union's comments come amid concerns that the attacks are no longer limited to vessels with ties to specific countries, making any vessel a potential target.

images.alt_text: The container ship, MSC Luciana, approaches the port of Felixstowe in the UK on Monday (Mar 4).

Hamburg-based maritime-technology firm OceanScore says Asia-based shipowners will foot 500 million euros under the European Union Emissions Trading System this year for a start, and rise each year thereafter.
The plight of the Galaxy Leader’s crew was discussed at a conference organised by the UK-based Seafarers Hospital Society.

site_title: Major Hong Kong grocery chain U Select shuts stores as China lures shoppers
summary: Hong Kong's U Select, a major grocery chain, has significantly reduced its store count from 100 to 57 in less than a year due to economic headwinds and increased competition from mainland Chinese cities offering cheaper goods and more choices. The chain's parent company, China Resources Holdings, is exploring partnerships with mainland Chinese cities to introduce new products and attract customers. The move reflects the challenges faced by Hong Kong's retailers as consumers increasingly shop across the border for more affordable options.

site_title: Is the bull market about to turn into a bubble?
summary: The global stock market is experiencing a surge, with investors both delighted and nervous about the rapid gains. Despite a brutal campaign by central bankers to raise interest rates, new technology and AI are driving the market's momentum. The S&P 500 index has risen in 16 of the past 19 weeks, with mega-cap tech stocks leading the charge. However, experts warn that this may be a bubble, citing signs such as high valuations, low cash holdings, and a lack of euphoria among investors. A potential correction could be triggered by a shift in investor sentiment, lower interest rates, or a surge in initial public offerings.

images.alt_text: The stockmarket rally has broadened widely over the last three months, suggesting a healthy bull market.

site_title: China selects Martell, Hennessy, Remy Martin brandies as part of anti-dumping probe
summary: China's commerce ministry has selected Martell, Hennessy, and Remy Martin as sample companies for an anti-dumping investigation into European Union brandy imports. The investigation, launched in January, targets France, which accounts for 99.8% of EU brandy exports. The move is part of a broader trade dispute between China and the EU, with both sides accusing each other of unfair competition and protectionism. France's cognac industry association believes the probe is linked to a broader trade row rather than the liquor market, and plans to fully cooperate with Chinese authorities.

images.alt_text: The investigation will focus on brandy products that come in smaller than 200 litre containers from the EU.

site_title: End of Chinese tariffs on Australian wine looms as key ministry proposes removal
summary: China's Ministry of Commerce has released an interim proposal to remove tariffs on Australian wine, with Treasury Wine Estates expressing optimism about the final result. The tariffs, as high as 218%, were first imposed in 2021 and have been a major challenge for Australia's wine industry. The decision is seen as a clear sign that China is on the verge of ending the duties, which could be finalized by the end of March. The move is part of China's efforts to lift trade barriers imposed in 2020, following an escalating spat over foreign investment and security.

images.alt_text: China has been lifting those trade barriers as relations improve and Australian officials and industry expect a review of the wine tariffs begun by Beijing last year will lead to their removal next month.

site_title: China’s first two consumption-related Reits close flat in Shanghai debut
summary: China's first two consumption-related Reits, Huaxia Jinmao Commercial Reit and Harvest Wumart Consumer Reit, closed flat on their Shanghai debut, reflecting investor caution towards property assets amid deflationary pressures. The Reits, backed by shopping centers and supermarkets, launched after China expanded the scope of Reits to commercial properties to prop up the battered property sector. Despite the positive start, a Reits-focused investment manager expressed concerns over high prices and macroeconomic conditions, while another firm took a wait-and-see approach due to the heavy pipeline of Reits supply.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the Moody's Corporation headquarters in Manhattan, New York, U.S., November 12, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly
The State Council – China’s Cabinet – is coordinating support efforts for China Vanke, sources say, adding that financial institutions have been requested to make swift progress.
China should support developers to finish the construction of homes and deliver to buyers on time, says Yi at the annual session of China’s top political advisory body.

“We will scale up the building and supply of government-subsidised housing and improve the basic systems for commercial housing to meet people’s essential need for a home to live in and their different demands for better housing," says Chinese Premier Li Qiang.
Vanke, whose biggest shareholder is Shenzhen Metro Group, has faced concerns about its debt obligations since last year.

site_title: Tesla, rivals get low marks for automated-driving technology
summary: Tesla and other automakers received "poor" ratings for their automated-driving technology from the US Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS), with only one system, Lexus Teammate with Advanced Drive, earning an acceptable rating. The IIHS found no evidence of real-world safety benefits from Autopilot or other assisted-driving systems, despite claims from Tesla and other manufacturers that they reduce crashes. The IIHS will continue to test and improve the safety of these systems, and automakers are advised to adopt existing technology to boost safety ratings.

images.alt_text: Tesla has said it would cease to be a member in June.

epa11199967 Police investigators inspect a damaged high-voltage pylon near the Tesla Gigafactory in Gruenheide near Berlin, Germany, 05 March 2024. Tesla confirms that production at the Tesla Gigafactory in Gruenheide has been stopped due to a blackout. Brandenburg's Interior Minister Michael Stuebgen announced that, according to initial findings, 'unknown perpetrators had set fire to a high-voltage pylon'. The fire had damaged the high-voltage line to such an extent that the power supply to the neighbouring villages and the Tesla plant had failed.  EPA-EFE/FILIP SINGER
Tesla also offers limited-time preferential financing plans that could save up to 16,600 yuan for purchases of Model Y.

site_title: Chinese Premier Li to skip meeting with global CEOs at key business summit
summary: Chinese Premier Li Qiang will skip a meeting with visiting global CEOs at the China Development Forum, a key event for foreign investment discussions. This decision raises concerns about Beijing's commitment to attracting foreign investment amid souring sentiment. The move follows a surprise cancellation of the premier's news conference at the end of China's annual parliamentary session, seen as a sign of the country's increasingly inward focus and centralized control.

images.alt_text: Beijing is expected to announce the target at around 5 per cent, a fairly ambitious number for a government grappling with severe economic challenges.

site_title: China’s champion gymnast Li Ning mulls taking company private: sources
summary: Chinese billionaire Li Ning, Olympic gymnastics champion, is considering taking his sportswear company private from the Hong Kong stock exchange, according to sources. Li Ning Co Ltd, which had a market capitalization of HK$52.85 billion, is reportedly in talks with global private equity firms, including TPG, PAG, and Hillhouse Investment, to join a consortium. Li feels his company is undervalued and would target a hefty premium over its current share price in a potential buyout.

images.alt_text: Bull statues are placed in font of screens showing the Hang Seng stock index and stock prices outside Exchange Square, in Hong Kong, China, August 18, 2023. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu
Chinese stocks are wallowing near a five-year nadir while yields on the country’s 30-year treasury bonds have plumbed record lows.

site_title: QR code immigration clearance for travellers in cars to begin on Mar 19
summary: Singapore residents can use QR codes for immigration clearance in cars starting March 19. The initiative requires travellers to download the MyICA mobile application, fill in their passport details, and generate a QR code. QR codes can be used for individual or group travel, with up to 10 people in the same vehicle. Face-to-face checks will be conducted by ICA officers to verify the information, and the QR codes are encrypted for security. The initiative aims to reduce waiting times by over 30% and is part of the country's Automated Passenger Clearance System (APCS) plans.

images.alt_text: More than 160 automated lanes were installed in 2023, with another 230 lanes to be set up in 2024.
An artist's impression of the Old Woodlands Town Centre extension.

site_title: Bank of Japan chief Ueda slightly tones down optimism on economy
summary: Bank of Japan governor Kazuo Ueda slightly toned down his optimism on the economy, citing weakening consumption for food and daily necessities amid higher prices. However, he noted that household spending is improving moderately on hopes for higher wages. The BOJ will assess its monetary policy in its upcoming meeting, with some market players expecting the central bank to end its negative interest rate policy by April. Economists expect hefty pay hikes in this year's annual wage negotiations, which could support the BOJ's decision.

images.alt_text: Governor Kazuo Ueda has repeatedly highlighted the importance of the wage talks, and anecdotal evidence indicates growing momentum on pay.
BOJ has yet to buy ETFs this year to support the market. The previous time was on Oct 4, when it bought 70.1 billion yen (S$634.8 million) of ETFs.
“There is greater momentum for wage hikes at this year’s spring wage negotiations compared with last year,” Masakazu Tokura, chairman of business lobby Keidanren says.
On a quarter-on-quarter basis, Japan's GDP grew 0.1 per cent, compared with the initial 0.1 per cent drop reading and a median forecast for a 0.3 per cent rise.

site_title: UK house hunters speed up plans to beat price hike, survey shows
summary: A survey of 1,000 UK adults with a minimum annual gross household income of £45,000 found that 42% of potential homebuyers are speeding up their plans to beat a potential price hike, with 47% in London. The fear of being priced out of the market is driving this behavior, according to Bloomberg Intelligence. The survey suggests that UK house-price growth may be supported by buyers' expectations of increased property values in 2024, despite a tough 2023 due to high interest rates and the cost-of-living squeeze.

images.alt_text: Residential properties in Guildford, UK, on Monday, Sept. 4, 2023. The downturn gripping the UK housing market steepened in August as the cost-of-borrowing squeeze sapped demand, according to a major mortgage lender. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg
British homebuilders have recently highlighted a recovery in buyer interest, but said wider economic concerns gave grounds to be cautious as some trimmed their build targets.

A British Union flag near residential properties in a suburb of Brighton, UK, on Wednesday, May 31, 2023. UK house prices resumed their decline, with Nationwide Building Society warning that headwinds for property sellers are increasing. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: Thai election commission to ask court to disband Move Forward Party
summary: Thailand's election commission plans to request a court to dissolve the opposition Move Forward Party, citing a constitutional violation for its campaign to change a law against insulting the monarchy. The party, which won last year's general election, was found to have undermined the democratic system with the king as the head of state. The move follows a Constitutional Court ruling in January.

images.alt_text: Move Forward Party leader and prime ministerial candidate, Pita Limjaroenrat, celebrate the party's election results in Bangkok, Thailand, May 15, 2023. REUTERS/Jorge Silva

site_title: CPF interest rate for Special, MediSave, Retirement accounts dips to 4.05% for Q2
summary: The Central Provident Fund (CPF) has announced a slight decrease in interest rates for its Special, MediSave, and Retirement (SMRA) accounts, effective for the second quarter of 2024. The interest rate for these accounts drops to 4.05% per annum, down from 4.08% in Q1. The interest rate for CPF Ordinary Account (OA) remains unchanged at 2.5% per annum, and the concessionary interest rate for HDB housing loans remains at 2.6% per annum. The changes aim to balance the fund's financial sustainability while maintaining competitiveness.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
The move to close SAs for those aged 55 and above will take effect in 2025.
‘Fairer’ to retain CPF Special Account for those already aged 55 and above: Foo Mee Har
For CPF members who are 55 and above in 2025, their special accounts will be closed, with the savings transferring to retirement account up to the Full Retirement Sum.

site_title: Jollibee targets exponential growth in China to triple profit
summary: Jollibee Foods, the Philippines' largest restaurant operator, plans to expand its brand internationally and exponentially grow in China, aiming to triple its net income in five years. With 567 stores in China, the company will open 700-750 outlets this year, boosting its network in multiple lower-tier cities. Jollibee reported a profit of 8.8 billion pesos for the past year, 16% higher from a year ago, and has allocated 20-23 billion pesos in capital spending to support growth.

images.alt_text: Jollibee Foods is best known as the operator of the Jollibee fast food chain.

site_title: Eric Carmen, Raspberries frontman and ‘All By Myself’ singer, dies at 74
summary: Eric Carmen, lead singer of the 1970s power-pop band the Raspberries and a solo artist known for hits like "All By Myself" and "Hungry Eyes," has died at 74. No cause of death was given, and his death was announced by his wife, Amy Carmen. The Raspberries, which formed in Cleveland, burst onto the American rock scene in 1972 with their self-titled debut album and hits like "Go All the Way" and "I Wanna Be with You." After the band broke up, Carmen had a successful solo career in the 1980s, with songs featured in films like "Footloose" and "Dirty Dancing."

images.alt_text: Vinyl records return to the inflation basket for the first time since 1992, joining compact discs, music streaming subscriptions and digital downloads after a resurgence in demand for more tangible forms of music.
Indonesia opened in 2022 its Jakarta International Stadium that can seat 82,000 people.
Tom Jones continues to reinvent him musically both on stage and in the studio.

site_title: What’s so funny about a naked man?
summary: At the 96th Academy Awards, John Cena presented the award for best costume design in a humorous routine that poked fun at the traditional female nudity on the red carpet. Cena, dressed in a makeshift fig leaf, awkwardly made his way to the stage, mirroring the precarious steps taken by female celebrities in revealing dresses. The joke highlighted the gender gap in fashion, where female bodies are often objectified and scrutinized, while male nudity is seen as comedic. The routine was a clever commentary on the double standards of the fashion industry.

images.alt_text: Christopher Nolan, Emma Thomas and Charles Roven pose with the Oscar for Best Picture for "Oppenheimer" at the 96th Academy Awards in Hollywood, Los Angeles, California,  March 10, 2024.

site_title: Thailand expects to complete free trade talks with EU next year, PM says
summary: Thailand expects to complete free trade talks with the European Union by 2025, Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin said. The talks, which resumed last year after a nearly decade-long halt, aim to boost the economy through trade and investment. Thailand exported $21.8 billion worth of goods to the EU last year, making the bloc its fourth-largest trading partner. French President Emmanuel Macron has expressed support for Thailand's visa exemption request from Schengen states, which will be considered after June and potentially completed by the end of the year.

site_title: China water giant Nongfu Spring’s stock falls on boycott calls
summary: China's largest beverage company, Nongfu Spring, has seen its stock fall nearly 6% amid calls for a boycott following the death of a rival founder. Netizens have criticized the company's products, business tactics, and founder Zhong Shanshan's son holding a US passport, questioning his allegiance to China. The online backlash has resulted in a significant decline in sales, with about HK$30 billion in market cap wiped out. The company's founder has defended himself, but it's unclear if it can recover from the online furore.

images.alt_text: Tesla says sorry as disquiet in China climbs after protest
Taiwan remains a critical player in advanced semiconductor manufacturing. But the US is also trying to diversify semiconductor production out of Taiwan into the US and other close allies.

site_title: Bitcoin sets another all-time high as crypto sees record inflows
summary: Bitcoin reached an all-time high of nearly $72,968 on March 12, 2024, driven by record inflows of $2.7 billion into crypto assets, particularly Bitcoin. The success of US spot Bitcoin exchange-traded funds has contributed to the momentum, with a net inflow of $9.5 billion. The looming reduction in Bitcoin's supply growth, combined with expectations of looser monetary policy, has fueled a bullish mood in the crypto market, with some analysts predicting further gains to $80,000.

images.alt_text: The wallets are digital addresses on the Bitcoin blockchain, in which users can store cryptocurrency.
The iShares Bitcoin ETF (ticker IBIT) pulled US$788.3 million on Tuesday (Mar 6), its 37th consecutive inflow.
Representations of cryptocurrencies including Bitcoin, Dash, Ethereum, Ripple and Litecoin are seen in this illustration picture taken June 2, 2021. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration

site_title: Lego wins market share, overcoming rival’s Barbie movie launch
