summary: Lego has solidified its position as the world's No 1 toymaker, growing consumer sales 4% in 2023 despite a 7% contraction in the overall market. The company's strong balance sheet and billionaire owners allowed it to invest heavily in new products and initiatives, such as gaming and digital toys, and expanding its portfolio to a record 780 products. Lego's CEO, Niels B. Christiansen, attributed the company's success to its strong brand and ability to win market share even in a challenging market, with sales increasing in the US and across geographies.

images.alt_text: Lego Fortnite is part of a larger strategy by Epic to create more virtual worlds where gamers can socialise and play.
Kirkbi's assets have swelled to about 166 billion kroner, mainly driven by rising profits at Lego, which has grown to become the world’s largest toy company.

site_title: Volvo invests in, taps Breathe Battery tech for 30% faster EV charging
summary: Volvo Cars has invested in UK startup Breathe Battery Technologies, utilizing its battery software to reduce charging time for its electric vehicles (EVs) by 30%. The technology, expected to be available on new Volvo EVs within 2-3 years, allows for full power charging while maintaining safety and battery health. This investment aims to address a key challenge in EV adoption: slower charging times. By leveraging Breathe's algorithm-based charging software, Volvo seeks to persuade more customers to switch to EVs.

images.alt_text: Truck demand continued to normalise in Europe and North America during the quarter from high levels, the world’s second-biggest truckmaker said on Friday (Jan 26).

site_title: UK unemployment rises unexpectedly, easing pay pressures
summary: The UK's unemployment rate rose to 3.9% in January, its first increase since July, as wage growth eased. Average earnings growth fell to 6.1%, the fifth straight decline, indicating a cooling labour market. This could ease inflationary pressures and lead to interest rate cuts later this year, according to economists. The pound fell 0.1% after the report, but the data suggests the labour market is moving in the right direction, with confidence that inflation is under control.

images.alt_text: The central bank is watching pay figures carefully for signs that price pressures will stick around longer than they expect.
The Body Shop has faced increasing competition from rivals better able to target younger consumers online.
Sainsbury’s says the jobs will go at its store support centre, its contact centre operations, in its in-store bakeries and in its general merchandise fulfilment network.

site_title: At Tefaf art fair, museums make up for shrinking private sales
summary: Museums are increasingly buying art at the Tefaf Maastricht fair, compensating for declining private sales. The fair, which opened to the public on Saturday, saw 300 museum directors among its 50,000 expected visitors. Curators from institutions such as the Boston Museum of Fine Arts and the Cleveland Museum acquired works by artists like Lavinia Fontana and Artemisia Gentileschi, with prices ranging from $6.54 million to $7 million. The focus on acquiring works by women artists aims to amend the discrepancy in museum collections.

images.alt_text: Personnel members hang for display a rare Vincent van Gogh painting, "Tete de paysanne a la coiffe blanche" (Head of an old farmer's wife with a white hat), painted circa 1884, that will be auctionned at the TEFAF Maastricht art fair, in Maastricht, on March 6, 2024. The TEFAF Maastricht art fair runs from March 9 to 14, 2024. (Photo by Nick Gammon / AFP) / RESTRICTED TO EDITORIAL USE - MANDATORY MENTION OF THE ARTIST UPON PUBLICATION - TO ILLUSTRATE THE EVENT AS SPECIFIED IN THE CAPTION

site_title: Support measures in Budget 2024 not meant to increase Singaporeans’ reliance on government: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized that the support measures in Budget 2024 aim to upskill and upgrade Singaporeans, rather than increase reliance on the government. He noted that Singapore's small economy is nimble and has bounced back from the Covid-19 pandemic, but urged local companies to adopt a long-term perspective. Heng also stressed the need to exercise prudence when using the nation's reserves and encouraged the community to help those in need, particularly lower-income families.

images.alt_text: With the right response from employers across the private sector, the support that the Singapore government provides around upskilling will work as a phenomenal catalyst.

The ST-BT Budget Roundtable 2024 was moderated by ST associate editor Vikram Khanna (left), with panellists (L to R) UOB senior economist Alvin Liew; Second Minister for Finance Indranee Rajah; Association of Small and Medium Enterprises president Ang Yuit; and NTUC deputy secretary-general Desmond Tan.

site_title: Signa to sell luxury Vienna landmarks to break debt impasse
summary: Signa Prime Selection, a luxury property unit of the troubled Benko empire, is close to an agreement to sell a portfolio of Austrian assets to Germany's Schoeller Group. The deal, worth billions, could help resolve a debt impasse with Schoeller and mark the first major transaction involving property held by the embattled investment office since its insolvency last year. The portfolio includes the Golden Quarter luxury store complex and the Park Hyatt hotel in Vienna. The sale is seen as a key step in Signa's broader restructuring efforts.

images.alt_text: The plan that Signa Prime will present on Monday seeks to convince creditors that the current management’s strategy will stabilise the firm and repay creditors at least 30 per cent of their claims within two years.
The insolvency of European luxury property group Signa could hurt more players across the financial industry, but demand for private debt is said to remain high.

site_title: Asian nations in race to build concert venues
summary: Asian nations are racing to build concert venues, with around a dozen new arenas set to debut by 2030. Countries such as Indonesia, South Korea, and Japan are investing heavily in entertainment infrastructure, with notable projects including Jakarta's 82,000-seat Jakarta International Stadium, Seoul's 18,000-seat arena, and Hong Kong's 50,000-seat Kai Tak Sports Park. The development is driven by the region's booming live entertainment scene and tourism revenue. Singapore, Bangkok, and Taiwan are also set to open new venues, with Singapore's new 18,000-capacity indoor arena and Bangkok's 15,000-seat arena expected to debut in 2026.

images.alt_text: Goh Ruoxue
Construction of the new tower is scheduled to commence in June 2025, and is expected to be completed by June 2030, with an estimated official opening in January 2031.
Construction of Hong Kong's Kai Tak Sports Park on the site of the former airport began in 2019. When construction is complete by end-2024, the facility will boast a 50,000-pax stadium.
As planning is in the early stages, there is currently no timeline for when construction will begin and more details will be shared later.

site_title: Gold’s record run stalls ahead of US inflation print
summary: Gold prices remained steady on Tuesday, holding at US$2,182.48 per ounce, after reaching a record peak of US$2,194.99 on Friday. The move comes ahead of the US consumer price index report for February, which is expected to show a 0.4% rise in prices for the month. The data is seen as a key indicator for the Federal Reserve's monetary policy trajectory, with traders pricing in three to four quarter-point interest rate cuts, boosting the appeal of non-yielding bullion.

images.alt_text: Gold has been trading for months around the US$2,000 mark – a level that would have been viewed as stratospheric just a few years ago, and which was only breached for the first time in 2020 as the global pandemic raged.
Bullion is set to post its biggest weekly percentage increase since mid-October.

site_title: Australia business conditions improve in February, prices rise
summary: Australia's business conditions improved in February, with a survey showing a rise in sales, profits, and employment, but a decline in business confidence. The National Australia Bank's index of business conditions rose to +10, while retail prices jumped 1.4% and purchase costs grew 1.8%. The Reserve Bank of Australia has lifted interest rates to a 12-year peak of 4.35% to restrain inflation, with economists warning that another hike may be needed despite the economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: The Australian government estimates companies will save more than A$30 million (S$26.6 million) in compliance costs a year, while US$8.5 billion of annual trade will be streamlined.
Australia has been a key coal supplier to Vietnam, which is heavily reliant on the fossil fuels for power generation.
The Australian Bureau of Statistics reported the balance on goods widened in January to A$11.03 billion (S$9.7 billion), from A$10.74 billion in December last year.

site_title: China EV makers woo buyers with in-car beds, kitchens and drones
summary: China's electric vehicle (EV) makers are innovating with novel add-ons such as in-car beds, kitchens, and drones to boost sluggish sales amid a slowdown in demand. Top EV makers like Xpeng, Geely Automobile, and BYD are offering features like sleeping kits, in-sync heartbeat technology, tailgate-ready camping kitchens, and drones that can capture high-definition images. These high-tech offerings highlight the risk for Western manufacturers to fall behind in the world's biggest auto market. The focus on innovation signals China's emphasis on redefining premium in the EV era, with experimentation expected to lead to new ideas.

images.alt_text: Under that deal, Stellantis would have exclusive rights to build, export and sell Leapmotor products outside China, a first for a legacy Western automaker.
Singapore is slowly making inroads, with EVs accounting for about 18 per cent of new cars registered last year.
Chinese auto companies currently have a very limited presence in the US because of a 27.5 per cent tariff imposed by former president Donald Trump.

site_title: Airbnb bans security cameras inside guest homes
summary: Airbnb has banned the use of indoor security cameras in guest homes globally, effective April 30, to prioritize guest privacy. The company had previously allowed visible and disclosed indoor security cameras in common areas. Doorbell cameras and noise decibel monitors for home security are still permitted. Outdoor security cameras must be disclosed and cannot monitor areas like outdoor showers or saunas. The policy change aims to simplify security camera rules and provide clarity for hosts and guests.

images.alt_text: Airbnb has been working to adapt its app to the local market and raise awareness to drive traffic and is starting to see the effort pay off.
Starting Apr 1, an additional fee of as much as 2 per cent will be charged to guests if they pay in a different currency from the listing.
Airbnb received more than 2,000 complaints from Australian customers over being charged in US dollars during this period.
The tax probe is related to Airbnb’s alleged failure to withhold 21 per cent of landlords’ rental income and pay it to Italian tax authorities.

site_title: Trump calls TikTok a threat but says some kids could ‘go crazy’ without it
summary: US President Donald Trump has called TikTok a national security threat, but also warned that banning the app could harm some kids and strengthen Meta Platforms' Facebook. A bill to give TikTok's Chinese owner ByteDance about six months to divest the app is set to be voted on by the US House of Representatives. TikTok has denied being owned or controlled by the Chinese government, and argued that selling the company would not protect US user data. The Justice Department has expressed security concerns about TikTok, and a classified briefing is planned for House members.

images.alt_text: Shein is seeking Beijing’s nod to go public in a listing that will likely face tough scrutiny from US regulators.

If any of the six tech giants are not compliant with the Digital Markets Act (DMA) by the EU’s Thursday deadline, they could ultimately face investigations and potentially fines of up to 10 per cent of their global turnover.

Representative Mike Gallagher, who chairs a House panel on China, introduced legislation on Tuesday with Representative Raja Krishnamoorthi, the panel’s top Democrat, that would give ByteDance about six months to sell TikTok or face a ban citing national security concerns.

This photo taken on February 12, 2023 in Brussels shows reflexions on a smartphone screen of logos of online platforms google, facebook, linkedin, Amazon, Apple store and Tiktok as the European Commission announced last September the world's biggest digital firms, identified as "gatekeepers" by the EU, must comply from March 6, 2024, with strict do's and don'ts under a landmark law, the Digital Markets Act (DMA). The EU has built a powerful legal arsenal to take on the internet giants, including the DMA which seeks to encourage competition in the digital world, and its sister milestone law, the Digital Services Act (DSA). The DSA demands the most popular social networks and websites police content online more aggressively and protect consumers while they shop. (Photo by Kenzo TRIBOUILLARD / AFP)

Biden faces huge problems that undercut his chances of getting re-elected, including doubts about his physical and mental fitness for office, looming fears over the country’s immigration crisis at the southern border, and continuing gloom about inflation despite falling prices.
Because TikTok is owned by a Chinese company, ByteDance, the short-form video platform's popularity among Americans carries implications beyond the mobile-phone screen.
Trump is facing mounting legal bills after being charged with 91 criminal offenses in four criminal prosecutions.

site_title: China’s Xiaomi to start deliveries of its first EV model, shares soar
summary: Xiaomi, China's fifth-largest smartphone maker, will start delivering its first electric vehicle, the Speed Ultra 7 (SU7) sedan, this month in 29 cities nationwide. The EV boasts "super electric motor" technology, capable of faster acceleration than Tesla and Porsche's EVs. Xiaomi plans to invest $10 billion in autos over a decade and aims to become one of the world's top five automakers. The company's shared operating system with its phones is expected to appeal to existing customers, with deliveries starting on March 28.

images.alt_text: Xiaomi last year was placed third globally for share of the smartphone market, accounting for 12.5 per cent of global shipments.
Xiaomi is also asking India to reduce import tariffs on sub-components used in batteries, USB cables and phone covers.

site_title: KKR says now a good time to lean into Asia’s credit markets
summary: KKR sees opportunities in Asia's credit markets due to strong demand, undervalued assets, and high-quality issuers. Defaults among Chinese property developers have reset asset prices, creating an attractive entry point. Demand for financing outstrips supply, and only high-quality issuers remain. With 56% of high-yield debt maturing in the next three years, KKR expects significant opportunities for players in private and broadly syndicated markets. The firm identifies sectors such as Chinese large technology firms and investment-grade insurers as potential investment areas. A likely US rate cut will provide additional support to growth.

images.alt_text: Private lending locks investors in for longer periods. Hence it offers an uplift over the yields available in public markets, depending on the level of risk.
FILE PHOTO: The logo for Goldman Sachs is seen on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, New York, U.S., November 17, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly
Antoine Flamarion (left) and Mathieu Chabran, co-founders of Tikehau Capital, want hope to be among the early movers in Asia's private credit space.

site_title: Asia: Most markets push higher as US inflation data loom
summary: Asian markets mostly rose on Tuesday, despite a sell-off in Tokyo, driven by anticipation of US inflation data and potential interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. Hong Kong, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, and Manila gained, while Tokyo and Shanghai fell amid speculation that the Bank of Japan will shift away from its ultra-loose monetary policy. Analysts warn that the recent rally could stall as investors lock in profits and assess the outlook for monetary policy.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 58 to 31.
The Stoxx 600 ended 0.4 per cent lower on Monday, coming off an all-time high hit in the prior session.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average was the only major Wall Street index to gain on Monday, rising 0.1 per cent to 38,769.66.

site_title: SGX to offer interest rate derivatives on Singapore, Tokyo benchmarks
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) will launch short-term interest rate futures linked to the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (Sora) and Tokyo Overnight Average Rate (Tona) for hedging and trading fluctuations in interest rates. The three-month Sora and Tona Futures contracts are targeted to be launched in the second half of 2024, subject to regulatory approval. This move aims to enhance capital efficiency, price discovery, and liquidity in the Singapore dollar interest rates market, driven by rising issuance of Sing dollar cash market products referencing the interest rate benchmark.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Mainland China and Taiwan index futures on Singapore Exchange had deep liquidity.

site_title: Foxconn Industrial’s 100% rally may extend on China’s AI frenzy
summary: Foxconn Industrial Internet, a Taiwanese semiconductor company, has seen its Shanghai stock more than double since mid-January, outperforming other companies on the CSI 300 Index. Goldman Sachs raised the price target of Foxconn Industrial by 12% to 30% upside, citing demand for AI servers. The company is expected to report results on March 13. This trend is attributed to China's AI frenzy, with local investors favoring Taiwanese companies over home-grown ones, including Semiconductor Manufacturing International.

site_title: One of New York’s ‘worst landlords’ faces arrest over building neglect
summary: New York City landlord Daniel Ohebshalom faces arrest over persistent "dangerous conditions" at two buildings in Washington Heights, including lead, mould, and pest issues. An arrest warrant was issued for up to 60 days unless corrections are made. The Department of Housing Preservation and Development reported nearly 700 open violations across the buildings, which have been on the city's "worst landlords" watchlist. This is a rare example of a landlord being held accountable through a criminal warrant, with advocates hailing it as a necessary step to hold Ohebshalom responsible for his tenants' suffering.

images.alt_text: The latest budget cuts capital gains tax by 4 percentage points to 24 per cent. Landlords who wish to sell their apartments and houses will benefit from the reduction, Knight Frank says.

site_title: To fix a housing crisis, New York leaders seek to revive a 1950s idea
summary: New York state leaders are proposing a sweeping housing legislation to address the growing housing crisis, including a revival of the 1950s Mitchell-Lama program. The plan would create a new public benefit corporation to finance housing construction on state-owned land, offer more robust affordability protections, and establish "good cause eviction" legislation to restrict landlords' ability to evict tenants. The proposal aims to incentivize new development while supporting landlords and tenants, and is seen as a potential compromise between competing stakeholders. The plan will be released on Monday and must be approved by the governor and both Houses of the Legislature by April 1.

images.alt_text: The landlord, Daniel Ohebshalom was taken to task for problems involving lead, mould and pests which have persisted at two of his buildings in Washington Heights for some 16 months.

site_title: SkillsFuture training allowance not meant to replace salary: Indranee
summary: Singapore's SkillsFuture Mid-Career Training Allowance aims to support workers aged 40 and above in acquiring new skills, with a monthly allowance capped at S$3,000. Second Minister for Finance Indranee Rajah emphasized that the allowance is not meant to replace salary, but rather to encourage workers to reskill and deepen their current competencies. The government hopes the scheme will help workers navigate a rapidly changing job market and support their career growth.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

From left: ST associate editor Vikram Khanna; UOB senior economist Alvin Liew; Second Minister for Finance & National Development Indranee Rajah; ASME President Ang Yuit; and NTUC deputy secretary general Desmond Tan.
The SkillsFuture Credit will now have two tiers. At age 25, Singaporeans will receive a base tier of S$500 that does not expire. This can be used for a wide range of over 28,000 approved courses.
The best way for Singapore to deal with inflation is for business and wages to grow in real terms, says Finance Minister Lawrence Wong.
In the first day of debate on Budget 2024, a total of 29 MPs made suggestions from "multi-tiered" financial support for retrenched workers to subsidies for part-time diplomas.
Singaporeans aged 40 and above will receive full government subsidies to pursue a second diploma at polytechnics, Institute of Technical Education, and arts institutions.
The new S$4,000 credit that is part of the programme will be more targeted in scope, as the government will restrict its usage to selected training programmes that have better employability outcomes.
Singaporeans aged 40 and above who enrol in a full-time course will get a monthly training allowance of up to 50 per cent of their last drawn pay, capped at S$3,000.

site_title: Employers must see real benefits if they are to support workers’ upskilling: ST-BT Budget 2024 Roundtable
summary: Singapore's employers must see tangible benefits from upskilling their employees to support workers' training, panellists said at a post-Budget roundtable. The need for real-world skills and relevance in training courses is crucial, and employers must be willing to bear the impact on staff strength for long-term gains. To address concerns, SkillsFuture courses should be aligned with industry outcomes, and employers should offer support for workers to stay with the company after training. The government will also provide funds and early warning signals to help companies and individuals prepare for the changing job market.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

The ST-BT Budget Roundtable 2024 was moderated by ST associate editor Vikram Khanna (left), with panellists (L to R) UOB senior economist Alvin Liew; Second Minister for Finance Indranee Rajah; Association of Small and Medium Enterprises president Ang Yuit; and NTUC deputy secretary-general Desmond Tan.

Second Minister for Finance and National Development Indranee Rajah and other panellists at the ST-BT Budget 2024 Roundtable will discuss how the Budget's initiatives can help to upskill and upgrade Singapore’s mid-career workers.

site_title: JPMorgan’s Dimon urges Federal Reserve to wait past June before cutting rates
summary: JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon urged the Federal Reserve to wait past June before cutting interest rates, citing the need to maintain inflation-fighting credibility. Dimon described the US economy as doing well, but cautioned against the "soft landing" narrative, warning that geopolitical tensions and market bubbles could pose risks. He put the odds of a recession at around 65% and refused to rule out stagflation. Dimon advised the Fed to be data-dependent and wait to see how the economy evolves before making any rate cuts.

images.alt_text: Speaking on Thursday, Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell said the Fed was "not far" from having the confidence it needed to cut rates.
The US added 275,000 jobs last month, in an unexpected pickup after January's figure was revised significantly lower.
“We’re well aware of that risk, of course, and very conscious of avoiding it,” Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell says.
Nonfarm productivity, which measures hourly output per worker, increased at an unrevised 3.2 per cent annualised rate last quarter, the Labor Department’s Bureau of Labor Statistics says.
The US labour market is steadily loosening up, with 1.45 job openings per every unemployed person in January, government data showed on Wednesday.

site_title: Covid-19 lowered life expectancy by 1.6 years worldwide: study
summary: A new study found that COVID-19 caused a 1.6-year decline in global life expectancy from 2020-2021, with 84% of countries experiencing a decrease. The pandemic led to 15.9 million excess deaths, a million more than previously estimated, with the highest declines in Mexico City, Peru, and Bolivia. Despite this, the study notes that global life expectancy has risen by 23 years since 1950, and that progress in reducing child mortality continues.

images.alt_text: New research has found that as the poor become richer, they become more likely to understate their income.
Novo’s widely-used diabetes drug Ozempic and weight-loss drug Wegovy belong to a class of drugs called GLP-1 agonists.

site_title: China has never cancelled this many shipments of US wheat
summary: China has cancelled 264,000 tonnes of US wheat export shipments, bringing the total cancellations to 504,000 tonnes, the most in USDA data since 1999. This is the third consecutive session of cancellations, weighing on Chicago wheat futures, which fell 2.7% to US$5.235 a bushel. The cancellations have significant implications for global wheat markets, leading to a decline in prices.

site_title: More women in tech, increasing digital adoption among key trends: UOB’s Choo Wan Sim
summary: Choo Wan Sim, head of UOB TMRW Digital, emphasizes the importance of data-driven decision-making in driving innovation and growth in the digital banking space. She highlights two key trends: increasing digital adoption and a surge in women in tech, which drives innovation. Choo notes that having a diverse team, including females, brings different perspectives and leads to more effective solutions. Her team uses data and AI to personalize experiences and cross-sell products, resulting in a 50% improvement in pick-up rates.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

From left: Choo Wan Sim, head of UOB TMRW Digital (Singapore) and Jacquelyn Tan, head of group personal financial services showcasing the "scan to pay" feature on UOB TMRW App. UOB customers in Singapore can now use the function to make payments when they travel to Malaysia, Thailand and Indonesia.  PHOTO: UOB

“At the heart of it, ‘digital’ is about understanding what the customers want, what the end users internally need and then connecting the dots for them, to deliver journeys and experiences that are seamless,” said Serene Koh, head of group digital business and transformation, global consumer financial services, OCBC.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Olam, SGX
summary: Keppel's Data Centre Fund II has signed a framework agreement with Mitsui Fudosan to purchase a data centre in western Tokyo, as part of a broader collaboration to explore data centre development and investment opportunities in Japan and South-east Asia. Meanwhile, Olam Group's food ingredients unit secured export credit agency linked financing of approximately US$500 million. These developments may impact trading of Keppel's securities, which closed 0.3% higher on the day.

site_title: Watchdogs probe ‘technical’ failure on Boeing-made Latam plane
summary: A Boeing 787 Dreamliner operated by Latam Airlines lost altitude mid-flight from Sydney to Auckland, injuring about 50 passengers. The incident occurred about two hours into the three-hour flight, with some passengers reporting that the plane "plunged earthward" and others were thrown out of their seats. The cause of the incident is currently under investigation by New Zealand air safety investigators, with assistance from Chilean officials. LATAM stated that only one passenger and one crew member have non-life-threatening injuries, and the flight arrived on time. This incident is part of a series of safety concerns surrounding Boeing's aircraft, including recent fatal crashes and quality control issues.

images.alt_text: Batik Air is owned by Lion Air Group, Indonesia’s largest air travel company, which has a troubled safety record.
FILE PHOTO: Workers walk by a 737 Max aircraft on the production line at the Boeing factory in Renton, Washington, U.S., March 27, 2019.  REUTERS/Lindsey Wasson
China was Singapore's top tourist source market pre-pandemic.

REUTERS/Leonhard Simon///File Photo

The problem with the Alaska Airlines jet is believed to stem from maintenance on the part performed at Boeing’s Renton, Washington factory in which the door plug is believed to have been removed and reinstalled.
Scoot's chief executive officer Leslie Thng says the airline will fly to five to seven more destinations in South-east Asia in FY2025, bringing the network points to as many as 74.
The airline is still waiting to learn how much it must pay after losing a separate lawsuit accusing it of illegally firing 1700 ground staff in 2020.

site_title: Half of BOJ watchers still see April rate hike while bets on March move jump
summary: Bank of Japan (BOJ) watchers remain divided on when the central bank will end its negative interest rates, with 54% predicting April and 38% expecting a move next week. Despite this, 90% agree there's a risk of an imminent hike. The BOJ will release a quarterly economic projection and Tankan business survey, which may influence the timing of a potential rate hike. Strong economic data, including rising wages and a avoided technical recession, supports the case for a hike, with economists expecting an average wage increase of 4.1% this year.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan headquarters in Tokyo. Photographer: Kentaro Takahashi/Bloomberg

site_title: Modi ramps up campaign to position India as alternative to China
summary: India has signed four free trade agreements (FTAs) since 2021, following a nine-year gap, as Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government aims to position the country as an alternative to China for global supply chains. The latest pact with European countries includes a $100 billion investment commitment over 15 years, signaling India's readiness to take on commitments in areas like labor, environment, and sustainability. The deals are expected to boost manufacturing, create 80 million jobs by 2030, and give India's textiles sector a level playing field. Negotiations with the UK and Australia are ongoing, with talks with Oman already concluded.

images.alt_text: There may be pockets of irrational exuberance in Indian equity markets, says the Securities and Exchange Board of India.

The EFTA bloc has committed to market access and non-discriminatory treatment for Indian services including in the audio-visual, accounting and auditing, legal and computer-related sectors under the pact.
Modi has made high growth and infrastructure development his key poll plank in his last two tenures and has promised to make India a developed country by 2047.

site_title: Singapore stocks open stronger on Tuesday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks opened stronger on Tuesday, advancing 0.4% to 3,151.54, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 13.12 points. The broader market saw gainers outnumber losers 58 to 31, with Singtel and DBS leading the gains. Local banks, including UOB and OCBC, also rose. The move follows mixed global equities overnight, with US stocks finishing largely flat ahead of consumer inflation data.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Keppel signed a framework agreement with Mitsui Fudosan for its first data centre project in Japan.

site_title: Oil prices steady as Middle Eastern supply concerns ease
summary: Oil prices remained steady on Monday, with Brent futures settling at $82.21 a barrel, up 13 cents. Concerns about Middle Eastern supply disruptions eased, and Chinese data showed weaker demand. Despite this, US refining activity increased, limiting price falls. Analysts expect a possible storage draw as refining rates jump. Oil prices have remained above $80 a barrel for over a month.

images.alt_text: “The US produced more crude oil than any nation at any time, according to our International Energy Statistics, for the past six years in a row,” the EIA says.

A nozzle is replaced on a fuel dispenser at a gas station in La Puente, California, on September 7, 2023. US gas prices this week hit the highest levels in a decade as the summer holiday season winds down, with rising crude-oil prices a likely contributing factor to higher gas prices. (Photo by Frederic J. BROWN / AFP)

site_title: Crypto product inflows soar to record high, CoinShares says
summary: Crypto product inflows have reached record-breaking levels, with $2.7 billion flowing into crypto assets last week, according to CoinShares International. The majority of inflows went towards Bitcoin, which has seen six straight days of gains and reached a new high of $72,000. The surge is driven by the approval of spot Bitcoin ETFs and the upcoming halving event, which will cut the supply of new Bitcoin in half. This year's inflows ($10.3 billion) are comparable to 2021's ($10.6 billion), with some investors hedging against a correction by taking short positions.

images.alt_text: The wallets are digital addresses on the Bitcoin blockchain, in which users can store cryptocurrency.
The iShares Bitcoin ETF (ticker IBIT) pulled US$788.3 million on Tuesday (Mar 6), its 37th consecutive inflow.

site_title: Olam food ingredients unit ofi secures US$500 million financing
summary: Olam Group's food ingredients unit, ofi, has secured a US$500 million financing facility through an export credit agency-linked loan backed by Italian agency SACE. The facility consists of a five-year US$250 million tranche and a seven-year 37.38 billion yen tranche (S$338.8 million). Proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes of ofi.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
Olam Group expects the acquisition, which is funded from a combination of existing cash and debt facilities, to be earnings accretive from 2024.
Olam's earnings per share stands at S$0.0567 for the half year, up from S$0.0478 the previous year.
Olam Group says all its businesses in Nigeria “continue to operate normally”.
Shares in Olam Group are 7.8 per cent lower by 3.06 pm, and are on track for the biggest daily decline since March 2020, after sliding for four straight months till August

site_title: Embrace upskilling to keep Singapore’s workforce competitive
summary: Singapore's workforce is urged to upskill and reskill to stay competitive in the rapidly changing job market. The government has introduced initiatives such as the SkillsFuture credits for mid-career workers aged 40 and above, allowing for up to S$3,000 monthly training allowance. Despite the need for reskilling, the take-up rate of SkillsFuture credits remains low due to financial, time, and recognition concerns. The government aims to address these issues through measures such as protected time off and recognition of skills. Experts emphasize the importance of industry attachment and training to alleviate manpower challenges and encourage companies to support workers' upskilling.

Singaporeans aged 40 and above will receive full government subsidies to pursue a second diploma at polytechnics, Institute of Technical Education, and arts institutions.

site_title: Mango’s US expansion helps sales top 3.1 billion euros in 2023
summary: Spanish fashion retailer Mango reported record sales of 3.1 billion euros in 2023, surpassing its forecast by 19%. The growth was driven by a focus on party wear and high-end fashion pieces, which appealed to upmarket shoppers less sensitive to higher prices. This helped the brand fend off pressure from online players like Shein, as it expanded in the US market, following in the footsteps of Inditex, the world's largest listed fast-fashion group.

images.alt_text: Shein is seeking Beijing’s nod to go public in a listing that will likely face tough scrutiny from US regulators.
FILE PHOTO: People walk past a Prada store in Brussels, Belgium September 5, 2023. REUTERS/Yves Herman/File Photo
Victoria’s Secret has been working to acquire and retain customers through initiatives like a rebranded fashion show and the expansion of swim and apparel categories.

site_title: Leverage upskilling measures as a catalyst
summary: The Singapore government's upskilling measures aim to boost the country's economic output by 4% and create up to 676,000 new jobs by 2030. To maximize the impact, employers should adopt a skills-based approach, assess both technical and transferable skills, and identify skills gaps. Additionally, fostering an equality in upskilling opportunities and creating a supportive culture and leadership are crucial. The government's S$2 billion top-up to the National Productivity Fund also supports innovation and productivity. By addressing these areas, employers can unlock the full potential of the government's upskilling initiatives.

images.alt_text: The ST-BT Budget Roundtable 2024 was moderated by ST associate editor Vikram Khanna (left), with panellists (L to R) UOB senior economist Alvin Liew; Second Minister for Finance Indranee Rajah; Association of Small and Medium Enterprises president Ang Yuit; and NTUC deputy secretary-general Desmond Tan.
Budget 2024: Upskilling package reflects urgency to protect mature workers

site_title: No Signboard not taking action against interim CEO for now over fiduciary duty allegations
summary: No Signboard Holdings, a food and beverage company, has decided not to take action against interim CEO Lim Teck-Ean over allegations of breaching fiduciary duties. The company continues to investigate the claims, which include the S$1.2 million acquisition of a 60% stake in caterer Dining Haus. Lim Teck-Ean had been placed on leave due to share-price rigging charges. The decision was made after receiving legal advice, and the company will update shareholders with material developments.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: Indonesia vastly under-reports methane emissions from coal: report
summary: Indonesia, the world's largest thermal coal exporter, under-reports methane emissions from coal-mining activities by up to eight times, according to a report by Ember, a London-based climate think tank. The country's official figure of 128 kilotonnes of methane emissions is significantly lower than the estimated 1,000 kilotonnes predicted by Ember. This discrepancy could jeopardize Indonesia's commitment to reducing global methane emissions by 2030, as it is a signatory to the Global Methane Pledge.

images.alt_text: Real risks must be big, economically significant events few fathom – stealth torpedoes unpriced by markets, says Ken Fisher.
Hanoi topped air monitoring website IQAir’s table of the world’s most polluted cities.

Geo Energy's SDJ coal mine in Kalimantan, Indonesia. The company's revenue fell 31.7 per cent to S$249.2 million on the half-year due to a drop in its coal's average selling price.
The new initiatives are designed to support Brazil’s ambition to halve its emissions by 2030, accelerate the decarbonisation of industry and restore natural ecosystems, GFanz says.

site_title: Oracle jumps as ‘large’ new cloud contracts spur revenue growth
summary: Oracle's cloud infrastructure business saw 25% revenue growth to $5.1 billion in the third quarter, surpassing Wall Street estimates. The company's remaining performance obligation, a measure of backlogged sales, was $80 billion, driven by "large new cloud infrastructure contracts." CEO Safra Catz attributed the growth to customer momentum and Oracle's rapid expansion of cloud data centers. The stock surged 11% in extended trading, marking a significant improvement from a 10% decline over the past six months.

images.alt_text: Oracle is focused on expanding its cloud infrastructure business to more forcefully compete with Amazon.com, Microsoft and Alphabet’s Google.

site_title: Winds of change for S-Reits as interest rates normalise
summary: Singapore real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) have rebounded 15% since November 2023 as interest rates are expected to decline this year. With the US Federal Reserve signaling a rate cut, S-Reits' share prices are poised for further growth, driven by attractive valuations and high estimated dividend yields of close to 7%. Investors are advised to focus on structural trends in suburban retail, logistics, and data centers, where supply constraints support continued rental and growth.

images.alt_text: PLife Reit has a portfolio of 63 healthcare properties, mostly in Singapore and Japan
FCT’s portfolio has grown to nine suburban retail malls and an office building with a combined S$6.5 billion in assets under management as at Dec 31, 2023.

site_title: When a meme platform becomes about me, me, me
summary: Reddit is set to go public with an initial public offering (IPO) valued at around $6.5 billion, with select moderators and users given the chance to buy in at the IPO price. The company's valuation has created tension among its users, who are concerned about the impact of increased monetization and data mining on the platform. The r/wallstreetbets community, in particular, is urging users to bet against the offering, highlighting the complexities of aligning user interests with ownership.

images.alt_text: The company plans for its shares to trade on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol RDDT.
reddit Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg

site_title: Biden’s 2025 budget plan highlights policy differences ahead of elections
summary: US President Joe Biden's 2025 budget proposal, totaling $7.3 trillion, highlights his administration's policy priorities ahead of the November general election. The plan includes populist measures such as a 25% minimum tax rate for the wealthy and a hike in corporate tax rate, as well as strengthening social spending programs. The budget aims to reduce the deficit by $3 trillion over the next decade through increased taxes on the wealthy and corporations. However, the proposal faces stiff opposition from Republicans and some Democrats, making its passage in Congress unlikely.

images.alt_text: GOFFSTOWN, NEW HAMPSHIRE - MARCH 11: President Joe Biden speaks during an event about lowering costs for American families at the Granite State YMCA Allard Center of Goffstown on March 11, 2024 in Goffstown, New Hampshire. Days after Biden delivered his last State of the Union address before the November general election, the President held the event to highlight his administration's achievements and vision going into the next eight months of his campaign. site_title: Standstill in approvals for Malaysia’s residency visa may dent foreigners’ interest
summary: Malaysia's residency visa scheme, the Malaysia My Second Home (MM2H) programme, has seen a prolonged standstill in approvals, causing concern among foreigners interested in residing and retiring in the country. Introduced in 2002, the programme has attracted over 50,000 foreigners, but new applications remain on hold until parliament gives its green light. The programme's refreshed criteria have yet to have an impact, with only existing visa renewals being processed. Industry players warn that the delay may hurt interest in the programme, which remains an attractive option for foreigners seeking a residency visa.

images.alt_text: Malaysian government announced a review of the MM2H programme amid a 90 per cent drop in applications, with the hope to make the programme attractive again by offering more “flexible” options.
Kuala Lumpur commanded the highest rental growth for the high-rise home segment in Q4 last year, with an average monthly rental of RM1,975.

site_title: Laos-China Railway a boon for recovering tourism sector
summary: The Laos-China Railway, a $6 billion project connecting Laos to China, has become a major tourist attraction, with 3.1 million passengers carried in 2023 and an expected surge in demand this year. The railway has reduced cargo transit times and transportation costs, and its launch has contributed to a 164% increase in international tourists to Laos in 2023. The Lao government aims to attract 6.2 million tourists in 2024, with the railway expected to expand tourism beyond main cities and increase access to hard-to-reach towns.

images.alt_text: People at an HSR exhibition during the groundbreaking ceremony on the cooperation between Thailand and China on the Bangkok-Nong Khai HSR development in Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand.
Tourists walk down the mountain through a night market in Luang Prabang, Laos. The country's public debt stands at 122 per cent of GDP.

Ng Aung San, founder and co-CEO of Sir Stamford Raffles Group, shows the proximity between Marum Estate and Cambodia's Techo Takmao International Airport, which is set to open in 2025.

site_title: Scholz courts Asean nations in bid to cut China dependency
summary: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz is seeking to diversify trade relations in Asia and reduce dependence on China by strengthening ties with Thailand, Malaysia, and the Philippines. Scholz will hold separate talks with the leaders of the three countries in Berlin, aiming to improve economic resilience through more diverse supply chains and raw-materials partnerships. Despite China remaining Germany's largest trading partner in 2023, Scholz's efforts aim to reduce one-sided dependencies and promote European economic diversification.

images.alt_text: Robotic arms weld parts to be used in an automobile chassis in the Volkswagen AG factory, as part of the Think Blue sustainability initiative in Wolfsburg, Germany, on Friday, May 19, 2017. site_title: ECB leaning towards keeping banks’ minimum reserve level at 1%
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is leaning against increasing the minimum reserve level for banks from 1% to a higher rate, amid concerns that a hike could reduce lending and increase losses in the financial system. The decision is expected to be made this week, but officials have not ruled out the possibility of a future increase. Banking stocks, including Deutsche Bank and BNP Paribas, have reacted positively to the news, with Deutsche Bank rising as much as 2% and BNP Paribas up as much as 0.6%.

images.alt_text: Lending growth has been hovering around zero since the autumn but is expected to slowly recover in the coming months as the ECB likely begins cutting interest rates.
The Bundesbank says it lost 21.6 billion euros (S$31.4 billion) last year, wiping out nearly all of its provisions
Inflation comes down rapidly last year and now stands just below 3 per cent, but the ECB says it could take more than another year to get it down to its 2 per cent target.

site_title: Bitcoin’s rally is creating around 1,500 ‘millionaire wallets’ daily
summary: Bitcoin's rally is creating approximately 1,500 new "millionaire wallets" daily, according to Kaiko Research. This surge is attributed to the cryptocurrency's 70% year-to-date gain, driven by surging demand for US exchange-traded funds. However, the pace is slower than during the 2021 bull market, when over 4,000 wallets reached the million-dollar mark daily. Factors contributing to the slower pace include a lack of fresh capital, whales taking profits, and storing holdings with custodians rather than personal wallets.

site_title: Nvidia ETF that delivers double gains sees record flows
summary: An exchange-traded fund (ETF) that doubles the daily return of Nvidia has seen record inflows, reaching $1.4 billion since its launch in 2022. The GraniteShares 2x Long NVDA Daily ETF has received $252 million in fresh capital in the past week and saw its second-highest trading volume on March 11. This surge in investment is driven by investors' confidence in Nvidia's role in the global economy's technological shifts, which are expected to create new wealth-generating opportunities.

images.alt_text: Nvidia shares have skyrocketed on the back of blowout earnings that reaffirmed Wall Street’s optimism on the potential for artificial intelligence to reshape the technology industry.
Nvidia’s rise from niche chipmaker to one of the biggest companies in the world is based on the premise that its phenomenal sales growth over the past year has staying power.
Nvidia is the world’s leading maker of artificial intelligence (AI) chips used to create systems like OpenAI’s ChatGPT.

site_title: Elon Musk takes another swing at OpenAI, makes xAI’s Grok chatbot open-source
summary: Elon Musk's AI startup xAI is making its ChatGPT rival "Grok" open-source, days after Musk sued OpenAI for abandoning its original mission in favor of a for-profit model. The move aligns with firms like Meta and France's Mistral, which also have open-source AI models. Musk aims to create a "maximum truth-seeking AI" and has warned against the use of technology for profit by big tech companies, sparking debate about the benefits and risks of open-sourcing AI technology.

images.alt_text: OpenAI says Musk wanted the company to merge with electric vehicle maker Tesla, and he forwarded an email that said the startup should “attach to Tesla as its cash cow”.
Musk sues OpenAI and its chief executive Sam Altman (above) for allegedly breaking their founding agreement
The lawsuit filed late on Thursday (Feb 29) says Altman and OpenAI’s co-founder Greg Brockman originally approached Musk (above) to make an open source, non-profit company.
Grok is being trained using data collected by X – a marketing point for xAI, which says that will make its chatbot more up to date on new information.

FILE PHOTO: Elon Musk, Chief Executive Officer of SpaceX and Tesla and owner of Twitter, gestures as he attends the Viva Technology conference dedicated to innovation and startups at the Porte de Versailles exhibition centre in Paris, France, June 16, 2023. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes/File Photo

site_title: How Temasek keeps its distance while working with boards
summary: Temasek, a Singaporean investment firm, has seen a value uplift of over S$10 billion since engaging with its portfolio companies. Notable transformations include CapitaLand's restructuring, Sembcorp Industries' demerger, and Keppel's divestment. However, the restructuring of Sembcorp Marine, now known as Seatrium, has faced criticism, particularly over the price tag of its acquisition of Keppel Offshore & Marine. Despite this, Nagi Hamiyeh, head of Temasek's portfolio development group, believes the company is turning itself around, citing reduced leverage and a focus on sustainable returns.

images.alt_text: Joan Ng
Temasek is "seriously considering" having inhouse operating specialists as it becomes a more active investor, said Nagi Hamiyeh, head of the portfolio development group.
Seatrium logo at their office’s lobby, Oct 19, 2023.

site_title: Active but not activist: Temasek’s Nagi Hamiyeh on creating value
summary: Temasek, Singapore's state investor, is shifting its investment approach from a passive to an active one. The company, which was formed 50 years ago, has created a portfolio development function to work with its portfolio companies, providing strategic reviews, business model changes, and connections with new talents and companies. This approach has led to significant revaluation gains for companies like Keppel and record profits for Singapore Airlines. Temasek is now considering having in-house operating specialists to further enhance its value creation efforts, with a long-term horizon and a focus on stability and dividends.

images.alt_text: Joan Ng
Seatrium's Floating Living Lab with the stacked energy storage system (left) and LNG tank, Oct 19, 2023. It is the first such offshore floating testbed in Singapore.
India's was among the five best performing stock markets in Asia last year.
Temasek Holdings said that persistent inflatoin, geopolitical tensions and rising nationalism and protectionism led to an increase in the firm's cost of capital.

site_title: Europe: Tech selloff drags down shares, US inflation data awaited
summary: European shares fell 0.4% on Monday, dragged down by a 2% decline in the technology sector, with chipmakers ASML and BE Semiconductor leading the losses. Investors await US inflation data this week, which could influence interest rate cuts, and market focus has shifted away from the Stoxx 600. The euro zone's 10-year bond yield edged up, while Germany's industrials sector and mining index also fell. Despite this, shares of LEG Immobilien rose 5.1% after beating earnings expectations, and Portugal's PSI index ended up 0.1% after the country's general election.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average was the only major Wall Street index to gain on Monday, rising 0.1 per cent to 38,769.66.

site_title: Billionaire Adani to start mapping Asia’s biggest slum next week
summary: Adani Group is set to start mapping Asia's largest slum, Dharavi, in Mumbai, India, on March 18. The company will collect data from hundreds of thousands of residents to determine their rehabilitation needs under the Dharavi Redevelopment Project, a joint venture between Adani and the Maharashtra state government. The project aims to make India's financial capital slum-free using laser mapping technology, creating the world's first digital map of a vast informal settlement.

images.alt_text: The flagship firm of billionaire Gautam Adani’s empire posted net income of 18.9 billion rupees (S$305 million) for the quarter through December
FILE PHOTO: A logo of the Adani Group is seen on a commercial complex in Mumbai, India, February 7, 2023. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas/File Photo
The flagship firm of billionaire Gautam Adani’s empire posted net income of 18.9 billion rupees (S$305 million) for the quarter through December

site_title: US: Stocks mixed as traders await consumer inflation data
summary: US stocks closed largely flat on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.1% to 38,769.66, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq fell 0.1% and 0.4%, respectively. Traders await consumer inflation data on Tuesday, which could provide clarity on the US Federal Reserve's battle against rising prices. The Fed has held its key lending rate at a 23-year high, and traders are watching for signs of sustained inflation. The market is anxious to see if January's inflation uptick was a one-off or a sign of a more sustained trend.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 55.48 points, or 0.14 per cent, at the open to 38,667.21.

site_title: Chinese developer Vanke cut to junk territory by Moody’s
summary: Moody's downgraded China Vanke's credit rating to Ba1, stripping it of investment-grade status, citing weakening credit metrics, financial flexibility, and liquidity buffer due to falling home sales and funding uncertainties. The downgrade reflects Moody's expectation that Vanke's credit situation will worsen over the next 12-18 months. This move is likely to further shake confidence in China's property sector, which has already seen record lows for the developer's shares and bonds.

images.alt_text: The State Council – China’s Cabinet – is coordinating support efforts for China Vanke, sources say, adding that financial institutions have been requested to make swift progress.

site_title: Oil prices slips amid concerns over the Middle East, China demand
summary: Global oil prices slipped on Monday, with Brent futures down 31 US cents at US$81.77 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) down 34 US cents at US$77.67, amid concerns over the Middle East and softening demand in China. The oil complex is in a wait-and-watch mode due to the Gaza war and its cascading conflicts. Opec+ agreed to extend voluntary oil output cuts, which could tighten the market as demand recovers.

images.alt_text: Lower interest rates could increase oil demand by boosting economic growth.

site_title: US leads global oil production for sixth straight year: EIA
summary: The US leads global oil production for the sixth consecutive year, with a record-breaking average production of 12.9 million barrels per day, according to the Energy Information Administration (EIA). US crude oil production reached a new monthly record high of 13.3 million barrels per day in December. The EIA believes it is unlikely that another country will break the record in the near term, citing Saudi Arabia's recent decision to halt its oil expansion plan and target a maximum sustained production capacity of 12 million barrels per day.

images.alt_text: A view of the logo of the International Energy Agency in Paris, France, December 15, 2023. REUTERS/Sarah Meyssonnier
IEA's new office in Singapore will focus on scaling up the deployment of renewables and other clean energy technologies, among other things.

“India will become the largest source of global oil demand growth between now and 2030, while growth in developed economies and China initially slows and then subsequently goes into reverse in our outlook,” says IEA.
Overall gas consumption across the globe is seen increasing by 2.5 per cent in 2024, with the Asia-Pacific region adding 4 per cent, followed by gas-rich countries in Africa and the Middle East.

site_title: US: Wall St slips ahead of key inflation test
summary: US stocks fell ahead of key inflation data, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 55.48 points, or 0.14%, to 38,667.21. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the S&P 500 falling 11.73 points, or 0.23%, and the Nasdaq dropping 32.49 points, or 0.20%. Investors are bracing for the inflation data, which could influence the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy path.

site_title: HSBC to hire almost 50 bankers for startup, venture lending in US
summary: HSBC plans to hire 50 bankers for its startup, venture lending business in the US, mainly targeting tech and healthcare sectors. The bank has already hired 40 people from Silicon Valley Bank and now has a team of 60 employees. Since its venture lending business launched, HSBC has signed up 250 companies, closed 35 deals, and signed 30 term sheets with clients averaging $15 million per deal. The bank's head of US commercial banking, Wyatt Crowell, believes the business is gaining traction and plans to expand globally.

site_title: Biden unveils US$7.3 trillion budget as campaign pitch for spending, tax goals
summary: US President Joe Biden has unveiled a $7.3 trillion budget for the 2025 fiscal year, aiming to sharply raise taxes on corporations and high earners to cut the federal deficit and fund new programs. The budget includes raising corporate income tax to 28%, hiking rates on those making over $400,000, and increasing taxes on individuals with wealth over $100 million. The plan also includes spending on childcare programs, paid family leave, and violent crime prevention, while aiming to cut annual deficit spending by $3 trillion over 10 years.

images.alt_text: Biden faces huge problems that undercut his chances of getting re-elected, including doubts about his physical and mental fitness for office, looming fears over the country’s immigration crisis at the southern border, and continuing gloom about inflation despite falling prices.

(Centre) Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's comments came one day after US President Joe Biden said Netanyahu “must pay more attention to the innocent lives being lost as a consequence of the actions taken” in Gaza.
US Senate passes spending bill, averts imminent shutdown
US President Joe Biden delivers the State of the Union address during a joint meeting of Congress in the House chamber at the U.S. Capitol on March 07, 2024 in Washington, DC.

site_title: Digging into the numbers in tech
summary: South-east Asian tech major Sea has turned in solid results, achieving its first profitable year, exceeding analyst forecasts, and guiding for healthy growth in its gaming and e-commerce arms. However, despite this, the company's financials show it is far from its glory days, with its cash cow, Garena, highly dependent on the success of hit game Free Fire, which has been sputtering. Sea's CEO, Forrest Li, has emphasized improving price competitiveness and digital banking and insurance services as key priorities, but investors want both profits, growth, and proof of the company's ability to beat the competition.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
One of the early movers in South-east Asia’s e-commerce space, Qoo10 got its start a good 14 years ago as Gmarket.
The financial viability of digital wealth platforms has been a sticky issue, writes BT Garage correspondent Claudia Chong.
Insects as a source of alternative proteins aren’t for everyone, as some startups in South-east Asia have found out over the years, writes Garage correspondent Claudia Chong.
Over at Grab, Singapore’s competition watchdog is further scrutinising its takeover of taxi operator Trans-cab, writes Garage correspondent Benjamin Cher.
VCs, too, have raised money for their funds, but it isn’t all cheery there, writes Garage correspondent Benjamin Cher.

site_title: Yen climbs as traders eye BOJ hike; Bitcoin hits new record
summary: The Japanese yen rose 0.2% against the US dollar, reaching a five-week high, as investors anticipate the Bank of Japan may hike interest rates this month. The yen's gain was fueled by a revision to Japan's economic growth figures, which avoided a technical recession, and growing bets on pay rises from Japan's biggest firms. Meanwhile, Bitcoin hit a new record high above $72,200, driven by hopes of a Fed rate cut and increased investment in spot Bitcoin exchange-traded funds.

images.alt_text: Speaking on Thursday, Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell said the Fed was "not far" from having the confidence it needed to cut rates.
The euro was 0.3 per cent up against the US dollar at US$1.0928, a six-week high.

site_title: Alibaba overhauls incentives to entice staff as stock languishes
summary: Alibaba is overhauling its employee incentives to attract and retain talent amid a struggling stock market. Starting April, employees will receive a combination of equity and cash, with stock options vesting quarterly instead of annually. The changes aim to improve compensation certainty and liquidity. This move follows similar changes by other Chinese tech companies, including ByteDance and JD.com, as they face intense competition and regulatory scrutiny.

images.alt_text: Signage at the Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. offices in Beijing, China, on Tuesday, Aug. 8, 2023. Alibaba is scheduled to release earnings results on Aug. 10. Source: Bloomberg

site_title: UK's Princess of Wales, sorry for 'any confusion' over edited photo
summary: Princess of Wales Kate, 42, apologized on social media for "any confusion" caused by an edited photograph of her family. The image, posted by her office Kensington Palace, showed Kate posing with her children and was taken by Prince William. Reuters and other news agencies withdrew the picture after discovering it had been altered, with some saying the sleeve of Kate's daughter's cardigan didn't line up properly. Kate had made minor adjustments to the photo, which was intended to mark Mother's Day.

images.alt_text: The Princess of Wales during a walkabout meeting members of the public on the Long Walk near Windsor Castle, Berkshire, where the Coronation Concert to celebrate the coronation of King Charles III and Queen Camilla is being held. Picture date: Sunday May 7, 2023.  Andrew Matthews/Pool via REUTERS

site_title: UK regulator to allow crypto exchange-traded notes for professional investors
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has approved the launch of crypto exchange-traded notes (ETNs) for professional investors, such as investment firms and credit institutions. These ETNs track the performance of underlying cryptocurrencies like bitcoin and ether, but are deemed too risky for retail investors. The FCA warned that crypto ETNs pose harm to retail investors and will remain banned for them. The London Stock Exchange has announced it will accept applications for bitcoin and ether ETNs starting in the second quarter of this year.

images.alt_text: (FILES) Physical imitations of bitcoins are pictured at a cryptocurrency exchange branch near the Grand Bazaar in Istanbul on October 20, 2021. Despite its irrepressible appeal on the markets, bitcoin still has a sulphurous reputation, given its history of scandals and sudden price collapses, and its still assiduous use by cybercriminals. (Photo by Ozan KOSE / AFP)

site_title: PGIM Real Estate puts up freehold strata offices at 108 Robinson Road for sale at S$54.6 million guide price
summary: PGIM Real Estate is selling three floors of strata office space at 108 Robinson Road in Singapore for S$54.6 million, or S$18.2 million per floor. The freehold building underwent renovation in 2023 and has been subdivided into 11 strata units. The sale is the first phase of PGIM RE's strata sales in the country, following its acquisition of the property in 2021 for US$107 million.

site_title: Abu Dhabi targets US$100 billion AUM for AI investment firm
summary: Abu Dhabi is launching a new technology investment firm, MGX, aiming to surpass $100 billion in assets under management (AUM) in AI and semiconductor investments. Funded by Abu Dhabi's government, MGX will pursue deals in AI infrastructure, semiconductors, and AI core technologies. Led by Mubadala Investment and AI firm G42, MGX will be chaired by UAE National Security Adviser Sheikh Tahnoon Zayed Al Nahyan and will focus on partnering with the best firms in its three main verticals.

images.alt_text: AI development, with its high energy demands, faces a challenge. Companies involved in AI research and development must reconcile their pursuit of innovation with the need to maintain a favourable ESG score.
In December, xAI rolled out its ChatGPT competitor Grok for Premium+ subscribers of social media platform X, aiming to create what Musk has said would be a “maximum truth-seeking AI”.

site_title: Embracing stock markets’ all-time highs
summary: The stock market rally has reached new all-time highs, with nearly 70% of developed market stocks trending upwards, contradicting the notion that narrow leadership is a sign of a market peak. Historically, new highs often indicate sustained bullish momentum, and the rally's broadening nature suggests a healthy bull market. While some investors may view the gains as frothy, leverage is not yet at worrying levels, and the resilience of financial markets is a testament to the global economy's underlying strength.

images.alt_text: The Morgan Stanley headquarters in New York. Photographer: Angus Mordant/Bloomberg
US tech stocks had fallen sharply on Wednesday. That included Apple, which finished 2.8 per cent lower.

site_title: Global energy treaty shaken by Europe
summary: The EU has signed around 120 new energy agreements with foreign powers in the last two years, with a significant number in the Middle East. This move contradicts growing concerns that the bloc may retrench from its climate ambitions ahead of the European Parliament elections. The EU is instead crafting a coordinated exit from the Energy Charter Treaty, a move seen as a step towards meeting its net-zero ambitions. The decision prioritizes energy security as the bloc transitions away from Russian fuels.

images.alt_text: Carbon removals seek to suck carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere and store it – ideally permanently underground or in the ocean.
The compromise allows for new fossil fuel investments to be excluded from protections and institutes a 10 year phase out period for protections on existing investments.

site_title: Magnificent Seven stocks aren’t too pricey: JP Morgan strategists
summary: JP Morgan strategists say the Magnificent 7 stocks, including Microsoft, are trading at lower valuations relative to the S&P 500 compared to the past five years, despite strong outperformance. This suggests trading is less stretched than a few years ago. Strategist Mislav Matejka notes that while there's concern over the group's strong performance, these stocks could hold out better than traditional cyclicals in case of general earnings disappointment.

images.alt_text: The stockmarket rally has broadened widely over the last three months, suggesting a healthy bull market.
financial, planning, report
The Magnificent Seven stocks, which include Nvidia, Apple and Amazon, led the surge in the S&P 500 in 2023.

site_title: Singapore-based Silicon Box to invest US$3.5 billion in new chip plant in Italy
summary: Singapore-based semiconductor startup Silicon Box is set to invest US$3.5 billion in a new chip factory in Italy, expected to generate 1,600 jobs. The project, which has an estimated operational cost of 4 billion euros (S$5.82 billion) over 15 years, aims to bolster Europe's chip production to reduce reliance on Asian facilities and mitigate supply shortages. This comes after the government failed to persuade US-based chip-maker Intel to invest in Italy, and follows Silicon Box's recent US$200 million financing round, which valued the company over US$1 billion.

images.alt_text: Silicon Box said its chiplet approach addresses a key bottleneck in chip production.
Silicon Box's semiconductor manufacturing facility will be worth US$2 billion when it is fully fitted out.

site_title: US opens probe into 250,712 Honda vehicles over braking issues
summary: The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) launched a preliminary probe into approximately 250,712 Honda Insight and Passport vehicles over inadvertent activation of automatic emergency braking. The issue affects 2019-2022 models, resulting in 46 complaints, including three crashes or fires and two injuries. Inadvertent activation can increase the risk of a collision, potentially causing injury and property damage. Honda's North American office has not commented on the matter.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Honda logo is seen during the New York International Auto Show, in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., April 5, 2023. REUTERS/David 'Dee' Delgado/File Photo

site_title: Goldman loses senior Asia macro sales executive Mats Dewitte
summary: Goldman Sachs has lost senior Asia macro sales executive Mats Dewitte after almost two decades with the company. Dewitte, who co-headed macro sales for Hong Kong and Singapore, was responsible for distributing Goldman's currency and interest-rate products in the region. His departure is the latest in a string of senior Asia sales executive departures for the bank in the past year. The exact reasons for Dewitte's resignation are not disclosed.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Goldman Sachs company logo is on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., July 13, 2021.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: Britain consults on easing burden of anti-money laundering checks
summary: Britain's finance ministry has proposed ways to ease the burden of anti-money laundering (AML) checks applied by banks, reflecting the impact of Brexit and new financial activities such as cryptoassets. The proposal, open for public consultation until June 9, aims to make AML rules more proportionate for companies and their customers, while providing greater clarity on how to apply existing rules. The ministry considers adjustments to digital verification of customer identities and potential legislation to improve data sharing among agencies to crack down on crime, amid an estimated £12 billion of annual criminal cash generated in the UK.

images.alt_text: Police have raided Jian Wen's house and seized Bitcoin worth over £1.7 billion (S$2.9 billion).

site_title: SGX’s February derivatives volume 24% higher
summary: SGX's February derivatives volume rose 24% year-over-year to 1.3 million contracts, driven by robust risk-management activity amid the extended Chinese New Year holidays. Mainland China and Taiwan index futures saw significant increases, with SGX FTSE China A50 Index Futures volume rising 8% year-over-year to 8 million contracts. Total derivatives traded volume climbed 9% year-over-year to 21.9 million contracts, while commodity derivatives volume surged 39% year-over-year to 4.9 million contracts.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
On the local bourse, gainers outnumbered losers 292 to 250 on Monday after 1.2 billion securities worth S$765.6 million were traded.

site_title: Assertive Biden launches campaign
summary: US President Joe Biden, 81, has launched his re-election campaign despite facing huge problems, including low approval ratings, doubts about his physical and mental fitness, and the immigration crisis. Despite a majority of Democrats wanting another candidate to run, Biden is out to consolidate his base and woo Nikki Haley's voters. His campaign comes as the country grapples with inflation and immigration concerns.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden delivers the State of the Union address during a joint meeting of Congress in the House chamber at the U.S. Capitol on March 07, 2024 in Washington, DC.
“The time has now come to suspend my campaign. I have no regrets.” Nikki Haley says.

site_title: Singapore stocks end lower on Monday amid mixed regional trading; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.3% to close at 3,138.42, as the benchmark ended lower amid a mixed regional performance. The US inflation report for February is set to release on March 12, contributing to the cautious tone. Top gainers included City Developments Ltd, which rose 3.1%, and FCT, which closed unchanged. Meanwhile, Emperador was the top STI decliner, shedding 3% as FTSE Russell announced its removal from the index.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Bull statues are placed in font of screens showing the Hang Seng stock index and stock prices outside Exchange Square, in Hong Kong, China, August 18, 2023. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu
City Developments is up a much as 3.7 per cent to S$5.96 after the midday trading break.

site_title: Google billionaire family office hires ex GIC head of sustainability for green deals
summary: Google billionaire Sergey Brin's family office has hired Rachel Teo, the former head of sustainability at Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC, to focus on green investments. Teo joins Bayshore Global Management, a Singapore-based office established in 2020. The move is seen as a strategic step to help the family office find and manage environmentally friendly investments.

images.alt_text: Rachel Teo, head of sustainability and head of total portfolio sustainable investing, at GIC.

site_title: Globalisation may not have increased income inequality, after all
summary: A new study challenges the notion that globalization has led to increased income inequality within countries. Researchers found that as the poor become richer, they are more likely to understate their income, leading to a more accurate picture of poverty rates. This means poverty may have fallen faster than previously thought, and inequality within countries may have decreased. The study's findings suggest a "true global middle class" has emerged, characterized by members who are less vulnerable to financial shocks and are more likely to report their income accurately.

images.alt_text: Robots and workers assemble electric vehicles at a new factory run by Chinese automaker Nio. Attitudes towards China have changed since businesses in the West realised it was evolving from being a supplier to a competitor.
People hold a banner which read "Peace not Capitalism!" during an anti-capitalism march in Berlin on April 30, 2023, on the eve of Mayday protests in the German capital.
Host China wants this week's BRICS summit to help usher in a new era of fairer global development.

site_title: Vinyl revival rocks Britain’s inflation basket
summary: Vinyl records are returning to Britain's inflation basket for the first time in 32 years, joining compact discs, music streaming subscriptions, and digital downloads. This change reflects a resurgence in demand for tangible music formats, as Britons increasingly prioritize physical music over digital alternatives. The Office for National Statistics (ONS) noted that cultural revivals, such as the vinyl revival, can impact spending habits.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak (left) and Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt at a cabinet meeting in February. The UK is now in recession after two straight quarters of negative growth.
British supermarkets’ most recent earnings have revealed solid growth over the Christmas period, with price cuts and customer loyalty initiatives boosting sales.
The Confederation of British Industry’s (CBI) monthly retail sales balance, a gauge of sales versus a year ago, rises to -7 from -50 in January, the slowest fall in 10 months.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 11)
summary: Singapore's Business Optimism Index for Q2 2024 is higher than the +4.60 percentage points in Q2 2023, marking a one-year high. Two residential sites are up for sale in River Valley Green, with one including a serviced apartment component. Fullerton Health's former director, Daniel Chan, claims trial on corruption charges related to falsifying entertainment claims. Singapore stocks ended lower on Monday with the STI down 0.3%, amid mixed regional trading.

site_title: Keppel data centre fund to buy upcoming data centre in Japan
summary: Keppel Data Centre Fund II has signed a framework agreement with Mitsui Fudosan to purchase a data centre in western Tokyo, Japan, with a planned gross floor area of over 300,000 square feet. The facility is expected to be ready for service in 2027. This is Keppel's first data centre project in Japan, and the company will work exclusively with Mitsui Fudosan on the acquisition. The deal is part of Keppel's expansion into the Japanese market, which is expected to reach US$21 billion in revenue by 2028.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
High capital expenditure, tech changes could dampen outlook for data-centre S-Reits

site_title: Tokyo stocks end more than 2% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks closed 2.19% lower on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index dropping 868.45 points to 38,820.49. The broader Topix index fell 2.20% to 2,666.83, influenced by a stronger yen and a sell-off in semiconductor shares. Investors were spooked by US high-tech shares, including Nvidia's decline, and the yen's rise against the dollar, according to IwaiCosmo Securities. The market sought to correct its course after sharp increases since the beginning of the year.

images.alt_text: Bull statues are placed in font of screens showing the Hang Seng stock index and stock prices outside Exchange Square, in Hong Kong, China, August 18, 2023. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu
