site_title: Bitcoin tops US$72,000 for the first time as rally builds steam
summary: Bitcoin reached a record high of US$72,201, advancing 5.5% on Monday, marking the sixth consecutive day of gains and a 70% increase this year. Massive inflows into US Bitcoin ETFs, worth nearly US$10 billion, fueled the rally. The surge also boosted smaller tokens like Ether and Solana. The London Stock Exchange confirmed it will accept Bitcoin and Ether exchange-traded notes, further solidifying the cryptocurrency's growth.

site_title: Former perm sec Tan Tee How to succeed outgoing chairman of CLCT’s manager
summary: Former Singapore permanent secretary Tan Tee How will succeed outgoing chairman Soh Kim Soon as chairman of CapitaLand China Trust Management's board, effective April 23. Tan joined the board as a non-executive independent director in August 2023 and was appointed to the nominating and remuneration committee in January. He brings extensive public sector and industry knowledge, real estate expertise, and management experience to the role, following Soh's seven-year tenure.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

The manager attributes the rise in gross revenue to higher contributions from CLCT’s retail portfolio. CapitaMall Wangjing, CapitaMall Yuhuating and Rock Square (above) benefited from asset enhancement initiatives.

site_title: Nomura rejigs US investing arm, plans to grow private credit
summary: Nomura Holdings has reorganized its US investment management under a new unit, Nomura Capital Management, to expand its private credit business. The new unit will house the firm's existing high-yield bond strategy and private credit investments, aiming to grow organically and through acquisitions. CEO Robert Stark, who joined the firm in 2022, will lead the new unit, with the goal of increasing the business's growth.

site_title: Reddit launches long-awaited IPO with US$748 million target
summary: Reddit is set to launch its initial public offering (IPO) with a target valuation of up to $748 million, selling 22 million shares at $31 to $34 each. The company, which averaged 73.1 million daily active users in the fourth quarter, reported a net loss of $91 million on revenue of $804 million in 2023. Reddit's largest shareholder, Advance Magazine Publishers, will retain a significant stake, and the company plans to trade on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol RDDT. The IPO is being led by Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase, and Bank of America Corp.

site_title: China passes law granting Communist Party more control over Cabinet
summary: China's parliament passed a revised State Council Organic Law, granting the Communist Party more executive control over the Cabinet. The amendment, which was approved by 2,883 delegate votes, emphasizes the party's authority and Xi Jinping's ideology. This marks a significant shift in the reorganisation of executive authority in China, as the party gains more control over policymaking and oversight. The move is seen as part of a broader trend of transferring power from the state to the party.

images.alt_text: “The government guarantees basic housing needs, and the market fulfils other diversified housing requirements and systems, establishing a market for both renting and buying,” says China’s Housing and Urban-Rural Development Minister Ni Hong.

China's five per cent target would be in line with its GDP growth last year, one of the country’s lowest in decades and a far cry from the double-digit growth that long drove its breakneck development in the nineties and 2000s.

site_title: Malaysia’s mini-market chain retailer 99 Speed Mart files IPO draft prospectus
summary: 99 Speed Mart, Malaysia's largest mini-market chain retailer, filed a draft prospectus for a domestic initial public offering (IPO). The company plans to offer up to 17% stake, with proceeds used for expansion, distribution centre establishment, and delivery truck purchases. The IPO aims to raise funds for 3,000 outlets nationwide by 2025, with 85.3% allocated to institutional investors and 14.7% to retail investors. CIMB Investment Bank is the principal adviser and underwriter for the IPO.

site_title: Hong Kong weekend home transactions jump to three-year high
summary: Hong Kong saw a three-year high in weekend home transactions with 37 apartments changing hands, a 48% increase from the previous week. The surge is attributed to recent easing steps, including the removal of extra property levies. Despite this, analysts predict home values will decline by 5% in 2024 due to high interest rates and ample supply. Shares of major developers, such as New World Development, Henderson Land Development, and Sun Hung Kai Properties, rose on the news, with some gaining as much as 2.8% and 2.3% respectively.

images.alt_text: The real estate crisis in mainland China has made Hong Kong’s residential market seem like a safer bet, adding to its dramatic rebound.
The number of transactions in the 10 biggest estates rose to the highest level in 61 weeks last weekend.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, March 11, 2024 (Ep 19)
summary: Stocks in Japan, Australia, and Singapore declined on Monday after a US unemployment rate increase, while Japfa shares rose after a potential privatization deal. The US unemployment rate ticked up, impacting regional markets. Japfa's shares jumped as the company reportedly considered a privatization deal. The market trends were influenced by the US unemployment data, which affected regional markets.

site_title: Intel-backed Astera seeks US$534 million in IPO with AI appeal
summary: Astera Labs, backed by Intel, is seeking US$534 million in its initial public offering (IPO) as it taps into investor demand for artificial intelligence (AI) plays. The company plans to sell 14.8 million shares at a price of US$27 to US$30, valuing it at US$4.5 billion to US$5 billion. This is the largest IPO by a tech company since Klaviyo's US$659 million IPO in September.

site_title: Asia: Most markets fall after strong US data, eyes on inflation
summary: Asian markets fell on Monday after a US jobs report beat expectations but didn't sway the Federal Reserve's interest rate cut plans. Investors now focus on inflation data this week, with traders expecting three rate cuts this year, down from six previously anticipated. Tech sell-offs in Japan and a stronger yen weighed on exporters, while Hong Kong and Shanghai saw mixed reactions to consumer price data. Bitcoin fell slightly after hitting a record high.

images.alt_text: Singapore's banking stocks are all trading higher on Monday morning.

site_title: US companies to invest US$1 billion in Philippines, Raimondo says
summary: US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo announced that US companies will invest over $1 billion in the Philippines, spanning areas like AI, digital upskilling, solar, nuclear projects, and a new airline route to Cebu province. This investment comes as part of the US-Philippines alliance, described as "ironclad" by Raimondo. The move is seen as a way to bolster economic relations between the two countries, amid the intensifying rivalry between Washington and Beijing.

images.alt_text: The BSP has kept interest rates at 6.50 per cent for three straight meetings since late last year and will next review policy on Apr 4.

site_title: India may review rule for funds targeting overheated small-cap stocks
summary: India's markets regulator, the Securities and Exchange Board of India (Sebi), is reviewing its rules for mutual funds investing in small-cap stocks amid concerns about stretched valuations. Chairperson Madhabi Puri Buch stated that allowing excessive growth could lead to "irrational exuberance." The regulator has also received feedback about potential misuse of small and medium-sized enterprises' listings and is collecting evidence on price manipulation. Sebi plans to introduce an optional T+0 settlement to ensure competitiveness and has seen record inflows into small-cap funds, with shares powering the record rally in Indian shares last year.

site_title: Bank of Japan makes no ETF purchases despite Topix slump
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) made no purchases of Japan stock exchange-traded funds (ETFs) on March 11, despite the Topix index closing 2.2% lower, exceeding the central bank's usual 2% threshold. This marks the BOJ's first time not buying ETFs this year, and could signal a shift in priorities. BOJ governor Kazuo Ueda previously stated the central bank would examine stopping ETF purchases when achieving its 2% inflation target. The BOJ's next monetary policy meeting is scheduled for March 18-19.

site_title: Orchard Road malls lack scale, but Taylor Swift-league events show a path to riches
summary: Singapore's Orchard Road malls can benefit from hosting major events, as seen in the recent Taylor Swift concerts, which drew over 300,000 tickets and boosted the economy. However, the area lacks scale compared to other leading malls in the region, such as One Bangkok in Thailand. Redeveloping key assets like Tanglin Shopping Centre, Far East Shopping Centre, and Hotel Properties Limited's voco Orchard Singapore hotel could rejuvenate the area and bring economic benefits. To stand out, Orchard Road malls need to differentiate themselves by focusing on the luxury segment and attracting affluent international visitors, capitalizing on Singapore's reputation as a world-class event destination.

site_title: Pilots at Qantas units to strike again amid ongoing pay dispute
summary: Pilots at QantasLink and Network Aviation will strike on Thursday and Friday, demanding higher pay. The Australian Federation of Air Pilots is negotiating a new enterprise deal to replace the 2016 agreement, which expired in 2020. The pilots have rejected three previous deals, including a 25% pay increase offer. The strike will halt work at these Qantas units, with no immediate comment from the airline.

site_title: Bob Tan to retire as chairman of CapitaLand Ascott Trust’s boards
summary: Bob Tan, chairman of CapitaLand Ascott Trust's boards, is retiring effective April 22, 2024, as part of the stapled group's board renewal process. Lui Chong Chee will replace him as board chairman and chairman of the nominating and remuneration committees. Tan's tenure began in 2016 and includes leading the group through the COVID-19 pandemic and overseeing the entry into the student accommodation sector.

site_title: Hot stock: CDL rises 3.7% on share buyback exercise
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) rose 3.7% to S$5.96 after announcing a share buyback exercise for its ordinary shares. The property developer bought back 954,000 shares at an average price of S$5.75. The share buyback is attributed to CDL's discounted share value. The company's shares were the fifth most actively traded in terms of value, with 2.6 million shares changing hands.

site_title: Investors push Zara owner Inditex to publish full supply chain
summary: Investors are pushing Inditex, the parent company of Zara, to publish its full supplier list, citing concerns over supply chain risks and labor practices. Inditex has declined to comment on the demands, making it an outlier among major clothing retailers that have followed rivals H&M and Primark in disclosing their supplier lists. The move comes as regulators and investors seek greater transparency and better disclosure from companies to ensure fair labor practices and prevent forced labor in supply chains.

images.alt_text: The restart of Zara’s operations comes as Venezuelans’ purchasing slowly recovers after widespread dollarisation tamed inflation.
Inditex reports a net profit of 4.1 billion euros (S$5.9 billion) for the nine-month period to end-October, up 32.5 per cent from a year earlier.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks close with big gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index jumping 1.43% to 16,587.57, driven by data showing Chinese inflation increased last month, a rare positive sign for the struggling economy. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also rose, with the Shanghai Composite Index increasing 0.74% and the Shenzhen Composite Index adding 2.12%. The gains were attributed to improved economic data, despite concerns over global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Don’t believe what you see in the age of AI ads
summary: Generative artificial intelligence (AI) has raised concerns in the advertising industry, as companies use AI tools to create unrealistic and fabricated images of food, products, and even people. Influencers and celebrities have been cloned to endorse products without their permission, with some reports of deepfakes being used to promote everything from candy to self-help courses. To combat this issue, regulators are reviewing the use of AI in advertising and considering guidelines to prevent exaggeration and fabrication. Consumers are advised to be more skeptical of ads and look for disclaimers to identify AI-generated content.

site_title: Frasers Property to redeem S$600 million perpetual securities
summary: Frasers Property's unit FPT is redeeming S$600 million fixed-rate subordinated perpetual securities at a redemption price of S$250,000 per S$250,000 nominal amount, plus accrued distribution. The securities were issued in two tranches in 2019 under the group's S$5 billion multicurrency debt programme. The redemption is set for April 11, after which the securities will be cancelled and delisted from the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei

site_title: India’s top court orders SBI bank to share political donors’ names by Tuesday
summary: India's top court orders State Bank of India (SBI) to share names of individuals and companies that donated billions to political parties by Tuesday, after rejecting a plea for more time. The court scrapped a seven-year-old election funding system allowing unlimited and anonymous donations in February, calling it "unconstitutional." SBI had asked for until June 30 to compile and match information involving 22,217 donations, but the court told it to share the information by Tuesday, with the Election Commission of India to publish the details by March 15.

images.alt_text: Modi has made high growth and infrastructure development his key poll plank in his last two tenures and has promised to make India a developed country by 2047.

site_title: Fullerton Health ex-director to plead not guilty as corruption case against co-founders moves to trial
summary: Former Fullerton Health director Daniel Chan will plead not guilty to 13 corruption charges related to nearly half a million dollars in entertainment claims and falsifying accounts to defraud the company. The charges are linked to bribes and gratification given to Aon Risk Solutions' former CEO Collin Chiew. Chan faces four charges, while the other nine will be dropped. His co-accused, David Sin and Michael Tan, also face similar charges and have pre-trial conferences scheduled. The case is set to proceed to trial on April 8.

site_title: Saudi wealth fund eyes US$20 billion windfall from Aramco dividend
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) is set to earn a US$20 billion annual payout from its 16% stake in Aramco, following Crown Prince Mohammed Salman's transfer of an 8% stake to the PIF. The dividend hike is part of a US$124 billion payout this year, and the PIF's assets now total around US$900 billion. The fund aims to spend US$40 billion annually domestically to diversify the economy, with plans to increase spending to US$70 billion by 2025.

site_title: Malaysia wealth fund’s assets, profits jump amid recovery
summary: Malaysia's sovereign wealth fund, Khazanah, reported a 4% increase in net asset value (NAV) to RM84.8 billion in 2023, driven by a tripling of profits to RM5.9 billion. The fund's recovery is attributed to improving market conditions, with higher dividends and fair value gains contributing to the jump. Khazanah plans to focus on domestic investments, particularly in connectivity, energy transition, and digitalization, to capitalize on Malaysia's economic growth.

site_title: Japan’s business lobby head sees near-term chance of BOJ policy shift
summary: Japan's business lobby head, Masakazu Tokura, expects the Bank of Japan to normalize its ultra-loose monetary policy in the near future due to heightened momentum for wage hikes. He believes pay increases will spread to smaller firms and that Japan will achieve the 2% inflation target. Tokura sees a high chance of policy normalization, but is uncertain about the timing, possibly in March. This shift could indicate a potential shift away from the BOJ's current expansionary stance.

site_title: London property market faces hit as UK ends tax haven advantage for super-rich foreigners
summary: The UK has abolished the "non-domicile" tax status for ultra-wealthy foreign residents, expected to boost the government's coffers by £9 billion and help pay for a two-pence cut in national insurance. The move is set to impact the London property market, with real estate agents warning of an exodus of overseas investors and a potential hit to the city's international allure. The UK Treasury's reforms aim to modernise and simplify the tax system, but experts fear the aggressive implementation could chase former non-doms out of the country, further weakening London's prime property market.

site_title: Australian shares skid off record high as banks, miners drag down benchmark
summary: Australian shares fell 1.8% on Monday, slipping off the all-time peak closing of 7,847.00 on Friday, as mining and banking stocks dragged down the benchmark. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 7,704.200, its worst day since early July last year. Heavyweight mining stocks, including BHP Group, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue, declined 2.7-3.5% due to weak iron ore prices. Investors await the Reserve Bank of Australia's monetary policy meeting next week, where a rate cut is expected.

site_title: Australia’s top banker renews warning on Apple’s payments power
summary: Australia's Commonwealth Bank CEO Matt Comyn reiterated his warning on Apple's dominance in the nation's payments market, calling for increased scrutiny. Comyn says Apple should be held accountable for limiting access to its near-field communication chip, giving banks limited control over wallet apps. He also expressed his stance on hybrid work, stating it's here to stay. Comyn's comments reignite a years-long dispute over competition in the payments market, with the US tech giant not giving banks access to the chip for Apple Pay.

site_title: Vopak, Air Liquide partner to study ammonia-to-hydrogen infrastructure on Jurong Island
summary: Vopak and Air Liquide have signed a memorandum of understanding to study and develop low-carbon ammonia supply chains in Singapore, with a focus on producing and distributing hydrogen on Jurong Island. The partnership aims to support Singapore's national hydrogen strategy, which aims to supply up to half of the city-state's power needs with hydrogen by 2050. Vopak, which owns Singapore's only ammonia tank, will explore the development of ammonia cracking facilities and associated infrastructure to produce low-carbon hydrogen.

site_title: New 'Kung Fu Panda' kicks all comers to top North America box office
summary: Kung Fu Panda 4 opened at the top of the North American box office, earning an estimated US$58.3 million for the Friday-through-Sunday period. The film's strong performance pushed it into an "elite" group alongside Toy Story and Despicable Me. Meanwhile, Dune: Part Two continued its successful run, earning US$46 million and surpassing the US$150 million mark domestically. The domestic box office saw a three percent decrease from a pre-pandemic average, with other films such as C Abrini and Bob Marley: One Love rounding out the top 10.

images.alt_text: Denis Villeneuve’s epic sequel to the original Dune - based on Frank Herbert’s 1965 novel about war and survival on the deeply inhospitable desert planet of Arrakis - raked in US$81.5 million over the weekend.

site_title: Surbana Jurong to spend S$300 million over next three years on strategic acquisitions
summary: Surbana Jurong, a Singapore-based consultancy, plans to spend S$300 million over three years on strategic acquisitions to drive revenue growth. Group CEO Sean Chiao aims to more than double revenue by 2026, focusing on sustainability, energy transition, and digital innovations. The company plans to expand its presence outside of Asia and Australia, increasing its global footprint. Key growth sectors include energy, infrastructure, and smart city facility management, with a focus on leveraging digital innovations and artificial intelligence.

site_title: No Signboard to hold dialogue session with Sias on Mar 13
summary: No Signboard Holdings, a restaurant operator, will hold a dialogue session with the Securities Investors Association (Sias) on March 13. The session, moderated by Sias founder David Gerald, aims to address concerns following a notice from its largest shareholder GuGong alleging interim CEO Lim Teck-Ean breached fiduciary duties. Shares of No Signboard have been suspended from trading since January 2022 due to the company's inability to demonstrate it can continue as a going concern.

summary: China's State Council has coordinated support efforts for embattled property firm China Vanke, requesting financial institutions to make swift progress in financing the company. Authorities have asked creditors to consider private debt maturity extension and have called on banks to guarantee the repayments of public bonds. This rare intervention aims to stabilize the real estate sector, which is experiencing a debt crisis, and prevent a potential market downturn.

site_title: Singapore business confidence hits one-year high in Q2 2024: SCCB
summary: Singapore business confidence reached a one-year high in Q2 2024, with the Business Optimism Index rising to +4.82 percentage points, up from +4.48 percentage points in Q1 2024 and +4.60 percentage points in Q2 2023. Indicators for sales volume, net profit, and new orders remained expansionary, while inventory levels fell further. However, selling price and employment levels moderated. The construction and transportation sectors were the most optimistic, with three indicators in positive territory, while the wholesale sector remained weak.

The film will be produced by Chris Meledandri and Shigeru Miyamoto, and written by Matthew Fogel. The success of the previous film, "The Super Mario Bros. Movie," which grossed $1.36 billion at the box office, has helped boost sales of Mario games and lifted Nintendo's profit forecasts.

site_title: Japan’s economy avoids recession one week before BOJ meeting
summary: Japan's economy avoided a technical recession, expanding at an annualized pace of 0.4% in Q4 2023, driven by strong corporate capital investment and upward revisions to capital investment figures. Economists expect the BOJ to end its negative interest rate policy this month or next, with a majority predicting a rate hike in March or April. Annual pay negotiations between companies and labor unions will culminate on March 15, with unions demanding a 5.85% pay hike.

summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.1% to 3,144.61, with losers outnumbering gainers 54 to 36. The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 2.48 points in morning trading, with Geo Energy Resources rising 4.1% and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding gaining 0.5%. The decline follows a mixed global market, with US indices closing lower on Friday.

site_title: Two River Valley sites offered for sale, to yield up to 960 units near Great World City
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched two plots of land in River Valley Green for sale, offering up to 960 residential units near Great World City. The smaller plot, Parcel A, can yield 380 units and the larger plot, Parcel B, can provide 580 units, including 220 serviced apartments. Analysts expect strong interest in Parcel A due to its prime location and smaller size, with estimated bids ranging from S$1,380 to S$1,600 per square foot per plot ratio. The tenders for both plots will close on June 19 and April, respectively.

site_title:
Share of funding for women-led startups rises, 
but challenges for equality remain
summary: Women-led startups in South-east Asia received 18.3% of private capital raised in 2023, with companies featuring all-female founding teams securing 6.6% of funding. Despite progress, challenges for equality remain, with uneven development across markets and limited support for women entrepreneurs. Vietnam led the way, with 53% of funding going to female-founded startups, followed by the Philippines, Malaysia, and Singapore. Experts call for more structured mentoring programs, tax deduction schemes, and dedicated gender-focused funds to spur female entrepreneurship.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
There are still lots of areas where more support is needed to encourage greater gender equity, including when it comes to connections.

site_title: Indonesia’s new capital city Nusantara progressing well as efforts to attract foreign investment continue
summary: Indonesia's new capital city, Nusantara, is progressing well, with the first phase nearing completion. The project, estimated to cost $40 billion, is expected to be fully complete in 2045. Singapore investors have expressed the most interest, followed by those from Japan and China. The government aims to attract over $100 trillion in private investment this year, with a focus on green projects such as renewable energy and electric vehicles. The project is backed by constitutional law, ensuring continuity despite potential changes in government.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
The Jakarta Composite index last traded 1.7 per cent higher after earlier hitting an over one-month peak, and was inching toward the record high of 7,403.578 points hit in January.

site_title: Sembcorp bags 440 MW wind-solar power project in India
summary: Sembcorp Industries has been awarded a 440 MW wind-solar hybrid power project in India by state-owned power producer SJVN. The project will be built, owned, and operated by Sembcorp's renewables subsidiary, with power to be sold under a 25-year agreement. The project is expected to be commercially ready within 24 months and will increase Sembcorp's gross renewables capacity to 14.3 GW. The project is considered ordinary business and is expected to have no material impact on earnings.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Oppenheimer wins seven Oscars including best picture, director
summary: Oppenheimer won seven Academy Awards, including Best Picture and Best Director for Christopher Nolan, at the 96th Academy Awards. Cillian Murphy won Best Actor for his portrayal of J. Robert Oppenheimer, while Emma Stone won Best Actress for her role in Poor Things. The film also won awards for film editing, cinematography, and score. The ceremony was marked by a heavy police presence outside the Dolby Theatre due to protests. Oppenheimer dominated the nominations, with 13, and was favored to win Best Picture, with gamblers needing to wager $5,000 to win $100.

images.alt_text: Christopher Nolan’s drama about the father of the atomic bomb, half of last summer’s massive “Barbenheimer” phenomenon, is the firm favourite to win the prize for best picture and much more.

site_title: Indonesia investigates how two pilots dozed off during Batik Air flight
summary: Indonesia's aviation authority is investigating how two pilots on a Batik Air flight dozed off during a three-hour journey from Kendari to Jakarta, causing the plane to veer off course. The incident occurred on January 25, when the captain took a nap while the co-pilot manned the flight. The National Transportation Safety Committee released a preliminary report, which will be reviewed to determine the cause of the incident and ensure airlines operate safely during night flights.

The airline is still waiting to learn how much it must pay after losing a separate lawsuit accusing it of illegally firing 1700 ground staff in 2020.

US Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg says air travel is the safest mode of US travel but “keeping it that way is going to require Boeing to step up and the FAA to keep Boeing under a microscope, including limiting how many aircraft they can produce in a month until they can do it safely.”

site_title: China reiterates stance that homes are not for speculation
summary: China's Housing and Urban-Rural Development Minister Ni Hong reiterated the government's stance that homes are for residents to live in, not for speculation, amid a property crisis. The clarification came after Premier Li Qiang's government work report draft omitted the slogan "housing is for living in, not speculation." Ni acknowledged the current difficulty in capital and proposed reforms, including treating real estate companies equally, pushing for the sales of completed homes, and building government-subsidized housing. The government aims to foster a new development model for real estate, in line with President Xi Jinping's "common prosperity" mantra.

images.alt_text: The real estate crisis in mainland China has made Hong Kong’s residential market seem like a safer bet, adding to its dramatic rebound.

site_title: Israel’s Netanyahu rejects Biden critique of war policy
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu rejected US President Joe Biden's criticism of Israel's war policy in Gaza, saying he's pursuing policies supported by the majority of Israelis. Netanyahu disputed the death toll issued by Gaza's health ministry, claiming it includes 13,000 militant fighters. The war has killed at least 31,045 people in Gaza, mostly women and children, according to Gaza's health ministry, which Netanyahu disputed. Netanyahu's comments come amid growing frustration with his leadership, including calls for early elections and criticism of his handling of hostages held by Hamas.

site_title: Tom Jones marks another era on stage
summary: Tom Jones, 83, performed his "Ages and Stages" tour in Singapore, featuring a 20-song setlist that spanned his 6-decade music career, including new material from his 2021 album "Surrounded By Time." The show included classic hits like "She's A Lady" and "You're My World," as well as lesser-known tracks. Jones successfully mixed old and new material to keep the crowd engaged, showcasing his signature baritone and showmanship. The performance marked a new era in his career, one that balances nostalgia with reinvention and confronts his own mortality.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Australia to end ‘nuisance’ tariffs on toothbrushes, bumper cars
summary: Australia's government will abolish nearly 500 "nuisance" tariffs on consumer goods, including toothbrushes, bumper cars, and feminine sanitary products, starting July 1. This move is expected to save companies over A$30 million in compliance costs annually and streamline US$8.5 billion in trade. The tariff reforms, the largest in two decades, aim to reduce red tape, boost productivity, and ease the burden on businesses.

site_title: Stars head to Oscars with ‘Oppenheimer’ poised for glory
summary: Hollywood stars are set to attend the Oscars, with Christopher Nolan's drama "Oppenheimer" favored to win Best Picture and several other categories. The film's director, cast, and technical crew are expected to take home awards, including Best Director, Supporting Actor for Robert Downey Jr., and technical prizes. "Oppenheimer" is also in the running for Best Actor for Cillian Murphy and Best Adapted Screenplay. The competition for Best Actress is tight, with Emma Stone and Lily Gladstone vying for the top spot. The ceremony, hosted by Jimmy Kimmel, is expected to be a star-studded event.

images.alt_text: 'Dragon Ball', created by Akira Toriyama seen here in a 1982 file photo, is one of the best-selling and most influential manga titles of all time.
Dune: Part Two is a political sci-fi tale that holds a mirror to our current world.

Singapore cinemas, operating under the Golden Village brand, accounted for nearly half of Orange Sky Golden Harvest’s revenue of HK$396 million (S$68 million) in the first half of 2023, as stated in its latest financial report.
17Live’s listing is the first de-Spac transaction completed in Singapore.

Denis Villeneuve’s epic sequel to the original Dune - based on Frank Herbert’s 1965 novel about war and survival on the deeply inhospitable desert planet of Arrakis - raked in US$81.5 million over the weekend.
Mattel, which saw a Warner Bros Discovery film tied to its Barbie doll line become the biggest motion picture of 2023, says it expects the toy industry to decline in 2024.

site_title: Japan boosts reliance on allies Australia, US for long-term LNG supplies
summary: Japan is increasing its reliance on long-term liquefied natural gas (LNG) supplies from allies Australia and the US, amid concerns over Russian LNG supplies set to expire in the early 2030s. Japan's biggest power generator JERA has agreed to buy a stake in Woodside Energy's Scarborough project in Australia. The country has secured 10- to 20-year offtake contracts from these countries for over 5 million metric tons annually, exceeding transactions elsewhere in the world. Despite US and Australian political issues, Japan's appetite for long-term supplies remains strong, driven by its energy security concerns triggered by Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

images.alt_text: Both production and new orders, the two main subindexes of Japan's PMI, declined at the fastest pace in a year. Respondents cited factors such as weak sales demand at home and overseas as well as production delays due to machinery shutdowns.
A breach of its 1989 peak by the Mini Topix Futures contract is likely to have a huge psychological impact on investors that could take it even higher.

site_title: Canadian property investor with C$2.5 billion prowls in ‘mispriced’ market
summary: Canadian private equity executive Rob Kumer is seeking to deploy $2.5 billion in fresh investor capital, believing the market has mispriced commercial properties such as office buildings and malls. Despite global financial markets' turmoil, Kumer expects these assets to maintain healthy income and points to his firm's trophy assets, including Scotia Plaza and Saskatoon's Midtown mall, as examples. He believes Canada's more conservative leverage and recourse loans will limit losses for lenders, driving a more stable market. Kumer is bullish on these properties, seeing them as opportunities for long-term cash flow.

images.alt_text: New York mall owner tries to hang on with debt storm swirling

site_title: The world has too much wine, and farmers are ripping up vines
summary: Wine production is experiencing a global glut due to falling demand, with many winemakers forced to abandon their vineyards. Australian farmers like Tony Townsend are destroying their vines, citing economic viability concerns, while others are replacing them with alternative crops. The industry faces long-term challenges, including changing drinking habits, increased input costs, and secular shifts in consumption patterns. Global production has hit a 60-year low, and some countries, like France, are experiencing an oversupply of wine, with demand lagging production since 1995.

images.alt_text: Australia sent wine worth almost US$800 million to China in the year to November 2020.

site_title: Vietnam’s bid for emerging-market upgrade faces reality check
summary: Vietnam's bid for an emerging-market upgrade is facing a reality check due to its demand for upfront funding by equity investors. The country aims to join the FTSE Advanced Emerging and Secondary Emerging universe by 2025, but its stock market is hindered by a requirement for fully-funded accounts and a cap on foreign holdings. Despite its fast-growing economy and stable macro-economic indicators, foreign investors are balking at the need for these conditions to be met. The FTSE review is scheduled for March 27, but the outcome is uncertain, with some analysts predicting that an upgrade may not be all it's cracked up to be.

images.alt_text: The bourse, the smallest among the main South-east Asian economies, is now classified by both the MSCI and FTSE indices as a frontier market.
The three banks have proposed to help finance the accelerated closing of the Cirebon-1 coal-fired power station in West Java.
A trader counts Indian rupee notes in Mumbai. The currency has remained largely stable against the US dollar over the past year, trading at around 83 rupees to the greenback.
Fewer qualifying buyers upgrading from HDB public flats is a factor that may dampen Singapore home prices this year.

site_title: Sustainable transition is an important journey, but we must get to our destination
summary: A growing focus on sustainable transition investments aims to address the climate crisis, but its effectiveness is uncertain. Current approaches prioritize environmental performance and financial returns, yet have not led to significant sustainable development or reduced carbon emissions. The European Commission defines transition as moving towards a climate-resilient economy, while taxonomies in Asia include similar definitions. However, the lack of a standardised definition in finance has led to dilemmas, such as whether a sustainable investment can be a transition investment. Fund managers must develop guiding principles for transition strategies, balancing sustainability objectives with risk and returns, and measuring progress at the company level.

images.alt_text: DBS chief sustainability officer Helge Muenkel speaks during a media briefing on the DBS sustainability report, on March 5, 2024.

site_title: Ruses, risks and real threats for 2024
summary: Ken Fisher, founder of Fisher Investments, shares his 2024 investment outlook, focusing on real risks that markets may not be pricing in. He notes that geopolitical tensions, such as Ukraine and Middle East conflicts, are economically small and pre-priced. However, risks from the nuclear-armed triangle of China, India, and Pakistan remain under the radar. Fisher also highlights concerns about regulatory risks, including a potential "silent" credit freeze and the impact of rising deposit rates on net interest income. Despite these concerns, he remains bullish on 2024, emphasizing the need to focus on potential new, undiscussed events rather than widely watched fears.

images.alt_text: Singapore's aging population can be a boon for its stock market.
Corporate travel spending is accelerating and should exceed pre-Covid levels in 2024

Pedestrians walk past Arturo Di Modica's 'The Bund Financial Bull' sculpture on the Bund at night in Shanghai, China, on Tuesday, Oct. 22, 2013. site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The global shipping market experienced a mixed week, with various sectors showing different trends. The Capesize market saw a decline, with the 5TC index falling to $5,939, its lowest level since late February 2023. The Panamax market also declined, with steady declines in rates across the North Atlantic basin. In contrast, the Ultramax/Supramax sector showed a buoyant week, with renewed interest pushing demand up and rates gaining ground. The Handysize market performed mixed, with stability in the Continent and Mediterranean regions, but minimal action in the US Gulf.

images.alt_text: A roundup of the week’s tanker and dry bulk market (Feb 7, 2025).

site_title: Saudi Aramco boosts dividend despite drop in 2023 profit
summary: Saudi Aramco increased its dividend to $20.3 billion for the fourth quarter, a 4% boost from the previous quarter, despite a 24.7% drop in net profit to $121.3 billion. The company's capital investments reached $49.7 billion in 2023, and it forecasts $48-58 billion for this year. Aramco aims to sustain capex, base dividend, and growth capex, with plans to increase gas production by 60% by 2030.

images.alt_text: Signage above the Saudi Aramco booth on day two of the Abu Dhabi International Petroleum Exhibition and Conference (ADIPEC) in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates, on Tuesday, Oct. 3, 2023. site_title: Race to become Asia’s top entertainment hub; Thai PM Srettha seeks closer ties with EU
summary: Southeast Asian countries are vying to become Asia's top entertainment hub, with Singapore stepping up its investments in infrastructure. Thai PM Srettha Thavisin seeks closer ties with the EU during a seven-day visit, aiming to push for a free trade agreement and attract investors for Thailand's 1 trillion baht land bridge project. Indonesia is expected to be a top performer in 2024, with a 8% economic growth target by 2045, and Prabowo Subianto's ambitious plan may boost the country's growth prospects.

images.alt_text: Zhao Yifan
US pop music sensation Taylor Swift kicks off the Asia-Pacific leg of her "Eras" world tour in Japan. Singapore will be her only stop in South-east Asia.
A helicopter flies over Indonesia's capital Jakarta. The nation’s housing market is expected to remain strong for the rest of 2024.
Defence Minister Prabowo Subianto celebrates on stage as unofficial vote counts show that he is poised to become Indonesia's next president.
Delegates convened at the fourth Asean Digital Senior Officials Meeting in Singapore on Jan 30 in preparation for the Feb 1-2 Asean Digital Ministers Meeting.
A man walks past the entrance of Bank Negara Malaysia in Kuala Lumpur. The country’s central bank maintained its overnight policy rate at 3 per cent in January.

site_title: Westports in RM39.6 billion expansion to tap Port Klang’s bullish prospects
summary: Westports Holdings, a Malaysia-listed port operator, plans to expand its container handling capacity by 50% to 28 million 20-foot-equivalent unit containers a year over the next two to four decades. The RM39.6 billion expansion will be funded through internally generated funds and borrowings, with a focus on maintaining its dividend payout ratio. The company is open to strategic investor funding, but believes it would dilute existing shareholders' equity. Westports aims to achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2050 through sustainability measures and technologies, and is working to automate and digitalize its operations.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
The port is the second-biggest in South-east Asia and its plan will see capacity increase to 27 million twenty-foot equivalent units, from 14 million currently.

site_title: Signa Prime set to present repayment plan in bid to avert liquidation
summary: Signa Prime, a luxury property unit of the insolvent Signa conglomerate, is set to unveil a repayment plan to creditors on Monday. The plan aims to stabilize the firm and repay at least 30% of claims within two years, meeting Austria's legal requirement for self-administration. A majority vote by creditors is necessary to avoid losing management rights and liquidation. The plan follows months of efforts by the insolvency administrator to untangle debt and guarantees. The leadership's success in adopting the plan will determine the company's future.

site_title: Director filings and buybacks continue at stronger pace
summary: Institutional investors sold Singapore stocks by S$224 million, while 26 companies conducted buybacks totaling S$24.4 million. Digital Core Reit Management and ESR-Logos Funds Management acquired units of their respective reits. Notable director filings include Wilmar International chairman Kuok Khoon Hong increasing his stake, Raffles Medical Group executive chairman Loo Choon Yong acquiring shares, and Centurion Corporation's CEO Kong Chee Min acquiring shares.

images.alt_text: Digital Core Reit’s data centre in Northern Virginia. Under the equity fundraising scenario, the proposed transactions will expand the Reit’s geographical presence to 6 cities – up from 4 currently.

site_title: Singapore marks catastrophe bond milestone amid record issuance and returns
summary: Singapore has achieved a milestone in catastrophe bond issuance, with nearly US$1 billion of renewals expected to launch and list on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) over the next few weeks. This marks the maturity and sustainability of Singapore as a hub for insurance-linked securities (ILS) origination. The renewals are significant, signaling the growth of the ILS market in Asia, with Singapore capturing around 33% of Asian risk volume. The milestone comes as the global ILS market grew by 20% to US$43.1 billion in 2023, with stellar returns for investors in cat bonds, which carry little or no correlation to stocks and bonds.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua
Rising cyber risks are raising the cost of traditional cyber protection. Issuers of catastrophe bonds are seizing the moment to offer cat bonds linked to cyber risks.
Achim Kassow, member of the board of management of Munich Re
Bold bets on catastrophe bonds and other insurance-linked securities have led firms to record-high returns.

site_title: Designing an office worth going back to
summary: Australian research suggests that designing flexible office spaces can boost productivity and effectiveness. An experimental work floor created by Mirvac in Sydney found that allowing employees to choose and use different spaces maximized collaboration and team connectivity. The key to success lies in prioritizing user experience, fine-tuning work spaces to support user needs, and designing for health and well-being. Connection to place is also crucial, as the physical workplace is tied to employees' sense of safety, belonging, and ritual. Trust among employees is essential, and leaders should empower employees' working styles and provide structural support for relationships to flourish.

images.alt_text: Women place a higher average value on working from home than men do in all but a few countries, according to Stanford University economics professor Nicholas Bloom.

site_title: Japan’s Topix expected to continue trending higher
summary: Japan's Mini Tokyo Price Index (Topix) Futures contract has continued to outperform its global counterparts, rising 15.22% year-to-date. Despite being below its 1989 peak, the contract is expected to breach the all-time high of 2,886, driven by structural factors such as a depreciating yen, rising corporate profits, and corporate governance reforms. Analysts predict the contract will hit 138.2% extension level at around 2,950-2,955 by the end of 2024, with a potential broadening of the rally that could push the Topix above its all-time high.

images.alt_text: An electronic board displays a share price of the Nikkei index of the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Tokyo on March 4, 2024. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)
Japanese government support should benefit employment and the local economy.

site_title: The future of work: Why we need to think beyond the hype of the four-day week
summary: The four-day week has resurfaced as a potential solution to improve work-life balance and boost productivity, following the COVID-19 pandemic. Countries like New Zealand, Japan, and several Asian nations are exploring ways to implement a four-day week, with varying approaches. Some propose a reduced 32-hour workweek, while others advocate for a compressed week with the same number of hours. However, experts argue that reorganizing working hours alone may not be enough to re-engage workers, and that a fundamental shift in the nature of work is needed to address issues of meaning, motivation, and personal fulfillment.

images.alt_text: Tripartite guidelines on flexible work arrangements are set to be released by the government later this year but the prevalence of such arrangements has decreased in Singapore, statistics show.

site_title: Pound is beating 92% of global currencies on UK economic rebound
summary: The British pound has surpassed 92% of global currencies in 2024, reaching its highest level in seven months, with a week-high of US$1.29 against the US dollar. Analysts attribute the pound's resilience to the UK's stronger-than-expected economic recovery and decreasing inflation. The Bank of England is expected to keep interest rates higher for longer, unlike the US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank, which are set to cut rates in June.

images.alt_text: The greenback is on pace for its worst weekly showing against the euro this year.

site_title: ESR Group divests ARA Private Funds business for US$270 million
summary: ESR Group has agreed to divest its ARA Private Funds (APF) business in Australia, Singapore, South Korea, and the US for US$270 million. The APF business, comprising finite-life funds with assets in traditional real estate sectors, is part of ESR's strategy to divest up to US$750 million of non-core businesses. The deal follows ESR's acquisition of ARA Asset Management for US$5.2 billion in 2022.

images.alt_text: ESR集团在日本的川崎浮岛配送中心（Kawasaki Ukishima Distribution Centre）。（ESR集团提供）

site_title: Big business is facing a big idea drought
summary: The management consulting industry, worth billions, has lost intellectual momentum and edge since the 1980s and 1990s, when innovative ideas and thinking dominated. Notable management gurus such as Michael Porter, Michael Hammer, and Gary Hamel created new approaches to business problems, but since the early 2000s, little new thinking has emerged, leaving the industry stagnant.

images.alt_text: While it is true that individuals “hold” symbolic positions of authority, for organisations to flourish, the distance between authority figures and those executing important work needs to be greatly reduced.

site_title: Making gender diversity a priority in the wealth management industry
summary: UBS Singapore's Country Head Young Jin Yee emphasizes the importance of gender diversity in the wealth management industry, citing McKinsey's estimate that women will inherit $30 trillion in assets by the end of the decade. Yee notes that diverse teams can better understand clients' diverse needs and make better decisions, driving innovation. UBS has been increasing women's representation in senior management and is committed to mobilizing private wealth for social impact. Yee believes that building a team culture that supports gender diversity is key to an organization's success and that leading by example is crucial.

images.alt_text: There are still lots of areas where more support is needed to encourage greater gender equity, including when it comes to connections.
Women increasingly enjoy the same opportunities as men in education and employment but there is still a gender gap, including in pay and promotions.

site_title: MAS waivers for Sabana, Sias rebuke of Great Eastern could be heartening signs for minorities
summary: Singapore's MAS waivers for Sabana and Sias rebuking Great Eastern's handling of minority shareholder rights may be encouraging signs for minority shareholders. This comes after Japan's Nikkei 225 breached 40,000 for the first time, following years of corporate governance reform efforts. The MAS's actions could encourage Singapore to emulate Japan and South Korea's approaches to unlocking value in companies. However, it also highlights the need to address controlling shareholders' attitudes, which have been a major concern in Singapore's local market.
