site_title: Japan's Nikkei posts first weekly drop in six on profit-taking, BOJ bets
summary: Japan's Nikkei index fell 0.6% for the week, marking its first drop in six weeks, due to profit-taking and rising bets on the Bank of Japan (BOJ) exiting its ultra-loose monetary policy. The benchmark rose to a record high earlier in the week, driven by corporate reforms and foreign inflows. Automobile firms declined on a strong yen, while banks rose 2.1% ahead of the BOJ's meeting on March 18-19.

images.alt_text: A screen displays the Nikkei 225 Stock Average figure on the trading floor at the Nomura Securities Co. headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Jan. 11, 2024. The Nikkei 225 rose 1.8% to the highest level in about 34 years on Thursday. Photographer: Nao Sano/Bloomberg

site_title: Tempers flare at Sabana EGM as unitholders vote for 8 of 10 resolutions on trustee’s handling of internalisation
summary: Sabana Industrial Reit's unitholders voted for nearly all 10 resolutions proposed by activist investor Quarz Capital Asia, directing the trustee HSBC Institutional Trust Services (Singapore) on the internalisation of the Reit. The resolutions aim to internalise the management function of the Reit, following a long-running attempt by Quarz Capital Asia. The move is seen as a significant step towards Quarz Capital Asia's goal of gaining control over the Reit.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
The Reit portfolio valuation for its 18 properties is up by 2.1 per cent on-year to S$903.9 million as at end-2023.
New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio.

site_title: Biden vows to raise taxes on wealthy, corporations in State of the Union address
summary: US President Joe Biden vowed to raise taxes on wealthy Americans and large companies in his State of the Union address, announcing plans to hike corporate minimum taxes and cut deductions for executive pay and corporate jets. The proposed fiscal 2025 budget aims to decrease the federal deficit by $3 trillion over 10 years while cutting taxes for low-income Americans and aiding middle-class homebuyers. Biden's tax plans contrast with Republican candidate Donald Trump's 2017 tax cuts, which slashed taxes on companies, the wealthy, and many middle-class Americans.

images.alt_text: The annual State of the Union address is a mainstay of the US political calendar, but the event has struggled to remain relevant in the social media age, especially among young people who largely tune out of traditional political coverage.

site_title: Asia: Markets join rally after Wall Street, European records
summary: Asian markets rose on Friday, tracking a record-breaking day in New York and Europe, amid optimism for US interest rate cuts this year. Expectations for a first rate cut in June increased after Federal Reserve boss Jerome Powell's comments, which suggested a more dovish tilt. Markets in Hong Kong, Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, and Taipei rose, with Singapore stocks notching a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. The rally was also driven by US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 hit an all-time high, closing 1.1 per cent higher, with the rate-sensitive technology sector climbing 2.3 per cent to a December 2000 peak.

site_title: TSMC’s sales gain 9.4% in first two months after AI boost
summary: TSMC, Asia's largest company, reported a 9.4% increase in sales to $12.6 billion for the first two months of 2024, driven by a surge in AI development. Despite Apple's struggling iPhone sales, particularly in China, TSMC's main chipmaker business is benefiting from the global AI growth, particularly with the rise of large language models. Analysts expect a recovery in smartphone and computing demand, and the company has raised its capital spending expectations. TSMC's revenue is also boosted by its second-largest customer, Advanced Micro Devices, which is gaining share in the AI chip market.

site_title: Your iPhone and EV were probably built on forced labour. Does this bother you?
summary: A US court has ruled that tech companies are not liable for the torture and death of enslaved cobalt miners in the Democratic Republic of Congo, clearing them of forced labor charges. Despite the ruling, the issue of child and forced labor in cobalt mining remains unresolved, with no clear estimate of the extent of the problem. The use of cobalt in lithium-ion batteries powering iPhones, laptops, and electric vehicles raises moral concerns, with companies relying on the mineral despite knowing the risks.

site_title: Former Fox chairman Rupert Murdoch, 92, gets engaged
summary: Former Fox and News Corp Chairman Rupert Murdoch, 92, has gotten engaged to his 67-year-old girlfriend, Elena Zhukova, a retired molecular biologist. The couple plans to hold their wedding at Murdoch's vineyard and estate in California. Murdoch stepped down from his role in September last year, ending a seven-decade career in the media industry.

site_title: Goldman Sachs expects US buybacks to top US$1 trillion in 2025
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts US share buybacks will reach US$1.08 trillion in 2025, a 16% increase from US$925 billion in 2024. Strong earnings growth from technology companies and easing financial conditions, driven by potential interest rate cuts, are driving this forecast. The bank attributes the growth primarily to megacap companies.

site_title: ‘Dragon Ball’ creator Akira Toriyama dies aged 68
summary: Akira Toriyama, the 68-year-old creator of the best-selling and influential manga title 'Dragon Ball', has died due to acute subdural hematoma. The news was announced by his production team, Bird Studio, on March 1st. Toriyama is remembered for his iconic creation, which has spawned numerous anime series, films, and video games, including the popular 'One Piece' manga franchise. Fellow manga creator Eiichiro Oda expressed sadness over Toriyama's passing, stating it was "too soon" and left "too big shoes to fill".

site_title: Japan’s household spending drop complicates BOJ rates messaging
summary: Japan's household spending declined 6.3% in January from a year earlier, the largest drop since February 2021, according to the Ministry of Internal Affairs. This is the 11th straight decline and steeper than economists' estimated 4.1% retreat. Spending on cars plummeted 30% due to a Daihatsu production halt. Despite this, some categories like education and clothing saw increases. The Bank of Japan may consider ending negative interest rates in March, but a rate hike in April is still possible.

summary: The European Commission has launched a probe into dating app Tinder after a 2022 Swedish study found the app applied 36 different price levels, charging some users as little as $3/month and others up to $36/month. The Commission states that personalizing discounts without informing consumers is unfair and hinders them from making an informed choice. Tinder has promised to explain the fee discrepancies to EU users.

The subpoenas, signed by the US attorney's Manhattan office, seek information on goods and cash transfers between company segments, below-cost sales to the Nutrition division, and communications related to accounting issues. site_title: Banks drive Australian shares to record high on firming rate-cut bets
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index reached a record high, closing at 7,847.00, a 1.1% gain. Interest rate-sensitive financial stocks drove the rally, with the "big four" banks and Commonwealth Bank of Australia experiencing significant gains. The expectation of potential US rate cuts, as hinted by the Federal Reserve, fueled the market's optimism. The benchmark touched its all-time high for the second time this week.

summary: US stocks closed at new records, with the S&P 500 up 1.0% and the Nasdaq soaring 1.5%, driven by tech stocks including Nvidia. Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell signaled interest rate cuts ahead, saying the economy is on the right track and the Fed "can and will" begin cutting rates this year if necessary. This sparked optimism in the market, with individual companies like Nvidia and Intel also rising.

site_title: Terra’s Do Kwon to be extradited to South Korea instead of US, Montenegro court rules
summary: A Montenegrin High Court has ruled that former cryptocurrency mogul Do Kwon should be extradited to South Korea rather than the US for prosecution over the $40 billion collapse of the TerraUSD stablecoin in 2022. This decision is a win for Kwon, as penalties for white-collar crimes are lower in South Korea. The ruling overturns a previous decision to extradite Kwon to the US, where he faces fraud charges. The US may still try to have Kwon extradited, but South Korea could potentially reach a deal to try him first, given its ability to seize Kwon's assets worldwide.

site_title: Hong Kong buyers rush to snap up homes after curbs removed
summary: Hong Kong's residential market has seen a dramatic rebound in sales after the government removed all extra property levies, with buyers rushing to snap up homes. Sales surged 10 times in the first five days following the policy change, with Henderson Land Development's Belgravia Place project selling almost 200 apartments in just a few hours. The city's secondary home market is also experiencing a recovery, with the number of transactions in the 10 biggest estates rising to the highest in 61 weeks. Analysts, however, are less optimistic about home price rebounds due to high interest rates and abundant supply.

site_title: OCBC to launch programme to accelerate growth of women-owned SMEs
summary: OCBC Bank is launching a new SME programme to accelerate the growth of women-owned businesses in Singapore, aiming to increase their representation in the economy. The OCBC Women Entrepreneurs Programme will provide financing of up to S$100,000 to women-founded startups, with a focus on traditionally male-dominated industries. The programme also aims to build support networks through educational workshops and mentorship opportunities, addressing the challenges faced by women entrepreneurs in accessing funding and support.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 jumps 1% after ECB rate decision; Novo Nordisk hits record high
summary: The European Stoxx 600 reached an all-time high, closing 1.1% higher, following the European Central Bank's decision to keep interest rates steady. The decision was seen as a sign of cooling inflation and was accompanied by a tweak in the ECB's messaging, indicating a potential rate cut as early as April. The tech sector led the gains, with Novo Nordisk's experimental obesity drug showing promising trial data, and Euro area bond yields falling.

images.alt_text: The broad-based S&P 500 closed up 1.0 per cent to hit a new record of 5,157.36, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq soared by 1.5 per cent to a fresh high of 16,273.38 on Thursday.

site_title: Revitalised Japanese stock market fuels investor optimism
summary: Japan's stock market has seen a surge in optimism due to government support, corporate earnings, and inflation, despite the country's fall in world rankings. The Nikkei 225 broke its highest level since 1989, with the FTSE Japan RIC Capped Index up 5.8% year-to-date. Economists predict higher wage hikes in 2024, which could benefit employment and the local economy. Foreign investors are also flocking to Japan, drawn by the country's growing corporate profits and diversification.

images.alt_text: BOJ governor Kazuo Ueda says the likelihood of achieving the bank’s inflation target was gradually rising.

site_title: Nominations now open for EY Entrepreneur of the Year awards 2024
summary: Nominations are now open for the EY Entrepreneur of the Year awards 2024 in Singapore, with the public and business community invited to nominate entrepreneurs until April 5. The annual awards, now in their 23rd year, recognize innovative and passionate entrepreneurs across four criteria: entrepreneurial spirit, growth, purpose and impact. The winner will represent Singapore at the EY World Entrepreneur Of The Year award next year, with a theme of "The Art of Entrepreneurship" this year.

images.alt_text: Celebrating the wins are (from left): Liew Nam Soon, EY Asean regional managing partner and Singapore and Brunei managing partner, EY; Yvon Bock, founder and CEO, Hegen; and Tan See Leng, Minister for Manpower and Second Minister for Trade and Industry.

Clockwise from top left: Phyllis Ong, group CEO of Armstrong Industrial; Althea Lim, co-founder and group CEO of Gushcloud International; Olive Tai, co-founder and managing director Synagie Group Asia and Europe; and Yvon Bock, founder and CEO of Hegen.

site_title: Singapore shares edge up at Friday’s open; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.5% to 3,148.31 on Friday, March 8, following overnight gains on global markets amid rate cut hopes. Banking stocks led the gain, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC up 0.3%, 0.2%, and 0.1% respectively. Global markets, including the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, closed higher, driven by tech stocks and the European Central Bank's rate decision.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei

site_title: Sweden finally joins Nato, ending non-alignment, in Ukraine war shadow
summary: Sweden officially joined NATO on March 7, 2024, becoming the 32nd member of the alliance, following a two-year diplomatic process. The move marks a significant shift for Sweden, which had maintained non-alignment for over 200 years. The accession is seen as a victory for freedom and a natural step for Sweden, with US Secretary of State Antony Blinken calling it a "strategic debacle" for Russia. Sweden's membership is expected to be formalized with the hoisting of its flag at the NATO headquarters in Brussels on Monday.

images.alt_text: Statistics from SBAB’s property listings site Booli published on Sunday (Mar 3) show that house prices rose 1.2 per cent in February, yet were little changed when adjusting for seasonal effects.
The Hungarian parliament ratifies Sweden's membership of Nato, the final step for the Nordic country keen to join the Atlantic Alliance since the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: New Bill gives MAS wider investigative, supervisory powers over financial services sector
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) has gained wider investigative and supervisory powers over the financial sector with the passage of a new bill. The bill expands provisions allowing MAS to enter premises without a warrant, issue legally binding directions to financial institutions, and approve appointments of key personnel. It also strengthens MAS' capabilities in gathering evidence and allows for the transfer of evidence between MAS, the police, and other law enforcement agencies. The changes aim to enhance MAS' ability to enforce its regulatory regime and supervise capital markets financial institutions, further strengthening Singapore's position as a safe and trusted international financial centre.

images.alt_text: Simulations by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) have showed that even if the nominal exchange rate had not been raised, the Singapore dollar would still have appreciated similarly in real terms, chief economist Edward Robinson said.
Singapore dollar notes in 2, 5, 10 and 50 denomination.
Fourth-quarter growth GDP growth was 2.2 per cent on year, lower than the advance estimate of 2.8 per cent.

In a consultation paper released on Friday (Feb 2), the MAS is proposing that consumers will not have to provide as much information for policies that are recommended based on the Basic Financial Planning Guide.

site_title: White House courts influencers ahead of high stakes speech
summary: The White House has briefed social media influencers ahead of President Joe Biden's annual State of the Union address, a crucial event for the 81-year-old leader facing intense scrutiny over his fitness for office. The speech aims to connect with young voters who largely tune out of traditional political coverage. This year's speech is seen as a key moment for Biden to showcase his leadership and prepare for the November electoral rematch against former president Donald Trump. The White House seeks to leverage social media influencers to increase the speech's relevance and engagement among young people.

images.alt_text: White House officials said President Joe Biden will preview the steps that will be part of a proposed fiscal 2025 budget released next week that aims to decrease the federal deficit by US$3 trillion over 10 years while cutting taxes for low-income Americans.
Since early January, US economic activity has “increased slightly, on balance,” the Fed announced in its regular update of economic conditions known as the “beige book.”

Wednesday’s House vote to approve a US$460 billion package - thrashed out over months of intense bipartisan negotiations - takes the United States a step closer to keeping the government funded through the end of the fiscal year on Sept 30.
“Just to be super clear, I am not donating money to either candidate for US President,” Elon Musk says.
“The time has now come to suspend my campaign. I have no regrets.” Nikki Haley says.

site_title: Fed’s Powell says aware of policy risks to workers, but cuts depend on inflation
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell stated that the central bank is aware of the risks its monetary policy poses to workers but will consider rate cuts if the economy evolves as expected, with continued lower inflation. Powell emphasized that ongoing progress in lowering inflation is not assured and that the Fed will carefully remove restrictive policies over the course of this year. This decision will depend on the economy's continued strong growth and labor market, as well as progress in bringing inflation down.

site_title: Oil prices nearly flat as market weighs Chinese demand, North America supply increase
summary: Oil prices remained nearly flat on Thursday, with Brent crude futures settling at US$82.96 a barrel. The market weighed new economic data from China, which showed improved import and export growth, against increasing supply from the Western Hemisphere. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 20 cents to US$78.93. The positive signal for policymakers suggests a turning point in global trade, but the overall impact on oil prices was minimal.

images.alt_text: Signage above the Saudi Aramco booth on day two of the Abu Dhabi International Petroleum Exhibition and Conference (ADIPEC) in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates, on Tuesday, Oct. 3, 2023. The annual strategic energy conference runs from Oct 2-5. Photographer: Christopher Pike/Bloomberg
Brent futures rose 92 cents, or 1.1 per cent, to settle at US$82.96 a barrel, while US crude rose 98 cents, or 1.3 per cent, to settle at US$79.13 on Wednesday.

site_title: Forget business as usual – transformation is the new normal
summary: Singapore's economy faces challenges as it transitions from its traditional growth model. The country needs to transform industries, build new growth engines, and strengthen its "TICK" quotient, comprising trust, infrastructure, connectivity, and kinships. With the global economy changing, Singapore must adapt by investing in technologies like artificial intelligence and fostering partnerships with businesses and trade partners. Retrenchments and manpower shortages are concerns, but the government aims to support SMEs in developing AI capabilities. By embracing transformation and focusing on the TICK fundamentals, Singapore can stay competitive and achieve growth over the next decade.

images.alt_text: Budget 2024 is a timely platform to drive initiatives that can strengthen enterprise digitalisation, sustainability, and internationalisation as levers for growth.

site_title: Singapore’s national accounting body makes S$3 million push to set up overseas learning centres
summary: The Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants (Isca) is investing S$3 million in the next three years to set up overseas learning centers, aiming to have at least six by end-2024. The centers will provide in-person learning resources for foreign trainees and solidify Isca's regional presence. The goal is to have 200 overseas enrollees in the Singapore Chartered Accountant Qualification (SCAQ) programme by the end of 2024, with plans to treble this number in the next few years.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo

the Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants (Isca) said the fee revision was part of efforts with the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) to attract more individuals to take on the SCAQ.
Industry body makes S$15 million push to enlarge pool of Singapore chartered accountants

In her speech, Minister in the Prime Minister’s Office and Second Minister for Finance and for National Development Indranee Rajah urged the more than 1,000 delegates present at the event to build new capabilities, and expand their roles to include sustainability-related issues.
The Singapore office of KPMG is training staff and building its own ESG capabilities accordingly, said managing partner Lee Sze Yeng.
Skybots has deployed more than 100 individual bots since February, founder and managing director Daryl Aw said.
Isca president Teo Ser Luck hopes that the programme will attract students from the "best universities" globally.
Many foreign accountants in Singapore – most of whom were Malaysians – left in the early days of the pandemic, and could not return when borders closed.

site_title: The power of connections will drive South-east Asia’s female entrepreneurs
summary: A new generation of young, confident female entrepreneurs in South-east Asia is driving growth and innovation, outperforming their male counterparts in terms of capital raising. Despite this progress, women still face a lack of connections and support networks, limiting their access to capital and business partners. Initiatives such as SheLovesTech and WEConnect aim to bridge this gap, providing female entrepreneurs with information about funding options, networking opportunities, and coaching to access capital and growth opportunities. The region's strong talent pool and economic potential make it crucial to address this imbalance and create a more level playing field for all entrepreneurs.

images.alt_text: Female representation on the Singapore companies’ boards have strengthened, with one in four board seats being filled by women last year, versus one in five in 2022, in line with the regional trend.
Funding gap, gender bias against female founders persist in South-east Asia

site_title: The Great Resignation is now the Big Stay
summary: US workers are leaving their jobs less often, with the quits rate falling to 2.1% in January, the lowest since August 2020. This shift, known as the Big Stay, is seen as a broad-based trend, particularly in white-collar industries, where the professional and business services sector has seen a drop in departures. The implications are unclear, with some seeing it as a sign of stable wage growth and others warning of underlying labor market weaknesses.

images.alt_text: Doctor protesters hold placards reading "Stop populist medical policy", during a protest against the government's medical policy near the presidential office in Seoul, South Korea, Feb 14, 2024.

site_title: Job-hopping: Path to success or red flag?
summary: Singapore's workforce is increasingly embracing job-hopping as a means to accelerate career growth and seek better work environments, with nearly 30% planning to leave their current employer in under two years. While job-hopping can lead to higher wages, experts warn that it may also limit deep expertise and relationships. Employers are shifting focus towards skills-based hiring, valuing logical progression and consistency in an individual's career. To mitigate job-hopping, organizations should create environments that foster employee growth and provide clear career paths. Job-hoppers can alleviate skepticism by emphasizing a quest for learning and growth, being truthful and professional, and showcasing their adaptability and versatility.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Hiring now will be more intentional and unlike 2021, where companies were on a mission to grab talent, says Elena Chow, founder of employment consultancy ConnectOne.
The best way to gain a competitive advantage is to embrace the right technologies.
(From left) Jerome Wong, Lim Wei Jie and Nadi Chan, part of Foreword Coffee Roasters' new training and development team at Foreword Bakehouse.

site_title: Hong Kong tax breaks spark condo sales at Henderson Land project
summary: Henderson Land Development's Belgravia Place project in Kowloon saw a surge in condo sales following the Hong Kong government's tax cuts, with over 190 units sold and 7,300 applications received. This marks the highest number of transactions in 61 weeks in the 10 biggest estates. The developer sold 138 units in just four hours, and the secondary home market is also experiencing a recovery, with the number of transactions rising to its highest level in 61 weeks. The government's tax cuts, including loosening mortgage rules and removing extra taxes, are believed to be a key factor.

site_title: Flying high with Bell & Ross
summary: Bell & Ross, a 30-year-old French watchmaker, is expanding into the higher-end market with its new BR 03 Cyber Ceramic timepiece. Inspired by a stealth aircraft, the limited-edition watch is priced at S$18,800 and features a unique faceting design. The brand's co-founder, Carlos Rosillo, aims to "elevate" the brand, citing a focus on readability, functionality, and aspirational designs. Despite its success, Bell & Ross is seeking to "regenerate" and expand globally, particularly in Asia, with 600 points of sales worldwide.

images.alt_text: Rexhepi and his team of 20 turn out about 40 watches annually.

site_title: State of the Union: Biden to push wealth, company tax ideas
summary: President Joe Biden will outline tax proposals in his State of the Union address, aiming to decrease the federal deficit by $3 trillion over 10 years. The plans include hiking corporate minimum taxes, curtailing executive pay and corporate jet deductions, and raising the corporate tax rate to 28% from 21%. Biden will also propose a "billionaire tax" with a 25% minimum tax on income above $100 million. Additionally, he will extend tax cuts for low-income Americans and call for measures to curb "corporate rip-offs" such as junk fees and price gouging.

images.alt_text: The most favourable scenario for Bidenomics is that US investments lead to cheaper green energy sources
Biden is expected to address housing affordability for both homeowners and renters in his State of the Union address next week.

site_title: US banking sector profits drop 44% in Q4 as big firms cover failed bank costs
summary: US banking sector profits dropped 44% in Q4, mainly due to non-recurring expenses, including a special assessment fee to replenish the FDIC's deposit insurance fund. Despite this, 2023 bank profits remained above pre-pandemic levels at $257 billion. Deposits rose 1.1% and unrealised losses on securities declined 30.2%. Net operating revenue exceeded $1 trillion, but non-current loans and charge-off rates increased. The FDIC added 8 banks to its "problem bank" list, totaling $66.3 billion in assets.

images.alt_text: “In total, it will be 20 years since the Great Financial Crisis by the time the last element of the outstanding Basel III standards is expected to be implemented in 2028,” Basel Committee chair Pablo Hernandez de Cos says.

This year’s tests will attract heightened scrutiny from investors, analysts and regulators following the failure of three banks last year, and as big banks are fighting the Fed over proposed new capital hikes that they say are excessive.
More than half of NYCB's total multifamily loan portfolio is secured by properties in New York state.
KeyCorp posts a near 92 per cent plunge in quarterly profit and forecast a 2 to 5 per cent drop in its net interest income (NII) in 2024.

The proposal, the Basel III Endgame rule developed in concert with international standards in response to the 2007-2009 financial crisis, would increase capital requirements by 20-25 per cent on the largest banks, JPMorgan Chase chief executive Jamie Dimon said.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims unchanged
summary: The US labor market showed no change in weekly jobless claims, remaining at 217,000 for the week ended March 2. This marks the first time since November that claims have remained unchanged. The labor market is gradually easing, with 1.45 job openings per every unemployed person in January, a decrease from 1.82 a year ago.

images.alt_text: Job seekers speak with representatives at the Choice Career Fair in San Antonio, Texas, U.S., on Thursday, April 16, 2015. Fewer than 300,000 American workers filed applications for unemployment benefits for the sixth consecutive week, pointing to labor-market strength even as hiring cooled last month. Photographer: Matthew Busch/Bloomberg

site_title: Japan sustains current account surplus for full year
summary: Japan sustained a current account surplus for the full year in January, driven by 7.6% year-on-year growth in exports and a 12.1% decline in imports. Exports grew due to demand for cars, car parts, and chip-making equipment, while imports declined due to declines in coal, liquefied natural gas, and communications equipment. The current account surplus stood at 438.2 billion yen in January, exceeding economists' median forecast of a deficit. This follows a surplus of 744.3 billion yen in December.

site_title: US trade deficit widens in January on imports
summary: The US trade deficit widened 5.1% in January to $67.4 billion, the highest on record, due to a surge in imports. Goods imports rose 1.2% to a record high, while services imports also reached an all-time high. Exports edged up 0.1% to $257.2 billion, with capital goods exports reaching a record high. The trade deficit narrowed to 2.9% of GDP, contributing to a 2% annualized growth rate in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Jardine Matheson FY2023 underlying profit up 5% to US$1.66 billion
summary: Jardine Matheson Holdings reported an underlying net profit of US$1.66 billion for FY2023, a 5% increase from 2022, driven by strong results from its automotive business Astra and improved contributions from DFI Retail and Mandarin Oriental. The company also posted a 94% increase in net profit to US$686 million, with earnings per share rising to US$2.37. Despite a challenging economic outlook, the group remains optimistic about its future, citing new leadership and an effective long-term strategy.

images.alt_text: Jardine Matheson Q3 performance ‘marginally’ better; Jardine C&C underlying profit up 14%
Generic pictures of SGX
Mandarin Oriental, part of Jardin Matheson's portfolio, reported improved H1 results led by strong performance of its hotels
Carro CEO Aaron Tan (left) will join the board of Republic Auto, while Jardine C&C managing director of direct motor interests Wilfrid Foo (right) will join the board of Carro.

site_title: ‘Slow Productivity’ by Cal Newport: When less means more
summary: Cal Newport's new book, "Slow Productivity," argues that knowledge workers need to slow down and focus on quality over quantity. Newport, a computer science professor, advocates for doing fewer things at a natural pace and obsessing over quality. He suggests principles such as scheduling slow seasons, no-meeting Mondays, and prioritizing rest. The book comes at a time of "untenable freneticism" and proposes a new standard: "accomplishment without burnout." Newport's ideas aim to encourage deep focus and away from the noise of social media and performative busyness, but some critics argue that his suggestions may not be realistic for those with caring responsibilities.

images.alt_text: The Uninterrupted Life: Time to put down your phone?

site_title: US Q4 worker productivity growth unrevised
summary: US worker productivity grew at a 3.2% annualized rate in the fourth quarter, as reported by the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics. This growth rate remains unchanged from the previous quarter. Rising productivity has been credited by some economists as a factor in the labor market's resilience. Productivity increased 1.3% in 2023, revised up from 1.2%. This solid growth in productivity puts a lid on labor costs, suggesting a more stable economic outlook.

site_title: OECD sees total bond debt to rise in 2024 on tightening financial conditions
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) expects total bond debt to rise to $56 trillion in 2024, with the US accounting for roughly half of this debt, up from 25% in 2008. This increase is driven by refinancing requirements, with 40% of sovereign bonds and 37% of corporate bonds globally set to mature by 2026, requiring further borrowing under higher interest rates. The OECD warns of increasing interest payments, amounting to 0.5% of GDP in the OECD area by 2026.

images.alt_text: World economic growth is expected to ease from 3.1 per cent in 2023 to 2.9 per cent this year, better than the 2.7 per cent expected in November in the OECD’s last outlook.

site_title: US: Wall St rises ahead of Powell's testimony
summary: US stocks rose ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's testimony, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average increasing 123.25 points, or 0.32%, to 38,784.30. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, gaining 27.62 and 115.78 points, respectively. Powell's comments, made overnight, reaffirmed the central bank's expectation to cut interest rates later this year, supporting market optimism.

site_title: Saudi Arabia moves US$164 billion Aramco stake to wealth fund
summary: Saudi Arabia has transferred an 8% stake in Aramco, valued at $164 billion, to the Public Investment Fund (PIF), reducing the government's direct ownership to 82%. The move aims to bolster cashflow for the state-backed investor, which has been increasing spending on local projects. The transfer has no impact on Aramco's $29 billion dividend, and a recent production halt may allow for a higher dividend payout. The move comes ahead of Aramco's annual results report on Sunday.

images.alt_text: Aramco says it wants to reach net zero emissions from its own operations by 2050.

site_title: StorHub pumps US$300 million into Australian expansion plan, snaps up 5 assets
summary: StorHub, a Singapore-based self-storage operator, has launched its Australian expansion plan with a US$300 million equity commitment. The company has acquired five assets in Sydney, Melbourne, and Canberra, with a combined gross floor area of 56,210 square meters. StorHub aims to accelerate its pan-Asia growth strategy, adding 655,000 sq m to its portfolio across seven markets. The move is seen as a natural step for the company, driven by favorable tailwinds in the Australian self-storage industry, including record population growth and increasing demand for modern storage solutions.

site_title: Corporate governance in a post-pandemic world
summary: In a post-pandemic world, corporate governance in Singapore is evolving with a focus on building resilience and future-proofing organizations. The Singapore Institute of Directors' (SID) 2023 report highlights opportunities for change, including enhancing board independence, increasing sustainability disclosures, and improving remuneration transparency. To address these challenges, firms need to develop a deliberate succession plan for their boards and chairs, and consider the potential risks of long-serving independent directors. The report also emphasizes the importance of sustainability reporting and the need for audited sustainability reports to ensure long-term sustainability.

site_title: Prada, Miu Miu sales jump as Italian fashion group draws fans
summary: Prada, an Italian fashion group, reported a 17% increase in net revenue to 4.73 billion euros (S$6.86 billion) last year, driven by strong demand for its hippest products such as brushed leather loafers and Miu Miu pumps. This surpassed analysts' expectations. Prada's Miu Miu brand was the second most searched brand on the Lyst index, and its products were among the most searched items.

images.alt_text: Retail sales in the US are staying strong amid a global slowdown in demand for luxury goods.

site_title: Hongkong Land sinks into red with full-year loss of US$582.3 million
summary: Hongkong Land, a property developer, reported a full-year loss of US$582.3 million for the financial year ended Dec 31, 2023, down from a US$202.7 million profit the previous year. Its underlying profit declined 5.4% to US$734.2 million, primarily due to reduced contributions from its Hong Kong office portfolio. However, profits from luxury retail and Singapore office portfolios improved, offsetting the decline.

Contributions from the investment properties segment was “marginally” higher year on year with a stronger showing from the retail segment.

site_title: When the fix for lower commodity prices isn’t low prices
summary: Commodities are often seen as a boom-and-bust industry, but the traditional principle that low prices cure low prices and high prices cure high prices may be misleading. The global nickel and US natural gas markets are experiencing disruptions due to technological advancements that have permanently cut production costs. Nickel, a key material for electric vehicle batteries, and gas, a bridge fuel between coal and renewables, are seeing low prices persist due to these technological changes, potentially harming producers and their shareholders, but benefiting the planet in the fight against climate change.

images.alt_text: Oil prices this year are trading in a tighter range compared to the corresponding prior-year period, Bloomberg data shows.
The new taxonomy was a revision to a 2022 document defining what is considered a sustainable investment in support of Indonesia’s pledge to achieve net-zero emissions by 2060.

site_title: Global banking watchdog to crack down on ‘window dressing’ by big lenders
summary: Global banking regulators proposed measures to crack down on "window dressing" by big lenders, aiming to stop attempts to temporarily reduce their systemic footprint. The Basel Committee plans to require banks to report and disclose G-SIB indicators based on an average of values over the reporting year, rather than year-end values. The proposals are out to public consultation until June 7 and are expected to take effect in January 2027. The goal is to increase capital requirements for globally systemic banks and reduce regulatory arbitrage behavior.

images.alt_text: “In total, it will be 20 years since the Great Financial Crisis by the time the last element of the outstanding Basel III standards is expected to be implemented in 2028,” Basel Committee chair Pablo Hernandez de Cos says.

site_title: US dollar slips vs euro as ECB keeps rates steady
summary: The US dollar slid against the euro, reaching a six-week high, as the European Central Bank (ECB) kept interest rates steady at 4% despite easing inflation. ECB President Christine Lagarde signaled the bank is "getting closer" to dialing back stimulus, but not yet ready to lower rates. The euro rose 0.3% to US$1.0928, while the yen surged 0.93% to its weakest level in over a month, driven by speculation the Bank of Japan may raise rates this month.

images.alt_text: China's foreign exchange reserves – the world’s largest – rise by US$6.5 billion to US$3.226 trillion last month.
The US dollar index, which measures the currency against a basket of six others, down around 0.1 per cent at 103.63.

site_title: Global patent filings fall for first time in 14 years: UN
summary: International patent filings fell for the first time in 14 years in 2023, with a 1.8% decline to 272,600 filings, according to the World Intellectual Property Organisation (WIPO). The decline was attributed to higher interest rates and economic uncertainty, but WIPO's chief economist believes it's a cyclical phenomenon that will reverse once the external environment improves. India, however, bucked the trend with a 44.6% surge in international patent filings, marking the country's largest growth.

images.alt_text: French shoe designer Christian Louboutin poses with some of his famous footwear while preparing for an exhibition of his work in Toronto.
Survival adventure game "Palworld" has sold more than eight million copies since its Jan 18 release.

Masimo, based in southern California, filed a complaint to the US International Trade Commission which decided in October to halt imports of the Apple Watch models over a patented technology for detecting blood-oxygen levels.
The findings, based on data from 2018 to 2021, show that fakes take the biggest toll on the clothing sector, costing 12 billion euros annually.
Singular has requested up to US$7 billion in monetary damages, which would be more than double the largest-ever patent infringement award in US history, according to Google court filing.

site_title: GE Aerospace sets tone with post-breakup profit goal, dividend
summary: GE Aerospace forecasts operating earnings of $10 billion by 2028, up from $6.5 billion this year, and plans to resume paying a 30% dividend. The company authorized $15 billion in stock buybacks and expects to generate over $5 billion of free cash flow this year. Following its planned breakup, GE Aerospace is poised to become an independent company, driven by robust demand for its products and services in the aerospace industry, which is expected to continue growing despite air travel's pandemic-induced slump.

images.alt_text: GE Aerospace should produce as much as US$6.5 billion in operating profit this year, even as it takes on about US$600 million in costs as it becomes an independent company, says GE.

site_title: Japan's fair trade watchdog says Nissan underpaid subcontractors
summary: Japan's fair trade watchdog says Nissan Motor has violated the subcontractor act by underpaying 36 suppliers by about 3 billion yen (S$27.09 million) over a two-year period from January 2021. Nissan unlawfully deducted the amount, violating Japan's Subcontractor Law, which prohibits unilateral payment reductions when the subcontractor is not at fault. Nissan has refunded suppliers and plans to strengthen its inspection system, while the Japan Fair Trade Commission calls for a management system for subcontractor payments and a board resolution to prevent future incidents.

site_title: As Big Tech scrambles to meet EU rules, investigations seen as likely
summary: Big Tech companies, including Google, Apple, Amazon, Microsoft, Meta, and TikTok owner ByteDance, are scrambling to comply with the EU's Digital Markets Act (DMA) by Thursday's deadline. Failure to comply could result in investigations and fines of up to 10% of their global turnover. Apple is seen as the most affected, with critics arguing its new fees undermine the incentives for developers to switch to rivals. EU regulators are focusing on one or two cases initially, and pressure for an investigation is coming from some companies themselves, with one stating it's unfair to follow DMA rules while a rival flouts them.

images.alt_text: The EU's decision is a win for Apple and Microsoft, as they would have been obliged to adapt their services to meet a swathe of new obligations and prohibitions.
After laying off more than 1,000 employees in January, Google warned workers that rolling layoffs could continue through the year.
Big Tech companies such as Amazon boast strong brands, massive scale and high customer switching costs.
Some bank industry representatives have reacted warmly to the proposal, saying companies that provide bank-like services should be regulated and directly supervised like banks.
The European Union's new Digital Markets Act imposes a rigid regime on the largest digital companies and boost the EU commission’s existing powers.

site_title: IWD: Empowering songs from Taylor Swift and others
summary: This International Women's Day, a music playlist celebrates women who uplift and empower each other through their songs. Featured artists include Taylor Swift, known for her strength and resilience anthems, Aretha Franklin, a civil rights and feminist icon, Madonna, a trailblazer for female self-expression, Blackpink, a confident and glamorous girl group, and Beyonce, a prolific singer-songwriter advocating for gender equality and female empowerment. Their songs, such as "Shake It Off," "Respect," "Vogue," and "Run the World (Girls)," inspire women to celebrate their authenticity, defy societal expectations, and chart their own destinies.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
The production value of Taylor Swift's Eras Tour is top-notch, with LED screens forming a gigantic backdrop as well as bringing the entire stage surface to life.
Taylor Swift’s six concerts in March could boost Singapore’s economy by up to S$500 million in tourism receipts, according to economists’ estimates.
Taylor Swift held the first of six shows here on Mar 2, with over 300,000 tickets sold.

site_title: DFI Retail Group posts 437% increase in underlying earnings to US$155m
summary: DFI Retail Group reported a significant increase in underlying earnings, posting a 437% rise to US$154.7 million for the fiscal year ended Dec 31, 2023. The company's net profit for the year was US$32.2 million, a substantial improvement from a loss of US$114.6 million in the prior year. This marks a full year net profit for FY2023, contrasting with a net loss in FY2022.

images.alt_text: From real estate to food: Cold Storage, along with 7-Eleven, Giant and Guardian belong to Jardine subsidiary Dairy Farm.

site_title: Bruce Lee film studio weighing sale of Singapore Golden Village cinemas: sources
summary: Orange Sky Golden Harvest Entertainment Holdings is considering selling its movie theaters in Singapore and Taiwan, seeking a valuation of at least US$400 million. The Hong Kong-listed company, which owns the Golden Village brand, generated nearly half of its revenue from Singapore in the first half of 2023. Other cinema operators and investment firms have shown interest in the potential divestment. The decision is preliminary and may depend on investor response, with the company also considering selling its cinemas in Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Cathay Cineplexes will be holding its last day of screenings in Cineleisure on Jun 30.

site_title: ECB keeps rates on hold but acknowledges some inflation cooling
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) kept its main interest rate at 4.0% as expected, but acknowledged that inflation is easing faster than anticipated. President Christine Lagarde said the ECB is making progress towards its 2% inflation target, but is not yet confident enough to declare victory. The ECB tweaked its message to reflect a continued fall in inflation over the past 1.5 years and new, lower economic projections. The central bank will wait until June to reassess its decision, with some analysts expecting a rate cut in June.

images.alt_text: Clouds and the sun are seen over the European Central Bank (ECB) building on September 14, 2023 ahead of the meeting of the governing council of the ECB in Frankfurt am Main, western Germany. (Photo by Kirill KUDRYAVTSEV / AFP)

site_title: Rolls-Royce, Mercedes linked to money laundering probe towed away from D’Leedon condo
summary: Three vehicles linked to Singapore's money laundering investigation, including a Rolls-Royce, Mercedes-Benz, and Toyota, were seized from a condominium in the prime Bukit Timah area on Wednesday. The vehicles belong to a male foreigner who lived in the unit with his family and were towed away after he had not been seen in the condo for at least half a year. The investigation has so far swept up over S$3 billion worth of cash, cars, properties, and luxury goods.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
A red Porsche 911 Targa was amongst the four vehicles towed away from a GCB in Third Avenue

site_title: Singapore Recreation Club plans S$16.6 million renovation, but some members baulk at S$3,000 fee
summary: The Singapore Recreation Club (SRC) is planning a S$16.6 million renovation of its 141-year-old clubhouse, aimed at attracting younger members and increasing its value. The club will seek S$3,000 from each of its 4,782 members to fund the project, with a 12-month instalment plan available. The renovation plans include a co-working space, children's play area, and expanded sporting facilities, and will be put to a vote by end-March. The club's ageing demographics pose a long-term threat to its survival, and the renovation is seen as necessary for its "survival" and "rejuvenation".

Nordic Group executive chairman Chang Yeh Hong.
The old City Hall (left) and the Padang (right), with other historical buildings around, on 7 April 2021.

site_title: Mandarin Oriental posts underlying profit of US$81 million for FY2023
summary: Mandarin Oriental International posted an underlying profit of US$81 million for FY2023, a 966% increase from US$7.6 million the previous year. Revenue rose 23% to US$558.1 million, driven by the return of Chinese tourists. Despite a net loss of US$365.4 million and a loss per share of 28.91 US cents, the group declared a dividend of five US cents per share. The company attributed its non-trading losses to a non-cash revaluation of a Hong Kong development site.

images.alt_text: Mandarin Oriental, Paris, which was opened in 2011, is one of the leading luxury hotels in the French capital.
Jardine Matheson Q3 performance ‘marginally’ better; Jardine C&C underlying profit up 14%
Visa hassles, a lack of flights, idiosyncratic payment systems and the language barrier also limit China’s appeal to tourists from places such as North America and Europe.
Mandarin Oriental Singapore is on track to re-open in September 2023

site_title: China should establish property presale fund to support developers, says former central bank chief
summary: China's former central bank chief, Yi Gang, suggests establishing a property presale fund to support developers by injecting 1% of escrow funds annually, totaling 10 billion yuan. The fund would help developers finish construction projects and deliver homes to buyers on time, addressing liquidity stress. Yi also proposes allowing developers to access a certain proportion of escrow funds to relax liquidity stress and facilitate a transition to selling existing homes.

images.alt_text: “We will scale up the building and supply of government-subsidised housing and improve the basic systems for commercial housing to meet people’s essential need for a home to live in and their different demands for better housing," says Chinese Premier Li Qiang.

site_title: China scrutinises bond buying at smaller banks as market soars
summary: Chinese regulators are scrutinizing bond investments by smaller regional banks amid concerns that they are speculating on securities rather than lending to boost the economy. Policymakers requested information from rural lenders on their bond-trading activities, major counterparties, and investment necessity. The regulators aim to prevent a market reversal that could expose banks to capital-eroding losses. The move follows a heated bond rally that sent longer-term sovereign yields to near a record low, with regulators seeking to reduce speculative trading and ensure more funds flow into the real economy.

images.alt_text: Chinese stocks are wallowing near a five-year nadir while yields on the country’s 30-year treasury bonds have plumbed record lows.

site_title: Dune 2 vs Spaceman: One soars, the other sinks
summary: Two sci-fi movies, "Dune: Part Two" and "Spaceman," were released within days of each other, showcasing the genre's ability to explore complex ideas about our present lives. "Dune: Part Two" is a faithful adaptation of Frank Herbert's novel, immersing viewers in an alien desert world and exploring themes of power, religion, and ecology. In contrast, "Spaceman" struggles to be relevant, focusing on a lonely astronaut's personal struggles and failing to offer new insight into human nature. The two films demonstrate the difference in execution and world-building, with "Dune: Part Two" receiving critical acclaim and "Spaceman" receiving negative reviews.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
In the participatory VR show Le Bal De Paris, audience get to be avatar dressed Chanel-designed fineries.
Taylor Swift has consistently fought for women in her music. She is currently performing in Singapore as part of her Eras Tour.

site_title: South Korea probes data protection by e-commerce platforms like AliExpress, Temu
summary: South Korea's Personal Information Protection Commission is investigating Chinese e-commerce platforms AliExpress and Temu for data protection practices. The probe follows a parliament audit last year that raised concerns about data handling by these platforms, which have seen a significant increase in South Korean use, with e-commerce purchases from China rising 121% in 2023. The commission will examine personal information processing policies, overseas transfers, and safety measures, and may take action if violations of South Korean law are found.

images.alt_text: Meta has said the service that applies to Facebook and Instagram aims to comply with EU rules to give users a choice whether their data can be collected and used for targeted ads.
The Chinese government is also interested in the type of Chinese data that the company will disclose to regulators in the US as Shein seeks a listing there.

site_title: Hong Kong property agents expect more big-ticket foreclosures this year
summary: Hong Kong's property market expects more big-ticket foreclosures this year due to landlords struggling to refinance and receivers speeding up sales after recent measures to bolster the market. CBRE and Savills have been appointed to sell foreclosed properties, including a HK$42 million residential building and two industrial buildings worth HK$510 million. The city's housing and commercial property prices have plummeted over 20% and 30% from their peaks, respectively, amid high interest rates and poor market conditions.

images.alt_text: It’s located in a remote part of Lantau Island, with no direct transport links to Hong Kong Island, shops or medical facilities, and a reputation for being a ghost town fringed by jungle.

With one of the highest debt ratios among Hong Kong peers, New World’s de-leveraging plan has been in the spotlight in the past year, especially after a string of defaults by Chinese property developers.

Buildings in Hong Kong, China, on Tuesday, Jan. 9, 2024.  The chill in Hong Kong's housing market is prompting owners of luxury homes to rent out their properties instead of selling. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg
Buyers remain cautious amid high interest rates, ample inventory and a weak economy, analysts said after authorities eased homebuyer levies and mortgage lending restrictions.
The low pricing by Sun Hung Kai shows that the government’s recent measure to cut property taxes is insufficient to lift the market.

According to a Reuters tally, around 20 Hong Kong-listed Chinese real estate developers have defaulted on dollar bonds which would require them to enter into restructuring talks with creditors or face liquidation.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 7)
summary: Scoot aims to expand its network to 74 destinations in South-east Asia by FY2025, with plans to fly to 5-7 more destinations. Meanwhile, the airline seeks to increase revenue through seat sales and add-on offerings to mitigate cost pressures. The Singapore central bank kept its interest rate unchanged at 3% for a fifth consecutive meeting. Additionally, Singtel sold a 0.8% stake in Indian associate Airtel for S$700 million, and Allgreen Properties acquired Seletar Mall for S$550 million.

site_title: Data points to Scoot raising China capacity for Northern Summer: aviation consultancy
summary: Scoot, a budget airline, plans to increase its seat capacity for mainland China during the Northern Summer 2024 season. According to an aviation consultancy, the airline's capacity is expected to peak in August, with daily round trips available to cities like Guangzhou, Hangzhou, and Xi'an. This marks a significant increase from pre-pandemic levels, when China was a top source of tourists for Singapore and other Asian countries. The move is seen as a positive sign for the airline's growth in the region.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Scoot's chief executive officer Leslie Thng says the airline will fly to five to seven more destinations in South-east Asia in FY2025, bringing the network points to as many as 74.
Scoot will be deploying the Embraer planes that it recently acquired to Koh Samui, Hat Yai and Krabi in Thailand, and Sibu and Miri in Sarawak, Malaysia.

site_title: Malaysia central bank keeps interest rate unchanged at 3%, as expected
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara, kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 3% for a fifth consecutive meeting, as expected. The decision was based on the global economy's moderate expansion and domestic demand supporting the Malaysian economy. The central bank stated that the current interest rate level remains supportive of the economy and consistent with inflation and growth prospects. Economists do not expect the central bank to use rate hikes to defend the ringgit, citing its weakness, and instead, Bank Negara is focusing on encouraging foreign investment repatriation and coordinating with government-linked companies to address the currency's weakness.

images.alt_text: Abdul Rasheed Ghaffour, governor of Bank Negara Malaysia, during a news conference at Sasana Kijang Center, which houses Bank Negara Malaysia facilities, in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Friday, Nov. 17, 2023. Malaysia’s economic growth accelerated in the third quarter as consumer spending along with the services and construction sectors helped counter the impact of faltering exports. Photographer: Annice Lyn/Bloomberg
The local currency fell 0.2% to 4.7965 against the dollar, its weakest level since an all-time low of 4.8850 in 1998 following the fallout from the regional financial crisis.

site_title: BT Explains: Has MAS policy tightening hurt Singapore exports?
summary: Singapore's export competitiveness may not have been significantly hurt by the strong Singapore dollar appreciation in recent years, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). Despite economic theory suggesting a stronger currency makes exports less competitive, MAS' simulations suggest that the appreciation was driven by "increases in relative prices" rather than a loss of external competitiveness. If MAS had not tightened monetary policy, Singapore would have faced higher inflation, higher wages, and lower real GDP growth, but the Singapore dollar would still have appreciated in real terms.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

site_title: Thai February consumer confidence at four-year high on support measures, tourism
summary: Thai consumer confidence reached a four-year high in February, reaching 63.8, driven by government support measures and tourism. The University of the Thai Chamber of Commerce expects further improvement, citing policies to boost the economy. Consumers remain concerned about global economic slowdown and geopolitical conflicts. Thailand aims for a record 40 million foreign visitors this year, up from 28 million last year, following a 49% increase in foreign visitors in the January to March period, with 6.73 million visitors received.

images.alt_text: The group expects 34 million to 35 million foreign arrivals this year.
The Finance Ministry says it and the central bank will consider applications within nine months of when the submission period ends.

site_title: China forex reserves unexpectedly rise to US$3.226 trillion in Feb
summary: China's foreign exchange reserves unexpectedly rose to $3.226 trillion in February, a $6.5 billion increase. This surpasses analyst predictions of $3.205 trillion. The yuan fell 0.25% against the US dollar, while the US dollar rose 0.6% against a basket of other major currencies. China's gold reserves also increased to $148.64 billion, with 72.58 million fine troy ounces held at the end of February.

site_title: To evolve, a florist firm turns to performance art
summary: This Humid House, a Singapore-based botanical design studio, has created a large-scale performance installation at the historic Chamber of the Arts House, commenting on colonial histories. The installation, designed by John Lim and Wagner Kreusch, features native materials such as pineapples, sugarcane, and palm oil, each carrying historical significance. The work is an anti-colonial statement, using the venue's colonial-era background to highlight the exploitation of these materials. The performance, accompanied by live electronic music, aims to raise awareness about botanical materials and promote education about their multiple perspectives and understanding.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Na Byung Ha's painting depicts South Korean archer An San, who won three Olympic gold medals, but was criticised for sporting short hair.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Thursday, March 7, 2024 (Ep 17)
summary: The Federal Reserve (Fed) reaffirmed its likelihood of a rate cut this year, citing a promising sign in China's export growth, which indicates a positive demand outlook. Meanwhile, gold prices reached a record peak as Fed Chairman Powell expressed the possibility of rate cuts. Singapore shares rose 0.1% at the open, driven by a positive market sentiment.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Thursday.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks end with big losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted on Thursday, March 7, 2024, with the Hang Seng Index sinking 1.27% to 16,229.78, amid expectations for weaker US jobs data. Despite a stronger-than-expected jump in Chinese exports, traders remained cautious. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell, with losses of 0.41% and 1.20%, respectively.

site_title: Scoot looks to raise top line to tackle cost pressures
summary: Scoot, the budget arm of Singapore Airlines, plans to increase its top line to mitigate the impact of rising costs on its profit margins. Despite a 70.5% drop in operating profit for Q3 FY2024, the airline aims to raise revenue from seats sold and add-on offerings. Scoot will add 5-7 new destinations in South-east Asia in FY2025, bringing its network points to 74, and take delivery of 18 narrow-body planes from Airbus in 2025. The airline also expects to tap into the returning demand from Chinese travellers, with bookings spiking after the mutual visa-free travel arrangement between Singapore and China was announced.

site_title: Aviva’s profit up 9% for 2023, offers £300 million buyback
summary: Aviva, a British life and general insurer, reported a 9% increase in 2023 operating profit to £1.47 billion, beating analyst expectations. The company announced a £300 million share buyback and upgraded its operating targets, aiming for £2 billion profit by 2026. This move aims to drive growth and increase shareholder value.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall amid cautious sentiment; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.1% or 2.36 points to 3,133.78 on Thursday amid cautious sentiment ahead of the US nonfarm payroll statistics. Losers outperformed gainers 280 to 242, with 1.39 billion securities worth S$1 billion changing hands. Major markets in the region were mixed, with Japan's Nikkei 225 shedding 1.2% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index falling 1.3%. The top gainer on the STI was Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, rising 4.5%.

The Great Eastern logo on the facade of Great Eastern Centre located at Pickering Street on 4 Dec 2019.
Singtel says it intends to remain invested in Airtel over the long term.

site_title: Former CEO and directors of Envysion charged in relation to nickel trading fraud case
summary: Former CEO and directors of Envysion, Shim Wai Han, Doo Chun Ki, and Tan Kay Siong, have been charged in relation to a nickel trading fraud case. They face fines of up to S$50,000 each for failing to implement an appropriate risk management framework and mitigate conflicts of interest. Shim also faces charges under the Financial Advisers Act and the Official Secrets Act for making false statements and forwarding sensitive information. The charges stem from Envysion's involvement in the US$1.1 billion nickel trading scam, one of Singapore's largest investment fraud schemes.

site_title: Su Wenqiang set to be first accused in S$3b money laundering case to plead guilty on Apr 2
summary: Su Wenqiang, a 32-year-old Cambodian national, is set to plead guilty on April 2 to two money laundering charges in Singapore's largest money laundering case, worth over S$3 billion. Wenqiang, who was arrested in August 2023, faces a total of 11 charges, including using his benefits from crime to buy luxury items and making false statements in applications for work passes. He has been held in remand for nearly seven months and is married to a person of interest in the case, with two young children.

site_title: BOJ's growing confidence in prices, wages point to end of negative interest rates
summary: Bank of Japan governor Kazuo Ueda and board member Junko Nakagawa signaled the economy is moving towards the central bank's 2% inflation target, increasing market expectations of an imminent end to negative interest rates. The remarks follow a recent surge in wage hike demand and intensifying labor shortages, which could lead to a broad-based pay rise and a stimulus exit. Analysts predict either the March or April meetings as possible timings of the pivot, with the BOJ poised to overhaul its tools when exiting negative rates.

images.alt_text: Kazuo Ueda, governor of the Bank of Japan (BOJ), during a press conference at Hotel Tivoli after the Group of 20 (G-20) finance ministers and central bank governors meeting in Sao Paulo, Brazil, on Thursday, Feb. 29, 2024. Splits over the conflicts in Gaza and Ukraine prevented Group of 20 finance chiefs from issuing a closing communique after their meetings in Sao Paulo. Photographer: Maira Erlich/Bloomberg

site_title: Asia: Markets swing ahead of key US jobs data
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday ahead of key US jobs data, with Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, and Wellington rising, while Hong Kong and Tokyo swung between gains and losses. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell indicated interest rates may start to decrease this year, citing progress on inflation towards the Fed's 2% goal. Investors await the US jobs data release on Friday, which showed a healthy but softening labor market.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.2 per cent to 38,661.05, while the broad-based S&P 500 Index jumped 0.5 per cent to 5,104.76 on Wednesday.
The pan-European Stoxx 600 index climbed 0.4 per cent on Wednesday, with Italy’s FTSE MIB index also hitting a record high.
Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 55 to 28 after 25.7 million securities worth S$27.3 million change hands.

site_title: Van Gogh, Kandinsky stars of the show at Dutch art fair
summary: A rare early work by Vincent van Gogh, "Tete de paysanne a la coiffe blanche" (1884), and a record-selling masterpiece by Wassily Kandinsky, "Blick auf Murnau mit Kirche II" (View of Murnau with Church 2), will be auctioned off at the TEFAF Maastricht art fair in southern Dutch city of Maastricht. The fair, running from Saturday to March 14, features a treasure trove of paintings, sculptures, and jewelry by famous artists like Manet, Rubens, and Rodin.

site_title: Singapore Indoor Stadium to make way for new ‘best-in-class’ indoor arena
summary: Singapore plans to build a new, state-of-the-art indoor arena, replacing the 32-year-old Singapore Indoor Stadium, with a budget of S$165 million over four years. The new arena, designed by Japanese architect Kenzo Tange, will have at least the same capacity as the current stadium and be "future-proofed" to host high-quality international events. The current stadium will continue to operate until the new arena is ready, minimizing disruption to events. A new Major Sports Event Fund will also be set aside to attract more major sports events to Singapore.

images.alt_text: Construction of Hong Kong's Kai Tak Sports Park on the site of the former airport began in 2019. When construction is complete by end-2024, the facility will boast a 50,000-pax stadium.

site_title: Australia and Vietnam upgrade relations, to begin talks on critical minerals
summary: Australia and Vietnam have upgraded their relations to a comprehensive strategic partnership, aiming to diversify supply chains away from China. The partnership will focus on critical minerals, including rare earths, with an annual ministerial dialogue on energy and minerals. The move marks a significant shift in Vietnam's "bamboo diplomacy" strategy, as it boosts ties with key powers amid rising global tensions. The partnership will support cooperation on climate, environment, energy, defense, and economic engagement.

images.alt_text: The Australian Bureau of Statistics reported the balance on goods widened in January to A$11.03 billion (S$9.7 billion), from A$10.74 billion in December last year.
The economic slowdown has followed aggressive monetary tightening by the RBA as policymaker look to bring inflation back to its 2 to 3 per cent target range.

site_title: Malaysia’s Anwar warns against attempts to block China’s rise
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim warned against attempts to block China's military and economic rise in the Asia-Pacific region, urging South-east Asian countries to defend international law and cooperate. He stated that such attempts would be seen as a denial of China's "legitimate place in history." Anwar emphasized the importance of cooperation to maintain regional stability and prevent conflicts.

Malaysia, a major hub in the semiconductor supply chain, is seen as well placed to grab further business as Chinese chip firms diversify outside of China for assembling needs.
Malaysia welcomed 498,540 Chinese tourists in the six months to June this year, a figure almost a third of pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Lufthansa doubles profit in 2023 as demand booms
summary: Lufthansa reported a net profit of 1.67 billion euros in 2023, doubling its 2022 profit of 791 million euros. The aviation sector's rebound from the pandemic is attributed to "continued high demand for travel" and a record result in its maintenance division. This marks the second straight year of profits for the group, following two years of losses due to pandemic-related border closures. The company faces ongoing challenges, including recent strikes by workers seeking higher pay rises.

images.alt_text: Lufthansa's adjusted operating profit will exceed 2.6 billion euros (S$3.76 billion) this year, after hitting 1.47 billion euros in the third quarter, beating analyst estimates.

site_title: UK house prices rise for 5th month in a row, says lender Halifax
summary: UK house prices rose 0.4% in February, marking the fifth consecutive month of growth, according to Halifax. The average home value increased to $371,710, 1.7% higher than last year. Prospective buyers are encouraged by easing mortgage costs and a rosier economic outlook. However, the Office for Budget Responsibility expects average house prices to fall modestly this year. Despite this, Halifax's director, Kim Kinnaird, suggests a stable start to 2024, with increased housing activity.

images.alt_text: British homebuilders have recently highlighted a recovery in buyer interest, but said wider economic concerns gave grounds to be cautious as some trimmed their build targets.

site_title: Tesla quits Australia auto lobby over claims on car emission standards
summary: Tesla is quitting Australia's major auto lobby, the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries (FCAI), due to claims made by the group about the country's proposed fuel efficiency standards and potential impact on car prices. Tesla accused the FCAI of making "demonstrably false" claims, and requested the competition regulator to investigate. The move comes as Australia plans to develop fuel efficiency standards, which could lead to more electric vehicles being sold in the country and boost adoption. Tesla will cease to be a member in June.

site_title: China’s export growth jumps in positive sign for demand
summary: China's exports grew 7.1% in the first two months of 2024, exceeding economists' forecast of 1.9% and beating December's 2.3% gain. Imports grew 3.5%, resulting in a record trade surplus of $125 billion. This positive sign for demand suggests China's economy is finding its footing, providing a boost to the world's second-largest economy.

images.alt_text: Zheng Shanjie, chair of the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC), says he expects the world’s second-largest economy to have a good first quarter.

site_title: Victoria’s Secret falls on weak guidance in faltering turnaround
summary: Victoria's Secret & Co. reported weak net sales guidance for the full year, falling short of analyst estimates, as the company struggles to grow and gain relevance with customers. The retailer expects net sales of $6 billion, down from last year, and comparable sales at Victoria's Secret fell 6% in the quarter ended Feb 3. The shares plummeted 26% in late trading, marking the company's ongoing struggle to turn around its turnaround efforts.

site_title: Cheapest Hong Kong luxury housing has a major catch
summary: Hong Kong's cheapest luxury housing, Sea Ranch on Lantau Island, offers apartments for HK$5.3 million (S$906,383) with stunning sea views. However, the remote location has no direct transport links, shops, or medical facilities, and is often referred to as a "ghost town" surrounded by jungle. Despite its isolation, Sea Ranch provides an affordable option for buyers seeking luxury real estate, with prices significantly lower than those in nearby areas like Discovery Bay.

images.alt_text: Non-residents do not have to pay a combined 15 per cent tax when purchasing properties while owners can sell their homes anytime without paying special duty.

site_title: UK’s ITV expects ad recovery to boost profits
summary: ITV, a UK broadcaster, expects a recovery in the advertising market to boost profits this year, driven by growth in its Studios production business and digital revenue. The company reported a 32% drop in full-year adjusted operating profit to £489 million in 2023, but forecast a 3% increase in total advertising revenue in the first quarter of 2024. ITVX, its streaming platform, also demonstrated success with its drama "Mr Bates vs the Post Office," attracting 14 million viewers. The company expects to deliver at least £750 million of digital revenue by 2026.

site_title: Sri Lanka ex-leader claims ousted over China investments
summary: Former Sri Lankan President Gotabaya Rajapaksa has claimed in his book that "geopolitical rivalry" between China and other countries, fueled by Chinese-funded infrastructure projects in Sri Lanka after 2006, led to his overthrow in 2022. Rajapaksa, who was forced into temporary exile, defends his government's economic policies that led to a foreign debt default and severe shortages. He accuses protesters of having "foreign funding" without providing evidence, and claims that the US warned Sri Lanka of the risks of signing infrastructure deals with China.

site_title: Foreign buyers drive Japanese stocks to new highs with renewed investments
summary: Foreigners purchased a net 68.31 billion yen (S$616.6 million) of Japanese stocks in the week to March 1, a significant increase from the previous week's marginal 2.83 billion yen of net selling. This surge in foreign investment drove Japanese stocks to new highs, bolstered by positive global market sentiment. The majority of the investments were in cash equities, with 383.48 billion yen worth of shares purchased.

images.alt_text: A woman walks past an electronic board displaying a share price of the Nikkei index of the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Tokyo, Japan, March 4, 2024.

site_title: FTX reaches settlement with BlockFi, may pay up to US$874 million
summary: FTX has reached a settlement with BlockFi, agreeing to pay up to $874 million to the bankrupt crypto company. The settlement, subject to US bankruptcy judge approval, includes a $250 million payment to BlockFi and the remainder contingent on FTX repaying its own customers. FTX also agreed to pay an additional $185.3 million to BlockFi, accounting for funds held in FTX trading accounts when the exchange collapsed. The deal resolves a dispute between the two companies, which had loaned each other before their 2022 bankruptcies.

site_title: China will ‘legitimately defend rights’ in South China Sea: Foreign minister
summary: China's foreign minister Wang Yi stated that Beijing will "legitimately defend" its rights in the South China Sea, amid rising tensions with the Philippines. China claims nearly the entire sea, despite competing claims from Southeast Asian nations and an international arbitration ruling that its stance has no legal basis. The country has clashed with Philippine ships in recent months, with the most recent incident occurring on March 5. Wang urged "certain countries" not to stir up trouble in the region, while China's coast guard fired water cannons at a Philippine resupply vessel.

site_title: Hong Kong stock exchange poised to name Carlson Tong as new chair: sources
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange, HKEX, is set to name Carlson Tong as its new chairman, replacing Laura Cha, according to sources. Tong, a 69-year-old non-executive director, has emerged as the frontrunner for the role. The appointment is subject to the approval of Hong Kong's chief executive. The change comes as the exchange faces challenges, including a faltering economy and geopolitical tensions. Tong will work alongside new CEO Bonnie Chan to devise a plan to address these challenges, following a recent reshuffle of the management structure.

site_title: Sias urges Great Eastern to address minority investors’ concerns instead of dismissing them on legal technicality
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) (Sias) has urged Great Eastern's board to "seriously consider" minority shareholders' concerns, instead of dismissing them on a legal technicality. The minority investor group had proposed three resolutions to address undervaluation of Great Eastern shares, including withholding directors' fees and replacing OCBC shares in executive share option schemes. Sias emphasized the importance of addressing persistent underperformance and aligning directors' interests with those of all shareholders. The investor association encouraged the board to exercise discretion and consider the spirit of the law to include the resolutions on the AGM agenda.
