site_title: Brokers’ take: Proposed policy changes could drive cost savings for ComfortDelGro
summary: Singapore's planned policy changes to the point-to-point transport services sector are expected to benefit ComfortDelGro, the country's largest taxi operator. The government will update regulations to lower taxi operating costs and rationalize inspection regimes. The changes include raising the statutory lifespan of non-electric taxis to 10 years, potentially leading to lower taxi rentals. Analysts believe this could translate to cost savings for ComfortDelGro, supporting their "buy" calls on the stock.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

If adjusted to exclude the one-off gain recognised in FY22 from the sale of the Alperton property in London, the earnings had in fact risen 26.6 per cent, from FY22’s S$142.6 million, the company highlighted.

The government says that having a separate Certificate of Entitlement (COE) category for private hire cars is possible, but the trade-offs must be studied carefully.

site_title: Apple’s 1.8 billion euro fine heralds a new antitrust dawn
summary: The European Union has fined Apple 1.8 billion euros for allegedly abusing its App Store, marking a new era of swift and efficient antitrust enforcement in Europe. The Digital Markets Act (DMA) comes into force, allowing regulators to impose fines and penalties without needing to prove consumer harm. The DMA offers a new approach to regulating tech giants, focusing on fairness and transparency. The fine is a significant step towards Europe's regulators taking a more proactive role in policing Silicon Valley's biggest companies, and signals a shift away from the traditional Chicago School approach that prioritizes market-driven outcomes.

images.alt_text: “For a decade, Apple abused its dominant position in the market for the distribution of music streaming apps through the App Store,” says EU antitrust chief Margrethe Vestager. “They did so by restricting developers from informing consumers about alternative, cheaper music services available outside of the Apple ecosystem.”

This photo taken on February 12, 2023 in Brussels shows reflexions on a smartphone screen of logos of online platforms google, facebook, linkedin, Amazon, Apple store and Tiktok as the European Commission announced last September the world's biggest digital firms, identified as "gatekeepers" by the EU, must comply from March 6, 2024, with strict do's and don'ts under a landmark law, the Digital Markets Act (DMA). The EU has built a powerful legal arsenal to take on the internet giants, including the DMA which seeks to encourage competition in the digital world, and its sister milestone law, the Digital Services Act (DSA). The DSA demands the most popular social networks and websites police content online more aggressively and protect consumers while they shop. (Photo by Kenzo TRIBOUILLARD / AFP)

site_title: Consumer goods enabler Ai Palette bags US$4 million from Tin Men
summary: Singapore-based tech startup Ai Palette has raised US$4 million from B2B-focused venture capital firm Tin Men Capital, bringing its total Series A1 funding to US$5.8 million. Ai Palette uses AI and machine learning to enable consumer packaged goods companies like Nestle and Kellogg's to capture consumption trends, generate product ideas, and improve cost efficiency. With the new funds, the startup plans to expand into the beauty and nutraceutical spaces, improve its generative AI capabilities, and enter new regions, including North America, Europe, and Asia-Pacific.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
FILE PHOTO: People walk along Nanjing Pedestrian Road, a main shopping area, in Shanghai, China May 5, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song

site_title: Qatar Airways says traffic up 31% in first two months on travel boom
summary: Qatar Airways reported a 31% increase in traffic for the first two months of the year, driven by a travel boom. The airline is expanding its network with more frequencies and new destinations, including Hamburg, Germany, to benefit from resurging demand. This growth is particularly strong in Europe to Asia routes, with markets like Thailand in high demand. Qatar Airways is leveraging its position as a connecting airline with its hub in Doha to capitalize on the increased travel demand.

site_title: DBS adjusts sustainable-financing policy to include early retirement of coal plants
summary: DBS, Southeast Asia's largest lender, has adjusted its sustainable-financing policy to include early retirement of coal plants. The bank's chief sustainability officer, Helge Muenkel, said it will be "super transparent" about early coal phase-out deals, releasing information on exposure to projects and emissions intensity. Despite a slight increase in financed emissions in the power sector, DBS remains on track to meet its decarbonisation goals. The bank has committed S$70 billion to sustainable financing and facilitated S$18 billion in environmental, social and governance bond issuances in 2023.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Sheng Siong says it is actively working to reduce both its own environmental footprint and that of its supply chain by encouraging SMEs within its network to embrace sustainable business practices.

FILE PHOTO: Smoke and steam billow from Belchatow Power Station, Europe's largest coal-fired power plant powered by lignite, operated by Polish utility PGE, in Rogowiec, Poland, November 22, 2023. REUTERS/Kacper Pempel/File Photo
MAS forms global coalition to develop transition carbon credits for coal-plant closures

Out of the five investment areas the document has set out, financing the early phase-out of coal has been the more contentious one for the local banks, as the commercial viability of such transactions has not been worked out.

site_title: Birds, beetles, bugs could help replace pesticides: study
summary: Researchers in Brazil, the US, and the Czech Republic analyzed past studies on natural predators controlling pests and found that they reduced pest populations by over 70% and increased crop yields by 25%. The study suggests that birds, beetles, and bugs could be effective alternatives to chemical pesticides, especially in regions with greater rain variability. The researchers also found that having a single species of natural predator was as effective as having multiple species, highlighting the importance of conservation efforts to maintain ecosystem health.

images.alt_text: Farmers in Poland block a road with tractors during a protest on Feb 9. Recent weeks have seen such protests across Europe, fuelled by discontent over various issues including some green policies.

site_title: Why Russia still can’t defeat Ukraine
summary: Russia's ability to defeat Ukraine remains elusive due to its own internal challenges and the country's increasing isolation. Despite some military successes, Putin's hope to restore Russia's brotherly ties to Ukraine has evaporated, and the country is headed for deepening isolation, impoverishment, and irrelevance. Western resources are focused on bolstering Ukraine's resistance, but managing Russia's unpredictable risks as a sullen, nuclear-armed, and resource-rich outcast is a greater challenge. The US and its allies must prepare for more global headaches from Russia, which has few incentives to cooperate and plenty of reasons to cause havoc.

images.alt_text: A makeshift memorial to late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, who died in a Russian Arctic prison, in front of the former Russian consulate in Frankfurt am Main, Germany, on Feb 20, 2024.
The Russia-Ukraine war has affected food security and energy prices, and it has been accompanied by massive disinformation and political destabilisation campaigns.
Putin’s Silk Road around sanctions

site_title: Paris 2024 organisers to invite 222,000 spectators to opening ceremony
summary: Paris 2024 Olympics organisers will invite 222,000 spectators to the opening ceremony, in addition to 104,000 paying spectators, bringing the total to 326,000. This revised total is nearly half of the original estimated 600,000 attendees. The spectators will be chosen by cities and organising bodies, with a security screening process supervised by intelligence services. The number of attendees may be revised downward if necessary.

site_title: Amazon cancels fees for customers moving to rival cloud services
summary: Amazon has canceled fees for customers moving to rival cloud services, following Google's recent move. The decision, announced by AWS vice-president Robert Kennedy, allows customers to transfer data to another provider without incurring charges. The change comes amid intensifying scrutiny of cloud services by regulators and lawmakers. The fees, which covered networking and infrastructure costs, were previously used to cover the costs of data extraction. The move is seen as a response to increasing competition in the cloud market, where Amazon, Google, and Microsoft are vying for dominance.

site_title: India tells banks to stop exclusive deals on credit cards
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), has ordered lenders to stop exclusive deals with credit card networks like Visa and Mastercard, citing terms that restrict customer choice. Banks must now offer customers the option to choose from multiple card networks at the time of issue, and existing cardholders can select their networks at renewal. This move aims to promote competition and increase consumer choice in the market.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Mastercard and Visa credit cards are seen in front of displayed Wirecard logo in this illustration picture taken June 26, 2020. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Singtel launches authentication solution SingVerify to tackle scams
summary: Singtel has launched SingVerify, a suite of authentication solutions to protect customer data and mitigate frauds. The solution simplifies complicated authentication processes and enables real-time verification of customers' digital identities between the telco and service providers. Number Verify is the first solution launched, validating customers' identities using their phone numbers and SIM card data. The device location API, expected to be launched in the second quarter, will allow companies to find users' real-time locations based on cell tower data.

site_title: 5 Questions with founder-turned-ecosystem builder Lim Jui
summary: Dr. Lim Jui, CEO of Singapore's deep-tech ecosystem builder SGInnovate, shares his unconventional journey from being a medical doctor to running a government-backed agency. He attributes his success to following his gut and taking calculated risks. Lim emphasizes the importance of nurturing a deep-tech ecosystem, which involves dollar investment, talent development, and community building. He advises his younger self to start a family earlier and shares two mantras: "Do first and say sorry later" and "three strikes and you're out," which guide his approach to innovation and risk-taking. Despite facing setbacks, Lim views his journey as an opportunity for growth and learning.

site_title: Philippine central bank governor rules out easing rates ‘soon’
summary: Philippine Central Bank Governor Eli Remolona ruled out rate cuts soon, citing upside inflation risks and a desire to ensure inflation remains within the 2-4% target range. Annual inflation in February rose to 3.4%, driven by higher food and transport costs. Remolona stated that the central bank will review policy on April 4, but emphasized the need to be cautious and avoid premature easing. Interest rates have remained at 6.5% for three consecutive meetings since late last year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A security guard stands beside a logo of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (Central Bank of the Philippines) posted at the main gate in Manila, Philippines April 28, 2016. REUTERS/Romeo Ranoco/File Photo

site_title: Saudis lift oil price to Asia after Opec+ extends output cuts
summary: Saudi Arabia has increased the price of its main oil grade, Arab Light crude, for Asian buyers by $1.70 a barrel to $80.60, amid Opec+ extending output cuts until the end of June to avert a global surplus and shore up prices. The decision comes as crude prices have traded in a tight range around $80 a barrel due to concerns over demand and economic growth. Opec+ also halted an expansion of its production capacity to 13 million barrels a day, raising speculation about mid-term demand.

site_title: Gold slips from record peak but holds above US$2,100 ahead of Powell testimony
summary: Gold prices slipped 0.2% to $2,124.46 per ounce on Wednesday, holding above the $2,100 level ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's testimony. The price hit a record peak of $2,141.59 per ounce on Tuesday, driven by rising bets on a June interest rate cut. Money market pricing shows a 71% probability of a rate cut, up from 65% on Tuesday morning. The US services industry growth slowed in February, while benchmark 10-year US Treasury yields hovered near a one-month low, making non-yielding bullion more attractive.

images.alt_text: London’s gold price benchmark hit an all-time high of US$2,098.05 per troy ounce at an afternoon auction on Monday.

site_title: Singapore seeks to woo drivers to EVs with splashy campaign
summary: Singapore is launching a campaign to promote electric vehicles (EVs) among residents, with a focus on making EVs more appealing and affordable. Despite EVs accounting for 18% of new car registrations last year, they still make up less than 2% of total passenger vehicles. The government aims to phase out internal combustion engine cars by 2030 and has set a goal of 60,000 EV charging points by the same year. Incentives and rebates are being offered to encourage car ownership, but high costs remain a barrier for many Singaporeans.

images.alt_text: Xie Yihui/Bloomberg

site_title: DBS chief Piyush Gupta’s 2023 salary down 27% at S$11.2 million after pay cut
summary: DBS CEO Piyush Gupta's 2023 salary decreased by 27% to S$11.2 million, following a 30% cut in variable pay. His base salary remained unchanged at S$1.5 million. Gupta's reduced total remuneration includes a lower cash bonus and deferred remuneration, with approximately S$4.6 million to be issued as shares. DBS's FY2023 financial results showed a 3% year-on-year drop in net profit to S$2.27 billion.

site_title: Optus fined A$1.5 million by Australian government on public safety rule breach
summary: Optus, a unit of Singtel, has been fined A$1.5 million by the Australian government for breaching public safety rules by failing to upload customer data to a database used by emergency services. The fine followed an investigation by the Australian Communications and Media Authority (Acma), which found that nearly 200,000 customers' information was not uploaded between 2021 and 2023. Optus has agreed to an independent review and may face further fines if found to have failed to comply with industry code.

site_title: Indranee Rajah to discuss upskilling of Singapore’s workforce at ST-BT Budget 2024 roundtable
summary: Second Minister for Finance and National Development Indranee Rajah will discuss the need for upskilling and upgrading Singapore's workforce at a roundtable on March 7, amid the ongoing Committee of Supply debates. The roundtable aims to address how Budget 2024's initiatives can help upskill mid-career workers, with a focus on the SkillsFuture Level-Up programme, which includes a S$4,000 top-up and a monthly training allowance for those aged 40 and above. The panel will also explore issues such as technological advancements, low take-up rates, and ageism bias among employers.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
The SkillsFuture Credit will now have two tiers. At age 25, Singaporeans will receive a base tier of S$500 that does not expire. This can be used for a wide range of over 28,000 approved courses.
Singaporeans aged 40 and above will receive full government subsidies to pursue a second diploma at polytechnics, Institute of Technical Education, and arts institutions.

site_title: Sell-offs show tech players’ pursuit of profitability not enough to win over investors
summary: Regional tech companies' pursuit of profitability has not convinced investors, despite achieving positive cash flow and growth targets. Shares of Grab and Sea slid after reporting below-forecast revenue, highlighting the need for sustainable growth and profitability. Despite their core businesses showing decent growth, these companies must balance profitability with long-term growth, as investors bet on their ability to quickly grow market share. Market reactions suggest investors are looking for companies to demonstrate both financial sustainability and growth potential.

Grab crosses into the black for 4Q 2023

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Wednesday’s open; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore shares rose at the opening bell on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.3% to 3,116.94. The broader market saw 53.4 million securities worth S$51.8 million trade, with gainers outnumbering losers 73 to 49. Key gainers included Seatrium, Thai Beverage, and mm2 Asia. Banking stocks also rose, with DBS, OCBC, and UOB climbing 0.3%, 0.2%, and 0.2% respectively.

images.alt_text: Singtel's Australian unit Optus was fined A$1.5 million (S$1.3 million) over large-scale breaches of public safety rules.

site_title: China investors rush abroad, hitting outbound investment limits and moves to stabilise yuan
summary: China's outbound investment surged in January, exceeding the country's outbound investment limits and complicating efforts to stabilize the yuan and revive domestic markets. QDII fund units sold increased 50% year-on-year, while domestic equity mutual funds dropped 35%. Assets under management for QDII funds rose 19% year-on-year, driven by low confidence at home and a desire for diversification among wealthy clients. The QDII scheme is capped at $165.5 billion, and managers are struggling to keep up with demand, with some turning away prospective investors or searching for workarounds.

China's five per cent target would be in line with its GDP growth last year, one of the country’s lowest in decades and a far cry from the double-digit growth that long drove its breakneck development in the nineties and 2000s.

site_title: Australia economy slows to a crawl, underscoring case for rate cuts
summary: Australia's economy grew at a slow 0.2% in the December quarter, beating forecasts, but annual growth slowed to 1.5%, the lowest since 2021. Household spending remained stagnant, and the balance of risks in the economy is shifting from inflation to growth, prompting the Reserve Bank of Australia to consider rate cuts. Treasurer Jim Chalmers declared that the central bank's focus should pivot from containing inflation to stimulating economic growth, with markets pricing in the first rate cut for August.

images.alt_text: The Singapore-Australia Green and Digital Shipping Corridor will explore facilitating digital information exchange to enable efficient port clearance, port calls and flow of vessels between Singapore and Australia.

Any deals that may be reached during the Australia-Asean summit are expected to be modest.

site_title: Australian dollar struggles as economy comes to a standstill
summary: The Australian dollar is under pressure due to soft economic data, with markets implying a 42% chance of a rate cut in June and 86% for August. The Aussie dollar fell to a two-week trough of US$0.6477, while the New Zealand dollar eased to a near three-week low of US$0.6071. This suggests investors expect future rate cuts to support economic growth.

images.alt_text: The economic slowdown has followed aggressive monetary tightening by the RBA as policymaker look to bring inflation back to its 2 to 3 per cent target range.
The euro rises 0.13 per cent to US$1.08.

site_title: Pacific Islands face challenges as growth slows, says World Bank
summary: Pacific Islands countries are expected to experience 3.5% growth in 2024 and 3.3% in 2025, according to the World Bank. Despite a rebound in tourism and remittances in some countries, growth slowed to 5.5% in 2023 due to shocks from cyclones and drought. Fiji's economy, which accounts for half of Pacific Islands output, grew 8% in 2023, while others like Nauru and Vanuatu lagged. The World Bank urges investment in education and calls for the US to renew funding agreements for Compact of Free Association States.

images.alt_text: The World Bank's report assesses, for the first time, how 190 countries are implementing existing laws to protect women. It reveals a 'shocking' gap between policy and practice.

site_title: Australian pension fund buys Sydney airport site to build A$3.9 billion logistics hub
summary: Australian pension fund UniSuper has acquired a 280-hectare site adjacent to Sydney's new international airport for A$3.9 billion to develop a logistics hub. The 50/50 joint venture with ISPT aims to build a 400,000-square-metre manufacturing, warehouse, and logistics hub over the next seven years. The site's potential for expansion was raised, with the possibility of doubling the hub's size subject to planning approvals and demand. This marks UniSuper's second major property deal in three weeks, following a A$260 million purchase in Melbourne last month.

images.alt_text: AustralianSuper will invest in UK assets such as precinct developments, digital infrastructure, ports and the energy transition.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, Nio, 17Live, mm2 Asia
summary: Singtel's Australian unit Optus was fined A$1.5 million for large-scale breaches of public safety rules, failing to upload customer information to a database used by emergency services between 2021 and 2023. Nio reported a narrower loss for the fourth quarter due to higher vehicle sales margin. 17Live and mm2 Asia signed a memorandum of understanding for joint entertainment offerings across South-east Asia.

site_title: South Korea inflation quickens in February after three months of easing
summary: South Korea's consumer inflation accelerated to 3.1% in February, surpassing market expectations, after three months of easing. The fastest jump since September was driven by a 5.7% increase in agricultural products. Policymakers expect inflation to stabilize after a volatile February and March, despite the Bank of Korea holding interest rates steady last month. The central bank aims to keep inflation below its 2% target.

images.alt_text: A customer picks up a lunch box at a convenience store in Seoul, South Korea, June 24, 2022. Picture taken June 24, 2022.  REUTERS/ Heo Ran

site_title: EU set to allow possible retroactive tariffs for Chinese EVs
summary: The European Commission is set to allow possible retroactive tariffs on Chinese electric vehicle (EV) imports if the investigation concludes they are receiving unfair subsidies. The probe, which began in October, found that imports increased 14% year-on-year and EU producers could suffer harm if imports continue. Registration of Chinese EV imports will start after the plan is published, potentially leading to tariffs. The EU's decision aims to protect domestic producers and is seen as a response to increasing demand for EVs in Europe.

site_title: US: Wall Street stocks tumble as major tech names slide
summary: US stocks plummeted on Tuesday as tech giants Apple, Microsoft, and Tesla slid, with the Nasdaq Composite Index falling 1.7% to 15,939.59. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also declined 1.0% each. Investors await Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's testimony, which may influence interest rate decisions. Analysts predict market consolidation, while one expert believes the market can still rise slightly in the short term. Economic data, including services sector activity and employment figures, will also be closely watched this week.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average falls 82.85 points, or 0.21 per cent, at the open to 38,906.98.

site_title: Climate change and nuclear waste are a toxic stew
summary: Climate change is exacerbating the risks associated with nuclear power and waste storage. Rising temperatures and chaotic weather patterns are making it harder to build and maintain nuclear facilities, with wildfires and floods threatening sites around the world. The US military has buried nuclear waste in Greenland, which could be disturbed by rising sea levels, and nuclear power plants are increasingly vulnerable to disasters like Fukushima. Experts warn that the lack of preparedness and resilience mechanisms in nuclear operations makes them ill-equipped to handle the rapidly evolving risks posed by climate change.

images.alt_text: The success shrouds a complicated relationship that Los Alamos has with its past and with Oppenheimer, who is played by Cillian Murphy.
Tokamak Energy's CEO Warrick Matthews (left) and Dr Victor Nian of the Centre for Strategic Energy and Resources see room for Singapore to play an active role in nuclear fusion research.

site_title: Ozempic is transforming the health of Denmark’s economy
summary: Novo Nordisk's weight-loss drug Ozempic has had a significant impact on Denmark's economy, preventing a recession in 2023. The company's success has transformed the nation's health, with Ozempic being a major contributor to the pharmaceutical industry. This reliance on a single company raises new economic and political dynamics, similar to those experienced by mid-sized economies dependent on natural resources. The phenomenon highlights the outsized effect a single company can have on a nation's economy and health.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Flags with the Novo Nordisk logo flutter outside their Danish company's offices in Copenhagen, Denmark, September 26, 2023. REUTERS/Tom Little/File Photo
The pharmaceutical giant has applied to build a campus covering 147,192 square metres in Clondalkin which would create up to 1,100 jobs in the region.

site_title: Citigroup CEO sees rising fees in investment banking, weaker markets revenue
summary: Citigroup CEO Jane Fraser expects a low-teens percentage increase in investment banking fees in the first quarter, with markets revenue expected to drop 8-12% compared to the previous year. The bank's financial results are likely to be better than expected, despite regulatory issues and a sweeping reorganisation aimed at improving data governance and risk management. Fraser plans to complete the reorganisation by the end of the month and will hold an investor day on June 18 to discuss the services business, which reported record revenue of $18.1 billion last year.

images.alt_text: The logo of Citigroup Inc. at the entrance to the bank's office in Paris, France, on Monday, Feb. 27, 2023. Citigroup is building a new trading floor in Paris as the Wall Street giant prepares to nearly double its staff in the French city. Photographer Benjamin Girette/Bloomberg

site_title: Goldilocks and the property bears
summary: Singapore's housing market has slowed down, with new home sales at recent project launches lower than expected. Prices have stabilized, and sales are moving at a slow and steady pace post-cooling measures. Sellers with reasonable price expectations can easily find takers, while buyers can browse without feeling pressured to sign on quickly. Suburban condos continue to see steady demand, while new projects in prime locations face slower demand due to higher stamp duty rates. The market's slower pace could be ideal for locals looking to rightsize, but developers are still wary of big-ticket land buys.

images.alt_text: Michelle Low
Wealthy people have been busy property shopping, writes BT senior correspondent Leslie Yee.
Private property owners have baulked at seeing their property tax bills shoot up this year, after a two-tiered tax hike designed as a de facto wealth tax kicked in
Is Meta’s exit from a grade A office building in downtown Singapore a foreshadowing of more vacancies to come?
Wee Cho Yaw's accomplishments stretch far beyond banking, writes BT senior correspondent Leslie Yee.
Residential rents are starting to come off their highs., writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.

site_title: Australia’s Qantas fined for firing worker who raised Covid-19 safety concerns
summary: Qantas Airways has been fined A$250,000 (S$218,421) for illegally firing an employee who raised Covid-19 safety concerns. The employee, Theo Seremetidis, a lift truck driver at Sydney airport, had ordered workers not to clean aircraft arriving from China, leading to his termination. The New South Wales state district court found Qantas guilty of "discriminatory conduct for a prohibited reason" and ordered the airline to pay Seremetidis A$21,000. The fine is part of the airline's ongoing efforts to address reputational challenges amid several lawsuits and controversies.

images.alt_text: Qantas posted an underlying profit before tax of A$1.25 billion (S$1.06 billion) for the six months ended Dec 31, compared with A$1.43 billion a year earlier.

John Mullen's appointment comes after Qantas' reputation was shredded by claims it sold tickets for thousands of flights it had already cancelled, leading to the early departure of former chief executive officer Alan Joyce.
The findings inflict further damage to the Qantas brand after a string of reputational crises.
Australia’s competition regulator is seeking a record fine of more than A$250 million after suing Qantas for allegedly selling seats on thousands of cancelled flights last year.

site_title: US vows to keep Boeing under microscope after audit
summary: US Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg vows to keep Boeing under the microscope after a six-week audit found multiple instances of non-compliance with manufacturing quality control requirements. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has limited Boeing's aircraft production to address quality issues, a step deemed "unprecedented." Boeing has committed to addressing the concerns and developing a comprehensive plan to fix systemic quality-control issues within 90 days. The FAA's audit was prompted by a mid-air emergency involving a 737 MAX 9 in January, and regulators will continue to monitor Boeing's production to ensure safety.

site_title: Temasek in discussions to invest in OpenAI: sources
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singaporean state-backed investment firm, is in talks to invest in OpenAI, the maker of ChatGPT, according to sources. The talks come as OpenAI CEO Sam Altman seeks funding to build a semiconductor business to reduce dependence on Nvidia chips. Despite being lossmaking, OpenAI has seen huge revenue growth since ChatGPT's launch in 2022, with employees participating in a stock sale that valued the company at $86 billion. Preliminary discussions are ongoing, with no agreement on investment size.

images.alt_text: Musk sues OpenAI and its chief executive Sam Altman (above) for allegedly breaking their founding agreement
Musk is bringing the suit in the capacity of a donor to OpenAI’s non-profit parent organisation as recently as 2019 and is seeking to force OpenAI to stop benefiting Microsoft and Altman personally.
The lawsuit filed late on Thursday (Feb 29) says Altman and OpenAI’s co-founder Greg Brockman originally approached Musk (above) to make an open source, non-profit company.
Even as OpenAI tries to turn the page on the dismissal of CEO Sam Altman, who was soon reinstated, the controversy continues to hound the company.

site_title: Cryptoverse: Asian traders give Bitcoin blast-off
summary: Asian traders are driving Bitcoin's recent surge, accounting for 70% of trading volumes and $791 billion of the $1.17 trillion worth of Bitcoin traded in February. Investors in South Korea, China, and other Asian countries are fueled by FOMO and anticipation of the "halving" event, which could reduce supply and push prices up. The trend is similar to 2021, when Bitcoin reached record highs. Despite this, North American investors lag behind, with $113 billion in trading volume in February.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Dollar banknotes are seen in this illustration taken July 17, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Bitcoin has gained 50 per cent this year and most of the rise has come in the last few weeks when inflows into US-listed bitcoin funds have surged.
The launch of spot Bitcoin exchange-traded funds has opened the way for new large investors, and has re-ignited enthusiasm and momentum reminiscent of the run-up to record levels in 2021.

site_title: UK digital bank Monzo valued at £4 billion after new funding round
summary: UK digital bank Monzo has raised £340 million at a valuation of £4 billion after a new funding round led by CapitalG and GV. The funds will be used to expand and introduce new products, following the company's profitability in March 2023.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip after China reforms underwhelm; tech leads losses
summary: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index declined 0.3% on Tuesday after China failed to meet investors' expectations with its economic stimulus measures, leading to a drop in mining shares. Technology stocks also fell 1.6%, while utilities rose 1.8% as bond yields dropped. The index hit an all-time high the previous day, and investors await this week's eurozone and US economic data and the European Central Bank's policy decision.

site_title: BYD spearheads Chinese electric car push in Australia, a friendlier market
summary: Chinese automaker BYD is expanding its presence in Australia, a market where it has not faced trade barriers, with a surge in electric vehicle (EV) sales. Since 2022, BYD has seen sales climb nearly six times to over 12,000 vehicles, with 14% of the Australian EV market. The government has introduced tax exemptions for EV leasing/purchase agreements, and state governments have set goals for EVs to account for 50% of all new car sales by 2030. BYD plans to add two SUVs and a pickup truck to its product line-up in Australia this year, with distributor EVDirect opening 30 more dealerships in the next 18 months.

images.alt_text: BYD has been counting on overseas markets for higher profit margins.
BYD, which operates in 51 locations across Japan, including 22 dealerships, aims to reach 100 by the end of 2025.

Chinese EV makers have been counting on South-east Asia, the Middle East and Europe as their largest exporting markets. There are relatively few Chinese-made light duty vehicles being imported into the US.
BYD is particularly cost-competitive and aggressive among Chinese players, according to executives from its Chinese rivals already selling cars in Mexico.

site_title: Pringles chips see surging demand, igniting expansion in Asia
summary: Kellanova, the parent company of Pringles, is experiencing a surge in demand for the popular snack, prompting the company to expand production in Asia and Mexico. CEO Steve Cahillane stated that Pringles is selling out rapidly and that the company is opening new factories to meet the demand. This growth is seen as a strategic move to gain market share and capitalize on the snack market. The company's focus on high-growth brands like Pringles and its presence in African countries, particularly Nigeria, are key factors in this expansion.

images.alt_text: Those hoping that human entomophagy will lead to more sustainable global food systems should be careful what they wish for.

site_title: Oil falls 1% on concerns over China’s economic growth plan
summary: Oil prices fell nearly 1% on Tuesday as investors expressed skepticism over China's economic growth target of around 5% in 2024, despite similar expectations. The US dollar weakened, supporting oil prices, while risk-off sentiment in financial markets also put downward pressure. The latest weekly US inventory reports are expected to show increased crude stocks, which could further weigh on prices. Brent crude futures settled at $82.04 a barrel, down 76 US cents, or 0.9%, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 59 US cents, or 0.8%.

images.alt_text: Brent futures settled 75 cents lower to US$82.80 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) settled US$1.24, or 1.5 per cent, lower to US$78.74 a barrel on Monday.

site_title: Toyota confirms 11 billion real investment in Brazil by 2030
summary: Toyota has confirmed an 11 billion real (S$3 billion) investment in Brazil by 2030, broken down into two parts with 5 billion reais invested until 2026 and 6 billion reais allocated up to 2030. The investment will support the production of a new hybrid flex vehicle by 2025 and a car designed specifically for the Brazilian market, with expansions at factories in Porto Feliz and Sorocaba.

images.alt_text: Toyota has issued three other recalls in the US over last two weeks.
Instead of reaching a pact on wages and bonuses, Toyota and union deepened their debate over workplace issues on Wednesday.

Output for January increased to 740,332 vehicles, while worldwide sales rose about 11 per cent from a year earlier as growth in overseas markets such as the United States made up for declining sales in Japan.
FILE PHOTO: The Toyota logo is seen at its booth during a media day for the Auto Shanghai show in Shanghai, China April 19, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Does AI hype echo the dot-com bubble?
summary: The article suggests that the current AI hype may be reminiscent of the dot-com bubble of the 1990s, where stocks with no earnings and stretched valuations were seen as "buy" due to their dot-com names. Analysts are now using metrics such as "price-to-innovation ratios" to value AI companies, which may lead to inflated valuations and a potential bubble. However, some AI companies, like Nvidia, have reasonable valuations, and investors should tread carefully in navigating the market with "casino-like" behavior.

images.alt_text: The world’s top chip foundry jumped 5.2 per cent to close at NT$725 (S$30.89) in Taipei on Monday (Mar 4), a record since its stock listing in 1994.
Nvidia’s rise from niche chipmaker to one of the biggest companies in the world is based on the premise that its phenomenal sales growth over the past year has staying power.

site_title: OCBC Cycle returns in May with new category for foldable bikes
summary: OCBC Cycle, Singapore's largest cycling event, will return in May with a new 40 km category for foldable bikes. The "Foldie Ride by Brompton" will cater to the growing number of cyclists who ride foldable two-wheelers. Over 7,000 cyclists from 10 categories are expected to participate, with 1,000 riders taking part in the new foldable bike category. The event marks the 16th edition of OCBC Cycle, which aims to promote cycling and sustainability in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Team Boss is fielding an all-female team at this year's BT Corporate Golf League. The event tees off on Thursday.

Nominations are open for the Sustainability Impact Awards 
2024 jointly presented by The Business Times (BT) and UOB  for second year. PHOTO: CHERYL ONG, BT

site_title: US services sector cools in February: ISM survey
summary: The US services sector's growth slowed in February, with the Institute for Supply Management's non-manufacturing PMI declining to 52.6 from 53.4 in January. Despite a six-month high in new orders and a five-month high in business activity, employment declined, and inflation slowed. The services sector accounts for over two-thirds of the US economy, and the data suggests continued economic expansion despite interest rate hikes. The Federal Reserve is expected to start cutting rates this year, but inflation remains high.

The Institute for Supply Management (ISM) says its manufacturing index stood at 47.8 per cent last month, down from 49.1 per cent a month earlier.
The sentiment index declines to 76.9 from 79 in January, according to the final February reading from the University of Michigan.

site_title: Adnoc says AI added US$500 million of extra value in 2023
summary: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (Adnoc) reported a US$500 million increase in value generated by artificial intelligence (AI) in 2023. The state oil giant has integrated over 30 AI tools across processes, including field operations, corporate decision-making, and resource mapping. AI technology has reduced unexpected shutdowns, improved efficiency, and aided in reservoir management, resulting in a reduction of up to one million tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions between 2022 and 2023. Adnoc plans to roll out the technology further, with Chief Technology Officer Sophie Hildebrand expecting the value generated by AI to rise.

images.alt_text: “The increased allocation will include investments to grow the company’s domestic and international carbon management platforms,” Adnoc says.

COP28 president Sultan Ahmed Al Jaber speaks during a press conference at the United Nations climate summit in Dubai on December 4, 2023. site_title: US: Nasdaq leads Wall St lower ahead of economic data
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday as the Nasdaq led losses, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 82.85 points and the S&P 500 down 20.43 points. The tech-heavy Nasdaq dropped 129.77 points, or 0.80%, ahead of economic data and key events, including Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's appearances.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., February 29, 2024.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: WTO backs EU in deforestation case against Malaysia
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has ruled in favor of the European Union (EU) in a case against Malaysia over deforestation. A three-person panel voted 2-1 to reject Malaysia's claims, while accepting complaints about the EU's measures on palm oil biodiesel. The EU must make adjustments but does not need to withdraw its measures, as the WTO's first ruling on deforestation has deemed the treatment of products according to their greenhouse gas emissions risks to be discriminatory.

images.alt_text: The expansion will be done in phases based on the readiness of biodiesel blending facilities across Malaysia, Commodities Minister Fadillah Yusof says.
Malaysia says the EU law is a “deliberate effort” to increase costs and barriers for its palm oil sector.

site_title: Qatar Airways says all A350s flying again, a year after Airbus legal dispute
summary: Qatar Airways has completed the return of its Airbus A350 fleet to service after a year-long dispute over damage to the aircraft's painted surface. The airline's chief commercial officer, Thierry Antinori, stated that the issue is now resolved and the fleet is fully operational. Qatar Airways sees opportunities with the increased aircraft in its fleet, particularly in growing markets between Europe, Asia, and Africa. The airline reported strong passenger numbers in January and February, with 7.2 million passengers, a 31% increase from the previous year.

images.alt_text: Airbus is hoping to deliver 720 aircraft this year – a target it initially had set for 2022.

site_title: US factory orders fall more than expected in January
summary: US factory orders fell 3.6% in January, exceeding expectations, as commercial aircraft orders dropped 58.9% after rising 1% in December. Despite this decline, demand for computers and electronic products accelerated. The decline in orders is attributed to interest rate hikes by the US central bank, but a survey from the Institute for Supply Management shows manufacturers are more upbeat about the outlook, suggesting manufacturing may be on the cusp of recovery.

images.alt_text: The Institute for Supply Management (ISM) says on Tuesday (Mar 5) that its non-manufacturing PMI slips to 52.6 last month from 53.4 in January.
The Institute for Supply Management (ISM) says its manufacturing index stood at 47.8 per cent last month, down from 49.1 per cent a month earlier.
The Commerce Department’s Census Bureau says that orders for durable goods, items ranging from toasters to aircraft meant to last three years or more, tumble 6.1 per cent last month.
FILE PHOTO: An employee works on an assembly line at startup Rivian Automotive's electric vehicle factory in Normal, Illinois, U.S. April 11, 2022. REUTERS/Kamil Krzaczynski/File Photo

site_title: Quiet luxury brands ring in greater returns
summary: Quiet luxury brands, characterized by understated elegance and exclusivity, have outperformed in terms of operating margins, revenue growth, and return on equity. Seven out of 30 companies, including Hermès, Moncler, and LVMH, have demonstrated these traits, resulting in a 7-9 percentage point lead over the Nasdaq Composite and global equities. The trend is driven by millennials' conscious consumption, desire for exclusivity, and growing income disparity, which has led to a backlash against ostentatious displays of wealth. As a result, quiet luxury brands continue to ring in returns, with the Quiet Luxury Index outperforming major indices in 2023.

images.alt_text: People stand with Hermes shopping bags as they wait at a traffic light in Tsim Sha Tsui, a bustling shopping hotspot, in Hong Kong, China December 5, 2023. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu
Hermes is defying a broader slump in the high-end goods market as its exposure to the ultra-rich shields it from the worst of the lull.

site_title: Starbucks Middle East franchisee AlShaya to cut over 2,000 jobs: sources
summary: AlShaya Group, the Middle East franchisee of Starbucks, plans to cut over 2,000 jobs, about 4% of its workforce, due to consumer boycotts linked to the Gaza war. The layoffs began on Sunday and are mostly concentrated in its Starbucks franchise in the Middle East and North Africa. The boycotts have led to tough trading conditions for the company, which has been committed to the region despite the challenges.

images.alt_text: Starbucks and Workers United agreed to begin discussions on a “foundational framework” that includes a fair process for workers to organise and a process to achieve collective bargaining agreements on a store-by-store basis.
Same-store sales at company-operated locations open for more than a year rose 5 per cent in the company’s fiscal first quarter, which ended Dec 31.

Sales trends in the snack and coffee industry have decelerated on a week-over-week basis for the seven-day period till Nov 19, according to data-driven research firm M Science.
The Egyptian McDonald's October and November sales fell by at least 70 per cent compared to the same months last year.

site_title: Five things to know about Vietnam’s multi-billion-dollar  fraud case involving property queen Truong My Lan
summary: Vietnam's real estate tycoon Truong My Lan, chairwoman of Van Thinh Phat, is on trial for allegedly misappropriating 304 trillion dong (S$22.6 billion) from Saigon Commercial Bank, where she controlled a majority of shares. The 67-year-old faces charges of bribery, embezzlement, and violating bank regulations, with accomplices including top bank officials. Authorities have confiscated millions of dollars in cash and assets, and frozen 1.8 trillion dong in bank accounts. The trial, set to run nearly two months, is seen as a major blow to Vietnam's real estate market, with over 1,200 projects stalled due to liquidity woes.

images.alt_text: A building under construction and owned by Van Thinh Phat group, chaired by tycoon Truong My Lan, in Ho Chi Minh City.

site_title: Trump ties up with Saudi developer on luxury housing, golf club
summary: Former US President Donald Trump is teaming up with Saudi developer Dar Global on a $200 million luxury housing development in Oman's capital, Trump Villas at AIDA. The gated community will be built within the Trump International Golf Club and offers views of the Gulf of Oman. This marks Trump's return to a region where he enjoyed broad support during his presidency. The development has raised concerns about conflict of interest, as Trump previously pledged not to sign new deals in foreign countries.

site_title: Meta’s Facebook, Instagram down for hundreds of thousands of users across globe
summary: Meta's Facebook and Instagram were down for hundreds of thousands of users worldwide, with over 300,000 reports of outages for Facebook and 40,000 for Instagram, according to outage tracking website Downdetector. The disruptions started around 10 am ET on March 5 and affected Meta's status dashboard, including WhatsApp Business. Meta spokesperson Andy Stone said the company was working to resolve the issue. The outage was trending on X, with users reporting sudden logouts from Meta-owned social media platforms.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Facebook logo is displayed on a smartphone in this illustration taken January 6, 2020. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Greenback steadies versus euro ahead of ECB and US data, Bitcoin in spotlight
summary: The US dollar steadied against the euro ahead of the European Central Bank's rate decision and US jobs data. The US dollar index edged slightly higher to 103.89. Bitcoin neared a record high amid ongoing crypto-mania, while China's yuan remained little changed after setting an ambitious economic growth target of 5% for 2024.

images.alt_text: The euro rises 0.13 per cent to US$1.08.

site_title: 17Live, mm2 Asia to explore joint entertainment offerings across South-east Asia
summary: 17Live Group and mm2 Asia have signed a memorandum of understanding to collaborate on entertainment marketing and production activities across South-east Asia. They aim to create new content and offerings through joint ventures and investments in entertainment content. The collaboration will focus on livestream content, movies, and long-form animation. The agreement may lead to the formation of a joint venture to deliver livestream content via a co-owned platform. The move is expected to bring about new opportunities for both companies.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: Morgan Stanley strategists see M&A surging as confidence builds
summary: Morgan Stanley strategists predict a 50% surge in mergers and acquisitions this year, driven by recovering corporate confidence and stable economic growth. Key sectors for M&A include healthcare, real estate, and technology, with potential targets such as Acadia Pharmaceuticals and ITV in the US and Europe. Quantitative screens identify companies with similar characteristics to past acquisition targets.

images.alt_text: Private market trades let employees and some institutional investors sell their stakes to accredited investors.

site_title: Nio narrows Q4 loss as vehicle sales margin improves
summary: China-based electric vehicle maker Nio narrowed its fourth-quarter loss by 4.3% year-over-year to 5.6 billion yuan, driven by a 4.6% year-on-year rise in vehicle sales to 15.4 billion yuan. Vehicle sales margin improved to 11.9% from 6.8% in the same period last year. Revenue rose 6.5% to 17.1 billion yuan, but net loss widened to 21.1 billion yuan for the full year. Nio expects to deliver between 31,000 and 33,000 vehicles in Q1 FY2024, with revenue forecast to decline 1.7% to 3.8% from the same quarter last year.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

The agreement will give electric car startup Forseven a global licence to use Nio’s technical information and software for the research and development, manufacturing, and distribution of its vehicles

site_title: South-east Asian companies lag peers in climate disclosures: EY
summary: South-east Asian companies are lagging behind their global peers in climate-related disclosures, according to EY's 2023 Global Climate Risk Barometer report. The region ranked third weakest-performing, with quality scores at 26% in 2022 and 34% in 2023, and coverage scores increasing from 84% to 90%. Mandatory climate disclosure requirements are seen as key to improving scores, with 89% of South-east Asian respondents not referencing climate-related matters in their financial statements.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
A survey by audit giant Ernst & Young (EY) Advisory found that 45 per cent of employees in Singapore are likely to resign from their current workplaces in the next 12 months.
EY UK’s pretax profit increased 4 per cent to £659 million in the year to June 2023.

site_title: Apple’s iPhone sales in China plunge 24% as Huawei’s popularity surges
summary: Apple's iPhone sales in China plummeted 24% in the first six weeks of 2024, with Huawei's unit sales rising 64% and the company now in second place. Apple's market share dropped to 15.7%, while Huawei's expanded to 16.5%. The decline comes amid increased competition from domestic rivals, with Apple offering discounts of up to 1,300 yuan to boost sales. The move may indicate a slowdown in demand for the US company, which has seen its shares underperform and revenue forecast revised downward.

images.alt_text: The iPhone 15 launch came at a time of slowing sales for Apple in China where it faces rising competitive pressure from domestic rivals like Huawei and Xiaomi.
The United States has charted a slow course towards depriving SMIC and Huawei of access to advanced US technology.

site_title: GM, Magna and Wipro team up for automotive software marketplace
summary: General Motors, Magna, and Wipro have formed a joint venture called SDVerse, linking buyers and sellers of automotive software through a digital platform. The platform will list software features and attributes. Wipro has invested $5.85 million, taking a 27% stake, while GM and Magna hold 46% and 27% stakes, respectively. This partnership aims to simplify the buying and selling of automotive software, promoting efficiency and innovation in the industry.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The new GM logo is seen on the facade of the General Motors headquarters in Detroit, Michigan, U.S., March 16, 2021. Picture taken March 16, 2021.  REUTERS/Rebecca Cook/File Photo
Alphabet’s Waymo accounts for 36 per cent of the miles recorded without a safety driver.

Honda will use fuel cells in a version of its popular CR-V sport utility vehicle due to be unveiled in March.

site_title: Singapore stocks track Wall Street losses on Tuesday; STI down 0.5%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.5% to 3,107.10 on Tuesday, tracking losses on Wall Street. The market saw a net loss of 356 to 194 gainers, with 1.4 billion securities worth S$959.6 million changing hands. The decline was attributed to the US market rally stalling ahead of key events, including US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's speech and non-farm payroll data.

Tokyo and Hong Kong dipped at Tuesday's open, a day after Japan’s benchmark Nikkei index hit a record high, closing above 40,000 points for the first time.
Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 63 to 45 after 36.2 million securities worth S$28 million change hands.
CDL is close to sealing a 244 million euros (S$356 million) deal to buy the Hilton Paris Opera hotel.

site_title: Scoot adds Koh Samui and Sibu to network with new Embraer planes
summary: Scoot, a Singapore-based budget airline, has added two new destinations to its network: Koh Samui, Hat Yai, and Krabi in Thailand, and Sibu and Miri in Sarawak, Malaysia. The airline will operate Embraer planes to these destinations, starting with direct flights to Koh Samui, Hat Yai, Krabi, and Miri in May 2024, and flights to Kuantan and Sibu in early June 2024. Sale fares for economy class start from S$172 to Koh Samui and S$72 to Sibu, inclusive of taxes. This expansion brings Scoot's network to 69 destinations.

site_title: Temasek shortlists Saudi Aramco, Shell in sale of Pavilion Energy assets
summary: Temasek is shortlisting Saudi Aramco and Shell to purchase Pavilion Energy's assets, excluding its gas pipeline business, in a sale process that could be finalized in coming weeks. Pavilion Energy, a liquefied natural gas trading firm, has seen a 40% decline in spot Asian LNG prices since mid-August, potentially affecting the deal's valuation. The sale comes after Pavilion Energy reported a profit of $438 million in the fiscal year ended March 2023.
