PIXGENERIC
Temasek International office at Orchard Road, July 5, 2023.

site_title: Primer on private credit: Premium yields but specialised skills required
summary: Private credit has grown significantly, with $1.5 trillion in funds invested, driven by its stable risk-adjusted returns and ability to tailor lending to meet investors' risk profiles. The market is expected to reach $3 trillion by 2034, driven by trends such as tighter regulations making it harder for banks to lend and companies seeking alternative financing options. Investors are drawn to private credit for its potential to generate alpha and fixed income-like yields, while borrowers benefit from bespoke loan agreements that provide more tailored solutions to capital requirements.

images.alt_text: The insolvency of European luxury property group Signa could hurt more players across the financial industry, but demand for private debt is said to remain high.
FILE PHOTO: The logo for Goldman Sachs is seen on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, New York, U.S., November 17, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly

site_title: Malaysian 2024 biofuel output seen rising if B20 biodiesel usage expanded
summary: Malaysia's biodiesel production is expected to rise to 1.8 million tonnes in 2024 if the government expands its 20% biodiesel mandatory programme to more areas, according to the Malaysian Biodiesel Association. The programme, currently implemented in phases, aims to increase biodiesel blending in the transportation sector. The expansion could be completed by the second half of 2024, but further discussions with stakeholders are needed. The government has also considered expanding the B10 programme to the industrial sector and reviewing price controls to support domestic biodiesel demand.

images.alt_text: Vopak has commissioned 40,000 cubic metres of capacity at its Sebarok terminal for the blending of biofuels into marine fuels.
Neste will merge its Renewable Aviation, Renewable Road Transportation and Renewable Polymers and Chemicals divisions into one.

site_title: Visa, Western Union expand partnership to more than 40 countries
summary: Visa and Western Union are expanding their partnership to allow customers to send money to eligible Visa cards and bank accounts in over 40 countries, up from 20 in 2020. The agreement, set to run to 2031, enables cross-border money movements in countries including Poland, Peru, and Pakistan. The expanded relationship is a result of past iterations focusing on North America and Europe, with Visa's head of commercial and money-movement solutions previewing the move during an earnings call in January.

images.alt_text: The Cartes Bancaires network processes 15 billion transactions every year by card or mobile phone, or more than 65 per cent of regular consumption in France.
Increased digitisation in key areas like payments has enabled small businesses to reach new audiences and improve efficiencies.
Visa, the world's largest payments processor, did not say why the Reserve Bank of India has issued the directive.

The outlook for payments firms has been marred by worries that a slowing economy and high interest rates will continue to pressure the wallets of consumers, particularly those in the lower-income bracket.
FILE PHOTO: Mastercard and Visa credit cards are seen in front of displayed Wirecard logo in this illustration picture taken June 26, 2020. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Apple on collision course with EU as new sweeping law kicks in
summary: The European Union's Digital Markets Act (DMA) is set to take effect, imposing strict rules on tech giants like Apple, Google, Amazon, and Meta. The law aims to curb market dominance and favor competition, with fines of up to 10% of a company's revenue for violating rules. Apple, which has faced previous EU fines, is expected to face scrutiny over its App Store and iOS offerings. The DMA's impact is being closely watched by other nations, and Big Tech players are preparing for potential lawsuits.

images.alt_text: This photo taken on February 12, 2023 in Brussels shows reflexions on a smartphone screen of logos of online platforms google, facebook, linkedin, Amazon, Apple store and Tiktok as the European Commission announced last September the world's biggest digital firms, identified as "gatekeepers" by the EU, must comply from March 6, 2024, with strict do's and don'ts under a landmark law, the Digital Markets Act (DMA). The EU has built a powerful legal arsenal to take on the internet giants, including the DMA which seeks to encourage competition in the digital world, and its sister milestone law, the Digital Services Act (DSA). The DSA demands the most popular social networks and websites police content online more aggressively and protect consumers while they shop. (Photo by Kenzo TRIBOUILLARD / AFP)

“For a decade, Apple abused its dominant position in the market for the distribution of music streaming apps through the App Store,” says EU antitrust chief Margrethe Vestager. “They did so by restricting developers from informing consumers about alternative, cheaper music services available outside of the Apple ecosystem.”

site_title: Private-hire COE category ‘possible’ but needs careful study; new measures to stabilise private-hire, taxi supply
summary: Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) will address the possibility of a separate Certificate of Entitlement (COE) category for private-hire cars in the second phase of its ongoing review, which will now end by the second half of 2024. The first phase introduces new standards for managing operational disruptions, requiring operators to inform LTA, commuters, and drivers within an hour of a disruption. Other changes include reducing costs for taxi operators and updating regulations to make it easier for commuters to request accessible vehicles.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
There are now more similarities than differences between private hire cars and taxis, which is why the former should not compete or bid for passenger car COEs.

If a separate COE category for PHVs were to be implemented, it would likely be timed separately from other regulatory changes in the P2P transport sector, said acting minister for transport Chee Hong Tat in an interview with Lianhe Zaobao.
Grab's acquisition of Trans-Cab includes about 2,200 cabs and more than 300 private-hire vehicles.

site_title: Singapore ‘open to’ idea of one-off rise in vehicle population, with higher usage-based charges: Chee
summary: Singapore is open to reviewing a one-off increase in its vehicle population, potentially accompanied by higher vehicle-usage charges to prevent congestion. Transport Minister Chee Hong Tat said the trade-offs need to be studied carefully, and higher charges could include location and time-based fees or distance-based charging. However, he noted that relying solely on usage-based charges may not be feasible due to high rates that could be unacceptably high for car owners. The government would also need to balance this with other ownership controls and measures to prevent traffic congestion.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong

The evolution of Singapore's road pricing system (from 12 o'clock, clockwise): A sign signifying the boundary of the Restricted Zone where the Area Licensing Scheme (ALS) was in operation; cars queueing up to buy ALS licences; a monthly ALS disc costing S$60; a motorcyclist signalling he wants to buy a S$1 licence (two fingers mean S$2 and
three, $3); a hut at the entry point into the city where Cisco guards looked out for vehicles without ALS discs; and people forming carpools, which were exempt from ALS charges for 15 years, until 1989.
Premiums for passenger car Certificates of Entitlement (COEs) fell in February's second round of bidding, while commercial vehicle COE premiums increased.
The MG Cyberster was displayed at the Singapore Motorshow 2024, and could be the first electric sports coupe from a mainstream brand here if it goes on sale.
Why a Toyota cost S$200,000 in Singapore
Singapore’s vehicle ownership cost remains not far from a record high, as the government’s zero-growth approach to registering new cars collided with demand from the island state’s burgeoning rich.

site_title: Air India-Vistara merger gets Singapore’s conditional approval
summary: Singapore's Competition and Consumer Commission (CCCS) has approved the merger between Tata Group-owned Air India and sister airline Vistara, subject to certain conditions. The merger, announced in November 2022, aims to create a dominant full-service airline in the domestic and international markets. Despite India's antitrust body approving the deal in September last year, the CCCS identified competition concerns. The CCCS' approval paves the way for the merger to proceed, pending the resolution of outstanding issues.

images.alt_text: Air India’s merger with Vistara, a joint venture between Tata and Singapore Airlines, will pose a challenge to local rival and market leader IndiGo.

site_title: Mixed signals from gold and the Magnificent Seven stocks
summary: The S&P 500, led by the "Magnificent Seven" stocks (Nvidia, Apple, Amazon, Alphabet, Meta, Microsoft, and Tesla), surged 26% in 2023, catching analysts off guard. However, removing these seven stocks from the index reduces the growth rate to 6%. The gold price also rose, driven by increased Chinese gold-buying and a potential shift away from the US dollar. The S&P 500 is currently at an all-time high, but investors should be cautious of trend weakness, with a potential head-and-shoulder pattern developing.

images.alt_text: A photo of Nvidia's graphic processing unit. Analysts said Nvidia’s latest earnings report demonstrates the current strength of AI infrastructure spending.
There is talk of whether the broad-based S&P 500 Index has risen too quickly over the last few months, with growth concentrated within the largest stocks.

site_title: S$15 million addition to Maritime Cluster Fund among moves to improve sector’s sustainability
summary: Singapore's Maritime Cluster Fund has introduced a new sustainability pillar, co-funding S$15 million until 2030 for companies adopting greener solutions. The fund will cover 50% of costs for SMEs and 30% for non-SMEs, capped at S$30,000. This move aims to "catalyse first-mover adoption of sustainable solutions" and complements existing initiatives like the Energy Efficiency Grant and Enterprise Financing Scheme – Green. The government also plans to streamline transhipment times and reduce costs by improving coordination between logistics players and adopting a digital platform.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
The enhancements to the EFS include trade loans, working capital loans and support for domestic construction projects via project loans, which saw extensions from Mar 31 this year to Mar 31, 2024.
Among the enhanced schemes for SMEs, the Energy Efficiency Grant has been expanded to include data centres and their users.
Kurt Wee, president of the Association of Small and Medium Enterprises (ASME), was hoping for the Energy Efficiency Grant to be extended to more sectors.

site_title: Singapore and Australia to enter new chapter of cooperation in 2025
summary: Singapore and Australia will enter a new phase of cooperation in 2025, with their leaders pledging to work together in areas such as renewable energy, supply chain resilience, and artificial intelligence. The two countries have agreed to develop an "ambitious" plan for their next chapter of cooperation, building on their existing Comprehensive Strategic Partnership, which marked its 10th year in 2024. The partnership aims to promote peace and stability in the region, including the South China Sea, and will comprise initiatives across various sectors, including food security, energy security, and cyber technologies.

site_title: Flag-state performance on implementing international rules ‘improves’
summary: The International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) released its updated Flag State Performance Table, showing improvements in flag-state performance on implementing international rules. 13 out of 175 states, including the UK and Singapore, have an unbroken row of green, indicating they meet minimum standards. However, ICS advises caution in interpreting the table, noting that a flag with a solid row of green does not necessarily mean it is superior. The table highlights areas for improvement, particularly for flag states with large numbers of negative performance indicators, such as Togo, Algeria, and Comoros.

images.alt_text: Hamburg-based maritime-technology firm OceanScore says Asia-based shipowners will foot 500 million euros under the European Union Emissions Trading System this year for a start, and rise each year thereafter.

site_title: Korea’s Kia, Thailand in talks over building new EV facility: sources
summary: Kia is in talks with Thailand to build an electric vehicle facility, with discussions focused on incentives sought by the Korean carmaker from the Thai government. Thailand aims to convert 30% of its annual vehicle production into EVs by 2030, and has rolled out incentives and tax breaks to position itself as a regional frontrunner. Kia's move follows similar investments by Chinese EV makers, and comes as Thailand separately negotiates with Tesla over a new facility. The talks are seen as a significant development for Thailand's automotive sector.

images.alt_text: The EV9 is unashamedly boxy, with flat, vertical surfaces that exaggerate its size instead of playing it down.

Kia President and CEO Song Ho Sung speaks during a briefing at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, Nevada, Jan 8, 2024. Uber and Kia announced on Wednesday the signing of an agreement on producing electric vehicles.
Hyundai is monitoring sentiment in the EV market, but believed the trend for EVs was positive regardless of issues over a shortage of charging infrastructure.

site_title: Navigating challenges in US commercial real estate
summary: The US office property sector is facing significant challenges due to the post-pandemic shift towards hybrid working arrangements and higher interest rates. Vacancies have risen, and demand for commercial real estate has fallen, resulting in huge discounts in valuations, with some owners selling assets at 45% losses. Defaults are also rising, with over $86 billion in distressed US properties, and lenders are cutting losses by selling loans or making loan provisions. The situation is expected to worsen with interest rates remaining elevated, posing risks to other stakeholders, including lenders and investors.

images.alt_text: The Hilton Paris Opera hotel is located next to the Paris Saint-Lazare train station.

HSBC recently announced that it will relocate its Canary Wharf headquarters to the City of London. Among the other major employers that are planning to leave are law firm Clifford Chance and fintech giant Revolut.

site_title: Alibaba backs US$2.5 billion AI startup in second major 2024 deal
summary: Alibaba has led a $2.5 billion financing round for Chinese AI startup MiniMax, its second major deal in the space this year. The funding, which is ongoing, values the two-year-old firm at over $2.5 billion. The deal follows Alibaba's $1 billion investment in Moonshot AI, also valuing it at $2.5 billion. The investments demonstrate Alibaba's focus on generative AI, a technology powered by ChatGPT, and its efforts to identify future leaders in the field amidst regulatory scrutiny and an economic downturn.

images.alt_text: The cuts mark one of the more aggressive moves by Alibaba to stay ahead of Tencent and Baidu in the cloud business

site_title: Scientists develop mathematical model to optimise elite athletes’ performance
summary: Scientists have developed a mathematical model to optimize training for elite athletes in 400 m and 1,500 m athletics events. The model is based on performance data from athletes such as Olympic champion Jakob Ingebrigtsen and Dutch world indoor 400 m record holder Femke Bol. The data was gathered using GPS sensors and integrated with equations calculating physiological variables, revealing the importance of a rapid start and maintaining maximum oxygen consumption throughout the race. The model aims to provide instant access to optimal training strategies for coaches.

images.alt_text: A strength training regimen that includes squats, lunges, glute bridges or, yes, kettlebells, can improve bone density and lower the risk of injury.

site_title: Lloyd's of London insurer Hiscox posts record annual profit, launches new buyback
summary: Hiscox, a Lloyd's of London insurer, posted a record annual profit of US$625.9 million, driven by strength in its commercial business and higher interest rates. The company also launched a US$150 million share buyback and expects 5-15% annual growth in its retail business. Despite rising claims and currency swings, Hiscox's undiscounted combined ratio improved to 89.8%, offsetting the impact of substantial claims in recent years.

site_title: Singapore, Australia ink pact for green and digital shipping corridor
summary: Singapore and Australia have signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to establish the Singapore-Australia Green and Digital Shipping Corridor (GDSC), aiming to facilitate digital information exchange and develop zero or near-zero greenhouse-gas emission fuel supply chains for the maritime industry. The partnership will explore digital solutions, alternative fuels, and technologies, and is expected to catalyze the development and uptake of green technologies, enhancing the resilience and efficiency of global maritime supply chains. The MOU was signed by Singapore's Transport Minister and Australia's Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
An artist's impression of the city centre of Tianjin Eco-City.
A container vessel prepares to dock at the Pasir Panjang port terminal in Singapore in August. The Rotterdam-Singapore Corridor has the powerful backing of two of the world’s largest ports.
Australia Prime Minister Anthony Albanese (left) and Singapore's Acting Prime Minister Lawrence Wong pose during an orchid-naming ceremony at the Istana on June 2, 2023.

Stacked containers are shown as ships unload their cargo at the Port of Los Angeles, the busiest seaport in the Western Hemisphere. Singapore is in talks with the port, together with the Port of Long Beach and C40 Cities, to establish a green shipping corridor.

site_title: British Airways plans £750 million on digital upgrades
summary: British Airways plans to invest £750 million over three years to modernize its digital systems, including a new website and mobile app, to improve on-time performance and customer experience. The airline aims to begin seeing improvements by the end of 2024, following repeated technology failures that have led to cancelled flights and sluggish online experiences. The investment is part of a £7 billion push to modernize the airline's operations and rebuild its reputation after struggling to compete with budget rivals.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A British Airways aircraft parks next to an EasyJet plane at Cointrin airport in Geneva, Switzerland June 24, 2021.  REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo

site_title: Chemicals giant Bayer rules out break-up 'for now' after huge loss
summary: German chemicals giant Bayer reported a 2.9-billion-euro loss in 2023 due to woes related to glyphosate-based weedkillers. CEO Bill Anderson vowed to address key challenges, including strengthening the pharmaceuticals pipeline, addressing massive litigation issues, and reducing high debt levels. Despite mounting pressure from activist investors, Anderson ruled out an imminent break-up of the company, stating "our answer is 'not now'". Bayer aims to make savings of two billion euros a year from 2026 and expects full-year sales to decline in 2024.

images.alt_text: Bayer has fallen deeper into crisis since the Monsanto acquisition that former CEO Werner Baumann spearheaded just weeks into his tenure.

site_title: Thailand opens applications for virtual banks
summary: Thailand is accepting applications for virtual banks, aiming to support those with limited access to financial services. Applicants must demonstrate sufficient experience and resources to support commercial banking. The Finance Ministry and central bank will consider applications within nine months, with approved banks required to prepare and begin operations within one year. The authorities have not limited the number of licenses, considering the suitability for the Thai financial system.

site_title: UK firms report growth at 9-month high but price pressures mount, PMI survey shows
summary: The UK's services sector experienced its strongest growth in February since May 2023, with order books expanding at a 9-month high, boosted by optimism over potential interest rate cuts by the Bank of England. The S&P Global composite PMI rose to 53.0, edging up from 52.9 in January. Despite this, inflation pressures remain a concern, with input prices rising at the fastest pace since last August. The Bank of England is likely to keep a close eye on these pressures as it considers its next move on interest rates.

images.alt_text: Commuters pass the Bank of England (BOE) in the City of London, UK, on Tuesday, Jan. 23, 2024. The Bank of England is being urged to end its bias toward further interest-rate hikes or risk undermining its own credibility, in what’s likely to be a tricky communication challenge for Governor Andrew Bailey. Photographer: Jose Sarmento Matos/Bloomberg

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 5)
summary: Transport Minister Chee Hong Tat stated Singapore is open to reviewing a one-off rise in its vehicle population, accompanied by higher usage-based charges to prevent congestion. A new housing estate with 10,000 homes is planned in Yishun, while a separate COE category for private-hire cars is possible but requires careful study. The government has also revised the Staggered Downpayment Scheme for HDB flats and signed a pact with Australia to establish a green and digital shipping corridor. Singapore stocks ended lower on Tuesday, tracking Wall Street losses.

images.alt_text: Generic photo for vehicle traffic, carbon tax related stories. Back view of cars caught in a jam.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Tuesday, March 5, 2024 (Ep 15)
summary: China has set a 5% GDP growth target for 2024, while India's Tata Motors plans to split into two listed firms. The Malaysia Derivatives Exchange is set to launch a soyoil futures contract. These market updates and announcements are part of the closing bell roundup by The Business Times, providing insights into regional market movements and news.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 63 to 45 after 36.2 million securities worth S$28 million change hands.
Tokyo and Hong Kong dipped at Tuesday's open, a day after Japan’s benchmark Nikkei index hit a record high, closing above 40,000 points for the first time.

FILE PHOTO: A man stands next to a sign of the brand of  Tata Motors' passenger electric vehicles 'Tata.ev ' at Bharat Mobility Global Expo organised by India's commerce ministry at Pragati Maidan in New Delhi, India, February 1, 2024. REUTERS/Anushree Fadnavis/File Photo
Price movements in palm oil, soyoil, sunflower oil and rapeseed oil depend on the price trends of other competing edible oils.

site_title: Hanoi chokes as Vietnam capital tops most polluted cities list
summary: Hanoi, the Vietnamese capital, has been ranked as the most polluted city in the world, according to air monitoring website IQAir. The city experienced hazardous levels of PM2.5 pollutants, exceeding the World Health Organization's annual guideline by more than 24 times. The thick haze obscured high-rise buildings and left nearly nine million residents breathing toxic air. The high levels of pollution have raised health concerns and highlighted the need for improved air quality measures in the city.

images.alt_text: Bangkok and the northern city of Chiang Mai have ranked among the most polluted cities in the world on a number of days last year.
Emission allowance prices are expected to rise this year as tighter regulations help to limit a surplus.

As many as 128 flights from the international airport in New Delhi, the capital, were delayed, with 33 cancelled, aviation site Flightradar24 showed, an effect that cascaded through flight schedules nationwide.
Chinese cities have grappled with high air pollution readings in recent months despite authorities’ efforts to improve air quality in recent years.
China's carbon emissions in the second quarter jumps 10 per cent on last year’s coronavirus-induced lull.

site_title: Jail for man linked to purchase of 3 houses worth over S$6m, bought on Chinese national’s behalf
summary: A Singaporean man, Tan Hui Meng, 57, has been sentenced to 2 years, 3 months, and 3 weeks in jail for his role in purchasing three houses worth over S$6 million on behalf of a Chinese national, Zhan Guotuan. Each house was bought despite being non-restricted residential properties, and foreigners are normally not entitled to buy such homes. Tan, an undischarged bankrupt, was also fined S$3,000 for his involvement in the redevelopment business of Zhan, a wealthy Chinese businessman with shares in over 100 organizations in China.

images.alt_text: gavel, auction, law

site_title: World’s biggest palm oil exchange to launch soyoil futures
summary: The Bursa Malaysia Derivatives Exchange (BMD) will launch a soyoil futures contract on March 18, the world's first non-palm based edible oil futures, to facilitate arbitrage between soyoil and palm oil contracts. The new contract will be denominated in US dollars and use the Dalian Commodity Exchange's settlement price as the basis for calculation. The move aims to increase market participation and liquidity, but may face competition from existing contracts offered by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and Dalian Commodity Exchange.

images.alt_text: By shortening the approval process, Bursa Malaysia and Securities Commission hope to enhance the Exchange’s attractiveness to companies seeking to list in Malaysia.
Bursa Malaysia recorded a higher profit and revenue in 2023, supported by higher operating revenue from the securities market and data business.

site_title: Japan seeing signs of positive wage momentum, says senior official
summary: Japan is seeing early signs of a positive cycle of rising inflation and wages, according to Deputy Chief Cabinet Secretary Hideki Murai. The government is focusing on broadening pay increases beyond big companies, requiring executives to take ownership in price-setting procedures and sanctioning firms that pressure suppliers to cut prices. The administration aims to boost profits of smaller firms, which can then hike wages. The Bank of Japan is also monitoring wage growth as a prerequisite for exiting ultra-loose monetary policy, with some market players expecting the bank to end negative interest rates in March or April.

images.alt_text: In the last few years the government has maintained that Japan was no longer in deflation, but it has stopped short of declaring a complete victory over falling prices.

site_title: 10,000 new homes planned in Yishun; Gillman Barracks being studied for residential use
summary: Singapore is planning to build 10,000 new homes in the Chencharu area of Yishun, with at least 80% set aside for public housing. The first Build-To-Order project will launch in June 2024. Additionally, the government is studying the possibility of introducing a new residential neighbourhood at Gillman Barracks, which could include both public and private housing, with environmental and heritage studies expected to begin in 2024. The plans aim to provide more housing supply and recreational spaces, with a focus on building on the character and charm of the former colonial buildings at Gillman Barracks.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
The S$300 rental voucher is part of a new scheme for couples eligible for the existing Parenthood Provisional Housing Scheme.

site_title: Bitcoin cools below US$67,000, but stays in sight of record high
summary: Bitcoin has jumped to a high above US$68,800, nearing its two-year peak, as money rushes into the world's most traded cryptocurrency. The cryptocurrency has gained 50% this year, with most of its rise coming in the last few weeks due to inflows into US-listed bitcoin funds. Experts predict further growth, with some forecasting a move towards US$80,000, despite concerns of "irrational behavior" in the market.

images.alt_text: The price of Bitcoin has historically increased after a halving event, with so-called miner production cost functioning as a lower bound to the price of the asset.
Bitcoin has jumped over 40 per cent already this year atop the successful debut of the ETF products, which directly hold the token.
FILE PHOTO: A bitcoin logo is pictured on a door in an illustration picture taken at La Maison du Bitcoin in Paris May 27, 2015. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier/File Photo

site_title: 10 years after MH370 vanished, families still in limbo
summary: Ten years after Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 vanished, families of the 239 passengers and crew remain in limbo. Despite the largest search in aviation history, only a few fragments of the Boeing 777-200ER have been found. Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim has announced his willingness to reopen the search if "compelling" evidence emerges. Relatives of the victims express ongoing pain and uncertainty, with some describing the past decade as "secondary damage" that surpasses the initial grief. The search's outcome remains a mystery, with various theories and no firm conclusions.

images.alt_text: Visitors look at the wreckage of an aircraft believed to be from the missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 during a remembrance event marking the 10th anniversary of its disappearance, Subang Jaya, Malaysia, March 3, 2024.

site_title: 13-19 Art Prize: Buy art, from the heart
summary: The 13-19 Art Prize, supported by BT, is an art competition for teenagers aged 13-19 to raise funds for underprivileged children through their artwork sales. The exhibition features paintings, sculptures, and digital artworks priced from S$150, with all proceeds going to The Business Times Budding Artists Fund. The contest attracted 188 entries and showcased a diverse range of talents. Artworks can be purchased through a silent auction on the TRCL website or viewed at an exhibition at Tekka 1001 in Singapore until the end of March.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
In the participatory VR show Le Bal De Paris, audience get to be avatar dressed Chanel-designed fineries.
The extraordinary work 'Sun & Sea' features sunbathers singing songs about climate change.

site_title: China’s Li vows more support for property market stuck in the doldrums
summary: Chinese Premier Li Qiang has announced targeted measures to stabilize the country's property sector, which has been struggling due to a glut of unfinished properties and unsold homes. The government will provide financing to "justified" projects, scale up the building and supply of government-subsidized housing, and improve commercial housing systems. Despite these efforts, analysts warn that the property market remains under pressure, with the mainland CSI 300 Real Estate Index down 42% in the past year, and the risk of deflation. China aims to achieve an economic growth of around 5% this year to address the sector's impact on the economy.

images.alt_text: Vanke, whose biggest shareholder is Shenzhen Metro Group, has faced concerns about its debt obligations since last year.
China’s housing market remains in a deep slump, even as authorities step up efforts to support the industry.

site_title: China Vanke assures it can repay US$630 million dollar bond amid liquidity worries
summary: China Vanke, the country's No 2 property developer, has assured investors it can repay a US$630 million dollar bond due on March 11, despite liquidity concerns. The developer cited an "orderly" repayment process and said it had funding in place to cover the debt. This comes amid reports of Vanke seeking debt maturity extensions with insurers, which has led to selling pressure on its bonds. The company's shares and bond prices recovered slightly after the statement, but remain under pressure due to concerns over its financial health and potential rating downgrades.

images.alt_text: China’s housing market remains in a deep slump, even as authorities step up efforts to support the industry.
Vanke is one of the few large property developers in China that hasn’t defaulted and is seen as a bellwether for the government’s support of the sector.
China’s property sector has lurched from one crisis to another since 2021 after a regulatory crackdown on debt-fuelled construction triggered a liquidity squeeze.
China has been ramping up measures to halt a downturn in a property sector that has lurched from one extreme to the other since 2021 after a regulatory crackdown on high leverage.

site_title: India's Tata Motors hits record high on plan to split into two listed firms
summary: Tata Motors, India's most valuable carmaker, hit a record high after announcing plans to split into two listed firms, separating its commercial vehicle business from its passenger vehicle arm. The stock rose 4.6% and reached an all-time high of 1,065.6 rupees, leading gains on the Nifty Auto index. The demerger is expected to allow the passenger vehicle business to compete more directly with Maruti Suzuki and other industry leaders, with Jaguar Land Rover set to be part of the new business.

images.alt_text: The commercial vehicles business and its related investments will be spun in one entity and the passenger vehicles (PV) businesses, including electric vehicles (EV), Jaguar Land Rover and related investments, in another entity.

site_title: Switzerland’s Sulzer opens S$10 million R&D facility in Singapore
summary: Swiss fluid and chemical engineering company Sulzer has opened a new research and development (R&D) facility in Singapore, its first in Asia-Pacific and the second outside of Switzerland. The S$10 million facility, called the Innovation Technology Hub (InTecH), will focus on developing energy-efficient chemical engineering processes, including recycling hard-to-recycle items and producing bio-based goods. Sulzer plans to grow its local team by 20-30 staff over the next three years, empowering manufacturers and processors to innovate and produce eco-efficient products, according to CEO Suzanne Thoma.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Sulzer buys Swiss-German device maker Haselmeier for US$118m

site_title: HSBC, StanChart, BOA aim to finance Indonesia coal retirement
summary: HSBC, Standard Chartered, and Bank of America have proposed to finance the early retirement of Indonesia's Cirebon-1 coal-fired power station, with Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group also in talks. The deal, backed by the Asian Development Bank, aims to convert plant equity into debt to compensate investors for future losses. This marks a significant step towards Indonesia's energy transition, with the goal of shutting down all coal-fired power plants by 2040 to limit global warming. The deal could also spur broader progress on the country's climate-finance package, which aims to attract private capital to support the transition.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Coal is seen as a heavy machinery unloads it from the barges into a truck to be distributed, at the Karya Citra Nusantara port in North Jakarta, Indonesia, January 13, 2022.   REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan/File Photo
A fisherman looks at the Suralaya coal-fired power plant in Cilegon, Indonesia, Oct 31, 2023.
Coal is transported on barges in Samarinda, East Kalimantan in January 11, 2022.

Out of the five investment areas the document has set out, financing the early phase-out of coal has been the more contentious one for the local banks, as the commercial viability of such transactions has not been worked out.

site_title: Eurozone business activity moves closer to recovery, PMI survey shows
summary: Business activity in the eurozone showed signs of recovery, with the services employment PMI rising to an eight-month high of 52.7 in February, up from 51.2 in January. This marked the first expansion in the services sector since July. The manufacturing sector, however, continued to contract, with the PMI at 47.9. The eurozone's overall economic health is still below the 50 mark separating growth from contraction, but the services sector's growth suggests a potential recovery.

Lending growth has been hovering around zero since the autumn but is expected to slowly recover in the coming months as the ECB likely begins cutting interest rates.
Inflation comes down rapidly last year and now stands just below 3 per cent, but the ECB says it could take more than another year to get it down to its 2 per cent target.

site_title: Singapore’s exclusive South-east Asia deal for Taylor Swift concerts ‘not unfriendly’ to neighbours: PM Lee
summary: Singapore has defended its decision to award a grant to Taylor Swift's promoter, allowing her to be the only South-east Asian stop on her world tour. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the deal was mutually beneficial, promoting the country's economy and tourism. The grant was provided by the Singapore Tourism Board's Tourism Development Fund, with no reported amount being "unfriendly" to neighboring countries. Minister Alvin Tan emphasized that the government assesses the benefits of each event, including its impact on foreign visitorship and tourism receipts.

images.alt_text: 泰勒丝Taylor Swift新加坡演唱会

site_title: Construction sector to get enhanced nationwide contractors’ registry, energy efficiency grant
summary: Singapore's government has announced updates to the construction sector, including an enhanced Contractors Registration System (CRS) to streamline the hiring of foreign construction workers, and an energy efficiency grant to support firms investing in energy-efficient equipment. The CRS will require firms to have a minimum paid-up capital of S$50,000 and a track record of S$300,000. The energy efficiency grant will provide up to 70% funding support for pre-approved equipment, with a total cap of S$350,000. The government aims to accelerate transformation in the built environment sector, meeting three key targets by 2030, including increasing green buildings to 80% of new developments.

images.alt_text: Land betterment charge rates for non-landed residential use were raised by 0.1 per cent on average.
Attention has been focused on the commercial property market, but the biggest effect so far has been in housing construction.

A construction site for apartment buildings in the HafenCity district in Hamburg, Germany, on Thursday, July 6, 2023. Germany’s efforts to increase housing supply are faltering as higher materials costs triggered a decline in residential construction orders by more than one third in the first quarter, according to the country’s main builders lobby. Photographer: Maria Feck/Bloomberg

site_title: China’s Huawei and Amazon in patent licensing agreement
summary: Huawei Technologies and Amazon have signed a multi-year patent licensing deal, resolving a lawsuit between them over patented technology. The agreement ends litigation in Germany over wifi and video playback technology. This deal comes amid US-China tensions, where the US has barred Chinese telecom companies from its market and restricted Huawei's access to US components. Despite this, the patent licensing agreement shows cooperation between American and Chinese companies, highlighting the ability to work together without limitations.

site_title: India’s February services growth remained robust but slowed slightly
summary: India's services sector activity accelerated in February, albeit at a slower pace, according to a business survey. The HSBC India services PMI fell to 60.6 from January's six-month high of 61.8, but remains above the 50-mark. New business softened to a six-month low, while orders from abroad remained resilient. Hiring slowed, and employment generation was barely positive. Inflationary pressures eased, with operating costs rising at the weakest pace since December. The survey suggests India's economy will continue to grow at a world-beating pace this year.

images.alt_text: India’s economy grew at its fastest pace in one-and-half years in the final three months of 2023, led by strong manufacturing and construction activity.

Employees make iron parts which are used to construct bridges inside a manufacturing unit in an industrial area on the outskirts of Kolkata, India, February 12, 2016. India's industrial output contracted an annual 1.3 percent in December, government data showed on Friday. REUTERS/Rupak De Chowdhuri/File photo
India, which is seeking to rival countries such as Taiwan in chipmaking, expects its semiconductor market to be worth US$63 billion by 2026.

site_title: Sea Group’s financial health in 7 charts
summary: Sea Group, Southeast Asia's largest internet firm, has closely watched financial numbers. Total adjusted Ebitda for Q3 2022 was $1.45 billion, with bookings reaching $2.31 billion. Revenue was $2.43 billion under Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP), mainly from transaction-based fees and advertising. Sea Group stopped providing product revenue figures in 2022. The company's financial performance is closely monitored by retail investors.

site_title: China defence spending to climb 7.2% as Xi pursues buildup
summary: China's defence spending is expected to rise by 7.2% in 2024, the largest increase in five years, amid efforts to modernize its military. The country's military expenditure is projected to reach 1.67 trillion yuan ($310.3 billion). Chinese leader Xi Jinping has set a 2027 deadline for his nation's military to become a "world-class force." However, corruption within the military is undermining these efforts, with several high-ranking officials replaced without explanation. The US has warned that China's expanding nuclear arsenal poses a threat, and tensions between the two nations remain high, particularly over Taiwan and the South China Sea.

images.alt_text: Any deals that may be reached during the Australia-Asean summit are expected to be modest.

A Filipino fisherman (front) sailing past a Chinese coast guard ship near the China-controlled Scarborough Shoal, in disputed waters of the South China Sea, Feb 16, 2024. Maritime security - and China’s increasingly aggressive behaviour in the South China Sea - figures to be one of Asean's major focal points.
Vanke, whose biggest shareholder is Shenzhen Metro Group, has faced concerns about its debt obligations since last year.

Wantalk, an artificial intelligence chatbot created by Baidu, is displayed at the Baidu headquarters in Beijing. China plans to step up efforts in big data and artificial intelligence (AI), launch an AI-plus initiative and also intends to launch a number of major science and technology programmes to meet major strategic and industrial development goals.

China's five per cent target would be in line with its GDP growth last year, one of the country’s lowest in decades and a far cry from the double-digit growth that long drove its breakneck development in the nineties and 2000s.
Chinese auto companies currently have a very limited presence in the US because of a 27.5 per cent tariff imposed by former president Donald Trump.
Organised by the Shenzhen and Shanghai stock exchanges, the training was aimed at helping quant funds understand the regulatory mindset and work requirements, the Shenzhen bourse says.
Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong says Canberra is providing A$286.5 million in funding for Asean projects in areas including maritime security.

site_title: London bids farewell, for now, to a beloved, overstuffed walrus
summary: London's Horniman Museum and Gardens has temporarily closed its Natural History Gallery, where a giant taxidermy walrus has been on display for over 120 years. The gallery is being redeveloped to focus on environmental sustainability and combating the climate emergency. The rest of the museum, including a large collection of musical instruments and an aquarium, will remain open. The walrus is expected to be returned to the gallery once the redevelopment is complete.

images.alt_text:
TOPSHOT - Italian restorer Eleonora Pucci cleans Michelangelo's statue of David using a backpack vacuum and synthetic fibre brush at the Galleria dell'Accademia, in Florence on February 19, 2024. Michelangelo's masterpiece received a delicate beauty treatment on Monday, part of routine maintenance on one of the world's most recognisable nudes.

Every two months, the marble sculpture of a muscular and steely-eyed David -- completed by a 29-year-old Michelangelo in 1504 -- undergoes the careful cleaning from his home within Florence's Accademia Gallery, where it has resided for over 150 years. (Photo by Tiziana FABI / AFP)

site_title: China to step up quantum computing, AI in tech self-sufficiency drive
summary: China plans to boost its efforts in big data and artificial intelligence, launching an AI-plus initiative and major science and technology programs to achieve strategic and industrial development goals. This move aims to increase tech self-sufficiency and drive innovation, following Baidu's introduction of its AI chatbot, Wantalk.

site_title: Chinese developers resume UK commercial property retreat
summary: Chinese developers have resumed selling UK commercial property, shedding £110 million in net sales in 2024, as they seek to raise cash amid a liquidity squeeze in China's property sector. This marks a reversal of three years of net selling, with £1.4 billion worth of UK real estate sold since 2021. The impetus to sell stems from a collapse in China's property sector and steep borrowing costs, leading to a decline in deal activity globally.

images.alt_text: Vanke, whose biggest shareholder is Shenzhen Metro Group, has faced concerns about its debt obligations since last year.
China’s housing market remains in a deep slump, even as authorities step up efforts to support the industry.

site_title: Has Bidenomics worked? It’s too soon to say
summary: US President Joe Biden's economic policies, known as Bidenomics, are being evaluated as a potential success. While the economy is booming and job market is growing, it's too soon to declare Bidenomics a success, as the investments are being paid for with borrowed money. The long-term impact of these investments is uncertain, and if they don't pay off, the boom could turn into a bust. Bidenomics aims to address pressing issues such as deindustrialization, climate change, and national security, but its effectiveness is disputed.

images.alt_text: epa11150727 US President Joe Biden delivers remarks in the State Dining Room of the White House in Washington, DC, USA, 13 February 2024. President Biden urged the US House of Representatives to pass a 95 billion USD bill with aid to Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan. The package passed with bipartisan support in the Senate but is unlikely to pass in the Republican-controlled House due to opposition from hard-right conservatives supporting former US President Donald J. Trump.  EPA-EFE/MICHAEL REYNOLDS / POOL

site_title: Gold hits record peak on US rate cut hopes
summary: Gold reached an all-time peak of US$2,141.79 per ounce on March 5, driven by expectations of US interest rate cuts amid economic gloom. The precious metal has gained about 15% in value since the same stage last year, with jewellery and investment buying as its twin drivers. Analysts attribute the surge to concerns over global economic prospects, geopolitical tensions, and uncertainty surrounding the Federal Reserve's plans to unwind monetary policy.

images.alt_text: Spot gold has edged 0.2 per cent lower to US$2,080.09 per ounce.

site_title: Stablecoin Tether crosses US$100 billion tokens in circulation
summary: Tether, a stablecoin issuer, has reached a milestone of crossing US$100 billion in tokens in circulation. The US dollar-pegged stablecoin maintains a constant value of US$1 by holding US dollar-based reserves. Despite trading at a premium, Tether has demonstrated resilience, with its reserves holding US$63 billion of US Treasuries, precious metals, and other assets at the end of 2023. The company's transparency has reduced concerns, but regulators have warned banks about the potential for rapid outflows from stablecoin reserves.

images.alt_text: The UK Treasury pledged in October to provide more clarity on specific areas of crypto by some point in 2024.
Tether’s USDT token is on the verge of surpassing US$100 billion in circulation for the first time.
Stablecoins are typically pegged 1-1 to fiat currencies and backed by reserves of cash and bonds.

site_title: JetBlue, Spirit Airlines cancel merger after blocked by US court
summary: JetBlue and Spirit Airlines have cancelled their merger after a US federal judge ruled the deal violated antitrust law. The companies had planned a $3.8 billion purchase of Spirit, but a judge sided with the US Justice Department, which argued the removal of Spirit would lead to higher fares. JetBlue will pay Spirit $69 million as a termination fee, and the merger's deadline of July 24, 2024, will not be met. The decision comes after the companies concluded they would not be able to meet the deadline given the legal situation.

images.alt_text: The American Airlines order comprises 260 new planes, plus options for an additional 193 aircraft.

A review of Boeing‘s safety culture released by an FAA advisory panel last week found that Boeing staff were confused and distrustful of changes to safety reporting systems implemented by the company after fatal plane crashes in 2018 and 2019.
US carriers earn billions of US dollars annually from agreements under which banks purchase miles that are then distributed to consumers using the cards.

Visitors look at the wreckage of an aircraft believed to be from the missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 during a remembrance event marking the 10th anniversary of its disappearance, Subang Jaya, Malaysia, March 3, 2024.
Boeing spun off Spirit in 2005 and in recent years has struggled with cost pressures and problems that have slowed aircraft deliveries and thinned its balance sheet.
Singapore's competition watchdog is seeking views on whether ANA's acquisition of Nippon Cargo Airlines will infringe section 54 of the Competition Act 2004.
A China's Comac C919 aircraft performs during a preview of the Singapore Airshow in Singapore on February 18, 2024. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)
Be cautious on being sold on the potential for synergies in such deals.

site_title: China plans one trillion yuan special ultra-long debt for economy
summary: China plans to issue 1 trillion yuan (S$187 billion) of ultra-long special central government bonds this year, aiming to boost fiscal stimulus for its economy. The move signals a focus on centralizing spending amid local government debt struggles. The issuance is the fourth in 26 years and comes as the country faces pressures from deflation, the property crisis, and dampened consumer confidence. China's fiscal deficit target remains at 3% of GDP, and experts expect looser monetary policy to stimulate demand.

images.alt_text: Wantalk, an artificial intelligence chatbot created by Baidu, is displayed at the Baidu headquarters in Beijing. China plans to step up efforts in big data and artificial intelligence (AI), launch an AI-plus initiative and also intends to launch a number of major science and technology programmes to meet major strategic and industrial development goals.

China's five per cent target would be in line with its GDP growth last year, one of the country’s lowest in decades and a far cry from the double-digit growth that long drove its breakneck development in the nineties and 2000s.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly down as China sets 5% growth goal
summary: Asian markets declined on Tuesday as China set a 5% annual growth target, in line with last year's GDP gains. Tokyo and Hong Kong fell, following Japan's record-high Nikkei index closing above 40,000 points. Wall Street retreated ahead of US economic indicators, while China's fiscal deficit for 2024 is expected to be balanced between growth and risk prevention. The European Central Bank is expected to keep interest rates unchanged, and analysts expect US rate cuts to start later this year.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 63 to 45 after 36.2 million securities worth S$28 million change hands.
The Stoxx 600 slipped 0.03 per cent, having scaled another record high earlier during Monday's session and coming close to the 500-mark.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.3 per cent lower at 38,989.83 on Monday.

site_title: Ex-Twitter executives sue Musk for unpaid severance
summary: Former Twitter executives, including CEO Parag Agrawal, CFO Ned Segal, and Chief Legal Officer Vijaya Gadde, have sued Elon Musk for nearly $130 million in unpaid severance. Musk terminated them after closing his $44 billion Twitter takeover in 2022. The lawsuit claims Musk broke the terms of the deal and "believes the rules don't apply to him." The executives are seeking $57.4 million and $44.5 million in benefits, respectively, and are also suing Musk to be reimbursed for costs related to their former jobs.

images.alt_text: The wealth gap between Elon Musk (above) and Jeff Bezos has been shrinking as Amazon and Tesla shares move in opposite directions.
Musk sues OpenAI and its chief executive Sam Altman (above) for allegedly breaking their founding agreement
Austin-based Tesla, with a US$645 billion valuation, is among the largest companies in the world by market cap.
Musk is bringing the suit in the capacity of a donor to OpenAI’s non-profit parent organisation as recently as 2019 and is seeking to force OpenAI to stop benefiting Microsoft and Altman personally.
The lawsuit filed late on Thursday (Feb 29) says Altman and OpenAI’s co-founder Greg Brockman originally approached Musk (above) to make an open source, non-profit company.
Zuckerberg, 39, has been selling Meta stock to fund philanthropy.

site_title: Catch Rod Stewart one last time in Singapore
summary: Rod Stewart will perform two intimate shows at Marina Bay Sands in Singapore on March 16 and 17 as part of his Live in Concert: One Last Time tour. The 79-year-old singer, known for hits like "Have I Told You Lately" and "Do You Think I'm Sexy?", will bring his setlist of biggest hits to the city-state after a 15-year hiatus. The shows are part of the Sands Live series and will be his first in the region in over a decade.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
The production value of Taylor Swift's Eras Tour is top-notch, with LED screens forming a gigantic backdrop as well as bringing the entire stage surface to life.

site_title: Indonesia’s Prabowo aims high, shoots for 8% GDP growth in next 5 years
summary: Indonesia's presumed president Prabowo Subianto has set an ambitious economic growth target of 8% in the next five years, aiming to vault the country's economy to advanced-economy status by 2045. This target, higher than outgoing President Joko Widodo's goal of 7%, is expected to bring the country's per capita GDP to $25,000 by 2045 and create 10 million jobs. Prabowo's plan includes effective management, privatization of state-owned enterprises, and tax reforms to attract foreign investment and create an investment-friendly environment.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
Expectations of lower production have driven up retail prices of the grain.
A worker arranges a rice sack at the warehouse in Jakarta, Indonesia, February 13, 2024. REUTERS/Ajeng Dinar Ulfiana

site_title: Stocks to watch: City Developments Ltd
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) is close to sealing a $356 million deal to buy the Hilton Paris Opera hotel from Blackstone. The acquisition is part of CDL's efforts to expand its portfolio in Europe. CDL's counter closed 1.4% lower at $5.62 before the news.

site_title: Asia’s growth star Philippines woos companies for projects worth US$43 billion
summary: The Philippines is reviving its push for private sector funding for infrastructure projects worth US$43 billion to ease fiscal strain and reduce foreign borrowings. The government aims to grow the economy by 6.5-7.5% this year and accelerate over 100 projects, including airport upgrades and subway operations, with the private sector. This move balances infrastructure goals with fiscal consolidation, as the government targets to reduce its budget deficit to 3% of GDP by 2028. The private sector is willing to invest in bankable and viable projects, but the government needs to do the work, according to officials.

images.alt_text: The Philippines has looked to retail bonds, typically offered in small denominations of 5,000 pesos, to raise a significant portion of its funding requirements.

Philippines transportation ministry selects a consortium led by conglomerate San Miguel as its preferred bidder to upgrade and operate the Ninoy Aquino International Airport (NAIA) in the capital Manila.

FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: A security guard stands beside a logo of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (Central Bank of the Philippines) posted at the main gate in Manila, Philippines April 28, 2016. REUTERS/Romeo Ranoco/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: The case for a European public-goods fund
summary: The European Union has agreed to revise its fiscal rules, replacing the Stability and Growth Pact with a modernized framework that allows for a differentiated approach. The new rules aim to maintain existing deficit and public debt limits while encouraging investment in green and digital technologies. However, funding for digital and green investments will be insufficient, prompting the proposal of a US$750 billion EU public-goods fund to bridge funding gaps. The fund would be financed by EU bonds, pooled national guarantees, and the EU budget, and would focus on cross-border investments to support transnational projects.

images.alt_text: Hamburg-based maritime-technology firm OceanScore says Asia-based shipowners will foot 500 million euros under the European Union Emissions Trading System this year for a start, and rise each year thereafter.
A draft statement for a meeting of EU foreign ministers later this month showed the 27-nation country bloc will argue the oil and gas sector should also contribute.

site_title: Hotpot restaurant chain Haidilao serves up franchise model
summary: Haidilao International Holding, a Chinese hotpot chain, has announced the launch of a franchise model to expand its restaurant network. As of June 30, 2023, the company operates 1,382 company-owned restaurants in Greater China. Under the franchise model, franchised restaurants will receive central and back-office services, including staff training, supply chain management, and brand marketing, to ensure food safety and customer experience. The move aims to support the company's further expansion and strengthen its presence in the market.

images.alt_text: Customers dine at the Hailao Huoguo, a new hotpot chain by Haidilao, in Beijing, China December 10, 2023. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang

site_title: Amazon’s AWS to launch Saudi Arabia data centres, invest over US$5.3 billion
summary: Amazon Web Services (AWS) plans to launch data centers in Saudi Arabia in 2026, investing over $5.3 billion, to enable secure content storage and high-speed workloads. The move follows increasing interest in the region for artificial intelligence (AI) technologies, with Saudi Arabia pitching itself as a hub for AI activity outside the US. This investment is part of a larger trend, with major tech companies including Google and Microsoft also expanding their presence in the kingdom.

site_title: Staggered down payment scheme enhanced to help more young couples buy new HDB flats
summary: Singapore's Housing and Development Board (HDB) has enhanced its Staggered Downpayment Scheme (SDS) to help more young couples buy new flats. The revised scheme will reduce the initial down payment to 2.5% of the flat price, regardless of the financing option, and provide an additional S$300 monthly rental voucher for eligible families. The changes aim to support young couples in settling down and starting families earlier. The revised scheme will take effect from the next Build-To-Order (BTO) sales launch in June 2024.

images.alt_text: Generic photos for Budget 2024
Ry-Anne Lim

site_title: Higher car sales push Singapore retail sales up by 1.3% in January, reversing December’s decline
summary: Singapore's retail sales grew 1.3% year-over-year in January, reversing December's 0.5% decline, driven by higher motor vehicle sales. Total retail sales stood at S$4.3 billion, with online sales accounting for 11.2% of this. Excluding motor vehicles, retail sales fell 2.1% year-over-year but grew sequentially. Half of the 14 retail sales categories recorded year-on-year growth, while food and beverage services fell 5.6% year-over-year but grew 0.3% sequentially.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Singapore retail sales down 0.4% in December, reversing November’s gain

site_title: Philippine inflation halts four-month slowdown on costlier rice
summary: The Philippines' inflation rate accelerated to 3.4% in February, surpassing economists' expectations, driven by higher rice costs. This increase builds the case for the central bank to maintain its key interest rate at 17-year highs. The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) stated that it will keep monetary policy settings unchanged, citing temporary price increases above its 2-4% target due to El Nino dry weather impacts.

site_title: Japan’s service activity grows in February on firm tourism
summary: Japan's service sector activity expanded in February, extending gains for one-and-a-half years, driven by solid demand in tourism and new product launches. The final au Jibun Bank Service purchasing managers' index rose to 52.9, above the 50.0 threshold, despite a slight easing in expansion. The service sector's growth is offsetting weakness in manufacturing, which weakened on soft demand. Employment grew at the strongest pace since May, and business confidence eased to a four-month low, but optimism remained in the service sector on increased business investment plans.

images.alt_text: In the last few years the government has maintained that Japan was no longer in deflation, but it has stopped short of declaring a complete victory over falling prices.
Investor focus is now on this year’s wage negotiations, which could deliver more hefty pay hikes, a prerequisite for ending negative interest rates.

Both production and new orders, the two main subindexes of Japan's PMI, declined at the fastest pace in a year. Respondents cited factors such as weak sales demand at home and overseas as well as production delays due to machinery shutdowns.

site_title: Waiter, there’s a fly in my soup
summary: Insect farming is unlikely to lead to a more sustainable global food system, contrary to expectations that it would reduce meat consumption. Instead, it will likely accelerate humanity's growing appetite for poultry and mammal flesh, addressing the protein deficit in intensive farming. Insect farming can be a more efficient way to convert waste into high-quality protein, but its integration into feed for livestock may not be as environmentally friendly as anticipated. Emissions from livestock remain a significant climate concern, and a shift towards insect-based feed may not be enough to mitigate this issue.

images.alt_text: Singapore-based Entobel uses by-products from Heineken Vietnam's beer production to rear black soldier fly larvae for aquafeed and pet food.
The Singapore Food Agency has extended its deadline to approve 16 species of insects for human consumption to the first half of 2024.

site_title: Does interest rate pain explain the consumer sentiment gap?
summary: US interest rates set by the Federal Reserve significantly impact perceptions of the cost of living, affecting consumer sentiment despite low unemployment, decreasing inflation, and rising real wages. A new study by former Treasury Secretary Larry Summers and economists at Harvard and the International Monetary Fund suggests that consumers consider the cost of money as part of their cost of living, contributing to the disconnect between economic indicators and consumer sentiment.

images.alt_text: money, home, coin
FILE PHOTO: The logo of the European Central Bank (ECB) is pictured outside its headquarters in Frankfurt, Germany, December 8, 2016.  REUTERS/Ralph Orlowski

site_title: Country Garden’s sales drop most in years amid wind-up fears
summary: Country Garden Holdings reported its largest sales decline in at least seven years, with contracted sales plummeting 85% in February compared to the same period last year. The Chinese property developer, facing a lawsuit seeking liquidation, has been utilizing a regulator's property funding program. Chairman Yang Huiyan stated the company will rely on its own resources to deliver sold housing projects, aiming to complete 480,000 units this year. The sales drought exacerbates the company's cash crunch, adding to the woes of the Chinese property sector, which is still reeling from the collapse of another giant, China Evergrande Group.

images.alt_text: China’s property sector has lurched from one crisis to another since 2021 after a regulatory crackdown on debt-fuelled construction triggered a liquidity squeeze.
In a sign that Country Garden’s creditors are ready for further negotiations, an ad-hoc creditor group hired financial and legal advisers in recent months.

The headquarters of Country Garden Holdings in Foshan, Guangdong province. The embattled developer's debt-restructuring process, which gathered momentum in recent weeks, is set to be clouded by the liquidation petition.
Property agent Knight Frank says it has been appointed by Risland UK – a susbidiary of Country Garden – to market the 1,000-home Calico Wharf development site.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat from records
summary: US stocks retreated from records on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.3% to 38,989.83. The S&P 500 declined 0.1% and the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.4%. Investors were cautious ahead of key economic data and central bank actions, including Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's testimony and a European Central Bank decision. Tech companies, including Nvidia, rose, while Apple slumped 2.5% after an EU antitrust fine.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, losers outnumber gainers 342 to 232 as 1.6 billion securities worth S$967.8 million change hands.

site_title: AMD hits US roadblock in selling AI chip tailored for China
summary: AMD has hit a roadblock in selling an artificial intelligence (AI) chip tailored for the Chinese market due to US export restrictions. The chip, designed to meet US export restrictions, has lower performance than AMD's standard AI chips. US officials told AMD that the chip is still too powerful and requires a license from the Commerce Department's Bureau of Industry and Security to sell. This decision comes as the US has been working to limit Chinese access to cutting-edge semiconductors that can develop AI models, out of fear that Beijing will gain a military edge.

images.alt_text: The company is seen as one of the primary beneficiaries of AI, and last month, optimism about new AI processors helped AMD shares recover from a weak forecast.
As companies look to develop and operate their own generative AI applications, enterprise budgets are being funnelled into processors used in AI servers.
AI-enabled PCs refer to machines that come with advanced chips capable of running large-language models and apps powered by the technology directly on the device, instead of the cloud.
AMD forecast current-quarter revenue of about US$6.1 billion, plus or minus US$300 million.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hover near record highs at start of busy week
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 slipped 0.03% on Monday, near a record high, as investors digested strong gains and awaited the European Central Bank's monetary policy meeting this week. Tech stocks led gains, while cyclical sectors like miners and retailers limited overall market gains. The ECB is expected to keep interest rates at 4% but lower inflation outlook, potentially leading to rate cuts in June.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.3 per cent lower at 38,989.83 on Monday.

site_title: Shell companies in Singapore linked to money laundering operation in India
summary: India's Enforcement Directorate has uncovered a money laundering operation involving fake invoices issued by shell companies in Singapore, linked to loan, gambling and betting apps controlled by Chinese entities. The operation allegedly laundered 1.23 billion rupees (S$19.9 million) through multiple shell companies in Indian cities and used Nium India to move funds, including cryptocurrencies. The agency has frozen these funds and raided locations in Mumbai, Chennai, and Kochi, recovering and seizing digital devices and bank accounts used for laundering.

images.alt_text: Narendra Modi is well placed to win a third term in a national election that will begin Apr 19.

site_title: JPMorgan joins French payments fray in tie-up with Visa rival
summary: JPMorgan Chase has joined France's Cartes Bancaires network, becoming the first US bank to be approved as a principal member. The move aims to provide "competitive transactions costs" for French clients and support the network. Cartes Bancaires processes 15 billion transactions annually, accounting for 65% of regular consumption in France. JPMorgan's goal is to offer the option to French merchants by the end of the year, following demand from merchant clients. The partnership is part of JPMorgan's expansion in Europe, where total payments revenues are expected to reach $500 billion by 2027.

images.alt_text: Within JPMorgan, Neovest’s platform serves more than 500 clients.
JPMorgan provides both global and local custodian services for clients in Hong Kong and Taiwan.
The price of Bitcoin has historically increased after a halving event, with so-called miner production cost functioning as a lower bound to the price of the asset.
JPMorgan CFO Jeremy Barnum expects the IPO market to be a bit weaker than expected. However, the investment banking fee is expected to rise in low-to-mid teens percentage in the first quarter.

site_title: US auditors find non-compliance at Boeing, Sprit AeroSystems
summary: US auditors found non-compliance at Boeing and Spirit AeroSystems, with multiple instances of failure to meet manufacturing quality control requirements. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) identified issues in Boeing's manufacturing process control, parts handling, and product control following a January incident where a 737 MAX suffered a mid-flight blowout. Boeing has 90 days to address quality control problems, with the FAA's investigation ongoing.

site_title: American Airlines orders 260 jets from Airbus, Boeing, Embraer
summary: American Airlines has ordered 260 new planes from Airbus, Embraer, and Boeing, with options for an additional 193 aircraft. The order includes 85 Airbus A321neo jets, 90 Embraer E175 planes, and 85 Boeing 737 MAX 10 jets. The total value of the order is over $29 billion. The announcement comes despite recent safety concerns surrounding Boeing's 737 MAX, with regulators giving the company 90 days to address quality control issues.

site_title: Oil settles lower on weak demand despite Opec+ cut extension
summary: Oil prices settled lower on Monday, despite Opec+ extending its voluntary output cuts through the middle of the year, due to weak demand and a warm winter in the northern hemisphere. Brent futures fell 75 cents to $82.80 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) dropped 1.5% to $78.74 a barrel. Analysts attributed the decline to lower heating oil demand and market expectations of a ceasefire in Gaza. However, Opec+ cuts are expected to lead to lower production and a tightening of sweet crude markets.

site_title: China sets ambitious 5% growth target for 2024
summary: China has set a 5% growth target for 2024, a challenging objective for the country's leaders. This target aligns with the country's GDP growth last year, one of the lowest in decades. Premier Li Qiang announced the goal alongside the overall budget and key government policies for 2024 during the annual National People's Congress. Achieving this target will not be easy, according to Li.

site_title: Morgan Stanley offers pre-IPO share trading to wealth clients
summary: Morgan Stanley's wealth management arm is offering pre-IPO share trading to its clients, allowing them to buy and sell shares of private companies before they go public. This service will assist clients in investing in the highly fragmented and opaque market for private shares, with over 1,000 unicorns valued at over $1 billion available. The bank will take an "open and agnostic approach" to complete trades, working with external platforms and its internal arms. This move aims to cater to investors seeking liquidity in the private market, which has seen increased pressure in recent years.

site_title: American Air wants more credit card revenue from bank partners
summary: American Airlines is renegotiating its credit card contract with Citigroup and Barclays to boost revenue from co-branded cards. The airline aims to increase its share of revenue from 7% to 10% by 2026, with current revenue at $5.2 billion in 2023. American will seek a bank that can create the largest branded credit card and a partnership that would drive growth. The airline's new contract will target a leadership position in the industry's business model, where US carriers earn billions of dollars annually from agreements with banks purchasing miles for co-branded cards.

site_title: Hwa Hong sells freehold data centre building in Paya Lebar Road for S$140 million
summary: Hwa Hong Corporation sold OneTen Paya Lebar, a freehold data centre building in Singapore, to an entity linked to Big Data Exchange (BDx) for S$140 million. The sale came after an expression of interest exercise closed in October last year. The property, located on a corner island site, has redevelopment potential if height restrictions are lifted and plot ratios increased. This sale follows a growing trend in demand for data centres in South-east Asia and North Asia, expected to expand by 25% annually to 2028.

site_title: War insurers shrug off Rubymar sinking in Red Sea, rates stable
summary: War risk insurance premiums for Red Sea voyages remain stable at 1% of a ship's value, despite the sinking of the Rubymar cargo ship, which was valued at $4.82 million and not covered by major London marine insurance market. The vessel was hit by a missile in February, but underwriters had already factored in the risk after the attacks started in November. The industry had previously seen a rise in war risk premiums due to the attacks.

site_title: EU seals deal on banning single-use plastic packaging in cafes from 2030
summary: The European Union has agreed to ban single-use plastics in cafes and restaurants from 2030, aiming to cut packaging waste by 5% by 2030, 10% by 2035, and 15% by 2040. The decision was reached after intense lobbying by fast-food giants and the paper industry, who argued that cardboard packaging is more environmentally friendly. The EU's 27 nations and lawmakers agreed on the draft text, marking a significant step towards reducing waste and promoting sustainability in the bloc.

site_title: Asean’s Taylor tussle; Swift jump in Indonesia stocks
summary: Taylor Swift's Asia-Pacific tour has sparked economic concerns in Southeast Asia. Her decision to only stop in Singapore has led to "Swiftonomics" being coined to describe her impact on the economy. Thailand's Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin claimed that Singapore offered a million-dollar subsidy for each concert in exchange for regional exclusivity, but Singapore confirmed only a grant was given. Meanwhile, Indonesia's presidential election has boosted investor confidence, with the Jakarta Composite Index rising 1.3% and the central bank maintaining its benchmark interest rate.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Tuesday’s open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.2% at the opening bell on Tuesday, driven by a gain in the Straits Times Index (STI). The STI gained 5.28 points to 3,127.49, with Seatrium trading flat and Golden Agri-Resources and AnAn International also unchanged. Banking stocks traded mixed, with DBS gaining 0.2% and OCBC and UOB flat. This follows overnight losses in global markets, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.3% and the S&P 500 down 0.1%.

site_title: Car auctions top US$180 million with Bugatti, Ferraris, US$12 million Mercedes
summary: Classic car sales in Florida reached a record-breaking US$181.67 million over four auction houses, surpassing last year's peak of US$178 million. The top seller was a 1903 Mercedes-Simplex 60 HP Roi Des Belges at Gooding & Co, which fetched US$12.1 million including premiums. Other notable sales included a 1967 Ford GT40 at Broad Arrow for US$4,405,000 and a 1953 Ferrari 250 Europa Coupe at RM Sotheby's for US$4,295,000. The average price of cars sold was US$384,954, with sell-through rates at 82% for 472 vehicles offered.

site_title: Elon Musk loses world’s richest person title to Jeff Bezos
summary: Elon Musk loses his title as the world's richest person to Jeff Bezos, who surpassed him with a net worth of $200.3 billion. Musk's wealth dropped after Tesla shares fell 7.2% on Monday, while Amazon shares have more than doubled since late 2022. A Delaware judge also voided Musk's $55 billion pay package, which could further impact his wealth. Bezos first held the top spot in 2017, but Musk briefly took it in 2021 before Bezos regained the lead.

site_title: China calls out US for ‘classic protectionism’ in tension over EVs
summary: China accused the US of engaging in "classic protectionism" over its efforts to restrict Chinese electric vehicles (EVs) from entering the American market. The US Commerce Department is investigating potential data and cybersecurity risks posed by Chinese EVs, while a 27.5% tariff imposed by former president Donald Trump limits Chinese auto companies' presence in the US. China warned it will take "forceful" measures to safeguard its legitimate rights and interests if necessary, amid concerns that tariffs alone may not keep Chinese cars out of the US market.
