site_title: Adani storms into bond market with a US$409 million sale
summary: Adani Group successfully raised $409 million in a 18-year bond sale, attracting around $2.9 billion of orders. The bond sale, which offered a yield of 6.70%, is seen as a sign of the company's regained investor confidence, following a report by short seller Hindenburg Research last year. The bond sale will be used to redeem a $500 million note maturing in December, and analysts believe the deal will help Adani Green Energy become an investment-grade company again.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of the Adani Group is seen on a commercial complex in Mumbai, India, February 7, 2023. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas/File Photo
Gautam Adani’s rebound is happening as global investors increasingly focus on the nation, helping boost stocks.
The flagship firm of billionaire Gautam Adani’s empire posted net income of 18.9 billion rupees (S$305 million) for the quarter through December

site_title: Nvidia leaps Aramco to be world’s third most-valuable company
summary: Nvidia has surpassed Saudi Aramco to become the world's third-most valuable public company, surpassing Apple and Microsoft. The chipmaker's shares have skyrocketed 66% this year, driven by strong earnings and optimism on the potential for artificial intelligence to reshape the technology industry. Nvidia's market value reached $2.06 trillion, surpassing Aramco's $2.03 trillion. The company's dominance in graphics chips for AI applications has fueled its growth, while Aramco faces challenges from lower production and a potential government offering.

site_title: Closing gender gap could lift global GDP more than 20%: World Bank
summary: The World Bank's 10th annual Women, Business and the Law report finds a significant gap between policy and practice in protecting women worldwide. Implementing existing laws to prevent discriminatory practices could raise global GDP by over 20%, doubling the rate of global growth over the next decade. Women face obstacles such as pay gaps, bans on working at night, and limited childcare services, with only 64% of legal protections for women compared to 77% for men. The report recommends reforms to address these issues and calls for countries to implement policies that promote women's economic empowerment.

images.alt_text: Job seekers at a career fair. The Bureau of Labor Statistics has reported that the annual average weekly earnings for women last year was US$1,005, or 83.6 per cent of the US$1,202 earned by men.
IMF's Kristalina Georgieva says that if there are other “consequences in terms of where the fighting goes, it could be more problematic for the world as a whole”.
“Without a major course correction, the 2020s will go down as a decade of wasted opportunity,” says World Bank Group chief economist Indermit Gill.
The World Bank released the second and final tranche of a total US$500 million package “considering the continued satisfactory progress made by the government with the reform programme”.
FILE PHOTO: The World Bank logo is seen at the 2023 Spring Meetings of the World Bank Group and the International Monetary Fund in Washington, U.S., April 13, 2023. REUTERS/Elizabeth Frantz

site_title: Government to assess sustainability criteria of Mice tenders from FY2025
summary: The Singapore government will assess the sustainability credentials of companies bidding for meetings, incentives, conferences, and exhibitions (Mice) tenders from financial year 2025. This move comes after the government introduced environmental sustainability criteria for tenders last year. Senior Minister of State for Sustainability and the Environment Amy Khor will consult with the Mice industry before finalizing details. The goal is to promote environmentally responsible practices in the public sector.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
The Sustainability Reporting Grant is for large companies with annual revenues of S$100 million and above.
Skyline of Singapore's Business District taken from Marina Bay Sands on Oct 17, 2023. For stories on sustainability, garden city, air quality and more.
Once fully operational in 2025, the facility can remove 3,650 tonnes of CO2 from the ocean yearly.
Airbus chief sustainability officer Julie Kitcher said Singapore's recently announced levy for outbound travellers as part of its sustainable air hub drive is a “very positive and concrete” step.
Solar panels deployed at Singapore's Kusu Island. The country is committed to accelerate its shift to low-carbon energy sources.

site_title: India’s Tata Motors plans to demerge business into two separate companies
summary: Tata Motors plans to demerge its business into two separate companies, one focusing on commercial vehicles and the other on passenger vehicles, including electric vehicles and Jaguar Land Rover. The demerger aims to enhance growth prospects for employees and increase shareholder value. The scheme will be placed before the board in the coming months and subject to necessary approvals, expected to take 12-15 months to complete. Shareholders will retain an identical shareholding in both entities, with no adverse impact on employees, customers, or business partners.

site_title: Euro, pound edge up at start of busy week ahead for investors
summary: The US dollar weakened slightly, rising 0.20% to 150.43 yen, while the euro rose 0.13% to US$1.08 and sterling gained 0.19% to US$1.2677. Bitcoin reached a two-year peak above US$65,000, and the British budget and European Central Bank meeting are set for this week, which could impact market volatility. Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell is also set to testify before lawmakers on Wednesday and Thursday, with US payrolls data due on Friday.

images.alt_text: People walk past a currency exchange bureau in downtown Nairobi, Kenya. Africa’s rapidly depreciating currencies are eroding households’ savings.
FILE PHOTO: U.S. Dollar banknotes are seen in this illustration taken July 17, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The US dollar index is flat at 103.94 and heading for a February increase 0.38 per cent.

site_title: Sea to make Shopee prices more competitive, build digital banking services after first year in the black
summary: Sea Ltd, the parent company of e-commerce platform Shopee, has announced plans to improve price competitiveness on its platform and build digital banking and insurance services under its payment arm, SeaMoney. Following its first profitable year since listing on the New York Stock Exchange in 2017, Sea chairman and CEO Forrest Li emphasized the company's commitment to putting users first and continues to focus on growth and user experience.

images.alt_text: Founder Forrest Li says Garena's most valued assets are its employees, on whom it relies to share immediate and up-to-date market intel on the latest disruptive trends, and to get ahead of them.
Navene Elangovan

site_title: EU wants fossil fuel sector to help pay to combat climate change, draft shows
summary: The European Union is set to propose that the fossil fuel industry contribute to combating climate change in poorer countries under a United Nations target. A draft EU statement for a meeting of foreign ministers shows the bloc will argue that the oil and gas sector should also pay towards the goal. The EU aims to rally support for international fossil fuel taxes, with the OECD estimating that poor nations' actual climate investment needs could total $1 trillion per year by 2025.

images.alt_text: Tuesday’s proposal will kick off political debate on the target, but it will be up to a new EU Commission and parliament, formed after EU elections in June, to pass the final target.
The green shift in the 27-nation bloc will affect every corner of the economy, requiring more sustainable consumer lifestyles and more effort from businesses and agriculture.
EU Climate Action Commissioner Wopke Hoekstra says the EU would not accept an outcome at COP28 that only reached deals on less contentious topics.

site_title: Traders wary UK’s budget risks revving inflation
summary: UK Chancellor Jeremy Hunt's upcoming budget is sparking concerns among traders about the risk of higher inflation if he delivers pre-election giveaways. Investors fear that tax cuts could increase consumer prices, making it difficult for the Bank of England to cut interest rates as expected this year. The budget is seen as a crucial test for Hunt, who must balance fiscal responsibility with the need to boost the Conservative Party's election prospects. A fiscal stimulus could further deteriorate the UK bond market, which is already off to a bad start to the year, with rate-cut expectations slashed amid worries on persistent price pressures and resilient consumer spending.

images.alt_text: British Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt is open to the idea of creating a so-called British ISA, a tax-free savings account for investing in UK equities.
British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak (left) and Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt at a cabinet meeting in February. The UK is now in recession after two straight quarters of negative growth.

site_title: Apple hit with 1.8 billion euro fine over abusive app store rules
summary: The European Union has fined Apple 1.8 billion euros for allegedly abusing its dominant position in the market for music streaming apps through the App Store. The EU's antitrust chief, Margrethe Vestager, claims Apple restricted developers from informing consumers about cheaper music services outside the App Store. Apple rejected the fine, stating regulators failed to uncover credible evidence of consumer harm. The EU's Digital Markets Act, set to take effect March 7, prohibits companies from favoring their own services and will allow users to download apps from rival platforms.

site_title: Boeing supplier Senior posts profit jump, boosts dividend
summary: Senior, a British aerospace engineer, raised its dividend after 2023 profits nearly doubled due to increased civil aircraft production rates and robust demand in land vehicle markets. The company forecasts 2024 performance to be in line with estimates, with Boeing maintaining production of 737 MAX plane parts at previously agreed levels. Senior's adjusted pre-tax profit jumped 91% to £38.3 million, with a proposed annual dividend of 2.3 pence, up 77%.

images.alt_text: Boeing spun off Spirit in 2005 and in recent years has struggled with cost pressures and problems that have slowed aircraft deliveries and thinned its balance sheet.

site_title: CDL in talks to buy Hilton Paris Opera hotel from Blackstone at reported price of 244 million euros
summary: CDL is in talks to acquire the Hilton Paris Opera hotel from Blackstone for 244 million euros, marking the group's third major European property acquisition from Blackstone. The 268-key hotel is located near the Paris Saint-Lazare train station and the Eiffel Tower. If the deal is completed, it will be CDL's third hotel in Paris, adding to its portfolio of the M Social Hotel Paris Opera and the Millennium Hotel Paris Charles de Gaulle.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim

From left: Yiong Yim Ming, group chief financial officer; Sherman Kwek, group chief executive officer; Kwek Leng Beng, executive chairman; Kwek Eik Sheng, group chief operating officer; and Chia Ngiang Hong, group general manager, at the CDL media briefing.

site_title: Sea books profit of US$162.7 million, expects e-commerce breakeven by second half of 2024
summary: Sea, a US$162.7 million profitable company for 2023, exceeded analysts' forecasts with 4.9% revenue growth to US$13.1 billion. E-commerce arm Shopee booked profits for the first two quarters of 2023, driving 23.5% revenue growth to US$9 billion. Digital entertainment unit Garena reported a profit of US$1.2 billion, while SeaMoney's first profitable year was driven by credit business revenue growth. Sea expects Shopee's 2024 gross merchandise value growth to be in the "high teens" and adjusted earnings to turn positive in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
FILE PHOTO: A lanyard showing logos of Southeast Asian e-commerce and gaming group Sea Ltd is pictured at its office in Singapore, March 5, 2021. REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo
Sea's chairman Forrest Li says that the company will continue to put its users first.
The offices leased to Sea are in the upper part of the 17-storey tower at Rochester Commons; The project was completed in phases in the second half of 2022.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, March 4, 2024 (Ep 14)
summary: The Nikkei 225 stock index in Japan reached a record-breaking level of 40,000 for the first time, surpassing a key threshold. Meanwhile, Singapore's shares rallied at Monday's open, with the STI up 0.3%. Thailand plans to clamp down on short selling, and Great Eastern shareholders have proposed resolutions to table at their upcoming Annual General Meeting (AGM).

images.alt_text: Singapore shares rally at Monday’s open; STI up 0.3%
A woman walks past an electronic board displaying a share price of the Nikkei index of the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Tokyo, Japan, March 4, 2024.

site_title: Lufthansa warns latest two-day strike will hit 200,000 travellers
summary: Lufthansa expects a two-day strike by ground crews to disrupt travel for over 200,000 passengers, as the Verdi union demands a 12.5% salary increase and 3,000 euros inflation bonus. The airline is willing to negotiate, but the strike will likely be exacerbated by a separate strike by Deutsche Bahn workers. This marks the third time in a month that thousands of passengers have been affected by strikes in Germany's transport industry, amid staff shortages and high inflation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Lufthansa's aircrafts are seen on the tarmac the day before VERDI union called airport workers at Frankfurt, Munich, Stuttgart, Hamburg, Dortmund, Hanover and Bremen airports to go on a 24-hour strike on Friday, at the Munich International Airport, Germany, February 16, 2023. REUTERS/Leonhard Simon///File Photo

site_title: BT Corporate Golf League returns with five-leg tournament
summary: The BT Corporate Golf League 2024 is set to begin on March 7 at Sentosa Golf Club, featuring 17 teams in the competitive and social categories. Defending champions Hugo Boss will field an all-woman team for the first time, led by captain Marilyn Lum and team manager Melanie Goh. The tournament will consist of five legs, with the finale held at Laguna National Golf and Country Club's Masters course on May 9. The competitive category features six all-male teams, while the social category has 11 teams, including Singapore Pools and Adidas as sponsors.

images.alt_text: Hannah Green of Australia lifts the trophy after winning the final round of the HSBC Women's World Championship golf tournament at Sentosa Golf Club in Singapore on Sunday.
我国15岁小将陈星彤在本地球员的资格赛脱颖而出，获得参加汇丰女子高球世锦赛的机会。（汇丰女子高球世锦赛提供）

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 4)
summary: Singapore's retirement age will rise to 64 in 2026, and re-employment age to 69, as part of a plan to reach 65 and 70 by 2030. The minimum qualifying salary for Employment Passes will increase to S$5,600 from 2025. Nearly 4,200 applications for the One Pass for top foreign talent have been approved in the first year. Retaining the CPF Special Account for those aged 55 and up will create a generational divide, according to the Manpower Minister.

site_title: Australia warns South-east Asia of 'coercive actions'
summary: Australia has warned South-east Asian countries of "coercive actions" amid tensions over China's growing assertiveness in the South China Sea. Foreign Minister Penny Wong announced A$286.5 million in funding for Asean projects, including maritime security, as regional leaders meet in Melbourne. China claims nearly the entire South China Sea, a conduit for $3 trillion in commerce, with the Permanent Court of Arbitration ruling its claims have no legal basis. Australia and the Philippines are conducting joint patrols in the area, while hundreds of protesters gathered in Melbourne calling for action against Myanmar's military junta.

images.alt_text: Taiwan, US to strengthen maritime coordination as China looms

site_title: Europe’s biggest pension fund ABP tightens ESG investing guardrails
summary: Europe's largest pension fund, ABP, has implemented stricter environmental, social, and governance (ESG) requirements for its portfolio, aiming to invest in companies that can mitigate climate and biodiversity risks. The policy excludes companies involved in fossil fuels, nuclear weapons, and other controversies. ABP will now apply tougher screens when reviewing holdings, prioritizing firms that manage risks and take long-term approaches. The fund aims to allocate €10 billion in impact investments, targeting €30 billion in total.

site_title: China exchanges hold compliance training session for quant funds
summary: China's Shenzhen and Shanghai stock exchanges held a compliance training session for 28 leading quant hedge funds to prevent trading risks. The training aimed to help quant funds understand regulatory mindset and work requirements, following recent regulatory scrutiny and market volatility. The session introduced typical cases of abnormal trading and emphasized the need for internal risk control management to ensure stable market operations. This comes after Chinese quant funds faced a market sell-off and government curbs on short-selling, with the blue-chip index hitting five-year lows last month.

site_title: A 'gentle reminder' on fashion's environmental harm from Stella McCartney at Paris show
summary: Stella McCartney's Paris fashion show highlighted the environmental harm of the fashion industry. The collection featured garments made from recycled materials such as wool, nylon, and polyester, and even apple-based leather. The show, held in a giant greenhouse, aimed to raise awareness about the impact of fashion on the planet. McCartney's message was echoed through the soundtrack, which featured images of melting icebergs and a voice asking, "What will be left of me, after you?" The show concludes that the fashion industry must adopt more sustainable practices to mitigate its environmental harm.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - (COMBO) This combination of pictures created on March 04, 2024 shows British model Lila Grace Moss (L) and models presenting a creation by Stella McCartney for the Women Ready-to-wear Fall-Winter 2024/2025 collection as part of the Paris Fashion Week, in Paris on March 4, 2024. (Photo by Miguel MEDINA / AFP)
Shoppers walk past a Christian Dior SE store in Shanghai, China, on Saturday 10 June, 2017. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Australia pledges US$1.3 billion to spur South-east Asia investment
summary: Australia has pledged US$1.3 billion to boost trade and investment in South-east Asia, aiming to strengthen regional ties amid uncertainty over the US-China economic relationship. The funding will support infrastructure financing partnerships, investment "landing pads," and extend business visas to eligible countries. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese will highlight the importance of South-east Asia to Australia's future, citing a record US$178 billion in two-way trade with Asean member states in 2022. The move is seen as a bid to diversify Australia's trading partners and counterbalance China's growing influence.

images.alt_text: Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong says Canberra is providing A$286.5 million in funding for Asean projects in areas including maritime security.

site_title: KPMG fined £1.5 million over Saatchi audit failings
summary: KPMG has been fined £1.5 million by Britain's accounting watchdog for its audit failings in the lead-up to an accounting scandal at advertising firm M&C Saatchi. The firm and its partner Adrian Wilcox failed to audit with sufficient professional skepticism, leading to £14 million of direct misstatements of profits. The Financial Reporting Council also fined Wilcox £48,750. The audit team's shortcomings included failing to properly audit journal entries and identify potentially high-risk journals.

images.alt_text: Partners at KPMG’s operations in the UK and Switzerland were told last Friday the firms were in talks about a possible combination, the FT report said, citing people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Singapore to raise retirement age to 64, re-employment age to 69 in 2026
summary: Singapore's retirement age will increase to 64 by 2026 and re-employment age to 69, as part of a plan to reach 65 and 70 by 2030. This follows a successful tripartite agreement and comes after the last age increase in 2022 to 63 and 68. The move aims to support the aging population and ensure a stable workforce.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
‘Fairer’ to retain CPF Special Account for those already aged 55 and above: Foo Mee Har
A larger balance in the Enhanced Retirement Sum enablre the distribution of a higher amount from CPF Life in retirement. This goes a long way to ensure a safe and basic income stream.

site_title: Li Qiang is first China premier to skip National People’s Congress briefing since 1993
summary: China's Premier Li Qiang has become the first premier in 30 years to skip a press briefing at the National People's Congress, a move that may fuel investor fears about opaque policymaking. The annual briefing has been in place since 1993, but Lou Qinjian, a spokesperson, announced that Li will not attend this year's meeting. The decision comes as the ruling Communist Party restricts access to information, and investors are closely watching the government's 2024 growth goal, expected to be around 5%, a relatively ambitious target given China's severe economic challenges.

images.alt_text: Premier Li Qiang will deliver the government work report for the first time at the National People’s Congress on Tuesday.
The plan, outlined at a recent Communist Party meeting, is one of a series of steps China is taking to boost the economy which has been recovering weakly since the Covid-19 pandemic.
China's purchasing managers’ index - a key measure of factory output - came in at 49.1 per cent in February, according to China’s National Bureau of Statistics.
Chinese firms has put US$28.2 billion into EV-related industries last year.

site_title: JPMorgan acquires startup Layerone to boost hedge fund offerings
summary: JPMorgan Chase has acquired LayerOne Financial, an investment management platform spun out from Fortress Investment Group, to boost its offerings for hedge funds. Neovest, a JPMorgan subsidiary, will integrate LayerOne's platform, allowing clients to manage their full investment life cycle from one software provider. The acquisition aims to improve Neovest's services for more than 500 clients and gain market share in the hedge fund services market.

site_title: Businesses do not see major cost impact from higher Employment Pass qualifying salaries
summary: Singapore's Employment Pass qualifying salary will increase to S$5,600 for new applicants and S$6,200 for the financial services sector, starting from Jan 1, 2025, and Jan 1, 2026, respectively. Businesses, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises, expect minimal impact due to their limited use of Employment Pass holders. The changes aim to ensure high-quality foreign workers and maintain a level playing field for locals. Meanwhile, foreign worker levies for the marine and offshore engineering sector will be raised, and the dependency ratio ceiling will be cut to one local employee per three foreign workers.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Singapore commits S$100 million over five years to support marine and offshore engineering through support package. PHOTO: PIXABAY
Singapore businesses may become increasingly "multi-city" or "multi-region", as they engage more workers abroad.

site_title: Aviva re-enters Lloyd's market with US$300 million acquisition
summary: British insurer Aviva has re-entered the Lloyd's insurance market with a US$307 million acquisition of insurance platform Probitas. The deal bolsters Aviva's global corporate and speciality business. Probitas's existing management team will continue to run the business, and the brand will be retained. Aviva CEO Amanda Blanc stated that the acquisition will accelerate growth in the company's capital-light General Insurance business, with analysts predicting it will be accretive to Aviva's non-life margins.

site_title: New programme helps fund Singapore companies to train employees for overseas expansion
summary: Singapore's government has launched the Overseas Markets Immersion Programme, providing financial support for companies to train employees for overseas expansion. The programme, which will last the duration of the training, aims to equip mid-career hires with global market experience in technology and business development. This complements the Global Business Leaders Programme, which will provide a nine-month fellowship and mentorship for selected companies to build a stable of Singaporean leaders. The programmes aim to enhance the competitiveness of Singaporean companies in overseas markets.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

site_title: China developer Vanke shares, bonds hit new lows on debt worries
summary: China property developer Vanke shares and bonds hit record lows due to renewed concerns about the company's debt repayment capabilities. The company's shares dropped 7.1% in Hong Kong and 4.7% in Shenzhen, while its US dollar bond fell to 47.3 cents. Vanke is seen as a bellwether for the government's support of the sector, but expectations of policy help remain low. The company is negotiating with lenders to delay payments, fueling concerns about its repayment abilities.

images.alt_text: Vanke needs to navigate a challenging path ahead.
China’s property sector has lurched from one crisis to another since 2021 after a regulatory crackdown on debt-fuelled construction triggered a liquidity squeeze.
China has been ramping up measures to halt a downturn in a property sector that has lurched from one extreme to the other since 2021 after a regulatory crackdown on high leverage.
Financial institutions need to prevent loans from being misappropriated and safeguard the safety of credit funds.

Residential buildings stand in Chongqing, China, on Tuesday, April 12, 2016. The municipality of 30 million people's state-led development approach fueled growth of 11 percent last year, the fastest pace nationwide, with President Xi Jinping praising policy innovations that have included subsidized housing and relaxed residency rules that encourage labor mobility. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

The headquarters of Country Garden Holdings in Foshan, Guangdong province. The embattled developer's debt-restructuring process, which gathered momentum in recent weeks, is set to be clouded by the liquidation petition.
This aerial photo taken on October 25, 2023 shows the Evergrande logo on residential buildings in Nanjing, in China's eastern Jiangsu province. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Nearly 4,200 applications approved in first year of Singapore’s One Pass for top foreign talent
summary: Singapore has approved nearly 4,200 applications under the Overseas Networks and Expertise (One) Pass, a program aimed at recruiting top global talent, in its first year of implementation. The One Pass allows pass holders to work for multiple companies and sponsor dependants, and is highly selective, targeting those with valuable networks and deep skills. To qualify, applicants must earn at least S$30,000 per month. The program is expected to facilitate the recruitment of top talent in growth sectors such as finance and information and communications technology.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

The Overseas Networks and Expertise (One) Pass will be open to top talent across all sectors, and allows them to start, operate and work for multiple companies at any one time. Pass holders will also be able to sponsor their dependants, and have their spouses work in Singapore on a Letter of Consent.

Safeguards will be put in place for the Overseas Networks and Expertise pass, said Minister of Manpower Tan See Leng in a ministerial statement where he also addressed the target nature of the government's recent work pass enhancements.
A global city should welcome foreign talent not just for a short duration until they are no longer ‘needed’, but also if they choose to stay.

site_title: Singapore stocks buck regional gains to end lower on Monday; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended 0.4% lower at 3,122.21 on Monday, bucking regional gains. The market saw 1.6 billion securities worth S$967.8 million trade, with losers outnumbering gainers 342 to 232. Global markets had risen last week, driven by hopes for US interest-rate cuts, cooling inflation, and artificial intelligence sentiment. Venture Corporation was the biggest gainer, while Seatrium was the biggest decliner.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
CMG20240206-HengYY01 / 王彦燕 / SGX Centre 新加坡交易所 [Shenton Way] SGX logo in front of the SGX Centre building at Shenton Way.受限股票（restricted stock unit）
Olam expects its subsidiary's acquisition of feed supplier Avisen to be earnings accretive from 2024.
Singapore shares rally at Monday’s open; STI up 0.3%

site_title: On the risks of inflation and longevity: Why we need to invest our CPF savings
summary: Singapore's Central Provident Fund (CPF) is a tool for individuals to control and grow their personal savings and wealth. Investing in CPF through the CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) can help build a bigger nest egg, but it comes with risk. Taking on too much risk can result in negative returns and losing money. A goal-based or liabilities-driven approach to investing is recommended, where the risk and return are correlated. Investing over the long term can reduce risk and volatility, and individuals should consider using the CPFIS to compound returns.

images.alt_text: Singapore to raise retirement age to 64, re-employment age to 69 in 2026
A larger balance in the Enhanced Retirement Sum enablre the distribution of a higher amount from CPF Life in retirement. This goes a long way to ensure a safe and basic income stream.
The move to close SAs for those aged 55 and above will take effect in 2025.

site_title: Nigeria’s naira woes point to a bigger problem in Africa
summary: Nigeria's naira has declined by 74% against the US dollar since January 2022, exacerbating inflation and eroding households' savings. Other African countries, including Ghana, Kenya, and South Africa, have also seen significant currency depreciation. To stabilize declining currencies, African policymakers must promote exports and adopt free floats, allowing markets to determine currency price levels. However, export weaknesses, high labor costs, and inefficient regulation limit competitiveness, increasing the risk of stagflation. Policymakers must address these challenges to prevent further economic and political instability.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Narendra Modi has been accused of weakening Indian democracy’s secular and liberal foundations.
Director-General Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala calls the WTO a “source of resilience” in a world shaken by geopolitical turmoil.

site_title: Thai Supreme Court clears ex-PM Yingluck in negligence case, says lawyer
summary: Thailand's Supreme Court has cleared former Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra of negligence in a 2013 case, handing her a favorable outcome in a case that has been pending for years. This decision comes as the dominant Shinawatra family, led by billionaire Thaksin Shinawatra, continues to hold influence in Thai politics, with Yingluck's party Pheu Thai currently in government. The ruling is the latest in a series of favorable outcomes for the Shinawatra family, who have faced various legal challenges in recent years.

images.alt_text: Thaksin was freed from detention last month after the coalition government headed by a party backed by his family granted him a special parole citing his old age and illness.

site_title: One-fifth of Mekong river fish species face extinction: report
summary: One-fifth of Mekong river fish species, totaling 19%, are facing extinction due to unsustainable development, including habitat loss, invasive species, and hydropower dams. The Mekong, a vital source of food for 40 million people, is home to over 1,148 fish species, many of which are critically endangered. Conservation groups warn that if countries in the Mekong delta do not take collective action to develop the river sustainably, the fish population may continue to decline, threatening food security.

images.alt_text: Fish in tanks at the Aquaculture Centre of Excellence at Eco Ark fish farm in Singapore., Dec 6, 2023.
The giant tuna is over three times the amount offered last year in the sale at Tokyo’s Toyosu fish market.

site_title: Chinese insurers warn of debt risks at property giant Vanke
summary: Chinese insurers are warning of debt risks at property giant Vanke, citing concerns over the developer's credit obligations. At least two Beijing-based insurers have advised their external portfolio managers to closely monitor Vanke's credit risks, while a life insurer has also curbed exposure to the company. Vanke's shares and bonds have hit record lows due to repayment concerns, following defaults by industry giants Country Garden Holdings Co. and China Evergrande Group. The company has begun negotiations with state insurers to extend maturities of some private borrowings, but no agreement has been reached.

site_title: China’s top solar panel maker calls on Beijing to control prices
summary: China's top solar panel maker, Longi Green Energy Technology, is urging Beijing to regulate prices and ensure panel quality due to excess capacity and fierce competition. Production cuts and layoffs are affecting the industry, but installations are forecast to remain near record levels. Longi Chairman Zhong Baoshen recommends introducing new bidding rules to discourage low prices and award firms providing long-lasting, reliable products. This comes after Trina Solar Chairman Gao Jifan warned smaller companies would be squeezed out by extremely low prices, potentially leading to lower-quality panels.

site_title: Economic benefits from STB grant to Taylor Swift ‘significant’, outweigh amount distributed: Edwin Tong
summary: Singapore Minister for Culture, Community and Youth Edwin Tong said the economic benefits from the government grant given to Taylor Swift to bring her show to Singapore outweigh the amount distributed. The benefits include additional tourist arrivals, greater spending on entertainment, retail, and dining sectors, and are estimated to be up to S$500 million. Tong emphasized that the grant was necessary due to the scale of the concert's setup and the need for economies of scale to attract top artists.

images.alt_text: Singapore faces "intense regional competition" for concerts and events like Taylor Swift's The Eras Tour and must continue to invest in its infrastructure and software to remain attractive, said Minister for Culture, Community and Youth Edwin Tong in Parliament on Monday (Mar 4).
The production value of Taylor Swift's Eras Tour is top-notch, with LED screens forming a gigantic backdrop as well as bringing the entire stage surface to life.
An exclusivity deal with Taylor Swift means the American popstar is making Singapore her only stop in South-east Asia on her Eras Tour.
Taylor Swift’s six concerts in March could boost Singapore’s economy by up to S$500 million in tourism receipts, according to economists’ estimates.
The idea of Singapore paying Taylor Swift to only perform here does not sit well with some people

site_title: China buys hefty amount of foreign grain as global prices slump
summary: China has purchased over 1.2 million tonnes of foreign grain, including corn, sorghum, and barley, in the past two weeks, taking advantage of the lowest global prices in over three years. The country secured shipments from suppliers such as Ukraine and the US, amid a decline in Chinese prices and a widening gap between domestic and international markets. This move is part of Beijing's efforts to support the market and stockpile grain for state reserves ahead of the new crop planting season.

images.alt_text: grain, corn, sorghum and barley Photographer: Mauricio Palos/Bloomberg

site_title: CapitaLand Development plans 11,000 more homes in Vietnam by 2028
summary: CapitaLand Development plans to increase its residential portfolio in Vietnam to 27,000 units by 2028, a 70% rise from its current 16,000 units. The company aims to develop 11,000 more homes in the country by 2028, with a focus on well-located, large-scale projects in key cities such as Hanoi, Ho Chi Minh City, and Binh Duong. The company has already launched two new projects, Sycamore and Lumi Hanoi, with a combined gross development value of over S$2 billion.

images.alt_text: Upcoming approvals and amendments to policy and legal frameworks will contribute to increased synchronisation and consistency for Vietnam's real estate environment, noted CBRE.

site_title: Thai economy in critical situation, PM's aide says
summary: Thailand's economy is in a "critical situation" due to unexpected contraction in the fourth quarter of 2023 and downgraded growth outlook for this year. Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin's government is pushing for stimulus measures to tackle household debt, boost tourism, and attract foreign investment. The government has proposed policies to make Thailand a regional hub for sectors like electric vehicles and finance, and has expressed interest from companies like Google and Tesla. However, critics caution that some measures may not be fiscally viable and could stoke inflation.

images.alt_text: The stock exchange last month has revealed more details about proposed stricter measures on short selling and programme trading.

site_title: Higher S$7,500 cap for salary support, wider eligibility for Career Conversion Programmes
summary: The Singapore government has announced key updates to the Career Conversion Programme (CCP) scheme in the 2024 budget. From April 1, the salary support cap for mature workers will increase to S$7,500, up from S$6,000, and the cap for long-term unemployed workers will also increase to S$7,500. Additionally, the reskilling support under the CCP will be available for more job roles, including growth job roles identified under Industry Transformation Maps or Jobs Transformation Maps.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
(L-R) Ng Jia Min, Assistant Team Lead SEO, OOm Pte Ltd; Cheow Yu Yuan, CEO, OOm Pte Ltd

site_title: Retaining CPF Special Account for those already aged 55 and up will create generational divide: Tan See Leng
summary: Singapore's Central Provident Fund (CPF) Special Account will be closed for members aged 55 and above in 2025, transferring savings to the Retirement Account (RA) or Ordinary Account (OA). Minister Tan See Leng stated that this move, which benefits the current generation, could create a generational divide, affecting younger Singaporeans. However, more than 99% of CPF members aged 55 and above will still be able to transfer their savings to their RA, earning higher interest rates and retirement payouts. Those unable to transfer savings can choose to grow them outside the CPF system or invest in safe instruments.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
The move to close SAs for those aged 55 and above will take effect in 2025.
‘Fairer’ to retain CPF Special Account for those already aged 55 and above: Foo Mee Har
The move to shift members' savings in the CPF Special Account to the Ordinary Account when they turn 55, and to close the SA has sparked unhappiness.
CPF contribution rates for those aged 55 to 65 will be raised by a further 1.5 percentage points in 2025.

site_title: TSMC surges to record high on AI optimism, global chip rally
summary: TSMC, the world's top chip foundry, surged to a record high of NT$725 (S$30.89) on March 4, 2024, with a 5.2% jump, its highest level since its 1994 stock listing. The surge lifted its market capitalization to US$597 billion, making it one step closer to reclaiming a spot among the world's 10 most-valuable companies. The chip foundry's stock has risen 22% so far this year, driven by optimism over artificial intelligence, with key suppliers like Apple and Nvidia also benefiting from the AI boom.

site_title: HDB resale volumes dip in February, prices continue to climb: SRX, 99.co
summary: HDB resale flat prices rose 0.5% in February, with year-on-year growth of 6.4%, according to SRX and 99.co. Five-room flats saw the largest year-on-year price increase at 7%, while prices for four-room flats rose 6.3%. Resale volumes declined 18.8% from January to 2,134 units, with most transactions coming from non-mature estates. The government's introduction of an ABSD refund for a replacement home may lead to a stabilization of prices for highly sought-after HDBs, potentially above S$1 million.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
The highest transacted price for a resale flat in January 2024 is S$1.57 million for a five-room flat in Toa Payoh.
Both Huttons and OrangeTee & Tie are projecting HDB resale price growth to range between 3 and 5 per cent for 2024.
Industry watchers largely expect demand in the HDB resale market to remain muted for December 2023 due to the holiday season.
Stricter rules for the non-selection of a BTO flat has led buyers to look towards the resale market instead, property analysts observe.

site_title: Island View relaunches en bloc sale with plans to cut price from S$575 million to S$532 million
summary: Island View condominium in Pasir Panjang is relaunching for sale by tender on March 5, with plans to lower the reserve price from S$575 million to S$532 million. Over 60% of owners are in favor of the price cut, following a previous attempt last year that failed to attract bids. The owners are collecting signatures to achieve an 80% mandate to reduce the price, amid softer market sentiment.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Land betterment charge rates for non-landed residential use were raised by 0.1 per cent on average.
Orchard Boulevard GLS
Monies that go into buying and sprucing up houses in GCB Areas can be productively used in many other areas.

site_title: Hydrogen wildcatters still need to find their first gusher
summary: A "clean energy gold rush" is underway in green hydrogen, a promising fuel that could displace 40% of current natural gas consumption. Despite decades of research, prospectors still need to find a "Spindletop" equivalent, a massive gusher of hydrogen to economically justify extraction. Unpublished research suggests vast quantities of hydrogen may be hidden beneath the Earth's surface, but experts warn that finding and extracting it will require new expertise and technology. Companies like HyTerra and Gold Hydrogen are racing to develop this new resource, but must undercut the cost of producing green hydrogen from wind and solar power to succeed.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A bronze seal for the Department of the Treasury is shown at the U.S. Treasury building in Washington, U.S., Jan. 20, 2023.  REUTERS/Kevin Lamarque/File Photo
The hydrogen-ready power plant is expected to be commissioned by end-2027.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise on US gains ahead of key China policy meeting
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday ahead of a key Chinese policy meeting, driven by US gains and optimism over AI. Japan's Nikkei 225 index surpassed 40,000 for the first time, while Tokyo and Frankfurt hit records. Analysts expect China to set an annual growth target of around 5% and announce policies that will shape investor sentiment and asset allocation decisions. Despite concerns over the nation's struggling economy and youth unemployment, Chinese leaders are likely to pursue measured interventions to support growth while maintaining quality-driven development.

images.alt_text: Singapore shares rally at Monday’s open; STI up 0.3%

site_title: CFA Society to put together code on diversity, inclusion and equity for Singapore investment firms
summary: The CFA Society in Singapore is developing a code on diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) for investment management firms, following the success of similar initiatives in North America and the UK. The code aims to promote a diverse and inclusive workforce, fair treatment, and better business outcomes. The Singapore initiative, led by a working group of 18 volunteers, is expected to launch in the second half of 2024 and will be regionally adapted to suit the local context. The goal is to attract and retain top talent, improve employee experience, and drive business success.

images.alt_text: CFA Institute -- This photo is licensed to the CFA Institute for its publication and marketing purposes. Third party use without consent of the photographer is prohibited.
Genevieve Cua

site_title: Oil nudges higher after Opec+ extends output cuts
summary: Oil prices rose 0.2% on Monday after Opec+ members agreed to extend voluntary output cuts to the end of the second quarter, with Brent futures up 14 cents to $83.69 a barrel and WTI up 2 cents to $79.99 a barrel. Russia also pledged to cut production and exports. The move is seen as a sign of supply tightening ahead, with traders expecting higher prices due to rising tensions in the Middle East and global economic concerns.

images.alt_text: The administration has been slowly trying to refill it – purchasing some 23 million barrels since last year.

Oil prices have found support from rising geopolitical tensions due to attacks by the Iran-aligned Houthi group on Red Sea shipping, although concern about economic growth and high interest rates has weighed.
The oil rig count, an early indication of future output, rises by three to 506 this week, the highest since September.

site_title: Swiss National Bank loses US$3.6 billion in 2023
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) reported an annual loss of US$3.62 billion for 2023, mainly due to paying out interest on overnight sight deposits. The central bank switched to positive interest rates in 2022 to combat inflation, resulting in a 8.5 billion franc loss. However, the SNB made a profit of 4 billion francs from foreign currency positions and a valuation gain of 1.7 billion francs on its gold holdings, improving from a record loss in 2022. The result confirmed the SNB's provisional forecast in January.

site_title: Fractures in global trade deepen as WTO musters only a small win
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) failed to achieve significant progress at its 13th ministerial conference in Abu Dhabi, where talks were marred by disorder and confusion. The only agreed-upon measure was extending a moratorium on tariffs on digital commerce, which was narrowly achieved after opposition from India, South Africa, and Indonesia. The meeting highlighted the deepening fractures in global trade, with the power balance shifting to Asia, and the rise of protectionism and inward focus ahead of elections in over 60 nations. WTO Director-General Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala acknowledged that progress was not achieved, but expressed relief at averting a collapse.

images.alt_text: Director-general Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, who calls the WTO a “source of resilience” in a world shaken by geopolitical turmoil, says: “We didn’t achieve all we wanted to, but what we did achieve I think was pretty amazing.”

site_title: China’s BYD prices new version of best-selling EV lower than predecessor
summary: China's BYD has launched a new version of its best-selling Yuan Plus crossover, the Atto 3, at a lower price than its predecessor. The new Atto 3 starts at 119,800 yuan (S$22,800), 11.8% lower than the final sales price of the previous model. This move comes as a price war rages in China's largest automobile market, with BYD and rivals such as Geely Auto and Tesla introducing incentives to attract customers. The Atto 3 is sold with a starting price of A$48,011 (S$31,336) in Australia, 85% higher than in China.

images.alt_text: The BYD logo is displayed on a car during the media day of the 91st Geneva Auto Show, in Geneva, Switzerland, February 26, 2024. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse

site_title: Ringgit gains as Malaysia steps up coordination to lift currency
summary: The Malaysian ringgit rose to a one-month high after policymakers increased coordination with state-linked firms to lift the currency, which has been the best performer in Asia in the past week. The currency advanced 0.6% to 4.7185 per US dollar, its strongest level since Feb 2. The move aims to drive more inflows into the market and boost sentiment towards the ringgit. Malaysian authorities are prepared to sell US dollars from its reserves to curb excessive moves in the ringgit, citing the nation's improving economic outlook.

site_title: Moody’s raises India’s 2024 GDP forecast sharply
summary: Moody's has sharply raised its GDP forecast for India to 6.8% for 2024, citing strong momentum in the South Asian economy, particularly in manufacturing and construction activity. The country's economy grew at its fastest pace in one-and-a-half years in the final three months of 2023, with a 8.4% growth rate. Moody's expects policy continuity and a focus on infrastructure development, but notes that headline inflation remains above the central bank's target. The ratings agency also expects private investment to improve, despite slow industrial capital spending.

images.alt_text: Employees make iron parts which are used to construct bridges inside a manufacturing unit in an industrial area on the outskirts of Kolkata, India, February 12, 2016. India's industrial output contracted an annual 1.3 percent in December, government data showed on Friday. REUTERS/Rupak De Chowdhuri/File photo
India, which is seeking to rival countries such as Taiwan in chipmaking, expects its semiconductor market to be worth US$63 billion by 2026.

site_title: ECB to hold rates again, awaiting clearer signs on inflation
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to hold its benchmark deposit rate steady at a record 4% for a fourth consecutive meeting on March 7, awaiting clearer signs of sustained inflation reduction. Despite slowing inflation, officials remain cautious, citing a bumpy inflation path and concerns about wage growth. Economists predict a slow-moving rate cut cycle, with a possible first reduction in June. The ECB's updated forecasts are also expected to show a slight downward revision for this year's GDP growth and inflation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A sign outside the European Central Bank building in Frankfurt, Germany October 27, 2022. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo
Lending growth has been hovering around zero since the autumn but is expected to slowly recover in the coming months as the ECB likely begins cutting interest rates.

site_title: Hong Kong law firms cut office space in new blow to business hub
summary: Hong Kong's top law firms are cutting office space in prime locations amid the city's economic slowdown, with Deacons reducing one floor in Alexandra House and DLA Piper shaving 465 square meters from its office in Exchange Square. The move highlights the malaise of Hong Kong's economic downturn, marked by a 14% decline in its benchmark Hang Seng Index last year, and a dearth of mergers and acquisitions. The economic slowdown, fueled by rising tensions with China and a property market crisis, is also affecting the city's commercial lawyers, who are battling competition from rival financial hub Singapore.

images.alt_text: Non-residents do not have to pay a combined 15 per cent tax when purchasing properties while owners can sell their homes anytime without paying special duty.

site_title: Japan corporate capex jumps, paving way for BOJ exit from stimulus
summary: Japan's corporate spending on plant and equipment surged 16.4% in the fourth quarter, suggesting positive revisions to GDP data that previously showed a recession. The data could bolster the case for the Bank of Japan to end negative interest rates, which may happen in April. Wage negotiations this year could deliver hefty pay hikes, a prerequisite for ending negative rates. Revised GDP data, due on March 11, may show an expansion in the fourth quarter, potentially avoiding a recession at the end of last year.

images.alt_text: Both production and new orders, the two main subindexes of Japan's PMI, declined at the fastest pace in a year. Respondents cited factors such as weak sales demand at home and overseas as well as production delays due to machinery shutdowns.
Japan’s chronic labour crisis is worsening as the ageing and shrinking of the population accelerates.

Under its massive stimulus programme, the Bank of Japan currently guides short-term interest rates at minus 0.1 per cent, caps the 10-year government bond yield around 0 per cent and continues to buy huge amounts of assets such as government bonds.
Manufacturers surveyed by Japan's Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry expect seasonally adjusted output to increase 4.8 per cent in February and rise 2.0 per cent in March.

site_title: Thailand mulls directly charging short sellers as shares slump
summary: Thailand is considering extending its crackdown on short selling, with plans to directly charge individuals and companies involved in the practice. The move comes after the country's benchmark SET Index has dropped over 3% this year, with shares falling 15% in 2023. Market authorities aim to boost investor trust and confidence, with proposed measures including increased fines and a reduction in allowed market value for short selling. Thailand joins peers like China and South Korea in tightening curbs on short selling, which has wiped out $156 billion in market value.

images.alt_text: Passengers and tourists on social media have complained about airport’s long immigration and check-in lines.

Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput, governor of the Bank of Thailand, speaks at the HKMA-BIS High-Level Conference in Hong Kong, China, on Tuesday, Nov. 28, 2023. The conference runs through Nov. 29. Photographer: Anthony Kwan/Bloomberg
In January, the economy improves from the previous month due to rising exports, but is still growing slowly, the Bank of Thailand says.
Thailand is a regional auto assembly and export hub, home to Japanese manufacturers such as Toyota and Honda.

site_title: Elite Commercial Reit secures £135 million debt facilities
summary: Elite Commercial Reit has secured £135 million debt facilities from a group of financial institutions. The new credit facilities will be used to refinance existing loan facilities and help manage working capital. The funds will also be used to reinforce the Reit's capital structure and maximize unitholder returns through asset repositioning strategies, including divestments and asset repurposing. This follows a £28 million preferential offering in January, which lowered the Reit's net gearing to 40.9%.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
The drop in DPU is mainly due to a marginally enlarged unit base and lower distribution payout ratio of 90 per cent versus 100 per cent in the same period last year amid macroeconomic uncertainty.
Revenue and net property income are higher year on year.

FCT raised S$200 million of gross proceeds through private placements, the majority of which will be used to repay existing debts, pending the use of such amount to partially fund the proposed acquisition of additional interest in Nex.

site_title: Malaysia may renew search for MH370 decade after plane vanished
summary: Malaysia is considering renewing the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, 10 years after the plane vanished. A marine exploration company, Ocean Infinity, has proposed a fresh search with a "no-cure, no-fee" agreement. Transport Minister Anthony Loke has asked Ocean Infinity for a briefing, and Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said he would reopen the search if "compelling" evidence emerges. The Boeing 777 disappeared on March 8, 2014, with 239 people on board, and investigators concluded it deliberately deviated from its planned route.

images.alt_text: People are seen outside the court that began hearing compensation cases filed by the relatives of passengers of the missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370, in Beijing on Nov 27, 2023.
Who's afraid of flying? (Or why aircraft engines explode)
Malaysia Airlines parent firm gets green light for restructuring
Fate of troubled Malaysia Airlines hangs by a thread
Malaysia Airlines 'ready to shut down if restructuring talks fail'

site_title: Julius Baer names new group head of South-east Asia
summary: Julius Baer has appointed Malcolm Tay as group head of South-east Asia, a newly created role based in Singapore. Tay joins from Credit Suisse, where he was deputy market group head and market leader for Indonesia. The appointment aims to consolidate leadership and foster growth in the region. Tay previously held leadership roles at Deutsche Bank Wealth Management, Merrill Lynch, and Citi Private Bank. His appointment reinforces Julius Baer's dedication to Asia as a key market, according to Yee Chin Lit, market head for South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Gold near two-month high as hopes for mid-year US rate cut rise
summary: Gold prices hovered near a two-month high on Monday after the US Federal Reserve raised hopes for a June interest rate cut, leading to a weaker US dollar and lower bond yields. Spot gold edged 0.2% lower to $2,080.09 per ounce, while benchmark US 10-year Treasury yields and the US dollar index retreated. The US manufacturing data showed a further slump in February, and construction spending fell in January, increasing the appeal for safe-haven assets like gold.

images.alt_text: Lower interest rates boost the appeal of non-yielding bullion.

site_title: Early family legacy planning, consistent review can help mitigate risks: panel
summary: A panel discussion at CIMB's insurance expo emphasized the importance of early family legacy planning and consistent review to mitigate risks. The panelists, including experts in financial planning, highlighted the need for a diversified portfolio, a "flexible portfolio" that can adjust according to changing risk profiles, and a focus on returns from the entire portfolio, not individual asset classes. They also stressed the importance of reviewing legacy plans regularly, using them as a template, and incorporating disability or mental capacity insurance to mitigate significant risks.

site_title: Singapore shares rally at Monday’s open; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% to 3,145.39 points at 9:01 am on Monday, March 4, 2024, following global equities' record gains last week. The broader market saw gainers outnumber losers 84 to 31, with top-traded counters including CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust and Golden Agri-Resources. Local banks traded mixed, with UOB and OCBC gaining, while DBS shed 0.2%. The rally comes after Wall Street stocks closed at fresh records on Friday, driven by technology stocks and declining Treasury yields.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Olam expects its subsidiary's acquisition of feed supplier Avisen to be earnings accretive from 2024.

site_title: Weiss multi-strategy hedge fund to shut after 46 years
summary: Weiss Multi-Strategy Advisers, a New York-based investment management firm founded in 1978, is shutting down after 46 years. The firm's founder and CEO, George Weiss, announced the decision due to various factors. Weiss managed $3.1 billion in assets as of mid-2023, with a 6% gain in 2023. The decline in investor appetite for hedge funds, particularly multi-strategy funds, is attributed to a Goldman Sachs report showing a 16% decline in interest this year. The firm has "diligently wound down" client portfolios, with 119 employees remaining.

images.alt_text: Nvidia will release its quarterly earnings results on Feb 21.

site_title: Hong Kong sees surge in home sales on weekend after curbs lift
summary: Hong Kong's property market saw a surge in home sales over the weekend after the government lifted decade-long curbs, with 27 transactions recorded by Midland Realty, 3.5 times higher than the previous week. The new home market also showed robust sales, with Henderson Land Development's Belgravia Place project selling all 138 units in four hours. However, analysts expect the medium-term outlook to remain challenging due to high interest rates and ample inventory, with interest rate cuts needed to boost investment demand.

images.alt_text: Growing demand may bolster the government’s case for a new cross-border railway linking northwestern Hong Kong to Shenzhen’s Qianhai economic zone.
The American diplomat’s criticism comes as Hong Kong tries to bolster its position as an international business centre and attract tourists to boost its flagging economy.
Hong Kong’s economy is expected to grow 2.5 to 3.5 per cent this year after expanding 3.2 per cent in 2023.
The crypto industry will sift through the applicants to gauge the allure of Hong Kong as a digital-asset centre amid competition from other jurisdictions.

site_title: Turkey’s inflation is spiralling closer to 70% with rates at peak
summary: Turkey's inflation is expected to reach 36% at the end of 2024, with a possible peak above 70% in May. The country's annual inflation rate has accelerated to a 15-month high, driven by a steep minimum wage hike and higher food prices. The central bank has adopted a wait-and-see approach, despite a stable lira, as policymakers focus on monthly inflation data due to be released on March 4. The latest data is expected to show price increases accelerated for a fourth straight month, with food prices rising 8.5% in February.

images.alt_text: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan on Monday (Dec 25) inaugurated the Sabiha Gokcen airport’s second runway, which costs about US$970 million.

site_title: A boring Dragon Year for the housing market could be ideal for locals looking to rightsize
summary: The housing market in Singapore is expected to remain stable in the Dragon Year, with private home and HDB resale flat prices potentially increasing by low single digits. Experts attribute this to low mortgage rates, which may help support the market. However, caution is advised as the economic outlook weakens. The stable market may be beneficial for locals looking to downsize, as it could lead to a more affordable housing market.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee

The panel at BT's Property Outlook 2024 (left to right): BT senior property correspondent Leslie Yee; PropNex Realty's CEO Ismail Gafoor; Alan Cheong, executive director for research and consultancy at Savills Singapore; and Justin Quek, CEO at OrangeTee & Tie.

site_title: Elon Musk is right about OpenAI’s hypocrisy
summary: Elon Musk has sued OpenAI, alleging the company broke its founding agreement to build powerful AI systems "for the benefit of humanity." Musk claims OpenAI, led by CEO Sam Altman, has become a closed-source subsidiary of Microsoft, contradicting its humanitarian mission. This case highlights a broader phenomenon among leading AI companies, where startups promise to harness AI's transformative potential for the public good but ultimately fall under the sway of tech giants, prioritizing profits over ideals. Musk's lawsuit aims to force AI companies to be honest about their intentions as they evolve.

images.alt_text: Mistral has positioned itself as a plucky European champion challenging US dominance in the field.
Musk is bringing the suit in the capacity of a donor to OpenAI’s non-profit parent organisation as recently as 2019 and is seeking to force OpenAI to stop benefiting Microsoft and Altman personally.

site_title: Condo rental market shifts: Landlords hit by high supply of newly completed units
summary: The condo rental market in Singapore has shifted, with landlords facing prolonged vacancies due to a high supply of newly completed units. This has led to a softening of the market, characterized by high demand and good returns in the past. Real estate agents attribute the decline to the increased supply of units, which has put downward pressure on prices and rental yields. As a result, landlords are struggling to find tenants, with some units remaining vacant for an extended period.

images.alt_text: Land betterment charge rates for non-landed residential use were raised by 0.1 per cent on average.

The panel at BT's Property Outlook 2024 (left to right): BT senior property correspondent Leslie Yee; PropNex Realty's CEO Ismail Gafoor; Alan Cheong, executive director for research and consultancy at Savills Singapore; and Justin Quek, CEO at OrangeTee & Tie.
Condominiums along Alexandra Road at night on Feb 26, 2022.

site_title: New Zealand central bank to implement cyber reporting rules through 2024
summary: New Zealand's central bank, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ), plans to implement cyber reporting rules for banks through 2024. Under the proposed rules, banks must inform RBNZ of all cyber incidents within 72 hours. Large entities must report all cyber incidents every six months, while smaller entities must report annually. The rules also require self-assessment measures to be reported. The move aims to improve cyber resilience and provide the RBNZ with accurate, timely information to understand the nature of risks facing banks and their ability to respond to incidents.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand building in Wellington. Photographer: Mark Coote/Bloomberg

site_title: South Korea’s January factory output unexpectedly falls month-on-month
summary: South Korea's factory output unexpectedly fell 1.3% in January on a seasonally-adjusted basis, after a revised 0.5% decline in December. This marks the second consecutive monthly decline. However, on an annual basis, output rose 12.9%, exceeding economists' median forecast of a 9.3% gain, which was the fastest since May 2021.

site_title: Nvidia becomes Tesla’s successor as market flips from EV to AI
summary: Nvidia has surpassed Tesla as the market's top performer, driven by its phenomenal sales growth in AI applications. The company's shares have risen 66% this year, fueled by insatiable demand for its chips used to train large language models. In contrast, Tesla's shares have plummeted 50% from their 2021 peak, following a slowdown in electric vehicle sales. Analysts warn of an AI bubble, citing parallels with the dot-com era, where investors paid for unproven growth. Despite massive profits, Nvidia's valuation is high, with a price-to-sales ratio of 18, and its competitors are eager to challenge its dominance in the AI market.

images.alt_text: Nvidia is the world’s leading maker of artificial intelligence (AI) chips used to create systems like OpenAI’s ChatGPT.

The HBM3E (High Bandwidth Memory 3E) will consume 30 per cent less power than rival offerings, and could help tap into soaring demand for chips that power generative AI applications, according to Micron.
A photo of Nvidia's graphic processing unit. Analysts said Nvidia’s latest earnings report demonstrates the current strength of AI infrastructure spending.

site_title: Country Garden faces heat from liquidation suit to get cracking on debt revamp talks
summary: Country Garden, a Chinese property developer, faces pressure from a liquidation suit filed by a creditor, Ever Credit Limited, over a $205 million loan. The court hearing is set for May 17, which may prompt the company to initiate debt restructuring talks. This comes after a regulatory crackdown in 2021 triggered a liquidity squeeze in China's property sector, which has been experiencing multiple crises since then. The development may also raise urgency for Country Garden to address its financial issues, following the liquidation order against peer China Evergrande in January.

images.alt_text: In a sign that Country Garden’s creditors are ready for further negotiations, an ad-hoc creditor group hired financial and legal advisers in recent months.

The headquarters of Country Garden Holdings in Foshan, Guangdong province. The embattled developer's debt-restructuring process, which gathered momentum in recent weeks, is set to be clouded by the liquidation petition.
Property agent Knight Frank says it has been appointed by Risland UK – a susbidiary of Country Garden – to market the 1,000-home Calico Wharf development site.

site_title: The submergence of emerging markets
summary: Emerging markets are experiencing a slowdown, with China's forced growth prioritizing the Communist Party over economics and India's secular and liberal foundations being eroded under Prime Minister Narendra Modi. Middle-income economies are slowing before becoming high-income economies, primarily due to bad domestic policies. Independent central banks have helped fight inflation, but the larger emerging markets can expect mediocre growth and stagnant real wages. The world's increasing equality is now at risk if emerging markets enter a sustained slowdown, which seems likely, as rapid growth in China, India, and other emerging economies may be coming to an end.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The World Bank logo is seen at the 2023 Spring Meetings of the World Bank Group and the International Monetary Fund in Washington, U.S., April 13, 2023. REUTERS/Elizabeth Frantz

site_title: Minority-investor action at Great Eastern, OCBC may spur expectations of value-unlocking initiatives
summary: Minority investors of Great Eastern, a Singaporean insurer, have proposed three resolutions to challenge the company's undervalued shares, which trade at a 51% discount to its embedded value. The resolutions aim to incentivize the board to boost the market value of its shares, reward executives with its own shares instead of OCBC shares, and appoint an independent financial adviser to explore options to enhance shareholder value. The move may challenge OCBC's narrative that owning Great Eastern is crucial to its strategy, potentially leading to a value-unlocking initiative.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
Why Great Eastern’s undervalued shares still hold great potential.

Initiatives to boost the vibrancy of the Singapore market mooted during the recent Mark to Market 'Live' event could become a difficult and disagreeable business if they run up against the vested interests of a company's board and controlling shareholder
Great Eastern's minority shareholders resisted privatisation proposals from OCBC nearly two decades ago
Sias lamented in a March commentary the "ridiculous lowball" offers that foment investor resentment and mistrust in the local market
Great Eastern proposed a final dividend of S$0.40 per share.
A group of close to 80 shareholders have raised concerns over GEH’s depressed share price and continued valuation decline over the last decade, despite its “strong financial position”.

site_title: Young Hongkongers who defied Xi are now partying in China
summary: Hong Kong residents, who once opposed Chinese President Xi Jinping's efforts to integrate the city with mainland China, are now embracing the mainland lifestyle. With travel times cut in half and prices significantly lower, many are flocking to Shenzhen for cheap food, massages, and entertainment. This shift is seen as a boon for Xi's efforts to integrate Hong Kong into the Greater Bay Area, a region that aims to challenge Silicon Valley's innovation and economic output. However, experts warn that this integration could also lead to Hong Kong losing its unique identity and becoming another mainland Chinese city.

images.alt_text: Travelers from Hong Kong at the Shenzhen Bay border crossing in Shenzhen, China, on Saturday, Jan. 20, 2024. Hong Kong's efforts to revive its ailing retail and hospitality sectors are facing mounting headwinds, with some of the city’s top nightlife spots left deserted as residents flock across the border to mainland China for cheaper shopping and entertainment options. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
The American diplomat’s criticism comes as Hong Kong tries to bolster its position as an international business centre and attract tourists to boost its flagging economy.
Hong Kong’s economy is expected to grow 2.5 to 3.5 per cent this year after expanding 3.2 per cent in 2023.
The crypto industry will sift through the applicants to gauge the allure of Hong Kong as a digital-asset centre amid competition from other jurisdictions.
JPMorgan provides both global and local custodian services for clients in Hong Kong and Taiwan.

site_title: Investors raise Macy’s buyout bid: WSJ
summary: Investors Arkhouse Management and Brigade Capital Management have increased their offer to acquire Macy's stock for US$24 per share, valuing the deal at US$6.6 billion. This is nearly US$1 billion higher than their initial proposal of US$21 per share, which was rejected by Macy's due to concerns over financing and valuation. The new offer comes after Macy's rebuffed their prior proposal, and the two firms did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

site_title: Japan’s Nikkei 225 breaches key 40,000 level for the first time
summary: Japan's Nikkei 225 index reached a milestone, breaching the 40,000 level for the first time, closing at 40,109.23. The benchmark index added 0.5% to its previous close, driven by tech shares and domestic investors. Despite concerns of overheating, many foreign investors remain bullish on Japanese stocks, citing strong earnings growth and valuation expansion. Analysts attribute the rally to the weaker yen, booming corporate profits, and improved shareholder returns. The Nikkei reclaimed its 1989 peak last month, with some predicting further gains in the coming months.

images.alt_text: A woman walks past an electronic board displaying a share price of the Nikkei index of the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Tokyo on March 4, 2024. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)
A visitor walks past Japan's Nikkei stock prices quotation board inside a building in Tokyo, Japan February 19, 2024. REUTERS/Issei Kato

Pedestrians walk past a signboard showing the closing numbers on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, along a street in Tokyo in January 11, 2024. Tokyo's Nikkei index closed above 35,000 for the first time in nearly 34 years on January 11, buoyed by US Tech rallies and hopes for an end to decades of sluggish inflation. (Photo by Richard A. BROOKS / AFP)

site_title: Indonesia’s fisheries sector seeks greater use of AI  to close technology gap
summary: Indonesia aims to modernize its fisheries industry to meet growing demand for farmed seafood, with a goal to export $7.2 billion worth of fishery products by 2024, a four-fold increase from 2020. The government plans to restore 300,000 hectares of idle shrimp-farming ponds and increase fishery product production to 30.8 million tonnes this year. The sector is seeking to close the technology gap through the use of AI, with startups like eFishery developing digital solutions to help fishermen participate in the digital economy.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
Liris Maduningtyas, co-founder and chief executive officer of JALA.

site_title: Olam Agri acquires feed producer in Senegal for 17 million euros
summary: Olam Agri, a subsidiary of the Olam Group, has acquired Avisen, a major feed supplier in Senegal, for 17 million euros. The acquisition, funded by existing cash and debt facilities, is expected to be earnings accretive from 2024. The deal bolsters Olam Agri's presence in West Africa, where it produces animal feed and day-old chicks. The acquisition combines Olam Agri's global commodity sourcing networks with Avisen's local market knowledge, aiming to improve feed quality and cost efficiency in the Senegalese market.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Olam's earnings per share stands at S$0.0567 for the half year, up from S$0.0478 the previous year.
Olam Group says all its businesses in Nigeria “continue to operate normally”.
Olam Group says its board has directed the audit committee to “nevertheless conduct a review of the matter”.
Olam Group's food ingredient unit, ofi, has secured a sustainability-linked facility worth US$1.75 billion to refinance its existing loans.

site_title: Bitcoin bursts above US$65,000, record high comes into view
summary: Bitcoin surged to a two-year high of over US$65,000 on March 4, breaking above record levels reached in November 2021. The largest cryptocurrency by market value has gained 50% this year, largely due to the launch of spot Bitcoin exchange-traded funds in the US, which has attracted new large investors. Net flows into the top 10 US spot Bitcoin funds reached US$2.17 billion, with BlackRock's iShares Bitcoin Trust receiving over half of that. The rally has also seen smaller rival Ether surge 50% in the year, with some analysts predicting a 2021-style market where everything goes up.

images.alt_text: The price of Bitcoin has historically increased after a halving event, with so-called miner production cost functioning as a lower bound to the price of the asset.
Bitcoin has jumped over 40 per cent already this year atop the successful debut of the ETF products, which directly hold the token.
