site_title: Hong Kong Jan retail sales rise 0.9% as tourism perks up
summary: Hong Kong's retail sales rose 0.9% year-over-year to HK$36.5 billion in January, driven by improved tourism. The city's economy is expected to grow 2.5-3.5% this year, following a 3.2% expansion in 2023. The government plans to roll out support measures, including over HK$1 billion for the tourism industry, with over 80 "mega events" staged in the first half. Visitor arrivals increased to 3.83 million in January, with mainland Chinese visitors rising to 2.98 million.

images.alt_text: Financial Secretary Paul Chan says the government will consolidate its public finances and “narrow our fiscal deficit progressively toward achieving the goal of restoring fiscal balance.”
The move will bring in about HK$910 million of additional revenue each year.
Speakers at the inaugural Climate Business Forum: Asia-Pacific say there is ample room for the region's advancement in green finance.
High mortgage rates will continue to limit investment demand, but a cut in buyer stamp duties may attract some cash-rich mainlanders to buy luxury homes.

site_title: Japan's Nikkei closes at record high as tech heavyweights surge
summary: Japan's Nikkei stock index closed at a record high of 39,910.82, surpassing a previous intraday peak of 39,426.29, as tech-heavyweights surged following comments from Federal Reserve officials suggesting an interest rate cut in June. The Nikkei rose 2% for the week, with chip-related shares, including Tokyo Electron and Advantest, contributing to the index's 17% year-to-date gain. The broader Topix index also finished 1.26% higher.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians walk past a signboard showing the closing numbers on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, along a street in Tokyo in January 11, 2024. Tokyo's Nikkei index closed above 35,000 for the first time in nearly 34 years on January 11, buoyed by US Tech rallies and hopes for an end to decades of sluggish inflation. (Photo by Richard A. BROOKS / AFP)

site_title: Local shares end week in the red as investor optimism fizzles out; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks ended the week lower, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 0.2% to 3,135.76, as investors became cautious amid US interest-rate cut risks. The US personal consumption expenditures price index rose 0.3% in January, and Chinese manufacturing activity fell for the fifth consecutive month. Despite this, the broader market saw a slight gain, with some regional markets, such as the Nikkei 225 and Hang Seng Index, rising.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
The Europeans have remodeled their fiscal rules - the Stability and Growth Pact - to increase flexibility in the effort to maintain fiscal discipline in the long run.
The Nasdaq surged 0.9 per cent to 16,091.92 on Thursday, surpassing a 2021 high.

site_title: Jeremy Hunt turns to retail investors to save UK market
summary: British Chancellor Jeremy Hunt is considering creating a British Individual Savings Account (ISA) to encourage UK retail investors to boost the country's underperforming stock market. The proposed tax-free savings account would allow investors to put up to £20,000 into UK equities. Additionally, the government plans to sell a stake in the bailed-out NatWest Group and will directly pitch to consumers. Hunt aims to revive the market, which has faced underperformance, outflows, and a decline in companies.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak (left) and Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt at a cabinet meeting in February. The UK is now in recession after two straight quarters of negative growth.

site_title: Singapore to tackle resilience, security risks with new law for digital infrastructure service providers
summary: Singapore plans to introduce a Digital Infrastructure Act to govern key digital infrastructure service providers and address resilience and security risks. The law aims to set higher security and resilience standards for large cloud service providers and data centers to reduce the likelihood of systemic disruptions. The existing Cybersecurity Act will be expanded to include data centers, cloud services, and key entities that hold sensitive data or perform public functions. The government is studying other countries' measures to address risks, including physical hazards such as fires and cooling system failures.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

The warnings come as one of Equinix’s data centres in Singapore saw some of its data halls overheat due to a technical issue with its chilled water system during a planned control system upgrade on Oct 14.
Market watchers said that it may not have been wise for Equinix to embark on such system upgrades in the day when digital services are likely to be depended on.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Friday, March 1, 2024 (Ep 13)
summary: The Nikkei index reached an all-time high due to lower US inflation, boosting global markets. Frasers Centrepoint Trust will replace Emperador on the Straits Times Index on March 18. In other news, Japan's Nikkei closed at a record high, driven by tech heavyweights, and Singapore shares opened flat on Friday, remaining unchanged.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 78 to 57 after 77.7 million securities worth S$98.6 million change hands.
A visitor walks past Japan's Nikkei stock prices quotation board inside a building in Tokyo, Japan February 19, 2024. REUTERS/Issei Kato
CapitaLand Ascott Trust, ComfortDelGro, Keppel DC Reit, Keppel Reit and Suntec Reit are in the STI reserve list.

site_title: Aztech CFO resigns after five months in role; company searching for replacement
summary: Aztech Global announced that its CFO, Leslie Tan, has resigned, effective March 28, due to personal reasons. The company is searching for a replacement and has temporarily assigned CEO Michael Mun to manage the accounting and finance functions. This move aims to maintain continuity and minimize disruption to the company's operations.

images.alt_text: Zhao Yifan
Michael Mun, executive chairman (right) and CEO, as well as Jeremy Mun, executive director and COO for Aztech Global.

site_title: Facebook owner Meta angers Australia with plan to stop paying for news content
summary: Meta, the owner of Facebook, plans to stop paying Australian news publishers for content that appears on its platform, sparking a fresh battle with the Australian government. The decision follows a 2021 law that forces internet giants to strike licensing deals with news publishers. Meta will discontinue its news tab and cancel commercial deals for traditional news content in Australia, potentially affecting 22 million users. The government has vowed to explore options to enforce the law, calling Meta's decision a "dereliction of its commitment to the sustainability of Australian news media."

images.alt_text: Meta has said subscription for no ads addresses the latest regulatory developments, guidance and judgments shared by European regulators and the courts in recent years.
Meta's CEO Mark Zuckerberg (centre), arrives at the LG Electronics headquarters.
The rapid growth of generative AI has triggered fears that the new technology could be used to disrupt major elections across the world this year.

site_title: IHH Healthcare guides for higher FY2024 capex as it pushes bed growth in key markets
summary: IHH Healthcare plans to expand its capacity by 33% by 2028, with around 4,000 new beds across several markets, including Malaysia and India. The healthcare group will spend RM2.7 billion to RM2.8 billion in FY2024 on capital expenditures, which is higher than usual, but funded by free cash. The expansions are expected to have a gradual impact on profit margins. IHH also revised its dividend policy to at least 30% of profit after tax and minority interests, and announced a second and final cash dividend of 5.5 sen per share for FY2023.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
The dividend policy is revised upwards to no less than 30 per cent of the group’s profit after tax and minority interests, excluding exceptional items, from a ‘no less than 20 per cent’ policy.
The group does not expect the claim to have any material operational or financial impact on the group.
The group attributes the weaker performance to the discontinuation of Covid-19-related activities in FY2023.

site_title: PropertyGuru reports S$1.1 million net profit in Q4 amid higher Singapore revenue
summary: PropertyGuru reported a net profit of S$1.1 million for the fourth quarter, reversing from a net loss of S$5.2 million a year prior. Revenue rose 3.5% to S$41.5 million, driven by growth in its Singapore marketplaces. Adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation (Ebitda) surged to S$8.9 million, with marketplaces revenue increasing 4.1% year on year. The company plans to focus on expanding internal operating leverage and improving profitability in 2024, with a full-year revenue outlook of S$165-180 million and adjusted Ebitda outlook of S$22-26 million.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
Hiring now will be more intentional and unlike 2021, where companies were on a mission to grab talent, says Elena Chow, founder of employment consultancy ConnectOne.
PropertyGuru has announced it will cut 79 roles in a review to 'future-proof the business'.
It is time to cut 15-month waiting period for ‘downgraders’, tweak ABSD, bring back estate tax, says PropertyGuru.
Analysts expect stamp duty collection and property tax takings to increase for Singapore's full financial year ended March 2024.

site_title: New grant for large businesses to defray costs of sustainability reporting
summary: Singapore has introduced a Sustainability Reporting Grant to support large businesses with annual revenues of S$100 million and above in developing their first sustainability reports. The grant will cover up to 30% of qualifying costs, capped at S$150,000 per company, to defray the costs associated with preparing a sustainability report. This move aims to enhance transparency and encourage businesses to adopt sustainable practices.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Skyline of Singapore's Business District taken from Marina Bay Sands on Oct 17, 2023. For stories on sustainability, garden city, air quality and more.

Singapore’s lack of preparedness to provide green skills training and development for employees has potentially negative implications for companies amid an increasingly competitive environment for such talent.

Generics view of the CBD with an incoming rain cloud as seen from Marina Bay Sands

site_title: Singapore Pools raises S$500,000 for Community Chest through digital fundraiser
summary: Singapore Pools has successfully raised S$500,000 for Community Chest through its digital fundraiser, "Community with a Heart (CWAH)". The donation was presented at a ceremony on February 28, supporting over 100 social service agencies in Singapore. This initiative demonstrates the philanthropic efforts of Singapore Pools and Tote Board, with the aim of enhancing community engagement and social services.

images.alt_text: Students from Metta School perform at Singapore Pools' 55th anniversary celebration, held at Gardens by the Bay with more than 350 people in attendance.
Josephine Teo (in grey jacket), Minister for Communications and Information with beneficiaries at the Singapore Pools Community Day 2023.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to file liquidation suit against Chinese developer Shimao
summary: Deutsche Bank is preparing to file a liquidation lawsuit in Hong Kong against Chinese developer Shimao Group, citing the developer's unacceptable debt restructuring terms. Shimao, which defaulted on a US$1 billion offshore bond in 2022, has US$11.7 billion in offshore debt deemed in default. The move is rare for a foreign firm, coming amid China's deepening property sector crisis and rising credit defaults. Deutsche Bank's credit exposure to Shimao is linked to private US dollar bonds, and the filing may pile pressure on Shimao to come up with restructuring proposals acceptable to creditors.

images.alt_text: The high number of projects already approved for possible support highlights the Chinese government’s efforts to free up funding for the debt-riddled industry, although it is unclear how many will secure loans.
An office block in London's Canary Wharf financial district is selling for 60 per cent less than it sold for in 2017 after it was seized by lenders from a Chinese investor.

site_title: Intel sees AI opportunity for standalone programmable chip unit
summary: Intel's standalone programmable chip unit, Altera, is poised for growth in the AI market, according to CEO Sandra Rivera. The company plans a stock offering for Altera over the next two to three years, leveraging its programmable chips for AI applications and tasks between custom processors and general AI chips. Market estimates for programmable chips are around $8-10 billion for 2023, but Rivera believes the opportunity is larger, driven by the use of multiple programmable chips at various stages of the AI workflow.

images.alt_text: Intel logo is seen near computer motherboard in this illustration taken January 8, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration
Intel has been seeking to prove it can compete in the foundry market, where companies produce custom chips for clients.
While AI is driving a boom in the chip sector, Intel seems to be an exception, analysts say.
AEM faces weak outlook at Intel after reports of a shortfall in its inventory.

site_title: UK house prices rise for first time in over a year
summary: UK house prices rose 1.2% in February 2024, the first annual increase since January 2023, according to mortgage lender Nationwide Building Society. This marks the first annual increase in house prices in over a year. The monthly increase was 0.7%. The recovery in the housing market is seen as a sign of improvement after a dip in mortgage costs.

images.alt_text: Banks and building societies approve 55,227 home loans, up from 51,506 in December, the fourth straight monthly increase.

site_title: Gold eyes second weekly gain on gradually easing US inflation
summary: Gold prices rose for a second week, steadying near month-high levels, as the US inflation data showed a gradual easing of price pressures. The US personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index rose 0.3% in January, with inflation at 2.4% for the 12 months to January, the smallest in nearly three years. Lower interest rates are expected to boost the appeal of non-yielding bullion, with traders betting on a 75% chance of a 25 basis point interest rate cut in June.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was steady at US$2,035.78 per ounce.

site_title: Singapore is bracing itself for a super-ageing society
summary: Singapore is facing a rapidly ageing society with a fertility rate of 0.97, below the replacement rate of 2.1. The city-state is offering special retention payments of up to S$100,000 to foreign nurses to prevent them from leaving and address the growing healthcare needs. With the population projected to be 65% or older by 2030, Singapore is shifting its focus to healthcare and social welfare policies to support its elderly population. The government has also introduced incentives for couples to have more children, such as paid paternity leave and subsidies for education programs.

images.alt_text: Seniors from Lions Befrienders and DBS volunteers upcycled 4,300 kg of festive Chinese New Year packets collected from DBS branches across Singapore into a 2.5-metre-tall artwork replicating the bank’s 2024 ang bao design.
DPM Lawrence Wong said he hopes this year's Budget will give Singaporeans confidence to build a better future even in an increasingly troubled world.

site_title: Asia’s factories struggle for growth as China, Japan falter
summary: Asia's major manufacturing economies struggled in February, with Japan's factory activity falling at the fastest pace in over three years. China's official PMI showed factory activity continuing to decline, while private-sector Caixin PMI showed a slight pick-up. Japan's recession and decline in motor vehicle production weighed on the sector, while China's economy is tentatively finding its footing after a property sector crisis. Other countries, such as South Korea and India, saw signs of improvement, with South Korea's export growth exceeding forecasts and India's manufacturing activity expanding at its fastest pace in five months.

images.alt_text: China's purchasing managers’ index - a key measure of factory output - came in at 49.1 per cent in February, according to China’s National Bureau of Statistics.

site_title: Four A*Star initiatives to commercialise R&D, including S$180 million semiconductor centre
summary: Singapore is launching four initiatives to commercialize research and development in semiconductors, nucleic acid therapeutics, robotics, and medtech, with a total investment of S$275 million. The National Semiconductor Translation and Innovation Centre, focusing on flat optics and silicon photonics, will open in April. The Nucleic Acid Therapeutics Initiative will receive S$97 million, while the Medtech Catapult initiative will receive S$38 million. The National Robotics Programme will receive S$60 million, with a focus on commercializing robotics capabilities in various sectors.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
A new initiative named the Future Energy Fund will receive an initial injection of S$5 billion to build critical infrastructure and improve energy security.

consortium members who are keen on expanding to the UK can do via the NHS route and make use of pre-existing business networks, said consortium chairman Willy Koh, who is also CEO of Racer Technology.

site_title: ‘Difficult discussions’ as WTO talks extended for third time
summary: World Trade Organization (WTO) ministers have extended their talks for a third time, pushing the conference's closing session to Friday afternoons. The talks, which began to address issues such as e-commerce moratoriums, fisheries subsidies, and agriculture agreements, are facing challenges due to disagreements among the 164 member states. The WTO's Director-General, Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, emphasized the need to demonstrate the organization's relevance by securing some wins, while a key sticking point in agriculture negotiations remains the demand for permanent rules governing public stockholding of food reserves.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Delegates pose for a family photo during the 13th WTO ministerial conference in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates, February 26, 2024. REUTERS/Abdel Hadi Ramahi/File Photo

site_title: BMW X2 review: X2 marks the sport
summary: The BMW X2, a compact coupe-SUV, has been revamped for success in Singapore. The new model boasts a larger, deeper boot with 560 litres of capacity and a more stylish appearance, thanks to its rising waistline and prominent features. The X2 is available in various versions, including a powerful M35i with 300 horsepower, and a more affordable eDrive20 electric model. While the X2's suspension can be firm on bad roads, its stable and agile handling makes it a promising contender in the Singapore market. The car's practicality and style are expected to appeal to both budget-conscious buyers and those seeking a more luxurious driving experience.

site_title: China banks approve US$28 billion loans for property market
summary: China's housing ministry announced that over $28 billion of bank loans have been approved for property projects as of February 28, a significant increase from the previous week. This move follows government pressure on banks to boost property loans through white lists, aimed at supporting the struggling real estate market. Despite the increase, home sales continue to decline, with new home sales from top 100 real estate companies dropping 60% from a year earlier. The government has urged local governments to coordinate negotiations with developers and banks to speed up implementation.

images.alt_text: Apartments buildings stand in Beijing, China, on Thursday, Feb. 17, 2011. Beijing will ban residents from buying more than two homes after the Chinese government extended property curbs to prevent a housing bubble, China Central Television reported. Photographer: Nelson Ching/Bloomberg

site_title: Huawei offers blueprint for China’s challenge to Boeing-Airbus duopoly
summary: China's state-owned Commercial Aircraft Corporation of China (Comac) showcased its C919 model at the Singapore Air Show, rivaling Airbus's A320 and Boeing's 737. The narrow-body plane has gained traction with local airlines, but needs foreign buyers to establish credibility and long-term viability. Comac's strategy, inspired by Huawei's success, should focus on offering cheaper upfront purchases coupled with competitively priced ongoing services, including after-sales maintenance and training of cockpit crew. This one-two punch could make Comac's planes more attractive to buyers, particularly smaller carriers in developing markets, and challenge the duopoly of Airbus and Boeing in the global passenger-jet market.

images.alt_text: A C919 performs during a preview of the Singapore Airshow in Singapore on Feb 18.
The Comac C919 is China's first international airliner and could gain sales as aviation giants Airbus and Boeing grapple with supply-chain disruptions.

A China Comac C919 aircraft during a preview of the Singapore Airshow in Singapore, Feb 18, 2024. Beijing wants to challenge the decades-long dominance of top plane-makers Airbus and Boeing while reducing its reliance on foreign technology.

site_title: Cordlife posts 50.3% lower H2 profit; sets up Vietnam subsidiary
summary: Cordlife Group reported a 50.3% decline in its second-half profit to S$1.5 million, due to a six-month suspension of its Singapore business amid concerns over temperature excursions in its cord blood storage tanks. Revenue fell 4.5% year-over-year to S$27.6 million. The company also set up a subsidiary in Vietnam, CL Biotech, to provide management consulting and medical research services. Cordlife's shares closed 3.3% lower at S$0.29, amid ongoing investigations and uncertainty over the lifting of its trading suspension.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Cord blood bank Cordife's chairman has stepped down with effect from Thursday (Feb 29) .

While Cordlife is in good financial shape at the moment, it should begin weighing its strategic options before too much value is lost

The MOH finds more lapses in the group's processes, including cord blood processing method and temperature warning systems.
Robust Plan has brought down its stake in Cordlife Group from 5.47 per cent to 3.67 per cent.
Cordlife says that each batch of the samples for testing may take between three and six weeks to be completed, depending on whether a repeat test of samples from the same tank is need.
Mainboard-listed Cordlife was in November slapped with a six-month suspension from collecting, processing and storing new cord blood and providing any new types of tests.

site_title: China new home prices rise at slower pace in February, survey shows
summary: China's new home prices rose at a slower pace in February, with an average increase of 0.14% compared to 0.15% in January, according to a private survey. The number of cities reporting price growth decreased by nine, while Shenzhen experienced a 0.28% price drop. Total sales by value among 100 real estate companies plummeted 51.6% year-on-year in the first two months of the year. Authorities have been ramping up measures to halt the downturn, including financing support policies, and may ease home purchase restrictions and mortgage interest rates after the government's annual "Two Sessions" meetings next week.

images.alt_text: China's purchasing managers’ index - a key measure of factory output - came in at 49.1 per cent in February, according to China’s National Bureau of Statistics.
Chinese firms has put US$28.2 billion into EV-related industries last year.
Financial institutions need to prevent loans from being misappropriated and safeguard the safety of credit funds.
Zhang Baichuan, 23, checks a job advertisement at a job fair in Shijiazhuang, Hebei province.

site_title: New grant of up to S$10,000 for ‘placemaking’ activities by heartland businesses
summary: Singapore has introduced a new Heartland Enterprise Placemaking Grant, offering up to S$10,000 to heartland businesses for innovative "placemaking" activities such as community engagement and public art installations. The grant, part of efforts to transform and revitalize the heartlands, aims to cover up to half of eligible costs for selected activities. Eligible businesses must have at least 30% local shareholding and a physical storefront in the heartlands, with two pilot projects to be launched in Bukit Gombak and Tampines West.

images.alt_text: Singapore can continue to secure growth by serving as a trusted node and connector, offer a strong innovation ecosystem, and transforming through tripartism, says Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat.
Ang, a mechanical engineer by training, and founder and chief executive officer of web consultancy The Adventus Consultants, was elected unopposed to Asme’s top role for a two-year term.
The Sustainability Reporting Grant is for large companies with annual revenues of S$100 million and above.

site_title: Who moved my cheese: Is Singapore’s status as top Mice hotspot getting stale?
summary: Singapore's status as a top Mice (Meetings, Incentives, Conferences, and Exhibitions) destination is facing a decline due to rising costs. Event management companies have seen a 20% drop in sales to stage Mice events in Singapore, with clients opting for cheaper destinations across South-east Asia. David Toh, founder of The Ebenex Group, is transforming Melaka into a premier Mice destination, partnering with Hatten Group to establish 828 Asia. The move aims to capitalize on Melaka's lower-cost base, with costs 20-30% lower than Singapore.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
A tour boat makes its way out to the Marina Bay in Singapore on December 9, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)

site_title: Tesla rolls out new incentives in China as price war escalates
summary: Tesla unveiled new incentives in China to combat a price war, including insurance subsidies and financing plans that could save up to 16,600 yuan for Model Y purchases. Existing inventory pickups by March 31 are eligible for a maximum 34,600 yuan worth of incentives. The move follows rival BYD's price cuts and discounts, with Tesla slashing prices on some Model 3 and Y cars in China in January and offering cash discounts for Model Ys from February 1.

images.alt_text: Tesla bears little to no incremental cost earning the credits, so the sales are virtually pure profit.
Tesla sent out the single-line query for each job after cancelling some employees’ biannual performance reviews.
US safety regulators have upgraded their probe into Tesla vehicles over power steering loss to the status of an engineering analysis – a required step before the agency could demand a recall.

site_title: Indian community leader to be new editor of Tamil Murasu from Apr 1
summary: Tamil Murasu, a Tamil-language daily in Singapore, will have a new editor starting April 1, as part of SPH Media's leadership and succession planning. T Raja Segar, 61, a former CEO of the Hindu Endowments Board and Singapore Indian Development Association, will take over from Jawharilal Rajendran, 66, who will continue as consulting editor and oversee special projects. Raja has a strong background in the local Indian community, having managed various roles in media and development.

images.alt_text: (From left) Willis Wee, CEO and Founder of Tech in Asia, and Wong Wei Kong, Editor-in-Chief of English/Malay/Tamil Media Group, SPH Media.

site_title: Singapore partners ExxonMobil-Shell consortium to study cross-border carbon capture and storage
summary: Singapore has partnered with an ExxonMobil-Shell consortium to study a cross-border carbon capture and storage (CCS) project, aiming to start the project by 2030. The project will aggregate CO2 emissions in Singapore and work with regional partners to identify potential storage sites. The consortium plans to capture and permanently store 2.5 million tonnes of CO2 annually, and Singapore will invest S$55 million in low-carbon energy research, including hydrogen and ammonia technologies. The partnership is part of Singapore's efforts to expand its range of technological solutions for reducing carbon emissions.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Many countries and regions have launched emissions trading systems (ETS) to put a price on carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions and incentivise companies to invest in low carbon technology.
Once fully operational in 2025, the facility can remove 3,650 tonnes of CO2 from the ocean yearly.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Friday; STI remains unchanged
summary: Singapore shares opened flat on Friday, March 1, 2024, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 0.09 point to 3,141.76. Despite overnight gains in global markets, the broader market saw gainers outnumber losers 78 to 57, with 77.7 million securities worth S$98.6 million changing hands.

site_title: Indonesia expects 17.5% drop in January to April rice output
summary: Indonesia expects a 17.52% drop in rice output from January to April, down to 10.7 million tonnes, due to dry weather and El Nino's impact on planting. This has led to higher retail prices, with the retail rice price index reaching a record high of 15,157 rupiah per kg. The government is boosting rice imports by 1.6 million tonnes to control prices and meet anticipated higher demand ahead of Ramadan.

images.alt_text: Indonesia aims to book 5.2 per cent economic growth in 2024, higher than the 5.05 per cent growth of last year.
The new palm oil replanting subsidy will rise to 60 million rupiah (S$5,149) per hectare.
The president has told his cabinet earlier that its 2025 state budget proposal must adjust to the programmes of the new president, who will take office in October.

site_title: JPMorgan picks HSBC, StanChart to run US$500 billion custody business in Hong Kong, Taiwan
summary: JPMorgan Chase has selected HSBC and Standard Chartered to operate its custody businesses in Hong Kong and Taiwan, respectively, worth over $500 billion. The US bank aims to complete the transition before the end of the year. HSBC and StanChart will manage transactions, settlements, and client accounts' compliance with tax regulations. JPMorgan previously withdrew from local custody services in Hong Kong and Taiwan due to rising costs.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A sign of JP Morgan Chase Bank is seen in front of their headquarters tower in Manhattan, New York, U.S., November 13, 2017. REUTERS/Amr Alfiky
The price of Bitcoin has historically increased after a halving event, with so-called miner production cost functioning as a lower bound to the price of the asset.
JPMorgan CFO Jeremy Barnum expects the IPO market to be a bit weaker than expected. However, the investment banking fee is expected to rise in low-to-mid teens percentage in the first quarter.
JPMorgan Chase CEO and chairman Jamie Dimon‘s compensation climbed about 4.3 per cent to US$36 million for 2023.

site_title: UK store traffic slumps most since Covid as economic woes linger
summary: UK retail traffic slumped 6.2% in February, the largest decline since the pandemic, due to a combination of train strikes, squeezed budgets, and extreme weather. High streets suffered the biggest drop, with footfall down 9.3% at city and town centre stores. The decline is attributed to weakened consumer confidence following a confirmed technical recession in 2023.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak (left) and Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt at a cabinet meeting in February. The UK is now in recession after two straight quarters of negative growth.
Only three of the banks listed “risk appetite” as a reason for closing accounts, with 4,214 cases listed.
British supermarkets’ most recent earnings have revealed solid growth over the Christmas period, with price cuts and customer loyalty initiatives boosting sales.

site_title: China’s Comac takes on Boeing and Airbus
summary: China's Comac unveiled the C919, a commercial jet comparable to Boeing's 737 and Airbus' A320neo, at the Singapore Airshow. The C919 aims to compete internationally, with state-owned Comac seeking to sell the aircraft globally. The C919's performance and capabilities will be evaluated against its Western counterparts. Comac's efforts to establish the C919 as a viable alternative to Boeing and Airbus' models are part of its strategy to expand its market share.

site_title: India’s Paytm discontinues inter-company agreements with its payments bank
summary: Paytm has discontinued inter-company agreements with its payments bank unit, Paytm Payments Bank, in an effort to reduce dependencies. The move follows a central bank clampdown and a major overhaul of the payments bank unit, which has faced concerns over compliance issues and a lack of arms-length distance from parent company Paytm. The Reserve Bank of India had asked Paytm Payments Bank to wind down operations by March 15. The simplification of the shareholders' agreement aims to support the bank's governance, independent of its shareholders.

images.alt_text: Softbank, which held 17.5 per cent stake in Paytm in September 2022, has trimmed its ownership for more than a year through multiple open market deals, with its most recent cut being in January.
If approved, Paytm will be allowed to continue processing payments via India’s popular unified payments interface.
Paytm has seen its shares lose more than half of their value since the banking regulator’s surprise clampdown amid concerns over the continuity of its business model.
The Reserve Bank of India in a January order has asked the Paytm unit to stop accepting any fresh deposits in its account or popular wallet from Feb 29.

site_title: What US$1 million buys in the world’s most expensive cities
summary: A US$1 million investment in the world's most expensive cities yields varying results, with Monaco offering the least amount of square footage at 172 square feet, followed by Hong Kong at 237 square feet and Singapore at 344 square feet. In contrast, New York, Paris, and Shanghai offer more space, with prices remaining high despite declining global luxury real estate sales. The top 1% of wealthiest individuals in Monaco now require a minimum of US$12.8 million to join their ranks.

images.alt_text: Private real estate investors, the most active buyers in 2023, look set to increase their buying activity in 2024, says Knight Frank.
The number of homes sold for more than £5 million (S$8.5 million) in January is down 17 per cent from last year.
New York is one of several global cities where rents on luxury apartments fell in the fourth quarter last year.

site_title: BOJ chief Ueda stops short of declaring 2% price goal met
summary: Bank of Japan (BOJ) governor Kazuo Ueda stopped short of declaring that Japan has met its 2% inflation target, citing the need to scrutinize wage outlook and data on wage negotiations. Ueda emphasized the importance of confirming a positive wage-inflation cycle and noted that companies' annual wage negotiations with unions later this month will be crucial in making the judgment. The BOJ has expressed its readiness to phase out its massive stimulus once it has judged that Japan can achieve its inflation target in a stable, sustainable fashion.

images.alt_text: Under its massive stimulus programme, the Bank of Japan currently guides short-term interest rates at minus 0.1 per cent, caps the 10-year government bond yield around 0 per cent and continues to buy huge amounts of assets such as government bonds.
Kazuo Ueda says Japan’s economy is likely to experience a positive cycle, in which higher job and wage growth leads to moderate rises in inflation.
With inflation exceeding the BOJ’s 2 per cent target for well over a year, many market players expect the BOJ to end its negative interest rate policy in the coming months.

site_title: Australian home prices accelerate, defying interest-rate squeeze
summary: Australia's housing market has defied interest-rate hikes, with home prices accelerating in February. Major cities like Sydney and Melbourne saw 0.5% and 0.1% increases, respectively, resulting in a 0.6% overall gain. Perth and Adelaide led the growth with 1.8% and 1.1% rises, respectively. The Reserve Bank of Australia has tightened policy to 12-year highs, but signs of easing inflation suggest rate cuts may follow as early as August. Housing values are expected to remain strong despite policy easing, with prices increasing 8.9% nationally over the past 12 months.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 closed 0.5 per cent higher at 7,698.7 points.
The RBA’s own forecasts show inflation will only fall back within target in December 2025.

site_title: ShopBack the latest player to sound retreat from ‘buy now, pay later’
summary: ShopBack, a loyalty platform, will discontinue its "buy now, pay later" service, PayLater, on March 22, affecting both online and physical transactions in Singapore and Malaysia. The decision follows a review of its business units and is driven by a strategic focus on sustainable models with growth potential. This move comes after several BNPL players, including Pace, have shuttered their services in recent months.

images.alt_text: 电商平台Shopback外观。
Benjamin Cher

site_title: Thailand aims for 150 million passengers a year at main airport
summary: Thailand aims to increase annual passenger capacity at Suvarnabhumi Airport in Bangkok to 150 million by 2025, more than doubling current capacity. The airport will add a third runway, allowing for 90 flights per hour, and upgrade regional airports to support tourism. Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin also announced plans to increase capacity at Don Mueng Airport to 50 million and Phuket airport to 18 million. The upgrades aim to establish Thailand as an aviation hub and boost the economy.

images.alt_text: Thailand became the first country in South-east Asia to decriminalise cannabis, initially for medicinal use in 2021, then for recreational use in 2022.
People at an HSR exhibition during the groundbreaking ceremony on the cooperation between Thailand and China on the Bangkok-Nong Khai HSR development in Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand.

site_title: JPMorgan predicts Bitcoin correction once halving euphoria cools
summary: JPMorgan analysts predict a Bitcoin correction after the halving event in April, citing a potential 20% drop in mining difficulty and lower production costs. The price of Bitcoin has historically increased after a halving event, but with increased mining difficulty and lower production costs, investors may see the price drifting back towards $42,000 after April. This is based on two key assumptions: post-halving electricity costs and a drop in private miners due to increased production costs.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin has jumped over 40 per cent already this year atop the successful debut of the ETF products, which directly hold the token.
FILE PHOTO: A bitcoin logo is pictured on a door in an illustration picture taken at La Maison du Bitcoin in Paris May 27, 2015. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier/File Photo

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly up after US gains
summary: Asian markets largely rose on Friday after US stocks gained, driven by tech rallies and inflation data meeting expectations. The US Federal Reserve's preferred inflation gauge, the personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index, increased 2.4% in January, down from 2.6% in December, suggesting the Fed may cut interest rates sooner. Analysts say the report restored confidence that the Fed will cut rates in 2024. Meanwhile, factory activity in China contracted for the fifth straight month, but Shanghai and Tokyo stocks were higher, while Hong Kong was flat.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 78 to 57 after 77.7 million securities worth S$98.6 million change hands.
The pan-European Stoxx 600 closed 0.1 per cent higher on Thursday, led by a more than 1 per cent advance in the insurance and construction and material sectors.
The Nasdaq surged 0.9 per cent to 16,091.92 on Thursday, surpassing a 2021 high.

site_title: US lawmakers approve stopgap bill to avert government shutdown
summary: US lawmakers have approved a stopgap bill to avert a government shutdown, extending funding for several key federal agencies until March 8. The measure, which was passed by the Republican-led House and Democratic Senate, gives lawmakers a few extra days to get back on track with the annual spending bills. A full shutdown would have occurred a week later, affecting critical functions such as food safety inspections and air traffic controllers' pay. The bill's passage comes after President Joe Biden called for lawmakers to work together to avoid a shutdown, but the measure only provides a short-term fix and does not address the underlying spending impasse.

images.alt_text: The agreement by Republican and Democratic leaders in the House and Senate would push back the start of a shutdown from Friday until March 8, giving policymakers some breathing room to try to reach a deal to fund the government.

White House said Joe Biden will meet Republican House Speaker Mike Johnson and his Democratic counterpart Hakeem Jeffries, as well as the Senate’s Democratic Majority Leader Chuck Schumer and opposition chief Mitch McConnell.

Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer, a Democrat from New York, speaks during a news conference at the US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, June 1, 2023. The Senate passed legislation to suspend the US debt ceiling and impose restraints on government spending through the 2024 election, ending a drama that threatened a global financial crisis. Photographer: Ting Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Japan’s February factory activity shrinks most in over 3 years on weak demand: PMI
summary: Japan's factory activity shrank at its fastest pace in over 3.5 years in February, with the PMI index falling to 47.2 from 48.0 in January. Production and new orders declined at the fastest pace in a year, citing weak sales demand and production delays. Export sales continued to contract, mainly due to weak sales in China. Employment also shrank at the steepest pace since 2021. Despite this, manufacturers' confidence for the year-ahead remained strong due to hopes for production and economic recovery.

images.alt_text: Under its massive stimulus programme, the Bank of Japan currently guides short-term interest rates at minus 0.1 per cent, caps the 10-year government bond yield around 0 per cent and continues to buy huge amounts of assets such as government bonds.
Japan’s chronic labour crisis is worsening as the ageing and shrinking of the population accelerates.
Manufacturers surveyed by Japan's Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry expect seasonally adjusted output to increase 4.8 per cent in February and rise 2.0 per cent in March.

site_title: Elton John items fetch more than US$20 million at New York auction
summary: Elton John's collection of over 900 items and artworks, including a Banksy triptych and a glam rock jumpsuit, fetched more than US$20 million at Christie's auctions. The collection, which includes works by Keith Haring and Andy Warhol, was sold in eight sales held in person and online. The grand piano, glasses, and a pair of sunglasses also sold for significant amounts, with the glasses fetching US$22,680. The collection was largely from Elton John's Atlanta home, which he sold recently.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Elton John performs at the Glastonbury Festival site in Somerset, Britain, June 25, 2023. REUTERS/Jason Cairnduff/File Photo

site_title: SEC is investigating OpenAI over its board’s actions
summary: The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is investigating OpenAI, the developer of ChatGPT, over its board's actions in removing and then reinstating CEO Sam Altman. The SEC sent official requests to OpenAI seeking information about the situation, but details on the investigation's scope remain unclear. OpenAI has hired a law firm to conduct its own investigation into Altman's behavior and the board's decision. The controversy surrounding Altman's ouster and reinstatement continues to hound the company, which is valued at over $80 billion.

images.alt_text: Baidu reports sales of nearly 35 billion yuan (S$6.5 billion) for the three months ended December, broadly in line with analysts’ projections.
The Mistral AI website. Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg
Alibaba’s new chiefs, Joseph Tsai (above) and Eddie Wu, have pledged to turn around a flagging company hammered by two years of regulatory scrutiny and an economic downturn.

From predicting product demand to optimising logistics, designing spaces and assessing investments, GenAI can drive improvements in critical areas such as lease writing, valuation, and legal processes.
Over the past few days some users on social media have flagged that the Google Gemini's AI model returns historical images which are sometimes inaccurate.

For more than 16 hours, ChatGPT gave “peculiar” responses, generating nonexistent words, incomplete sentences and general gobbledygook, developers using the tool said in a discussion forum on the OpenAI website.
OpenAI led a revolution in artificial intelligence when it placed its ChatGPT program online in late 2022.
Code-named Izanagi, the project marks Masayoshi Son’s next big endeavor as SoftBank sharply curtails startup investments.

site_title: Japan mayor quits over 99 sexual harassment allegations
summary: Japanese Mayor Hideo Kojima has resigned after an official investigation accused him of 99 allegations of sexual harassment, including touching colleagues' breasts and buttocks. Kojima, 74, denied some allegations, claiming his gestures were not intended to be harassing, but were misinterpreted. The mayor's resignation comes amid growing public outcry and a global #MeToo movement that has recently forced a reckoning in Japan. No criminal case has been launched against Kojima, who will leave his post on Tuesday.

images.alt_text: The BOJ has stressed its readiness to phase out its massive stimulus once it has judged that Japan can achieve its inflation target in a stable, sustainable fashion.

Both production and new orders, the two main subindexes of Japan's PMI, declined at the fastest pace in a year. Respondents cited factors such as weak sales demand at home and overseas as well as production delays due to machinery shutdowns.
Japan’s chronic labour crisis is worsening as the ageing and shrinking of the population accelerates.
Nintendo is looking to clamp down on the operations of a company called Tropic Haze, registered in the US state of Rhode Island, which owns and runs Yuzu, a popular video game emulator.

A woman passes Japanese cosmetics company Shiseido's counter at a department store in Tokyo January 15, 2010. Shiseido said it will buy U.S.-based Bare Escentuals Inc for $1.7 billion in a bid to revamp its global brand and expand in North America.   REUTERS/Yuriko Nakao (JAPAN - Tags: EMPLOYMENT BUSINESS)

Pedestrians walk past a signboard showing the closing numbers on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, along a street in Tokyo in January 11, 2024. Tokyo's Nikkei index closed above 35,000 for the first time in nearly 34 years on January 11, buoyed by US Tech rallies and hopes for an end to decades of sluggish inflation. (Photo by Richard A. BROOKS / AFP)

site_title: Gildan’s ex-CEO lambastes possible sale, unveils strategy for his return
summary: Gildan's former CEO, Glenn Chamandy, has unveiled a strategy to nearly double the clothing maker's profits by 2028 if he returns to the job. Under his plan, Gildan would borrow more, accelerate stock buybacks, and focus on organic growth, aiming to boost earnings per share and raise the stock price to $60 by the end of next year and $100 in five years. Chamandy's allies, including Browning West, are leading a campaign to unseat the current board and bring him back, but the company's board members are fighting back, exploring a potential sale to investors.

images.alt_text: Piccioli has been the sole creative director of Valentino since July 2016, when Maria Grazia Chiuri leaves to become creative director at Dior.
Nike is shifting its sneaker offerings as it tries to find sweet spots across categories.

site_title: BYD bolsters Japan push with EV lineup, dealership network
summary: BYD, the Chinese electric vehicle (EV) giant, is expanding its presence in Japan with a new lineup of models and dealership network. The company aims to reach 100 locations by the end of 2025, up from 22 dealerships currently. BYD will introduce a luxury sedan later this year, followed by new models in 2025 and 2026. Despite struggling to gain traction in the Japanese market, BYD sees an opportunity to push into a developed market where foreign brands face resistance. The company's Atto 3 electric SUV has recently been revamped for the Japanese market.

images.alt_text: Chinese EV makers have been counting on South-east Asia, the Middle East and Europe as their largest exporting markets. There are relatively few Chinese-made light duty vehicles being imported into the US.
BYD is particularly cost-competitive and aggressive among Chinese players, according to executives from its Chinese rivals already selling cars in Mexico.
The pricing indicates that BYD is giving bigger discounts on most of these models than last year.

site_title: US sees China’s space threat growing at ‘breathtaking pace’
summary: The US is concerned about China's growing space threat, with a record 100 Chinese missions expected in 2024, up 40% from last year. China is developing advanced space weaponry, including satellites, human spaceflight, and robotic space exploration, to counter US satellites and improve its ability to monitor and target forces on Earth. The US Space Command's head, General Stephen Whiting, warns that China is growing its military space capabilities at a "breathtaking pace" and is rapidly building programmes to threaten US satellite architecture. China's Defence Ministry has denied the allegations, calling them "false information."

images.alt_text: Khaldoon Mubarak, the CEO and Managing Director of Mubadala Investment, says that sovereign wealth funds have an opportunity and responsibility to transform from asset investors to enablers of global progress.
A view from onboard the Odysseus mission in Earth's orbit on Feb 16, 2024. For the first time in more than 50 years, an American spacecraft has landed on the moon.
SpaceX's Falcon 9 rocket lifts off with Intuitive Machines' Nova-C moon lander on top.

site_title: China’s factory output shrinks for fifth straight month
summary: China's factory output contracted for the fifth consecutive month in February, with the purchasing managers' index (PMI) falling to 49.1% from 50.7% in January. This marks the lowest level since the pandemic years. The contraction is attributed to sluggish demand, a global slowdown, and unprecedented turmoil in the property sector. Despite efforts to boost economic activity, results have been mixed, and China is set to unveil its official economic goals, including a GDP growth target expected to be among the lowest in three decades.

images.alt_text: Chinese firms has put US$28.2 billion into EV-related industries last year.
Financial institutions need to prevent loans from being misappropriated and safeguard the safety of credit funds.

Residential buildings stand in Chongqing, China, on Tuesday, April 12, 2016. The municipality of 30 million people's state-led development approach fueled growth of 11 percent last year, the fastest pace nationwide, with President Xi Jinping praising policy innovations that have included subsidized housing and relaxed residency rules that encourage labor mobility. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
The iPhone 15 launch came at a time of slowing sales for Apple in China where it faces rising competitive pressure from domestic rivals like Huawei and Xiaomi.
China earlier this month broadly took aim at quant funds, which relied on computer-driven trading to outperform the market for much of the last three years.

site_title: South Korea’s exports keep rising, supporting growth outlook
summary: South Korea's exports continued to grow, increasing 12.5% year-over-year in February, with unadjusted exports rising 4.8% and a trade surplus reaching $4.29 billion. The growth supports the country's optimistic economic outlook for 2024, with the Bank of Korea forecasting a 2.1% GDP growth. However, threats to the economy include slowing consumption, construction investment, and geopolitical tensions, as well as a global economy projected to grow 3.1% this year.

images.alt_text: shipping container Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

site_title: Hewlett Packard Enterprise sees downbeat Q2 revenue on weak networking solutions demand
summary: Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) reported a downbeat Q2 revenue, missing analysts' estimates, due to weak demand for networking solutions. The company forecasts Q2 revenue of $6.6-7 billion, below expectations of $7.11 billion. An uncertain economy and high interest rates have led clients to cut back on expenses. HPE's CFO attributed the decline to the "softening of the networking market and GPU deal timing." The company expects to roughly double its networking market share with its planned $14 billion deal for Juniper Networks.

images.alt_text: Juniper, like its bigger rival Cisco Systems, makes networking devices such as routers and switches.

site_title: UK-Canada trade barriers to increase amid failure to reach deal
summary: The UK and Canada failed to reach an agreement on extending provisions allowing the UK to sell products containing EU parts to Canada tariff-free, resulting in a 6.1% levy on affected exports. The UK's post-Brexit trade policy has been criticized, with critics calling it "embarrassing" that the country was unable to secure a deal with a close ally. The lapse of these provisions may deepen rifts in the Conservative Party and impact the UK's tariff-free trade with non-EU markets, potentially hindering its ability to boost exports.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: New cars are parked in rows after arriving by ship at Annacis Island in Delta, British Columbia, Canada, July 31, 2023. REUTERS/Chris Helgren/File Photo

site_title: Gwyneth Paltrow’s Goop products face trademark infringement suit
summary: Good Clean Love (GCL) is suing Gwyneth Paltrow's company Goop for allegedly selling products using a confusingly similar trademark "Good. Clean. Goop" that contain known harsh chemicals, despite GCL's established "Good Clean Love" trademark. GCL claims Goop's actions are likely to mislead consumers, cause confusion at major retailers, and threaten its reputation and ability to expand. GCL seeks preliminary and permanent injunctions, damages, and attorneys' fees.

images.alt_text: Television still: The Goop Lab hosted by Gwyneth Paltrow
Paltrow's wellness brand Goop accused of peddling pseudoscience
Gwyneth Paltrow's Goop names new CEO, plans e-commerce push

site_title: Tax governance – a blueprint for tax health
summary: Singapore's Inland Revenue Authority (Iras) has introduced a tax governance and tax risk management framework to help companies manage their corporate income tax and GST risks. The framework, which includes a tax governance framework, tax risk management and control framework, and the Assisted Compliance Assurance Programme, aims to ensure companies have adequate and effective controls and processes in place. Companies that implement the framework can benefit from reduced penalties, tax-compliance audits, and a step-down in compliance audits. Implementing a tax governance structure is seen as crucial in reducing tax risks and fostering trust with Iras.

images.alt_text: Tax authorities around the world face resource and compliance monitoring constraints as transactions become more digitalised.
It is interesting that the U-turn to levy a top-up tax is conveniently happening at a time when the developed world is no longer the net exporter of e-commerce services.

site_title: Luxury house linked to Evergrande’s founder Hui Ka Yan put on sale in Hong Kong
summary: A three-storey luxury house in Hong Kong's Peak area, valued at 10E at Black's Link, linked to China Evergrande Group's founder Hui Ka Yan, has been put up for sale. The 4,933 sq ft property features a private garden and internal elevator. The sale comes as the luxury property market in Hong Kong is expected to rebound following the government's removal of property curbs. The sale is part of a pair of Black's Link properties seized by a creditor last November, and another house is still looking for a buyer.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: China Evergrande Group Chairman Hui Ka Yan attends a news conference on the property developer's annual results in Hong Kong, China March 28, 2017. REUTERS/Bobby Yip/File Photo
The parties “are still considering whether the Proposed transactions will proceed, and have yet to form a definitive view”, Evergrande New Energy Vehicle says.

(FILES) The Evergrande logo is seen on residential buildings in Nanjing, in China’s eastern Jiangsu province on August 18, 2023. Troubled Chinese real estate giant Evergrande was issued a winding-up order on January 29, 2024, after failing to convince a Hong Kong court that it had a working restructuring plan. (Photo by STRINGER / AFP) / China OUT

site_title: ‘We’ve been fighting for our lives every day’: Ritual Gym founder, following abrupt closure of   Singapore branches
summary: Ritual Gym, a Singapore-based boutique high-intensity interval training studio, abruptly shut down its four branches on February 29 due to a critical investor pulling out funding. The gym, founded in 2013, had struggled with securing investors during the Covid-19 pandemic and faced crippling rents and mounting debt. Founder Brad Robinson assured that the 35 full-time employees will be compensated and that the company is exploring ways to revive the business. Ritual Gym has been hit by slow post-Covid recovery, low membership numbers, and high operating costs, leading to a net loss of S$1.4 million in 2021.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Home-grown boutique fitness gym Ritual is the latest gym to bite the dust in Singapore. It follows a string of closures in recent months.
UFC Gym's flagship outlet in CityLink Mall., which shut without warning. It will be replaced by gym chain Anytime Fitness.

On Sep 27, Pure Group announced that it would be closing its two Suntec City branches. It is the latest body blow to Singapore’s gym industry, which could see more closures in central areas, said observers.

Pure Fitness'  branch at Suntec City.  Pure Group said membership acquisitions at Suntec City “proved challenging” in spite of "multiple efforts and campaigns to drive awareness and customer engagement”.
Fenix Fitness' sole outlet at Raffles Place.
Haus Athletics first announced the closure of its OUE outlet on Apr 19, followed by the closure of its Cross Street Exchange outlet on Apr 24.

site_title: Stocks to watch: IHH Healthcare, Cosco Shipping, MLT, FCT, ComfortDelGro
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean companies reported earnings for the fourth quarter of 2023. IHH Healthcare saw a 280% jump in earnings to RM727.5 million, while Cosco Shipping reversed a full-year net loss to a profit of S$1.9 million. Mapletree Logistics Trust announced the acquisition of three warehouses, and Frasers Centrepoint Trust will be added to the Strait Times Index. ComfortDelGro reported a 76.5% increase in net profit to S$102 million, while OUE posted a 59.6% decline in earnings. Hong Fok Corporation also reported a 61.5% drop in earnings to S$81.2 million.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.1 per cent or 2.92 points to finish the trading day at 3,141.85.

site_title: Japan’s tight labour market to keep upward pressure on wages
summary: Japan's job market remained tight in January, with the unemployment rate falling to 2.4% and a job-to-applicants ratio of 1.27. This has put upward pressure on wages, with economists predicting strong wage increases as companies try to secure manpower. Japan's chronic labour crisis is worsening due to an ageing and shrinking population, and the Bank of Japan is watching the annual wage talks as it considers ending its negative interest rate policy. The outcome of these talks may lead to the BOJ's first interest rate hike since 2007 as early as March.

images.alt_text: Under its massive stimulus programme, the Bank of Japan currently guides short-term interest rates at minus 0.1 per cent, caps the 10-year government bond yield around 0 per cent and continues to buy huge amounts of assets such as government bonds.
Manufacturers surveyed by Japan's Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry expect seasonally adjusted output to increase 4.8 per cent in February and rise 2.0 per cent in March.
Japan’s 2.0 per cent core consumer inflation, which includes oil products but excludes fresh food prices, compared with economists’ median estimate for a 1.8 per cent annual gain.

site_title: How the ‘Magnificent Seven’ misleads
summary: The "Magnificent Seven" tech stocks, consisting of Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Meta, Microsoft, Nvidia, and Tesla, have lost their collective appeal as a market powerhouse. By the end of 2023, the group had added $3.4 trillion to their combined market value, but by mid-2024, three of the seven have underperformed, and Tesla has fallen outright. The group's disbanding signals broader shifts, including investors becoming less anxious about higher interest rates and a growing willingness to be skeptical about tech stocks. Nvidia has outperformed, with a 129% rise in shares, while Microsoft has done only slightly better than the average S&P 500 member.

images.alt_text: Generative AI is likely to touch all areas of the economy, and productivity is likely to be enhanced across many industries.
JP Morgan strategists say while there is concern over the strong outperformance of the Magnificent 7 stocks, trading is less stretched than a few years ago.

site_title: US updates export curbs on AI chips and tools to China
summary: The US has revised rules to halt shipments to China of more advanced artificial intelligence (AI) chips designed by Nvidia and others, aiming to hobble Beijing's chipmaking industry due to national security concerns. The new rules, released in October, will go into effect on April 4, and are part of an effort to restrict China's access to US AI technology. The move is aimed at slowing China's growing tech sector, which could help boost its military capabilities.

site_title: Country Garden delays earnings report, Vanke net tumbles as woes deepen
summary: China's property firms Country Garden and Vanke reported disappointing earnings, with Country Garden delaying its annual results and Vanke posting a 46% net profit decline. The slump in home sales and price declines highlight the challenges facing authorities in salvaging the beleaguered market. The downturn has also led to increased bad loans at state banks and a downgrade of some developers to junk territory. Fitch Ratings expects a 5-10% fall in new home sales this year, as weaker home-buying demand continues to weigh on the industry.

images.alt_text: Country Garden's operations focus on smaller cities, which expand faster in good times but have been harder hit by the housing slump and economic slowdown.

site_title: Eurozone bank lending stagnated again in February
summary: Eurozone bank lending stagnated in February, with adjusted loans to households growing only 0.3% and credit to companies accelerating to 0.4% from 0.2%. High interest rates, aimed at taming inflation, have discouraged borrowers and lenders. The European Central Bank's borrowing costs reached record highs, but the economy remains in a doldrums, with inflation now under control. The ECB is expected to start cutting interest rates in June, as the quantity of money circulating in the economy began to grow at a 0.4% rate in February.

site_title: Who’s afraid of price controls?
summary: Germany's economy is paying dearly for the government's failure to cap energy costs in 2022, with a 4% short-run output loss and a 10% decline in real wages. The lack of effective price controls prolonged economic insecurity, contributing to a surge in support for the far-right Alternative for Germany party. The government's "wait-and-see" approach led to a delayed introduction of energy price caps, which succeeded in shielding households but left the industrial base vulnerable. Economists' fear of price controls may be baseless, and Germany's experience highlights the need for governments to reconsider their assumptions in the face of supply shocks.

images.alt_text: Workers of electricity transmission operator TransnetBW assemble a 380-KV power line on a high-voltage power pole near Pforzheim, southern Germany, on August 3, 2023. TransnetBW operates the electricity transmission grid in Federal state Baden-Wuerttemberg and expands it with a new 12 kilometers long  high-voltage line near this city. (Photo by THOMAS KIENZLE / AFP)
Facilities of natural gas transport and pipeline network operator Gascade in Lubmin, northeastern Germany : The EU agreed a natural gas price cap on Dec 19.
The construction site of a new liquefied natural gas terminal in Germany. Europe is discussing the possibility of a gas price cap to reduce revenue flows to Russia.

site_title: Fidelity lowers value of stake in Musk’s X by 5.7% in February
summary: Fidelity's Blue Chip Growth Fund reduced its stake in X (formerly Twitter) by 5.7% in February, valuing the position at $5.28 million, a 73% decline since Elon Musk's purchase in October 2022. This follows a month earlier valuation of $5.6 million. The fund's X stake has fallen 73% since Musk's takeover, amid efforts to lure back advertisers.

site_title: ECB rate cuts totalling 100 points possible this year: Greek central banker
summary: European Central Bank policymaker Yannis Stournaras suggests the ECB could cut interest rates by 100 basis points this year, with four potential 25-point cuts, but there's no consensus among ECB members. Stournaras believes a rate cut in June is likely and that the bank shouldn't wait for the US Federal Reserve to cut rates first.

site_title: US inflation increases moderately in February; consumer spending surges
summary: US inflation increased moderately in February, rising 0.3% as consumer spending surged 0.8% and core inflation increased 2.8% year-over-year. The Federal Reserve tracks the Personal Consumption Expenditures (PCE) price index, which is its 2% inflation target. With price pressures subsiding but at a slower pace, policymakers anticipate three rate cuts this year, with a potential June rate reduction. Despite this, Fed governor Christopher Waller cautioned against cutting interest rates too quickly.

images.alt_text: Productivity has been growing at a surprising clip, allowing the US economy to grow fast without adding to price pressures.

site_title: Chanel flap bag now costs more than 10,000 euros in Paris
summary: Chanel has increased the price of its medium-sized flap bag to 10,300 euros in Paris, a 6.2% hike from 9,700 euros earlier this year. The price adjustment, effective March 27, 2024, is attributed to constant inflation in raw materials and production costs. This move is part of Chanel's twice-yearly review of product prices, which also saw a 6-8% increase in September. The luxury brand maintains that prices are determined by cost, and the increase aims to ensure fairness for all clients.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A woman walks past a wall with logos of French luxury goods maker Chanel in Nice, France, February 22, 2017.    REUTERS/Eric Gaillard/File Photo

site_title: Hyundai Motor Group to invest 68 trillion won over 3 years
summary: Hyundai Motor Group plans to invest 68 trillion won (S$68 billion) over three years to boost its electric vehicle (EV) and new mobility business. The majority of the investment, 35.5 trillion won, will be allocated for new EV research and development infrastructure and assembly lines. Additionally, 31.1 trillion won will be invested in EV research and development, including software-defined vehicles and battery technology. The company also plans to hire 80,000 new employees to support its growth.

site_title: iPhone shipments in China fell 33% in February: data
summary: Apple's iPhone shipments in China fell 33% in February, marking a second consecutive month of lower sales, according to official data. The decline is attributed to the later timing of the Chinese New Year and the return of Huawei as a rival in the premium phone segment. The Chinese smartphone market also contracted by almost a third in February, with analysts predicting growth over the year but deteriorating iPhone sales.

images.alt_text: Customers at an Apple Store in Shanghai, March 15, 2024. Apple has deep ties in the country, its second-largest market. But there are signs that Chinese consumers are becoming a harder sell.

Tim Cook, chief executive officer of Apple Inc., center, and Deirdre O'Brien, senior vice president of retail, left, during the opening of the new Apple Inc. Jingan store in Shanghai, China, on Thursday, March 21, 2024. Cook opened an expansive new store in central Shanghai Thursday, signaling his company's commitment to China as a market and production base. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
Apple battles falling iPhone sales in China and rising competition from domestic rivals such as Huawei.
The US lawsuit alleges that Apple has used its power over app distribution on the iPhone to thwart innovations that would have made it easier for consumers to switch phones.

The Justice Department, which was also joined by the District of Columbia in the lawsuit, alleges that Apple uses its market power to get more money from consumers, developers, content creators, artists, publishers, small businesses and merchants.

site_title: Beware AI euphoria
summary: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is being touted as a transformative technology that will "change the world" and boost global GDP by $40 trillion by 2030. However, experts warn that this narrative is built on uncertain assumptions, including the ability of tech giants to monetize AI and the long-term profitability of the technology. The AI industry is also facing concerns over copyright, monopoly power, and worker complaints, with potential litigation and regulatory challenges on the horizon. As a result, some analysts are cautioning against the hype surrounding AI and the potential for a future bubble.

images.alt_text: AI is devouring baseload power from often carbon-intensive sources at a time when the world’s efforts are focused on installing renewable capacity to meet climate goals.
The mystique of Ivy League universities such as Harvard has blinded American companies to the wealth of talent that is available outside these institutions.

Big Tech has provided us with electronic wonders that put much of the world’s knowledge at our fingertips. Likewise AI is also empowering regular workers by making it easier to find and present information, in effect, providing us all with our own research assistant.

site_title: Health, manufacturing sectors continue to lead Singapore’s gender pay gap
summary: Singapore's gender pay gap narrowed to 14.3% in 2023, down from 16.3% in 2018. The health and social services sectors still have the largest disparity, with men earning 29% more than women. The industry with the biggest reverse gap was transportation and storage, where women earned 25% more than men. Experts attribute the gap to occupational differences, with men often selecting higher-paying jobs, and women taking on more managerial roles. To narrow the gap, employers are advised to recruit and retain women, especially in traditionally male-dominated sectors, and promote STEM education and equal sharing of caregiving responsibilities.

images.alt_text: Female representation on the Singapore companies’ boards have strengthened, with one in four board seats being filled by women last year, versus one in five in 2022, in line with the regional trend.
Women increasingly enjoy the same opportunities as men in education and employment but there is still a gender gap, including in pay and promotions.
The World Bank's report assesses, for the first time, how 190 countries are implementing existing laws to protect women. It reveals a 'shocking' gap between policy and practice.
“Numbers tell a lot of things, and how you interpret them will affect your decision,” said Choo Wan Sim, head of UOB TMRW Digital (Singapore).

site_title: Ravi Menon appointed Singapore’s ambassador for climate action
summary: Former Monetary Authority of Singapore chief Ravi Menon has been appointed as Singapore's first ambassador for climate action, effective April 1. He will represent Singapore at international climate action platforms and drive public-private partnerships to help businesses succeed in a low-carbon future. As senior adviser to the National Climate Change Secretariat, Menon will advise on whole-of-government climate policies and action, leveraging his strong international network in climate finance and past work building the region's green financing ecosystem.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Chia Der Jiun, managing director of the Monetary Authority of Singapore, speaking at the launch of the Singapore Sustainable Finance Association on January 24, 2024.

site_title: New season, new blooms at Van Cleef & Arpels
summary: Van Cleef & Arpels has unveiled five new pieces in its Frivole collection, featuring floral designs reminiscent of spring blooms. The new additions include the Between the Finger ring, continuing the brand's long history of floral-inspired jewellery dating back to 1907. The collection showcases the brand's technical skills and creative development through various designs, including clips, earrings, rings, bracelets, and pendants. The new pieces are part of Van Cleef & Arpels' ongoing celebration of fresh flora and its iconic style.

images.alt_text: The main salon at Louis Vuitton's Apartment retail concept.
The latest variation to the Alhambra collection combines the lucky red-orange hue of carnelian with the soft glow of rose gold.

site_title: Swapping Bordeaux for Kent, climate change to shift wine regions: study
summary: Climate change is expected to significantly alter the world's wine regions, with 49-70% of wine-producing areas becoming economically unviable by 2100. Research suggests English wines could thrive in previously unfavorable regions, while French and Italian vines may struggle. The extent of warming will determine the outcome, with 90% of coastal and lowland areas in Spain, Italy, and Greece at risk. In contrast, warmer conditions in northern US wine regions and the UK could lead to an increase in premium wine production.

images.alt_text: The largest remaining sanctions are those on Australian wine, including tariffs as high as 218 per cent.

Three single-vineyard wines produced by Tiberio, at the estate in Cugnoli, Italy, in the countryÕs Abruzzo region, Feb. 22, 2024. A new generation of exacting growers and winemakers has brought vitality to an Italian region known for its cheap wines. (Massimo Berruti/The New York Times)

site_title: Huawei says Chery's Luxeed S7 premium EV starts mass delivery
summary: Huawei's Luxeed S7 electric sedan, developed with Chery Auto, has started mass delivery after production issues and semiconductor shortages delayed its release. The vehicle, priced from 249,800 yuan, had 20,000 orders as of November 2023. Huawei's smart car unit, which has been experiencing production issues, is expected to turn a profit from April. The Luxeed S7 is the first model for Chery's Luxeed EV brand, and Huawei's revenues grew the fastest in four years in 2023.

images.alt_text: (FILES) A Huawei logo is seen during the Huawei Connect Conference in Shanghai on September 23, 2020. (Photo by AFP)

Huawei has three models for working with autos manufacturers: providing parts, providing smart solutions or designing and building vehicles.
Aito relaunches M7 with a new five-seater version and a lower starting price point than the original.

site_title: Tokyo’s Sézanne wins the best restaurant in Asia; Singapore excels with nine in the top 50
summary: Tokyo's Sezanne has been named the best restaurant in Asia, according to this year's Asia's 50 Best Restaurants list. The French restaurant, located in the Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi, advanced from second place to top of the list. Singapore excelled with nine of its restaurants on the top 50 list, surpassing Bangkok's previous dominance. Last year's No. 1 restaurant, Le Du in Bangkok, dropped to 12th, while Nusara, a Thai restaurant, came in sixth. The list was voted on by over 300 anonymous industry experts in the region, with no criteria for what constitutes "best".

images.alt_text: Noi in Hong Kong climbed to two stars in the new Michelin rankings.
People watch the first sunrise of the new year from a footbridge overlooking the city skyline in Seoul on January 1, 2024. (Photo by Jung Yeon-je / AFP)

Now, it’s a cherry on top.”
